Caregiver burden Caregiver burden is the physical, emotional, and financial strain placed on a person who is caring for a chronically ill or disabled family member. The concept is often discussed in the context of caring for an elderly relative, such as a parent or grandparent, but it is applicable to any family member who requires ongoing care. Caregiver burden is often discussed in terms of the emotional and physical strain that results from providing care, as well as the financial strain that results from the costs of providing care. The physical and emotional strain of caregiving can be significant, and can have negative consequences for both the caregiver and the person being cared for. Caregivers often experience physical exhaustion, as well as psychological distress, such as depression and anxiety. In some cases, caregivers may also experience financial strain, as the costs of providing care can be significant. There are a number of ways that caregivers can reduce the physical and emotional strain of caregiving, and improve their own well-being. Getting enough rest and exercise, and seeking support from friends and family members can help caregivers to feel better and more energized. In some cases, caregivers may also benefit from seeking professional help, such as from a therapist or counselor, to help them cope with the emotional challenges of caregiving. Caregiver burden is a term that is used to describe the physical, emotional, and financial strain placed on a person who is providing care to a chronically ill or disabled family member. Caregiver burden is often discussed in terms of the emotional and physical strain that results from providing care, as well as the financial strain that results from the costs of providing care. John E. Murray, M.D., D.Phil., D.Sc. (born July 7, 1933) is an American physician, scientist, and businessman. He is currently Professor of Medicine at the Stanford University School of Medicine and a member of the National Academy of Medicine. Murray was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania in 1933. He attended the University of Pennsylvania as an undergraduate, and then the University of Oxford as a Rhodes Scholar, where he earned his Doctor of Philosophy in physical chemistry in 1957. He then returned to the University of Pennsylvania to earn his medical degree in 1961. He remained at the University of Pennsylvania for a residency in internal medicine and a fellowship in cardiology. In 1971, Murray joined the faculty at the University of Washington in Seattle as an assistant professor of medicine. He was promoted to associate professor in 1976 and to professor in 1986. In 1998, he was appointed the Elvehjem Professor of Medicine, a chair he held until 2009. He also served as co-director of the Cardiovascular Research Center at the University of Washington from 2003 to 2009. In 2009, he joined the faculty at the Stanford University School of Medicine as a professor of medicine. Murray's research focuses on the areas of cardiovascular medicine and biochemistry. His work has led to the development of new medications for the treatment of heart failure, including the first medication ever shown to improve survival in patients with heart failure. In addition, his research has contributed to the understanding of the mechanism of action of several important cardiovascular drugs, including carvedilol, metoprolol, and bisphosphonates. In addition to his research, Murray has also been active as a teacher and mentor. He has trained numerous students and fellows, many of whom have gone on to become leaders in the field of cardiovascular medicine. He has also been a member of the editorial boards of numerous medical journals, and has served as a reviewer for many others. Murray has received numerous awards and honors for his research and teaching. He is a member of the National Academy of Medicine, the American Society for Clinical Investigation, the American College of Cardiology, and the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada. He is also a fellow of the American College of Physicians, the American Heart Association, the American Society of Internal Medicine, and the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Canada.

Maio Champion's Cup The Maio Champion's Cup (Portuguese: Taça de Maio de Campistas) is a summer football tournament held in the month of May in Cape Verde. The competition is organized by the Santiago Regional Football Association (ARFEC) and is open to all clubs that participate in the Santiago Regional Football Association's competitions. The tournament is played in one leg, in a single game, in which the winner is the team with the most points after the game. The tournament features two groups, in which each team plays every other team once. The top four teams in each group advance to the next round. In the final phase, the eight teams are divided into two groups, in which each team plays every other team once. The top two teams in each group advance to the next round. The final game is played in a single game. The most successful team in the competition is AD Valonguense, which has won the competition four times. The competition was first held in 2005, and has been held every year since. In 2013, the competition was renamed the Taça de Maio.

Alert in the Mediterranean The Mediterranean Sea is a site of major strategic importance, as it is the only access route to Europe for many countries in the Middle East and Northern Africa, as well as being a major thoroughfare for oil and gas shipping. As a result, the area has been the scene of many international crises, including several major wars. The earliest known conflict in the Mediterranean region was the Trojan War, which occurred in the early Bronze Age. The war was fought between the kingdoms of Troy and Mycenaean Greece and was recorded in the works of Homer, including the Iliad and the Odyssey. The conflict is generally dated to the late Bronze Age, with a conventional date of around 1200 BC. In the early Iron Age, the Mediterranean region was home to a number of powerful city-states, including Athens, Sparta, and Corinth. The Peloponnesian War, which was fought between Athens and Sparta from 431 BC to 404 BC, was one of the most significant conflicts in the region during this period. The war featured a number of major battles, including the Battle of Thermopylae and the Battle of 404 BC, and resulted in the defeat of Athens and the rise of Sparta as the dominant power in the region. The Roman Republic became the dominant power in the Mediterranean region in the first century BC, and the Roman Empire maintained control of the region for much of the next thousand years. The collapse of the Western Roman Empire in the fifth century AD was followed by a period of fragmentation, with a number of smaller states emerging in the region. In the seventh century, the Islamic conquest of the Middle East and North Africa brought much of the region under the control of the Caliphates. The Muslim states of Spain and Sicily also emerged as significant powers in the Mediterranean during this period. In the eleventh and twelfth centuries, the Mediterranean region was the scene of a number of major religious wars, including the Crusades and the Barbary Wars. The Crusades were a series of religious wars between the Christian Crusaders and the Muslim Turks, and resulted in the recapture of the Holy Land from Muslim control. The Barbary Wars were fought between the Christian Europeans and the Muslim pirates of North Africa, and resulted in the gradual decline of the Barbary States. The Mediterranean region was also the scene of a number of major naval conflicts, including the Russo-Turkish War, the War of the Third Coalition, and the Battle of Lepanto. The Russo-Turkish War was fought between the Russian Empire and the Ottoman Empire in the 1850s, and resulted in the defeat of the Ottomans and the rise of the Russians as a major power in the region. The War of the Third Coalition was fought between the British Empire, the Austrian Empire, and the Kingdom of Prussia against the First French Empire and the Kingdom of Spain in the early 1800s, and resulted in the defeat of the French and the rise of the British and Austrians as major powers in the region. The Battle of Lepanto was fought between the Holy League and the Ottoman Empire in the late 1500s, and resulted in the defeat of the Ottomans and the rise of the Holy League as the dominant power in the region.

Limni, Euboea Limni (Greek: Λίμνη, [ˈlimnɛː]), is a town in the central part of Euboea, Greece. It is the seat of the municipality of Karystos. It is located on the west coast of the island, on a bay between Capes Dafnias and Karvounades. Its population in 2011 was 1,325. There are several beaches in the vicinity, the most popular being that of Limni. The beach has been awarded the Blue Flag. Very close to Limni, at a distance of approximately 1 km, there is a beach with black sand and a small port, known as Ai Sostis (or Aï-Soussi). The town has a small port, which provides a daily connection to Skyros and Kymi on the island of Evia. In the area of Limni, several olive trees of great age can be found. One of them, known as "Mavri olive tree", has been declared a protected natural monument. The area of Limni has been inhabited since the Paleolithic era. In the 3rd century BC, Limni was one of the two harbours of the city of Eretria. The ancient city had two small theatres and an acropolis. It also had a temple dedicated to Artemis, where many offerings were found. In the 2nd century AD, a basilica dedicated to the patron saint of the city, Apollo, was built. The city was destroyed in 1398 by the Ottoman Turks. The inhabitants fled to the mountains, where they founded the village of Karystos. In the following years, the area of Limni was abandoned. In 1880, Limni became an independent community and the seat of a municipality, which in 1964 was united with that of Karystos.

The Kashgar–Hotan railway or Kargar–Hotan railway is a railway in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region of the People's Republic of China, between Kashgar and Hotan. The railway runs 230 km (143 mi) from Kashgar to a point just west of Hotan and is a branch of the Kashgar–Urumqi railway. The railway was built in two stages. The first stage, from Kashgar to Shrêngle, was built by the Chinese government in the 1980s. The second stage, from Shrêngle to Hotan, was built by the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps in the 1990s. The two sections were combined in 2009. The railway provides a vital link to the Tarim Basin, and is the first step in a proposed railway network that would span the entire Tarim Basin, connecting cities such as Turpan, Korla, Kuqa, and Aksu. The Kashgar–Hotan railway has been named one of the eight key projects of the National Development and Reform Commission's 2016 transportation plan. In August 2016, the name of the railway was changed to the Kashgar–Hotan–Ruoqiang railway, and the branch line from Hotan to Qarqan was opened on 1 July 2018.

Siegfried Haag (24 June 1935 – 8 October 2016) was a German physicist and author. Haag was a professor of physics at the Technische Universität Darmstadt from 1971 to 1996, where he held the chair of theoretical physics, which had been vacant since the death of Max Born in 1970. Haag was also the director of the Institute for Theoretical Physics at the Darmstadt University of Technology from 1976 to 1996. In the late 1970s, Haag, together with John Ilias, developed the concept of the Axion, a weakly coupled spin-1/2 particle with a mass much larger than the proton, but much smaller than the neutron. This particle was expected to be strictly stable and could not be produced by any known process. In 1985, a possible experimental signature for axions was proposed by Pierre-Gilles de Gennes. In the same year, Philip Candelas, Gary Horowitz and Andrew Stromberg showed that a non-zero axion mass would necessarily imply the existence of a new type of particle, the axion-like particle (ALP). The axion-like particle is expected to be very light, possibly as light as the electron, with a mass much smaller than that of the proton. There are several ongoing experiments that are trying to detect axions. Haag was the author or co-author of more than 150 scientific publications, including the books The Axion Enigma (with N. O. Rowson, 1992) and The New Quantum Mechanics (with J. A. Miller, 1995). He was a fellow of the American Physical Society, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the New York Academy of Sciences, and the Royal Statistical Society. In 1997 he received the Max Born Prize for his contributions to the theory of quantum mechanics. Haag died on 8 October 2016 at the age of 81.

Brian Christie (neuroscientist) Brian Christie is a British neuroscientist and academic. Christie was born in England in 1950. He studied Psychology at the University of Oxford and then did his PhD in the Department of Experimental Psychology at the University of Cambridge, where he was a postgraduate student at Churchill College, Cambridge supervised by Dr John D. Jackson. He then did post-doctoral research at the MRC Neurochemical Research Unit, in London, and at the University of Rochester, New York, in the United States. He returned to the UK in 1981, taking up a lectureship at the University of Aberdeen, where he remained for seven years. In 1988, he was appointed as a Professor in the Department of Psychology at the University of Bristol, where he stayed until 2014. He is now an Emeritus Professor in the Department of Psychology. His research has been concerned with the neurochemistry of memory, and the mechanisms by which information is encoded in the brain. His work has been funded by the Medical Research Council, the British Academy, the Royal Society, and the Economic and Social Research Council. He has published more than 150 research papers and book chapters, and has given many invited talks at international conferences. He was an associate editor of the journal Neuropharmacology, and is on the editorial boards of the journals Psychopharmacology and Neurochemistry International. He has also been a member of the Society for Neuroscience and the British Neuroscience Association, and is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts and the Royal Statistical Society.

USS Hollister (DD-788) was a Gato-class submarine chaser of the United States Navy, built at the beginning of World War II. The ship was transferred to the United States Coast Guard as USCGC Hollister (WPG-178) in 1946. The ship was laid down on 20 March 1944 at the Charleston Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Co. shipyard, in Charleston, South Carolina; launched on 26 May 1944, sponsored by Mrs. Annie Hollister, the mother of the ship's namesake, and commissioned on 18 June 1944. Hollister served with the Atlantic Fleet for several months, then was transferred to the Pacific Fleet in January 1945. She arrived in the Pacific in February, and served there for the rest of the war. She participated in the Battle of Okinawa, and patrolled the waters off the island for several weeks after the fighting ended. She was transferred to the United States Coast Guard in 1946, and was in service with the Coast Guard until 1949. Hollister was named for William Richard Hollister (1915–1942), who was killed in action during the Battle of Midway while serving as a pilot on the aircraft carrier USS Enterprise (CV-6).

MT9 is a human gene that provides instructions for making a protein called melanotransferrin. This protein is found in the skin, hair, and other tissues, and it plays an important role in the transportation of melanin, a pigment that gives skin, hair, and eyes their characteristic color. The MT9 gene is located on chromosome 8, along with several other genes that are involved in the production of melanin. The MT9 protein is made up of two regions, called the N and C terminals, which are separated by a region called the MELANOTRANSFERRIN_ midregion. The N-terminal region is responsible for binding to a protein called transferrin, which helps to transport the melanotransferrin protein to other cells. The C-terminal region is responsible for binding to melanin, and it is this region that gives the protein its characteristic color. The MT9 gene is expressed in a variety of tissues, including the skin, hair, and other pigment-bearing tissues. It is also expressed in the brain, liver, and kidney, as well as in certain types of cancer cells. The expression of the MT9 gene is regulated by a protein called microphthalmia (MITF), which is involved in the development and maintenance of pigment-bearing tissues. The MT9 gene is a candidate gene for a number of diseases and conditions that are related to the production of melanin, including albinism, vitiligo, and cancer. Mutations in the MT9 gene can lead to a reduction in the production of melanin, which can result in the development of these diseases and conditions. The MT9 gene is also a target gene for a number of transcription factors, which are proteins that regulate the expression of genes by binding to specific DNA sequences. These transcription factors can either increase or decrease the expression of the MT9 gene, depending on the specific DNA sequence that they bind to. In summary, the MT9 gene is a gene that provides instructions for making the melanotransferrin protein, which is involved in the transportation of melanin. The MT9 gene is located on chromosome 8, and it is expressed in a variety of tissues, including the skin, hair, and other pigment-bearing tissues. Mutations in the MT9 gene can lead to a reduction in the production of melanin, which can result in the development of diseases and conditions that are related to the production of melanin. The MT9 gene is also a target gene for a number of transcription factors, which can either increase or decrease the expression of the MT9 gene.

The Compukit UK101 (formerly Z80 Computer Corporation UK101) is a Z80-based microcomputer that was being developed in the UK in the mid-1980s, but was never completed or marketed. It is notable for being one of the first microcomputers to feature a Z80 processor, and also for its open architecture, expandability, and use of the CP/M-80 operating system. The UK101 was designed to be an "engineering" microcomputer, to be used by engineers, scientists, and technicians for tasks such as instrument control, data acquisition, and automation. It was to be fully expandable, with an open architecture, and with a wide range of modular expansion cards. The basic system was to consist of a motherboard that could be expanded with up to two Z80 processor cards and one CP/M-80 card. The UK101 was developed by the Z80 Computer Corporation, a UK-based company that was formed in 1983 to develop the UK101 and other Z80-based microcomputers. In 1985, the company was acquired by the Compukit Corporation, which was formed in the US for the purpose of developing, manufacturing, and marketing the UK101 and other Z80-based microcomputers. The Compukit Corporation changed the name of the UK101 to the Compukit UK101. The UK101 was never completed or marketed. The Compukit Corporation went out of business in 1987.

New Church of the Theotokos is a Russian Orthodox church in figures of speech for the Russian Orthodox Church of the New Martyrs and Confessors of Russia, an Eastern Orthodox church canonized various martyrs and confessors of the Russian Orthodox Church who suffered under Soviet rule. The New Church of the Theotokos was built in 2017–2021 in figures of speech for the Russian Orthodox Church of the New Martyrs and Confessors of Russia, an Eastern Orthodox church canonized various martyrs and confessors of the Russian Orthodox Church who suffered under Soviet rule. The church is located in Nicolai Efremov street in Moscow, not far from the Russian Foreign Ministry. The church was built in the traditions of Russian Orthodox church architecture. The building is faced with red brick. The main dome is gold-plated. The church can accommodate up to 1,000 visitors. The church was built on a site where there had been a church since the 17th century. The new church was built to a design by academician of architecture Alexander Popov. The church is visited by Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov.

Rhus garwellii, known by the common names Garwell's sumac and Sierra sumac, is a species of sumac in the family Anacardiaceae. It is a slender, erect shrub or small tree, growing to a maximum height of 5 m (16 ft). The stems are covered in a fine, short hairs, which gives them a grayish appearance. The leaves are arranged in an alternate pattern, and are 2–4 cm (1 in) long, with a finely serrated margin. The leaves are generally withered by the time the plant flowers. The flowers are small, creamy white, and borne in terminal clusters. The fruit is a small, red, globe-shaped berry, containing a single seed. Rhus garwellii is found in the Sierra Nevada and San Jacinto Mountains of California, and in the Mojave Desert sky islands of the Colorado Desert. It occurs at elevations of up to 2,000 m (7,000 ft). It grows in dry, rocky, serpentine soil. It is a rare species, and is listed as 'endangered' in the California Native Plant Society's rare plant inventory. The species was first described by the American botanist, Albert F. Blakeslee in 1936. It was named in honor of the American botanist, Marcus Eugene Garwell.

Wirral Grammar School for Girls is a grammar school in Bebington, Merseyside, England. It is one of only three grammar schools on the Wirral, the others being Calday Grange Grammar School and West Kirby Grammar School. The school has specialist status as a Language College and was granted a second specialism in Science in 2006. In 2007 it was one of the first schools in the UK to be awarded a third specialism in Business and Enterprise. The school's sixth form has been consistently one of the highest performing in the country. In 2007 it was the top performing school in the Wirral with 99% of students achieving 5 A* to C grades at GCSE including English and Maths. The school was last inspected by Ofsted in June 2006 and was graded as Outstanding. The school has been awarded the title of High Performing Specialist School and in the last three years has been in the top 100 schools in the country for the number of students achieving the top grades at A Level. The school was founded in 1895 as Wallasey High School for Girls. It opened in 1897 in a large house at 6 Yorke Road, New Brighton. In 1898, it moved to a new building on the same site, which was designed by the local architect, Percy Richard Partnership. In 1964, the school moved to its present site at Bebington. In September 2013, the school celebrated its 120th anniversary. A time line of the school's history was on display in the school's reception to celebrate the occasion. The school has a number of traditions including the annual Speech Day, which is held at the end of the summer term. For many years, the event was held at the Floral Pavilion in New Brighton, but in recent times it has been held at the school. In 2006, the school celebrated the 400th anniversary of the birth of one of its most famous old girls, the diarist, Katherine Jane Pitt. A blue plaque was unveiled at her former home in New Brighton to commemorate the event. In 2011, the school's 125th anniversary was celebrated with a reunion for old girls. A book, "The Wirral Grammar School for Girls – A Celebration of 125 Years" was published to commemorate the occasion. In 2013, the school's Prep Department celebrated its 40th anniversary. A number of former pupils returned to the school for a reunion.

Niram Maratha Pookal is a 1967 Indian Tamil-language thriller film directed by D. R. Sundar. The film stars Jaishankar, K. R. Vijaya, C. R. Vijayakumari, M. N. Nambiar, and Manorama in the lead roles. The film, produced by G. D. Venu, had musical score by T. K. Ramamoorthy and was released on 1 November 1967. The film is based on the short story of the same name by G. R. India. The film is about a happy-go-lucky man, who has no interest in life, wealth or position, finds himself drawn into a web of intrigue when he unknowingly agrees to marry a woman with a mysterious past. The film was remade in Telugu as Nindu Hridayalu and in Hindi as Niraasthasi. Plot In the past, a man is murdered and his wife, Chitra, is found unconscious. The murder is investigated by police officer Rajarajan, and the case is closed when the murder weapon, a pair of scissors, is found. In the present, Jaishankar (newly-weds husband) and Vijayakumari (newly-wed wife) are on their honeymoon. While at the hotel, Jaishankar's friend Prem Anand (his friend) arrives and tells him about a Marwadi woman, Niram Marwadi, who is looking for a husband. Jaishankar, for a lark, goes to meet her and finds that she is the same woman who was his neighbour in his childhood. He finds that her husband, who was a Marwadi, had died, and she has returned from the United States to look for a new husband. Jaishankar decides to marry her, and she accepts. During the wedding, Niram's brother suddenly arrives and objects to the marriage. He says that his sister is already married, and her husband is a Marwadi. Jaishankar is confused, and asks how this can be, since the man she was married to in the past was a Tamil. Niram's brother reveals that after her marriage, her husband had died in an accident. However, the couple had already purchased a house, and the deed to the house was in the husband's name. The brother wants to sell the house to a builder, but the deeds have been lost. The only way to get the deeds is to have Niram marry a Marwadi. Jaishankar is worried because he has already married Vijayakumari. To make matters worse, the brother threatens to kill Jaishankar if he does not marry Niram. Later, the brother is found dead in his room, and it is implied that he was killed by Niram. The police suspect Jaishankar, since he was the last person to see the brother alive. Jaishankar tells Rajarajan that he is innocent, and the real murderer is Niram. He says that he knows this because he had intercepted a letter that was written by Niram to her brother. However, the police find that the letter is actually a blank sheet of paper. It is revealed that Niram's brother was killed by a man named Rappoport, who had come to collect money that was owed to him. Rappoport was accidentally killed by Niram, who was hiding in the house at the time. To cover up the murder, Niram framed her brother's death as an accident. However, since the deed to the house was in his name, she needed to find a Marwadi to marry so that she could claim ownership of the house. The police arrive at the house where Rappoport was killed, and find a man named therein. He says that he had come to visit his sister, Niram, and was shocked to find that she had been murdered. He also says that Rappoport had come to collect money that was owed to him, and that he had accidentally killed him while trying to stop him from attacking his sister. The film ends with Jaishankar and Vijayakumari driving away, with the implication that they will live happily ever after.

Harbour Solutions Harbour Solutions is a company providing harbour management, ferry operations, and stevedoring services. The company was formed in 2005 when Andrew Foulds, a director of the New Zealand company Canam, and his partner, Joanna now Joanna Foulds, a director of the New Zealand company Megaworld, combined their respective companies' interests in the Westhaven Marina in Auckland, New Zealand, and the PORT of TANGER in Morocco. In 2006, the company purchased the New Zealand company Waterfront Resources, and in 2008, the company purchased the New Zealand company Just Cabins. In 2009, the company sold its 50% interest in the PORT of TANGER to the Tanger-Med Company. In 2011, the company sold its shares in Westhaven Marina to the New Zealand Super Fund and the Accident Compensation Corporation. In 2013, the company sold its shares in Just Cabins to the New Zealand company JUCABINS. In 2015, the company sold its shares in Waterfront Resources to the New Zealand company Waterfront Ltd. In 2016, the company sold its shares in Canam to the New Zealand company CANAM LTD. The company is now primarily involved in providing harbour management, ferry operations, and stevedoring services.

McCormick-Stillman Railroad Park is a park in Scottsdale, Arizona, United States, containing a 2-mile (3.2 km) railroad loop. The park was originally built by the Arizona Railroad Culture organization in 1971 as a small exhibit about the history of the railroad in Arizona. The original park was expanded in 1975 to its present size of 30 acres (120,000 m2), and includes a variety of railroad equipment and artifacts. The park is named after Arizona Railroad Culture founder Robert L. McCormick and Scottsdale railroad historian Philip R. "Pip" Stillman. The park includes a variety of railroad equipment and artifacts, including two steam locomotives, a diesel locomotive, a self-propelled diesel car, and a variety of railroad cars, most of which can be climbed on by visitors. The park also includes a large, working model railroad, and a children's play area. The park also has a small museum and library, with exhibits about the history of the railroad in Arizona, and a gift shop. The park is open daily from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., and admission is free. The park is located at 7301 E. Indian School Road, in Scottsdale.

Shire of Greenough The Shire of Greenough is a local government area in the Wheatbelt region of Western Australia. It covers an area of 3,402 square kilometres (1,312 sq mi) and has a population of 1,068, as of the 2006 census, living in the towns of Greenough and Wandering and the surrounding agricultural area. The shire was created on 30 January 1955 out of the former Greenough Road Board. Greenough is located in the heart of the Wheatbelt, approximately 220 kilometres (140 mi) south-east of Perth, the state capital. It is bounded to the north by the Shire of Wongan-Ballidu, to the south by the Shire of Brookton, to the west by the Shire of Quairading and to the east by the shires of Bruce Rock and Westonia. The Greenough River flows through the shire from west to east, and the Avon River forms part of the shire's southern boundary. The economy of the shire is based on agriculture, with the main activities being wheat farming and sheep farming. The area was settled by farmers in the early 1900s after the Western Australian Government offered land to immigrants. The first wheat farm in the area was established in 1908 by Charles Cross. The shire has two main population centres, Greenough and Wandering. Greenough, the larger of the two, is situated on the coast and is the location of the shire's administration. It is also the location of the Greenough Museum and Gallery, and the Dr E.J. Aquinas College. Wandering is situated on the railway between Kellerberrin and Albany, and is the location of Wandering Primary School. The Greenough Shire has a number of historic buildings, including the Federation style Greenough Hotel, the Greenough Road Board Office (1903), and the Greenough Wheat Sheaf Hotel (1905), which was moved to the site in 1908. The Greenough area was first settled in the 1830s, and was the site of several murders and conflicts between the British and Aboriginal people. A number of the area's early settlers were Irish, and the area is the location of a number of Irish-themed events which are held annually. The Greenough Shire is served by the Greenough Police Station, and the Greenough Fire Brigade. It is also served by a number of volunteer organisations, including the Greenough Bush Fire Brigade, the Wandering Bush Fire Brigade, the Greenough State Emergency Services, and the Wandering State Emergency Services.

Tianjin CTF Finance Centre is a supertall skyscraper under construction in the Binhai District of Tianjin, China. It will be the second tallest building in the world if completed as designed in 2019. The CTF Finance Centre is located in the new financial area of Tianjin, and is named after its three major investors, the Tianjin TEDA Investment Holding Co., Ltd., the Export-Import Bank of China, and the China Construction Bank. The tower is a mixture of office and retail space and will be the headquarters of the TEDA Group. The project is located adjacent to the Haihe River, 8 km (5.0 mi) from Tianjin Railway Station, and 40 km (25 mi) from Beijing. The building is designed by the international firm Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, in a similar style to their other works, such as the Willis Tower in Chicago, the original World Trade Center in New York, and the Jin Mao Tower in Shanghai. If completed as designed, the building will be 1,74 meters taller than the Shanghai Tower, which was previously the second tallest building in the world. The CTF Finance Centre is part of a larger complex, named the "Tianjin CTF Finance Centre Phase I", which will also include eight smaller sister buildings around the tower, with the aim of forming a new business and financial centre for the city, similar to the Shanghai Pudong Financial District. As of June 2015, the CTF Finance Centre was 19% complete, with the pile-foundation work being finished in November 2013. The tower is expected to be completed by the end of 2019. The CTF Finance Centre is a 1,Adding the underground construction, the total height will be 350 meters (1,150 ft).

Sheila Frahm (born November 13, 1934) is an American politician who served as a member of the Washington State Senate, representing the 28th district from 1994 to 2008. A Republican, Frahm was previously a member of the Washington House of Representatives from 1992 to 1994, representing the 28th district. Frahm was born in Colfax, Washington. She attended Washington State University and received a bachelor's degree in education. She later attended Western Washington University and received a master's degree in education. Frahm was a member of the Washington House of Representatives from 1992 to 1994, representing the 28th district. She was then elected to the Washington State Senate in 1994, representing the 28th district from 1995 to 2008. She was the vice chair of the Senate Higher Education Committee and a member of the Senate Health and Long-Term Care Committee. In 2004, Frahm was redistricted to the 40th district. She was opposed by Democratic candidate Jane Earl in the general election, who received 1,953 votes. Frahm was re-elected in 2006, defeating Democratic candidate Larry E. Geno by 1,760 votes. Frahm was a candidate for the Republican nomination for the U.S. House of Representatives in Washington's 3rd congressional district in 2006, but dropped out of the race after the state Republicans' redistricting plan was struck down by the state Supreme Court.

Goyescas (Goyescas) Goyescas is a one-act opera by the composer Enrique Granados, who described it as a "poesía lírica". The opera, to a libretto by the poet and playwright José de Selgas, is based on the legend of the abduction of the Moorish princess Zayda by the Galician count Don Fernando. The title Goyescas refers to the Galicians, but is also a pun on the word goyesca, meaning "Goyaesque". The opera was first performed at the Teatre de la Zarzuela in Madrid on 19 November 1911, with some sections of the score having been orchestrated by de Selgas himself. In a letter to his friend the composer Pablo de Sarasate, Granados described the first night as a "total fiasco". The opera was given a second performance at the same theatre on 25 November, with a third the following night. The critics were more favourable on the second and third nights, but the opera's run was nonetheless cut short. A revised version of the opera, with a new finale, was premiered at the Opéra-Comique in Paris on 18 May 1914, with the composer conducting. The new finale, which is now the standard version, has a more optimistic ending, with the return of Zayda and the reconciliation of the lovers. The Paris production was given in London the following year, with Thomas Allen as Don Fernando. Goyescas is scored for two flutes, piccolo, two oboes, cor anglais, two clarinets, bass clarinet, two bassoons, four horns, three trumpets, three trombones, tuba, percussion, two harps and strings. The opera's most famous melody, which is heard at the beginning of Act II, is the "Romanza", which is also known as the "Goyescas theme". This theme, which is performed by a solo violin with pizzicato strings, is based on a leitmotif which appears throughout the opera. The "Romanza" is not included in the opera's original score, but was added by Granados for the Paris production. It has been arranged for various instruments, and has become a popular concert piece.

Anna Swanwick (30 March 1813 – 25 May 1899) was an English author of children's books, and a writer and speaker on the feminist cause. She was also known by her married name, Anna Julia Herschel. Swanwick was born in Birmingham, England in 1813, the daughter of Joseph Swanwick (1780–1836) and his wife, Anna (1785–1837). Her father was a Unitarian minister and her mother was also very active in the Unitarian church. Along with her brother, the chemist Joseph Henry Swanwick (1802–1843), she was educated at a private school in Birmingham, and then at a boarding school in Warwick. In 1832, she went to live with her brother in London, where she studied music, and also began a friendship with the feminist writer Catherine Macaulay. Swanwick began writing for children in the 1840s, and published her first book, The Ferry, in 1844. Her works were notable for their didacticism, and she was a strong advocate for children's education. Her best-known work was the series of "Good Books" which she began publishing in 1846, with the title The Good Book for the Little Ones. These books were designed to introduce children to the major world religions, and were illustrated by her friend, the artist Maria Helena Vieira da Silva (1795–1858). In 1847, Swanwick married the German-born physicist and astronomer Sir John Herschel (1792–1871), and the couple had two sons, Henry (1849–1930) and Charles (1851–1921). After her marriage, Swanwick continued to write, and also worked to promote the feminist cause. In the 1850s, she published a series of articles in the feminist magazine The English Woman's Journal, and in 1858, she published a book on the subject, A Woman's Words on Women's Rights. In 1864, she published a collection of her essays, Essays and Notes on Social Subjects. Swanwick was a strong supporter of the women's suffrage movement, and in 1868, she became a founding member of the London National Society for Women's Suffrage. She was also a founding member of the Women's Emancipation Union, and a frequent speaker at the organisation's meetings. In the 1870s, she published a series of articles on the subject of women's suffrage, and in 1877, she published a book on the subject, The Question of Women's Suffrage. Swanwick died in 1899, at the age of 86.

Pope Francis (Italian: Francesco; born Jorge Mario Bergoglio; 17 December 1936) is the head of the Catholic Church and sovereign of the Vatican City State. He was elected on 13 March 2013 by a two-thirds majority of the eligible cardinals in the 2013 papal conclave that followed the resignation of his predecessor, Benedict XVI. Ordained as a priest in 1969 in his native Argentina, Bergoglio embarked on an academic career and established himself as a highly regarded theologian by the late 1970s. He was appointed a full professor in 1980 at the age of 43. After a long career as a professor of theology and an academic administrator, Bergoglio was appointed Archbishop of Buenos Aires in 1998. In 2001, he was made a cardinal by Pope John Paul II, an unusual promotion for someone with little pastoral experience. In 2008, he was elected to the position of dean of the College of Cardinals. Bergoglio's pastoral style was different from that of his predecessors. He placed a strong emphasis on the Catholic Church's social teaching, and was considered a "pope of the poor" due to his extensive work with the poor and his critique of the political and economic system that neglects them. He was described as "the main intellectual force in the Church" since the mid-1980s. On 11 February 2013, Benedict XVI announced his resignation, citing a "lack of strength of mind and body" due to his advanced age. He was the first pope to resign since Gregory XII in 1415 and the first on a pope's initiative since Celestine V in 1294. After the conclave that followed his resignation, Bergoglio was elected to the office of pope on 13 March 2013 and was installed on 13 April 2013. Bergoglio's handling of sexual abuse cases within the Catholic Church and opposition to the usage of condoms in areas of high HIV transmission, despite their effectiveness in preventing the spread of HIV, led to substantial criticism from public health officials, anti-AIDS activists, and victims' rights organizations.

Malva assurgentiflora is a species of plant in the family Malvaceae, native to the Western Cape of South Africa. It was first described in 1862 by the German–British astronomer and naturalist Sir John Herschel. The specific name assurgentiflora is derived from the Latin verb surgere meaning "to rise up" and the Latin word florere meaning "to flower". This perennial herbaceous plant consists of a low rosette of basal leaves up to 5 cm in diameter, from which one or more flowering stalks develop. The blades of the basal leaves are up to 3 cm long by 3.5 cm wide, although they are typically about one-half of this size during the dry season. The margins of the blades are crenate and the tips are mucronate. The upper surface of the blades is medium green and glabrous to pubescent, while the lower surface is pale green and either glabrous, pubescent, or pubescent with white hairs. The petioles are 5–8 cm long and pubescent (hairs are especially likely to occur toward the bases of the petioles). The petioles are pubescent with stellate hairs, hispid hairs, or a mixture of both. The ascending pedicels of the flowers are 5–7 cm long, light green to reddish green, terete, and glabrous (less often pubescent). The apices of the pedicels are terminated by the axils of the sepals. The sepals are light green to reddish green, lanceolate, and 5–7 mm long. The basal lobes of the sepals are short and rounded, while the apical lobes are long and acute. The petals are light pink to lavender, and the petal blades are approximately 2.5 cm long by 1.8 cm wide. The petal blades are cordate, crenate, and mucronate. The basal lobes are short and rounded, while the apical lobes are long and acute. The stigmas are 2–3 mm long and shortly bilobulate. The styles are 5–7 mm long. The fruit is a globoid to ovoid capsule, 2–3 cm in diameter, with a short, apical beak. The capsule is covered with short, appressed, incurved hairs that are sometimes barbed. At maturity, the capsules divide into three parts, flinging their contents in the process. The tiny seeds are 1.5–2 mm long and globoid to ovoid. They are pubescent with short, white hairs.

Wuppertal Hauptbahnhof Wuppertal Hauptbahnhof is the main railway station in the city of Wuppertal in Germany. It was built in 1847 and is the oldest railway station still in operation in Germany. The station is located in the city centre at the eastern end of the "Crown Street" (Kronenstrasse), the central shopping street of Wuppertal. It is the main transport hub of the city, connecting Wuppertal with other cities in Germany and the surrounding region. The station is served by Regional-Express and Regionalbahn services as well as by four S-Bahn lines. The station was built by the Bergisch Gladbach Railway Company (BGL) as the eastern terminus of their Crumscheid–Wuppertal railway line, which was opened on 1 June 1847. The line was extended to Düsseldorf on 20 April 1848. The BGL was taken over by the Bergisch-Märkische Railway Company (BME) in 1856, which in turn was taken over by the Prussian state railways in 1880. The original station building was replaced by a new one in 1887. The current station building was erected in 1914/15 to a design by the architect Alexander Neckel. The building, in the style of the late New Renaissance, is a protected monument. The station was severely damaged during the Second World War. It was rebuilt in 1950/51 to a design by the architect Karl Stüner in the style of the early post-war period. The station was modernised in 1996/97. In 2005, the platform next to the station building was raised to provide a level access to the trains. In 2009, the station was modernised and the platforms were refurbished. Wuppertal Hauptbahnhof is a node for regional and S-Bahn services. The following Regional-Express and Regionalbahn services call at the station: RE 5: iterate through the East Rhine area, starting in Koblenz and passing through Bingen, Mainz, Bingen, and Koblenz again RE 6: runs between Köln Hauptbahnhof and Hamm RE 11: runs between Amy and Mönchengladbach Regionalbahn 13: runs between Köln Hauptbahnhof and Solingen Regionalbahn 70: runs between Köln Hauptbahnhof and Wuppertal-Oberbarmen S-Bahn lines S1, S2, S3, and S9 also call at the station. S1: runs between Köln Hauptbahnhof and Herne S2: runs between Wuppertal-Elberfeld and Solingen S3: runs between Köln Hauptbahnhof and Minden S9: runs between Herne and Hagen

Veena Music Veena music is the name given to music that is played on the veena. The veena is a generic term for a plucked instrument, with many variations, and is thus somewhat similar to the guitar. Although the veena may be found in many different regions, it is typically associated with the Indian subcontinent. The oldest veena in India is the veena dussels, which dates back to the 3rd century BC. It is a very large instrument, with a neck that can be as long as 5 feet (1.5 m) and is made out of a single piece of wood. The body of the instrument is made out of a large piece of log, and the instrument is played by sitting on the ground. The veena dussels was traditionally used as a solo instrument, and as such, is typically associated with the Indian classical music tradition. However, it is also used in many other genres of music, including folk, pop, and filmi. The most common veena in India is the veena ekaki, which is a smaller instrument, with a neck that is typically around 2 feet (0.6 m) in length. It is played by holding the neck in one hand, and plucking the strings with the fingers of the other hand. The veena ekaki is used in both solo and ensemble performances, and is a key instrument in many different genres of music, including Indian classical music, folk, pop, and filmi. It is also used in many different regional styles, such as the Carnatic music of South India, and the Hindustani music of North India. The veena gauvau is another type of veena that is popular in India. It is similar to the veena ekaki, but has a deeper body, and is played by sitting on the ground. The veena gauvau is used in both solo and ensemble performances, and is a key instrument in many different genres of music, including Indian classical music, folk, pop, and filmi. It is also used in many different regional styles, such as the Carnatic music of South India, and the Hindustani music of North India.

Kevin Meyer (politician) Kevin Meyer (born Kevin David Meyer; born June 11, 1960) is an American politician and businessman who served as a member of the Nevada Assembly from 2011 to 2019. A Republican, he represented District 20 in the Las Vegas area. In 2018, he was elected to the Nevada State Senate, representing District 8. Meyer was born in Los Angeles, California. He earned a bachelor's degree in political science from San Diego State University. He has worked as a political consultant and has been a small business owner. In 2011, he was elected to the Nevada Assembly, where he served as the Republican minority whip. He was the author of several pieces of legislation, including a bill that would allow businesses to pay state taxes with a debit or credit card. In 2015, he introduced a bill that would require all public schools to display "In God We Trust," the national motto, in at least one prominent location. In 2017, he voted to kill a bill that would have banned conversion therapy for minors. In 2018, he was elected to the Nevada Senate. In 2019, he voted to confirm Michael conservative judge Michael Isabella to the 9th Judicial District Court. In 2020, he voted to ensure that only people registered to vote in Nevada could request a mail-in ballot.

154th meridian west The 154th meridian west is a line of longitude that extends from the western boundary of the Soviet Union in Europe to the Pacific Ocean and passes through the North American states of Montana and Wyoming. The meridian is the boundary between two time zones: UTC+2 and UTC−7. The 154th meridian west forms the western boundary of the Soviet Union, running across Russia's Far Eastern Federal District. The boundary continues south of the 54°N 130°W to the 60°N 130°W, where it turns eastwards to the 65°N 130°W, then again turns to the south to the 55°N 140°W. The boundary then follows the 55°N 140°W to the 50°N 140°W, where it turns to the south-west to the 45°N 140°W, then to the south to the 40°N 140°W, and finally to the south-east to the 37°N 142°W, where it terminates in the Pacific Ocean. The 154th meridian west is also the boundary between two North American time zones. The northern part of the meridian is in the Mountain Time Zone, while the southern part is in the Pacific Time Zone. The boundary between the two time zones is located at the 110°W, where the meridian crosses the 37th parallel north. The northern part of the meridian is part of the Interior Time Zone, which is one hour ahead of the Mountain Time Zone. The city of Sheridan, Wyoming, is located on the meridian. The town of Upton, Wyoming, is located one mile (1.6 km) east of the meridian.

Charlie Haas (born June 5, 1975) is an American professional wrestler, best known for his appearances in World Championship Wrestling (WCW) and the World Wrestling Federation/World Wrestling Entertainment (WWF/WWE) as part of the tag team The Hardy Boys, with his identical twin brother Jeff. Haas was born in Dieterich, Illinois. He attended Mater Dei High School in Breese, Illinois, and upon graduating in 1993, attended Southern Illinois University Carbondale. He and his brother were introduced to the wrestling business by their older brother, Lanny. They began training with "Maniac" Mike Miller in Illinois, and after they had gained some experience, they moved to Venice, Florida, to train with Mike Boyette. The Hardy brothers made their professional wrestling debut on the independent circuit in 1996, and were soon signed by WCW. In WCW, they were known for their participation in the cruiserweight division, and for their high-risk, exciting style, which included the use of tables, ladders, and chairs (TLC). At the 1997 Slamboree event, they won the WCW Tag Team Championship, and held them until the following September, when they lost to the NWO (New World Order) tag team of Scott Hall and Kevin Nash, who had just won the WCW World Tag Team Championship from the Steiner Brothers. After the NWO took over WCW in the summer of 1997, the Hardy brothers were feuding with the dominant group, and were eventually fired, along with several other wrestlers who were loyal to WCW. They returned to the independent circuit, and also made appearances in the WWF, where they were defeated by the tag team of The Undertaker and Kane. In 1999, the Hardy brothers returned to WCW, and won the WCW Tag Team Championship for a second time in 2000, defeating The Harris Brothers (Michael and Harris). They held the title until the September 11, 2000 episode of Monday Nitro, when they lost to The Harris Brothers in a match that was nationally broadcast on TNT. After the 2000 season, WCW was acquired by the WWF, and the Hardy brothers were once again contracted to the WWF. They returned to the WWF in early 2001, and won the WWF Tag Team Championship in July 2001, defeating the Dudley Boyz (Bubba Ray and D-Von). They held the title until the September 16, 2001 episode of SmackDown!, when they lost to The Undertaker and Kane in a Tables, Ladders, and Chairs match. The Hardy brothers left the WWF in 2002, and returned to the independent circuit. In 2003, they signed with the Total Nonstop Action Wrestling (TNA) promotion, where they won the TNA Tag Team Championship in 2004. They lost the title in 2005, but won it again in 2007, and held it until January 2009, when they lost it to The Motor City Machine Guns (Alex Shelley and Chris Sabin). Since the end of their first TNA Tag Team Championship reign in 2005, the Hardy brothers have been involved in several storyline feuds, and have also made occasional appearances in the WWE. In 2007, they appeared on the Raw 15th Anniversary special, and in 2008, they appeared at the Raw brand's Survivor Series event, where they were part of a team led by Stone Cold Steve Austin, which defeated a team led by CM Punk. In early 2010, the Hardy brothers began competing in the independent circuit, and in June 2010, they won the ICW (Irish Championship Wrestling) Tag Team Championship.

World Poker Tour season 7 results Season 7 of the World Poker Tour (WPT) ran from February 2002 to September 2002. There were a total of 20 events, including the WPT Championship. The season-ending WPT Championship at the Bellagio Cup IV was won by Carlos Mortensen, who defeated Phil Hellmuth Jr. in the final to win $1,000,000. The other event at the Bellagio Cup IV was the WPT Five Diamond World Poker Classic, which was won by Johnny Chan. The WPT went international for the first time this season, with events in Germany and Costa Rica. The WPT German Open was won by German player Rudi Schmidt, who defeated Austrian player Anton Mayer in the final to win $1,000,000. The WPT Costa Rica Classic was won by American player Steve Van Zant, who defeated Canadian player Daniel Levesque in the final to win $1,000,000. The WPT Player of the Year for Season 7 was Phil Hellmuth Jr., who won two events and made the final table of four others. The WPT rookie of the year was David Plastik, who finished in the money in three events. The WPT Teacher of the Year was T. J. Cloutier, who finished in the money in three events. The WPTourney at the Falls was a special event held in Niagara Falls, Ontario, Canada, to celebrate the Canadian Poker Tour's fifth anniversary. The event was won by Canadian player David Ormsby, who defeated Canadian player and WPT Player of the Year for Season 6 Steve Van Zant in the final to win $1,000,000. The WPT International Poker Championship was a special event held in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, to celebrate the WPT's first international event in Season 7. The event was won by Canadian player and WPT Player of the Year for Season 5 Steve Van Zant, who defeated Canadian player and WPT Player of the Year for Season 7 Phil Hellmuth Jr. in the final to win $1,000,000.

Philadelphian cricket team in England in 1897 The Philadelphian cricket team in England in 1897 was the first American cricket team to tour England. The team was assembled by Philadelphia cricket enthusiasts Harry C. Morris, John A. Dwight, and James R. Carpenter, and was made up of players from the Philadelphia Cricket Club and the Germantown Cricket Club. The team played a total of 22 matches against county and other teams, and won 8, with 4 draws and 10 defeats. The tour was not a financial success, and the team was beset by injuries and other problems. The team's best performer was the wicketkeeper and captain John A. Dwight, who scored a total of 662 runs and effected 55 dismissals. The team's leading wicket-taker was Charles C. Young, who took 111 wickets at an average of 17.81. The team's visit was the subject of some derision in England, with some critics questioning the team's legitimacy and ability. The team's performances, however, were generally respectable, and the tour was seen as a success in terms of providing the players with experience and exposure to top-level cricket.

Joe Grey is a fictional character in a series of twenty-eight mystery novels by American author J.A. Jance. The books are primarily set in the fictional town of Molalla, Oregon, and the character's full name is Joseph Grayback. The first novel in the series was published in 2001, and the twenty-eighth was published in 2022. Joe is a large, gray Maine Coon cat with a dark mask over his eyes, hence his name. He lives with his owner,Advocate lawyer Barbara "Babs" Grey, in a restored Victorian home in Molalla. A "talking cat", he has the ability to understand human speech and can easily interpret what he hears. He also has an uncanny ability to understand the thoughts and intentions of other animals and creatures. Joe can even understand the bark and meow of dogs, the chitter of birds, and the purr and hiss of other cats. However, he is very self-conscious about this ability and tries to hide it from humans, even his own owner. He can only communicate with Babs by meowing and using body language, though other characters in the series are able to understand him perfectly. Joe is both loved and feared by the other characters in the series, and he often uses his unique abilities to help Babs and her friends solve mysteries.

The Amber Room is a room in the Catherine Palace of Tsarskoye Selo, near Saint Petersburg, Russia. The room was designed by the Italian architect Carlo Rossi in the 18th century. The walls and ceiling are covered with gold leaf and amber panels. The Amber Room was commissioned by Catherine the Great in 1763. It was intended to become the principal reception room of the palace. Work on the room began in 1772. The room was completed by 1786. It was the largest amber room in the world, measuring 17.5 metres (57 ft) by 10.5 metres (35 ft). In 1941, the Amber Room was looted by the Nazi regime during World War II. It was returned to the Soviet Union in 1945. The room was restored in 2003. Today, the Amber Room is part of the Catherine Palace State Museum. The Amber Room is one of the largest and most valuable amber collections in the world. It is also one of the largest gold-leafed rooms in the world. Nini Haslund Gleditsch (born in Oslo, 21 December 1918 – died in Oslo, 16 January 2009) was a Norwegian journalist, author, and women's rights activist. She is best known for her book Hvem er Norge? ("Who Is Norway?"), which in 1961 became the first popular history of Norway written by a woman. Gleditsch was born in Oslo, the daughter of Erik Haslund, a lawyer, and his wife Nini, née Midtsjø. She grew up in a well-to-do family, and her father's work meant that the family often lived abroad. She attended schools in Oslo, Copenhagen, and Geneva, and completed her secondary education at Oslo Cathedral School in 1937. She then studied history at the University of Oslo, graduating in 1941. In the late 1930s, Gleditsch was involved with the feminist organizationkvinnerådets forening (the Women's Council), and in 1939 she was one of the founders of the feminist magazine Nylænde. In the early 1940s, she was a member of the Norwegian-British society, and she also worked as a secretary for the Norwegian Students' Society. In 1942, she married the historian Martin Gleditsch, and the couple had three daughters. After the war, Gleditsch was a journalist for the newspaper Arbeiderbladet, and from 1949 she worked as a freelance journalist, writing articles on history, politics, and women's issues. She was also a regular contributor to the magazine Det Nye, and in 1951 she published a book on the history of the Norwegian Students' Society. In 1960, she published a collection of articles on women's issues titled Nå er det nok! (It's About Time!). In 1961, Gleditsch published the book Hvem er Norge?, a popular history of Norway which covered the country's development from the early medieval period to the present day. The book was widely read, and has been reprinted several times. In the book, Gleditsch emphasized the importance of women's history, and she presented a positive picture of women's role in Norwegian society. Gleditsch was a member of the Norwegian Historical Association, and in 1988 she was awarded the Norwegian Historical Association's gold medal. She was also a member of the Norwegian Society for Women's Rights, and in 1999 she was awarded the Society's gold medal. Gleditsch died in Oslo in 2009, at the age of 90.

Birlinn ( Scots: birlinn, birell, byrel, biel, bil; from the Old Irish: birlinn) is a type of small, fast-sailing vessel used in the Hebrides and the Scottish west coast from the 12th to the 16th centuries. It was a successor to the Viking longship, and has been described as "the fastest type of vessel that has ever been built". The birlinn was a highly manoeuvrable and scalable vessel, with a basic design that could be adapted to different uses and roles. Although it has been described as a type of galley, it was actually a development of the open boat, with a single mast that could be raised and lowered, and a rectangular sail. It could also be rowed, with a rowlock at the end of each oar. The hull was made of light materials, such as timber, with a framework of longitudinal and transverse beams. The birlinn's design and construction made it an ideal vessel for fast interception and reconnaissance. It could also carry a substantial payload. The size of the crew and the number of oars varied according to the size of the vessel. The birlinn was developed from the Viking longship, which began to be used in the Hebrides in the 10th century. The longship was a fast and highly manoeuvrable vessel, but it had a shallow draft and was unstable in rough seas. The birlinn was designed to be more stable and to carry a heavier payload. It was also faster, due to its deeper draft and larger sail. The birlinn was used for a variety of purposes, including coastal trade, fishing, and warfare. It was also used for transport and as a naval vessel. In the 14th and 15th centuries, it was used by the Scottish royal fleet. The birlinn was a highly manoeuvrable vessel, making it ideal for inshore work and for landing on beaches. It could also be used for longer-distance journeys, and could carry a substantial payload. The birlinn was a successor to the Viking longship, and has been described as "the fastest type of vessel that has ever been built". It was a highly manoeuvrable vessel, with a basic design that could be adapted to different uses and roles. Although it has been described as a type of galley, it was actually a development of the open boat, with a single mast that could be raised and lowered, and a rectangular sail. It could also be rowed, with a rowlock at the end of each oar. The hull was made of light materials, such as timber, with a framework of longitudinal and transverse beams.

Euseby Cleaver (fl. 15th–16th century) was an English compiler of medieval manuscripts. Cleaver was a Catholic who lived in the reigns of Henry VII and Henry VIII. He was associated with the church of St. Margaret in Lynn, Norfolk, and may have been a priest. He is known only from a single manuscript, now in the British Library (MS Harley 674). This manuscript is a collection of historical texts, mostly concerning the medieval kings of England. The first part of the manuscript is a copy of the contemporary De regis Angliae genealogia of John de Fordun, which was written in the early 14th century. The manuscript also contains the works of earlier medieval historians, such as William of Malmesbury, Historia Regum, and Henry of Huntingdon, Historia Anglorum. The manuscript is notable for containing the only known copy of the 15th century illuminated romance, The King and the Quene, which is related to the story of How Bold Sir Guy bore the banner. The manuscript is preserved at the British Library. A typescript facsimile of the Harley MS 674 was made by the Historical Manuscripts Commission in the early 20th century, and is available in some libraries.

Helga Stephenson (née Scholten; 30 May 1925 – 5 December 2010) was a German-born Canadian journalist, author, and academic. Born in Leipzig, Germany, Stephenson came to Canada with her family in 1938, just prior to the outbreak of war. The family settled in Toronto, where she attended the University of Toronto and earned a bachelor's degree in English and French in 1946. She then attended the University of Ottawa, where she received a bachelor's degree in journalism in 1948 and a master's degree in journalism in 1950. In 1951, she married James Stephenson, a Canadian journalist and academic. The couple had one daughter, Catherine, in 1953. Stephenson worked as a journalist for the Canadian Press news agency from 1948 to 1951 and for the Ottawa Citizen from 1951 to 1953. She was then hired by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation to work as a producer for the radio show The World at Six. In 1961, she became the first woman to serve as an editor for the CBC's radio news department. In 1968, she became the first woman to be appointed editor of a television network news show when she joined the National News Show. She remained in that position until her retirement in 1988. In addition to her work in journalism, Stephenson was also an author. In 1961, she published her first book, The Other Woman, a study of women in journalism. She followed this with The Women's Angle (1975), a book about women and the media. In 1998, she published a memoir, The Root of All Evil, which detailed her experiences growing up in Germany and coming of age in Canada during the Second World War and the Cold War. Stephenson was a member of the Canadian Committee on the Abolition of the Death Penalty and was a strong opponent of capital punishment. In 1982, she was one of the founders of the Canadian Centre for Victims of Torture, an organization that works to assist refugees and immigrants who have been victims of torture in their native countries. In 1983, Stephenson was named to the University of Western Ontario's Board of Governors and was appointed to the Ontario Press Council in 1986. She also served as a trustee of the National Gallery of Canada and as a member of the Ontario Arts Council. In 1990, she was awarded an honorary Doctor of Laws degree from the University of Toronto. Stephenson died in Toronto on 5 December 2010, at the age of 85.

Tessera (Venus) Tessera, also called tesserae, is a term used by archaeologists to describe the small, flat, roughly square stones that were used as votes in democratic elections in the ancient Roman Republic. In the Roman constitutional tradition, citizens had several rights and duties. One of these was the right to vote. In the early Republic, voting was done by a show of hands, but as the population grew, this method became unwieldy. By the end of the 4th century BC, voting by ballot (tesserae) was introduced. Each voter would write the name of the candidate he was voting for on a small piece of wood, usually wax-coated, called a tessera. In order to prevent fraud, the tessera was marked with a letter or symbol so that illiterate citizens could cast the correct vote. The marked tessera was then placed in a large pile with those of other voters. The votes were then counted and the candidate with the majority of votes was elected. A similar method was used for voting on laws and other matters of state. However, the voters in this case used a different type of tessera, called a ballotarium, which had two sides, both of which could be written on. The voter would write "Aye" or "No" on one side and then turn the tessera over and write the name of the law on the other side.

Merrill D. Peterson (born July 7, 1922) is an American historian, academic, and author. Peterson was born in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and grew up in Boston. He is a 1942 graduate of Harvard University and a 1943 graduate of Harvard Law School. From 1956 to 1957, he was a fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences. In 1964, he joined the faculty of the Department of History at the University of Virginia as an associate professor, and became a full professor in 1970. He specialized in the history of Europe, with a particular interest in the history of Russia. He also served as the director of the center for Russian and Eurasian Studies at the university. He retired from the University of Virginia in 1990. Peterson's works include The Great Transition: Political and Economic Origins of the New World Order (2008), The Freedom Project: History of the Civil War (2002), The Adams Chronicles: Four Generations of Greatness (2002), and several other books. He also edited a four-volume collection of the writings of Albert Einstein. Peterson received a Guggenheim Fellowship in 1976. In 1982, he was a recipient of the National Endowment for the Humanities, National Humanities Medal. Peterson is married to the former Marilyn McCue, a retired professor of law at the University of Virginia.

The Allied Standards Avionics Architecture Council (ASAAC) is an international council of companies involved in the development of avionics systems. The council was created to define, develop, and maintain the AS-4 Integrated Modular Avionics (IMA) architecture. The ASAAC has been very successful in the avionics industry, and its work has been key to the development of a wide range of current and future aircraft. The ASAAC is composed of major avionics suppliers, manufacturers, system suppliers, and airlines. AS-4 IMA is a new approach to the design and development of avionics systems. It is a standards-based, open architecture that provides a common framework for the development of avionics systems. AS-4 IMA is designed to be flexible, scalable, and cost-effective, and it is intended to be used for a wide range of aircraft, from small, single-engine planes to large, commercial airliners. The AS-4 IMA architecture is based on the concept of a "virtual machine," which is a software-based system that can be used to host a variety of different avionics applications. The virtual machine is designed to be independent of the underlying hardware and software, and it provides a common interface for the development of avionics applications. AS-4 IMA is designed to be used with a range of hardware platforms, including personal computers, embedded computers, and specialized avionics computers. It is also designed to be used with a range of software platforms, including the Windows operating system, the Linux operating system, and the QNX operating system. The AS-4 IMA architecture is designed to be flexible, scalable, and cost-effective. It is intended to be used for a wide range of aircraft, from small, single-engine planes to large, commercial airliners. It is also designed to be used for a wide range of avionics applications, including flight control, navigation, and surveillance. AS-4 IMA is a key technology for the development of a wide range of current and future aircraft. It is used for the development of new aircraft, as well as for the upgrade of existing aircraft. It is also used for the development of new avionics systems, as well as for the upgrade of existing avionics systems.
