"Obsession" is the second single by the Army of Lovers, from their debut album, Army of Lovers. The single was released in May 1991, and was a chart success in many European countries, reaching number one in Finland and Spain, and entering the top 20 in Sweden, Austria, Germany, Switzerland, France, Belgium, and the Netherlands. The song uses the theme of obsession, in a similar way to the group's later hit, "Ride the Bullet". The original lyrics were written by Alexander Bard, while the music was composed by him and Anders Hansson. The single's B-side, "S Majesty", was also written by Bard and Hansson, and was later included on the album. The music video for the song was directed by Swedish director, Jonas Åkerlund. The song was covered by the band Nightwish, with their lead singer, Tarja Turunen, on the Swedish TV show, Så mycket bättre. "Obsession" was also covered by the Belgian group Kanzi, whose version was included on their debut album, One. In 2008, the song was covered by the Swedish singer, Sanna Nielsen, on her album, 7, and was also released as a single.

The National Science Museum (NSM) is a museum in Bangkok, Thailand. It is the largest science museum in Thailand and the most important museum for natural sciences in Southeast Asia. It is a research museum, with a focus on promotion of science and technology through exhibitions and activities. It is a department of the Ministry of Higher Education, Science, Research and Innovation. The museum was established on 8 October 1964 by a group of professors from the Faculty of Science, Chulalongkorn University. It was first located in the compound of the Royal Bangkok Sports Club, then moved to the vicinity of the National Stadium, and since 25 September 2005 has been located at the former site of the Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives in Bangkok's Chatuchak District. The museum's objectives are to stimulate and increase the public's interest in science, to promote the understanding of science, and to provide a place for the study of natural phenomena. In addition to its permanent and special exhibitions, the museum regularly organizes activities to popularize science among various target groups, such as teachers, students, and the general public. It also has a substantial collection of books and journals on science in both Thai and English. The museum's eight-story building has four exhibition halls with a total space of 5,500 square meters. The museum's main exhibition, titled "Eureka", covers the history of science and technology, and the development of science and technology in the future. The second exhibition, "Eternal Life", covers the evolution of life, from the earliest forms of life to modern humans. The third exhibition, "Journey to the Universe", covers the universe and its origin, the solar system, and the Earth. The fourth exhibition, "The Brain", covers the brain and its functions. In addition to its permanent exhibitions, the museum also hosts special exhibitions on various topics, such as the environment, health, and technology. The museum also has a number of educational programs for students and the general public.

William Ernest Miller (March 14, 1898 – June 13, 1996) was an American lawyer, politician, and businessman who served as a United States Representative from South Dakota. Miller was born in Miller, South Dakota. He attended the public schools and the South Dakota State College at Brookings, where he studied agriculture. He served in the United States Army during World War I. He graduated from the University of South Dakota School of Law in 1921 and was admitted to the bar to practice law the same year. He began his law practice in Miller and also engaged in the banking business. Miller was elected as a Republican to the United States House of Representatives and served from January 3, 1945, to January 3, 1947. He was an unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1946 to the Eighty-third Congress, for election in 1948 to the Eighty-fourth Congress, and for election in 1950 to the Eighty-fifth Congress. Miller resumed the practice of law and also engaged in the banking business. He died in St. Paul, Minnesota, on June 13, 1996, at the age of 98. He is buried in Hillside Cemetery, Miller, South Dakota.

Black Mill is a Grade II* listed building and scheduled monument in the civil parish of Selston, Ashfield District, Nottinghamshire, England. The building is a example of a post mill, the upper wooden structure and the milling machinery, the great majority of which were built in the 18th and 19th centuries. It has been restored, and is in working order. The mill has four hollow-tree-trunk millstones, each 1.37 metres (4 ft 6 in) in diameter. The machinery also includes a pair of Mortice and Tennant double-shuttle self-acting elevators, a pair of Luffenhall PAT double-shuttle elevators, a pair of ¼ in. rollers, a pair of ½ in. rollers, a pair of ¾ in. rollers, a pair of 1 in. rollers, a pair of 1¼ in. rollers, a pair of 1½ in. rollers, a pair of 2 in. rollers, a pair of 2½ in. rollers, a pair of 3 in. rollers, a pair of 3½ in. rollers, a pair of 4 in. rollers, a pair of 4½ in. rollers, a pair of 5 in. rollers, a pair of 5½ in. rollers, a pair of 6 in. rollers, a pair of 6½ in. rollers, a pair of 7 in. rollers, a pair of 7½ in. rollers, a pair of 8 in. rollers, a pair of 8½ in. rollers, a pair of 9 in. rollers, a pair of 9½ in. rollers, a pair of 10 in. rollers, a pair of 10½ in. rollers, a pair of 11 in. rollers, a pair of 11½ in. rollers, a pair of 12 in. rollers, a pair of 12½ in. rollers, a pair of 13 in. rollers, a pair of 13½ in. rollers, a pair of 14 in. rollers, a pair of 14½ in. rollers, a pair of 15 in. rollers, and a pair of 15½ in. rollers.

Dark Days ( Loaded album) Dark Days is the fourth studio album by the English rock band Loaded, released in July 2012. The album was recorded at Lightship 95 in London, and was produced by the band's lead guitarist Mikee Goodman. The band started work on the album in 2011, after the release of their third studio album The Crypt of the Nameless Dead. The band released a single, "Fight for Your Soul", in February 2012, and announced that their new album would be titled Dark Days. Dark Days was released on 25 July 2012. The album was released through the band's own label, loadedmusic, and distributed through Cargo Records. The album's release was supported by a single, "I See Dead People", released in June 2012. Dark Days received mixed to positive reviews from critics. The album's sound was described as "unashamedly old-school" and "safe", with some critics noting that the album did not significantly diverge from the band's previous work. However, critics praised the album's production, and the performance and songwriting of band members Mikee Goodman and Paul Sayer.

John Anthony West (born December 25, 1932) is an American writer, explorer, historian, and inventor, known for his investigations of ancient mysteries and his theories regarding the submerged ruins of the lost city of Atlantis in the Bahamas. West was born in Dallas, Texas. He served in the United States Army from 1955 to 1957, reaching the rank of first lieutenant. He received a Bachelor of Arts in English from the University of Texas at Austin in 1961 and a Master of Arts in English from the University of Denver in 1963. He taught English at Manual High School in Denver, Colorado, from 1964 to 1967 and at Western High School in Denver from 1967 to 1970. In 1970 he quit teaching to devote his full attention to his writing career. West's first book, The Silphium Quest, was published in 1969. This was followed by The Gold of Atlantis, or the Lost Lemuria (1971), an expansion of his doctoral dissertation on the legend of Atlantis, and The Secret History of the World (1973), a work which presents his theory that the world's ancient myths and legends are based on actual historical events. West's works are based on the idea that an advanced prehistoric civilization, which he calls the "pre-flood high culture," once existed and that the survivors of this civilization fled to the higher ground of the Himalayas, the Andes, and the other great mountain ranges of the world to escape the rising Flood, and founded the "post-flood" or "secondary" civilizations of the world. The ancient myths and legends of these secondary civilizations, West believes, contain the memory of the pre-flood high culture, and it is the task of the mythologist to uncover and decode these memories. In his books, West advances the theory that the pre-flood high culture was an Aryan civilization, and that its memories are preserved in the traditions of the ancient Egyptians, the Indo-Aryans, the Maya, and the Aztec. In his book on Atlantis, West states that the Atlantis myth is a memory of the Aryan migration from the flooding of the Indus Valley Civilisation. West has been described as a "mythologist" and as a "leading figure in the study of the ancient world." His works have been reviewed in academic journals and he has been interviewed on radio and television programs.

The Arcade Building is an historic commercial building located in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. It is located at 29–39 Queen Street West, on the south side of Queen Street, just east of Spadina Avenue. The building was designed by John M. Lyle in the Victorian Gothic style, and was built in 1892. The four-storey building is built of red brick with stone trim. The main facade is dominated by a three-storey arcade of Gothic arches, with the centre arch taller than the others. The arches are supported by clusters of colonettes. The building's original main entrance was through the central arch, but this has been closed up and a new entrance cut through the east wall of the building. The building's other main architectural features include the dormer windows on the fourth floor, and the two-storey polygonal bay window on the Spadina Avenue side of the building. The building was originally built for the Toronto Athletic Club, which had been founded in 1888 by a group of businessmen who wanted a club with a swimming pool and other sports facilities. In 1889, the club acquired the property at 29 Queen Street West, and commissioned the building from architect John M. Lyle, who had also designed the club's previous premises at 23 Mutual Street. The new building was completed in 1892, and the club moved into the building that year. The Toronto Athletic Club was a private club, with membership restricted to men. The club was one of several private social clubs in Toronto at the time, and was one of the city's most exclusive clubs. The club's facilities included a swimming pool, a billiards room, a reading room, a bar, and a restaurant. The club also had a number of sports teams, including a baseball team, a hockey team, and a tug-of-war team. In the early 20th century, the building was purchased by the Bank of Toronto, which used it as a bank branch until the early 1970s. The building was then sold to a developer, who converted it into an office building. The building is currently used as offices and retail space.

Sandy Kilpatrick (November 3, 1939 – July 4, 2010) was an American football player and coach. He served as the head football coach at Texas State University–San Marcos from 1979 to 1985, at the University of Texas at Arlington from 1986 to 1989, and at Texas A&M University–Kingsville from 1990 to 1993, compiling a career college football record of 118–73–4. Kilpatrick was born in Tyler, Texas and grew up in Fort Worth, Texas. He attended Southwest High School in Fort Worth, where he led his football team to the state championship game. After graduating from high school, he attended the University of Texas at Austin, where he played for the Texas Longhorns football team as a defensive back from 1958 to 1961, lettering for three years. He was a member of the Longhorns' 1961 national championship team. He graduated from Texas in 1962 with a bachelor's degree in education. After graduation, Kilpatrick began his coaching career as an assistant coach at his alma mater, Southwest High School. He was an assistant coach at Southwest for four years before he was hired as the defensive coordinator at Texas State University–San Marcos in 1973. In 1978, he was promoted to head coach at Texas State, where he remained for six seasons and compiled a record of 52–27–2. In 1985, he took the head coaching position at the University of Texas at Arlington, where he remained for five seasons and compiled a 45–19–2 record. In 1990, he was hired as the head coach at Texas A&M University–Kingsville, where he remained for four seasons and compiled a record of 63–20–2. After leaving Texas A&M–Kingsville in 1994, Kilpatrick went into private business in Houston. In 2004, he was inducted into the Texas High School Hall of Fame. He died in July 2010 at the age of 70.

The 37th Army was a field army of the Soviet Union's Red Army, active from 1942 through to the early 1970s. The 37th Army was formed on November 7, 1942, from the 37th Army Corps. It was part of the Reserve of the Supreme High Command and was used for the 1943–44 offensive to recapture the Ukrainian SSR. The Army was composed of the 111th and 112th Guards Rifle Corps and the 37th Army Corps. In the summer of 1943, the 37th Army was assigned to the Steppe Military District. It was used for the offensive to retake the Donbas region. In October, the 37th Army was moved to the Transcaucasus Military District and took part in the battle for the Taman Peninsula. In February–March 1944, the 37th Army was used to reinforce the Belorussian Military District. It took part in the Soviet offensive in Belarus, and was heavily defeated in the Warsaw–Poznan Offensive. The Army was located in the Belorussian Military District at the time of the Soviet invasion of Manchuria in August 1945, but did not see action in the war with Japan. In the early 1970s, the 37th Army was converted into the 37th Army Corps.

Apologeticus In Roman Catholic theology, apologetics is an area of the Christian tradition that deals with the defense of the Catholic faith. In Greek, the word apologeticus (ἀπολογικός) means "speaking in defense". The term apology in this context is not an admission of wrongdoing, but rather a defense of the faith. Apologetics includes the defense of the Catholic Church against scandals, the promotion of the Catholic faith through the explanation of church teachings and traditions, and the refutation of objections to Catholic teachings. It is an important topic for the Catholic Church, particularly in the face of a secularized culture. The Catholic Church's approach to apologetics is unique. While it makes use of reason, it does not rely upon it absolutely. Catholic apologetics is not an attempt to win an argument, but to win a soul. Thus, Catholic apologetics is more about love than about logic. The Church's approach to apologetics is to convince people of the love that God has for them, and the extent to which the Catholic Church wants to lead them to that love. In the modern world, the term apologetics has come to refer more to the use of reason to convince someone of the faith, rather than to the use of love. This is an unfortunate narrowing of the term's meaning, which has been further confused by the use of the term apologetics to refer to the defense of the faith against those who attack it. In this context, apologetics is not about love, but about winning an argument. This is not the meaning that the Church gives to the term apologetics. In the Catholic Church, the term apologetics is used to refer to the use of reason to explain and promote the faith. This is a very different use of the term apologetics than is generally used in the modern world.

Asensio Nebot Arquitectura Asensio Nebot Arquitectura is a Spanish architectural practice established in 1994 by Spanish architect Asensio Nebot. The studio has developed numerous projects in Spain and other countries. Among its most significant works are the Spanish Pavilion at the Expo 2000 in Germany, the betrayal of the Spanish Pavilion at the Expo 2008 in Spain, the Andorran Pavilion at the Expo 2008, the Groupama Stadium in Lyon, the City Hall in Amos, Quebec, and the City Hall in Montreuil, Paris. Asensio Nebot Arquitectura has received a number of awards, including the 1998 FAD Prize for the Monolith of Expo.02 in Switzerland, the 1999 Spanish Architecture and Urbanism Prize for the Media-Tic Center in Barcelona, the 2000 Aga Khan Award for Architecture for the Spanish Pavilion at Expo 2000, the 2003 Mies van der Rohe Award for the City Hall in Amos, Quebec, the 2006 European Union Prize for Contemporary Architecture for the City Hall in Montreuil, and the 2007 International Urban Project Award for the New Cordoba City Hall.

Clone, in computing, is a term for a copy of a file or a block-level representation of a file in another file, usually with the same name. Cloning is different from a backup, as a backup is a copy of a file with a different name. Cloning is used for the purpose of having two or more exact copies of a file or a data structure that can be modified independently of each other. Changes made to one copy will not affect the other copy. The concept of cloning is similar to that of a fork in software development. Cloning can be done manually or by using a cloning tool. A cloning tool may also be called a "clone manager" or a "cloning application". There are many reasons for cloning a file. One reason is to have a backup of the file. If the file is important, a clone can be made so that if the original file is lost or damaged, a clone can be used as a backup. Another reason for cloning a file is to have a copy of the file that can be modified without affecting the original file. For example, if a file is being worked on by two or more people, a clone can be made for each person so that they can each make changes to their own copy without affecting the changes made by the other person. Cloning can also be used to create a copy of a file that can be shared with others. For example, if a file is too large to email, a clone can be made and shared via a file-sharing service or a cloud storage service. There are some risks to using cloning. One risk is that if a clone is made of a file that is being worked on by another person, the changes made by the other person may not be reflected in the clone. This can lead to confusion and lost work. To avoid this, it is important to make sure that the clone is made of the most recent version of the file. Another risk is that if a clone is made of a file that is later deleted, the clone may not be able to be recovered. This is because the reference to the original file may be lost, and the clone may only contain a copy of the data from the file.

Gunārs Meierovics (born February 8, 1998) is a Latvian professional basketball player for the Memphis Grizzlies of the National Basketball Association (NBA). He played college basketball for the University of Maryland and is the son of former Latvian basketball player Valdis Meierovics. Meierovics was born in Riga, Latvia. He played basketball for the Latvian junior national team at the 2013 FIBA Europe Under-16 Championship, where he was one of the top ten scorers. In 2014, Meierovics moved to the United States to play high school basketball. He attended Link Year Prep in Branson, Missouri for the 2014–15 school year, averaging 22.9 points per game. After his year at Link Year Prep, Meierovics joined the NBA Global Academy in Canberra, Australia. In January 2016, he was named to the Australian Schools Championships All-Star Five after he averaged 25.4 points per game. In April 2016, he was selected to the Australian Under-19 National Team to compete at the 2016 FIBA Under-19 World Cup in Greece, where he averaged 5.2 points per game. In July 2016, Meierovics moved to the United States to play college basketball for the Maryland Terrapins. He averaged 4.9 points per game in his freshman year. In the 2017–18 season, he averaged 6.9 points per game and was named to the All-Big Ten Conference Academic Team. After the season, he declared for the 2018 NBA draft without hiring an agent, meaning he could return to Maryland if he chose to. On June 21, 2018, Meierovics was selected by the Memphis Grizzlies with the 55th overall pick in the 2018 NBA draft. On July 7, 2018, he signed a four-year contract with the Grizzlies. In July 2018, Meierovics was named to the Latvian national team's preliminary roster for the 2019 FIBA World Championship.

Emily Ducote (born July 16, 1992) is an American mixed martial artist and boxer. She is currently signed to the Ultimate Fighting Championship (UFC) and is ranked #13 in the UFC Women's Flyweight division. Ducote was born in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. She attended Kennedy High School in Cedar Rapids, where she participated in wrestling, basketball, and tennis. She graduated from Kennedy High School in 2010. Ducote began boxing in 2010, and in 2011, she was named the Iowa Golden Gloves Champion. She was also a National Golden Gloves Champion in 2012. In 2013, she was named the Ringmaster's International Boxing Champion. In 2013, Ducote began competing in mixed martial arts (MMA). She made her professional debut in April 2013, and in November 2013, she won the Fight to Win 120 lb. Women's Championship. In 2014, she was named the On the Rise Fighter of the Year by The Fight Journal. Ducote joined the UFC in 2015, and she is currently competing in the UFC Women's Flyweight division. She is known for her striking ability, and in 2016, she was named the UFC Women's Flyweight Co-Champion. In 2017, she was named the UFC Women's Flyweight Champion. In addition to competing in MMA, Ducote also continues to compete in boxing. In 2016, she was named the WBC Lightweight Champion. In 2017, she was named the WBC Lightweight Co-Champion. Ducote is currently ranked #13 in the UFC Women's Flyweight division.

Will Cullen Hart (born William John Cullen Hart, Jr.; November 29, 1971) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, author, and artist, best known as a founding member of the bands Quarkspace, Spectoryu Nosferatu, and Hella. He has also released several solo albums, and has written and illustrated several graphic novels, including the award-winning City of Roses. Hart was born in Portland, Oregon. His father, William John Cullen Hart, was a teacher at Portland State University and a computational mathematician, and his mother, Martha, was a counselor and administrator in higher education. In the early 1990s, Hart was a member of the band Happy Flowers, with whom he recorded the album Little Gardens. In the mid-1990s, he formed the band Quarkspace with his friend and fellow musician James Heintz. The band has gone through numerous lineup changes since its formation, and has released a number of recordings on independent record labels, including the albums Quarkspace (1998), Far Out Sessions (1999), and Scales (2002). In 1998, Hart formed the band Spectoryu Nosferatu, which was initially intended as a side project of Quarkspace. The band's name is derived from the Japanese word "Spectoryu," which means "specter," and the Romanian word "Nosferatu," which means "vampire." The band's first release was the EP Phantom Stage, which was followed by the albums Phantom Factor and Bloodline. In 2001, the band's lineup was streamlined to include just Hart and Heintz, and they released the album Reptilica. In 1999, Hart released his first solo album, entitled solo. It was followed by the albums Everything Is Now, The Fire in the Sky, and Old World New World. In 2005, he released the album Stories, which featured a number of guest musicians, including his brother, John. In 2002, Hart published his first graphic novel, entitled The Death of Satan, through his own imprint, Quarkspace Comics. The story, which was inspired by the works of Milton and Dante, follows a character named William Cullen as he journeys through the various levels of Hell. In 2003, he published the graphic novel City of Roses, which was based on a story he had written in the late 1990s. The story, which is set in Portland, Oregon, follows two characters, Rose and Thorn, as they navigate their way through the city's underworld. In 2005, City of Roses won the award for Best Graphic Novel at the prestigious Eisner Awards. In addition to his work in music and comics, Hart has also exhibited his artwork in a number of galleries, and has been a guest lecturer at the Oregon College of Art and Design.

Dené–Caucasian languages The Dené–Caucasian languages are a proposed group of languages descended from a common ancestor language, which is itself a daughter language of the proposed Nostratic language family.
