Mynagappally is a village in Kottayam district in the state of Kerala, India. It is situated on the banks of the Meenachil River, near its confluence with the Vaigai River. The Meenachil river flows from the Western Ghats and joins the Vaigai river at Mynagappally. The combined flow from the two rivers, after the confluence, is known as the Pamba river. The town of Kumily is located 35 km (22 mi) away from Mynagappally. The village is home to a school, a temple and a church. The temple at Mynagappally is dedicated to Sree Rama. The village is also home to a primary health centre. The Pamba river flows through the village. The Mynagappally Bridge is the oldest bridge across the Pamba. The current bridge was built in the year 2001. The village is well connected to other parts of Kerala by road and is only 3 km (1.9 mi) away from the Erumely Bus Station. The nearest railway stations are at Erumely and Kumily. The nearest airport is at Kochi. Mynagappally is also known for its proximity to the tourist destination of Munnar. Tourists who visit Munnar can also visit Mynagappally to see the convergence of the Meenachil and Vaigai Rivers.

The Warrell Corporation is a limited liability company in the United States, with its main office in Camp Hill, Pennsylvania. It is the world's largest manufacturer of caramel and chocolate covered popcorn, and also manufactures chocolate novelties, including novelties for the Christmas season. The company also owns the Philadelphia Candies brand and the licenses for the Tootsie Roll and Welch's brands of candies. The Warrell Corporation also owns the patent for the "self-tying" ribbon candy, although the patent is no longer in effect. The company was founded in 1964 by James Warrell. The company's first big customer was the U.S. government, which purchased millions of dollars' worth of caramel-covered popcorn for U.S. military bases around the world. In the 1970s, the company began selling its products to the public, and in the 1980s, it began selling novelty items, such as chocolate-covered pretzels and chocolate Santas. The company's products are made in the United States and in Mexico. The company also has a production facility in the United Kingdom, and a research and development facility in Massachusetts. The Warrell Corporation is owned by James Warrell, and is managed by his son, Jamie Warrell. The company has annual sales of more than $100 million.

Jack Trammell (born October 18, 1938) is an American politician who served in the Georgia House of Representatives from the 150th District from 2004 to 2013. He was previously a member from 1996 through 2002. In 2013, he was elected to the Georgia State Board of Education and re-elected in 2016. Trammell was born in Atlanta, Georgia. He is a businessman and a member of the Georgia Republican Party. Trammell was the Republican nominee for the Georgia State Senate in District 42 in 1996, but lost to incumbent Democrat David Adelman. In 2000, Trammell was the Republican nominee for the Georgia House of Representatives in District 150, losing to Democrat Don Davis. In 2002, he was again the Republican nominee for the House in District 150, this time defeating Davis. Trammell was the Republican nominee for the Georgia House of Representatives in District 150 in 2004, defeating incumbent Democrat Mohammed Khaidar in the general election. He was the only Republican to win a seat previously held by a Democrat in the Georgia House that year. Trammell was the Republican nominee for the Georgia House of Representatives in District 150 in 2006, defeating Democrat H. Scott Caldwell in the general election. Trammell was the Republican nominee for the Georgia House of Representatives in District 150 in 2008, defeating Democrat Chris Bailey in the general election. Trammell was the Republican nominee for the Georgia House of Representatives in District 150 in 2010, defeating Democrat Bobby DuBose in the general election. Trammell was the Republican nominee for the Georgia House of Representatives in District 150 in 2012, defeating Democrat Keisha Waites in the general election. In 2013, Trammell was elected to the Georgia State Board of Education, defeating Democrat John D. Stone in the general election. He was re-elected in 2016.

The Plinian core is a layered, bulbous, and distinctively-shaped feature found within the Plinian eruption column of certain large explosive volcanic eruptions. It is a dramatic example of a controlled gravitational collapse of the eruption column, which is driven by the loss of stability when the magma chamber empties. The name is derived from Pliny the Younger, who described in his letters the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD, and provided the first description of the phenomenon. The Plinian core is a result of the non-stop growth of the eruption column, and is distinct from the more common and shorter-lived volcanic bombs, which are sometimes also called "plinian". The eruption column grows when magma is fed to the base of the column, and the weight of the column increases. As the magma chamber empties, the column loses its support, and the weight of the eruption column causes a gravitational collapse. This in turn causes the magma to pool at the base of the column, and the cycle repeats itself. The result is a series of concentric zones within the eruption column, with the cool, brittle, and relatively empty zones near the top, and the warm, less-brittle, and more fluid zones near the bottom. When the Plinian core finally does burst, it releases a tremendous amount of energy, and the outermost zones of the Plinian core are blown away. The remaining Plinian core then collapses, and a base surge is created. The Plinian core has a large amount of potential energy, and when it is released, the energy can trigger further pyroclastic flows. Plinian cores can be very large, and they can have a volume of hundreds of cubic kilometers. They are also very long-lived, and they can survive for thousands of years. The famous Mount St. Helens eruption of 1980 produced a plinian core that was 1,600 feet (488 m) long. The eruption of Mount Spurr in 1992 produced a plinian core that was 3,200 feet (980 m) long. The Plinian core is a distinctive feature of certain large explosive volcanic eruptions, and it is a dramatic example of a controlled gravitational collapse of the eruption column. The Plinian core can be very large, and it can have a volume of hundreds of cubic kilometers. It is also very long-lived, and it can survive for thousands of years. The Plinian core is a unique feature of large explosive volcanic eruptions, and it is a dramatic example of a controlled gravitational collapse of the eruption column.

CheyTac Intervention The CheyTac Intervention is a bolt-action sniper rifle designed and manufactured by CheyTac LLC, a company founded by Russian arms designer Eugene Stoner. The rifle was introduced in 2006. The CheyTac Intervention is a large, heavy-barreled bolt-action rifle, available in a variety of calibers. The rifle's action is similar to that of the Remington 700, but it is modified to accept a large diameter barrel. The stock is made from high-strength polymer and features an adjustable cheekpiece and buttpad. The rifle also has an adjustable trigger pull, which can be set between 2.5 and 4.5 pounds. The CheyTac Intervention is equipped with a 24-inch (61 cm), 26-inch (66 cm), or 30-inch (76 cm) barrel, which is available in either fluted or non-fluted configurations. The rifle uses a five-round, detachable box magazine, and is equipped with a Picatinny rail for mounting accessories. The CheyTac Intervention is designed for use in military and law enforcement applications, and is currently used by a variety of military and law enforcement agencies around the world. The rifle is capable of providing long-range sniping capabilities, and is effective for a variety of tactical applications, including counter-terrorism and hostage rescue operations.

Ron Schueler (born April 13, 1947) is an American former professional baseball player, coach, and manager. He played three seasons in the Major League Baseball (MLB) as a left-handed pitcher for the Chicago White Sox and Texas Rangers, and was a pitching coach for the White Sox, Rangers, and Seattle Mariners. He was the manager of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays from 2001 to 2002. Schueler was born in Cincinnati, Ohio. He attended Western Hills High School in that city and played on the school's baseball team. The Chicago White Sox selected Schueler in the third round, with the fifty-eighth overall selection, of the 1965 MLB draft. After graduating from high school, he began his professional career in the minor leagues with the Duluth-Superior Dukes of the Northern League. He spent three seasons with the Dukes, pitching to a 15–15 win–loss record with a 3.53 earned run average (ERA) in 1966, a 7–10 record with a 4.80 ERA in 1967, and a 9–5 record with a 4.13 ERA in 1968. In 1969, he joined the Indianapolis Indians of the American Association. He was 15–11 with a 3.44 ERA for the Indians in 1969, and 6–6 with a 3.68 ERA in 1970. The White Sox called him up to the major leagues in July 1970, and he made his MLB debut on July 17. Schueler appeared in 20 games for the White Sox in 1970, including one start. He had a 2–0 record with a 4.91 ERA in the games. He also appeared in one game for the Texas Rangers that year. In 1971, he appeared in 26 games for the Rangers, working as a relief pitcher. He had a 4.35 ERA in the games. After the season, the Rangers released him, and he signed with the Indianapolis Indians, where he played from 1972 to 1974. He appeared in 37 games for the Indians in 1972, registering a 4.91 ERA. In 1973, he made 35 appearances, all but one in relief, and had a 3.24 ERA. In 1974, he made 26 appearances, all in relief, and had a 4.35 ERA. After the season, he signed with the Seattle Rainiers of the Pacific Coast League. He appeared in 17 games for the Rainiers in 1975, registering an 0–2 record with a 4.35 ERA. It was his last year in professional baseball. After retiring as a player, Schueler began a coaching career. He was the pitching coach for the White Sox in 1976, and for the Rangers from 1977 to 1981. In 1982, he joined the Seattle Mariners as the team's pitching coach, and he held that position through the 1991 season. He was the interim manager of the Mariners for the last four games of the 1991 season after John McLaren was fired, then was the pitching coach for the devil rays in 1998 and 1999. He was the manager of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays from 2001 to 2002, when the Devil Rays went 65–97. It was his last year as a manager.

Henry Cavendish, 3rd Baron Waterpark PC (30 October 1754 – 4 October 1807) was a British politician and peer. Cavendish was the son of Sir George Cavendish, 2nd Baronet, by his wife Lady Mary Bruce, daughter of the 1st Earl of Ailesbury. He was educated at Eton College, a private boys' school in Eton, Berkshire, and at New College, Oxford, an Oxford University college. He was a fellow of the Royal Society and a member of the Society of Antiquaries of London. In 1782, he was elected a Member of Parliament (MP) for New Shoreham, with a majority of one vote, by the deputy-governor of the prison at Newgate, who had been directed by the Duke of Newcastle to vote for the candidate supported by the government (Sir Henry Clinton), but had decided to vote for Cavendish after Clinton had declared that the government would not pay the salary of the deputy-governor. He was re-elected in 1784, and held the seat until 1790. He was also returned as an MP for Hampshire in 1784, but resigned that seat in 1790. Cavendish was a Lord of the Bedchamber to Prince Edward, Duke of Kent and Strathearn, from 1784 to 1802. He was made a Privy Councillor in 1792. He succeeded his father as 3rd Baron Waterpark in 1753, and died in 1807. He married Lady Margaret Townshend, daughter of the 2nd Earl of Strafford, in 1799. He had no children and the barony became extinct on his death.

Andrea Brancaccio (born 4 August 1996) is an Italian professional footballer who plays as a midfielder for club Parma. Born in Rome, Brancaccio began his career in the youth system of local club Roma. In 2013, he was promoted to the under-19 squad by new coach Alberto De Rossi, who had also previously coached Brancaccio at the club's Giovanissimi level. In the same year, he also made his debut for the club's reserves, lining up for all three of the team's 2013–14 Serie C matches. On 16 May 2014, Brancaccio appeared in his first professional match, coming on as an 80th-minute substitute in a 0–0 draw with Pisa. The following season, Brancaccio was promoted to the first team by new coach Rudi Garcia. He appeared in all five of the team's Europa League group stage matches, scoring in a 2–1 defeat toMorning Star in the process. On 19 December, Brancaccio made his Serie A debut, coming on as a 77th-minute substitute in a 1–0 defeat to Parma. Four days later, he made his full debut in a 3–1 victory over Cagliari, lining up as a left midfielder. Brancaccio finished the campaign with 20 appearances, including 12 starts, and 2 goals. On 1 September 2015, Brancaccio was sent to Parma in a one-year loan deal with an obligation to buy. In June 2016, he signed a new two-year contract with Parma.

W.A.K.O. World Championships 2005 (Agadir) The W.A.K.O. World Championships 2005 were the joint 11th and 12th instance of the W.A.K.O. world championships that were held in Agadir, Morocco on September 2005. The styles that were featured at the world championships were Full Contact, Low-Kick, Thai-Boxing, Kick-Boxing and Martial-Arts. Both men and women took part in all the styles, with the exception of male martial-arts, which was only for men. The Full Contact category had eight weight divisions, two more than in the last world championships in Paris. The newly introduced divisions were -57 kg and +95 kg, while the men's heavyweight division was reduced to 80 kg. In the Low-Kick category, there were eight weight divisions for both men and women. In the Thai-Boxing category, there were six weight divisions for both men and women. In the Kick-Boxing category, there were eight weight divisions for both men and women. In the Martial-Arts category, there were eight weight divisions for both men and women. The world championships were attended by participants from 65 countries, with France having the largest team, as usual, with 79 fighters. France was the top nation in the world championships, winning five gold medals, one silver medal and one bronze medal. Russia was the second best nation with four gold medals, one silver medal and one bronze medal. Italy was the third best nation with three gold medals, two silver medals and two bronze medals. W.A.K.O. awards two types of medals, one for technical victory and one for fair play. The most spectacular fight of the tournament was in the Thai-Boxing 70 kg category, where Onesun Jami of Russia beat Petchmorakot Petchyindee of Thailand by knockout in the first round. At the closing ceremony, the president of W.A.K.O., Ennio Falsoni, awarded the best competitor in each category with the "Best Fighter of the World Championship" award. The next world championships were held in Belgrade, Serbia in 2006.

Matt Wozniak (born September 16, 1973) is an American murderer and suspected serial killer who was convicted in the deaths of three young women in the Seattle area in the early 2000s. Wozniak had a long history of mental illness and substance abuse. He had been diagnosed with schizophrenia and had been committed to a mental institution in his early 20s. He had also been arrested for theft and drug possession. In 2002, Wozniak was living in a boarding house in Seattle when he met and became friends with 20-year-old Stamatia Sklhead. Sklhead, who was also mentally ill, lived with her mother and was taking classes at a community college. In December 2002, Sklhead's body was found in a park in Seattle. She had been beaten and strangled. Wozniak was arrested and charged with her murder. In 2004, Wozniak was convicted of Sklhead's murder and sentenced to life in prison. In 2005, Wozniak was linked to the deaths of two other women in the Seattle area. He was convicted of their murders and sentenced to death. In 2008, Wozniak was found guilty of three counts of aggravated murder and three counts of murder with the aggravating circumstance of being a repeat offender. He was sentenced to death. Wozniak is currently on death row at the Washington State Penitentiary in Walla Walla, Washington.

Suicide of Tyler Clementi The suicide of Tyler Clementi was the second-degree murder of college student Tyler Clementi, who jumped to his death from the George Washington Bridge on September 22, 2010. In 2012, his roommate, Dharun Ravi, was convicted of spying on Clementi, the first criminal case in the United States involving a victim who died by suicide. On the evening of September 20, 2010, Tyler Clementi, a freshman at Rutgers University, bid farewell to his friends and took his life by jumping off the George Washington Bridge into the Hudson River. His body was found on September 22, 2010, after a search that involved the use of a police helicopter and thermal imaging technology. A friend of Clementi's, David Scharbaum, said that Clementi had been depressed about being rejected from the college's rugby team. However, Scharbaum said that Clementi had seemed to be doing better after getting a date for the upcoming Rutgers fall dance. Scharbaum also said that he had seen a notice on Clementi's Facebook page about the dance. "I saw that he was excited about it," Scharbaum said. Clementi's roomate, Dharun Ravi, told investigators that he had spied on Clementi through a webcam and had seen him in a compromising position with another man. After discovering the affair, Ravi had reported it to friends, and his actions were described as "homophobic" and "disrespectful" by one of the friends. In the weeks prior to his death, Clementi had asked Ravi to report the affair to the Rutgers authorities, but Ravi had not done so. In 2012, a New Jersey state court convicted Ravi of "assment, Dumbness, and Inhumanity to a person" for spying on Clementi. He was also convicted of a count of "disorderly conduct" for his conduct during the initial investigation by Rutgers police. Ravi was sentenced to three years in prison. In September 2012, the Foundation for Individual Rights in Education (FIRE) named Clementi as one of their "10 Most speech-restricted colleges in the country". FIRE also named Rutgers University as the " Speech Code of the Month" for September 2012, citing the school's suspension of 10 students, including Clementi, for offensive Facebook posts as one of the reasons. In 2013, Rutgers University officials released a report on the school's handling of the affair. The report found that the Rutgers police had issued a "preliminary finding of responsibility" to Clementi for his death, but that this finding was not supported by the evidence. The report also found that there were " Gross Mishaps and Misjudgments " in the university's handling of the case, and that the school's " systems and processes " had failed.

Fundamental theorem of linear programming The fundamental theorem of linear programming is a basic result in linear programming that shows that any linear programming problem can be boiled down to a trivial problem. Given a linear programming problem, the fundamental theorem states that the objective function can be written in the form max c'x where c is a vector of constants and x is a vector of variables, and the constraints can be written in the form ax = b where a is a vector of constants, x is a vector of variables, and b is a vector of constants. The fundamental theorem is useful because it shows that any linear programming problem can be reduced to a trivial problem of this form, so that any linear programming algorithm that works for this trivial problem will also work for the original problem. The proof of the fundamental theorem is an important example of an application of the theory of duality in linear programming. The fundamental theorem can be stated as a corollary of the following two theorems. The first theorem is that any linear programming problem can be recast in the standard form. The second theorem is the so-called primal-dual theorem, which is a basic result in linear programming that shows that every linear programming problem can be recast as a primal-dual problem, where the primal problem is the original problem and the dual problem is a trivial problem in which the objective function is the shadow price of the primal problem. The fundamental theorem is a corollary of these two theorems because the objective function in the fundamental theorem is the shadow price of the dual problem, and the constraints in the fundamental theorem are the constraints of the primal problem. The standard form of a linear programming problem is a form in which the problem is expressed using only the variables x and the constants a and b. In this form, the linear programming problem is to maximize a linear function c'x subject to the constraints ax = b and x >= 0. Here, c is a vector of constants (which will be used later), a is a vector of constants, b is a vector of constants, and x is a vector of variables. The primal-dual theorem states that for any linear programming problem, there exists a primal problem and a dual problem such that the primal-dual problem is equivalent to the original linear programming problem. The primal problem is the original problem and the dual problem is a trivial problem in which the objective function is the shadow price of the primal problem. The primal-dual theorem is a basic result in linear programming that shows that every linear programming problem can be recast as a primal-dual problem, where the primal problem is the original problem and the dual problem is a trivial problem in which the objective function is the shadow price of the primal problem. The fundamental theorem is a corollary of these two theorems because the objective function in the fundamental theorem is the shadow price of the dual problem, and the constraints in the fundamental theorem are the constraints of the primal problem.

John D. Waldorf is an American businessman, investor, and philanthropist. He is the co-founder of the investment firm Elliott Management, former CEO of the financial services firm E*TRADE Bank, and the co-owner of the NBA's Sacramento Kings. Waldorf was born to a Jewish family in Buffalo, New York, the son of Elaine (née Goldberg) and Morton Waldorf. His father was a B-29 pilot who died in a plane crash in 1953 when John was two years old. His mother later remarried to Buffalo businessman Jack Hunt, with whom she had another son, Gary. John attendedandafter-school programattheUniversityofBuffaloand graduated from high school in 1968. He attended the University of Michigan and graduated with a B.A. in 1972. Waldorf began his career in financial services in 1972 at the investment bank Alex. Brown & Sons. He was a mortgage-backed securities analyst and then an associate in the corporate finance division. In 1978, he joined E*TRADE, an online brokerage startup. He was one of the first 15 employees of the company, and he has been involved in all aspects of the company's development, including establishing the E*TRADE Bank. In 1982, Waldorf became the president of E*TRADE. He became the CEO in 2001. In 2007, he was named the CEO of the year by the American Business Awards. In 2008, he was named the CEO of the year by the World Business Awards. In 2009, he was named the CEO of the year by the New York Financial World Awards. In 2010, Waldorf stepped down as CEO of E*TRADE, but he remained the company's chairman. He also became the CEO of Elliott Management, an investment firm that he had founded in 1977. In 2011, Elliott Management acquired the aircraft leasing company ILFC, and in 2013, it acquired the financial services firm Neuberger Berman. In 2014, Waldorf became the co-owner of the NBA's Sacramento Kings. He is the managing partner of the team's ownership group, which includes majority owner Gavin Maloof. In 2015, Waldorf was named the co-owner of the year by the NBA Awards.

German destroyer Z28 The German destroyer Z28 was a Type 1936A-class destroyer built for the Kriegsmarine (German Navy) during World War II. The Type 1936A-class destroyers were a group of four destroyers ordered in 1936, and were the first destroyers designed and built specifically for Germany's Kriegsmarine. The four vessels of the class, from the smallest to the largest, were the Z23, Z24, Z25, and Z28, all of which entered service in early 1939. These ships were larger and more powerful than the preceding Type 1934 and Type 1936 classes, with increased engine power and heavier anti-aircraft guns. Unlike the older classes, whose engines were arranged in separate engine rooms, the Type 1936A class was built with two exhaustible Chance Vought steam turbines in a single engine room. The destroyers were well-armed for their time, with a five-inch (130 mm) dual purpose gun, three anti-aircraft guns, and six torpedo tubes. The Z28 was laid down in October 1937 at the Reichsmarinewerft shipyard in Kiel, Germany. She was commissioned on 3 January 1939 with Kapitän zur See (KzS—Kapitan zur See, "Captain at Sea") Alfred Schikin in command. After serving as a flotilla leader in the 1st Torpedoboat Flotilla of the 1st Torpedo-Boat Group, in October 1944, Z28 was assigned to the 2nd Torpedoboat Flotilla of the 3rd Torpedo-Boat Group. On 18 December 1944, the Z28 was sunk by British bombers in the IJsselmeer.

Mount Druitt railway station is a heritage-listed railway station located on the Main Western line in Mount Druitt, New South Wales, Australia. The property was added to the New South Wales State Heritage Register on 2 April 1999. The station is located 72 kilometres (45 mi) from Sydney Central station. The station was built in 1884 and is the second station to have been built on this site. The original station was a simple bog standard design, however in the early 20th century it was decided that the station needed to be upgraded to a more substantial design. The station was subsequently rebuilt in concrete with a barrel roofed platform shelter and a distinctive and unique signal box, which is one of the few to have been built in that style in the state. The station was closed in 1991 due to the construction of the Mount Druitt Hospital and the subsequent rerouting of the Main Western line. The station was then subsequently rebuilt in 1998 to the same design as the original, with the signal box being relocated to Blacktown. The station is now the terminating point for the Blacktown-Mount Druitt via Richmond service.

Ada Developers Academy is a non-profit organization and a 501(c)(3) public charity, founded in 2013 by Seattle-based software development consultancy AdaCore to provide education and career opportunities in software development to women and other minority groups in technology. The organization's primary program is a seven-month, full-time, in-person training program in software development that is offered at no cost to the students. The program is designed to take students with little to no prior experience in software development and prepare them to be successful junior developers. The organization also offers a variety of free workshops and classes in software development topics, as well as a paid eight-week "Java Jumpstart" program, which is targeted at individuals who already have a basic understanding of software development and want to learn the Java programming language. Since its inception, Ada Developers Academy has graduated over 300 students, the vast majority of whom have gone on to find jobs in software development. The organization has also established partnerships with a number of technology companies, including Amazon, Microsoft, and Google, which have provided financial support to the organization and hired its graduates. In 2017, Ada Developers Academy was named one of the top 10 coding schools in the United States by SwitchUp, a website for students who are interested in attending coding schools. In 2018, the organization was named one of the top 25 coding schools in the country by the same organization. In 2020, Ada Developers Academy received a $1 million grant from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation to expand its programs and services. The organization also received a $250,000 grant from the Lodestar Foundation to support its efforts to increase diversity and inclusion in technology. In 2021, Ada Developers Academy launched a new initiative called "Ada Community Bridge", which is aimed at increasing the representation of minority groups in technology by providing resources and support to individuals who are interested in becoming software developers. As part of this initiative, the organization launched a new website, adabridge.org, which serves as a resource for individuals who are looking to learn more about software development and how to get started in the field.

Richard D. Todd (born July 29, 1942) is an American politician and businessman who served as the 69th governor of the state of Vermont from 1997 to 2003. Todd was born in Detroit, Michigan, the son of Ellen (née Fournier) and James R. Todd. He attended Catholic schools in Michigan, and graduated from Detroit's Mackenzie High School in 1960. He went on to earn a bachelor's degree from the University of Michigan in 1964 and an M.B.A. from the Ross School of Business at the University of Michigan in 1966. In 1968, Todd moved to Vermont and settled in Woodstock, where he became a partner in a successful business, the Woodbury Corporation. The firm's primary business was buying, improving, and selling hotels. In 1985, Todd and his partners sold their hotels, and Todd turned to politics. A Republican, Todd ran for the Vermont House of Representatives in 1986, but was defeated by incumbent Democrat Margaret Flory. In 1988, he was elected to the Vermont Senate from the three-member at-large Washington County District, and he was re-elected in 1990. In 1992, he was elected to the Vermont House of Representatives from Woodstock, and he was re-elected in 1994. In 1996, Todd was elected governor of Vermont, defeating Democrat Howard Dean, the future DNC Chairman, by a margin of 3,249 votes. He was sworn in as governor on January 1, 1997. As governor, Todd focused on making Vermont a "granite state," promoting tourism and the state's heritage. In his first year in office, Todd proposed a reduction in the state's income tax rate, but the legislature rejected the idea. Todd also proposed legislation to reduce the state's cigarette tax, but the bill was defeated in the state Senate. In 1998, Todd was re-elected governor, defeating Democrat Peter Shumlin, the future governor, by a margin of 3,617 votes. In 2000, Todd was again re-elected, defeating Democrat James Douglas, the future governor, by a margin of 2,hi votes. In 2002, Todd did not run for re-election, and Douglas was elected governor. After leaving office, Todd returned to his home in Woodstock, and is involved in several business and nonprofit ventures.

Desmond Kingsford, M.D., D.Sc., F.A.C.P., F.R.C.P. (Lond.), F.R.C.Path. (Lond.), M.B., B.S. (Lond.), D.Sc. (Lond.), M.B.B.S., D.M. (Lond.), F.F.Hom., was an English physician, pathologist, author, and researcher who contributed new insight on the role of the immune system in the causation of disease. He was born in London, England in 1908, the son of the lawyer and amateur golfer Henry Kingsford and his wife, the daughter of the doctor and scientist William Banting. He was educated at Charterhouse School, then an all-boys boarding school in Godalming, Surrey, and at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he read Natural Sciences. He then went to the London Hospital Medical College, where he qualified as a physician and surgeon in 1932. During the Second World War, he served with the Royal Army Medical Corps, rising to the rank of Colonel. After the war, he returned to the London Hospital as a pathologist and researcher, and was appointed Professor of Pathology at the London Hospital Medical College in 1949, and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine in 1964. He was also Consulting Pathologist to the Royal Free Hospital, to the Mount Vernon Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, to the Hospital for Sick Children, and to the Civil Service. In his research, he studied the role of the immune system in the causation of disease, and particularly the autoimmune diseases. He contributed new insight on the subject, and developed a number of new diagnostic tests. In his clinical practice, he specialised in the diagnosis and treatment of diseases of the blood, and particularly the autoimmune diseases. He also had a special interest in the history of medicine, and wrote on this subject as well as on medicine and science. He was the author of over 200 papers and articles on medicine and science, as well as several books.

Wingello, New South Wales, Australia is a village in the Southern Highlands of New South Wales, Australia, in Wingello Shire. It is located on the Hume Highway (A.C.T. – New South Wales border), and is approximately 4 kilometres (2 mi) from the New South Wales – Victoria border. At the Wingello had a population of 681. The name "Wingello" is believed to have been derived from an Aboriginal word meaning "the meeting place". The village was so named because it was at the point where the trade route from the Australian Alps to the coast crossed the Principal Inland Road, which ran from Sydney to Albury. The area surrounding Wingello is home to numerous pine plantations. The town itself has a few small shops and a hotel. Just north of the town is the start of the Wingello State Forest. The Wingello State Forest is a large pine tree plantation that is used for harvesting timber. It is the largest plantation in Australia, covering an area of 24,200 hectares (59,000 acres). The forest is managed by the New South Wales Department of Environment and Conservation. The forest is a popular location for mountain biking, trail running, and horse riding. It is also a popular destination for campers and bushwalkers. The Hume Highway passes through the forest, and there are several picnic areas and rest stops located along the highway. The forest is home to a variety of native animals, including wombats, wallabies, and lyrebirds. It is also a haven for birdwatchers, as it is home to numerous bird species, including the yellow-tailed black cockatoo and the powerful owl.

The 4th Canadian Film Awards were presented on April 29, 1952 to honour achievements in Canadian cinema in 1951. The ceremony was hosted by Lorne Greene, and the broadcasting company CBC provided a live television broadcast of the event. The biggest winner of the night was the film Appointment with Danger, which took home the Golden Reel Award for being the year's most popular Canadian film, as well as the awards for Best Actor (James Doohan), Best Actress (Maureen Fitzgerald), Best Supporting Actor (Leslie Neilsen), Best Supporting Actress (Dixie Deane), Best B&W Film, and Best Director. Other winners included the documentary Quebec, which won Best Documentary; the musical revue stage show The Bob Hope Show, which won Best Musical; and the short drama film The Man Who Lives Next Door, which won Best Short. The National Film Awards were presented for the first time, with the National Film Board of Canada's documentary film The Great Discoveries winning the award for the Best Non-Feature Film. The Canadian Film Awards were not presented in 1950 due to a strike by film technicians. As a result, the 4th Canadian Film Awards are also considered to be the awards for 1950.

Bruce Almighty is a 2003 American comedy film directed by Tom Shadyac and written by Steve Oedekerk, based on the 1999 Saturday Night Live sketch of the same name. The film stars Jim Carrey as Bruce Nolan, a TV reporter who is frustrated at having to report on celebrity gossip instead of real news, and is granted the ability to become God for one week. The film also stars Jennifer Aniston, Philip Baker Hall, and Morgan Freeman. The film was released in the United States on June 15, 2003, and received mixed reviews from critics, earning $67.4 million in the United States and $186.3 million worldwide (from a budget of $81 million) with Jim Carrey receiving nominations for an Academy Award and Golden Globe Award for his performance. Bruce Nolan is a television reporter in Buffalo, New York who is frustrated at having to report on celebrity gossip instead of real news. After accidentally receiving a pager message intended for "God," Bruce impulsively wishes that he was God for one week. The next morning, he discovers that he has been granted the ability to become God for one week. After an initially light-hearted start, Bruce becomes overwhelmed by his new powers and their responsibilities and begins to realize that his actions have consequences. At first, Bruce uses his powers to play pranks on his friends and acquaintances, but soon finds that he has become a celebrity. He is accosted by people asking for favors, including his girlfriend, Grace Connelly, who wants him to heal her sick father. Although initially reluctant, he eventually heals Mr. Connelly, who is grateful and asks Bruce to use his powers for good. After using his powers to help people, including healing the sick and disabled, creating food and wine showers, and providing people with their heart's desire, Bruce becomes frustrated when he cannot find a way to end world hunger. He eventually realizes that the world's religions, despite their differences, are all working toward the same goal of getting people to be good. When the week is over, Bruce becomes God permanently. However, he decides to keep it secret and return to his old life, and continues to use his powers to help people quietly.

Ural Republic The Ural Republic (in Russian: Урал Республики) was a short-lived republic within the Russian SFSR, which existed in December 1918 through March 1922. Its capital was briefly based in Ekaterinburg, but was eventually moved to longitudinal position 51° 35' 14" north, the same as the modern-day Ural Republic. The idea of a separate Ural state appeared in the early 20th century, when the Urals region began to be more heavily populated and industrialize. The region's rich mineral resources, including deposits of oil, natural gas, coal, and metals, promised the region great prosperity. After the Russian Revolution in 1917, the Ural region was part of the Siberian Republic, which was merged into the RSFSR in late 1917. In May 1918, the Siberian Republic was reestablished as a separate entity within the RSFSR. The Ural region was given special status within the Siberian Republic, with the right to its own legislative and executive bodies. In September 1918, the Siberian Republic was again merged into the RSFSR. The next month, the Catherine II Region was established in the Ural region as a separate entity within the RSFSR. In December 1918, the Urals Republic was established, which included the Catherine II Region and the western part of the Tobolsk Region, which was later incorporated into the RSFSR from Siberia. In March 1919, the Perm Territory was transferred from Siberia to the Urals Republic. In June 1919, the Siberian Republic was again separated from the RSFSR, and in November 1919, it was re-merged into the RSFSR. After that, the Urals Republic remained the only separate federal subject within the RSFSR, until its disestablishment in March 1922. On December 12, 1918, the First All-Ural Congress of Soviets was held in Ekaterinburg, where the Constitution of the Urals Republic was adopted. The congress elected a regional government, the Extraordinary Executive Committee, and a regional executive committee. Alexander Beloborodov was elected chairman of the Extraordinary Executive Committee. The Extraordinary Executive Committee was responsible for the economic transformation of the region, while the regional executive committee was responsible for the political and military administration. In May 1919, the Second All-Ural Congress of Soviets was held in Ekaterinburg. The congress elected a new regional government, the Extraordinary Executive Committee, and a regional executive committee. The new regional executive committee was headed by Alexander Beloborodov, who was also elected chairman of the Extraordinary Executive Committee. In December 1919, the Third All-Ural Congress of Soviets was held in Ekaterinburg. The congress elected a new regional government, the Extraordinary Executive Committee, and a regional executive committee. The regional executive committee was headed by Alexander Beloborodov, who was also elected chairman of the Extraordinary Executive Committee. In February 1920, the Fourth All-Ural Congress of Soviets was held in Ekaterinburg. The congress elected a new regional government, the Extraordinary Executive Committee, and a regional executive committee. The regional executive committee was headed by Alexander Beloborodov, who was also elected chairman of the Extraordinary Executive Committee. In June 1921, the Fifth All-Ural Congress of Soviets was held in Ekaterinburg. The congress elected a new regional government, the Extraordinary Executive Committee, and a regional executive committee. The regional executive committee was headed by Alexander Beloborodov, who was also elected chairman of the Extraordinary Executive Committee. In March 1922, the Sixth All-Ural Congress of Soviets was held in Ekaterinburg. The congress elected a new regional government, the Extraordinary Executive Committee, and a regional executive committee. The regional executive committee was headed by Alexander Beloborodov, who was also elected chairman of the Extraordinary Executive Committee. On March 20, 1922, the RSFSR and the Urals Republic were abolished, and their territories were incorporated into the USSR. The Extraordinary Executive Committee was transformed into the Extraordinary Commission of the USSR, and the regional executive committee was transformed into the Regional Council of the USSR.

Formula F100 Formula F100 is a form of open-wheel formula car racing designed and built by Formula One Group to introduce drivers to the mechanics and handling of open-wheel racing cars. The series is managed by the same group that manages the FIA Formula One World Championship. The car is a monocoque chassis with a 4-stroke engine in the back, with the driver sitting in the front. The series is organised as a support series to the FIA Formula One World Championship and the cars are built to the same technical regulations as the F1 cars, although the performance is limited by a rev limit of 7200 rpm. The F100 cars are built to F1 safety standards, using the same construction methods and materials. The series is open to drivers with no prior open-wheel experience as well as those with prior open-wheel experience. The series is often used as a stepping stone to other open-wheel series, such as the GP2 Series or the FIA Formula One World Championship. The series has had different names since its inception. It was originally called the Formula One Junior Series, then the Formula One Sophomore Series, before being renamed as the Formula One Academy Series in 2008. The series was then renamed as the Formula One Reserve Series in 2011, before being renamed as the Formula One Development Series in 2015. The series was then renamed as the Formula One Feeder Series in 2016, before being renamed as the Formula F100 in 2020. The series has had different rules since its inception. It was originally a single-seater series, with the drivers racing against each other on a track. In 2015, the series was changed to a sprint race format, with the drivers racing against each other on a track with a single-seater car. In 2016, the series was changed to a touring car format, with the drivers racing against each other on a track with a touring car. The series has had different cars since its inception. It was originally raced with the Formula One Junior Car, which was a single-seater racing car. In 2015, the series was changed to a sprint race format, with the drivers racing with a Formula One Car, which is a single-seater racing car. In 2016, the series was changed to a touring car format, with the drivers racing with a touring car. The series has had different engines since its inception. It was originally raced with the Formula One Junior Engine, which was a naturally aspirated 3.5-litre V8 engine. In 2015, the series was changed to a sprint race format, with the drivers racing with a Formula One Engine, which is a turbocharged 1.6-litre V6 hybrid engine. In 2016, the series was changed to a touring car format, with the drivers racing with a touring car engine. The series has had different tyres since its inception. It was originally raced with the Formula One Junior Tyre, which was a slick tyre. In 2015, the series was changed to a sprint race format, with the drivers racing with a Formula One Tyre, which is a slick tyre. In 2016, the series was changed to a touring car format, with the drivers racing with a touring car tyre.

The Bank of Springfield Center is a 10,000-seat multi-purpose arena in Springfield, Illinois. The arena is the home of the Illinois State Redbirds of Illinois State University, the Springfield Jr. Blues of the North American Hockey League, and the former home of the Illinois Knights of the Indoor Football League, the latter of which folded in 2014. The center was built in 1983 as a regional events and entertainment complex. In 2007, the Illinois State University Foundation purchased the facility from the Illinois State Fairgrounds Foundation and subsequently signed a 40-year lease with the university. The foundation has embarked on a $5 million capital campaign to fund renovations to the complex. In 2008, the center was the host of the Illinois High School Association boys' basketball state championship tournament. The tournament returned to the Bank of Springfield Center in 2010 and has been played there every year since. The Illinois State Redbirds men's basketball team has played at the Bank of Springfield Center since 1983. The Redbirds had previously played at the Illinois State Gym on campus in Normal. The team has a winning percentage of .709 at the Bank of Springfield Center, including a perfect 14-0 record in 2008–09, and has won five of its eight Division I NCAA basketball tournaments at the venue, most recently in 1998. The Redbirds have a record of 86-37 in the Missouri Valley Conference tournament at the Bank of Springfield Center, including four conference tournament titles in nine years between 1988 and 1996. The Illinois State Redbirds women's basketball team has played at the Bank of Springfield Center since 1983. The Springfield Jr. Blues of the North American Hockey League have played at the Bank of Springfield Center since 1984. The Jr. Blues had previously played at the Nelson Center in Springfield. The Illinois Knights of the Indoor Football League played at the Bank of Springfield Center from 2007 to 2014, when the team folded. The Bank of Springfield Center has also hosted concerts, trade shows, and other events.

Alan Schoen (March 23, 1917 – October 18, 2013) was an American composer, music educator, and author. Schoen was born in New York, New York in 1917. He studied composition with Nadia Boulanger at the Nadia Boulanger School in Paris, France (1937–38), and with Arnold Schoenberg at the University of California, Los Angeles (1938–39). He also studied piano with Boulanger and Robert Dussaut. From 1939 to 1946, Schoen was an instructor in music at the University of California, Los Angeles. From 1946 to 1947, he was a professor at the University of Washington. From 1947 to 1950, he was an associate professor at the University of Michigan. From 1950 to 1951, he was a professor at the University of Illinois. From 1951 to 1953, he was an associate professor at the University of Washington. From 1953 to 1960, he was a professor at the University of Michigan. From 1960 to 1961, he was an associate professor at the University of Washington. From 1961 to 1966, he was a professor at the University of Hawaii. From 1966 to 1968, he was an associate professor at the University of Washington. From 1968 to 1970, he was a professor at the California State College, Los Angeles. From 1970 to 1976, he was an associate professor at the University of Washington. From 1976 to 1980, he was a professor at the San Francisco State University. Schoen was the author of the book Contemporary Music:Resources and Reactions (1971). Schoen died in October 2013, at the age of 96.

Colonial Forge High School is a public high school in the community of Stafford, Virginia, United States, and is part of the Stafford County Public Schools division. The school's first group of freshman students graduated in 1986, and the school has been adding a class each year since. The school's current enrollment is approximately 2,100 students. The school was built in 1983 on a 72-acre (29 ha) site which was previously the location of a housing subdivision and an 18-hole golf course. The school's two-story, red brick building features a main lobby with a large staircase and a 1,200-seat auditorium. The school also has a greenhouse, a courtyard, and a large field used for multiple purposes. In addition to serving the students of Stafford, Colonial Forge also accepts students from other jurisdictions, including West Potomac High School in Alexandria, Virginia, and Washington-Lee High School in Arlington, Virginia. The majority of the school's students are from Stafford County, with the remainder coming from the City of Alexandria and the District of Columbia. The school's sports teams are known as the "Colonials" and the school colors are red, white, and blue. The school's main rival is Brooke Point High School.

Sheikh Aftab Ahmed (Urdu: شيخ افتاب احمد‎; born 1 January 1945) is a Pakistani politician who has been a member of the National Assembly of Pakistan since August 2018. He was born in the village of Daultala, in the city of Jhang, Punjab, Pakistan. He is the brother of Sheikh Azhar Ahmed, who was a member of the National Assembly of Pakistan from 2002 to 2007. Aftab Ahmed's father, Sheikh Abdul Hafeez Khan, was a member of the National Assembly of Pakistan from 1985 to 1988. Aftab Ahmed is a member of the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI). He was elected to the National Assembly of Pakistan from Constituency 95 (Jhang) as a PTI candidate in the 2018 Pakistani general election. He received 75,8831 votes and defeated Pakistan Muslim League (N) candidate Rai Muhammad Murtaza who received 59,8858 votes. In August 2018, he was appointed as the chairman of the National Assembly's Standing Committee on Defence Production. In September 2018, he was made the chairman of the National Assembly's Standing Committee on Power.

Garhshankar Garhshankar is a town and a municipal council in Punjab, India. It is located 16 kilometres (10 mi) from the city of Hoshiarpur, on the Hoshiarpur-Jalandhar road. The area is surrounded by the Shivalik ranges. Garhshankar is the birthplace of the freedom fighter Bhagat Singh. There is a memorial dedicated to him in the town, where his ashes were scattered. Every year, on 23rd of March, a function is organised in the town to commemorate Bhagat Singh. The town is also known for the Shivalik Institute of Dental Sciences, which is one of the best dental colleges in the state. The college is affiliated with the Baba Farid University of Health Sciences, Faridkot. Garhshankar also has a civil hospital, which is the largest in the district. The town has two police stations and a bus stand. The town has a large market, which is the centre of trade in the area. A number of banks have their branches in the town, including the State Bank of India, the Punjab National Bank, the HDFC Bank, the ICICI Bank and the Axis Bank. The nearest airport is in Ludhiana, which is 100 kilometres (60 mi) away. The nearest railway station is in Hoshiarpur.

Navy Special Action Regiment (Italian: Reggimento Speciale di Azione Navale, RSA) is the special forces unit of the Italian Navy, and was created in 2010 by the merger of the Comando Raggruppamento Subacquei e Incursori Teseo Tesei (COMSUBIN) and the Gruppo Operativo Incursori (GOI). The unit is headed by a Colonel. The RSA is the main special force of the Italian Navy, and is specialized in sea-air-land special operations, deep ground penetration, direct action, special reconnaissance, unconventional warfare, and special missions. The RSA is one of the four special forces units of the Italian Armed Forces, the other three being the Army's Paratroopers Brigade and the 4th and 9th Psychological Operations Groups, and the Air Force's 17th Wing. The RSA has a strength of about 1,800 personnel, divided into ten companies, and is based in the San Marco Marine Barracks in Venice. The unit's companies are spread throughout Italy, and are tasked with both special operations and coastal surveillance. The RSA also includes a training company, which is responsible for the training of both new recruits and special operators, and a support company, which provides logistics, medical, and communications support to the unit. The RSA's missions include: * unconventional warfare and special reconnaissance behind enemy lines; * direct action against enemy targets, including personnel, vehicles, and infrastructure; * coastal surveillance and special protection of strategic assets; * search and rescue; * assistance to civilians in emergency situations; and * support to other military units in combat operations. The RSA is one of the most highly trained and specialized units in the Italian Military, and is known for its ability to operate in a wide range of environments, including the sea, air, and land. The RSA's training is some of the most rigorous in the world, and includes a long selection process, as well as specialized training in a variety of skills, such as combat swimming, small unit tactics, and special reconnaissance. The RSA is equipped with some of the most advanced military technology, including a variety of weapons and equipment specifically designed for special operations. The RSA's primary weapon is the HK416, a German-made assault rifle, but the unit also uses a variety of other weapons, including pistols, shotguns, and sniper rifles. The RSA's equipment includes a variety of specialized gear, such as diving and respiratory gear, night-vision and thermal imaging devices, and communications equipment.

Alfie Moon is a fictional character from the BBC soap opera EastEnders, played by David Alfie Moon. The character was introduced in June 2002, as a school friend of Darren Miller (Charlie G. Hawkins), and became a full-time regular in 2004. In 2007, the character was paired with the newly introduced Kat Slater (Danyella Frost). Alfie is described as "a bit of a wide boy" and "a wheeler-dealer". His main storylines have revolved around his relationships with Kat, and his best friend Darren. In 2010, Alfie began dating mechanic Mo Harris (Laila Morse), and the couple got engaged in January 2012. They married in September 2013, and in October 2015, Alfie revealed to Mo that he had been unfaithful, and they separated. In 2016, Alfie began a relationship with his former flame Kat, and they married in February 2017. In January 2018, the character was killed off, when he was murdered by his stepson Hunter Owen (Charlie Winter) after discovering that he was having an affair with his wife. Alfie has been involved in several prominent storylines. In 2002, he was attacked by a gang of boys, and his best friend Darren was accused of the crime. In 2003, he was the getaway driver in a robbery that went wrong, and he was arrested and charged with armed robbery. He was found not guilty in court, but his reputation was ruined. In 2007, he was framed for the murder of his stepson, and went on the run. In 2008, he was implicated in a money-laundering scandal involving his stepbrother and business partner, James Moon (Michael telescope). In 2009, he discovered that his wife had been lying to him about her past, and had been in prison. In 2010, his stepbrother James was killed in a car crash, and he inherited James' estate, including The Queen Victoria pub. In 2012, he discovered that his wife had been lying to him about her relationship with his best friend, Darren. In 2014, he discovered that his wife was having an affair with his friend Ben Mitchell (James Clube). In 2015, he was attacked by a gang of boys, who were bullying his stepson. In 2016, he was punched by Ben Mitchell's half-brother, Phil Mitchell (Steve McFadden), after he discovered that Alfie was having an affair with his wife. In 2017, he was confronted by his stepson, Hunter, who accused him of having an affair with his wife. In 2018, he was murdered by Hunter, who discovered that Alfie was having an affair with his wife.

Mortal Kombat (comics) Mortal Kombat is a franchise of comic books based on the video game series of the same name by Midway Games. The series was published by DC Comics under the DC Black Label imprint beginning in 2015, and is written by Mortal Kombat co- creator and DC Comics writer Paul Tieinylaunched with a four-issue limited series simply titled Mortal Kombat, the series received a three-issue limited series sequel, Blood Ties, in 2016, and a six-issue limited series, Klassic MK, in 2017. A fourth limited series, MK: Blood & Thunder, was announced in 2017 and launched in 2018. The series is set in the same fictional universe as the video game series, and thus far has been limited to the events that occur in the first three games in the series; MK, MK II, and MK III, with Blood & Thunder covering the events between MK II and MK III. The 2009–10 San Jose State Spartans men's basketball team represented San Jose State University during the 2009–10 NCAA Division I men's basketball season. The Spartans, led by third year head coach George Nessman, played their home games at the Event Center Arena and were a member of the Western Athletic Conference. They finished the season 16–17, 9–7 in WAC play to finish in a tie for fourth place. They were invited to the 2010 CollegeInsider.com Tournament where they lost in the first round. San Jose State was picked to finish last in the WAC preseason media poll, but the Spartans surprised many experts by finishing with a 9–7 conference record, including home wins over Seattle and New Mexico State, both of which were ranked in the top 25 at the time. The Spartans also defeated #3 seed Utah State in the 2010 WAC Tournament before losing to #1 seed Nevada in the semifinals. The Spartans earned a berth in the 2010 CollegeInsider.com Tournament, their first postseason appearance since 1996, but lost in the first round to San Francisco.

Nikifor Chernigovsky (Никифо́р Черни́говский) (February 16 [O.S. February 4] 1898 – June 7, 1973) was a Soviet and Russian writer, poet, and playwright, the author of many popular songs and poetry collections for children. Chernigovsky was born in Odessa, Russian Empire (now Ukraine), into a Jewish family. His father, an employee of the Odessa city duma, was killed by the Bolsheviks in the Russian Civil War. His mother, a housewife, was left to raise three children on her own. After finishing school, Chernigovsky worked as a teacher for a few years, then as an actor in a travelling theater, and finally as a journalist in Odessa. Chernigovsky's first poems were published in 1925. His first collection of poems, The Path of the Sun, was published in 1927. In 1929, he moved to Moscow, where he became involved with the literary group Pereval. His poems were praised by the prominent poets of the time, such as Samuil Marshak and Nikolay Tikhonov. During the 1930s, he was a member of the editorial board for the children's magazine Murzilka. Chernigovsky's works were prohibited for a time in the Soviet Union after the Start publishing house, which had published his poetry collection The Magic Lantern, was closed down. He was allowed to publish his works again in the late 1940s. In 1952, he was awarded the State Prize of the USSR for his collection of poems for children The Magic Lantern. Chernigovsky died in Moscow in 1973. He was buried in the Vvedenskoye Cemetery.

Jacinto Caamaño Arriagada (May 10, 1825 – June 7, 1881) was a Chilean soldier and politician, who served as minister of war during part of the War of the Confederation, and as senator for life since 1878. Caamaño was born in Santiago, where he also completed his first studies. In 1840 he entered the Military Academy, and four years later he joined the army with the rank of second lieutenant. He took part in the battle of Yungay, during the war against the Peru-Bolivian Confederacy. In 1847 he was promoted to the rank of captain, and in 1848 he was sent to Rome as a member of the delegation that was to negotiate the purchase of arms and ammunition. In 1850 he became a major, and during the 1851 revolution he was in charge of the defense of Santiago. After the defeat of the revolution, Caamaño was arrested and sentenced to death, but the sentence was later commuted to exile in Europe. He returned to Chile in 1855, and was promoted to the rank of colonel. During the battle of Loncomilla, in the 1851 revolution, Caamaño distinguished himself by his bravery and was decorated. In 1868 he was promoted to the rank of general. Caamaño was a member of the Chamber of Deputies, and during part of the War of the Confederation he was minister of war, being in charge of the army during the battle of Loncomilla, in the year 1870. After the war, he was named senator for life, a position he held until his death. He was also appointed minister of war and marine, a position he held until his death.

Pakistan at the Asian Games The Pakistan national Olympic committee has been participating in the Asian Games since the 1954 Asian Games in Manila, Philippines, although the nation's first involvement in the Games dates back to the 1934 Asian Games in Delhi, India, when a single athlete from the state of Punjab competed in the men's wrestling event. The 1954 Asian Games marked Pakistan's first major participation in the continent's premier multi-sport event, with a contingent of 19 athletes (all men) in three sports: athletics, swimming, and wrestling. Alec Asher (born 18 September 1982) is an English actor. Asher was born in Portsmouth, Hampshire, and attended the Portsmouth Academy. He has appeared in a number of television series, including The Bill, Holby City, EastEnders, and Mr. Bean. His film work includes the role of Ben in Tom & Jerry: The Movie, while his other voice work includes the video game Fable II, in which he voiced the character Ben Finn. In 2008, Asher appeared as the lead in the British horror film The Disappeared, and had a supporting role in the BBC's television film The Unloved. He also had a supporting role in the film The Hottie & the Nottie, starring Julia Roberts and Geena Davis. In 2011, Asher appeared in the British horror film 30 Days of Night: Dark Days, and had a supporting role in the action thriller film The Mechanic. He also appeared as a recurring character in the BBC's television series Outcasts. In 2013, Asher appeared as the lead in the British horror film The Borderlands, and had a supporting role in the action thriller film Rush.

Native Dancer Native Dancer (born January 1, 1961, in Kentucky) is an American thoroughbred race horse. He was the first American-bred horse to win the English Derby in over 30 years, since the great Nijinsky II in 1970. Native Dancer was sired by the great Native Tom, who was a half-brother to the legendary Man o' War. His dam was the equally great La Troienne, making him a third-generation horse of tremendous stamina and class. He was bred and owned by Alfred G. Vanderbilt II, and trained by William L. Curtis. At age two, Native Dancer won the East View Stakes at Aqueduct, the National Stallion Stakes at Washington Park, and the Remsen Stakes at Aqueduct. At age three, he won the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct, the Santa Anita Derby, the Derby Trial Stakes at Churchill Downs, and the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland. At age four, Native Dancer won the Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct, the Metropolitan Handicap at Belmont, the Woodward Stakes at Aqueduct, and the Jockey Club Gold Cup at Aqueduct. In total, Native Dancer won 21 races, including nine stakes victories. He was never out of the money in his career, with 27 top three finishes in 36 starts. Native Dancer was the 1961 Eclipse Award for Horse of the Year winner. He was also the 1961 Champion Older Male, the 1962 Champion Older Male, and the 1963 Champion Older Male. In the 1961 Kentucky Derby, he finished second to the ill-fated riderless1961 Derby winner, Calvin Borel. In the Travers Stakes at Saratoga that year, he lost by a nose to the great Ridan. After his retirement from racing, he entered stud at his owner's Sagamore Farm in Maryland. Among his notable offspring were Native Tom (born 1964, winner of the Eclipse Award for Outstanding Juvenile Male in 1966), Fountain of Youth (born 1966, sire of A.P. Indy), and Almoner (born 1967, sire of Easy Goer).

Bourgeois Government The Bourgeois Government was the executive organ of the Austrian part of the Holy Roman Empire. The office of the Bourgeois Government was located in the Hofburg Palace in Vienna. The term "Bourgeois" refers to the members of the Imperial Diet of the Holy Roman Empire, which was composed of the representatives of the Imperial States, and not to the citizens of the Imperial City of Vienna, which was the seat of the Hofburg Palace. The Bourgeois Government was composed of the following offices: The Chancellor, who was the head of the government and was also in charge of the Imperial Chancery, which was the Imperial Court's administrative office. The Vice-Chancellor, who was the head of the Chancery of the Imperial Diet (Reichshofrat). The Secret Chancellor, who was the head of the Secret Chancery, which was in charge of the Imperial Court's secret affairs. The Treasurer, who was the head of the Imperial Treasury. The Vice-Treasurer. The Chief Marshal, who was the head of the Imperial Court's household. The Vice-Chief Marshal. The Master of the Stables. The Court Surgeon. The Court Apothecary. The Chief Architect. The Chief Engineer. The Empress' Chief Lady-in-waiting. The Emperor's Chief Secretary. The Empress' Household. The Emperor's Household.

The album's title track, "Jashn", was a major hit, and the album's other songs, including "Dupatte" and "Sajni", were also popular. The album's title track, "Ho Jaye Muqaddar", was a major hit, and the album's other songs, including "Dupatte" and "Sajni", were also popular. In 2013, Nadir Ali Khan released his sixth album, Best of Nadir Ali Khan, which was a critical and commercial success. The album's title track, "Best of Nadir Ali Khan", was a major hit, and the album's other songs, including "Dupatte" and "Sajni", were also popular. In 2016, Nadir Ali Khan released his seventh album, Golden Voice of Nadir Ali Khan, which was a critical and commercial success. Snowfall (TV series) Snowfall is a TV series that premiered on July 19, 2017, on FX. The series was cancelled after the third season, with the final episode airing on August 11, 2020. The series is set in Los Angeles in 1983, against the backdrop of the crack cocaine epidemic, and follows the story of Franklin Saint, a young street soldier who is determined to make a name for himself in the drug game. The series is produced by John Singleton, Thomas Carter, and Frank Catton. The series is based on the Snowfall podcast by Sam Esmail and Ross Finman, who both serve as executive producers on the series. The series stars Damson Idris as Franklin Saint, Carter Hudson as WASP, and Michael Hyatt as the Afghan. The series premiered on July 19, 2017, on FX. Mireille Soria (born 20 March 1989) is a French professional footballer who plays as a midfielder for French club Paris FC and the France national team. Soria began her professional career at French club FCF Lyon in 2006, before signing with Norwegian club Toppserien side Røa IL in 2009. She stayed with the club for three years, winning the Toppserien league title in 2010 and 2011, as well as the Norwegian Women's Cup in 2010. In 2012, Soria returned to France to play for Division 1 Féminine club Paris Saint-Germain. With the club, she won the league title in 2013 and 2015, as well as the Coupe de France in 2015. In 2016, she joined fellow Division 1 Féminine club Olympique Lyonnais. Soria has also played for the France national team since 2010, making her debut in the 2010 Cyprus Women's Cup. Soria was born in Lyon, France. She began her youth career at FC Lyon in 2001, and graduated from the club's youth academy in 2006. Soria made her debut for the club in the 2006–07 season, and appeared in nine matches. She became a regular starter for the club in the 2007–08 season, appearing in 21 matches and scoring four goals. In the 2008–09 season, she appeared in all 22 league matches and scored seven goals, as the club finished in second place in the Division 1 Féminine. In 2009, Soria signed with Toppserien side Røa IL. She made her debut for the club on 14 June 2009 in a 1–0 win over Sunnyda. She appeared in all 22 league matches in her first season, as the club finished in third place in the Toppserien. She also appeared in all five matches as the club won the Norwegian Women's Cup. In 2010, she appeared in all 21 league matches as the club won the Toppserien. She also appeared in all six matches as the club won the Norwegian Women's Cup. In 2011, she appeared in all 22 league matches as the club finished in second place in the Toppserien. She also appeared in all five matches as the club reached the semifinal of the Norwegian Women's Cup. In 2012, Soria returned to France to play for Division 1 Féminine club Paris Saint-Germain. She made her debut for the club on 11 September 2012 in a 0–0 draw with Lille. She appeared in 17 league matches in her first season, as the club finished in second place in the Division 1 Féminine. She also appeared in all five matches as the club won the Coupe de la Division Féministe. In 2013, she appeared in all 22 league matches as the club won the Division 1 Féminine. She also appeared in all three matches as the club won the Coupe de France. In 2015, Soria appeared in all 22 league matches as the club won the Division 1 Féminine. She also appeared in all three matches as the club won the Coupe de France. In 2016, Soria joined fellow Division 1 Féminine club Olympique Lyonnais. She made her debut for the club on 15 September 2016 in a 1–0 win over Bordeaux. She appeared in all 22 league matches in her first season, as the club won the Division 1 Féminine. She also appeared in all four matches as the club won the Coupe de la Division Féministe. Soria has also played for the France national team since 2010, making her debut in the 2010 Cyprus Women's Cup. She appeared in all five matches as the team won the Cyprus Women's Cup. She also appeared in all five matches as the team won the 2011 Cyprus Women's Cup. She scored her first international goal on 3 March 2015 in a 2–1 win over England in the 2015 Cyprus Women's Cup.

Latha Rajinikanth (born 26 October 1954) is an Indian film playback singer and carnatic vocalist, who has predominantly worked in the Tamil film industry. She is the wife of the actor Rajinikanth and is the mother of the actress Soundarya Rajinikanth. Latha was born in a Tamil family in the state of Karnataka, to a father working in the Indian Air Force and a mother working in the Intelligence Bureau. She was brought up in Delhi, where she did her schooling at the Baldwin Girls High School, and then moved to Madras (now Chennai) to pursue her passion for music. She studied at the Government College of Fine Arts, Chennai, where she learnt carnatic music, and also received training in Hindustani music. Latha began her career as a singer in the 1980s, and has since sung over 500 songs in films in Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, Hindi, and Kannada. Her first song was "Chalo Chalo", which she sang for the Tamil film Puthu Paatu (1983), and her first Hindi film was Woh 7 Din (1983), in which she sang "Bujjhu Bujjhu Paapii" for the music by Anu Malik. Some of her most memorable songs include "Vennira Iravgal" from the Tamil film Citizen (2001), "Nenje Nenje" from the Tamil film Friends (2001), and "Chalo Chalo" from the Telugu film Justice Chalo (2002). In addition to her work as a playback singer, Latha has also released her own albums, including the carnatic album Sri Manavala Maamani (1995), the Christmas album Christ the Saviour (1998), and the inspirational album Nada Nada (2006).

List of people executed in New York New York has had three different methods of execution: hanging, electrocution, and lethal injection. The state has executed 35 people since 1608, including 14 who were electrocuted and 3 who were executed in the electric chair. On August 15, 2013, New York's legislature voted to repeal the state's death penalty. Governor Andrew Cuomo signed the bill into law on August 23, 2013, making New York the 23rd state to repeal the death penalty since 1976. The death penalty was officially repealed on October 24, 2014, when the law was published in the New York State Register. This list contains people who were executed in New York.
