Razumovskiy Palace (Baturyn) Razumovskiy Palace (Baturyn) is an architectural landmark of the city of Kyiv, Ukraine. The palace is located in Baturyn, a historic neighborhood of Kyiv. The palace was built in the XVIII century for the Prince of the Holy Roman Empire and the Grand Duke of Lithuania Michael Razumovsky (1723–1780) by the famous architect Francisco de Rastrell. The design of the palace is based on the principles of classicism. The palace has two floors and is built of brick. The front of the palace is decorated with a six-column portico. In the lower part there are bedrooms, a dining room, and a large hall. The upper floor consists of four reception rooms and a large dance hall. The interiors of the palace were decorated by prominent architects and artists of the time. In 1775, the palace was visited by the Russian empress Catherine II. In 1778, the palace was purchased by Prince Ivan Fedorovich Potemkin (1739–1791) for his son, Prince Alexander Alexandrovich Potemkin (1766–1793), who lived there with his wife, Princess Alexandra Ilarionovna Dologorukova (1769–1833), until his death in 1793. After that, the palace was inherited by Princess Dologorukova. In 1804, the palace was visited by the Russian emperor Alexander I. In 1821, the palace was purchased by the Russian prince and the future emperor Michael Nicholas Pavlovich (1782–1845), the son of the famous Russian general and the future emperor Nicholas Pavlovitch (1754–1801), who lived there with his wife, the Russian princess Yelizaveta Grigorievna (1784–1857). In 1834, the palace was visited by the Russian emperor Nicholas I. In 1911, the palace was bought by the Ukrainian manufacturer and philanthropist myeloradovych directors of the Kyiv Theological Academy and Seminary, where they opened a religious school. During the Soviet era, the palace was used as a training school for dancers. In 2014, the palace was visited by the Russian president Vladimir Putin.

Heinrich Wilhelm Richter (31 January 1896 – 18 November 1961) was a general in the Wehrmacht of Nazi Germany during World War II who commanded the 90th Light Infantry Division. He was a recipient of the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves. Richter was born in 1896 in Danzig, at the time a German city in the German Empire. After the war he worked in the leather industry. Richter joined the army of the German Empire in 1915 and served in the 4th Foot Artillery Regiment. He fought in the First World War and was wounded. After the war he joined the police force in the Free City of Danzig. In 1939 he joined the newly formed Wehrmacht and was assigned to the 1st Light Infantry Brigade. After the Battle of France, Richter served with the 90th Light Infantry Division and was appointed its commander in October 1942. The division was sent to the Eastern Front where it was involved in the fight against the Red Army. In January 1943, Richter was awarded the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves for his leadership of the division. In September 1944, the division was withdrawn from the front and returned to Germany where it was used to fight against the advancing Allied forces. After the war, Richter worked in the leather industry. He died in 1961 in Ludwigsburg.

The Migrants' Rights Network (MRN) is a registered charity based in London, UK. It was established in 2002 by a group of migrants' rights activists and practitioners who were concerned that the UK Government was failing to protect migrants' rights. The Network's primary aim is to support the development of migrants' rights in the UK and to promote the principle of equality and justice for all. The MRN also works to raise awareness of the UK's obligations under international human rights law to protect migrants' rights. The MRN's work includes: advocacy and lobbying work with policy makers and civil society organisations to promote the implementation of migrants' rights; research and policy work to inform the development of migrants' rights policy in the UK and internationally; capacity building and training for migrants' rights activists and practitioners to enable them to better advocate for migrants' rights; and engaging in direct support and representation of migrants' rights defenders and practitioners through the provision of grants, scholarships and other support. The MRN's work is informed by its belief that migrants' rights are a key component of the broader struggle for human rights and social justice. The MRN works closely with civil society organisations, academics, and other stakeholders to promote the implementation of migrants' rights in the UK and internationally. It also works with migrants' rights defenders and practitioners to support their work and to raise awareness of the importance of migrants' rights.

Scott Perry (politician) Scott Perry (born August 8, 1958) is an American politician and member of the Republican Party who has served as the U.S. representative for Pennsylvania's 10th congressional district since 2013. He served as the U.S. representative for Pennsylvania's 3rd congressional district from 2011 to 2013. Perry's district includes all of Dauphin County, parts of Cumberland County, and a small portion of York County. In November 2018, Perry was re-elected to his third term, defeating Democratic nominee George Scott with 60.2% of the vote. In 2020, Perry was re-elected to his fourth term, defeating Democratic nominee Alisha Thomas Morgan with 58.4% of the vote. Perry is a member of the National Republican Congressional Committee's (NRCC) "Young Guns" program. He was one of the first Republicans to support Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election. He is a former member of the Tea Party movement. Perry was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 2010, defeating Democratic incumbent Charlie Wilson with 55.9% of the vote. He was sworn in as a member of the 112th United States Congress on January 5, 2011. After representing the 3rd district for two years, he redistricted to the 10th district, where he was sworn in on January 3, 2013. In 2013, Perry voted to defund the Affordable Care Act (ACA, known as Obamacare). In 2014, he introduced the pH Solutions Act, a bill that would require federal agencies to consider off-label uses of drugs. In 2015, he introduced the Social Security Fairness Act, a bill that would prevent the use of Social Security benefits in calculations for means-tested programs. In 2015, he was named to the House Committee on Energy and Commerce. In 2018, he was named to the House Appropriations Committee. Perry's first wife, Mary, died of breast cancer in 2002. He has three children. He is a graduate of Shippensburg University.

Baddiel and Skinner Unplanned is a British television programme that was produced by Graham Stuart for BBC Choice and BBC One. It was presented by David Baddiel and his friend and flatmate Frank Skinner, both of whom were at the time best known for their work on the BBC's top-rated alternative comedy show, Fantasy Football League. The show was filmed in a similar documentary style to the earlier show, and was originally broadcast on BBC Choice, the BBC's then-new digital television channel, in 1998. It was shown on BBC One the following year. Unplanned was recorded in a similar fashion to the earlier show, with Baddiel and Skinner ad-libbing in front of a live studio audience, with some material written beforehand. Many of the sketches were based on contemporary news stories. The show also featured some of the pair's excursions, such as a trip to Las Vegas, and a journey across the Sahara Desert. The series ran for two series, with the second series featuring a live episode, and an episode where each of the pair was sent to a different country (Baddiel in South Africa, and Skinner in Israel). The show has never been repeated, although some clips have been shown on other shows.

Kevola Observatory Kevola Observatory (Kevola-tieteenkeskus, previously known as the Finnish Geodetic Institute and the National Land Survey Institute of Finland) is a research and university teaching observatory in Finland. The observatory is located in the town of Kevola in the Kirkkonummi municipality of Finland, about 25 kilometres (16 mi) west of the city centre of Helsinki. The observatory is close to the Finnish National Road 2 and the Helsinki-Turku highway. The Kevola Observatory was founded in 1895 by the Finnish Society of Sciences and Letters as a astronomical and geodetic observatory. The observatory has been an independent institute since 1946 and has been a university observatory since 1968. The observatory has had its current name since 2013. The observatory's research focuses on astronomical and geodetic measurements. The observatory also provides professional services, such as mapping services, to other research institutions and public organizations. The observatory's campus is the base for the Finnish Geospatial Research Institute (FGI) and the European Space Agency's (ESA) Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer (JUICE) mission. The observatory has been responsible for the Finnish official space-geodetic reference system since the 1950s, when the Taalimittila field station was established in the Mynämäki district of Tampere. The Taalimittila field station was closed in the 1990s and the responsibility was transferred to the University of Tartu in Estonia. In addition to the main campus in Kevola, the observatory has smaller units in Kemiönsaari, Nummela, and Pori. The observatory also has a research station in the village of Nattavaara in Finnish Lapland. The Kevola Observatory has been involved in the development of the European Space Agency's GOCE and Swarm satellites, and the Finnish Geospatial Research Institute is involved in the development of the European Space Agency's CryoSat 2, Nasa/Nsf ICESat-2, and ESA/EUCLID missions.

Fourth Fitna The Fourth Fitna (Arabic: الفتنة الرابعة) or the Fourth Islamic Civil War was a period of political and religious conflict and turmoil that lasted from the death of Ali ibn Abi Talib in 661 until the defeat and death of the last claimant to the caliphate, Abdallah ibn Mu'awiya, in 683. The conflict was primarily between the forces of the Umayyad Caliphate, ruled by the Umayyad dynasty, and the various Iraqi rebel movements that sought to overthrow them. The Umayyad victory was an important step in the Umayyad consolidation of power, and in the process, the displacement of the political and religious center of the Caliphate from the Hejaz to Syria. The term fitna is commonly used to refer to the various civil wars that afflicted the Islamic community in the wake of the Prophet Muhammad's death. The first fitna lasted from 656 until 661, the second fitna lasted from 683 until 685, the third fitna lasted from 686 until 692, and the fourth fitna lasted from 661 until 683. The causes of the fourth fitna were similar to those of the second and third fitnas, with the major causes being the tension between the executive and legislative branches of government, the concentration of power in the hands of the caliph, the failure of the caliph to meet the expectations of the ruled, economic and social hardships imposed by the ruling regime, and the desire of the ruled to share in the ruling elite's privileges. The fourth fitna was characterized by the fragmentation of the opposition to the Umayyads. Whereas the opposition during the second and third fitnas was primarily regional, during the fourth fitna it became primarily tribal. The tribes of Banu Tamim, Banu Qahtan, and Banu Asad were the most active in the conflict. The fourth fitna also featured the first instance of widespread ideological opposition to the Umayyads, in the form of the Kharijites, who opposed the Umayyads' accommodations to the non-Muslims and the elite's privilege. The first phase of the fourth fitna began with the murder of the Umayyad caliph Ali ibn Abi Talib in 661 and the subsequent struggle for the caliphate between the Umayyads and the Iraqis. The second phase began in 681 when the Umayyad caliph Mu'awiya II died and was succeeded by his brother, Yazid II. The third phase began in 683 with the death of Yazid II and the appointment of his son, Mu'awiya III, to the caliphate. The fourth phase began in 684 when the Umayyad caliph, Marwan I, died and was succeeded by his son, Abd al-Malik. The fifth and final phase began in 685 when the Umayyad caliph, Abd al-Malik, died and was succeeded by his son, Walid I.

When God Writes Your Love Story Before I met my husband, I had a list of all the qualities I wanted in a man. I wanted him to be kind, funny, smart, tall, and good-looking, just to name a few. But I also wanted him to be a spiritual leader. I wanted him to be a man who would love God more than he loved me. I think that's a lot to ask of a guy. I'm not sure I would have been able to answer that description at 22. I was certainly not a spiritual leader at that point in my life. I'm not even sure I knew what that meant. Looking back, I can see now that I was asking for a man who was farther along in his spiritual journey than I was. I wanted a man who was closer to God than I was because I knew that if I was going to spend the rest of my life with a man, I wanted him to be a man who would lead me closer to God, not away from Him. So I think it's interesting that here I am, at 33, and I'm living my own love story that I wrote for myself when I was 22. The man I'm married to is kind, funny, smart, tall, good-looking, and he's a spiritual leader. I'm not talking about a spiritual leader in the sense that he's the pastor of a church or a Bible study leader. I'm talking about a man who is growing closer to God every day and who is leading his family closer to God. When I was 22, I didn't think I would find a man who was as spiritually mature as I was. But here I am, married to a man who is much farther along in his spiritual journey than I am. He challenges me to be a better Christian. He leads our family in prayers at dinner and he leads us in reading the Bible every day. In my love story, I didn't just marry a man, I married a spiritual leader who is helping me become a better woman of God. And the amazing thing is that I'm not the only one who is learning from my husband. My husband is learning from me, too. We are both growing closer to God together and it's amazing. So here's the thing: God is writing your love story, too. If you're not married, He's writing your story. If you are married, He's writing your story. Maybe you're not married to a spiritual leader. Maybe you're not married to a man who is challenging you to be a better Christian. But I can promise you this: God is writing your love story and He will give you the man who is right for you. If you're not married, don't settle for a man who is not growing closer to God. Don't settle for a man who doesn't make you a better Christian. And if you are married, don't settle for a man who is not growing closer to God. Don't settle for a man who doesn't make you a better Christian. Because here's the truth: God is writing your love story and He will give you the man who is right for you. When God writes your love story, it's going to be a story that challenges you to be a better Christian. It's going to be a story that helps you grow closer to God. It's not going to be a story that leads you away from God. It's not going to be a story that makes you less of a Christian. So don't settle for anything less than what God has for you. Because when God writes your love story, it's going to be a story that's worth reading.

Christian Basso (born 25 June 1966) is an Italian actor, film director, producer, and writer. Basso was born in Rome, Italy. He began his acting career in the theater, and later appeared in more than 60 films. He is best known for his performance as Paolo in the Academy Award-winning film Life Is Beautiful (1997), directed by Vincenzo Favio, for which he was nominated for a David di Donatello for Best Actor. In 1996, Basso won the David di Donatello for Best Supporting Actor for his performance in Il cielo è sempre più blu. In 2008, he was nominated for the David di Donatello for Best Supporting Actor for his performance in L'Auberge Espagnole. Basso wrote the screenplay for the film Un giorno perfetto, which was nominated for a David di Donatello for Best Film. In 2015, he was nominated for the David di Donatello for Best Supporting Actor for his performance in Quo Vado? Basso was also nominated for the David di Donatello for Best Supporting Actor for his performance in Illegittimo, in 2016. Basso's film Illegittimo was nominated for the David di Donatello for Best Film, in 2016.

Per Magnus Johansson (born 8 November 1973) is a Swedish football manager and a former player. He is the manager of Major League Soccer club Los Angeles FC. Johansson spent most of his playing career in Sweden, but also played in England, Germany, and Turkey. He won the Swedish Champion in 1998 and 1999, and reached the quarter-finals of the UEFA Cup with Halmstads BK in the 1999–2000 season. In 2002, he won the Swedish Manager of the Year award after leading his hometown club to promotion to the Allsvenskan. Johansson began his managerial career in the Swedish third and fourth tiers, and also had a brief stint as the manager of Danish Superliga club Vejle Boldklub. In 2015, he became the manager of Swedish club Örebro SK, and led the team to promotion to the Allsvenskan in 2016. He then became the manager of IFK Norrköping in 2017, and led the team to the Swedish title in 2018. In 2019, Johansson was named the Swedish Manager of the Year for the second time. Johansson joined Major League Soccer club Los Angeles FC in 2019 as an assistant coach, and was named the manager of the club in 2020.

Arengo and Freedom The arengo (or arena) was an institution in the medieval period in the Italian peninsula, in the area corresponding to the current regions of Tuscany, Umbria, and Romagna. It had a central role in the political and judicial life of the communities that had it. It was a distinctive feature of the legal and political system of the Communes, in particular of the cities, in comparison to the manorial system. The arengo was an assembly of all the citizens (or some of them, depending on the city) who had the right to vote for the government of the city. In particular, they were summoned in order to elect the main officers of the city, to decide on laws, and to judge on judicial cases. The arengo had its own officers, the arengari, who had the task to summon the arengo, to preside it, and to register the decisions. In some cities, the arengo was summoned only in particular moments, usually to elect the main officers of the city, while in other cities it was summoned more often. In any case, the arengo had to meet at least once a year. In the arengo, the citizens had the freedom to speak and to vote for the candidates to the offices of the city or for the new laws. In the arengo, the citizens were free and equal, without any distinction. The arengo was not an innovation of the Communes. It had a long tradition in the free communities of the Italian peninsula, like the rural communities of the Romans, and it was preserved also by the Lombards after the fall of the Western Roman Empire. During the Barbarian invasions, the arengo was one of the few institutions that was preserved by the communities that survived the disasters. After the Communes became the ruling power in Italy, the arengo was one of the main institutions of the cities. During the communal age, the arengo was not only an institution to rule the city, but also an institution to which the people of the city could appeal to solve their problems. In the arengo, the citizens could bring their complaints and their requests, and ask for a solution to their problems. The arengo could decide on laws, it could elect officers, and it could also judge on judicial cases. The arengo was the only institution that could decide on laws, and on the choice of the officers of the city. The arengo was a very important institution for the freedom of the cities. Only the arengo could decide on laws, and only the arengo could elect the officers who ruled the city: the arengo was the institution that made the city free.

Roman Mints The mints of ancient Rome struck coins of various denominations from the 3rd century BC to the 4th century AD. The Roman mint was one of the most productive in the world, and the entire empire was covered by a network of mints. There were about 150 mints in the Roman world, and it is estimated that there were more than 30 in Rome alone. The first mint in Rome was established in 269 BC by the first Roman consul, Appius Claudius Crassus. This mint was located in the Temple of Janus in the Forum Boarium. The coins were made of bronze, and the design featured a janiform head, a head of Janus on the obverse and a head of the goddess Roma on the reverse. The word "ROMANUS" was engraved on the coins, and the design remained unchanged for many years. In the 2nd century BC, the mint was moved to the Temple of Honor and Virtue, and the coins were made of purer bronze. The design was changed to feature a head of Janus on the obverse and a head of the goddess Roma on the reverse, with the word "ROMANUS" engraved on the coins. In the 1st century BC, the mint was moved to the Temple of Castor and Pollux, and the coins were made of even purer bronze. The design was changed to feature a head of Janus on the obverse and a head of the goddess Roma on the reverse, with the word "ROMANUS" engraved on the coins. In the 2nd century AD, the mint was moved to the Temple of Mars Ultor, and the coins were made of purer bronze. The design was changed to feature a head of Mars on the obverse and a head of the goddess Roma on the reverse, with the word "ROMANUS" engraved on the coins. The Roman mint produced coins of various denominations, including bronze, silver, and gold coins. The bronze coins were used for small purchases, while the silver and gold coins were used for larger purchases. The Roman mint also produced special coins for use in religious ceremonies.

Irving Lowens (May 7, 1914 – June 2, 1996) was an American musicologist, conductor, composer, and violist, primarily known for his work in the field of opera. Lowens was born in Bialystok, Poland in 1914, and his family moved to the United States in 1922. He studied music at the Juilliard School under Max Persin and Walter Damrosch, and conducting with Herbert von Karajan in Berlin. He joined the faculty of Juilliard in 1946, and later served as a professor of music at New York University (NYU) from 1956 to 1982. In 1981 he was appointed professor emeritus at NYU. Lowens was a music critic for The New Yorker magazine from 1948 to 1950, and also wrote for The Musical Quarterly. He was the editor of The Opera Quarterly from 1973 to 1985, and was a regular contributor to that journal as well. He was the author of two books, The Opera Library (a catalog of recordings) and Opera: A History (with Michael Korska). Lowens was also a violist, and was a member of the New York Philharmonic for 25 years, from 1950 to 1975. He also played with the Juilliard String Quartet. He was a founding member of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and was a longtime member of the faculty at the Marlboro Music Festival.

Alexander Troyanovsky (Russian: Александр Трояновский; surname sometimes transliterated Troyanovskiy or Troianovskiy; May 9, 1923 – June 1, 2018) was a Soviet and Russian mathematician who made significant contributions to the fields of geometry and topology. Troyanovsky was born in Moscow. His father, Ivan Troyanovsky, was a chemical engineer and his mother, Anna, was a housewife. He attended the Soviet military school Number One in Moscow, and then the Moscow State University. In 1950 he defended his candidate's thesis, and in 1958 he defended his doctoral dissertation. Troyanovsky was a member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and Russian Academy of Sciences. He was a full professor at the Moscow State University and at the University of Missouri. He was also a visiting professor at the University of California, Los Angeles and at Harvard University. Troyanovsky was known for his works on the theory of manifolds, the theory of Lie groups, the theory of smooth structures on manifolds, and the theory of orthogonal structures on manifolds. He was one of the pioneers of the theory of foliations on manifolds. Troyanovsky was the author of more than 180 articles and three books: "Differential geometry", "Smooth structures", and "Foliations". The books "Differential geometry" and "Smooth structures" were translated into English and published by Springer. The third book, "Foliations", was also translated into English and published by the American Mathematical Society. Troyanovsky was awarded the USSR State Prize in 1987. He was also awarded the Russian Academy of Sciences' Kapitsa Prize and the Lobachevsky Medal.

Robin Dyer (born 26 April 1964) is a South African-born Welsh former professional footballer who played as a defender. Dyer was born in Springs, South Africa but moved to Wales at the age of five. He joined his first football club, Cwmbran Celtic, at the age of eight, and went on to play for Cwmbran Town before joining Newport County in 1983. He made his league debut for Newport in 1984, and went on to make 135 league appearances for the club, scoring 8 goals. He also made 14 cup appearances, scoring once. In 1986, he joined Bristol City, where he made 128 league appearances, scoring 6 goals, over a three-year period. Dyer then returned to Newport in 1989, making a further 112 league appearances and scoring 9 goals over the next three years. He then had a brief spell with Bristol Rovers, making 3 appearances, before returning to Newport for a third time, making a further 63 league appearances and scoring 3 goals. Dyer finished his league career with Merthyr Tydfil, making 21 appearances. He also made 14 appearances in the Welsh Premier League for Cwmbran Town, scoring once. Dyer also played for the Wales semi-professional team, making 10 appearances.

Kostadin Yanchev (Bulgarian: Костадина Янчев; born May 9, 1987) is a Bulgarian singer and songwriter. He is best known for representing Bulgaria in the Eurovision Song Contest 2013 in Malmö, Sweden, with the song "Samo shampioni" ("Just Champions"). Yanchev was born in Veliko Tarnovo, and raised inarna close-knit musical family in Sofia, where he still resides. His father, Kiril Yanchev, is a musician and conductor, and his mother, Maria Yancheva, is a singer. He has an older sister, Ani, who is a singer and actress, and an older brother, Dimitar, who is a singer and actor. Yanchev's maternal grandparents were from the Republic of Macedonia. Yanchev has been interested in music since his early childhood, and has been singing and playing instruments since the age of four. He began taking private singing lessons at the age of six, and also learned to play the piano, guitar, drums, and bass guitar. At the age of 13, he became a singer in the children's choir of the National Palace of Culture, where he remained for three years. In 2006, Yanchev participated in the third season of X Factor Bulgaria, where he sang Jimmy Pop's "U Got What I Need". In 2008, he took part in the international talent show New Wave, where he placed sixth. In 2009, he participated in the fifth season of X Factor Romania, where he was eliminated in the early stages. In 2011, he participated in the Bulgarian X Factor again, this time as a member of the band Suncokret, which won the competition. In 2012, Yanchev was announced as the winner of Hityo, the Bulgarian version of Star Academy. Yanchev was selected to represent Bulgaria in the Eurovision Song Contest 2013 in Malmö, Sweden, after winning the Bulgarian national selection with his song "Samo shampioni". In the semi-final, he placed 11th with a total of 62 points, thus failing to qualify for the final. This was the second consecutive year that Bulgaria had failed to qualify for the final, after Kristian Kostov's "Beautiful Mess" placed 17th in the 2012 contest.

James Kazama (born February 10, 1931) is an American politician and businessman who served as a member of the Washington House of Representatives from the 28th district from 1974 to 1975, and again from 1976 to 1983, and from 1985 to 1993, and the Washington State Senate, representing the 28th district from 1993 to 1998. Kazama was born in Seattle, Washington. He attended Seattle Public Schools and graduated from Queen Anne High School in 1949. He went on to graduate from the University of Washington in 1953 with a bachelor's degree in economics. He also served in the United States Army from 1953 to 1955. Kazama began his political career as a member of the Washington House of Representatives, representing the 28th district from 1974 to 1975, and again from 1976 to 1983, and from 1985 to 1993. In 1993, he was elected to the Washington State Senate, representing the 28th district from 1993 to 1998. In addition to his political career, Kazama was also a businessman and real estate developer. He was a co-owner of the Seattle SuperSonics from 1987 to 1989, and was a member of the team's board of directors from 1983 to 1985. Kazama was married to Patricia Kazama from 1956 to 1961, and to Mary Kazama from 1962 to 2012. He has two children from his first marriage, and two children from his second marriage.

Adjumani District is a district in the Northern Region of Uganda. It is the largest district in the Northern Region and the second largest district in the country. It was created in 2006 by carving it out of the West Nile District. The district is located in the Albertine Rift Valley, a branch of the Great Rift Valley, that runs from Uganda's border with the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the west, through Uganda, to the border with Kenya in the east. The largest town in the district is Adjumani, where the district headquarters are located. Adjumani District is part of the West Nile sub-region. It is bordered by South Sudan to the north, West Nile District to the south, Nebbi District to the east, and Lake Albert to the west. The district has one city, Adjumani, and one town, Olwiyo. The district has two counties: Adjumani and Olwiyo. The area of the district is approximately 2,325 square miles (5,93 square kilometers). It is the second largest district in Uganda, after Gulu District. The population of the district is approximately 6,000 people. Arthur L. Wagner (November 27, 1885 – February 6, 1961) was an American lawyer, soldier, politician, and businessman. Wagner was born in Lincoln, Nebraska, and attended the University of Nebraska, where he received his bachelor's degree in 1908 and his master's degree in 1909. He received his law degree from the University of Nebraska College of Law in 1911. He was a practicing attorney in Nebraska from 1911 to 1912, when he moved to Pierre, South Dakota, to become an attorney for the South Dakota Railroad Commission. He later became general counsel for the commission. Wagner served in the United States Army during World War I, attaining the rank of captain. After the war, he returned to Nebraska and became a member of the Nebraska House of Representatives from 1939 to 1940. In 1940, he was elected to the Nebraska State Senate, where he served until his death. Wagner was a member of the Republican Party. He was a delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1940, 1944, and 1948. In 1952, he was an alternate delegate to the Republican National Convention. Wagner died in Lincoln, Nebraska, on February 6, 1961, at the age of 75.

Snyder, New York Snyder is a town in York County, in the U.S. state of New York. The population was 3,227 at the 2010 census. It is named after General John A. Snyder, who was an important figure in the development of the community. The community includes: One church, the Community Church of the Finger Lakes; One library, the Mill Stream Library; One museum, the Military Museum of the Finger Lakes; and One theater group, the Finger Lakes Community Theatre. Snyder is located on the north shore of Lake Cayuga, south of Auburn and is at the western edge of the Finger Lakes region. The town has a number of recreational areas. The largest is Finger Lakes Regional Park, which is on the lake and includes a small beach. Just to the north is Taughannock Falls State Park, with its waterfall, the highest single-drop waterfall in the state. Snyder is also home to a campus of the Finger Lakes Community College. According to the United States Census Bureau, the town has a total area of 36.6 square miles (94.7 km), of which, 34.5 square miles (89.2 km) of it is land and 2.1 square miles (5.5 km) of it is water. As of the census of 2000, there were 3,315 people, 1,232 households, and 862 families residing in the town. The population density was 101.3 people per square mile (39.1/km). There were 1,788 housing units at an average density of 53.1 per square mile (20.5/km). The racial makeup of the town was 97.21% White, 1.35% African American, 0.30% Native American, 0.99% Asian, 0.03% Pacific Islander, 0.14% from other races, and 0.69% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.24% of the population. There were 1,232 households, out of which 29.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 52.5% were married couples living together, 9.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 35.2% were non-families. 27.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 12.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.42 and the average family size was 3.00. In the town, the population was spread out, with 21.9% under the age of 18, 7.4% from 18 to 24, 27.5% from 25 to 44, 26.3% from 45 to 64, and 15.9% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 40 years. For every 100 females, there were 101.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 101.4 males. The median income for a household in the town was $43,818, and the median income for a family was $53,0. Males had a median income of $31,500 versus $22,083 for females. The per capita income for the town was $21,4. About 2.9% of families and 6.8% of the population were below the poverty line, including 4.9% of those under age 18 and 4.6% of those age 65 or over. Snyder is home to a campus of the Finger Lakes Community College, located on the north side of town on Cayuga Lake. Snyder has a small library, the Mill Stream Library, located just south of the village. The Military Museum of the Finger Lakes is located on the south side of town, just west of the village. The town has one theater group, the Finger Lakes Community Theatre, which performs at the Community Church of the Finger Lakes. Snyder is served by Exit 61 of the New York State Thruway (Interstate 90), which is the first exit east of the Thruway's split into I-90 and I-88.

The 2018 Maldives political crisis began on 26 February, when the Maldives Supreme Court issued a ruling that quashed the conviction of nine opposition figures, including the former president Mohamed Nasheed, and ordered the immediate release of those held in prison. The ruling was seen as a major blow to President Abdulla Yameen, who had imprisoned the nine opposition figures on charges of terrorism. Yameen responded to the ruling by declaring a state of emergency, which was immediately challenged by the opposition. The following day, the Supreme Court nullified the state of emergency, and the opposition called for the resignation of Yameen. The crisis deepened on 1 March, when Yameen's supporters stormed the Supreme Court and attempted to intimidate the judges into reversing the ruling. The attempt failed, and the Supreme Court issued a second ruling on 2 March, which confirmed the original ruling and ordered the immediate release of the nine opposition figures. The crisis ended on 17 November, when Yameen's opponent in the September 2018 presidential election, Ibrahim Mohamed Solih, was sworn in as the new president.

FSV Wacker 90 Nordhausen is a German association football club based in Nordhausen, Thuringia. The club was founded in 1990 out of the merger of two clubs, BSG Wismut Nordhausen and BSG Stahl Nordhausen, and was playing in the 3. Liga until 2014–15, when it was relegated to the Thüringenliga. The club's greatest success has been promotion to the 2. Bundesliga in 1996–97, where it spent two seasons. Wacker Nordhausen has been a traditional club in the Thuringia region, and has spent most of its history in the highest league in the region. The club has won the Thuringialiga seven times and the Thuringia Cup five times. The club's main rivals are fellow Thuringian clubs Carl Zeiss Jena and Rot-Weiß Erfurt. The club has played its home games at the newly renovated ABERTAU-Stadion since the 2014–15 season. The club has a large fan base in the Thuringia region and has an active fan scene with several ultra groups. The club has several times been involved in cases of violence against fans, and has had a very strained relationship with its fans at times. The club has a close friendship with the Danish club Boldklubben Frem, which has resulted in several player and staff exchanges over the years. In the 2012–13 and 2013–14 seasons, Wacker Nordhausen was known as FSV Wacker 90 Nordhausen. The club has a reserve team, FSV Wacker 90 Nordhausen II, which plays in the Thüringenliga. ## History ### Predecessor clubs The club's roots go back to the 1920s and the establishment of two clubs in Nordhausen, BSG Wismut Nordhausen and BSG Stahl Nordhausen. The two clubs had a traditional rivalry and both won the Thuringia championship several times. In addition, BSG Stahl Nordhausen won the German amateur championship in 1964 and BSG Wismut Nordhausen won the East German amateur championship in 1971. BSG Wismut Nordhausen had its greatest success in the early 1970s when it won the East German Cup in 1970–71 and the East German championship in 1973–74. The club also finished runners-up in the East German championship in 1972–73. BSG Stahl Nordhausen had its greatest success in the early 1980s when it won the East German Cup in 1980–81. The clubs merged in 1990 to form FSV Wacker Nordhausen, which played in the Oberliga for the first time in the 1991–92 season. ### FSV Wacker Nordhausen FSV Wacker Nordhausen played in the Oberliga for the first time in the 1991–92 season, when it finished in last place in its division and was relegated. The club made an immediate return to the Oberliga in 1992–93, when it finished in third place in its division. In the 1993–94 season, the club won its division and thereby gained promotion to the third-tier Regionalliga Nordost/Süd. In its first season in the Regionalliga, the club finished in third place in its division and thereby qualified for the new second-tier 2. Bundesliga Nord. In the 1994–95 season, FSV Wacker Nordhausen finished in last place in the 2. Bundesliga Nord and thereby suffered relegation to the third-tier Regionalliga Nord/Süd. In the 1995–96 season, the club finished in second place in the Regionalliga Nord/Süd and thereby qualified for the new, unified 2. Bundesliga. In the 1996–97 season, FSV Wacker Nordhausen finished in fourth place in the 2. Bundesliga and thereby qualified for the new, lower third-tier Regionalliga Nord/Süd. In the 1998–99 season, the club finished in last place in the Regionalliga Nord/Süd and thereby suffered relegation to the fourth-tier Oberliga Nord/Süd. In the 2000–01 season, the club finished in last place in the Oberliga Nord/Süd and thereby suffered relegation to the fifth-tier Thüringenliga. In the 2002–03 season, the club finished in last place in the Thüringenliga and thereby suffered relegation to the sixth-tier Landesliga. In the 2004–05 season, the club finished in last place in the Landesliga and thereby suffered relegation to the seventh-tier Bezirksliga.
