Morgxn (born Josh Morgan; November 4, 1983) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and record producer. He is best known for his 2017 single "Home", which has been featured on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, The Good Place, and Station 19. Morgxn was born and raised in a small town in Michigan. He had a religious upbringing and his family regularly attended a local church. He was exposed to music at an early age, as his mother played the piano and his grandfather was a church choir director. As a child, he often sang in church and at school. When Morgxn was a teenager, he began to take an interest in pop and rock music. He started to play the guitar and write his own songs. He eventually formed a band with some of his friends and began to perform locally. After high school, Morgxn attended college in Chicago, where he studied music and audio production. After graduation, he moved to Los Angeles to pursue a career in the music industry. He soon began to work with a number of well-known artists, including Lady Gaga, Katy Perry, and Justin Bieber. In 2017, Morgxn released his first solo single, "Home", which became a hit. The song was featured on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, The Good Place, and Station 19. He followed up with the release of his debut EP, Vital, in 2018. Morgxn's music has been described as "epic, emotional, and atmospheric". He has said that his goal is to create music that is both "soulful and relatable". In addition to his solo work, Morgxn has also written and produced music for other artists, including Camila Cabello, Charlie Puth, The Chainsmokers, and David Guetta.

Edwin Lascelles, 1st Baron Harewood (22 June 1713 – 13 August 1795) was an English landowner, lawyer, politician, and Member of Parliament for Northallerton, Yorkshire, from 1747 to 1768. Lascelles was the son of Henry Lascelles, of Northallerton, Yorkshire, and his wife, Mary, daughter of Edward Harrison, of York. He was admitted to Middle Temple on 20 November 1733 and was called to the bar on 25 November 1741. He became Recorder of Ripon and a member of the Yorkshire Committee for the Electorate of York. In 1746, Lascelles purchased the estate of Scrog's Hill, near Northallerton, from a member of the Belasyse family and set about building a house on the site, which he named after his grandfather, Harewood. In 1747 he was elected to Parliament for Northallerton and was re-elected in 1754, 1756, and 1761. Lascelles married twice. His first wife, Anne, daughter of William Belasyse, 2nd Earl of Fauconberg, whom he married in 1744, died in 1747. His second wife, Mary, daughter of William FitzHerbert, of Tissington, Derbyshire, whom he married in 1759, died in 1783. He had no children by either marriage, and on his death, his lands were inherited by his nephew, Henry Lascelles, who later served as Chancellor of the Exchequer. Lascelles was buried at Northallerton on 17 August 1795.

Srinish Aravind is an Indian actor and model who works in the Tamil film industry. He is best known for his role as Bhargav in the Tamil drama film, Marudhamalai (2011). Srinish was born in Chennai and completed his schooling at the Asan Memorial School in the city. He then completed a bachelor's degree in computer science at M.G.R. College in Chennai. He worked as a software engineer for a company called Cisco for two years, before leaving to pursue a career in modelling. Srinish began his modelling career in 2007 and has since been in several commercials and advertisements. He has also been on the covers of several magazines, including the June 2009 issue of Granthan. In 2010, he was named as the "Most Promising Model of the Year" at the Vijay Awards. In 2011, Srinish made his acting debut in the Tamil drama film, Marudhamalai, directed by SSethupathi. He played the role of Bhargav, a rich man's son who falls in love with a poor woman. The film was released in June 2011 and received positive reviews from critics. Srinish's next film was the romantic comedy, Thattathin Marayathu, directed by Linden Bagali. He played the role of Arul, a man who falls in love with a woman from a wealthy family. The film was released in July 2012 and was a commercial success. In 2013, Srinish made his debut in the Kannada film industry with the romantic comedy, Bhajrangi, directed by V. Ravichandran. He played the role of Karthik, a man who falls in love with a woman from a wealthy family. The film was released in April 2013 and was a commercial success. Srinish's latest film is the romantic comedy, Vanmurai, directed by Rajeev NC. He played the role of Arul, a man who falls in love with a woman from a wealthy family. The film was released in October 2013 and was a commercial success.

Acacia phasmoides Acacia phasmoides is a species of Acacia native to eastern Australia. It occurs in Queensland, New South Wales, the Northern Territory, and Victoria. Common names for this species include: acacia, blackwood, false mahogany, ironwood, Jacaranda, Jarrah, mallee, merivale, native mahogany, phillott, phylirea, phylireum, red mahogany, silkwood, white mahogany Acacia phasmoides grows as a shrub or tree to 30 m (98 ft) high, with a maximum height of 50 m (160 ft) in some cases. It has smooth, pale grey bark, with the older bark becoming scaly. Like most Acacias it has phyllodes rather than leaves. These are a dull green to grey-green colour and have a narrowly oblong shape. They are 3–8 cm (1.2–3.1 in) long by 1–2 cm (0.39–0.79 in) wide. The phyllodes have a prominent central vein and no lateral veins. The species is often confused with A. maidenii, A. pentaphylla, and A. Robusta. It can be distinguished from these species by its phyllodes, which are not noticeably biserrate, and by its racemose inflorescences. The inflorescence is a bright yellow, cylindrical flower-spike. It is 2–4 cm (0.79–1.6 in) in diameter and 3–5 cm (1.2–2.0 in) long. The spike is borne on a 1–3 cm (0.39–1.18 in) long stalk. The fruit is a pod, 3–7 cm (1.2–2.75 in) long by 1.5–2 cm (0.59–0.79 in) wide. It is dark red to black in colour, and covered with a fine, short, hairs. The pod contains 2–4 dark brown seeds.

Ethnodoxology is the study of the relationship between the Christian faith and the cultural forms that shape and express it. It is a portmanteau of the words "ethnography" and "doxology". The word "ethnography" is used in the anthropological sense of a description of the beliefs and practices of a particular culture, in this case, the Christian culture. "Doxology" refers to the beliefs and practices that are expressed in the cultural forms. In some ways, ethnodoxology can be seen as the study of "what the church sings when it praises God in a particular language and culture". The term was coined in 1964 by the Brazilian Catholic priest, composer, and musician Orlando distribution, who was the founder of the anthropological school of thinking about music in the Catholic Church that is known as "ethnodoxology". Orlando was an assistant to the famous Brazilian anthropologist Roberto da Matta, and, as a musician, he was influenced by the musicologist Jacques Ibert. Together with other Brazilian musicians, Orlando developed the field of study known today as "ethnodoxology", with a particular concern for the relationship between music, faith, and culture. ethnodoxology has also been strongly influenced by the Chicago school of musicology, whose concern for the relationship between social context and musical form is reflected in the work of scholars such as George List and Nelson Goodfellow. The basic concern of ethnodoxology is the relationship between music, faith, and culture. It is a branch of musicology, but with a particular focus on the relationship between musical forms and the cultural and religious context in which they are created and performed.

Transport in Suriname As of 2022, Suriname's transport system is still underdeveloped, with the country having only 3,091 km (1,919 mi) of paved roads, and another 3,352 km (2,08 mi) of unpaved roads. The country has one international airport, Zorg en Hoop Airport, near the capital city of Paramaribo, however, it is not a major hub and there are few flights that arrive from other Caribbean countries. The country's main port is the Suriname River, which allows for the transportation of goods between Paramaribo and the Atlantic Ocean. A much smaller port is located in Nickerie, close to the border with Brazil. There are 5,000 km (3,100 mi) of navigable waterways, mostly along the Suriname and Commewijne rivers. The country's rail system has 1,386 km (860 mi) of track, all of which is in poor condition and almost all of it is not used. The country's road network is made up of 6,733 km (4,225 mi) of paved and unpaved roads. The most common mode of transport in Suriname is the bus. The country has numerous bus companies, such as Red Dot, N.V.TB, and SRD, that provide services between all major cities and towns. The country's largest bus company, Red Dot, was founded in 1964. It has since become a major company, offering not only bus services, but also air and sea travel, as well as courier services. The country's second-largest bus company, N.V.TB, was founded in 1952. It has since become a major company, offering not only bus services, but also air and sea travel, as well as courier services. The country's third-largest bus company, SRD, was founded in 2008. It has since become a major company, offering not only bus services, but also air and sea travel, as well as courier services. The country's fourth-largest bus company, RVB, was founded in 2012. It has since become a major company, offering not only bus services, but also air and sea travel, as well as courier services. The country's fifth-largest bus company, TCV, was founded in 2013. It has since become a major company, offering not only bus services, but also air and sea travel, as well as courier services. The country's sixth-largest bus company, PPA, was founded in 2016. It has since become a major company, offering not only bus services, but also air and sea travel, as well as courier services.

Blue Hills Reservation The Blue Hills Reservation is a 7,000-acre (2,700 ha) reservation in the Boston Metro area, primarily in the city of Milton, Massachusetts, and the towns of Canton, Dedham, Milton, and Randolph. The reservation is managed by the Massachusetts Department of Conservation and Recreation and is the centerpiece of the Metropolitan Park System of Massachusetts. The Blue Hills are a range of low, rocky hills in the upper Charles River Valley just south of Boston, Massachusetts. The hills are named for the blue-grey color of their rocky slopes, which is a result of the weathering of basaltic bedrock. The Blue Hills are not tall enough to be called mountains, and are in fact only a few hundred feet above sea level at their highest point. The hills are part of a larger geologic formation that includes the recycling of the igneous rock of the Boston Basin, and the soil is mostly made up of glacial till. The Blue Hills Reservation consists of a series of seven drumlins, or hills formed by glaciers during the last ice age. The hills are joined by two glacial spurs, or lateral moraines, that form the borders of the reservation. The Blue Hills Reservation is also home to several kettle ponds, including Tinkers Pond and Spectacle Pond, formed by the glaciers that once covered the region. The Blue Hills Reservation is a popular destination for outdoor recreation. The reservation's many hiking trails, which total over 125 miles (201 km), are used for hiking, walking, and running. Bicycling and horseback riding are also allowed on some trails. The Blue Hills are also a popular destination for rock climbing, with over 1,000 established climbing routes. The reservation's many ponds and lakes are used for swimming, boating, and fishing, and the numerous parks and overlooks are used for passive recreation. In 2009, the Blue Hills Reservation was designated as a National Natural Landmark by the U.S. Department of the Interior. In addition, the reservation is listed on the National Register of Historic Places as a National Historic Landmark District.

Nocturnal is the sixth studio album by the American death metal band The Black Dahlia Murder. The album was released on June 21, 2011, through Metal Blade Records. Nocturnal was produced by The Black Dahlia Murder and was mixed and mastered by James Murphy, known for his work with Death, Testament, and Obituary. Nocturnal is The Black Dahlia Murder's first album to be released on Metal Blade Records since their 2005 debut, Unhallowed. The band had previously been signed to Indianapolis-based label Rowe Productions, which released their 2007 album, Miasma. In 2009, the band was signed to Metal Blade Records, and released their EP, Warped & Decayed, through the label. Nocturnal was the band's final album to feature founding guitarist Mike Hodgin, who amicably left the band in early 2012 to pursue other musical interests. In July 2011, Nocturnal was released as a limited-edition double vinyl album. The album was re-released in June 2012, following the band's signing to eOne Music. The 2012 re-release was issued as a single vinyl album, and featured a slightly different track listing. The most notable difference was the replacement of the song "Satanic Panic (2009)" with a new track, "Mama". Nocturnal received generally positive reviews from critics. Review aggregator Metacritic, a review aggregate, gave the album a score of 72, indicating "Generally favorable reviews", based on four critical reviews. All About Jazz awarded Nocturnal five stars, and described it as "one of the best metal albums of the year". NME also awarded it five stars, and said that the band had "reinvented death metal for the new decade".

Sparks are an American rock band formed in Los Angeles in 1970 by brothers Ron (the lead guitarist, vocals, kazoo, piano,organ) and Russell Mael (the lead vocalist, keyboards, guitar, drums, percussion) with the intention of doing experimental pop music. The band's current line-up consists of the Mael brothers and drummer Steve Durand, with various bassists and programmers in rotation. Since the band's formation, they have released twenty studio albums, two live albums, and numerous singles and music videos. The band came to international attention in 1974 with the release of their second studio album, Kimono My House, which featured their first hit single, "This Town Ain't Big Enough for Both of Us". The song was among the first to feature a disability-related theme, and it reached the top five on the UK Singles Chart. The album's title track was also a hit, reaching the top ten in the United States and Canada. The band's next album, Big Beat (1976), featured two more UK top ten hits, "Never Turn Your Back on a Friend" and "Get Crazy". Their 1978 album, This Town Ain't Big Enough for Both of Us, was their first UK number one. It featured their only UK number one single, "The Number One Song in Heaven", and "Tryouts for the Human Race", which was the first of their songs to hit the Billboard Hot 100. In the early 1980s, the band's popularity began to wane. They changed their style and became more experimental to catch the interest of the audience. Their 1983 album, Kimono Wars, was a critical and commercial failure. A new direction in 1984 with the release of the album, Music That You Can Dance To, did not lead to a commercial recovery. A series of collaborations with other artists, including "I Predict (We'll Be Famous)", with Annie Lennox, helped to keep the band in the public eye. In 1986, the band's contract with Columbia Records expired and they signed with Virgin Records. They began to work on what would become their first major hit album in eight years, Whomp That Sucker. The title track was released as a single and became their biggest hit in the United States since "This Town Ain't Big Enough for Both of Us". The next year, they had another hit with "Angst in My Pants", from the album Luxury Problem. In 1989, they released the album, The Whomp That Sucker Tour, a live album with a studio recording of "Let's Go to Bed", which was their final hit. In the early 1990s, the band's popularity began to wane again. They released the album, Angst in My Pants, but it failed to chart. In 1996, they released a greatest hits album, and they have not had a hit since. In 2001, the band released a new album, Lil' Beethoven. They continue to perform and tour, and have released several live albums.

Oakhurst is an unincorporated community and census-designated place (CDP) located within Ocean Township in Monmouth County, New Jersey, United States. As of the 2010 United States Census, the CDP's population was 4,234. Oakhurst is located in the eastern portion of Ocean Township and is bordered by the Toms River on the south and east, with the border in some places following the river's edge and in some places following the river's former edge prior to coastal flooding and restoration projects. The community is also bordered on the east by the Manchester Township and on the north by the Howell Township. Oakhurst is home to the main campus of Toms River High School South as well as the intermediate and primary schools of the Toms River School District. The community is named for the many oak trees that once lined the streets. In 1975, the Toms River Country Club, the only country club in the township, was opened in the Oakhurst neighborhood. The course was designed by Hal Purdy and has 18 holes. As of the 2010 United States Census, there were 4,234 people, 1,632 households, and 1,][2] families residing in the CDP. The population density was 1,288.3 per square mile (498.5/km2). There were 1,690 housing units at an average density of 483.4 per square mile (186.5/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 95.24% White, 2.35% African American, 0.02% Native American, 2.60% Asian, 1.14% from other races, and 1.05% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 4.36% of the population. There were 1,632 households, out of which 31.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 62.9% were married couples living together, 9.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 23.9% were non-families. 21.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.61 and the average family size was 2.97. In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 20.3% under the age of 18, 4.9% from 18 to 24, 25.5% from 25 to 44, 27.5% from 45 to 64, and 18.8% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 43 years. For every 100 females, there were 95.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 96.9 males. As of the 2000 United States Census, there were 4,217 people, 1,606 households, and 1,210 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 1,287.0 per square mile (498.5/km2). There were 1,697 housing units at an average density of 481.3/sq mi (186.5/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 97.57% White, 1.27% African American, 0.02% Native American, 1.65% Asian, 0.02% Pacific Islander, 0.69% from other races, and 0.52% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 3.88% of the population. There were 1,606 households, out of which 27.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 63.0% were married couples living together, 8.9% had a female householder with no husband present, and 25.1% were non-families. 22.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.49 and the average family size was 2.94. In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 19.0% under the age of 18, 5.0% from 18 to 24, 26.2% from 25 to 44, 26.4% from 45 to 64, and 18.4% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 42 years. For every 100 females, there were 96.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 99.3 males. As of the 2000 census, the median income for a household in the CDP was $69,219, and the median income for a family was $84,444. Males had a median income of $50,192 versus $36,451 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $31,886. About 1.

Someone to Watch Over Me (TV series) Some to Watch Over Me is a British television drama series, produced by the BBC and transmitted on BBC One from 28 September 1998 to 1 May 2002, although the final episode was postponed due to the death of Princess Margaret. The series starred Francesca Annis as Julia, a former MI5 agent who has been forced into retirement due to her age and a back injury. To make ends meet, Julia takes a job as a dinner lady at a local school, and is also offered a small flat by her old friend and colleague George (Nia Roberts). Although Julia is keen to start a new life, she is unable to shake off her previous career as a spy, and finds herself drawn into a world of intrigue and danger when she discovers that George's flat is actually a front for a local spy cell, and that her friends are not all who they seem. The series was originally conceived as a vehicle for Francesca Annis, who had previously appeared in another BBC spy drama, The New Avengers, in the mid-1970s. The New Avengers had been a success in Britain, but had not been particularly well-received by the American networks, who had therefore refused to consider any spin-off series featuring the character of Cathy Gale. This left British writer David Collison (who had also written for The New Avengers) to develop a new concept for a thriller series, which eventually became Someone to Watch Over Me. The series was initially produced by independent company Spooksville, but after the first series was completed, the BBC took over production. The series was shot on location in London, with many scenes being filmed around the city's Docklands area. Someone to Watch Over Me was not a major critical success, but it did gain a small cult following, and the first series was released on Region 1 DVD in the United States. The series was also screened on cable channel Bravo. A novelisation of the series, written by Barry Vanes, was published by BBC Books in 1999.

Miku Kanemura (金村 美玖, Kanemura Miku, born February 8, 1988) is a Japanese singer, songwriter, and television personality. She is best known for her work as a Vocaloid producer, and for her collaborations with the Vocaloid software singing synthesizer, Hatsune Miku. Kanemura's involvement with the Vocaloid community began in 2007, when she submitted her first original Vocaloid song to the Internet. Her breakthrough came in 2009, when her song "Melt" became the first Vocaloid song to receive a major label release in Japan, as part of the compilation album Vocaloid Collection 2. In 2010, she released her first Vocaloid album,Discovery, through independent label Honey Bee Music. In 2011, Kanemura released her second Vocaloid album, Coordination, through major label Sony Music Japan. The album featured contributions from various other Vocaloid producers, as well as a bonus CD featuring covers of Vocaloid songs by other producers. In 2012, she released her third Vocaloid album, fluency, through Sony Music Japan. In 2013, Kanemura announced that she would no longer be producing Vocaloid songs, and would instead focus on original music. Her first original album,Butterfly Effect, was released in June 2014. Kanemura has also performed at various Vocaloid-related events, including the annual Vocaloid concerts in Tokyo, and has made appearances on television shows and variety programs to promote the Vocaloid software.

George N. Turner (born July 13, 1933) is an American politician who served as a member of the United States House of Representatives from Texas from 1987 to 2003. Turner was born in Houston, Texas. He attended the University of Houston and the University of Texas at Austin. In 1955 he joined the United States Marine Corps and served for three years, reaching the rank of captain. After his discharge from the Marine Corps, he returned to Houston and entered the oil business. In 1986, Turner was elected to the United States House of Representatives, representing Texas's 2nd congressional district. He was reelected in 1988, 1992, and 1996. In 1998, he was redistricted to the 18th district, where he served until 2002. Turner was the chair of the House Republican Policy Committee from 1995 to 1999. He also chaired the Energy and Environment Task Force for the House Republican Policy Committee. In addition, he was a member of the National Republican Policy Committee and the Republican Study Committee. Turner decided not to run for reelection to the House in 2002. In 2003, he was appointed to the Texas State Board of Education, on which he served until 2007.

Sergei Shmatko (Russian: Серге́й Шматко́; born 18 November 1950) is a Russian politician and the former Minister of Energy of the Russian Federation, a position he held from 17 May 2006 until 7 May 2012. He was also the president of JSC Atomenergoprom, Russia's nuclear power corporation, from 2011 to 2013. Sergei Shmatko was born in 1950 in Vinica, near Kherson, Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic. In 1973 he graduated from the Lugansk State Medical University. From 1973 to 1975 he was a physician at a Lugansk hospital. In 1976 he became an assistant professor at the Lugansk State Medical University. From 1981 to 1991 he was the director of the Lugansk Regional Children's Hospital. In 1991 he became the Minister of Health of the Lugansk Republic. In 1994, Shmatko became the chief doctor of theNUMBERED]]. In 1995, he became the Minister of Health of the Chuvash Republic. From 1996 to 2000 he was the Minister of Health of the Russian Federation. From 2000 to 2004 he was the Minister of Public Health of the Russian Federation. In 2004 he became the president of the Russian Public Health Academy. On 17 May 2006, Shmatko was appointed Minister of Energy of the Russian Federation, a position he held until 7 May 2012. He was also the president of JSC Atomenergoprom, Russia's nuclear power corporation, from 2011 to 2013. In 2010, Shmatko was awarded the State Prize of the Russian Federation for his work on the development of diagnostic and treatment methods for urological diseases.

Great Naval Battles: North Atlantic 1939-1943 In World War II the North Atlantic was the scene of a struggle between the German Kriegsmarine and the Royal Navy and the United States Navy. The German effort was to transport men and material to Europe from 1939 to 1943. The Allies' effort was to prevent this. The area of conflict was the North Atlantic Ocean, which stretches from the coast of North America to that of Europe. The fighting took the form of a naval war, a war fought by aircraft and ships, with the conflict lasting from September 1939 until May 1945. The North Atlantic was the key area for the supply of war materials to the European theatre. The majority of the shipping used in the Atlantic supply convoys came from the United States and Canada. In the early part of the war, the Germans had a decisive victory in the Battle of the Denmark Strait. This, coupled with the invasion of Norway, gave them control of the North Atlantic for several months in 1940. In 1941, the Germans attacked the United States through their occupation of Denmark and Norway, which gave them control of the North Atlantic sea lines of communication. This, in turn, threatened the flow of supplies to the Soviet Union, Britain, and the Mediterranean. The United States and Britain went on the offensive in the North Atlantic, and by the end of 1941 had defeated the German effort to control the North Atlantic sea lines of communication. The Battle of the North Atlantic was a major factor in the defeat of Germany in World War II. The U-boat campaign in the Atlantic was one of the longest and most bitterly fought campaigns of World War II, and it is often described as the "Second Trafalgar" in reference to the First Battle of Trafalgar, a British naval victory in 1805 that had dealt a crushing blow to Napoleon's campaign against the British Empire. In this second Trafalgar, the Allies won a victory so decisive that the German Navy (Kriegsmarine) was never again able to pose a serious threat to the sea lines of communication between the New World and the Old World. In the first two years of the war, the German U-boats and the Royal Navy and the United States Navy were locked in a deadly war of cat-and-mouse in the North Atlantic. The Germans enjoyed a period of success in this campaign in the early months of the war, but the Allies gradually gained the upper hand, and by the end of 1941 they had won a clear victory. In the spring of 1943, the Germans launched a major offensive in the North Atlantic, with the aim of breaking the sea lines of communication between the United States and Britain. This offensive, known as "Operation Drumbeat", was the largest U-boat campaign of the war, and it resulted in a major defeat for the Allies. However, the Allies were able to recover from this defeat, and by the end of the year they had once again gained the upper hand in the North Atlantic. In the final two years of the war, the Allies carried on a relentless offensive in the North Atlantic, with the aim of completely destroying the German U-boat force. This offensive, coupled with the defeat of the German surface fleet in the Battle of the Atlantic, led to the complete destruction of the German economy, and the surrender of Germany in May 1945.

Estádio Kléber Andrade The Estádio Kléber Andrade is a multi-purpose stadium in the city of Niterói, state of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. It was built in 1970, and it has a maximum capacity of 8,560 people. The Estádio Kléber Andrade is named after the Brazilian athlete Kléber de Souza Andrade, who was the first Brazilian to win two Olympic titles, winning the 3000 metres steeplechase events at the 1932 and 1936 Summer Olympics. The stadium is part of the Complexo Desportivo da Cidade de Niterói (Niterói Sports Complex), which includes the Niterói Municipal Olympic Pool, the Niterói Tennis Club, and the headquarters of the Niterói Sports Confederation. The complex is located in the Copacabana neighborhood, near the Juscelino Kubitskey Bridge, which connects Niterói to the city of Rio de Janeiro. The stadium is the home ground of the Botafogo de Futebol e Regatas football club. In 2007, the stadium was chosen as one of the host venues for the 2009 FIFA U-17 World Cup. In 2013, it was chosen as one of the host venues for the 2014 FIFA World Cup. However, in June 2013, the stadium was not approved by the FIFA due to its short length, and it was replaced by the Estádio Olímpico João Havelange in Rio de Janeiro. In 2016, the stadium was chosen as one of the host venues for the 2016 Olympic and Paralympic Games, hosting the track and field events and the football matches of the 2016 Summer Olympics and the 2016 Summer Paralympics. However, in February 2016, the stadium was not approved by the International Olympic Committee due to its short length, and it was replaced by the Estádio Olímpico João Havelange in Rio de Janeiro.

Paul Billerbeck (born 1967) is a German serial killer and sex offender, known as the "Killer of the Lower Rhine Area". Billerbeck was born in 1967 in Solingen, Germany. He was sentenced to five years in prison for attempted murder in 1994, and to life in prison for murder in 1998. Billerbeck's victims were all young women, most of them trainees or students. He strangled them after a period of stalking, and then posed their bodies in a sexual manner. He always chose his victims from a large distance, and never used his real name. His first murder was in 1996, and his last one was in 1997. In October 1998, Billerbeck was arrested after a woman he had been stalking escaped and notified the police. He confessed to the five murders after being presented with a psychological profile prepared by the police. He showed no remorse, and claimed that he had only killed women who "deserved" to be killed. Billerbeck was sentenced to life in prison for the five murders, as well as to a term of ten years in prison for attempted murder. He will be eligible for parole in 2036, when he will be 69 years old. Billerbeck's victims are: - Birgit Knoll, 18, on 12 January 1996 in Düsseldorf-Urdenbach - Tanja W., 19, on 11 April 1996 in Meerbusch-Büderich - Barbara C., 23, on 27 April 1996 in Kaarst - Sarah B., 21, on 18 May 1996 in Kleve - Elke M., 23, on 16 June 1996 in Wesel

RAF Dalton RAF Dalton was a Royal Air Force station in West Yorkshire, England, located 2.4 miles (3.9 km) west of Huddersfield, just off the A640 road and close to the village of Kirkheaton. The RAF station was opened in the late 1930s as a bomber base, with the first aircraft arriving in January 1939, just before the outbreak of war. It became the home of No. 1 Group, Royal Air Force, and its resident aircraft were a mixture of Wellington, Halifax and Lancaster bombers, and the odd Mustang fighter. During the war, the bombers of No. 1 Group were used to attack enemy industries, communications, and transport in Germany, Italy, and occupied Europe. No. 1 Group was one of the few Groups to have a permanent base in Yorkshire. During the war, the Group consisted of four squadrons (No's. 101, 102, 103, and 104), and four bombing schools (No's. 1, 4, 5, and 11). The Group was equipped with a wide range of aircraft, and during the war it operated Wellingtons, Halifaxes, Lancasters, Mustangs, and Mosquitos. Dalton was one of the few RAF stations to have an all-female ground crew. They were part of the Women's Auxiliary Air Force, or WAAF. No. 1 Group was the first to be equipped with the de Havilland Mosquito. These were used for fast, low-level, daylight operations, particularly at the start of the war when the German industries were the main target. As the war progressed and the German night-time defences became more effective, the Mosquito was used for night-time operations. The station was also used by No. 4 Group, Royal Air Force, and No. 627 Squadron, Royal Air Force, as well as a number of other units. In November 1947, the station closed. The site is now the location of the Huddersfield Golf Club.

Vampyre is the fifth studio album by the heavy metal band Blue Oyster Cult, released in April, 1979. The album was re-released in 1985 with a different cover and the bonus track "Veteran of the Psychic Wars" which was the theme to the film The Sentinel. In 2002, the album was re-released again with a different cover and a bonus DVD with a live performance by the band. The album's working title was Night of the Vampyre, as stated in a interview by the band's bassist, Fernando Saunders, in 2002. The songs on the album are influenced by the works of horror writer H. P. Lovecraft, with the track "The Dream Quest of Unknown Kadath" based on the short story of the same name. "Necrophagist" is derived from the same word as the band Necrophagist takes their name from. "Godzilla (King of the Monsters)" is based on the film series of the same name, and "Vampyre" is of course based on the mythological creature. "Out of the Ashes" is a remake of the song "Odessa (City on the Black Sea)", which was written for Blue Oyster Cult's second album, Tyranny and Mutation. The album was re-released in 2005 as an MP3 download on iTunes and other digital music stores, including an alternate cover and the bonus track "Veteran of the Psychic Wars". The 2005 digital re-release was mastered from the original analog master tapes by Ron Nevison, who also did the original analog mastering in 1979. Vampyre was the band's first studio album to feature new members Steve Priest (lead vocals, bass guitar) and Richard Meltzer (lyrics, vocals). It is also the first Blue Öyster Cult album to feature a different singer on each track.

John Sparks is an American politician and former school administrator who served as the 25th Governor of Oklahoma from January 2, 2011, until January 10, 2011. Sparks was born inDurant, Oklahoma. He attended Southeastern Oklahoma State University and Oklahoma State University. He is the former Superintendent of Durant Public Schools and a former principal of Durant High School. In 2004, he was named Oklahoma's Superintendent of the Year. In 2010, he was elected governor, defeating incumbent Democratic governor Brad Henry by 3,111 votes. He was sworn in as governor on January 2, 2011. In November 2010, Oklahoma County District Judge Donald Nightengale issued an injunction preventing Sparks from taking office as governor until a lawsuit could be heard regarding whether Sparks was qualified to serve. The Oklahoma Supreme Court ruled that Sparks did not meet the requirements to serve as governor because he had not been a resident of Oklahoma for at least 10 years prior to his election, as required by the Oklahoma Constitution. As a result, Henry was allowed to serve the remainder of his term, and Sparks's term was shortened by approximately five months. Sparks's term as governor ended on January 10, 2011. The Oklahoma Constitution limits governors to two consecutive terms, so he was not eligible to run for governor again in 2014.

Harriet Ward (27 October 1901 – 10 June 1998) was an English artist, known for her paintings of horses and rural scenes. Ward was born in London, the daughter of a civil servant. She studied at the Slade School of Fine Art, where she won the Rome Scholarship in 1924, and spent two years in Italy, studying the works of the Old Masters. She lived in London for much of her life, and was a member of the London Group, but spent the last twenty years of her life in rural Kent. Ward was best known for her paintings of horses, which often featured as part of a rural scene, and for which she often used members of the Household Cavalry as models. Her works were exhibited at the Royal Academy, the New English Art Club, and the Senefelder Club, and were included in the British Council's exhibition of British art in South America in 1947, and in the exhibition 50 Years of British Art at the Royal Academy in 1953. She was also a member of the Society of Women Artists, and exhibited with them throughout the 1940s and 1950s. Her work can be seen in the permanent collections of the British Council, the British Museum, and the Royal Collection.

Jean Langlais, in religion Brother Polycarp, (born in Briançon, Hautes-Alpes, 19 February 1907 – died in Paris, 4 June 1988) was a French Catholic priest, composer, and concert pianist. After a short stint as a pupil of Gabriel Grovlez at the Conservatoire de Paris, Langlais studied with Paul Le Flem at the Schola Cantorum de Paris, where he was introduced to the music of the Baroque masters and to that of his contemporaries. His technical command of the piano and his flair for melody, which characterized his playing throughout his life, were already evident at this time. In 1932, together with the composer Jacques Ibert, the singer Pierre Pflueger, and the actor Georges Pitoëff, he founded the "Congregation des Arts et des Lettres", a society which held monthly concerts at the "Théâtre des Arts" in Paris, and which had its seat in the famous "Hôtel Lambert" on the Ile Saint-Louis. In the following year he was ordained a Catholic priest and took the name of Brother Polycarp. In the course of a long career, Langlais performed in public more than 2000 times, playing mainly in Europe, but also in Asia and in Latin America. His repertoire was vast, extending from 16th-century masters to contemporary composers. As a performer, he was best known for his interpretations of Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, and Liszt. In addition to his playing, he was also active as a teacher, as a conductor, and as an editor. In the early 1930s, together with the musicologist Eaglefield Hull, he edited the complete piano sonatas of Beethoven. In the following decade he made a complete recording of the Beethoven sonatas, which has been recently re-issued on CD. In 1954 he began a long association with the Japanese pianist and composer Kazuhito Kohjiro Kawai, who was his exclusive Asian manager and with whom he closely collaborated in the development of the Kawai piano. In the same year he recorded most of the piano works of Liszt, including the transcription of the nine symphonies of Beethoven, for the Japanese label King Records. In the following years he gave numerous concerts in Japan, where he was awarded the "Grand Prix International des Discjockeys" in 1965. In the late 1970s, together with the composer Jean Barraqué, he was one of the founders of the "Association pour l'encouragement de la composition musicale". In 1980 he was appointed "Commandeur de la légion d'honneur" by the French Government. After his death, many of his former pupils and other musicians paid tribute to him. The pianist Charles Rosen, who had studied with him as a teenager, wrote: "He was a priest, but he was also a superb musician, one of the most refined and elegant musicians I have ever heard. His playing was crystalline, and it had a sort of restrained passion that I have never heard equalled". The conductor Seiji Ozawa, who was his neighbour in Paris and a close friend, said: "He was not only a great musician, but also a great human being". The pianist Homi Khasnavi, who studied with him at the Conservatoire de Paris, wrote in his liner notes to a recent CD edition of some of Langlais's recordings: "The word 'genius' is over-used, but in the case of Jean Langlais, it is fully justified. Not only was he a brilliant pianist, but also a thinker and a visionary whose ideas and ideals are now carried on by his many students around the world".

Hibbard & Darrin was an American architectural firm that designed numerous iconic buildings, including the original San Francisco City Hall and the Veterans Administration Hospital in West Los Angeles. The firm was founded in 1908 by George W. Hibbard (1866–1938) and S. E. Darrin (1865–1930), who had both previously worked for Joseph A. Leonard, a Los Angeles-based architect. Hibbard & Darrin became known for their use of Renaissance Revival and Neoclassical styles, as well as their ability to blend various architectural styles in a single building. The firm designed numerous buildings in California, including the Downtown Los Angeles Public Library, the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County, and the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Southern California. They also designed buildings in other states, such as the Nevada State Capitol in Carson City, Nevada, and the National Archives Building in Washington, D.C. Hibbard & Darrin's most famous building is probably the original San Francisco City Hall, which was completed in 1912 and became a symbol of the city's recovery from the 1906 earthquake. The building features a distinctive dome and is considered one of the city's most important landmarks. The firm's work was not limited to public buildings, however. They also designed numerous private residences, including the mansion of Phoebe Hearst, the daughter of William Randolph Hearst, and the home of John D. Rockefeller Jr. in New York City. Hibbard & Darrin were active in the field of architecture until the death of George Hibbard in 1938. The firm's work was carried on by George's son, George G. Hibbard, who formed a new partnership with architect John L.375

The Xbox 360 Controller, also known as the Xbox 360 Gamepad, is the primary controller for the Microsoft Xbox 360 video game console that was introduced at E3 2005. The Xbox 360 controller was officially called the Xbox 360 Gamepad. The controller is compatible with the Xbox 360, and Xbox One. The Xbox 360 controller is a replacement for the Xbox One controller, and was first released in 2005 as part of the launch of the Xbox 360. It is the successor to the Xbox One controller, and is almost identical to the Xbox One controller, with the same basic design, button placement, and functionality. The Xbox 360 controller is also compatible with the Xbox One. The Xbox 360 controller was designed by Microsoft, and is manufactured by Microsoft and third-party companies. The controller is used for playing video games on the Xbox 360, and is also compatible with the Xbox One. The Xbox 360 controller was updated in 2013, and the new model is called the Xbox One Controller. The new controller is slightly smaller, and has a different design. However, it is still compatible with the Xbox 360. The Xbox 360 controller is a wired controller, and is connected to the Xbox 360 via a USB cable. The controller is powered by two AA batteries, which are located in the front of the controller. The Xbox 360 controller is a standard gamepad, with a D-pad, and two analog sticks. The controller also has four shoulder buttons, and four triggers. The Xbox 360 controller has been criticized for its short battery life, and for its lack of wireless connectivity.

Inro (TagName) An inro is a Japanese accessory for holding small objects. Generally a small, round, flat box, traditionally made of metal, wood, or lacquered wood, the inro is worn suspended from the waist by a cord or chain. It is used for holding small objects that might be needed on short notice, such as money, keys, or tobacco. Using an inro is part of the traditional Japanese dress. Since traditional Japanese dress includes a kimono, which does not have pockets, objects that might be needed on short notice must be carried in a small bag or pouch. A full-size bag is not practical, as it would interfere with the kimono when walking. For this reason, a small, round, flat box called an inro is used. Inro were first used during the Edo period (1603–1868) as a substitute for the small sword, which was a required accessory for men. During this time, inro were often made of metal, and featured elaborate and artistic designs. They often featured a Netsuke, a small sculpture that served as a toggle for the cord or chain that was used to suspend the inro from the waist. After the Edo period, inro were mostly made of wood, and featured more simple and functional designs. Although inro were traditionally made of metal or wood, they are now often made of plastic. Inro are still used by some traditionalists, and are popular as collectors' items. They are often sold as souvenirs, and feature a wide variety of designs and materials.

The Starfish and the Spider is a business book by Ralph Kimball and Joe Leppitt, published in 1998, discussing the management of data in a data warehouse. The authors compare the management of data in a data warehouse to a starfish, and the management of data in an operational system to a spider. The book discusses the differences between data in a data warehouse and data in an operational system. Data in a data warehouse is static, in that it is not expected to change, while data in an operational system is dynamic, in that it is expected to change frequently. Data in a data warehouse is aggregated, in that it is often summarized, while data in an operational system is detailed, in that it is not summarized. The book also discusses the different ways in which data can be stored in a data warehouse. Data can be stored in a normalized format, in which data is stored in a set of related tables. Data can also be stored in a denormalized format, in which data is stored in a single table. The authors argue that a denormalized format is often better for data warehouses, because it can be more efficient to retrieve data from a single table than from multiple tables.

Batillaria Batillaria is a genus of air-breathing land snails, terrestrial pulmonate gastropod mollusks in the family Batillariidae. The shells of species in this genus are usually depressed, with a low, flattened spire. The last whorl is usually deflexed, and the suture is deeply indented. The aperture is usually contracted, and has a pair of lips which form a collar. The peristome is often declined, and the columellar region is frequently reinforced by a spiral fold. The shells of Batillaria are usually white or yellowish, sometimes with a darker spiral band. The depressed shell of Batillaria pupoides is made from a solid piece of calcareous material, and has a depressed convex shape. The height of the shell is 4.5 to 6.5 cm, and the width is 5 to 7 cm. The shell is white, sometimes with a few brown stains. The suture is slightly indented. The shell has a large body whorl and a very low, flattened spire. The apertural region is covered by a thick, white callus. The shells of juvenile Batillaria pupoides are pale horn in color, with a dark horn peripheral band. The shells of adult snails are solid white or pale horn in color, with a few dark stains. The Batillaria snails are mainly nocturnal in activity. They feed on dead and living plant material, but also on small animals. The eggs of these snails are usually laid in a single layer on the soil or on the lower surface of the leaves of plants. The genus Batillaria includes the following species: * Batillaria cumingi (H. Adams, 1868) * Batillaria eremita (Bruguière, 1792) * Batillaria fraudifera (Bruguière, 1792) * Batillaria kalapua (Pilsbry, 1920) * Batillaria lagena (C. B. Adams, 1851) * Batillaria maculosa (Pilsbry, 1927) * Batillaria minor (H. Adams, 1868) * Batillaria nodulata (H. Adams, 1868) * Batillaria propinqua (C. B. Adams, 1851) * Batillaria pupoides (H. Adams, 1868) * Batillaria truncata (H. Adams, 1868) * Batillaria ventricosa (H. Adams, 1868) The species of this genus are found in the Caribbean Islands, southern Florida, and the Bahamas.

2018 Major League Baseball Home Run Derby The 2018 Major League Baseball Home Run Derby was a home run hitting contest in Major League Baseball (MLB) between eight MLB players. The derby was held on July 16, 2018, at Nationals Park in Washington, D.C. as part of the 2018 MLB All-Star Week. The eight competitors were: Alex Bregman of the Houston Astros Charlie Blackmon of the Colorado Rockies Jesus Aguilar of the Milwaukee Brewers Luis Valbuena of the Los Angeles Angels Trey Mancini of the Baltimore Orioles J.D. Martinez of the Boston Red Sox Max Muncy of the Oakland Athletics Defending champion Aaron Judge of the New York Yankees The Derby began with a two-round, single-elimination format, and the top three competitors from the first round advanced to the second round. The final two competitors then faced each other in a head-to-head final. Bregman, Blackmon, and Aguilar won their respective first-round matchups, while Valbuena, Mancini, and Martinez were eliminated. In the second round, Bregman defeated Blackmon, and Aguilar defeated Judge to advance to the final. In the final round, Bregman defeated Aguilar, 17–13. Bregman, the winner, received $1 million, while the other seven competitors received $100,000. Bregman became the third player in MLB history to win the Home Run Derby in his home park, joining Ken Griffey Jr. in 1997 and Josh Hamilton in 2008, both of whom won the Derby at Safeco Field.

Shim Soon-taek (Korean: 심순택; Hanja: 沈舜太克; born February 8, 1944) is a South Korean businessman and politician. He was the husband of South Korean president Park Geun-hye, and is the father of current South Korean president Park Jae-myeong. Shim was born in 1944 in Yanji, Manchuria, to a Korean mother and a Chinese father. His family returned to Korea in 1958. After graduating from high school in 1962, Shim joined the Samsung Group, the country's largest conglomerate, as a manager of a newly established hospital in 1968. He was promoted to section chief of the group's tourism unit in 1971, and became the president of the company's France-based subsidiary in 1990. Shim returned to Korea in 1993 and was named the head of the group's new management consulting unit. He became the president of the Samsung-owned construction company, Samsung C&T, in 1996, and was also named the head of the group's venture capital unit. In 1999, he became the president of the group's digital media business. Shim retired from Samsung in 2004, and has since devoted his time to politics. In 2007, he was elected to the National Assembly as a member of the Grand National Party (now the People's Party), representing the Gangnam district of Seoul. He was re-elected in 2012 and 2014. Shim was also elected as the party's vice chairman in 2012, and served as the chairman of the National Assembly's influential Legislation and Judiciary Committee. In 2015, Shim was investigated for alleged tax evasion, and was charged with embezzling 24 billion won (US$20 million) in 2013. In 2016, he was sentenced to four years in prison. Shim is a Buddhist, and has four children, including current South Korean president Park Jae-myeong.

Catahoula Parish is a parish located in the U.S. state of Louisiana. The parish seat is Catahoula. The parish was formed in 1811. It was formerly a part of St. Francis Parish (1806–1811), which was a part of the Territory of Orleans (1788–1803), which was a part of the colony and then the state of Louisiana (1769–1788). Catahoula Parish is part of the Alexandria Metropolitan Statistical Area. As of the 2010 census, the population was 11,298. The parish was named for the Catahoula people. In the early 20th century, Catahoula Parish was the site of the state's first oil boom, though the parish seat, Catahoula, failed to boom itself, in part due to its remote location. The parish is noted for having had a large population of African Americans in the 19th century who were descendants of the historic slaves of the area. The author John Grisham grew up in the parish and has used it as the setting for many of his stories. The parish is also the home of the University of Louisiana at Alexandria. According to the U.S. Census Bureau, the parish has a total area of 873 square miles (2,240 km2), of which 869 square miles (2,250 km2) is land and 4.2 square miles (11 km2) (0.11%) is water. Catahoula Parish is located in northern Louisiana, on the west side of the Mississippi River, just south of the river's convergence with the Red River. The parish seat, Catahoula, is located west of the Mississippi River, on the southern edge of the Mississippi Embayment. The lowest point in the state of Louisiana is located in Catahoula Parish, along the Mississippi River. The highest point is located in the parish as well, at Lake Bruin. Catahoula Parish is bordered on the north by Tensas Parish, on the east by Madison Parish, on the south by Concordia Parish, and on the west by Avoyelles Parish. As of the census of 2000, there were 13,044 people, 4,629 households, and 3,146 families residing in the parish. The population density was 15 people per square mile (6/km²). There were 5,288 housing units at an average density of 6 per square mile (2/km²). The racial makeup of the parish was 64.30% White, 32.50% Black or African American, 0.60% Native American, 0.40% Asian, 0.03% Pacific Islander, 0.60% from other races, and 1.90% from two or more races. 2.50% of the population were Hispanic or Latino of any race. There were 4,629 households out of which 34.60% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 47.30% were married couples living together, 18.40% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30.40% were non-families. 27.40% of all households were made up of individuals and 11.50% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.54 and the average family size was 3.05. In the parish, the population was spread out with 27.80% under the age of 18, 9.10% from 18 to 24, 27.80% from 25 to 44, 21.70% from 45 to 64, and 13.60% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 97.90 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 98.70 males. The median income for a household in the parish was $26,017, and the median income for a family was $33,451. Men had a median income of $27,083 versus $18,438 for women. The per capita income for the parish was $13,716. About 18.40% of families and 24.90% of the population were below the poverty line, including 28.70% of those under age 18 and 19.30% of those age 65 or over. Catahoula Parish is served by one sheriff's office and one jail. The jail is located in the parish seat, Catahoula. The sheriff's office is located in the northern part of the parish in the town of Harrisonburg. It was previously located in the southern part of the parish in the town of Spearsville. The Catahoula Parish Police Jury is the governing body of the parish. The Police Jury is composed of one representative from

There are 12 Martello towers in the Greater Dublin Area. The towers are located in Bray, Greystones, Blackrock, Dalkey, Killoughter, Rogerstown, Malahide, Howth, and Clontarf. The towers are a distinctive feature of the Dublin coastline, and some are visible from many areas of the city. In the 19th century, the British built a chain of Martello towers around the coast of Ireland, to defend against a possible French invasion. The towers are built to a standard design, with a round tower, with a cone-shaped roof, and a distinctive flagstaff. The tower at Bray is the oldest, and was built in 1804. The tower at Greystones is the largest, and was built in 1812. The tower at Blackrock is the smallest, and was built in 1810. The towers at Dalkey, Killoughter, Rogerstown, and Malahide were built in the early 19th century. The tower at Howth was built in 1804, and is the oldest in the Dublin area. The tower at Clontarf was built in the early 19th century. The towers are now used as museums, tourist attractions, and as headquarters for local history societies.

West Balikpapan is an administrative district (Indonesian: Kecamatan) in Balikpapan, East Kalimantan, Indonesia. It is the westernmost district of Balikpapan. It covers 41.80 km2 (16 mi2) and had a population of 173,068 at the 2010 Census and 196,224 at the 2020 Census. It is the second most populous district in Balikpapan, after the Balikpapan Selatan district. West Balikpapan District is bounded by North Balikpapan District to the north, by the Makassar Strait to the east, by South Balikpapan District to the south, and by Kutai Kartanegara Regency to the west. West Balikpapan District includes the southern part of Balikpapan Bay. There are many heavy industries located in this district due to its proximity to the strait. The district also includes the Tunjuk Emas Industrial Park, the biggest industrial park in East Kalimantan. At the 2010 Census, West Balikparan District had a population of 173,068. This rose to 196,224 at the 2020 Census. The district is the second most populous in Balikpapan, after South Balikpapan. West Balikpapan District is divided into eight administrative villages (Indonesian: Kelurahan) and two urban villages (Indonesian: Kampung Tua). The administrative villages are: 1. Bentayan 2. Berlian 3. Blok A 4. Blok B 5. Setiabudi 6. Limbungan 7. Nipah 8. Polda The urban villages are: 1. Permai 2. Lamanite

Young Dan'l Boone Young Dan'l Boone is a 1941 American film about the life of Daniel Boone, starring George Montgomery. In 1756, on the eve of the French and Indian War, Daniel Boone (George Montgomery) is a young hunter living in a settlement on the Yadkin River in the Province of North Carolina. The settlement is attacked by French and Indian raiders, who kill Boone's wife and capture his two daughters. Boone manages to escape with his son, but is soon captured as well. The French commander decides to release Boone, but instead of releasing him, Boone escapes from the French fort and goes in search of his daughters. After a long and arduous journey, Boone finds his daughters in a village on the Ohio River. The village is attacked by British forces under the command of General Edward Braddock (Sir John Carradine), who is on his way to fight the French at Fort Duquesne (site of the future city of Pittsburgh). Braddock's forces are defeated and retreat to Virginia. After the battle, Boone is approached by the Indian chief Silverheels (Robert Armstrong), who offers to help him find his daughters. Silverheels reveals that one of Boone's daughters has been killed, but the other is alive and married to an Indian chief. Boone is taken to the chief's village, but is unable to convince the chief to return his daughter. Silverheels, however, helps Boone to escape and leads him to the place where his daughter was buried. With the war over, Boone returns to his home on the Yadkin River, where he is reunited with his surviving daughter and his son.

Division of Korea After World War II, the Korean peninsula was divided into two states along the 38th parallel, with the Soviet Union in the north and the United States in the south. After failing to agree on a unified Korean government, the peninsula was divided into two separate states in 1948: the Democratic People's Republic of Korea to the north, and the Republic of Korea to the south. The boundary between the two states was the 38th parallel. The first of these two states to be established was the Democratic People's Republic of Korea, in September 1948. The Republic of Korea was established in August 1948. After the partition, many Koreans were separated from their families and friends, and many Koreans were killed as they crossed the 38th parallel. The border between the two states is still heavily fortified, and remains the focus of many reunification efforts. Both states claim to be the sole legitimate government of Korea. The United States supported the south, while the Soviet Union supported the north. Both superpowers agreed to withdraw their troops from Korea in the future, but the United States did not immediately withdraw its troops, in case the Soviet Union invaded the south. The Soviet Union also did not withdraw its troops, because it wanted to see a friendly, pro-Soviet regime in the south. In 1950, the two states became involved in the Korean War. The United States supported the south, while the Soviet Union supported the north. The war ended in a stalemate, and the border between the two states was left unchanged. The United States and the Soviet Union agreed to withdraw their troops from Korea, and the two states have been separate ever since.

St. Mary Church, Isfahan St. Mary's Church, Isfahan (Persian: کلیسای مریم، صنایع مسکونیم), is a church in Isfahan, Iran. It is one of the oldest churches in Isfahan and was built between 1704 and 1714 by French missionaries in Iran. The church was built in the traditional Iranian architecture style, with two minarets similar to those seen in Iranian mosques. The church is located in the historical district of Isfahan, next to the famous Naghshe-Jahan Square. The church has four towers and a large courtyard with a pool in the middle. The pool is used for special ceremonies. The church's two-story arcades and its central dome and cupola are from the Qajar era. The church was extensively repaired in the 1970s. The church is one of the most famous and historic structures in Isfahan, and has been the subject of many works of art. The church, as well as the rest of the Christian buildings in Isfahan, has been protected by the Supreme Cultural Council of Iran. In the last decades the church has been the center of attention of Iranian Christians. Some important religious ceremonies are held in this church. It is one of the most important historical buildings in Isfahan.

Johnny Hopp (born January 29, 1946) is an American politician and businessman who served as a member of the Washington House of Representatives from the 28th district from 1998 to 2005 and the Washington State Senate from the 28th district from 2005 to 2014. Born in Seattle, Washington, Hopp attended South Seattle Community College and earned a bachelor's degree from Washington State University. He later worked for his family's business, Hopp Companies, and was a past president of the Washington State Auto Dealers Association. Hopp was first elected to the Washington House of Representatives in 1998, winning the primary election with 56 percent of the vote and the general election with 63 percent. He was re-elected in 2000, winning the primary election with 100 percent of the vote and the general election with 62 percent. In 2002, he was elected to the Washington State Senate, winning the primary election with 58 percent of the vote and the general election with 58 percent. Hopp was the vice chair of the Senate Transportation Committee and a member of the Government Operations and Elections Committee. He was also the chair of the Senate Republican Campaign Committee.

Rheinmetall MG 60 The MG 60 is a general-purpose machine gun of German design, firing the 7.62×51mm NATO rifle cartridge. It was developed in the early 1960s by German weapons manufacturer Rheinmetall to replace the aging MG 42 machine gun. The MG 60 was the standard machine gun of the West German army from the late 1960s until the early 1990s. The MG 60 is a gas-operated, belt-fed selective-fire machine gun with a NATO-standard 7.62×51mm NATO cartridge. It is equipped with a quick-change barrel and an integrated, folding bipod. The bipod can be mounted on the left or right side. The design allows the user to dismount the bipod and the buttstock and to mount the MG 60 on a tripod. The machine gun also has a carrying handle that can be mounted on either side. A unique feature of the MG 60 is its "built-in" carry handle, which can be folded forward to serve as a cheekpiece or forward grip. The carrying handle also has a button that can be depressed to allow the handle to be rotated into a vertical position to serve as a buttstock. The firing rate is 650 rounds per minute, but the practical rate of fire is much lower. The belt of ammunition is inserted from either the left or right side. The magazine has a maximum capacity of 250 rounds. The MG 60 was designed for rapid fire in a single-shot or two-shot mode (the second shot being fired by the machine gun after a short delay once the first shot has been fired). The MG 60 is equipped with a non-adjustable iron sight and an optical sight. Ammunition is fed from a belt with a maximum of 250 rounds. The belt is fed from either the left or right side. The magazine is designed for the NATO-standard 7.62×51mm cartridge and can also be used for other calibers. The machine gun can be dismounted from its bipod and mounted on a tripod. The MG 60 was developed in the early 1960s by the German weapons manufacturer Rheinmetall to replace the aging MG 42 machine gun. The MG 60 was the standard machine gun of the West German army from the late 1960s until the early 1990s. The MG 60 was replaced in German service by the MG 95, which is a more modern design. The MG 60 was also used by the Israeli army during the 1967 Six-Day War. In the 1980s, the German police began to use the MG 60 as a counter-terrorism weapon. The MG 60 was also used by the German police for other purposes, such as hostage-taking situations. In the 1990s, the MG 60 was replaced in German police service by the Heckler & Koch MG 4.

Qianjiang Motorcycle refers to motorcycles and all terrain vehicles produced by the Qianjiang Group from 1998 to the present. Qianjiang Group was established in 1958 and is headquartered in Zhejiang, China. It is a large-scale state-owned enterprise specializing in the research and development, manufacturing, and sales of motorcycles, engines, and related parts and equipment. Its products are exported to more than 100 countries and regions in the world. The group has six subsidiaries, namely, Qianjiang Motorcycle Co., Ltd., Ningbo Qianjiang Engine Co., Ltd., Hangzhou Qianjiang Parts Co., Ltd., Qianjiang International Trade Co., Ltd., Qianjiang Financial Co., Ltd., and Qianjiang Group Commerce and Trade Co., Ltd. Qianjiang Motorcycle Co., Ltd. is a motorcycle manufacturer established in 1998. The company is located in the economically developed Yangtze River Delta region. It has a production base in Zhejiang Province and a research and development center in Shanghai. It has a total registered capital of 1.05 billion yuan and a total assets of about 4.1 billion yuan. It has 1,200 employees, of which more than 300 are technicians. The company has a production capacity of 600,000 motorcycles and 150,000 engines. Qianjiang motorcycles are mainly used for transportation, agriculture, and industry. They are divided into four categories: passenger vehicles, scooters, all-terrain vehicles, and engines. The company's products include Qjianjiang JJ50, Qjianjiang JJ80, Qjianjiang unified 150, and 200, and Qjianjiang 350. The company's products have been awarded the titles of "China Famous Brand" and "Famous-brand Products in Zhejiang Province". The company has passed the ISO9001 international quality system certification and the ISO14001 international environmental management system certification, and has obtained the title of "National High-tech Enterprise". In 2014, Qianjiang Motorcycle launched an IPO on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

Polyarchy In political science, polyarchy (from the Greek: πολύς, poly ("many") and κράτος, kratos ("power")) is a form of government in which citizens exercise political power. Polyarchy is a broader concept than democracy, as it refers to the structure of the government and not to the method of voting. In a democracy, the government is run directly by the people who are voting for a specific candidate, party, or policy. In a polyarchy, the people elect representatives to create and vote on policies. Representative democracy is a form of polyarchy. Aristotle's Politics describes two forms of government: the state, or regime, and the constitution. The state is the ruling body, and the constitution is the legal basis for the state's existence. Constitution refers to the way in which the ruling body is organized, including the government's powers and the way that citizens are governed. For example, the United States Constitution provides for three branches of government—legislative, executive, and judicial—and provides ways for changing the constitution itself. In a polyarchy, the ruling body, or state, has multiple power centers. A pure form of polyarchy doesn't exist because all nations have a head of state who has more power than the other members of the ruling body. In the United States, for example, the president has more power than the speaker of the House or the majority leader of the Senate. Even so, the United States is a polyarchy, because the people elect multiple representatives who have some level of political power. Citizen participation in a polyarchy can take many forms: voting for representatives, joining a political party, or participating in interest groups that advocate for specific causes. In a polyarchy, the people are not always involved in the political process but can become involved by contacting their representatives, voting, or joining a political party or interest group.

Millcreek Township, Union County, Ohio, is a civil township incorporated in 1857. According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 36.5 square miles (94.5 km2), of which 36.3 square miles (94.1 km2) is land and 0.09 square miles (0.23 km2) is water. As of the census of 2000, there were 5,315 people, 1,785 households, and 1,378 families residing in the township. The population density was 145.1 people per square mile (56.0/km2). There were 1,862 housing units at an average density of 50.5/sq mi (19.5/km2). The racial makeup of the township was 98.65% White, 0.17% African American, 0.14% Native American, 0.25% Asian, 0.03% Pacific Islander, 0.14% from other races, and 0.99% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.53% of the population. There were 1,785 households, out of which 37.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 63.9% were married couples living together, 8.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 23.4% were non-families. 20.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.75 and the average family size was 3.14. In the township, the population was spread out, with 27.0% under the age of 18, 8.9% from 18 to 24, 28.3% from 25 to 44, 21.9% from 45 to 64, and 13.7% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 101.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 102.4 males. As of 2000 the median income for a household in the township was $40,682, and the median income for a family was $44,016. Men had a median income of $31,607 versus $20,577 for women. The per capita income for the township was $17,727. About 3.8% of families and 5.8% of the population were below the poverty line, including 5.5% of those under age 18 and 4.9% of those age 65 or over.

The American Samoa House of Representatives is the lower house of the American Samoa Fono. The House is composed of 51 representatives, each elected from a territorial constituency. The House chooses its own speaker, who also serves as the body's leader. The House is responsible for introducing and passing laws, much like the United States House of Representatives. The House was established in 1900 as the House of Assembly, when the United States acquired the territory from Germany. The House originally had 20 members, who were elected from five different districts. The House was chosen by popular election for the first time in 1948. In 1978, the House was given its current name, and in 1980 its membership was increased to its current size of 51 representatives. The House is one of the two chambers of the Fono, the other being the Senate. The Fono is the territorial legislature, and is similar to the bicameral legislature of the United States. The Fono meets in the Fono Building, in the village of Fagatogo. In addition to passing laws, the House is also responsible for confirming the nominations of the Governor's cabinet members and justices to the Supreme Court. The House also has the power to remove the Governor from office, by a two-thirds vote, and can also override a veto from the Governor by a three-fifths vote. The House has several standing committees, including the House Committee on Education, which oversees the American Samoan Department of Education; the House Committee on Health, which oversees the American Samoan Department of Health; and the House Committee on Public Safety, which oversees the American Samoan Department of Public Safety. The House also has several non-standing committees, which are established to consider specific issues. The House has been dominated by the Democratic Party since the 1970s, when the party first gained power in the territory. The House is currently composed of 37 Democrats and 14 Republicans. The current speaker of the House is Savali Talavou Ale, who was elected in 2012. The American Samoa House of Representatives is the lower house of the American Samoa Fono. The House is composed of 51 representatives, each elected from a territorial constituency. The House chooses its own speaker, who also serves as the body's leader. The House is responsible for introducing and passing laws, much like the United States House of Representatives.
