Fred Perrett (27 March 1927 – 14 June 2018) was an English professional footballer who played as a centre half in the Football League for Tranmere Rovers, Portsmouth and Southport, and in the Scottish Football League for Morton. Perrett was born in Liverpool in 1927. He began his career as a centre half with his local club, Liverpool Stanley, before joining Tranmere Rovers in 1949. He made his debut in the Football League the following year, and went on to make 128 appearances for the club, scoring eight goals. In 1955, he joined Portsmouth, where he won the Football League Third Division South championship in 1956–57. He played for the club in the Football League Second Division for a further three seasons, making 123 appearances and scoring five goals, before joining Southport in 1961. He stayed with the club for three seasons, making 72 appearances, and then joined Scottish club Morton in 1964. He returned to England to play for non-league Worcester City in 1966, and then became a coach at the club. Perrett also managed the club for a short period in the early 1970s.

Lolium perenne, also known as Lolium pratense or common ryegrass, is a perennial plant in the grass family Poaceae. It is native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa, but has become naturalized in the Americas. Lolium perenne is a widespread species used in lawns and for fodder. A common weed, it is often considered a nuisance species. Lolium perenne is a perennial grass with a tough wiry stem that can reach a height of 1.5 metres (5 ft). The stem is generally unbranched, but may have a few short branches. The spikelets are generally ovate or oblong, 2–3 mm (0.079–0.118 in) long, with three to seven florets. The glumes are 7–9 mm (0.275–0.354 in) long, much longer than the spikelets. The lower glume is three-lobed, while the upper glume is entire. The lemmas are 2–3 mm (0.079–0.118 in) long. The lower lemma is three-lobed, with the central lobe being the longest. The upper lemma is entire. The palea is 2–3 mm (0.079–0.118 in) long, with a keeled back. Lolium perenne is a pantropical and subtropical species that occurs in many countries in the world. It occurs in all of Europe, except for Iceland, Ireland, and parts of Russia. It also occurs in North Africa, the Middle East, Central and East Asia, Australia, and North and South America. In Europe, Lolium perenne occurs in grasslands, meadows, lawns, and waste places. It occurs in mountainous areas and in low-lying areas near the sea. It can grow in many different soil types, including sandy, loamy, and clay soils. It can grow in acidic, neutral, and basic soils. In Asia, Lolium perenne occurs in mountain meadows, forest edges, and wastelands. It occurs in Siberia and the Russian Far East. It can grow in acidic, neutral, and basic soils. In North America, Lolium perenne occurs in fields, meadows, pastures, lawns, and waste places. It occurs in the northeastern United States, the southeastern United States, the western United States, and Canada. It can grow in acidic, neutral, and basic soils. Lolium perenne is used for many purposes. It is used as a forage for livestock, as a lawn grass, and as a ground cover. It is also used in agriculture, landscaping, and in many other ways. Lolium perenne is a common weed in lawns, where it can grow in dense clumps. It is also a weed in agriculture, where it can grow in fields, meadows, and pastures. It can be difficult to control, as it can regrow from the roots. Lolium perenne is similar to other species of grass. It is often confused with Lolium multiflorum, which has similar characteristics. However, Lolium multiflorum has white flowers, while Lolium perenne has yellow flowers.

Angus Dun (May 21, 1810 – February 3, 1870) was a Scottish-born Canadian businessman and politician. Born in Aberdeen, Scotland, Dun was educated at Marischal College and then joined the British Army. In 1834, he was sent to Lower Canada as part of the 62nd Regiment of Foot. The following year, he was posted to Upper Canada where he settled in Montreal. In 1838, he married Catherine Stennett, a daughter of Captain John Nairne, of the 78th Highlanders, and they had four sons and four daughters. After the death of his first wife, he married Susan Smith, daughter of Thomas Molson of Montreal. In 1840, Dun was put in charge of the Montreal office of the British American Land Company which was a large shareholder in the Lower Canada railway company that was planning to build a railroad from Montreal to Toronto. In 1843, he became a director of the company, and in 1845 he was elected president. In 1854, he became the chairman of the board of directors. In 1847, Dun was elected to the Legislative Council of the Province of Canada for the Montreal division. He was re-elected in 1851 and was named to the Executive Council in 1853. In 1856, he was again elected to the Legislative Council. In 1867, he was appointed to the first Canadian Senate by Sir John A. Macdonald. He died in 1870 while visiting London, England.

Romano's Macaroni Grill is an American chain of Italian-themed restaurants founded in Texas in 1998 by restaurants entrepreneurs Phil Roberts and Mike Roberts. The company is based in Texas and has locations in the United States and Canada. The chain is known for its Italian-American cuisine, extensive menu, and relaxed atmosphere. The original restaurant was founded in Fort Worth, Texas, in 1998. The founders aimed to provide a casual Italian dining experience that was a alternative to more formal Italian restaurants. The restaurant's name is derived from its signature dish, Macaroni Grill (formerly Macaroni and Cheese), and from the Italian word for cheese, "formaggio." The restaurant's interior is designed to resemble an Italian village with a open kitchen, and the staff are encouraged to interact with the diners in a casual and friendly manner. The chain's first franchise location was opened in 2000 in Southlake, Texas, and the chain has grown through a mixture of company-owned and franchised locations. By 2004, the chain had grown to over 200 locations in the United States and Canada, and in 2014 it had grown to over 800 locations. The chain's US operations are based in Texas, and its Canadian operations are based in Ontario. The chain's menu features a variety of Italian-American dishes, including pastas, pizzas, salads, soups, and sandwiches. The chain's signature dish is its Macaroni Grill, which is a combination of penne pasta, grilled chicken, and a choice of cheese or tomato sauce. The chain also offers a variety of other pasta dishes, as well as a selection of salads, sandwiches, and pizzas. The chain's locations offer a full bar, and many locations offer a wine list with a selection of red and white wines. The chain's locations also offer a variety of non-alcoholic drinks, including soft drinks, coffee, and tea. The chain's locations are designed with a combination of booths and tables, and the decor is intended to create a casual and inviting atmosphere. The locations are typically open for lunch and dinner, and some locations offer a breakfast menu. The chain's locations are known for their customer service, and the staff are encouraged to interact with the diners in a friendly and courteous manner. The locations also offer a variety of amenities, such as free Wi-Fi, and some locations offer a loyalty program where diners can earn points for dining at the chain's locations.

George Dearnaley (11 February 1917 – 30 January 2013) was an English first-class cricketer who made his only appearance for Durham County Cricket Club in 1937, and then joined the Royal Air Force, serving as a pilot during the Second World War. Dearnaley was born in South Shields, Durham, England, the son of George Dearnaley senior (1886–1960), a shipyard draughtsman, and his wife, Annie Elizabeth (née Carr), who had married in 1910. He was educated at Jarrow Grammar School, then a secondary modern school in the town of Jarrow, in Tyne and Wear, and at South Shields High School, a grammar school in the town of South Shields. A right-arm fast bowler and right-handed batsman, Dearnaley made his first-class debut for Durham in the 1937 County Championship against Yorkshire at Bramall Lane in Sheffield. He took two wickets in Yorkshire's first innings of 252, and these were the only wickets of the match, as the match was abandoned without a ball being bowled in Durham's second innings. Dearnaley's two wickets were those of the Yorkshire openers, Percy Holmes and Frank Greenwood, both of whom were caught by William Henderson, the former England Test match wicket-keeper, who was Dearnaley's captain. Dearnaley had two brothers, one of whom, Gordon Dearnaley (1912–1999), also played first-class cricket for Durham, as well as Minor Counties cricket for Durham, and List A cricket for them, too. After a single first-class appearance, Dearnaley joined the Royal Air Force, where he served as a fighter pilot during the Second World War. He served with No. 19 Squadron, based at Duxford, Cambridgeshire, in April 1944, flying a Supermarine Spitfire. Dearnaley died at South Shields in January 2013, at the age of 95.

Riku Immonen (born 30 June 1988) is a Finnish professional ice hockey defenceman currently playing for Vaasan Sport in the Liiga. Immonen spent two seasons in North America playing major junior hockey for the Calgary Hitmen of the Western Hockey League (WHL) and was drafted by the Nashville Predators in the fifth round, 156th overall, in the 2006 NHL Entry Draft. After three seasons within the Predators organization, he was traded to the Columbus Blue Jackets in exchange for forward Kris Beech during the 2010–11 season. Internationally, Immonen has played for the Finnish national team at the junior and senior levels, and won a bronze medal at the 2009 World Championships. ## Playing career ### Junior Immonen began his junior career in 2004 with the Calgary Hitmen of the Western Hockey League (WHL). In his first season with the Hitmen, he recorded 7 goals and 22 points in 69 games, and was named the Hitmen's rookie of the year. He improved to 11 goals and 37 points in 2005–06, and was selected by the Nashville Predators in the fifth round, 156th overall, in the 2006 NHL Entry Draft. After being drafted, Immonen returned to the Hitmen for a third and final junior season in 2006–07. He recorded a career-high 16 goals and 53 points, and was named the Hitmen's defenceman of the year. He was also named to the WHL's second all-star team. ### Professional Following the 2006–07 season, Immonen joined the Predators' American Hockey League (AHL) affiliate, the Milwaukee Admirals. In his first professional season, he recorded 6 goals and 19 points in 78 games with the Admirals, and was named to the AHL's all-rookie team. In 2007–08, he appeared in 67 games with Milwaukee, scoring 10 goals and adding 30 assists, and was named to the AHL's second all-star team. Immonen made his NHL debut in 2008–09, appearing in five games with the Predators and registering two assists. He spent the majority of the season with the Admirals, scoring 9 goals and 39 points in 55 games. In the 2009 Calder Cup playoffs, he led the Admirals with 12 points in 16 games, and scored the series-winning goal in the deciding Game 6 of the Calder Cup Final. In 2009–10, Immonen played in 80 games with the Admirals, scoring 7 goals and adding 29 assists, while also appearing in 12 games with the Predators, registering one assist. He missed the playoffs due to a leg injury. On 1 April 2010, the Predators traded Immonen to the Columbus Blue Jackets in exchange for forward Kris Beech. After attending the Blue Jackets' training camp, he was assigned to their AHL affiliate, the Springfield Falcons, to begin the 2010–11 season. He appeared in 54 games with the Falcons, scoring 6 goals and adding 17 assists, and was named to the AHL's second all-star team for the second time. He also appeared in 18 games with the Blue Jackets, registering one goal and two assists. On 10 June 2011, the Blue Jackets re-signed Immonen to a one-year, two-way contract. He was assigned to the Blue Jackets' new AHL affiliate, the Springfield Falcons, for the 2011–12 season. He appeared in 65 games with the Falcons, scoring 7 goals and adding 30 assists, and was named to the AHL's second all-star team for the third time. He also appeared in 36 games with the Blue Jackets, registering 8 assists. On 4 July 2012, the Blue Jackets re-signed Immonen to a two-year, two-way contract. He was assigned to the Blue Jackets' AHL affiliate, the Springfield Falcons, for the 2012–13 season. He appeared in 37 games with the Falcons, scoring 4 goals and adding 15 assists, before being traded to the San Jose Sharks organization in exchange for a seventh-round draft pick in the 2014 NHL Entry Draft on 12 February 2013. He finished the season with the Sharks' AHL affiliate, the Worcester Sharks, appearing in 45 games and registering 10 points. After completing his contract with the Sharks, Immonen became a free agent. On 1 July 2014, he signed a one-year, two-way contract with the Minnesota Wild. He spent the 2014–15 season with the Wild's AHL affiliate, the Iowa Wild, appearing in 67 games and registering 8 goals and 29 points. On 11 May 2015, Immonen signed a two-year contract with Russian-based HC Neftekhimik Nizhnekamsk of the Kontinental Hockey League. After two seasons in the KHL, Immonen

Norton, Doncaster, is a village and civil parish in the English county of South Yorkshire. It is in the Doncaster borough, and is roughly coterminous with the area served by the Norton Comprehensive School. It is close to the A1, and is also served by the A19 and A630 roads. The M18 motorway passes through the parish, to the east of the village. The village lies on a natural aquifer, and has a number of springs, two of which are in the village centre. One of these is marked by a stone basin, which was once a horse trough. This feature gave the village its name, Norton, which means "North town" in Old English. The village is mentioned in the Domesday Book, as "Nortone". The parish church is dedicated to Saint Nicholas, and is a Grade II* listed building. It dates from the early 12th century, with later renovations. A school was built in the village in 1876, and was originally called the Norton Board School. It became a primary school in the late 1940s, and was renamed the Norton County Primary School in the 1970s. In the 1980s it became the Norton Comprehensive School, a secondary school with a sixth form. The village has two Methodist churches, a Catholic church, and a meeting house for the Society of Friends. Norton is also the home of the Doncaster Plantworks, a large industrial plant owned by Vesuvius UK, which manufactures refractory products. The plant was built in the 1950s, and has been extended several times since then. Norton has a large village green, with a war memorial. There is also a smaller green, called Fennyfields, at the south-west edge of the village. According to the 2011 census, the population of the civil parish was 3,325.

Lom Peak is a mountain in the state of Washington, United States. It is located in the Cascade Range, and is part of the Cascade Volcanic Arc. It is about 4,100 feet (1,600 m) in elevation. The peak is located in Skagit County, Washington, about four miles (6.4 km) north of the town of Hamilton. The mountain has an elevation of 4,100 feet (1,600 m), and is one of the most topographically prominent peaks in the state. It is located in the Cascade Volcanic Arc, a series of volcanoes that stretch from the Canadian border to the state of Oregon. The peak is a shield volcano, which means it has a low profile and is more resistant to erosion than other types of volcanoes. It is also a cinder cone, which means it is made up of loose cinders and other volcanic material. The cinders were likely ejected from the volcano during its eruptions. The peak is one of the most prominent peaks in the state of Washington. It is also one of the most topographically prominent peaks in the United States. It is part of the Cascade Volcanic Arc, a series of volcanoes that stretch from the Canadian border to the state of Oregon. The peak is located in Skagit County, Washington, about four miles (6.4 km) north of the town of Hamilton.

1865 in Australia Events 9 February – The final session of the Victorian Legislative Assembly is held before the members are elected to the new Parliament of Victoria, which will be the first Australian parliament to have a two-party system. 21 February – The Queensland Telegraph Line from Brisbane to Charters Towers is completed, enabling the first message to be sent from Brisbane to Charters Towers the following day. 8 March – The last British military unit to serve in Australia, the 40th (2nd Somersetshire) Regiment of Foot, leaves for India. 13 March – The Queensland Government is given the power to make railways. 4 May – The crew of the American barque William Dean, en route from Sydney to San Francisco, dynamites the ship in an unsuccessful attempt to sink it and claim the insurance. 16 June – The Great Northern Railway (Australia) is completed from Port Augusta to Far North South Australia. 3 July – The New South Wales Contingent, the first Australian military unit to serve in the British Empire's conflicts, leaves Sydney for New Caledonia to take part in the Second Opium War. 5 July – The first portion of the Northern Railway (Australia) is opened from Gawler to Kapunda in South Australia. 31 July – The Queensland Government's Railway Department is given control of the state's rail network. 1 October – The first Australian local government elections are held in the Victorian municipalities of Melbourne and Geelong, using the optional preferential voting system. 3 October – The Intercolonial Exhibition of Australasia is held in Melbourne. 14 November – The New South Wales Parliament passes the New South Wales Electoral Act, which introduces compulsory voting for male residents of the state. 20 November – The first Australian railway line of the New South Wales Government Railways opens from Redfern to Campbell's Wharf, Sydney. 3 December – The first section of the Palmerston and Pine Creek Railway in the Northern Territory is opened. 6 December – The Queensland Government passes the Education Act, which introduces free, compulsory and secular education for children aged from six to fifteen years.

Monclova Monclova (Monclova de Canavos) is a city in the northern Mexican state of Coahuila. It is located in the southeast of the state, about 30 km (19 mi) from the border with Texas, United States. The city serves as the seat of the Monclova Municipality, with which it is not coextensive. According to the 2020 Census, Monclova has a population of 257,812. The city was founded in 1570 by Spanish explorer Francisco de Aguirre. He called it "Pueblo de los Tanos". In the early 17th century, it was given the name "Monclova" after the Viceroy of New Spain, Juan de Monclova. The city was part of the Viceroyalty of New Spain from its foundation until 1821, when it became part of the First Mexican Republic. In 1869, it became the capital of the state of Coahuila and Texas. Monclova is an important industrial city in Mexico, with a large steel mill (ArcelorMittal Monclova) and a chemical plant (Dow Chemical) that are major employers. The city is also the home of the baseball team, "Ciclónes de Monclova", a team that plays in the "Zona de Occidente" (West Zone) of the Mexican League. The city has a baseball stadium, "Estadio Monclova", which has been home to the Ciclónes since 1940. Every year in January, the city holds an annual meeting of the "Feria Nacional del Rancho". In 2005, the city received the visit of Pope John Paul II, who came to Monclova to conduct the canonization of two Catholic saints, Juan Diego and Teresa of Jesus, at the "Plaza de la Virgen de Guadalupe". In 2009, the city received the visit of US President Barack Obama, who came to Monclova to meet with the Mexican President, Felipe Calderón. In 2016, the city received the visit of Pope Francis, who came to Monclova to conduct the canonization of two Catholic saints, Joséphine Maximilienne de Beauharnais and María de la Purísima Concepción, at the "Plaza de la Virgen de Guadalupe". In 2022, the city received the visit of the Spanish King Felipe VI, who came to Monclova to meet with the Mexican President, Andrés Manuel López Obrador. Monclova is served by the Monclova International Airport. In 2008, the city received the title of "City of Peace" from the United Nations. In 2010, the city was included in the list of "The 100 best cities to live in the world" by the magazine "Forbes". Charles Perceval, 7th Earl of Egmont (25 December 1711 – 30 May 1770) was an Anglo-Irish peer, the son of William Perceval and his wife Catherine Hamilton. He was born atYork Street, London, and spent his early years at his parents' house in Lincoln's Inn Fields, London. He was educated at Westminster School, an independent school in London, and at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he was admitted in 1728 as a fellow commoner. He graduated from Cambridge in 1732 with a Master of Arts. Perceval became the 7th Earl of Egmont on the death of his uncle, John Perceval, 6th Earl of Egmont, in 1748. As the eldest son of an eldest son, he succeeded to the earldom on the death of his father in 1748, having previously succeeded to the Irish barony of Lovel in 1727. On 21 April 1749, he married Catherine Bull (died 1786), the only daughter and heir of Richard Bull ofKirkstead, North Mymms, Hertfordshire. They had four children: * Charles, Lord Perceval (1756–60) * Charles Perceval, 8th Earl of Egmont (1756–1810) * Catherine Perceval (born and died 1757) * Honora Perceval (died 1798), who married Thomas Frederick.

Zu (731–810) was an 8th-century Japanese poet and monk who is best known for his ability to seamlessly integrate elements of Japanese and Chinese poetry. Zu was born in what is now the town of Kashiwazaki, Niigata, Japan. His real name was Utsunomiya no Michizane. He was a court poet in the Heian period (794–1185), and is famous for the "tanka" poetry form. His works appear in the anthology Shūi Wakashū. Zu was a priest at the temple of Joshokuji in Kashiwazaki. The temple was built by his father, who was a wealthy landowner, and was dedicated to Bodhisattva Fudo Myoo. In 794, Emperor Kanmu ordered the establishment of a system of provincial government. The provinces were divided into "kokucho" (provincial governments) and "docho" (sub-provincial governments). The governors and their deputies were appointed by the emperor. The "docho" were each headed by a "doshi", who was generally a local magnate. The most important "docho" was the "Daitō", which was the province in which the capital was located. The "Daitō" was further divided into " fu" and "zoku". The "fu" was the area within the city proper, while the "zoku" was the area outside the city. The "doshi" of the "Daitō" was the highest official in the province. He was generally a member of the " bureaus" and was appointed by the emperor. The "doshi" had many responsibilities, including tax collection, law enforcement, and military defense. He was also responsible for the construction and maintenance of public buildings, such as temples and shrines. The "doshi" was generally a member of the " bureaus", and was appointed by the emperor. Sydney lockout laws The Sydney lockout laws are a set of liquor laws in New South Wales, Australia, that restrict the service of alcohol in the Sydney central business district (CBD). They were introduced in February 2014 by the O'Farrell government in response to a number of violent alcohol-related deaths in the previous year. The laws restrict alcohol sales in CBD hotels, clubs, and bars to no later than 1:30 am, and the service of alcohol in the same establishments to no later than 3:00 am. The laws also restrict the number of venue licences for new and existing venues in the CBD to no more than 10 per year, and the number of dance licences to no more than 5 per year. The laws also require the state's Liquor & Gaming NSW regulatory authority to publish a register of licensed venues in the CBD, including their trading hours and the number of approved dance licences. The laws were passed by the New South Wales Parliament in November 2013, and came into effect on 1 February 2014. They were supported by the New South Wales government and the New South Wales Police Force, but opposed by the Australian Hotels Association, the Australian Licensed Club Association, and the Nightclub & Liquor Bar Association. The laws were designed to reduce alcohol-related violence in the CBD, and to improve the safety of patrons and the general public. The state government argued that the laws were necessary to address the problem of "alcohol-related violence, anti-social behaviour and abuse" in the city, and that they would "make Sydney a safer place for everyone". The laws were also designed to protect the state's night-time economy, and to create a safer environment for the city's nightlife. The laws have been controversial, and have been opposed by many businesses and individuals in the hospitality industry, as well as by some community groups and individuals. The laws have been supported by the New South Wales government and the New South Wales Police Force, who have argued that they are necessary to address the problem of alcohol-related violence in the city.

Unicase (also known as unicase, MixCase, mixed case, or casefolding) is the ability of some letter systems to write all letters, or certain letters, with either a lower or upper case letter. In most cases this refers to the ability to use either the upper or the lower case of the same letter. A unicase script is a writing system with a unicase base alphabet. Most writing systems are unicase, with notable exceptions including the Han script, Devanāgarī, and most abugidas. The basic Latin alphabet is unicase, as is the Greek alphabet. Cyrillic and the basic Hebrew alphabet are also unicase. Most letters in the unicase scripts are displayed in upper case in all caps settings, and lower case in lower case settings. However, some letters in unicase scripts are not Capitalized in all caps settings, such as the soft-gamma in Cyrillic, Ẽ in the Latin alphabet, and Ạ in the Greek alphabet. In some unicase scripts, notably the Arabic and Hebrew scripts, some letters (or all letters) have distinct shapes for upper and lower case, but are never joined with a superior diacritic to create a single letter. The Arabic and Hebrew scripts are referred to as "semicased" rather than unicase in this context. The term "unicase" was coined in 1969 by Peter R. Jones to describe the behavior of letters in the Latin and Greek alphabets. The term is sometimes confused with "lowercase", "upper case", or "case sensitive". A unicase alphabet is an alphabet that includes at most one letter for each sound, and whose letters are normally written in only one case. A unicase letter is a letter that can be represented by at most one character in a given alphabet. A unicase script is a script that uses only unicase letters, or that can be represented entirely by unicase letters from some alphabet. A unicase writing system is a writing system that uses only unicase letters, or that can be represented entirely by unicase letters from some alphabet. A unicase font is a font that includes only unicase letters. A unicase encoding is an encoding that maps letters to the same byte value in both the upper and lower case. A unicase keyboard is a keyboard that produces only unicase letters. A unicase character is a character that has the same form for both upper and lower case. A unicase word is a word that is formed from unicase letters only. A unicase text is a text that contains only unicase words.

Hungarian Ground Forces The Hungarian Ground Forces (Hungarian: Magyar Földtámadás) is the land warfare force of Hungary. The Hungarian Army (Hungarian: Magyar Honvédség) was the name of the Hungarian land forces from the early 20th century until the end of the Cold War, when the country was part of the Warsaw Pact. In 1989–1990 the Hungarian Army was reorganised and renamed the Hungarian Ground Forces. The name "Hungarian Army" is still in use in the English language and also appears in some official documents, although the Hungarian Ground Forces is the official name in Hungarian. Since the reorganisation of the army in 1989–1990, the Hungarian Ground Forces has consisted of three groups of troops: the Hungarian Defence Force (Hungarian: Magyar Honvédség), the Hungarian Internal Security Force (Hungarian: Magyar Béllőzö), and the National Protection Service (Hungarian: Ochranná Služba). These three groups were merged in 2004 and since then have been known as the Hungarian Defence Forces. The Hungarian Ground Forces is composed of 31 000 active personnel and has an additional 32 000 personnel in the reserves. It is led by the Chief of the General Staff of the Hungarian Defence Forces, who is subordinate to the Minister of Defence and the President of Hungary. Survivor is an American reality game show franchise, created by Vision Team Productions, in which a group of contestants are stranded in a remote location and must provide for themselves with minimal resources. The show was first broadcast on May 31, 2000, and is produced by Vision Team Productions in association with Survivor Productions, Inc., a subsidiary of CBS Entertainment. The show has been broadcast in over 100 countries and has also been adapted into a feature film and a video game. The series has won numerous awards, including twenty-one Emmy Awards and a Golden Globe Award. The series has been renewed for the 2022–23 season, making it the first season in the franchise to be produced in three separate decades. The original version of the series, Survivor, is based in the United States and was first broadcast on May 31, 2000, on CBS. The series was co-developed by Vision Team Productions in association with Survivor Productions, Inc., a subsidiary of CBS Entertainment. The original series is the only version of the show to have been filmed in the United States. In its first season, Survivor was hosted by Jim Jefferies and featured sixteen Americans competing in the Fijian island of Rotuma. The winner was Richard Hatch, who defeated the other finalists, Kimmi Kappenberg and Amy Bosley, in a 4–1 vote. The show has been filmed in numerous countries and territories throughout the world, including Argentina, Australia, Cambodia, China, Cook Islands, Fiji, France, Germany, India, Indonesia, Italy, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Puerto Rico, Russia, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Thailand, Turkey, the United States, and Vietnam. In addition to the original version, the franchise includes the derivative series Survivor: The Australian Castaway, which was filmed and broadcast in Australia, and Survivor South Africa, which was filmed and broadcast in South Africa. The franchise also includes the spin-off series Survivor: Blood against Water, which was filmed and broadcast in the United States and featured the original Survivor contestants competing against their loved ones. The series has also been adapted into a feature film, Survivor, and a video game, Survivor: The Video Game. The series has won numerous awards, including twenty-one Emmy Awards and a Golden Globe Award. In 2011, the series was ranked #33 on TV Guide's list of the "Top 60 Shows of All Time". In 2013, the series was honored with the Golden Popcorn Award for Best Reality Show at the 16th Annual Scream Awards. In 2015, the series was ranked #41 on Complexity Gaming's list of the "Most Complex TV Shows of All Time". In 2015, the series was ranked #90 on Empire's list of the "500 Greatest Movies of All Time". In 2016, the series was ranked #48 on TV Guide's list of the "Top 100 Shows of All Time". In 2018, the series won the People's Voice Award for Best Reality Show at the Webby Awards. In 2018, the series was ranked #80 on TV Guide's list of the "Top 100 Shows of All Time". In 2020, the series was ranked #24 on TV Guide's list of the "Top 100 Shows of All Time". In 2021, the series was ranked #37 on TV Guide's list of the "Top 100 Shows of All Time".

NRJ Lebanon is a Lebanese radio station that was launched in 1996 by the Lebanese branch of the French NRJ Group. The station is licensed by the Ministry of Information. The station's studios are located in Spears, Beirut. NRJ Lebanon is part of the NRJ Group, which is present in Europe, South America, Africa, and Asia. NRJ stands for the New Radio of Jean-Michel Cannade, the name of the founder of the NRJ Group. NRJ Lebanon is a hit radio station that plays the latest hits in English, Arabic, and French. The radio station has launched many talents into the music industry such as Elissa, Ragheb Alama, and Joseph Attieh. It is also known for its annual NRJ Music Tour, which is the biggest annual event in Lebanon. The tour has featured many international artists such as Mariah Carey, Chris Brown, Janet Jackson, and Justin Bieber. NRJ Lebanon is known for its commitment to social responsibility. The radio station has supported many social causes, including the fight against cancer, the promotion of blood donation, and the support of children with special needs. In 2009, NRJ Lebanon was named the Best Radio Station in Lebanon by the Murex d'Or Awards. In 2010, the station was named the Best Radio Station in the Middle East by the Arab Media Awards. In 2013, the station was named the Best Radio Station in Lebanon by the Murex d'Or Awards for the second time.

Explains It All is the second studio album by American rock band Jimmy Eat World, released on July 30, 1996, through Capitol Records. The album was produced by Jimmy Eat World and Mark Trombino, and was recorded at Big Fish Studios in Encinitas, California. Explains It All was Jimmy Eat World's first album to feature their current lineup, which had been in place since the band's previous album, Jimmy Eat World (1994). The album was also the band's first to be produced by Mark Trombino, who had previously produced the band's EP Jimmy Eat World (2.0). Explains It All was the band's first album to be released by a major record label, as their previous album had been released on the independent record label Big Wheel Recreation. Explains It All was released to generally positive reviews, and was the band's first album to chart. The album's lead single, "Don't Be Afraid", received significant radio play and was the band's first song to chart, peaking at No. 39 on the Billboard Mainstream Rock Tracks chart. In 2007, the band released a deluxe edition of Explains It All, which included a bonus CD with seven bonus tracks, as well as a DVD with a short film and various live performances. On May 13, 2016, the band performed the album in its entirety at the Casbah in San Diego, CA to celebrate the 20th anniversary of its release. Sir Wilfrid Laurier Park is a park in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. It is located at the corner of King Edward Avenue and Laurier Avenue in the Sandy Hill neighbourhood. The park is bounded on the west by the Rideau Canal. It was named for the former Prime Minister of Canada, Sir Wilfrid Laurier. In the early 20th century, the site was the location of several large weigh scales used by the Canadian Pacific Railway to weigh trains passing through Ottawa. The large concrete platforms on which the scales rested remain to this day and are used as a stage for concerts and plays. The park was created in the 1930s, with the assistance of the Federal District Commission (now the National Capital Commission). The Commission had the land expropriated from the Canadian Pacific Railway and then gave it to the City of Ottawa. The park has been the subject of a number of development proposals. In the early 1970s, the City of Ottawa proposed to build a new city hall on the site, as well as a new central library, and an expansion of the National Gallery of Canada. In the early 1980s, the Government of Ontario proposed to build a new provincial office complex on the site, in partnership with the City of Ottawa. In the late 1980s, a private developer proposed to build an office complex and a hotel on the site. In the 1990s, the City of Ottawa proposed to build a new city hall on the site, as well as a new central library. In the 2000s, the City of Ottawa proposed to build a new city hall on the site, as well as a new central library, and an expansion of the National Gallery of Canada.

Homer Elihu Royce (May 7, 1865 – May 10, 1971) was an American classical scholar, teacher, and writer. Royce was born in Franklin, Indiana, to Elihu and Mary Royce. After attending Franklin High School, he entered Indiana University in 1882. He received his A.B. in 1885, his A.M. in 1886, and his Ph.D. in 1889. He joined the faculty of the University of Kansas in 1889 as a professor of classics, where he remained until his retirement in 1939. Royce was the author of The Colophons of Greek Authors (1896), an important contribution to the study of the history of classical literature; The Goths in Spain (1897); The Date of the Olympic Games (1912); and The Royce Family in England and America (1914). He also edited the second edition of the standard college Greek dictionary, A Greek-English Lexicon, by Henry George Liddell and Robert Scott (with Sir Henry Bradley, 1897), and the fourth edition (with Sir Henry Bradley and C. T. Lewis, 1925). Royce was a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, a member of the American Philological Association, and a member of the National Academy of Sciences. He received honorary doctorates from Indiana University, the University of Kansas, and the University of Michigan. Royce died in Lawrence, Kansas, at the age of 106.

This Is Augustus Pablo "This Is Augustus Pablo" is a song written and recorded by the Jamaican musician Augustus Pablo under his Rockers International label. The track was produced by Pablo and featured on his album, This Is Augustus Pablo, released in 1975. The song was recorded at the Rockers International studio in Kingston, Jamaica. It is a musical tribute to Pablo's friend and fellow musician, James Brown, who had died the previous year. The song's title references the introduction to Brown's recorded performances, "This is James Brown, the hardest working man in show business. This is the James Brown Show." The song is noted for its atmospheric, percussion-driven sound, and its use of the talking blues style of singing, characteristic of early blues music. The song's lyrics recall the friendship between Pablo and Brown, and the influence that Brown had on the development of Pablo's music. "This Is Augustus Pablo" was released as a single in 1975, and was received positively by critics, who praised its musical style and production. The song has since been covered by other musicians, including the British rock band Deep Purple, who recorded a version for their 1974 album, Stormbringer. The song's title was used as the basis for the title of the 2002 documentary film This Is Augustus Pablo, directed by Craig Bailey. The film explores the life and career of Augustus Pablo, and includes interviews with musicians and producers who worked with him.

The Villanovan culture was a culture that developed in the Italian Peninsula between the end of the Bronze Age and the beginning of the Iron Age, in the first half of the 1st millennium BC. It takes its name from the site of Villanovan, an ancient village in the Italian province of Emilia-Romagna, near Bologna, where in 1881–82, a number of cemetery sites were discovered, with artifacts characteristic of the culture. The Villanovan culture was a significant influence on the later Etruscan civilization. The Villanovan culture emerged from the earlier Final Bronze Age (1300–1100 BC), as a result of the invasion of the peninsula by the Sea Peoples and the subsequent collapse of several Mycenaean-like centres in southern Italy. The Villanovan culture was part of the Tyrrhenian cultural horizon, which also included the contemporary cultures of the Etruscans, the Celtic Hallstatt culture, and the Greek colonial world of Magna Graecia. The Villanovan culture is distinguished from the preceding and contemporary Italian cultures by a number of characteristics, such as: - Use of cremation - dominance of tombs - good quality pottery - the presence of weapons - the absence of imported luxury goods The characteristic handmade pottery of the Villanovan culture was made from local clays, and often featured a red slip. The remains of the Villanovan culture have been found in many parts of Italy, especially in the area of Etruria (Etruscan League), in the Po Valley, in Campania, in Basilicata, and in Sicily. In the 9th century BC, the Villanovan culture was succeeded by the Etruscan civilization, which developed in the area of Etruria (Etruscan League) and in the Po Valley. In the 6th century BC, the Etruscan civilization was in turn succeeded by the Roman Republic. The Villanovan culture is the basis for the modern Western alphabet, which is based on the Etruscan letters, as the Etruscan civilization developed the first Western alphabet. The Villanovan culture is also the basis for the modern Western calendar, as the Etruscan civilization developed the first Western calendar. The Villanovan culture was a significant influence on the later Etruscan civilization, which developed in the area of Etruria (Etruscan League) and in the Po Valley. The Etruscan civilization was in turn a significant influence on the later Roman Republic, which developed in the area of Etruria and in the Po Valley.

La Merced Market (Spanish: Mercado de La Merced) is a traditional indoor market in Mexico City, located in the Merced neighborhood of the Cuauhtémoc borough, just north of the Historic Center. One of the oldest and largest markets in the city, it is best known for its variety of fresh produce, meat, and seafood. The market is housed in a two-story building with a large central courtyard. The ground floor is devoted to produce, meat, and seafood, while the upper level has stalls selling kitchen utensils, dried fruit and nuts, herbs, and other food products. The market also has a separate section for fresh juices and cooked food. The market is a popular destination for both locals and tourists, and is known for its lively atmosphere and competitive prices. It is also a favorite spot for photographers and tourists interested in capturing images of traditional Mexican life. In recent years, the market has undergone several renovations to improve its infrastructure and cleanliness. However, it has retained its traditional atmosphere and character, and remains a popular destination for food shoppers and browsers.

Mississippi gubernatorial election, 1991 Gubernatorial elections were held in Mississippi in 1991. The elections were held on November 5, 1991, and were the first since the adoption of a new constitution in 1986. The old constitution had required that the governor be elected by the State Legislature, so this was the first election in which the people directly elected the governor. In the primary election, Democratic incumbent Governor Ray Mabus was defeated by his Lieutenant Governor, James E. Ford. In the general election, Ford was defeated by Republican Eddie Bernice Johnson, who was the first woman to be elected governor in Mississippi. This was the first election in which the people directly elected the governor. The old constitution had required that the governor be elected by the State Legislature, so this was the first election in which the people directly elected the governor. The Democratic candidate was James E. Ford, who had been the Lieutenant Governor under Governor Ray Mabus. The Republican candidate was Eddie Bernice Johnson, who had been the State Auditor. Johnson became the first woman to be elected governor in Mississippi. The election was held on November 5, 1991. Johnson won the election with 55% of the vote, while Ford received 45%.

The Art Genome Project The Art Genome Project is a project and ongoing research initiative of the Art.com Group, Inc. launched in February 2008. The project is designed to create a comprehensive database of art history based on the analysis of art works. The Art Genome Project uses a complex set of algorithms and taxonomies to organize, analyze, and interpret art works and their relationships with other art works. The project is based on the idea that all art works are a combination of artistic genes, based on their creator, subject, style, and other attributes. These genes combine in different ways to create art works. The Art Genome Project's database contains over 100,000 art works and over 1,000,000 genes. The Art Genome Project uses the concept of a "genome" as a means to organize and categorize art. The word genome is a blend of the Greek gene, which means "origin," and the Latin genoma, which means "model." The genome is a set of instructions, or a map, for the growth and development of a living organism. In the same way, the Art Genome Project's database is a set of instructions, or a map, for the growth and development of art. The Art Genome Project is intended to be a tool for the study and understanding of art. It can be used to trace the development of art styles and to identify relationships between art works that may not be immediately apparent. The project can also be used to predict the appeal of art works and to identify potential collectors.

Beeline (album) Beeline is the sixth studio album by the British electronic musician James Zabiela. It was released on 9 October 2006 on Zabiela's own label, Zabiela Ltd. Beeline is a concept album, and its name was inspired by the flight path of a bee. The album was mixed and produced by James Zabiela, with additional production by Dave Spoon, and was mastered by Christian Wright at Abbey Road Studios. Beeline is Zabiela's first album to be released on his own label, after his five-album deal with ZTT Records expired. The album's release was preceded by the lead single, "In My Mind", which was released on 19 June 2006. The album's title was revealed in July, when Zabiela began recording material for it. The album features a diverse range of collaborators, including pop singer-songwriter Beverley Knight, electronic musician and producer Dave Spoon, and composer and producer Michael Nyman, who provides the album's string quartet arrangements. It also features live performances by Zabiela and his band, including a cover version of The B52's "Love Shack". Beeline was released in the United Kingdom on 9 October 2006. It was released in the United States on 6 November 2006, with a slightly different track listing. The album received positive reviews from critics. musicOMH's Ben Hogwood gave it a rating of five stars, describing it as "one of the most surprising, engaging and consistently enjoyable listens this year". Online music magazine Resident Advisor gave it a rating of four stars, stating that it was "an album that grows and grows, and rewards patience". Beeline was nominated for Best Electronic/Dance Album at the 2007 Grammy Awards, but lost to TiVo's visual album. "I Need a Man" is a song recorded by Grace Jones in 1985. It was released as her first single from her seventh studio album, Island Life. The single was released in November 1985, but due to its explicit lyrics, it was banned by the BBC, who also refused to interview Jones. The song became Jones' first hit in France, where it reached number two on the charts. The song was written by Jones in collaboration with Tomi Rae Brown, who also provides background vocals. The song is written in G minor with a tempo of 124 beats per minute. The song is in 4/4 time, and the key is G. The lyrics tell of a woman who is in search of a man to satisfy her. The woman describes what she wants in a man, and tells the man what he needs to do to please her. The woman is very explicit about what she wants, and the song has been described as "lewd" and "pornographic". The music video for the song was directed by Richard Quartz and features Jones and her band performing the song. The video also features a number of men who are trying to please Jones. The video has been described as "provocative" and "erotic". "I Need a Man" was the first single from Island Life, and was released in November 1985. The single was banned by the BBC, who also refused to interview Jones. The song was a hit in France, where it reached number two on the charts. The song was also a hit in the United States, where it reached number sixty-one on the Billboard R&B charts.

PForth is a public domain implementation of the Forth programming language. It is available for Microsoft Windows, Apple Mac OS X, and Unix-like operating systems such as Linux, FreeBSD, NetBSD, OpenBSD, and Solaris. PForth is a direct descendent of forthware's Open Firmware implementation, which in turn descended from the original forth distribution by FORTH, Inc. PForth includes a number of additional features not found in the original FORTH, Inc. distribution: * Tail call optimization * A full-featured interactive debugger * A virtual machine with threaded code * Support for relative and indirect addressing * Support for the use of full words as literals * A word for bit-twiddling, including the ubiquitous "not" and "and" operations * A standard method for creating new words * A simple built-in assembler * Standard access to the host operating system's features * Support for the Threaded interpretively-compiled code (TIC) technique for creating new words * A basis for the TIC Forth and TIC Pascal systems * Support for a simple, portable interface to the C programming language * Support for the CFFI interface to C * A basis for the popular cross-platform development environment Ch * A basis for the small, high-level programming language Ce * A basis for the research operating system Rekursiv * The basis for the TIS-100 emulator TIS-99 * A basis for the forth-like scripting language 4DMW PForth is free software, licensed under the conditions of the GNU General Public License (GPL), with the exception of the TIC and CFFI modules, which are licensed under the MIT License. PForth runs on a standard ANS Forth engine, and most standard ANS Forth words are implemented.

Sonwar Bagh Sonwar Bagh is a heritage hotel in the city of Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, India. The hotel is one of the finest and most prestigious heritage hotels in Srinagar, which was built by the Prince of Kashmir, Pratap Singh in the year 1911. The hotel is located on the banks of Jhelum River and has a majestic view of the river and the Shankaracharya Temple. The hotel has been a witness to many historical events and has hosted many dignitaries, including the Viceroy of India, Lord Mountbatten, the Prince of Wales, and the Shah of Iran. It has also been a favorite destination for many famous personalities, including Guru Nanak Dev, Woodrow Wilson, and Prince Philip. The hotel has a unique architectural style, with a blend of British and Indian architecture. The hotel has a large lawn and a beautiful garden, which is a perfect place to relax and enjoy the beauty of nature. The hotel also has a spa, where you can relax and rejuvenate yourself. The hotel has a variety of rooms, including deluxe rooms, super deluxe rooms, and suites. The rooms are well-appointed and have all the modern amenities, including Wi-Fi, television, and 24-hour room service. The hotel also has a restaurant, which serves a variety of dishes, including Indian, Chinese, and Continental cuisine.

Robert Finlay, 1st Viscount Finlay, PC, QC, LLD, DL (13 August 1851 – 9 February 1929) was a Scottish lawyer, judge, and politician. He was the first Scottish advocate to become a Lord of Appeal in Ordinary and the first to hold the office of Lord Chancellor of Great Britain and Ireland. Finlay was born in Edinburgh, the son of the physician and scientific writer John Finlay (1799–1869) and his wife, Elizabeth (1807–1897), daughter of Robert Smith, a prosperous Edinburgh businessman. He was educated at Edinburgh Academy, Edinburgh High School, and University of Edinburgh, where he won the Vans Agnew Medal and the Senior Medal in forensic medicine. He then went to Balliol College, Oxford, where he obtained a first class degree in classics and a second class degree in law. He was called to the bar in 1876 and built up a large practice in Scotland, specialising in medical law. In 1901 he was made a Queen's Counsel and in 1908 a silk. He was an outstanding lawyer and his services were in great demand. He was asked by the Home Office to draft the bill which became the Sea Fisheries (Conservation of Stocks) Act 1902, and he advised the government on the Workmen's Compensation Act 1906 and the National Insurance Act 1911. He was a member of the Royal Commission on the Poor Law of 1909–1910, and of the Royal Commission on the Private Manufacture of Drugs and poisonous Chemicals, 1912–1915. In 1913 he became a member of the Committee on the Unauthorised Practice of Medicine, and in 1916 he was appointed a member of the Advisory Committee on Child Labour. He was also a member of the International Commission of Lawyers appointed to inquire into the methods of settlement of international disputes. In 1908 he became a member of the Faculty of Advocates' Committee on the Law of Medicine and in 1912 he was appointed Dean of the Faculty of Advocates. In 1919 he was made a Lord of Appeal in Ordinary and was sworn in as a member of the Privy Council. Two years later, in 1921, he was appointed Lord Chancellor, in which office he served until his death. In 1922 he was made a life peer as Baron Finlay, of Nairn in the County of Nairn, in the Peerage of the United Kingdom, and in 1927 he was further honoured when he was made a Viscount, entitling him to sit in the House of Lords as Lord Finlay. Lord Finlay was an excellent public speaker and a sound lawyer, but his appointment as Lord Chancellor was politically motivated, and he was not regarded by his contemporaries as a great lawyer. His tenure of the office of Lord Chancellor was not marked by any important legislation, and he is best remembered for his work in connection with the development of the law relating to medical negligence. In 1925, in the case of Donoghue v. Stevenson, he gave the first decision in a test case which was to become a landmark in the development of the law of negligence. He also gave the decision in the case of Allen v Sir Alfred McAlpine & Sons Ltd [1927] AC 696, in which it was held that the employer of a workman is not liable for an injury sustained by the workman due to the negligence of a fellow workman. Lord Finlay was a member of the Roxburghe Club and the Selborne Society. He was also a member of the council of the Scottish History Society and a vice-president of the Royal Society of Edinburgh. He was a keen golfer and a member of the St. Andrews Golf Club and of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews. Lord Finlay married twice, first in 1880 to Jessie, daughter of David Smith of Aberdeen, by whom he had one son and one daughter, and, after her death in 1917, to Annie, daughter of Thomas Millie of Aberdeen, by whom he had one son and one daughter. He died in London on 9 February 1929, aged 77, and was succeeded in his titles by his elder son from his first marriage, John, who became a distinguished lawyer and judge in his own right. His second son, Robert, became a general in the Royal Air Force. His daughter from his first marriage, Janet, married the statistician and golfer Sir Henry Cotton. A collection of his speeches and essays was published in 1930, and a biography, by Sir WilliamWedgwood Benn, in 1931.

Pembroke, Kentucky, is an unincorporated community and census-designated place in Christian County, Kentucky, United States. As of the 2010 census, it had a population of 1,451. It is located on Kentucky Route 101 (the Pennyrile Parkway) between Hopkinsville and Madisonville. The community was named for the Pembroke Hill neighborhood in Kansas City, Missouri, the home of a railroad official. Pembroke is located at 36°49′46″N 87°52′59″W (36.831694, -87.863472). According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of 2.9 square miles (7.4 km2), all land. As of the 2010 census, there were 1,451 people, 562 households, and 435 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 483.8 people per square mile (186.3/km²). There were 599 housing units at an average density of 201.6/sq mi (78.2/km²). The racial makeup of the CDP was 95.26% White, 1.87% African American, 0.41% Native American, 1.15% Asian, 0.14% Pacific Islander, 0.49% from other races, and 1.08% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.31% of the population. There were 562 households out of which 36.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 59.3% were married couples living together, 10.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.4% were non-families. 21.5% of all households were made up of individuals and 9.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.54 and the average family size was 2.93. In the CDP, the population was spread out with 23.5% under the age of 18, 7.9% from 18 to 24, 28.2% from 25 to 44, 25.4% from 45 to 64, and 13.2% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 37 years. For every 100 females, there were 99.3 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 100.6 males. As of the 2000 census, the median income for a household in the CDP was $35,417, and the median income for a family was $40,417. Men had a median income of $29,444 versus $20,417 for women. The per capita income for the CDP was $16,325. About 4.8% of families and 9.5% of the population were below the poverty line, including 11.4% of those under age 18 and 15.8% of those age 65 or over. The first post office in Pembroke opened in 1884. The ZIP Code for the community is 42268.

James Hodge Codding (September 6, 1927 – August 25, 2022) was an American electrical engineer and computer scientist, who, with his wife, Barbara, invented the concept of a "linked list", a data structure used in nearly every modern computer application. Codding was born in Lincoln, Nebraska, in 1927. He received a B.S. in electrical engineering from the University of Nebraska in 1949, and an M.S. in electrical engineering from Stanford University in 1950. In 1952, he joined the Information Control Division of the Stanford Research Institute, where he remained for the rest of his career. In 1981, he became the head of the division, which was later renamed the Computer Science Laboratory. In 1990, he became the institute's associate director for computing, and in 1992, he became the director of the Center for Integrated Systems, a position he held until his retirement in 1996. In 1956, Codding and his wife, Barbara, invented the concept of a linked list, a data structure used in nearly every modern computer application. The Coddings published their invention in a paper in the December 1957 issue of the Proceedings of the IEEE. The paper, entitled "A Method for Impressing Information on a Persisting Memory", described a method for organizing data in a memory so that the information can be updated efficiently. The paper has been cited more than 2,000 times, making it one of the most cited papers in computer science. Codding was a fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, the American Association for Artificial Intelligence, and the Association for Computing Machinery. He was also a member of the National Academy of Engineering and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. In 1994, he received the IEEE Computer Society's Charles Babbage Award, and in 1996, he received the ACM's Turing Award, along with his wife, Barbara, and Robert Tarjan, for their work on linked lists. In 1998, the three received the AAAS' Prize for the Application of Science. Codding died in 2022 at the age of 94 from complications related to COVID-19.

The Arduino Uno is an open-source hardware and software project aimed at creating a low-cost, easy-to-use, open-source hardware and software platform for building microcontroller-based interactive projects. It is a development board based on the ATmega328P microcontroller. It is pin- and software-compatible with its predecessor, the Duemilanove, which means that it can be used as a drop-in replacement in most projects. The Arduino Uno is a microcontroller board based on the ATmega328P (datasheet). It has 14 digital input/output pins (of which 6 can be used as PWM outputs), 6 analog inputs, a 16 MHz crystal oscillator, a USB connection, a power jack, an ICSP header, and a reset button. It comes in a standard form-factor that is backward-compatible with the former boards in the Arduino series. The board is equipped with a set of female headers (holes) which allow it to be connected to external electronics. The board is powered via the USB connection or with an external power supply. Arduino Uno is the successor to the Duemilanove. It is larger, providing more I/O pins (14 digital, 6 analog), a bigger power supply (up to 20 mA, compared to the previous 5 mA), and more memory (8 KB of RAM, compared to 2 KB). The larger size makes it more versatile, as it can be equipped with a protoboard or a breadboard to create more advanced projects. Like its predecessor, the Arduino Uno is an open-source hardware and software project. The hardware design is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License, while the software is licensed under the GNU General Public License (GPL) v3. The Arduino Uno is available with either a 6-pin or a 10-pin ICSP header. The 6-pin header is more compact, while the 10-pin header provides more flexibility, as it can be used with more sophisticated programmers.

Beatfreakz are an electronic music production and DJ duo, consisting of the members Mazer & INCL. The members of Beatfreakz met in high school and became friends. They both had an interest in music and started making music together in 2003. Their first release was on the B-Side of the "Waltzing Mathilda" single by The Black Eyed Peas. In 2007, they released their first single, "Dumbass", which was featured on the soundtrack to the film "Halloween". The song became a hit, reaching number one on the Billboard Dance Chart. The duo has since released several other singles, including "Foolish Games", "In My Mind", "You Got Me", and "Creepin'". They have also released a number of remixes, including a remix of "Bad Boys" by Inner Circle. In 2013, they released their first album, "Beatfreakz". The album featured a number of guest appearances, including vocals from Kreesha Turner and Ryan Starr. In 2015, they released their second album, "We Are Beatfreakz". The album featured a number of guest appearances, including vocals from Sean Paul and Elephant Man. In 2017, they released their third album, "Future Freaks". The album featured a number of guest appearances, including vocals from Lil Jon and 2 Chainz. In 2019, they released their fourth album, "Next Level". The album featured a number of guest appearances, including vocals from NLE Choppa and Waka Flocka Flame. In 2021, they released their fifth album, "The Beatfreakz". The album featured a number of guest appearances, including vocals from Baby Keem and Drake. In 2022, they released their sixth album, "Freakz on Fire". The album featured a number of guest appearances, including vocals from Rick Ross and 21 Savage.

Only Fools and Horses Only Fools and Horses is a British sitcom created and primarily written by John Sullivan. It was first broadcast on BBC One in 1981, and lasted until 2003, making it the longest-running British sitcom by a margin of four years. It is set in London and follows the lives of two young men, Del Boy and his brother Rodney, who live with their Grandad in a council flat in Peckham. The series was mostly filmed in London, although some location scenes were shot in Malta. Only Fools and Horses is set in the 1980s and 1990s, and follows the lives of two brothers, Del Boy (David Jason) and Rodney (Nicholas Lyndhurst) Trotter, and their Grandad (Lennard Pearce), who together run a small family business, 'Trotters Independent Traders', from their council flat in Peckham, London. In the pilot episode, Del dreams of making it rich one day, while Rodney is more cautious. Their Grandad, an ex-colonel, frequently Comments on the situation in which the brothers find themselves, and their often dysfunctional family life. In later episodes, the brothers' oddball uncle, Uncle Albert, (Buster Merryfield) and their mother, Joan (Barbara Flynn), also feature, as does the brothers' cousin, Nicolás (Francisco Bello). In the final two series, the brothers' girlfriend, Raquel (Tessa Peake-Jones), and their daughter, Sharon (Fennella Jaye), are also main characters. The series is mainly set in London, and the surrounding area. The Trotter family flat is in a high-rise block in Peckham, while their business premises are located in nearby Trotters Lane, in an area called the "Black Country". In the early series, the brothers' main source of income is from Del's get-rich-quick schemes, which are often dodgy, and which never seem to work out as he had planned. In later series, the brothers' business, Trotters Independent Traders, becomes more successful, and they are able to upgrade their flat and their car. As well as the main cast, Only Fools and Horses also features a number of supporting characters, including Del and Rodney's solicitor, Mr. China (Clifford Barry), and their local MP, Michael von Bismarck (Michael Sheard). Many episodes also feature guest stars, including Christopher Biggins, Robert Vaughn, William Rushton, and the cast of rival sitcom, Hi-de-Hi!. Only Fools and Horses ran for a total of 64 episodes, including the pilot. The series was produced by John Sullivan, and was mainly written by Sullivan with help from a number of other writers. The series was first broadcast on BBC One in 1981, and its final episode was broadcast in 2003. In 2002, a special, The Green Green Grass, was produced, and in 2013, a musical adaptation of the series was performed in the West End. In 2015, a one-off special, The Comic Relief Special, was produced, and in 2019, a one-off special, The Royal Command Performance, was produced. In 2020, a prequel series, Only Fools and Horses: The Early Years, was produced, and in 2021, a sequel series, Only Fools and Horses: The Last of the Summer Wine, was produced.
