In 2015, a poll of UK viewers named it the second-greatest British sitcom of all time, behind Only Fools and Horses. In 2017, a poll of UK viewers named it the third-greatest British sitcom of all time, behind Dad's Army and Only Fools and Horses. In 2020, a poll of UK viewers named it the third-greatest British sitcom of all time, behind Dad's Army and Only Fools and Horses.

The Essential Kenny Loggins is a greatest hits album by American singer-songwriter Kenny Loggins, released in 2002. This album was released on the heels of the successful benefit concert, A&T's "Concert for the Kids", in which Loggins and his former bandmate, Jim Messina, reunited to perform a sell-out concert at the Universal Amphitheatre in Los Angeles. The concert was originally supposed to be a one-time event, but due to the overwhelming response from fans, the pair decided to mount a national concert tour in 2002. This album was released to coincide with the tour, and contains a number of tracks not previously available on any of Loggins' previous greatest hits albums, including "The More We Try", "Don't Fight It", "Love Will Find a Way", "We Will Not Be Afraid", "The Best of Me", "I Will Go On", "What's Forever For", "The Other Side of the Mirror", "She's Got You", "Cody's Song", and "The UnSOCIAL Worker". The Essential Kenny Loggins is the third greatest hits album to be released by Loggins, following the releases of The Best of Kenny Loggins (1977) and The Gold Standard (1982). The Essential Kenny Loggins has proven to be the most popular of the three, having been certified platinum by the RIAA, for sales of over one million copies. In 2006, a second volume, The Essential Kenny Loggins, Volume 2 was released, containing a number of additional hits, including "This Is It", "Don't You Hear the Mockingbird", "How Do I Live", "The Champion", "The Power of Your Love", "Lonesome, On'ry and Mean", "She's in Love with the Wrong Guy", "Danger Zone", "A House With Love in It", and "A Man's Gotta Do What a Man's Gotta Do".

JibJab JibJab is an American digital entertainment company founded in 1999 by brothers Evan and Gregg Spiridellis, based in Los Angeles. The company's website is known for its personalized e-cards, which use its patented technology to integrate a digital photo with animated effects in a variety of templates, designed by the company's staff of artists. The company's products are oriented toward the holiday market, with a substantial portion of its revenue coming from Halloween and Christmas cards. The company has received $40 million in venture capital funding. In 2007, it was valued at $200 million, with more than 1.5 million active members and a revenue base of more than $20 million. In 2008, the company was valued at $300 million, with 2.4 million active members, and in 2010 it was valued at $650 million, with 3.8 million active members. In 2007, the company was ranked #33 on the Deloitte Technology Fast 50 list, with 5,698% growth over the previous five years. In 2008, the company was ranked #61 on the Deloitte Technology Fast 500 list, with 3,733% growth over the previous five years. In 2009, the company was ranked #43 on the Deloitte Technology Fast 500 list, with 3,000% growth over the previous five years. JibJab has produced numerous other entertainment products, including JibJab Jr. for children, JibJab Sports, and JibJab Music. In 2010, the company launched JibJab Photos, a tool for creating photo collages. In 2013, the company launched JibJab Video, a tool for creating video collages. In 2015, the company launched JibJab Kids, a collection of children's music.

Shed (deity) Shed is a deity in the sqlrunen mythos. Shed is described as a giantess, a daughter of the primordial mother, Nott. In most traditions, Shed is a single entity, but in some traditions, Shed is a collective of giantesses. Shed is the mother of the first race of giants, the primordial beings of chaos and destruction. Shed mothered the giants through her mating with the primordial god, Odin. In some traditions, the giantess Gunnlod or Hyr is described as the mother of the giants, while Shed is described as the mother of the gods. Shed is the spouse of the primordial god, Odin. Odin and Shed had many offspring, including the gods, the giants, the Lamonts, the Maquas, the Frost Giants, and the Ice Giants. Shed is described as a beautiful giantess, with golden hair, a beautiful face, and a beautiful body. She is said to have worn a long golden gown and a gold crown. She is described as the most beautiful of all the giantesses. Shed is the goddess of fertility and reproduction. She is also the goddess of the harvest. In some traditions, Shed is also the goddess of war and death. Shed is the mother of the gods. She gave birth to the gods through her union with the primordial god, Odin. The gods were born from her body, and she nourished them with her milk. Shed is the protector of the gods. She is said to have fought alongside the gods in their war against the giants. She is also said to have fought against the dragons and the serpents. Shed is the goddess of the hunt. She is said to have accompanied the gods on their hunting expeditions. She is also said to have provided them with food and shelter.

John Slim, 2nd Viscount Slim was a British peer and a member of the House of Lords. Slim was the son of William Slim, 1st Viscount Slim and his wife Diana Edith Cazalet. He was born on 9 August 1928 in Chelsea, London, and was educated at Eton College and New College, Oxford. Slim served as an officer in the Coldstream Guards from 1949 to 1950. He then worked in the family business, Slim Brothers, printers and publishers, from 1950 to 1955. He then became a director of several companies, including Slim Brothers, Royal Insurance, National Benzole, Shell-Mex and BP. Slim was appointed a justice of the peace for the county of Kent in 1955, and was a deputy lieutenant from 1961. He was also a member of the National Union of Conservative and Unionists. Slim married Elizabeth Ann Camoys, daughter of the 9th Baron Camoys, in 1961. They had three sons, including the actor Julian Slim. Slim succeeded to the viscountcy on the death of his father in 1970. He died on 11 November 1999 and was succeeded in the viscountcy by his son, John Slim, 3rd Viscount Slim.

Disruptive selection, in evolutionary biology, is a form of selection in which the fitness of one sex is much higher than that of the other, driving the population toward a unisex state. Disruptive selection occurs when the sex ratio is uneven, causing a deviation from the expected sex ratio, which is 50 percent male and 50 percent female. The sex ratio is the proportion of one sex to the other in a population. In disruptive selection, the actual sex ratio does not stay constant. Instead, the ratio oscillates between two levels. The population's gender composition shifts over time from one extreme to the other and then back again. In a population with even numbers of males and females, the gender composition should stay the same from one generation to the next. In a population with disruptive selection, the gender composition changes every generation. In the first generation, the ratio may be 60 percent male and 40 percent female. In the next generation, the ratio may shift to 70 percent male and 30 percent female. In the third generation, the ratio may be 80 percent male and 20 percent female. This pattern of shifting back and forth between two levels continues in subsequent generations. The cause of disruptive selection is usually a combination of a preference for one sex over the other and a shortage of the preferred sex. For example, in a population of birds, the females may prefer to mate with the males who have the brightest plumage. If there are not enough brightly colored males to go around, the females may be forced to mate with males who have duller plumage. Over time, this can cause the population to become more and more male-heavy, as the females prefer the males who are the most colorful and the males with the least colorful plumage have the highest fitness.

Rachel is the name of several fictional characters in the Bible. Rachel (Hebrew: רָחֵל, lit. "ewe"), according to the Book of Genesis, was the wife of Jacob and the mother of Joseph and Benjamin, and the daughter of Laban and Leah. According to the Bible, she was born in Paddan-Aram (now Northwest Syria) in the region of Upper Mesopotamia. The Midrash says that she was the daughter of Laban's chief servant, Zilpah. The narrative in Genesis does not explicitly refer to Rachel as Jacob's wife, only as "Laban's daughter". The Bible states that she was beautiful, modest, and kind, although it does not explicitly use the word "beautiful". She was a niece of Laban, and married her first cousin, Jacob. According to the Book of Genesis, Jacob loved Rachel and agreed to work seven years for Laban in order to marry her. It also states that on the wedding night, Jacob impulsively consummated the marriage without waiting for the week-long wedding feast to finish. This resulted in Rachel becoming pregnant with Joseph. When Laban found out, he forced Jacob to agree to another seven years of service for Rachel. Years later, after Joseph was born, Jacob took his family and possessions and fled from Laban's house to go to his own country. Rachel died on the journey to Ephrath (also called Bethlehem), about 20 miles (32 km) south of Jerusalem, and was buried in a cave in the city. According to the Bible, Rachel died after giving birth to Benjamin, her second son. Rachel is listed in the genealogies of Jesus in the New Testament. In Matthew 1:2–3, she is listed as the mother of Joseph, the husband of Mary, who gave birth to Jesus. In Luke 3:32–33, she is listed as the mother of Joseph, the husband of Mary, who gave birth to Jesus and James. Rachel is a major character in the deuterocanonical books of the Bible, the Book of Tobit and the Book of Judith. In the former, she is the wife of Tobit, who is portrayed as a righteous man. She falls sick and, in the course of the narrative, dies. In the latter, she is the mother of Judith, a heroine who saves her people from destruction by the invading Holofernes. Rachel is also a character in the Quran, where she is called Rayhanah and is the wife of Isma'il, the son of Ibrahim (Abraham). She is said to have died during a trip to the Levant, and is buried in the Cave of the Patriarchs.

Wydawnictwo Uniwersytetu Śląskiego The Wydawnictwo Uniwersytetu Śląskiego (the "University of Silesia Press") is a publisher, located in Katowice, Poland. It is one of the largest and most prominent academic publishers in Poland. It was established in 1968, and since then it has published over 6,500 books, as well as about 30 journals. It is a publisher of monographs, textbooks, albums, dictionaries, reference books, and journals. The University of Silesia Press has also published the works of poets, such as Jarosław Iwaszkiewicz, Czesław Miłosz, Zbigniew Herbert, and Adam Zagajewski, as well as the philosophical works of Leszek Kołakowski. It also publishes series of books on the history of Silesia, the history of technology, and the history of the university. Since 2011, the University of Silesia Press has been the publisher of the yearbook "Philosophy and Culture". In 2013, the University of Silesia Press received the "Mark of the Year" for the book "God, The Devil, and The Other One" by Leszek Kołakowski.

Chakkar (English: Circle) is a 2017 Indian Assamese language drama film written and directed by debutant Manoj Kumar Das. The film was produced by Dr. Naveen Talukdar and starred by Assamese actor Zubeen Garg in the lead role with Labonya Cruz in the female lead. The film was released on 5 August 2017. The film is a socio-political commentary on society and politics in the state of Assam. The film is also the first film in the Assamese language to be released in Dolby Digital. Chakkar is the story of a young man, Bhupen, who is a part of a musical band, whose life is devastated after his father goes missing. The story is told in a non-linear fashion, with flashes of the past and the present. The film starts with a couple in bed, with the man, Bhupen (Zubeen Garg), awake and the woman, Priya (Labonya Cruz), sleeping. He looks at her sadly and recalls the events that have led to this situation. The film goes into a flashback. Bhupen is a part of a musical band, the members of which are all very close to each other. The band's name is Chakkar, which means Circle, and the members are known as the "Chakkar Boys". They are shown performing at a number of events and enjoying their time together. However, their lives are turned upside down when Bhupen's father, Dr. Anupam Hazarika (Gulpan Prince), a doctor at the local hospital, goes missing. The police are unable to find any leads, and the family is devastated. Bhupen, in a desperate attempt to find his father, starts to investigate the case himself. He discovers that his father's hospital is being used to carry out illegal activities, and that his father may have been involved in the illegal activities. Chakkar is a commentary on the state of the society and politics in Assam. The film is a criticism of the corruption and the power politics that is rampant in the state. The film also highlights the fact that the youth in the state are being denied their rights and are being forced to leave the state in search of better opportunities.

Via Bona Award The Via Bona Award is an award for people, projects or groups that have made "an outstanding contribution to the development of the theory or practice of electrical engineering, electronics or computer science". The award is given annually by the Swedish Electrotechnical Association (SFE), and was first awarded in 1964. The award is named after Professor Nils von Bonsdorff (1894–1970), who was the first to hold a chair in electrical engineering in Sweden. The Via Bona Award is awarded for "an outstanding contribution to the development of the theory or practice of electrical engineering, electronics or computer science". The contribution may be of theoretical or practical nature, and it may be based either on a scientific or an engineering achievement. The contribution shall be of permanent value and shall be internationally recognized. The Via Bona Award is presented at the annual general meeting of the SFE. The recipient(s) receive a diploma and a silver statuette, and are obliged to give a speech.

Narzullo Oblomurodov (Нарзулло Абломуродов, May 3, 1902 – August 7, 1992) was a Soviet and Russian writer, poet, playwright, andologist, and literary translator. He was awarded the title of People's Writer of the USSR in 1988. Oblomurodov was born in a halachically Jewish family in Nesvizh, Russian Empire (now in Belarus). His real surname was Nosov, but he changed it to Oblomurodov after the Russian Revolution. In 1923 he graduated from the Maxim Gorky Literature Institute in Moscow. He was the author of numerous poems, novels, plays, and essays, including The Thaw (1976), The Ajarian Night (1985), The Romanovs' Last (1986), and The Gold of the Azov (1989). His most famous work is the novel The Day Lasts More Than a Hundred Years (1986), which was adapted into a film of the same name by Leonid Menaker in 1988. He was awarded the Order of Friendship of Peoples (1981), the Order of the Badge of Honour (1982), and the Order of Lenin (1986). Oblomurodov died in Moscow in 1992. He was buried in the writers' section of the Novodevichy Cemetery.

Jurisdiction stripping is the legal term for the set of tactics in which a state reduces the sovereignty of another state. The state that is the victim of jurisdiction stripping is typically a small state, and the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping is typically a large state. The term was coined by Robert Jackson in a 1981 article entitled "The New UN Law of Self-Determination". Jurisdiction stripping can take many forms. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may announce, for example, that it no longer recognizes the independence of the victim state. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also integrate the victim state into its own legal system. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also take over the victim state's territory. Jurisdiction stripping is often accomplished by the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping by simply declaring that the victim state is no longer independent. The victim state may have a very small military force and the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may have a very large military force. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may then use its large military force to occupy the victim state. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also use its large military force to occupy the victim state's territory. Once the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping has occupied the victim state or the victim state's territory, the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may then integrate the victim state into its own legal system. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also take over the victim state's government. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also use its own legal system to interpret the victim state's laws. For example, the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may use its own legal system to interpret the victim state's tax laws. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also use its own legal system to adjudicate disputes involving the victim state. There are many variations on jurisdiction stripping. For example, a state may strip jurisdiction from another state with which it has a territorial dispute. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may then use its own legal system to adjudicate the territorial dispute. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also use its own legal system to settle disputes involving the victim state. For example, the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may use its own legal system to settle disputes over tax payments or other financial matters. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also use its own legal system to settle disputes over the victim state's natural resources. There are also many variations on the types of states that are guilty of jurisdiction stripping. For example, a state may be guilty of jurisdiction stripping if it occupies the victim state's territory but does not formally announce that it has stripped the victim state of its sovereignty. A state may also be guilty of jurisdiction stripping if it occupies the victim state's territory and integrates the victim state into its own legal system, but does not formally announce that it has stripped the victim state of its sovereignty. A state may also be guilty of jurisdiction stripping if it occupies the victim state's territory and integrates the victim state into its own legal system, but does not take over the victim state's government. In this case, the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may have to allow the victim state to maintain its own legal system. A state may also be guilty of jurisdiction stripping if it uses its own legal system to interpret the victim state's laws, but does not use its own legal system to adjudicate disputes involving the victim state. In this case, the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may have to allow the victim state to maintain its own legal system. The legal consequences of jurisdiction stripping can be severe. If a state strips another state of its sovereignty, the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may be responsible for the victim state's debts and liabilities. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also be responsible for the victim state's natural resources. In addition, the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may be responsible for the victim state's legal system. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also be responsible for the victim state's government. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also be responsible for the victim state's international legal obligations. For example, if the victim state has signed onto an international treaty, the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may be responsible for the victim state's compliance with the terms of the treaty. The state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may also be responsible for the victim state's relationships with other states. For example, if the victim state has diplomatic relations with other states, the state that is guilty of jurisdiction stripping may be responsible for the victim state's compliance with the terms of those relationships.

Miller, New South Wales, is a suburb of Sydney, in the state of New South Wales, Australia. Miller is located 40 kilometres (25 mi) west of the Sydney central business district, in the local government area of the City of Fairfield. Miller is located on the northern bank of the Georges River, opposite the suburb of Dharruk. The suburbs of Bass Hill, Cabramatta and Canley Heights are to the west, and Mount Pritchard and Concorde are to the north. Miller was named after an early settler, Thomas Miller. Miller has a mixture of residential, commercial and industrial developments. The main shopping strip is located along the main street, Miller Road. The residential areas are generally located in the flatter areas towards the river and the hills to the west. The industrial and commercial developments are generally located in the areas surrounding the major roads. Miller is served by a number of bus routes that travel between Liverpool and Sydney via Mount Pritchard and Canley Heights. The nearest railway stations are Liverpool and Cabramatta.

Linda Gates Linda Gates (born September 1, 1945) is an American actress, writer, director, and producer, best known for playing Mary Alice Claire, the wife of the title character in the television series Hart to Hart. Gates was born in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, the daughter of Letha (née McClure) and James Earl Gates. Her family moved to Los Angeles, California in 1957. She attended North Hollywood High School, where she was a member of the debate team. She graduated from the University of California, Berkeley in 1967 with a bachelor's degree in English. After graduation, Gates worked as a computer programmer for three years at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California. She then worked as a technical writer for two years at the Los Angeles County Office of Education. In 1973, she began her acting career with a small part in an episode of police drama S.W.A.T. Her first movie role was as a law student in The Paper Chase in 1973. She played a recurring role as Sgt. Worski in the television series Police Story in 1974, and had a regular role as Sgt. Chana from 1976 to 1977 in the series Most Wanted. She played the role of Det. Sgt. Mary Alice Claire in the television series Hart to Hart from 1979 to 1984, and again in the series' revival from 1996 to 1997. She also starred in the short-lived series Baywatch Nights in 1995. Her other television credits include CHiPs, Hawaii Five-O, The A-Team, The Facts of Life, and She-Wolf of London. Her movie credits include roles in The Buddy Holly Story (1978), Wise Guys (1986), and Space Jam (1996). In addition to acting, Gates has also written, directed, and produced. She wrote and directed the television movie The Return of Frank Cannon in 1990. She produced and directed the documentary The Creative Impulse in 1984. She also produced and starred in the movie The Last Word in 1996. Gates has been married to actor Michael Pare since 1986. They have two daughters, Jennifer and Laura.

The 2011 Elite League speedway season was the 75th season of the top division of UK speedway and the 16th since its establishment as the Elite League in 1997. The season started on 2 April at the Norfolk Arena, King's Lynn with the King's Lynn Stars hosting the Belle Vue Aces in a challenge match which the Aces won by 48–41.
