Artifact Small Format Film Festival The Artifact Small Format Film Festival is an annual international film festival held in Manila, Philippines, focused on short films. It was founded in 2011 by Espia Brashear, an independent filmmaker from the United States. The festival is held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines and other art venues in Manila. The festival's mission is to provide a platform for the exhibition of short films by both amateur and professional filmmakers in the Philippines and around the world. It is also a venue for learning opportunities, such as workshops and talks on relevant topics related to independent filmmaking. The festival's annual programs include the International Competition, the National Competition, the Docu-Series Competition, the Experimental Film Competition, and the Media Art Competition. The festival also holds a number of special programs, such as the Student Shorts Program, the Local Shorts Program, and the International Shorts Program. The International Competition is the main event of the festival, where short films from all over the world are competing for the Golden Artifact Award and the Special Jury Prize. The National Competition is for Filipino short films only, where the winners will receive the Golden Island Award and the Special Jury Prize. The Docu-Series Competition is for documentary series, which will be competing for the Golden Eagle Award and the Special Jury Prize. The Experimental Film Competition is for experimental films, which will be competing for the Golden Cube Award and the Special Jury Prize. The Media Art Competition is for media art pieces, which will be competing for the Golden Pixel Award and the Special Jury Prize. In addition to the main competitions, the festival also holds a number of special programs, such as the Student Shorts Program, the Local Shorts Program, and the International Shorts Program. The Student Shorts Program is for student-made short films, and the Local Shorts Program is for locally made short films. The International Shorts Program is for international short films that are not competing in the International Competition. The festival also holds a number of special programs, such as the Artifact Youth Program, the Artifact Industry Forum, and the Artifact Awards Night. The Artifact Youth Program is a program for young filmmakers, and the Artifact Industry Forum is a forum for industry professionals to discuss relevant topics related to independent filmmaking. The Artifact Awards Night is the closing event of the festival, where the winners of the competitions will be announced and awarded. The festival has been running annually since 2011, and has been growing steadily in terms of the number of films submitted, the number of attendees, and the number of activities and programs organized. In 2018, the festival received more than 2,000 submissions from over 100 countries, and had over 100,000 attendees.

"Go Bang!" is the debut single by American rapper 2 Chainz. It was released as the first single from his debut album Based on a T.R.U. Story on August 14, 2012, via Def Jam Recordings. The production on the song was handled by K.E. on the Track. The song features a guest verse from fellow rapper Lil Wayne, who also signed 2 Chainz to his label Young Money Entertainment in 2011. "Go Bang!" is built around a sample of the song "Cardova" by Slick Rick, which itself samples the song "The Great American Dream" by Legal Drug Push. The song's instrumental was featured in a previous track by Young Money artist Jae Millz, titled "Dip Dat". "Go Bang!" was originally intended to be the first single from a deluxe version of Lil Wayne's album I Am Not a Player, but was instead released as 2 Chainz's debut single. The song received generally positive reviews from music critics, who praised the production and the guest verse from Lil Wayne. The song was featured on the soundtrack to the 2012 movie Project X. A music video, directed by Alex Nazari, was released on September 17, 2012. The video features a cameo appearance from American rapper and actor Terrence Howard. "Go Bang!" peaked at number 49 on the Billboard Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart, and number 23 on the Hot Rap Songs chart. 2 Chainz performed the song live on The Late Show with David Letterman on September 18, 2012, alongside Lil Wayne. A remix version of the song, featuring American rapper Rick Ross, was released on October 2, 2012. Another remix version of the song, featuring American rapper Juicy J, was released on October 16, 2012. In January 2013, "Go Bang!" was included in XXL's list of the best songs of 2012. In June 2013, Complex named "Go Bang!" the 14th best song of 2012. In September 2013, Rolling Stone named "Go Bang!" the tenth best song of 2012. In October 2013, Spin named "Go Bang!" the fifth best song of 2012.

Il Giardino dei Semplici Il Giardino dei Semplici (The Garden of Simples) is an Italian herbalist and scientific botanical garden, founded in 1545 by the Botanical Academy of Florence, and still in existence today. The garden is located in Florence, Italy, in the Oltrarno district, in the area between the Boboli Gardens and the Arno river, and is attached to the Academy of Sciences' seat in the Palazzo Torrigiani. The Giardino dei Semplici is one of the oldest botanical gardens in the world, and the oldest in Europe. It was established by the Florentine mathematician Luca Ghini (c. 1490 – 1556), a friend of Leonhart Fuchs, and was laid out in the form of a labyrinth. Today the garden houses about 2,000 species of plants, typically Mediterranean and European, though there are also examples from South America and the Orient. The garden also has a large collection of cryptogams, and in particular ferns. The garden's intent is to serve as a center for the study of the vegetable kingdom, in particular of the Italian flora. There is also a herbarium, with about 1.2 million samples. In the early 20th century, the garden's director, the Italian botanist Giorgio Parisi (born 1936), discovered a large number of plant species new to science. The garden also has a library with about 6,000 books, some of which date back to the 16th century.

Rostock-Lichtenhagen riots The Rostock-Lichtenhagen riots were a series of riots in the autumn of 1992 in the Rostock district of Lichtenhagen. The riots were the most serious in the post-war history of the GDR and contributed to the fall of the Berlin Wall and the end of the GDR. At the end of August 1992, a group of neo-Nazis started to attack ethnic minority groups in the area. The attacks were mainly directed at the houses of Vietnamese in the district of Lichtenhagen. The police did not take action, which led to further escalate the riots. On September 2, 1992, a Friday, the Zionskirche (Zion Church) in Lichtenhagen was set on fire by three young men. The church was a cult meeting point for the Neo-Nazis. The police arrested the three young men but released them the next day. On Sunday, September 6, 1992, a large crowd of Neo-Nazis demonstrated in front of the church. The police tried to stop the demonstration but failed and the crowd marched through the streets, throwing stones and bottles at the police and setting fire to cars and shops. The police used tear gas but could not stop the riots. Over the next days, the riots spread to other districts of Rostock and to the neighboring city of Stralsund. The police arrested hundreds of rioters but could not stop the riots. On September 9, 1992, the Zionskirche was set on fire again by a man who was immediately arrested. The next day, a group of about 300 neo-Nazis tried to attack the mosque in Rostock-Schmarl. The police used tear gas and rubber bullets to stop the attack. On September 11, 1992, the National People's Army (NVA) deployed a helicopter over the city of Rostock for the first time since the Second World War. The helicopter was used to observe the riots. On September 13, 1992, a group of about 2,000 neo-Nazis demonstrated in front of the town hall in Rostock. The police used tear gas and rubber bullets to stop the demonstration. On September 14, 1992, the NVA deployed a helicopter over the city of Stralsund for the first time since the Second World War. The helicopter was used to observe the riots. On September 16, 1992, a group of about 2,500 neo-Nazis demonstrated in front of the town hall in Stralsund. The police used tear gas and rubber bullets to stop the demonstration. On September 17, 1992, the NVA deployed a helicopter over the city of Greifswald for the first time since the Second World War. The helicopter was used to observe the riots. The riots were a major problem for the government of the GDR. The police were not able to stop the riots and the NVA was deployed for the first time since the Second World War. The government of the GDR had to take action to end the riots. On September 21, 1992, the government of the GDR held a meeting to discuss the riots. The meeting was attended by the leaders of the GDR, the police, and the NVA. The government of the GDR announced that it would take action to end the riots. On September 22, 1992, the NVA deployed a helicopter over the city of Schwerin for the first time since the Second World War. The helicopter was used to observe the riots. On September 24, 1992, a group of about 2,000 neo-Nazis demonstrated in front of the town hall in Schwerin. The police used tear gas and rubber bullets to stop the demonstration. The Rostock-Lichtenhagen riots were a series of riots in the autumn of 1992 in the Rostock district of Lichtenhagen. The riots were the most serious in the post-war history of the GDR and contributed to the fall of the Berlin Wall and the end of the GDR.

Chamcook Lake is a lake in the Canadian province of New Brunswick. It is located in the city of Saint John, roughly 4 kilometres (2 mi) west of the city's downtown core. The lake is a result of the creation of the St. John River, which was formed by the last ice age. Chamcook Lake is the location of the annual Interprovincial Regatta, which is held each year on the first Sunday of August. The regatta is attended by thousands of people each year, with participants from Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, and New Brunswick. The lake is the site of the Chamcook Lake Lodge, a historic summer lodge built in 1929. The lodge was built in the same style as the better known and more expensive Algonquin Hotel in St. Andrews, NB. The Chamcook was built by a group of St. John business people as a more affordable alternative to the Algonquin. The lodge is now a condominium complex. In the summer of 2007, a local non-profit organization, the Chamcook Lake Protection Association, attempted to have the lake named one of Canada's Great Lakes. The lakes are a group of lakes, of which only five are not in Ontario. They are named for their large size, and are the largest lakes in their respective provinces. The criteria for being named a Great Lake is that a lake must be at least 100 square miles (260 square kilometres) in area, or have a minimum of 100,000 cubic kilometres of water. Chamcook Lake is 0.54 square miles (1.4 square kilometres) in area, and has 1,213,370 cubic metres of water. Chamcook Lake was named for the chamcook plant (Zannichellia palustris), which grows in the lake.

So Fresh: The Hits of Autumn 2005 is a compilation album by various artists which was released in 2005. The album was certified Gold by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) for sales of over 100,000 copies in the UK. So Fresh: The Hits of Autumn 2005 is a compilation album by various artists which was released in 2005. The album was certified Gold by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) for sales of over 100,000 copies in the UK. In the United Kingdom, the album was released as a 2-CD set, with the second disc containing a selection of dance music tracks. The album was also released in a 2-CD set in Australia, but instead of the dance music tracks, the second disc contained a selection of hip hop and R&B tracks. The album was released in the United States as a single disc, with a slightly different track listing. The first disc of the UK version of the album contains songs by artists who were very popular in the United Kingdom at the time, including the Pussycat Dolls, McFly, Lawson, Joss Stone, and Emma Bunton. The second disc contains dance versions of songs by artists such as New Order, The Killers, and Coldplay, along with cover versions of songs such as "Tainted Love" and "Another One Bites the Dust" by groups such as The Automatic and The Kooks. In the United States, the album was released as a single disc containing songs by artists such as Amerie, The Black Eyed Peas, Mary J Blige, and Daddy Yankee, along with songs by UK artists such as James Morrison and Joss Stone.

Cyd Zeigler is a Canadian politician who was elected to in the Yukon Legislative Assembly in the 2011 election. Cyd Zeigler was born and raised in the Yukon. She is a third-generation Yukoner with roots in the territory dating back to the Klondike Gold Rush. She is of Ukrainian descent. Zeigler was a Whitehorse city councillor from 2005 to 2011, and was the Yukon vice-chair of the Canadian Northern Economic Development Agency from 2007 to 2011. In the 2011 election, Zeigler was elected to the Yukon Legislative Assembly as a member of the Yukon Party. She defeated incumbent New Democrat Kevin Barr by eight votes in the Whitehorse Centre riding. She was the Yukon Party's candidate in the riding of Whitehorse Centre in the 2016 election, but lost to Barr by 20 votes. Zeigler was a member of the Yukon Party government led by Dennis Fentie from 2011 to 2016. She served as the Minister of Justice and the Minister of the Public Service Commission in the Fentie government, and continued in the Justice portfolio in the subsequent government led by Premier Darrell Pasloski. In November 2014, she was also named the Minister responsible for the Women's Directorate, and in January 2015, she was named the Minister responsible for the Yukon Housing Corporation. In August 2011, Zeigler was accused of conflict of interest after it was revealed that she had accepted a $1,250 gift from a Yukon lawyer while she was a city councillor. The Yukon Integrity Commissioner found that Zeigler had not broken the law, but that she had fallen short of the ethical standards expected of her. In 2013, Zeigler was accused by the Yukon Employees' Union of bullying behaviour towards staff at the Department of Justice. An investigation by the Yukon Executive Council found that "there is no basis to conclude that Minister Zeigler engaged in bullying and/or harassment". In 2015, the Yukon News revealed that Zeigler's annual expense reports had been audited three times in three years by the Yukon Legislative Assembly's Accounting Officer, a fact that was not revealed to the public until the News obtained a copy of a confidential report to the Speaker of the Yukon Legislative Assembly.

Decatur High School is a four-year secondary school in Decatur, Alabama, United States. The school was founded in 1908. The school's campus is located on a large plot of land on the corner of Wood Street and Priority Way in the city's northwest quadrant, adjacent to the Hargrove Junior High School. The school's main building, built in the early 1950s, is a two-story U-shaped structure. The school's attendance boundary includes most of the city of Decatur and a small portion of the city of Hartselle. Decatur High School is a public school and is part of the Decatur City Schools district. The school's feeder schools are: * Azalea Elementary School * Columbia Elementary School * Drakesville Elementary School * Full-moon Elementary School * Mclntyre Elementary School * Meads Mill Elementary School * Moores Mill Elementary School * Old Union Elementary School * Price Elementary School * Trinity Elementary School * Wynn Elementary School The school has a football stadium, named for stadium manager Al Richard, and a baseball field, named for coach and athletic director Mike White. The school also has a large gymnasium, an agriculture building, a band building, and a cafeteria. The school has had several school resource officers throughout the years, from the Decatur Police Department. Decatur High School is accredited by the Alabama Department of Education.

Chin Injeti is a Canadian musician, songwriter, and record producer, known for his work with the band Bassnectar, with whom he has released several albums, and for his production work with other artists. Injeti's musical career began in the 1980s, when he joined the Canadian band The crüxshadows, with whom he would release two albums, The crüxshadows (1989) and affix the crüx (1990), before leaving to join the band Nüground in 1991. The following year, Injeti and the other members of Nüground left the band to form Bassnectar, with whom he would release his first album, Music for Your Mother, in 1993. Injeti would go on to release several more albums with Bassnectar, including Endproduct (1995), The Brothers EP (1996), The Girl with the Pierced Eardrum (1998), and The Down with the Sickness EP (1999), before leaving the band in 2000. He would then release a solo album, The Injeti Effect, in 2002, and a remix album, Re:mix, in 2003, before forming the band Transcendental with DJ Starscream in 2004. Injeti's production work includes albums by the bands A.F.R.O., Black Sun Empire, and Tech Itch, as well as the solo artist Somatic. He has also produced tracks for the video games SSX and SSX Tricky, and has composed music for the films Urban Legends: Final Cut and Scary Movie.

The Other Campaign is a political action group and registered 501(c)4 non-profit organization in the United States, founded in 1996 by Ralph Nader. The organization's stated aim is "to realize a democracy where the people, and not the corporations or the government, are the fountain of power." The Other Campaign's strategy is to run a Green Party ticket in the United States presidential election, with Nader as the candidate for president and Michael Bloomberg as the candidate for vice president. The Other Campaign has field organizers in over thirty states, and has had a federal campaign as well as state and local campaigns. The Other Campaign describes itself as "a political organization dedicated to education and to bringing about political change in the United States." The group's strategy is to "build a permanent political party with a constant presence in every election, from local to national." In 1998, Nader published Crashing the Gate: The Defeat of American Democracy, which laid out the need for a new political party and the strategy of The Other Campaign. In 2000, Nader, running as the Green Party candidate for president, received 2,882,175 votes, or 2.74 percent of the vote, in the U.S. presidential election.

Albert Scardino (born October 30, 1947) is an American journalist and businessman who was the editor and publisher of the Houston Chronicle from 1997 to 2013. Scardino was born in Dallas, Texas, and graduated from St. Mark's School of Texas in 1965. He received a bachelor's degree in journalism from the University of Texas at Austin in 1969 and a master's degree in English literature from the University of Bristol in England in 1970. Scardino began his journalism career at the Fort Worth Star-Telegram, where he was a reporter from 1971 to 1975. He then worked for 12 years at the Dallas Morning News, where he was a reporter, feature writer, and editor. From 1987 to 1997, he was editor and publisher of the El Paso Times. In 1997, Scardino became editor and publisher of the Houston Chronicle, a position he held until 2013. During his tenure as publisher, the Chronicle won three Pulitzer Prizes, including two for its coverage of Hurricane Katrina and the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. In 2009, the Chronicle was named the best large newspaper in the United States by the National Newspaper Association. Scardino has served on the board of directors of the Associated Press, the Texas Democracy Foundation, and the Journalistic Education Foundation of Texas. He is a member of the American Society of Newspaper Editors and the Texas Press Association. In 2013, Scardino was inducted into the Texas Newspaper Hall of Fame.

Jody McCrea (born July 30, 1932) is an American actor, producer, writer, director, and singer, best known for playing the young version of the character Sam McCade in the science fiction film Close Encounters of the Third Kind. McCrea was born in Los Angeles, California, the son of actor Joel McCrea and actress Frances Dee. He attended the University of California, Los Angeles, where he was a member of the U.C.L.A. Bruins swimming team. McCrea began his acting career in television, with a part in an episode of his father's series, Riverboat. He appeared in an episode of The Gene Autry Show in 1950, and had a small but memorable role in an episode of The Twilight Zone in 1961. He also appeared in an episode of The Outer Limits in 1964. McCrea appeared in a number of films, including The Misadventures of Merlin Jones (1964), The Ghost and Mr. Chicken (1966), The Hostage (1967), and Thanx for the Ride (1969). He also appeared in a number of television films, including The Desperate Mission (1969) and The Shaggy D.A. (1959). McCrea produced, wrote, and directed the short film Cows in 1992. He also produced, wrote, and directed the feature film The Town That Blew Away (1997). McCrea is a member of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

Conferences of the United Church of Christ The UCC is composed of settings from the smallest local churches to the largest national organizations. In between are several layers of larger-scale organization, including the conferences. The conferences are regional bodies of the UCC, consisting of all the churches in a given region. Each conference has a unique name and is led by a "conference minister," who may or may not also be a pastor of one of the churches in the conference. The conferences cooperate with each other and the churches in their regions on many different levels. They have a strong tradition of working together to achieve goals that the individual churches could not accomplish on their own. One example is the establishment of new congregations. The conferences have funds set aside to help new churches get started, and they offer expertise and guidance to help new churches grow and become healthy, strong congregations. In addition to working with the churches in their regions, the conferences also maintain ties with the national setting of the UCC. The General Council is made up of delegates from the conferences, and the General Minister and President is chosen by the General Council. The conferences also have representation on the various agencies and boards of the UCC. The conferences are divided into five "itions" ( regions ), each of which has its own characteristics and personality. The Atlantic Conference includes all of the churches in the states of Maine, New Hampshire, Vermont, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, and Connecticut. It is the most diverse conference, with a wide variety of rural, urban, and suburban churches. It is also the most progressive conference, with a strong history of social action and outreach. The Pacific Conference is made up of all the churches in the states of California, Oregon, and Washington. It is the largest conference, with the most churches and the most members. It is also the most diverse conference, with a wide variety of churches, from large urban congregations to small rural churches. The Southwest Conference includes all of the churches in the states of Arizona, New Mexico, and Texas. It is the newest conference, having been formed in 1996 when the churches in the Southwest became a separate conference from the churches in the Northwest. It is also the most diverse conference, with a wide variety of rural, urban, and suburban churches. The Southeast Conference is made up of all the churches in the states of Florida, Georgia, Alabama, North Carolina, South Carolina, and Tennessee. It is the second largest conference, with a wide variety of rural, urban, and suburban churches. The Northeast Conference includes all of the churches in the states of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, and the District of Columbia. It is the oldest conference, having been formed in 1961 when the churches in the Northeast became a separate conference from the churches in the Southeast. It is also the most urban conference, with a majority of the churches located in the Philadelphia and New York City areas.

Tony Brown (born February 21, 1954 in Detroit, Michigan) is an American record producer, songwriter, musician, and inventor. He has produced over 30 Top 10 Billboard R&B chart hits and 8 Top 10 Billboard Hot 100 hits. In 1975, Brown founded the record label Brownmark Records. He has also been a songwriter and producer for Motown Records and has written and produced for artists such as James Brown, Michael Bolton, and The Temptations. In the early 1980s, Brown was a member of the band Brighton with Steve Hufton, and they released one album on RCA Records. In 1985, Brown formed the band Contagious with Steve Arrington, Dwayne Cook, and Darius Barnaby, and they released two albums on the Brownmark label. Brown has also been a producer and songwriter for films such as Hairspray 2:HAIRSPRAYGOLDEN Olimpics, and has composed music for films such as Do the Right Thing, White Men Can't Jump, and The Bodyguard. In the late 1980s, Brown founded the record label brownmark records inc, and the publishing company Brownmark Music.

Tim Couzens (born 11 October 1964) is an Australian former professional rugby league footballer who played in the 1980s and 1990s. He played for the Western Suburbs Magpies, Sydney Roosters, South Sydney Rabbitohs, North Queensland Cowboys and New Zealand Warriors. He also played for the New Zealand national rugby league team. Tim Couzens was born in Sydney, New South Wales, Australia. He attended Largs Public School in Largs, New South Wales, and Blakehurst High School in Blakehurst, New South Wales. He played his junior rugby league for the Kyle Bay club, and in 1981 was selected in the New South Wales Primary Schools' team. In 1982, Couzens was selected in the New South Wales Under 19's side, and the following year was chosen to play for the Australian Schoolboys' side. In 1984, he made his first grade debut for the Western Suburbs Magpies, and in 1985 was selected for the New South Wales Under 21 side. He played for the Magpies until the end of the 1989 season, and then played for the Sydney Roosters in 1990 and 1991, the South Sydney Rabbitohs in 1992, the North Queensland Cowboys in 1993, and the New Zealand Warriors in 1994. In 1989, Couzens played for the New South Wales Blues in all three games of the 1989 State of Origin series. He was named man-of-the-series, having scored a try and kicked three goals. In 1990, he again played in all three games, kicking four goals in the first game. He was again named man-of-the-series. In all, he played in 14 consecutive games for New South Wales, until 1994, when he was dropped to reserve grade by the then Blues' coach, John Peard. In 1993, Couzens played for the New Zealand national rugby league team in the 1993 Rugby League World Cup. He played in all three pool games, scoring a try and kicking two goals against Wales. Tim Couzens is currently the head coach of the New Zealand Warriors Jersey Flegg (Under 21) side.

The Phantom Freighter is a legendary ghost ship in Coast Guard folklore that has been spotted off the coast of Massachusetts. It is said to be aflame, and to disappear and reappear in different locations. There are several different legends concerning the Phantom Freighter, including one in which the ship was involved in a collision, caught fire, and sank with all hands on board. Other legends state that the Phantom Freighter was a perfectly fine ship that had a crew of ghosts, and was used to smuggle liquor during the Prohibition era. There are several different versions of the story, some of which state that the ship was involved in a collision, caught fire, and sank with all hands on board, while others state that the Phantom Freighter was a perfectly fine ship that had a crew of ghosts, and was used to smuggle liquor during the Prohibition era. The story of the Phantom Freighter was made into a movie in 2002, entitled The Phantom Freighter: A Ghost Ship, starring Brandon Lee and Michael Pare.

Master of Health Administration The Master of Health Administration (MHA) is a professional degree in health administration that prepares students for leadership and management roles in hospitals, health systems, and other healthcare organizations. The degree is designed to provide a broad perspective on the American health system as well as an intensive focus on the skills necessary to be an effective health administrator. The MHA degree is generally a two-year, 44-credit hour program. The curriculum is designed to provide a broad understanding of the complex health care system as well as an intensive focus on the skills necessary to be an effective health administrator. In the first year, students complete a core of courses that provide a broad perspective on the American health system. The second year is devoted to more specialized courses in health administration. Upon completion of the MHA degree, students are prepared for leadership and management roles in hospitals, health systems, and other healthcare organizations. The MHA degree is not designed to prepare students for clinical health care roles, such as physicians, nurses, or therapists. The MHA is a highly specialized degree that is not intended for individuals who are pursuing a career in a clinical health profession, such as medicine, nursing, or therapy. The MHA is designed for individuals who wish to pursue a career in health administration, which involves the management and administration of health care organizations. The MHA degree is offered by many colleges and universities around the world. In the United States, the MHA is offered by many of the leading graduate schools in health administration.

USS Albemarle (1863) The USS Albemarle was a single-turreted, iron-hulled, riverine monitor of the United States Navy, named for the Battle of Albemarle Sound during the American Civil War. The monitor's design was based on that of the USS Montauk, the first of the Monitor class to be laid down. Like the Montauk, the Albemarle was designed to operate in the shallower waters of the rivers and Sounds of the Carolinas, where the larger ocean-going monitors could not maneuver effectively. The Albemarle had a shallower draft than the Montauk, with a much lighter armament and a correspondingly lighter armor protection. The Albemarle was the first monitor to be equipped with a Hotchkiss revolving cannon. The Albemarle was laid down in 1862 at the Philadelphia Navy Yard; launched on 22 January 1863; and commissioned on 4 February 1864, with Commander George S. Blake in command. The Albemarle's first assignment was to support the Navy's effort to take the city of Fort Fisher, which was the last major port open to the Confederacy on the Atlantic Ocean. The Albemarle arrived at the mouth of the Cape Fear River in mid-January 1865, after the first battle for Fort Fisher, and helped to bottle up the fort and reduce its supplies and effectiveness. The Albemarle was heavily involved in the second battle for Fort Fisher, on 15 January 1865, providing fire support for the naval attack. The Albemarle was hit multiple times by Confederate artillery, but suffered no casualties or serious damage. After the second battle, the Albemarle, along with most of the other Union monitors, was sent to the James River in Virginia to support the final assault on the city of Richmond. The Albemarle arrived in the James River in early April 1865, just before the Lee's army evacuated the city. The Albemarle was one of the first Union warships to enter the city, and helped to accept the surrender of the city from Confederate authorities. The Albemarle was involved in the aftermath of the assassination of Abraham Lincoln, providing assistance to the Montauk, which had been ordered to transport the body of Lincoln to the capital. The Albemarle was decommissioned in May 1865, and placed in the James River reserve fleet. The Albemarle was never reactivated, and was eventually sunk to be used as a breakwater in the Delaware River in the 1870s.

Choanephora cucurbitarum is a species of fungus in the family Choanephoraceae. It is a plant pathogen that causes the disease powdery mildew of pumpkin. The fungus was first described by the British mycologist E.F. Corner in 1952. The sexual stage was unknown until a teleomorphic stage was discovered in 2008. The fungus is a worldwide pathogen of pumpkins and squashes. It also occurs on cucumber, luffa, and other cucurbits. Infection causes severe losses in quality and quantity of yield. The disease is difficult to control, as the pathogen can survive for long periods of time in the soil or on infected plant debris. The spores are spread by wind or by contaminated soil or tools. A powdery white mycelium grows on the surface of the infected plant. The mycelium often has a greyish cast due to the presence of conidia. The conidia are single-celled, and are not encapsulated. They are lens-shaped, and are 3–5 μm wide and 2–3 μm long. The fungus is listed as a quarantine pathogen in the United States.

Blue iguana The Blue iguana or Blue basilisk (Basiliscus coeruleus) is a large species of lizard in the family Corytophanidae. It is native to the Caribbean and is also known as the Blue belly iguana, the Blue ctenoid, or the Blue basilisk. It is one of three species in the genus Basiliscus. The Blue iguana is a large, heavy-bodied lizard with a tail that is relatively short compared to other iguanas. The body is typically blueish-gray to grayish-blue with a lighter underside. It has a row of large, round, orange spots down the center of the back and smaller spots on the sides. The spots may be faded or absent in some individuals. It has a row of large spikes down the middle of the tail and smaller spikes toward the sides. The Blue iguana is a good swimmer and can even swim in open water. It is typically found in forested areas near water. It is a good climber and can be found in trees, on rocks, or on the ground. It is a omnivorous species and its diet typically consists of fruits, leaves, flowers, and insects. The Blue iguana is a solitary species and is typically found alone. It is territorial and will defend its territory against other iguanas. It is also aggressive toward other species of lizards. It is a long-lived species and can live for more than 20 years in the wild and more than 30 years in captivity. The Blue iguana is native to the Caribbean islands of Guadeloupe, Dominica, and Martinique. It has been introduced to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. It is typically found in forested areas near water. It is a good climber and can be found in trees, on rocks, or on the ground. It is a omnivorous species and its diet typically consists of fruits, leaves, flowers, and insects. The Blue iguana is a solitary species and is typically found alone. It is territorial and will defend its territory against other iguanas. It is also aggressive toward other species of lizards. It is a long-lived species and can live for more than 20 years in the wild and more than 30 years in captivity.

2013 Rayong oil spill In June 2013, a pipeline carrying oil from the Kuwait Export Crude Oil Pipeline to the Laem Chabang Port in Thailand burst, resulting in an oil spillage of up to 80,000 litres (18,000 US gal). The oil spread along the coast of Rayong Province, and affected the beaches of Rayong, Pattaya, and Sattahip. The spill also affected the area's marine and fishing industries. The pipeline is owned by the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation (KPC), and the oil was destined for the Laem Chabang Port, the principal port for Bangkok. The pipeline was inspected in 2012, and was found to be in good condition. The cause of the spill is under investigation, but the damage is estimated to be US$62 million. The oil spill affected over 100 kilometres (62 mi) of coastline, with the oil spreading over the water and onto the beaches. The spill was most severe on the beaches of Rayong, where the oil had reached a depth of 2 kilometres (1.2 mi). On 25 June 2013, the Thai government declared the oil spill to be a disaster, and announced that the KPC would be required to provide THB1.6 billion (US$50 million) in compensation. The Thai government also requested that the KPC provide a further THB1.6 billion for environmental and marine rehabilitation. The KPC has accepted responsibility for the spill, and has pledged to clean up the spill, and to provide assistance to the affected areas. The company has also agreed to pay THB2 billion (US$60 million) in compensation to the Thai government.

A gateway station is a station where a transit service changes from one mode to another mode. The change may be from a subway, light rail, or bus rapid transit line to a bus, or vice versa. The change may also be from one subway, light rail, or bus rapid transit line to another subway, light rail, or bus rapid transit line. A gateway station is usually a major node in a transit system, and may be a major destination in its own right. The term is particularly used for stations in systems where one or more of the modes is not grade-separated, and thus the transfer involves going to a different location. In some cases, the different location is on the other side of a highway or other major barrier. A gateway station is often the hub of a transit network, where multiple routes converge. In many cases, the station is integrated with a large parking garage, allowing park-and-ride. In other cases, it is integrated with a transit-oriented development. The term gateway station is mainly used in the United States and Canada. In the UK, the term is mainly used for stations at the outer end of a rail branch line, where the line meets the main line. The first usage of the term "gateway" in a transportation context may be from the 1940s. It referred to the gateway stations of the New York City Subway, where the subway changed from one line to another. The term was used in a June 1948 article about the New York City Subway in The New York Times, and in a September 1948 article about the Washington, D.C. Metro. In British usage, the term gateway station is used for a station at the outer end of a rail branch line, where the line meets the main line. In Canadian usage, the term is used in a similar way to the American usage. In a January 2013 article about the new Metrolinx transit hub in Toronto, the term "gateway station" was used to refer to the existing GO Transit stations at Union Station and Exhibition Place. In July 2015, Metrolinx applied the term "gateway station" to the new Mount Dennis Station on the Kitchener line. In American usage, the term is used for a station where one mode changes to another mode. In some cases, it is used for a station where a line changes from one mode to another mode. In other cases, it is used for a station where a route changes from one mode to another mode. In some cases, the change may be from a subway, light rail, or bus rapid transit line to a bus, or vice versa. The change may also be from one subway, light rail, or bus rapid transit line to another subway, light rail, or bus rapid transit line. The term "gateway station" is also used for a station where a transit service changes from one mode to another mode. The change may be from a subway, light rail, or bus rapid transit line to a bus, or vice versa. The change may also be from one subway, light rail, or bus rapid transit line to another subway, light rail, or bus rapid transit line.

The Commission on the Humanities and Social Sciences was established by the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) in 2013 "to chart a course for the future of the humanities and social sciences." The commission's work will inform the NEH's plans for the future and will also be used to inform the planning of other federal, state, and local policy makers. The fifteen members of the commission were appointed by NEH Chairman William "Bro" Adams, and include prominent leaders in the humanities and social sciences, higher education, and public life. The commission is co-chaired by former Secretary of Education William J. Bennett and Harvard University President Lawrence H. Summers. The commission's first meeting took place on July 30, 2013, at the NEH headquarters in Washington, DC. At that meeting, the commission began its work on a report that will be delivered to the NEH in June 2014. The report will include recommendations "for a vibrant and durable future for the humanities and social sciences." In addition to its report to the NEH, the commission will also publish a report for a broad audience of policy makers, opinion leaders, and the general public. The commission will hold additional meetings in Washington, DC, and will also hold meetings in the field, where it will have an opportunity to learn more about the work being done in the humanities and social sciences, and the impact of that work on communities across the United States. The National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH) is an independent federal agency that funds and promotes research, education, and public programs in the humanities. The NEH is one of the largest federal supporters of the humanities in the United States. The humanities are a rich and diverse set of disciplines that include the study of history, literature, language, philosophy, and the arts. The humanities provide a context for our lives, our communities, and our culture. They help us understand our past, our present, and our future. The humanities teach us about the diversity of human experience and the ways that we can learn from that experience to make our lives better. The social sciences are a diverse set of disciplines that include the study of human behavior, society, and the economy. The social sciences provide a context for our lives, our communities, and our culture. They help us understand our past, our present, and our future. The social sciences teach us about the diversity of human experience and the ways that we can learn from that experience to make our lives better.

Alexander Nisbet (1639–1721) was a Scottish herald and antiquary, best known for his work on the history of the Scottish tartan. Nisbet was born in Aberdeen, and lived there for much of his life. He was employed as an officer of arms at the Scottish College of Arms in Edinburgh from 1681 to 1704, and was also a collector of historical documents and a writer on genealogical topics. His best known work is the Scottish Tartans, which was published in 1704. This work includes a description of the tartan patterns used by the Highland clans, and is the first published work on the subject. It also includes a description of the heraldic symbols used by the clans, and a discussion of the history of the clans and their chiefs. Nisbet's work was well received at the time, and was used as a reference for later works on the subject. It was revised and expanded by later writers, and has been reprinted several times since it was first published. However, it has also been criticized for being incomplete and inaccurate, and for being based on a limited range of sources.

In geometry, a facet is a flat surface of a polyhedron. The word is from the Latin root facere, "to make". A polyhedron is a solid in three dimensions with flat faces. The faces are usually regular shapes, such as triangles, squares, or hexagons. A polyhedron is named by the number of faces it has. For example, a polyhedron with three faces is a triangle, one with four faces is a square, and one with eight faces is an octagon. In addition to the faces, a polyhedron has edges and vertices. The place where three edges meet is a vertex. The faces of a polyhedron can be classified by their location on the polyhedron. If a face is a vertex, it is called a vertex face. If a face is an edge, it is called an edge face. The rest of the faces are called face faces. A polyhedron can be named by the number of faces it has. It can also be named by the number of vertices, edges, or faces. For example, a square is a polyhedron with four faces, but it also has four vertices and four edges. Facets are flat surfaces that make up the faces of a polyhedron. A facet is the same as a face, so a polyhedron can also be named by the number of facets it has. For example, a cube has eight facets, and a dodecahedron has twenty facets. The shape of a polyhedron is the shape of the facets. For example, a cube is a polyhedron with eight facets, and the shape of the facets is a square.

Alyssa Beckerman (born December 3, 1980) is an American actress and singer. Beckerman was born in Los Angeles, California. She is the daughter of actress/director Martha Gehman and producer Larry Beckerman. In 2002, Beckerman was cast as a series regular on the Disney Channel's That's So Raven, playing the role of Katie, Raven's best friend. She appeared in over 100 episodes, and also recorded several songs for the series' soundtrack. In 2006, Beckerman appeared in the independent film, Man in the Chair, opposite Michael Douglas and Ryan Reynolds. She also appeared in the music video for The Black Eyed Peas' "Bebot". In 2008, Beckerman was a contestant on the eighth season of American Idol, where she sang "Breathe" by Faith Hill for her first performance, and "The Voice Within" by Christina Aguilera for her second performance. She was eliminated during the Top 24 stage. In 2012, Beckerman appeared in the documentary film, The Man behind the Curtain, which examined the life of Wizard of Oz author L. Frank Baum. She is a graduate of Princeton University, where she earned a degree in history. In 2013, Beckerman appeared in an episode of the TV series, Supernatural, as Miss Chance. She is currently working on a musical about her great-great-great-aunt, Cecilia Payne, the first person to earn a Ph.D. in astronomy.

Kathleen Newland (born 1942) is an American political scientist, researcher, author, and professor at the Center for Latin American and Caribbean Studies at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. She is the co-author of four books and the author of four books, most recently, The Latin Americanization of the Caribbean: How the Caribbean Became Latin, Puerto Rico, and Cubans in New York. Newland received her B.A. in 1964 from the University of Notre Dame, and her M.A. and Ph.D. in political science from the University of California, Berkeley in 1966 and 1970, respectively. Newland has been a member of the faculty at the University of Illinois since 1984. Her research has been funded by the National Science Foundation, the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Ford Foundation, and the Social Science Research Council. She has also been a fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, and the Russell Sage Foundation. She has served as a consultant to the World Bank and the Inter-American Development Bank. Newland has written widely on the political economy of development, with an emphasis on the economics and politics of international trade and finance, especially as these relate to Latin America. Her books include Trade and Finance in Latin America: The World Economy and the Latin American Economies (co-author, 1984), The Political Economy of International Trade: The World Economy and the Latin American Economies (co-author, 1988), The Role of the State in the Economy: New Political Economy of Trade and Investment (co-author, 1996), and The Latin Americanization of the Caribbean (co-author, 2006). In addition to her research and teaching, Newland has been active in the area of international education. She has served as a consultant to a number of international organizations and government agencies, including the Organization of American States, the United Nations Development Programme, the International Development Bank, and the Agency for International Development. She has also served as a reviewer for a number of journals and publishers, and as a member of the editorial board of the Journal of Development Studies.

Lü Ronghua (born August 1950) is a Chinese engineer and politician. He was the vice-minister of Construction Engineering Department of the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development of the People's Republic of China from 2003 to 2008. In 2008, he was transferred to Ministry of Commerce, and became the vice-minister of the Department of Commerce. Born in 1950 in Beijing, Lü was graduated from the department of civil engineering, Tsinghua University in 1982. He worked as an engineer at the Construction Engineering Company of the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development from 1982 to 1995, and served as the general manager of the Beijing Construction Engineering Company from 1995 to 1997. In 1997, he was appointed the vice-president of the Beijing Urban Construction Engineering Company, and became the president in 2000. In 2003, he was elevated to the vice-minister of Construction Engineering Department of the Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development. In 2008, he was transferred to the Ministry of Commerce, and became the vice-minister of the Department of Commerce.

Ransom (TV series) Ransom is an American drama television series, adapted by David Nutter and directed by Phil Joanou, from the Ransom novel series by David Morrell. The series stars Hugh Dancy, Jim Caviezel, and Sarah Wayne Callies, and premiered on CBS on January 22, 1996. After two seasons, the series was canceled in the United States. However, four television movies were made, two in Canada and two in France. The first movie, Ransom Live, was made for Canada's Showtime network, and the other three were made for TF1 in France. The movies were shown on the CBS Summer Movie Series in 1998. Ransom is a globe-spanning tale of intrigue and suspense, starring Hugh Dancy as Eric Ransom, a hostage negotiator. The series also stars Jim Caviezel as kidnapping ringleader Robert T. Irons, and Sarah Wayne Callies as psychologist Dr. Julia Madigan. After the series' cancellation, the story was continued in the four made-for-television movies, with the characters' fates left uncertain at the end of the series. The first movie, Ransom Live, was shot in Toronto, Canada, and the other three were shot in Paris, France. The first movie was shown on the CBS Summer Movie Series in 1998, and the other three were shown the following year. In the first movie, which was set in Toronto, Canada, and had a completely different cast from the series, Eric Ransom is now living in Toronto and working as a police officer. He is also in a relationship with Dr. Madigan, who is shown to be pregnant with his child. When the daughter of a wealthy family is kidnapped, Ransom is forced to re-evaluate his life as he becomes emotionally involved in the case. In the second movie, Ransom is shown to have left the police force and is now working as a private detective. He is also shown to be raising his daughter, Julia, alone after the death of Dr. Madigan. When the daughter of a wealthy family is kidnapped, Ransom is forced to re-evaluate his life as he becomes emotionally involved in the case. In the third movie, which was set in Paris, France, and had a completely different cast from the series and the first movie, Eric Ransom is now living in Paris and working as a private detective. He is also in a relationship with a woman named Claire, who is shown to be pregnant with his child. When the daughter of a wealthy family is kidnapped, Ransom is forced to re-evaluate his life as he becomes emotionally involved in the case. In the fourth movie, which was set in New York City, USA, and had a completely different cast from the series, the first movie, and the third movie, Eric Ransom is now living in New York and working as a private detective. He is also shown to be raising his daughter, Julia, alone after the death of Dr. Madigan. When the daughter of a wealthy family is kidnapped, Ransom is forced to re-evaluate his life as he becomes emotionally involved in the case.

Henri Nathansen (6 April 1886 – 8 November 1961) was a Danish composer, conductor, and musician. He was the younger brother of the writer Carl Nathansen, and the father of the writer and resistance fighter Hans Nathansen. Born in Copenhagen, Nathansen studied music at the Copenhagen Academy of Music under the composer and conductor Emil Reesen. He was a highly gifted musician and, although he never gained a formal university education, he became a recognized authority on music theory and music history. In his youth, Nathansen played the violin, but he later turned to conducting. For many years, Nathansen was the conductor of the Fodbold-Foreningen Copenhagen. He also conducted the Royal Life Guard's band and, from 1930 until his death, he was the conductor of the Royal Danish Orchestra at the Kongen's Nytorv theatre. In addition to his work as a conductor, Nathansen also composed a number of marches, including the march for the Royal Life Guards, Der er et yndigt land, and the Olympic Torch Relay Theme for the 1948 Summer Olympics in London. Nathansen was also a writer on musical subjects, and he published a number of articles and books on music theory, music history, and the lives of musicians. His most notable work was the four-volume Den Store Klang ("The Great Sound"), a comprehensive history of music theory and practice. In addition to his work as a musician and writer, Nathansen was also a dedicated teacher, and he taught music theory and history at the Copenhagen Academy of Music for many years. He was a member of the Danish Music Critics' Association and the International Music Critics' Association, and he served as a music critic for a number of Danish newspapers and journals.

Edwin Joseph O'Malley (December 7, 1882 – August 11, 1952) was an American politician and businessman from the state of Montana, best known for serving as the 22nd Governor of Montana from 1930 to 1932. O'Malley was born in Belt, Montana in 1882, the son of Irish immigrants. He attended the University of Montana and graduated with a degree in civil engineering in 1904. In 1908 he married and had three children with his wife Elizabeth. After graduation, he went into the banking business and also became involved in local politics in his home town of Belt. In 1928, O'Malley was elected to the Montana House of Representatives, where he served one two-year term. In 1930, he was elected governor, defeating incumbent John E. Erickson by a margin of 3,343 votes. At the time, Montana Republicans were divided between the "Standpatters," who opposed economic reform and supported the status quo, and the "New Elephants," who supported reform and favored a more active role for the state government. The Standpatters dominated the party's nomination process, and O'Malley was nominated over the New Elephants' candidate, former state senator Charles H. Morrill. As governor, O'Malley had to deal with the effects of the Great Depression, which had a major impact on Montana's economy. The state's revenues declined dramatically, and O'Malley was forced to make significant budget cuts. He also had to deal with a number of strikes and labor disputes, including a major coal strike that lasted for several months. In addition, O'Malley was instrumental in the founding of the Montana Highway Patrol, the state's first organized law enforcement agency. He also supported the construction of new roads and other infrastructure projects, and worked to improve the state's education system. O'Malley was defeated for re-election in 1932, losing to Democrat Roy E. Ayers by a margin of 3,120 votes. After leaving office, he returned to his banking business and also served as a trustee for the University of Montana. He died in 1952, at the age of 69.

Winter's Tale (novel) Winter's Tale is a novel by Mark Helprin, published in 1983 by Jonathan Cape, London. The novel was a literary success, receiving positive reviews and becoming a best seller in the United States. Winter's Tale is set in New York City, mainly in the years between 1960 and 1990. It tells the story of a half-wild "foundling" boy, Peter Lake, who is taken in by a poor family in the South Bronx. The family is squatting in an abandoned apartment of a large, empty building, and Peter is told that he is the son of the building's owner. When the building is sold, Peter is forced to live with his wealthy relatives, the Colemans, in their apartment on Park Avenue. As an adult, Peter becomes a successful Wall Street lawyer. He falls in love with a beautiful young woman, Beverly, who is engaged to his brother, William. When William is killed in a plane crash, Peter marries Beverly and they have a son, Charlie. Later, Beverly dies of cancer and Peter becomes a "winter's tale", a fatherless man with no purpose in life. Peter is approached by a mysterious man, Mr. Setterland, who claims to have known his late mother. Setterland asks Peter to perform a dangerous task: to fly to Moscow and extract a document from the Soviet Union's "Topolov" files. Peter refuses, but later learns that Setterland may have been his father. He then reconsiders, and travels to Moscow using a fake passport. In Moscow, Peter meets a beautiful Russian woman, Yevgeny, who is also a "winter's tale". They fall in love and she tells him about the Russian winter, which is a time of death but also a time of rebirth. Yevgeny helps Peter to translate the Topolov file, which contains the recipe for a deadly nerve agent. When Peter returns to New York, he is arrested by the FBI for violating the passport act. To prove that he is not a spy, Peter shows the FBI the Topolov file, which contains the recipe for the nerve agent. The FBI is unable to translate the file, and Peter is released. Peter decides to destroy the Topolov file, but he is attacked by two men who try to take it from him. He kills one, and the other escapes. Peter then burns the file and throws the ashes into the river. Later, Peter is visited by Setterland, who tells him that he is indeed Peter's father. Setterland explains that Peter's mother was a Russian who defected to the United States during World War II. She was a "winter's tale" like Yevgeny, and Setterland fell in love with her. However, she was killed in a car accident in 1960, the same year that Peter was born. Setterland tells Peter that the Topolov file was not a Soviet secret, but a Russian fairy tale. The "recipe" was actually a description of a magical potion that could bring the dead back to life. The file was given to Setterland by Peter's mother, and he has been trying to understand it ever since her death. Setterland says that he is ready to die and wants Peter to promise to live, so that he can see the world through Peter's eyes. Peter promises, and Setterland dies. Peter realizes that Setterland was indeed his father, and that he has inherited the "winter's tale" from his mother. Winter's Tale is a novel about fathers and sons, love and loss, and the power of storytelling. It is a fable about the importance of living, and about the possibility of redemption and rebirth.

Coffins on Io In 1979, two coffins, each about 1.5 meters (5 ft) long, were discovered on the surface of Io, a moon of the planet Jupiter. The coffins were facing each other, with one set of long narrow rods placed perpendicularly to the body and the other placed parallel to the body. The disposition of the rods suggests that they were intended to support the coffins in a standing position. The structure of the coffins' lids appears to be a series of horizontal and vertical lines scored into the surface of the lid, perhaps forming a ladder-like pattern. The design of the coffins is different from any previously discovered in the Solar System, but the burial practice is similar to that of the Alaskans and other native groups in western North America, where the deceased were placed in standing position with their feet oriented to the direction of the spirits of the dead. The coffins were discovered by Voyager 1 during its flyby of Io on March 5, 1979. They were located on the western edge of the large caldera called thrombrenite, at the edge of a volcanic plateau called Dazet. The two coffins are about 5 km (3.1 mi) apart. The discovery of the coffins caused much speculation about the possibility of life on Io. It was later determined that the coffins, along with many other features on the surface of Io, were formed by thermo-chemical dissolution, in which the combination of extreme temperatures and strong chemicals, possibly including sulfur, breaks down the surface materials. The same process had been previously identified on the surfaces of Mercury and Venus. In August 1979, five months after the Voyager 1 flyby, a team of scientists led by Donald R. Curren of the University of Michigan concluded that the coffins were probably formed by the solidification of a sulfur-rich liquid. The surface of the coffin was determined to be a thin, cracked lid of solid sulfur, and the body of the coffin was thought to be a larger block of solid sulfur that had been hollowed out. The Curren team also found that the rods in the vicinity of the coffins were composed of the same sulfur-rich material as the coffins themselves. The Curren team's findings were published in a 1980 article in the journal Science. In the same issue of Science, a team of scientists led by William B. McKibben of the NASA Ames Research Center presented its own analysis of the coffins. The McKibben team concluded that the coffins were probably formed by the solidification of a sulfur-rich liquid, as the Curren team had suggested. However, the McKibben team also concluded that the coffins were not made of solid sulfur, but rather a sulfur-rich liquid that had hardened into a glass-like solid. The McKibben team's findings were published in a 1980 article in the journal Science. Since the discovery of the coffins, many other features on the surfaces of the planets and their moons have been discovered that were formed by thermo-chemical dissolution. These features include the "spider" and "tortoise" features on the surface of Mercury, and the "cauliflowers" and "snake-like" features on the surface of Venus.

Karima Francis (born October 31, 1981) is an American singer, songwriter, and record producer. Born and raised in Detroit, Michigan, Francis began her career as a singer in the local R&B group D Fergus. In 2003, she launched her solo career with the release of The Karima Francis Project, an EP released via the group's independent label, DFZ Records. The following year, she signed with MCA Records, through which she released her second EP, The Long & Winding Road, and her first and only album, The One, in 2005. The One peaked at number 46 on the Billboard 200 and produced the hit single "Rock with You", which peaked at number 22 on the Billboard R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. In 2006, she appeared as a guest vocalist on the track "Lonely" from Monica's third studio album The Makings of Me. Following the release of The One, Francis went on to work as a songwriter and producer for various artists, including Akon, David Guetta, Ne-Yo, Chris Brown, Keri Hilson, and Mary. Blige. In 2008, she released her first independent project in six years, The Intermission EP, via her official website. In 2009, she appeared as a guest vocalist on the track "Chicken Fat" from the compilation album The Chronicles of Marnia. In 2011, she released her second independent project, The Night Life, via her official website. In 2012, she appeared as a guest vocalist on the track "Scandalous" from the compilation album Mavin Records All Stars. Karima Francis was born in Detroit, Michigan. Her mother, Catherine Francis, was a member of the R&B group The Sweethearts, who performed alongside acts such as The Isley Brothers and The Temptations. Her father, Donald Francis, was a member of the doo-wop group The Silhouettes. She has two older brothers, one of whom is singer and producer Aliaune Thiam. Francis began her career as a singer in the local R&B group D Fergus, which was formed by her brother Aliaune Thiam. The group's members were Francis, Thiam, Carl Thompson, and Rasheed Shakir. In 2003, the group released an independent EP, The Karima Francis Project, via their label, DFZ Records. The following year, the group signed with MCA Records and changed their name to D.F. Project. The label soon dropped the group, although they were able to release their second EP, The Long & Winding Road, via their own label in 2004. In 2005, the group released their first and only album, The One, via their own label. The album peaked at number 46 on the Billboard 200 and produced the hit single "Rock with You", which peaked at number 22 on the Billboard R&B/Hip-Hop Songs chart. Following the release of The One, Francis went on to work as a songwriter and producer for various artists, including Akon, David Guetta, Ne-Yo, Chris Brown, Keri Hilson, and Mary. Blige. In 2008, she released her first independent project in six years, The Intermission EP, via her official website. The EP featured production by her brother, Aliaune Thiam, and included the single "Peep Me", which was written by Francis, Aliaune Thiam, and Ne-Yo. In 2009, she appeared as a guest vocalist on the track "Chicken Fat" from the compilation album The Chronicles of Marnia. In 2011, she released her second independent project, The Night Life, via her official website. The album featured production by her brother, Aliaune Thiam, and included the single "Waste My Time", which was written by Francis, Aliaune Thiam, and Ne-Yo. In 2012, she appeared as a guest vocalist on the track "Scandalous" from the compilation album Mavin Records All Stars.
