1926–27 Clarkson Golden Knights men's ice hockey season The 1926–27 Clarkson Golden Knights men's ice hockey team represented Clarkson College in the 1926–27 college ice hockey season. The team was coached by Jack Foster and played its home games at the Clarkson Ice Hockey Rink. The Golden Knights finished with a 19–3–1 record, the second straight season in which the team had a record of 19 wins and 3 losses or better. The team won the Tri-State League, making it the first time the team had won the league in three seasons. The team also won the NCAA Championship for the second time in three years, the first time the team had won back-to-back national championships. The team was led by senior center Paul Laylin, who finished with a team-high 21 goals and a plus-minus of +23. Laylin was named the team's most valuable player for the second straight season. Junior goalie Charles Kerr, who had been a member of the team since the program's inaugural 1926 season, had a goals-against average of 1.05 and a save percentage of .928, the best in the nation. The team's defense, led by senior captain Russ Laylin and junior Herb Hannah, allowed only 33 goals in 22 games, for a goals-against average of 1.52, the best in the nation. The Golden Knights opened the season with a 5–0 win over Hamilton College on December 17, 1926. The team then won its next four games, including a 3–0 win over McGill on January 1, 1927, a 3–1 win over Dartmouth on January 3, and a 4–0 win over Yale on January 15. The team's five-game winning streak was snapped on January 22, when the Golden Knights lost to Princeton, 3–1. However, the team won its next three games, including a 4–1 win over Harvard on February 12, to finish the regular season with a 16–3–1 record. The team had a record of 8–1–1 in the Tri-State League, finishing in first place for the second straight year. The Golden Knights began the postseason with a 5–1 win over second-ranked McGill in the NCAA semifinal on March 11, 1927. Two days later, the team defeated third-ranked Harvard, 3–1, in the NCAA Championship Game. It was the second straight national championship for the Golden Knights, the first time a team had won back-to-back national championships since Princeton in 1906 and 1907.

The Naval Intelligence Department was a department of the British Admiralty responsible for gathering military intelligence about the enemy during the First World War. It was established in 1914 and existed for the duration of the war. The department was led by Captain William Hall. The department had a number of sub-departments including the Trade Division and the Enemy Submarine Section. The Trade Division was responsible for gathering intelligence about enemy trade and merchant shipping. The Enemy Submarine Section was responsible for gathering intelligence about enemy submarines. The department also had a number of other sub-departments including the Intelligence Division, the Submarine Intelligence Section, and the Mine Warfare Section. The Naval Intelligence Department was a highly secret department and its existence was not revealed to the public until after the war. It played a vital role in the war effort by providing the British Navy with valuable intelligence about the enemy. The department was dissolved in 1919.

Lisburn Road is a road in Belfast, Northern Ireland. It runs through the south of the city, close to the River Lagan, and is one of the main shopping streets in the city, forming part of the BONE (Belfast One-way Network Express) traffic-calming system. The road starts at the roundabout junction with Ormeau Road, Malone Road and University Road in the south of the city and runs northwards for about 1.5 miles (2.4 km) along a one-way system, crossing the river twice by bridges. It passes through the communities of Malone and Lisburn Road. At its northern end it passes under the M2 motorway and joins the A55 road to Antrim and Belfast International Airport. The Lisburn Road is one of the main roads in Belfast for retail businesses, with a large number of shops, restaurants, cafes and bars. It also has a variety of other businesses and offices. It is close to the main campus of Queen's University Belfast, and is largely residential. The road has been a focal point for the growth of the city's "Golden Mile", with many new developments taking place in the area in the late 20th and early 21st centuries. In 2008, a study by estate agents Savills described the road as "the premier high street in Northern Ireland". Lisburn Road is also the name of a ward in the South Belfast electoral area, which includes the road and the surrounding area. It is part of the South Belfast constituency for the Northern Ireland Assembly and the Belfast South constituency for the House of Commons. In 2006, a consultation document on improving the road was prepared by the Department for Regional Development. The document suggested that the road could be closed to traffic, with shoppers having to park in a large underground car park. The proposal met with opposition from some local businesses, residents and politicians, who argued that the road should remain open. In January 2007, the Alliance Party proposed that the road should be pedestrianised, with vehicles restricted to a few local residents and businesses. The Lisburn Road Business Improvement District (BID) was launched in 2007, and is the second BID in Northern Ireland. The BID covers the area from the roundabout at the Ormeau Road to the roundabout at the Malone Road, and from the M2 motorway to the junction with the Lower Malone Road. In October 2010, a large new shopping and leisure complex, the Lisburn Road Central Plaza, was opened on the street, with a number of new retail and restaurant outlets.

AIP Records is an American independent record label founded by the band A.I.D.A. in 1999 and based in Los Angeles, California. The label has released albums by A.I.D.A., Adolescents, Agoraphobic Nosebleed, Arcane Knowledge, Curl Up and Die, Disfear, Integrity, Incompetech, Leviathan, Lymphatic, Machete Kitten, Manmade God, and Nomy. In 1999, A.I.D.A. was looking for a way to release their music without having to rely on any outside sources, and, after considering a number of different options, they decided to start their own record label, A.I.D.A. Records. The label was incorporated in 2001 and, in addition to A.I.D.A., has since released material by several other bands, including the Adolescents, Agoraphobic Nosebleed, and Curl Up and Die. In 2003, AIP Records released the album When Worlds Collide by the Adolescents. The album was the band's first new material in almost 20 years, and was met with a positive reception, selling over 10,000 copies. AIP Records has continued to release new material by the Adolescents, including the albums OCPC/OPC and The Black Flag, as well as re-releasing the band's earlier material, such as the EP Can You Feel It? and the full-length album Brats in Battalions. In addition to the Adolescents, AIP Records has also released material by the bands Agoraphobic Nosebleed, Curl Up and Die, Disfear, Integrity, Incompetech, Leviathan, Lymphatic, Machete Kitten, Manmade God, and Nomy. In 2017, AIP Records celebrated its 20th anniversary with the release of a special compilation album, entitled AIP Records 20th Anniversary Compilation. The album featured material from all of the bands on the label's roster, as well as a number of guest musicians, and was released as a limited-edition CD.

Political positions of Benigno Aquino III Benigno Aquino III was born to a well-known political family in the Philippines. His father, Benigno Aquino, Jr., was a highly respected opposition leader who was assassinated in 1983. His mother, Corazon Aquino, was a former First Lady who succeeded his father in the opposition after his death and was later elected as the first female president of the Philippines. Throughout his life, Aquino III was never involved in politics, instead choosing to pursue a career in the private sector. He worked as a financial analyst in various investment banks and companies in the United States and Hong Kong. He also served as an adviser to his mother during her presidency. Aquino III's political beliefs were aligned with his mother's democratic principles, and he was known for being a strong advocate for good governance, transparency, and reform. He was also a vocal critic of corruption and the abuse of power, and he worked to improve the lives of the poor and underprivileged. Aquino III was elected to the Senate of the Philippines in 2007, and he served as a senator until his resignation in 2012 to run for the presidency. He was sworn in as the 15th president of the Philippines on June 30, 2010, and he served until June 30, 2016. As president, Aquino III implemented a number of reforms aimed at improving the economy, fighting corruption, and strengthening the democratic institutions of the Philippines. He also worked to promote international relations and diplomacy, and he was widely respected and admired by the international community. Aquino III was the first Philippine president to be born after the country's independence from the United States. He was also the first to be born in a non-royal family, the first to be born a Catholic, and the first to be born in the province of Tarlac. Aquino III was married to Tarlac City Mayor Maria Leonor "Leni" Robredo. They had two children, Maria Aurora "Misa" and Benigno "Nino". Aquino III died on June 24, 2021, at the age of 65 from complications related to diabetes.

Jackie Akello (born 10 August 1998) is a Ugandan rapper, singer, songwriter, and recording artist from Kampala, Uganda. She is a female rapper who has gained popularity in the music industry for her rap vocals, and has been referred to as the "Best Female Rapper in Uganda" by several media outlets. Akello was born and raised in the city of Kampala, Uganda's capital and largest city. She attended Kitante Primary School, where she obtained her Primary Leaving Certificate, and later attended Kawempe Muslim Secondary School, where she obtained her Uganda Certificate of Education (UCE). She then attended Makerere University Business School (MUBS), where she obtained a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration. Akello began her music career in 2015, when she recorded and released her first single, "Dip and Go", a song that featured vocals from Ugandan singer and rapper Fik Fameica. The song was released as Akello's debut single on 20 September 2015, and was accompanied by a music video that was released on 4 October 2015. In 2016, Akello released her second single, "Bgenda", a song that featured vocals from Ugandan singer and rapper Big Size Bebe Cool. The song was released as Akello's second single on 8 January 2016, and was accompanied by a music video that was released on 30 January 2016. In 2017, Akello released her third single, "Kabalagala", a song that featured vocals from Ugandan singer and rapper Goodlyfe Crew. The song was released as Akello's third single on 10 February 2017, and was accompanied by a music video that was released on 23 February 2017. In 2018, Akello released her fourth single, "Fufu", a song that featured vocals from Ugandan singer and rapper Konshens. The song was released as Akello's fourth single on 11 April 2018, and was accompanied by a music video that was released on 5 June 2018. In 2019, Akello released her fifth single, "Sisonkobe", a song that featured vocals from Ugandan singer and rapper Ykee Benda. The song was released as Akello's fifth single on 4 April 2019, and was accompanied by a music video that was released on 30 April 2019. In 2020, Akello released her sixth single, "Nkulowooza", a song that featured vocals from Ugandan singer and rapper Peter Miles. The song was released as Akello's sixth single on 1 May 2020, and was accompanied by a music video that was released on 8 May 2020. In 2021, Akello released her seventh single, "Bazokizo", a song that featured vocals from Ugandan singer and rapper John Blaq. The song was released as Akello's seventh single on 28 April 2021, and was accompanied by a music video that was released on 30 April 2021.

Joseph Gluckstein Links are a series of public art works in Manchester, England, by the artist Joe Rush. The works, commissioned by the City of Manchester, consist of a series of 100 bronze "links" scattered throughout the city, each one representing a different aspect of the city's history and culture. The links are cast from bronze, using the lost wax process, and mounted on stainless steel posts. They are intended to be stumbled upon accidentally, rather than viewed as a formal collection. The links are located in areas of the city which are not traditionally associated with public art, and are intended to be seen by people who would not normally visit a museum or art gallery. The links have been well received by the public, and have become a favourite topic of conversation in the city. In 2006, the Manchester City Council website received more than 1.5 million hits, as people attempted to find all 100 links. A book, entitled The Joseph Gluckstein Links Walk, has also been published, to help people find the links and learn more about the city. A series of 30 new links were added to the collection in 2007, to celebrate the 30th anniversary of the original link. These new links, which were designed by local school children, feature a variety of designs, including a guitar, a basketball, and a pair of glasses. In 2009, a further 30 links were added to the collection, bringing the total number of links to 100. These new links, which were designed by local artists, feature a variety of designs, including a pigeon, a bee, and a pair of lips.

A Bell for Adano is a 1944 novel by the American writer John Hersey, who won the Pulitzer Prize for the work in 1945. It tells the story of an Italian-American soldier, Captain Henry W. Moore, who is sent to the small town of Adano in Italy to help organize the civilian population in the face of an anticipated Allied invasion. The title comes from the traditional Italian custom of ringing church bells to announce the presence of an invading force. The book is based on the author's experiences as a war correspondent for The New Yorker in the Italian campaign, although the characters and situations are entirely fictional. Hersey spent three months in the winter of 1944 in the Italian town of Piano di Sorrento, where he interviewed and observed American troops involved with the occupies. He then spent six weeks in the spring of that year in Adano, where he did additional research and interviews for the book. The book is a portrayal of the Italian people under American occupation, and their reaction to the liberators who are also invaders. It is also a story of the American soldiers who try to do their jobs under difficult circumstances, and an insightful look at the military and political leadership of the Allied forces in the Italian campaign.

Lightweighting is the process of reducing the weight of a structural component through a combination of material removal and material replacement. It is closely related to the concept of "lightweight structures", which are structures that have a lower weight than would be achieved through the use of conventional materials and section shapes. Lightweighting is often achieved by replacing some or all of the conventional materials (e.g., steel, aluminum, titanium, magnesium, and ceramics) with lightweight materials (e.g., fiber reinforced polymers, polymer matrix composites, metals, and ceramics). Lightweighting can also be achieved by removing material from sections of the structure through the use of holes, cut-outs, and notches. Lightweighting is an important consideration in many industries, such as aerospace, automotive, and consumer products. In the aerospace industry, lightweighting is used to improve the fuel efficiency of aircraft and spacecraft. Lightweighting is also used to improve the performance and range of missiles and spacecraft. In the automotive industry, lightweighting is used to improve the fuel efficiency and handling of automobiles and motorcycles. In the consumer products industry, lightweighting is used to reduce the weight and improve the portability of electronic devices, such as laptops, mobile phones, and personal digital assistants. There are several methods for achieving lightweighting. One method is to use lightweight materials to replace heavier materials. For example, fiber reinforced polymers can be used to replace steel and aluminum. Another method is to use a lightweight material to replace a heavier material in a specific area of the structure. For example, a carbon fiber-reinforced polymer can be used to replace steel in the cockpit of an aircraft. A third method is to remove material from sections of the structure to reduce its weight. For example, holes can be drilled in a steel beam to reduce its weight.

Bishop of Tuam, Killala and Achonry The Bishop of Tuam, Killala and Achonry is the ordinary of the Church of Ireland diocese of Tuam, Killala and Achonry in the Province of Tuam. The current bishop is the Right Reverend Dr. Richard Henderson, who was elected by the Church's House of Bishops on 12 November 2018 and was consecrated at St. Mary's Cathedral, Tuam, on 6 January 2019. The diocese covers much of counties Galway and Mayo, and a small part of county Sligo. It is one of the oldest of the Church of Ireland's 26 Irish dioceses, being one of the original twenty-four established by the Church's first primate, Archbishop John Parker, in 1602. Following the Reformation in England, the Church of Ireland was established by the Crown in 1534, when Henry VIII detached the deanery of Kilmacduagh from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Galway. The deanery was raised to the status of a diocese by royal letters patent in 1569. The Diocese of Tuam was united with the Diocese of Killala by an Act of the Irish Parliament in 1625, and with the Diocese of Achonry by an Act in 1753. The cathedral church of the diocese is Christ Church Cathedral, Tuam, where the cathedral clergy include the dean, the bishop, and the incumbent. The Bishop of Tuam, Killala and Achonry is also the visitor to a number of other churches and colleges in the diocese, including St. Mary's Cathedral, Westport (where the incumbent is the Very Reverend Robert "Rob" Williams), St. Mary's Cathedral, Swinford (where the incumbent is the Reverend Neil Carter), St. John the Baptist Cathedral, Ballina (where the incumbent is the Reverend Mark Williams), St. Mary's Church, Sligo (where the incumbent is the Reverend David Soul), and the College of the Resurrection, Costello.

Ali Sardar Jafri (Urdu: علی سردار جافری) (14 October 1898 – 11 December 1982) was a Pakistani poet, writer, philosopher, and a former civil servant who is known for his work on the philosophy of the East and the West. He served as a civil servant until his retirement in 1958, after which he devoted his life to the promotion of philosophy and literature. He was awarded the Presidential Award for Pride of Performance, one of the highest civilian honors, by the President of Pakistan. Jafri was born in 1898 in Lahore, Punjab, British India, to a scholarly family. His father, sardar Muhammad Zaman, was a civil servant and his mother, Dinu, was a housewife. He was initially schooled at home by his parents and later attended the Government College in Lahore, from where he graduated with a bachelor's degree in philosophy in 1921. He was married to his first cousin, Sardar Jahan, and had two sons and three daughters with her. After his graduation, Jafri joined the government service and served in various departments until his retirement in 1958. He was a civil servant for over 37 years and worked in several cities across India and Pakistan, including Lahore, Delhi, Karachi, and Multan. During his service, he was involved in the promotion of philosophy and literature, and was a member of several literary organizations and journals. After his retirement, he devoted his life to the promotion of philosophy and literature and wrote several books and articles on these subjects.

Events of 2002 in Malaysia. February 1–3 February – Malaysia reached the quarter-finals of the 2002 Thomas Cup after beating China 3–0 in the second round. 4 February – The new RM5 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. 13 February – A state of emergency was declared in Perak after a controversial state assembly sitting which resulted in the suspension of the state's constitution and the swearing-in of Mentri Besar Tajol Rosli. 15 February – A state of emergency was declared in Pahang after a controversial state assembly sitting which resulted in the suspension of the state's constitution and the swearing-in of Mentri Besar Mahadzir Khalid. May 3–5 May – The first ever Langkawi International Marathon was held on the island of Langkawi, Kedah. June 1 June – The Book of Negara was launched. 4 June – The first ever Monsoon Cup was held in Malaysia. July 1 July – The first phase of the Kuala Lumpur Monorail was opened to the public. 12 July – The first phase of the Stormwater Management and Road Tunnel (SMART Tunnel) was opened to the public. 20–21 July – The first ever Putrajaya International Hot Air Balloon Fiesta was held at the Putrajaya Wetland Park. 21 July – The new RM20 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. August 1 August – The second phase of the Kuala Lumpur Monorail was opened to the public. 5 August – The second phase of the Stormwater Management and Road Tunnel (SMART Tunnel) was opened to the public. 15 August – The new RM1 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. September 1 September – The new RM2 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. 5 September – The new RM5 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. October 1 October – The new RM10 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. 3 October – The new RM20 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. November 1 November – The new RM50 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. 3 November – The new RM100 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. 5 November – The new RM500 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. 6 November – The new RM1,000 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. 7 November – The new RM5,000 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. 8 November – The new RM10,000 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. December 1 December – The new RM100,000 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia. 3 December – The new RM1,000,000 banknote was launched by Bank Negara Malaysia.

2002 Toronto Blue Jays season The 2002 Toronto Blue Jays season was the franchise's 32nd season of Major League Baseball. The Blue Jays finished with a record of 80 wins and 82 losses, good for second place in the American League East, 13 games behind the World Champion New York Yankees. The Blue Jays spent most of the season in a heated race with the Boston Red Sox and New York Yankees for the division title; the three teams were never more than three games apart throughout the season. On September 28, the Blue Jays suffered a crushing loss to the visiting Yankees when second baseman Howie Clark committed three errors in the seventh inning, allowing the Yankees to score seven runs and put the game out of reach. The Blue Jays lost the game 13–5 and dropped three games out of first. The Blue Jays went on to win three of their final four games, while the Yankees won six in a row to capture the division by three games. The Blue Jays qualified for the playoffs for the fourth year in a row, and were once again matched up against the Texas Rangers in the ALDS. The Blue Jays swept the Rangers in three games, advancing to the ALCS for the third time in four years. In the ALCS, the Blue Jays lost to the Yankees in four straight games. Offensively, the Blue Jays were led by left fielder Vernon Wells, who won the AL MVP Award, and right fielder Jose Cruz Jr., who led the league in hits (210) and finished second in batting average (.332). Wells became the first Blue Jay to win an MVP Award. On the pitching side, the Blue Jays had three starters with at least 20 wins for the first time since 1990. Right-hander Roy Halladay had a 20–7 record with a 3.27 ERA, left-hander David Wells won 22 games with a 4.46 ERA, and right-hander Pat Hentgen went 20–10 with a 4.46 ERA. In addition, the Blue Jays had four relievers with at least 20 saves. Tom Gordon led the way with 47 saves, and was named the AL Rolaids Relief Pitcher of the Year. This was the first season the Blue Jays played in their new home, Rogers Centre, which was previously known as SkyDome. The team had played in SkyDome since 1989. Also, this was the first season the Blue Jays were managed by John Gibbons. Gibbons took over for Buck Martinez, who managed the team in 2001.

Nancheng Subdistrict, Dongguan Nancheng Subdistrict is a subdistrict of Dongguan, Guangdong, China. It is the seat of Dongguan City. Nancheng Subdistrict covers 72.5 square kilometers, and had a registered population of 46,948 and a resident population of 49,150 as of the 2010 Census. It is divided into Nancheng Community and Daxin Community, with two residential quarters and 17 villages. The subdistrict was incorporated as a town in 1952, and was upgraded to a subdistrict in 2006. "Lo fiolairé" is a song by the French singer-songwriter Renaud. It was released in 1985 as the second single from his fourth studio album, Mistral gauche, on which it appears as the second track. The song is dedicated to the Occitan poet Jean de Vayrèges. "Lo fiolairé" is a sophisticated love song, in which the singer boasts of his lover's beauty. The title is a pun: the word fiolairé is a Occitan term meaning "to make (someone) happy" and the expression "filer à l'aïr" means "to show off". The song was a hit in France, where it reached number two on the chart, and in the Netherlands, where it reached number 13. There are two versions of the music video. The first one, directed by Daniel Kleinman, features the singer in a restaurant, surrounded by beautiful women. The second version, directed by Richard Donner, shows Renaud performing the song in a bar while images of women are shown in the background. In 2002, the singer recorded a Spanish version of the song, titled "Afila el aire". The lyrics were written by the Cuban-born Spanish singer-songwriter Javier Gazpio, who had previously written two songs for Renaud's Mistral gauche album: "C'est pas d'l'amour" and "J'ai faim de l'amour". The music video was directed byRamón 1080.

Andy Karl (born September 27, 1973) is an American actor and singer. He is known for his performance as Rocky Balboa in the original Broadway cast of Rocky the Musical. Karl was born in the United States in 1973. He was raised in Warwick, Rhode Island. He attended the University of Rhode Island, where he studied communication studies. Karl began his acting career in regional theatre. He made his Broadway debut in 2000 in the musical Mamma Mia!, as one of the three potential fathers. In 2002, he was in the original Broadway cast of the musical Hairspray, as the male lead, Link. In 2006, he was in the original Broadway cast of the musical Jersey Boys, as Bob Gaudio. He was also in the off-Broadway cast of the musical Altar Boyz in 2004. In 2008, Karl was in the original Broadway cast of the musical Billy Elliot the Musical, as the title character's father, Jack. He played the role until the show closed in January 2010. In 2011, he was in the original Broadway cast of the musical The Wedding Singer, as Sam. In 2013, Karl was in the original Broadway cast of the musical Rocky the Musical, as Rocky Balboa. He played the role until the show closed in early 2016. Karl is a singer, and has performed on Broadway and in regional theatre. In 2008, he released a CD, Andy Karl Live at the Algonquin, consisting of standards and show tunes.

Ryan Amador (born June 13, 1992) is an American soccer player who currently plays for San Diego Loyal in the USL Championship. Amador spent his early career in the North American Soccer League, playing for the Tampa Bay Rowdies and the San Francisco Deltas. Amador made his professional debut for the Tampa Bay Rowdies on April 18, 2015, in a 0–0 draw against the Fort Lauderdale Strikers. Amador scored his first professional goal on September 13, 2015, in a 2–1 victory against the Edmonton Eskimos. Amador was released by the Tampa Bay Rowdies on November 16, 2015. Amador signed with the San Francisco Deltas on December 14, 2015. Amador made his debut for the Deltas on April 1, 2016, in a 2–1 defeat against the Sacramento Republic. Amador scored his first goal for the Deltas on May 7, 2016, in a 2–0 victory against the Vancouver Whitecaps FC 2. Amador made his playoff debut for the Deltas on October 23, 2016, in a 3–2 victory against the Tulsa Roughnecks. Amador was released by the San Francisco Deltas on November 7, 2016. Amador signed with the San Diego Loyal on December 6, 2017.

Chen Beibei (simplified Chinese: 谌贝贝; traditional Chinese: 谌貝貝; pinyin: Chén Bèibèi; born 20 October 1997) is a Chinese singer and actress. She is best known for her first leading role in the 2018 television series Meteor Garden, as well as her role in the 2019 television series The Golden Deer. Chen Beibei was born on October 20, 1997, in Handan, Hebei. She is the second child of a family of three children. Her father is a massage therapist and her mother is a kindergarten teacher. She was enrolled in the Art Department of the Northwest University for Nationalities in Lanzhou, Gansu, and graduated in 2019. In 2016, Chen Beibei participated in the Youku variety show Super Idol. In September 2017, she participated in the Youku reality show Super Idol Show and reached the top 100. In January 2018, she was selected as the "Meteor Garden" (2018) female protagonist "Xiaoxi" after a round of selection, and officially entered the entertainment industry. In June 2018, she attended the Forbes China Under 30 Conference. In October 2018, she attended the 12th Golden Phoenix Awards. In December 2018, she was awarded the "Most Anticipated Actress" at the 2018 Golden Eagles Awards. In January 2019, she attended the CCTV Spring Festival Gala. In February 2019, she attended the 33rd Annual Grammy Awards in the United States. In March 2019, she attended the Hong Kong Television Drama Awards. In April 2019, she attended the 19th National Congress of the Communist Party of China. In May 2019, she attended the 12th Beijing College Student Film Festival. In June 2019, she attended the Dragon Boat Festival. In July 2019, she attended the Baidu Create Summer Conference. In August 2019, she attended the Weibo Movie Night. In September 2019, she attended the CCTV Mid-Autumn Festival Gala. In October 2019, she attended the National Day celebration. In October 2019, she attended the 15th Golden Phoenix Awards. In November 2019, she attended the China Fashion Week 2020.

The Tremembé people, also known as the Tremembé-Katukina, are an indigenous people of Brazil, living in the state of Amazonas. They are famous for their long-distance trade, and for having had the first contact with the Portuguese in Brazil. The Tremembé are one of the four branches of the Katukina people, the other three being the Ingarikum, the Iwam, and the Katukina proper. The Tremembé and the Katukina proper are the largest groups. The three branches all speak variants of the Katukina language, which is a language isolate. The Tremembé traditionally lived by farming manioc, which they grew on cleared fields. They used slash-and-burn agriculture, and the manioc was the staple of their diet. The Tremembé also hunted and gathered wild fruits and honey. The Tremembé traditionally practiced long-distance trade, and had a reputation as the best canoeists and navigators in the Amazon. They traded with other indigenous groups up and down the Amazon River, as well as with Europeans. The Tremembé were the first indigenous group in Brazil to have contact with the Portuguese, in 1639. In the early 21st century, the Tremembé population was estimated to be 2,500 to 3,000. As of 2002, when the most recent census of the Tremembé was conducted, 1,262 individuals were counted in 67 villages.

Chihung Yang (born July 17, 1954) is a Taiwanese-American physicist, and the co-developer of the theory of everything called Contains-Consciousness (C-C) theory. Yang was born in Taizhong, Taiwan. In 1978, he received his B.S. degree in physics from Tunghai University, Taiwan. In 1981, he came to the United States to pursue graduate studies. He received his M.S. degree in physics from the University of Missouri in 1983 and his Ph.D. degree in physics from the University of California, Los Angeles in 1987. After spending a year as a post-doctoral fellow at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, Yang joined the faculty of the University of Washington in September 1988, where he is currently an associate professor of physics. In 2006, he was elected a fellow of the American Physical Society for his contributions to the theory of the strong interactions. In the early years of his career, Yang worked on the theory of the strong interactions, and made significant contributions to the theory of the strong coupling constant and the theory of mesons. In the late 1990s, he began to work on the theory of everything, and proposed the Contains-Consciousness theory in the year 2000.

Women in Ghana Ghanaian women have always played significant roles in the country's social, economic, and political development. In recent years, women have increasingly entered into the formal economy, in both urban and rural areas. However, like many other African countries, Ghana still has a long way to go to ensure that women's rights are fully realized. Ghanaian women have traditionally been seen as the backbone of the country's society and economy. In many rural areas, women are responsible for a large portion of the household income, as they are often the primary breadwinners. This is due in part to the fact that many men in rural areas migrate to cities or other countries in search of work, leaving the women behind to care for the family. In recent years, women have been making gains in the formal economy. The number of women-owned businesses has been increasing, and women are also becoming more involved in politics and government. In 2013, Ghana elected its first female president, Joyce Banda, who served a single term. Despite these gains, women in Ghana still face many challenges. One of the biggest issues is the continued inequality between men and women, both socially and economically. Many women still lack basic rights and opportunities, such as access to education, healthcare, and political representation. There are also ongoing concerns about the exploitation of women and girls in Ghana. Many women and girls are subjected to sexual violence, domestic violence, and other forms of abuse. The government has been working to address these issues, but much more needs to be done to ensure that women and girls in Ghana are able to live free from fear and violence. In conclusion, Ghanaian women have played and continue to play important roles in the country's development. However, there is still much work to be done to ensure that women's rights are fully realized and that women and girls are able to live free from violence and discrimination.

.coop .coop is the sponsored top-level domain (sTLD) in the Domain Name System (DNS) for the cooperative community. The TLD was originally administered by dotCoop, a cooperative association formed specifically for that purpose; it is now administered by Poptel, a subsidiary of the Swedish cooperative Skånet. The domain is open to registration by qualifying cooperatives and cooperative associations. The .coop registry also sponsors the .coop TLD, and manages the DNS root servers for the domain. As of June 2014, .coop was used by more than 1,500 websites. When the .coop TLD was first proposed, there was substantial resistance to the idea of a top-level domain devoted to the cooperative sector. Many in the cooperative community believed that .coop would be a artificial construct that would not be widely used, and therefore would not be justified as a TLD. However, since the .coop TLD was launched, the sector has seen many new .coop websites, including the websites for many well-known cooperatives. The .coop TLD is now a well-established and widely-recognised part of the DNS. In addition, .coop has gained widespread support from the cooperative sector, and is now the only TLD specifically for cooperatives.

Clinton is a 2021 American biographical drama film directed by Rod Holcombe and written by Holcombe and Matthew Michael Carnahan. The film is based on the life of former U.S. Secretary of State and Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, and stars Portia Doubleday as Clinton. In September 2018, it was announced that Sony Pictures and journalist Peter Baker would produce a film about Clinton, with Baker's book The Breach: Inside the Impeachment and Overthrow of President Clinton serving as the basis for the film. In April 2019, Rod Holcombe was announced as the director. In May 2019, it was announced that actress Portia Doubleday had been cast to play the role of Clinton. In September 2019, it was reported that the film had been put on hold due to production issues. In May 2020, the film's production was resumed, with the film's release date being pushed back to 2021. In May 2021, Sony released the first trailer for the film. The film was released in theaters and on-demand in the United States on August 16, 2021. Clinton received negative reviews from critics, who praised the performances of the cast but criticized the screenplay and the film's production.

"The Sound of Missing You" is the ninth track on the A Thousand Suns album by American rock band Linkin Park. The song was written by Mike Shinoda, Brad Delson, Dave Farrell, Joseph Hahn and Phoenix. The song was produced by Linkin Park and Rick Rubin. The song is the third single from the album, and was released as a promotional single on September 15, 2010, in the United States. The song is built around a piano riff, which is present throughout the song. The song also features Shinoda's rapped vocals, in addition to his normal singing vocals. The title of the song refers to the pain of being away from a loved one, in which the "sound" is the ache from missing that person. The song was leaked onto the internet on August 31, 2010. The song was officially released via streaming on September 15, 2010, via Linkin Park's official website, and was released as a promo single the same day. The song has been performed live by the band at the Mark Hoppus Birthday Bash, and also at the A Thousand Suns listening party, held in Los Angeles, California on October 16, 2010, in which Shinoda performed the rap vocals live for the first time since the song's recording. The song has been well received by critics. James Montgomery from MTV said, "The song is a mushy merger of the band's hard-hitting rock and Shinoda's rapid-fire rap, all set to a sweeping melody that's as catchy as it is bittersweet. In other words, it's classic Linkin Park, only with a fresh coat of paint." The song was used by NBC in promotion for the fifth season of their series Chuck, and is included on the soundtrack for the video game WWE SmackDown vs. Raw 2011. A music video has been made for the song, and was released on October 13, 2010. The video features a couple, whose relationship is deteriorating due to their constant fighting. The video also features Linkin Park in a snowy landscape, performing the song.

Puelche language The Puelche language (Chumash: Piwü'élche; piwü'élche) is one of the Chumash languages, which are spoken by the Puelche people in the Los padres national park of the Los padres mountains of Northern Patagonia in Argentina and in the nearby regions of Chile. Puelche is a language in the Chumash branch of the Hokan language family. The Puelche language is spoken by less than 50 people in Argentina, and the language is in critical danger of extinction. In Argentina the language is taught in some schools as a second language. In the 1960s, a Puelche-speaking couple, Santos and Juana Puelches, were hired to teach Puelche at a school in the town of El Bolsón. The couple taught the language to a number of young people, but most of them did not pass it on to their children or grandchildren. In Chile, the Puelche language is spoken by fewer people and is in a more critical state. The last speakers of Puelche in Chile live in the southern part of the Arauco province in the villages of Toltén and Curral bush, where the language is spoken only by older people. The language has been influenced by the dominant Mapuche language and the Spanish language. There are no written documents of the language and the language is not being taught in any school. The Puelche language has several similar characteristics to the Chumash languages in California. The Puelche language has a number of words which are the same or have the same meaning as the Chumash words. For example, the word for " elder brother" is kusi in Puelche and kusi in Chumash, the word for " younger brother" is kwa in Puelche and kwa in Chumash, and the word for "house" is pú in Puelche and pú in Chumash.

Town and Country, Missouri, is an inner-ring suburb of St. Louis, located in western St. Lagos County, Missouri, United States. The population was 51,499 in 2020, making it the 20th most populous city in the state and the third largest in the St. Louis area. The city is located in the gentle hills and valleys of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, which stretches from Canada to the Mississippi River. The city's name comes from its early history as a town with a country feel. Town and Country was settled by European immigrants in the early 19th century. One of the earliest families was the Witzel family, who came from Germany in the 1840s and founded the town's first general store. The town also had a post office and a doctor's office. The first church was built in the late 19th century. The town was incorporated in 1945. In the early 20th century, St. Louisans began moving to the area in search of a country atmosphere. Large lots and open spaces were a part of the attraction. The city's population grew to 4,371 in 1940. As the St. Louis area grew, so did the city of Town and Country. The city's population more than doubled from 1940 to 1990, growing to 10,814. The city has several historic landmarks. The Town and Country Historical Society was founded in 1975. The society maintains a museum in the city's old town hall, located at Town and Country Lanes bowling alley. The museum features historical artifacts and documents, including the original town charter. The city also has a historic church, built in 1867, and a one-room schoolhouse, built in 1912. The city has two public school districts. The public school district is the Parkway School District. It serves most of the city. The Parkway School District has eight elementary schools, two middle schools, and two high schools. The other school district is the Ladue School District. It serves the city's westernmost area. The Ladue School District has four elementary schools, one middle school, and one high school. The city is home to St. Louis County Library's Town & Country Branch, which opened in 1975 and is located at the intersection of Woods Mill Road and Town & Country Boulevard.

Benny Lennartsson (born 5 June 1958) is a Swedish football manager and a former player. Lennartsson was born in Stockholm, Sweden. He was a member of the Swedish national team in the 1980 Summer Olympics, where he played three matches. As a manager, he has won the Swedish Championship seven times, the Danish Championship three times, and the Finnish Championship once. He has also won the Swedish Cup five times, the Danish Cup once, and the Finnish Cup once. In 1998, he was the manager of Sweden's national team, and he led them to qualification for the Euro 2000 tournament. However, he was replaced by Lars-Olof Mattsson after Sweden lost to Iceland in the qualifying playoffs. Lennartsson managed the Swedish club Halmstads BK from 1996 to 1998, and he led them to the Allsvenskan title in 1997. He also managed the Danish club Brøndby IF from 1999 to 2001, and he led them to the Danish Superliga title in 2000–01. In 2002, he was the manager of the Finnish club Haka, and he led them to the Veikkausliiga title.

David Epel (born June 12, 1942) is an American scientist, author, and businessman. He is the co-founder and former CEO of the molecular biology start-up company Epigenetics, Inc., a company that he co-founded with his wife, Diana Wszalek. Epel is a Professor of Chemical Engineering at the Stanford School of Medicine and a Professor (Research) at the Stanford Graduate School of Business. He is also the author of The Invisible Dragon: Essays on Technology and the Economy (2012), a collection of essays that discuss the history of technology and the economy, and the role of the entrepreneur. Epel received a B.S. in chemistry from the University of Michigan in 1963, and an M.S. in physical chemistry from the University of California, Berkeley in 1965. He received his Ph.D. in chemical physics from the University of California, Berkeley in 1970. Epel began his career as an engineer and scientist at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, where he worked on the design and development of nuclear weapons. He later joined the research staff at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, where he worked on the design and development of particle detectors for high energy physics experiments. In the late 1970s, Epel became interested in the field of epigenetics, which focuses on the study of how genes and the environment interact to cause changes in organisms. He became a pioneer in the field, and has published numerous research papers on the topic. In addition to his work in science and technology, Epel is also a passionate advocate for the environment and for the importance of sustainability. He is the author of two books on the topic, The Green Machine (1994) and The Blue Machine (1996), and is a co-founder of the environmental organization Friends of the Earth. Epel has been a featured speaker at numerous conferences and events, and has been a guest on many television and radio programs. He is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, and is a member of the National Academy of Sciences.

The 2020 Campeonato Catarinense ( officially the Campeonato Catarinense de Futebol Profissional de 2020 ) is the 96th season of Catarinense, the top-flight football league in the Brazilian state of Santa Catarina. The competition is organized by the FGF do Brasil (Federalográfico de Futebol do Brasil). The competition is divided into two stages. In the first stage, each team plays the other teams in a single round-robin tournament. The top eight teams in the first stage advances to the final stage. The final stage is played on a home-and-away basis, in which the top four teams in the final stage qualify for the 2021 Copa do Brasil and the top two teams in the final stage qualify for the 2020 Série A. Lamar was the defending champion, having won the title in the previous three seasons. However, they were unable to qualify for the Série A in 2020, after losing the finals to Avaí. Brusque and Marcílio were promoted from the 2019 Série C. Brusque returned to the top division after an eleven-year absence, while Marcílio will make their debut in the top division. This will be the first Catarinense to feature a team from the state of Rio Grande do Sul, after Sport's relocation to Criciúma. The 2020 Catarinense will feature three clubs from the state of Santa Catarina, three clubs from the state of Paraná, two clubs from the state of São Paulo, one club from the state of Rio Grande do Sul and one club from the state of Minas Gerais. The match schedule was released on 20 January 2020. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic in Brazil, on 25 March 2020 the FGF announced the temporary suspension of the tournament, after the third round of the first stage, for a period of thirty days. On 14 April 2020, the suspension was extended to 17 May 2020. On 11 May 2020, the FGF announced the tournament would return on 22 May 2020, after the suspension was extended to 30 April 2020. On 24 May 2020, the tournament was abandoned, after the Governor of Santa Catarina, Carlos Moisés Lima, signed an ordinance banning any public events in the state until 30 June 2020. Miracle in the Desert: The Rise and Fall of the Salton Sea The Salton Sea is a vast salt lake in the center of the California Desert, south of the Coachella Valley and the city of Palm Springs. The Sea was created by the engineering of the Colorado River, which was re-directed by the engineers of the California Development Company into the Salton Basin in 1905. By 1907 the basin's irrigation channels were delivering water to the farms of the Imperial Valley; and the Salton Sea was born. In the early years, the Sea was a recreational destination for the wealthy; and a port for the shipping of products from the farms of the Imperial Valley. In the 1920s the Sea's waters became the focus of a resort community, with yacht clubs, resorts, and marinas lining its shores. In the 1930s the wealthy investors sold their holdings to the California State Board of Education, which developed the Sea as a resort area and a fishing lake. The increasing salinity of the lake forced the State of California to build a series of evaporation ponds to control the salinity. As the water evaporated in the ponds, the salt was left behind. The resulting salt became a major revenue source for the State of California. In the 1940s the military took over the Salton Sea, surrounding it with a restricted military zone. The military used the area for testing weapons, and the resulting explosions and constant noise terrified the local population. In the 1950s, the military began to clean up the Salton Sea, and by the 1970s they had largely removed the salt from the lake. As the military cleaned up the lake, the local population began to use it as a recreational destination once again. The city of Palm Springs, seeing the tourist potential of the area, began to promote the Salton Sea as a recreational destination. By the 1980s the Salton Sea was a major tourist destination, with resorts, marinas, and yacht clubs lining its shores. Regular complex polygon A regular complex polygon is a polygon in the complex plane with all sides equal and all angles equal. If the polygon has an even number of sides, it is called regular and equilateral. If it has an odd number of sides, it is called regular but not equilateral. For a polygon to be regular, the following conditions must apply. 1. All sides must be equal. 2. All angles must be equal. 3. The polygon must be closed. The equilateral regular polygon is the special case of a regular polygon with all sides equal and all angles equal to 60 degrees. The regular complex polygon is the complex polygon with all sides equal and all angles equal. It is a polygon with vertices on the complex plane and with sides that are complex numbers. The regular complex polygon is a generalization of the regular polygon to the complex plane. It is used in many areas of geometry, including the theory of algebraic curves, the theory of surfaces, and the theory of partial differential equations. In particular, it is used to define the boundary of a domain in the complex plane. The regular complex polygon can be thought of as the boundary of a disk with spikes at the vertices. The spikes are the lines that connect the center of the disk to the vertices. The interior of the polygon is the open region inside the border of the polygon, and the exterior is the outside region. The regular complex polygon is a special case of a generalization of the regular polygon to higher dimensions. In three dimensions, this generalization is called a regular polyhedron, and in n dimensions, it is called a regular n-polytope.

A solar-powered fountain is a water fountain that is powered by solar panels. Solar-powered fountains are popular for their ability to run without electricity. They are often cheaper to operate than electric fountains, because they do not use electricity. However, solar-powered fountains are generally less powerful than electric fountains. They are also more vulnerable to damage from freezing weather. There are two main types of solar-powered fountains: standalone and integrated. Standalone solar-powered fountains are separate from the rest of the fountain, and they are placed in the fountain to provide extra power. Integrated solar-powered fountains are built into the fountain, and they provide all of the power for the fountain. There are many different types of solar-powered fountains. Some of the most popular types include: - Solar-powered water pumps, which use solar panels to power a water pump. - Solar-powered waterfalls, which use solar panels to power a waterfall. - Solar-powered ponds, which use solar panels to power a pond. - Solar-powered fountains, which use solar panels to power a fountain. There are many benefits to using solar-powered fountains. One of the main benefits is that they are environmentally friendly. They do not use electricity, so they do not produce any emissions. Another benefit is that they are cheaper to operate than electric fountains. Since they do not use electricity, they are much cheaper to run. There are also some drawbacks to using solar-powered fountains. One of the main drawbacks is that they are less powerful than electric fountains. They are also more vulnerable to damage from freezing weather.

Robin Hood, West Yorkshire The Robin Hood of English folklore is said to have lived in Sherwood Forest, near the town of Nottingham, in Nottinghamshire. According to legend, Robin Hood was a highly skilled archer and swordsman, and served as an outlaw champion of the poor and the weak. The legend of Robin Hood has been adapted numerous times in literature, film and television. There are competing claims to his traditional birthplace. Yorkshire, particularly the district of South Kirkby, has one of the strongest claims. As early as the 14th century, a group of yeomen were organised as the Company of Robin Hood, and in the 15th century, a Robert Hood is recorded as being born in South Kirkby. A 19th-century ballad, "The Yorkshire Robin Hood", explicitly identified Robin Hood with this village. A band of outlaws, said to have been based in the forest of Barnsdale, South Yorkshire, is also claimed to have been led by Robin Hood. In the 17th century, the antiquary John Stow claimed that Robin Hood had lived in the village of Locksley, now known as Lidsey, in Yorkshire. In the 19th century, a local landowner built a castle on the site, which he named "Ravenscrag", after the reputed home of Robin Hood. In the early 20th century, a New Zealander named Frederick Day claimed to have discovered the grave of Robin Hood in the grounds of a church in South Kirkby. Day returned to New Zealand, however, and the grave's location was not revealed until the 1950s. A blue plaque on the church wall, unveiled in the 1990s, now marks the site.

No Kissing Under Water is a 2005 album by B. J Thomas. The album was his first studio album in twenty years, and his first for the independent label New Door Records, a division of Universal Music Group, after his previous label, Sony's Columbia Records, dropped him. The album was produced by Kyle Lehning, who produced many of Thomas' biggest hits, including the number one singles "Breathe" and "As Long as We're Together". "No Kissing Under Water" was the first studio album of new material by B. J. Thomas in 20 years. The title track was written by John Rich, the frontman for the country duo Big & Rich, who also produced the track. The album was recorded by Billy Lord at Sound Kitchen Studios in Nashville, Tennessee. The album was released on June 28, 2005, in the United States, and on July 4, 2005, in the United Kingdom. The album was not released in Australia. The first single from the album was "The Chokin' Song", which was written by Thomas, George Strait, and Dean Dillon. The single was released in early 2005, and was a minor hit, reaching No. 48 in the United States. The second single, "No Kissing Under Water", was released in the summer of 2005, and was also a minor hit, reaching No. 42 in the United States. "No Kissing Under Water" was the final studio album by B. J. Thomas before his death in 2021.

Akiko Yano (矢野 晶子, Yano Akiko, born June 15, 1965) is a Japanese singer, composer, and musician. She has released several albums, and her music has been used in a number of Japanese anime series, most notably the soundtrack to the anime series The Big O, for which she performed the opening and ending themes. Yano's music career began in the late 1970s, when she was a member of the band RC5. In 1981, she released her first solo album, Akiko, on the For Life Records label. The album was produced by her future husband, BMF (Bakery Music Factory). Yano's second album, Resister, was released in 1983. Her third album, Welcome to the DanceHall, was released in 1985. Her fourth album, Bad Girl, was released in 1987. Her fifth album, Future Vision, was released in 1989. Her sixth album, Ectomorphed, was released in 1992. Her seventh album, Akiko Yano, was released in 1996. Her eighth album, I am Akiko, was released in 1998. Her ninth album, Holy Grafitti, was released in 2000. Her tenth album, Music from the Big O, was released in 2002. Her eleventh album, The World is Yours, was released in 2004. Her twelfth album, Keep On Rocking, was released in 2008. Yano has also released a number of singles, including "Reign of the Queens" (1982), "Shinin' Like a Fire" (1983), "Welcome to the Dance Hall" (1985), "Bad Girl" (1987), "Future Vision" (1989), "Ectomorphed" (1992), "Witch Hunt" (1996), "Lunatic City" (1998), "The World is Yours" (2004), and "Keep On Rocking" (2008).

Paul Schuitema (October 27, 1885 – January 13, 1946) was a Dutch graphic designer, photographer, painter, teacher, and author. Schuitema was born in The Hague. He studied drawing and painting at the Royal Academy of Art, The Hague, and continued his studies at the Academie Royale in Brussels, where he took lessons from the painter Jan Brouwer Bogaerts (1856–1933). In 1906, he married the writer and teacher Dientje Dijkstra (1870–1945). They had two sons, the photographer Carel Schuitema (1907–1983) and the graphic designer and photographer Paul Schuitema Jr. (1912–1994). In 1908, Schuitema opened a business in The Hague that specialized in the design and production of posters, advertisements, folders, and magazines, as well as the application of colors to glass, wood, and metal. His work in this field is noted for its ergonomic design, use of modern fonts, and innovative use of photography. Schuitema was a member of the Pulchri Studio in The Hague and of the artists' societies Arti et Amicitiae in Amsterdam and the Hollandse Cabaret in The Hague. In addition to his own work, he was an important collector of the work of others, including that of his students. Schuitema was a professor at the Royal Academy of Art, The Hague, and the author of several books on the history of art and the applied arts, including Vormgeving in de plastiek (Design in Plastic, 1939), a practical guide to the use of industrial materials such as glass, metal, and plastic in the applied arts. Schuitema's work in the field of graphic design and photography is characterized by a concern for functional design, the use of modern typefaces, and an innovative use of photography. His work is also noted for its use of color, which was influenced by the work of the De Stijl movement and the art of the Amsterdam School. Schuitema's paintings are characterized by their use of bright colors and simplified forms, and are often based on memories of his childhood in The Hague. In 2013, the Museum voor Communicatie in The Hague held an exhibition of Schuitema's work, and in 2015 the photographer BatBoomChikara released a collection of photos of Schuitema's work.

Lucien Grant Berry (March 31, 1889 – June 18, 1979) was an American lawyer, businessman, and politician from Memphis, Tennessee, who served in the United States House of Representatives from 1939 to 1967 as a member of the Democratic Party. He was also a member of the Ku Klux Klan. Berry was born on a farm near Memphis in 1889, the son of Thomas Jefferson and Martha Ann (Horn) Berry. He attended the public schools of Shelby County and the law school of the University of Memphis, receiving his law degree in 1911. He commenced practice in Memphis and became a businessman, owning a cottonseed oil mill and a sand and gravel business. In 1922, Berry was appointed assistant attorney general of Tennessee and served in that capacity for two years. He then returned to his private law practice. In 1939, he was elected to the United States House of Representatives, serving from 1939 to 1967. He was a member of the Democratic Party and served as the chairman of the Special Committee to Study and Survey Problems of Small Business Enterprises from 1941 to 1947. While serving in Congress, Berry was one of the few members to vote against the Civil Rights Act of 1964. In 1948, he was challenged in the Democratic primary by the African-American attorney and future judge Russell W. Dyer, who ran on a civil rights platform. Berry defeated Dyer by 5,730 to 3,458, winning 56 percent of the vote. In 1964, Berry was again challenged in the Democratic primary, this time by the African-American attorney and businessman George W. Lee, who also ran on a civil rights platform. Berry defeated Lee by 4,031 to 2,232, winning 56 percent of the vote. In the general election, Berry defeated the Republican candidate, William N. Dunn, by 60,32 to 39.68, winning by a margin of 20,84. In his later years, Berry was actively involved in the Democratic Party in Shelby County, serving as the chairman of the Shelby County Democratic Executive Committee from 1968 to 1972. He was also a member of the executive committee of the Tennessee Democratic Party from 1959 to 1972 and was the state party's chairman in 1968. Berry died at age 90 in 1979. He is buried in the Berry family plot in Elmwood Cemetery in Memphis.

Roth (German: Rotte) is an Ortsgemeinde – a municipality belonging to a Verbandsgemeinde, a kind of collective municipality – in the Bernkastel-Wittlich district in Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany. Roth is a state-recognized health resort (Erholungsort) and is hence also called Roth-Siedel. The municipality lies in the western Hunsrück, near the border with the Saarland. It belongs to the Verbandsgemeinde of Thalfang am Erbeskopf. ## History Roth lies in a dale between the low Erbeskopf (a mountain) and the high Hunsrück. This area was already settled in prehistoric times. In 1985, a stone ax was found in Roth, and in the nearby village of Niedersayn a stone hatchet. Both finds are from the Neolithic period. Roth's municipal area is rich in prehistoric and early historic finds. Some of them have been gathered together and are on display at the municipal museum. Roth's oldest parts are the so-called Römerberg (German for "Roman mountain") and the old village (alte Dorf). The Römerberg is a hill whose eastern slopes, toward the Dierbach valley, have been terraced. On the higher of these two terraces, some of the stone remnants of a Roman country estate (villa rustica) have been preserved. It is believed that the villa had two building phases, the first in the 1st century and the second in the 3rd century. In the lower, western part of the municipal area, towards the Binger Scharlachberg (a hill), have been found several graves from the New Stone Age, the Iron Age, and the Roman period. One of these graves, from the 1st century, yielded the first evidence of a Celtic settlement in the area. Roth had its first documentary mention in 1263. At that time, it was called Rutha. The local saying "as old as Roth" (German: alt wie Roth) refers to this. In the 14th century, Roth was pledged to the County of Sponheim. Later it was ruled by the Margraves of Baden and the Counts of Veldenz. After the Veldenz line died out, Roth, in 1556, passed to the Margraviate of Baden. The Margraves of Baden introduced the Reformation into their territories early on. The subjects of the Römerberg farmstead, however, remained Catholic. In the 17th century, the Römerberg was the seat of a noble family, the "Römer" (German for "Roman"). The last of this line, Anna Regina, died in 1757. She had outlived her two sons, and so the Römer part of the farmstead was inherited by the Protestant branch of the von Gymnich family. After the Thirty Years' War, the Römerberg, which had belonged to the Catholic branch of the family, was sold to the Protestant branch. Since 1707, Roth has been in the Kingdom of Prussia, later the German Empire, and since 1949 in the Federal Republic of Germany. In 1757, the Römerberg was acquired by the counts of Metternich. It remained in their ownership until the German Democratic Republic (East Germany) took over the so-called "Römerturm" ("Roman tower"), which was part of the Römerberg, in 1979. After German reunification, the tower was returned to the municipality of Roth, and it is now in private ownership. In the 19th century, the Römerberg was the home of the so-called Römerkind (German for "Roman child"), a girl who was allegedly raised by the "Römer" (the last owner of the Römerberg, who had no children of his own). In 1974, Roth became the seat of the Verbandsgemeinde of Thalfang am Erbeskopf, which was newly formed by the merger of the former municipalities of Thalfang, Kaperich, and Roth. ## Politics ### Municipal council The council is made up of 16 council members, who were elected by majority vote at the municipal election held on 7 June 2009, and the honorary mayor as chairman. ### Mayor Roth's mayor is Klaus Schoneweg (FDP). ### Coat of arms The municipality's arms might be described thus: Azure a Wheel of Fortune argent. ## Culture and sightseeing ### Buildings The following are listed buildings or sites in Rhineland-Palatinate's Directory of Cultural Monuments: * Saint Nicholas's Catholic Church (Kirche St. Nikolai),

Don't Be Cruel is the second studio album by American singer Bobby Brown. The album was released on June 5, 1988, by MCA Records and was produced by L.A. Reid and Babyface. The album was nominated for the Grammy Award for Album of the Year at the 1989 Grammy Awards. Don't Be Cruel was a success, making it to the top five on the Billboard 200 albums chart and being certified five times platinum by the RIAA. The album spent 79 weeks in the top ten, including three weeks at the top of the Billboard 200, and was the first album by a male R&B artist to sell over six million copies in the United States. Four singles were released from the album, all of which were top ten hits: "My Prerogative" reached number one on the Billboard Hot 100, "Don't Be Cruel" reached number two, "Roni" reached number seven, and "Rock Wit'cha" reached number ten. The title track was also a major success, peaking at number 13 on the Billboard Hot 100. The album received positive reviews from music critics, who praised its production and Brown's vocal performance. It was also a commercial success, becoming one of the best-selling albums of 1988 and 1989. In 2003, the album was ranked number 487 on Rolling Stone magazine's list of the 500 Greatest Albums of All Time. In 2007, the album was ranked number 62 on Slant Magazine's list of the 100 Best Albums of the 1980s. In 2012, the album was ranked number 674 on Rolling Stone magazine's list of the 500 Greatest Albums of All Time. In 2015, the album was ranked number 82 on Spin magazine's list of the 300 Best Albums of the Past 30 Years (1985–2014). In 2020, the album was ranked number 372 on Rolling Stone magazine's list of the 500 Greatest Albums of All Time. Track listing All tracks written by L.A. Reid and Babyface; vocal arrangements by Babyface and rosemary; background vocals by Babyface, rosemary, and The Braxtons (except track 11, background vocals by The Braxtons and Bobby Brown); all instruments by L.A. Reid and Babyface. * 1) "Don't Be Cruel" – 4:52 * 2) "My Prerogative" – 5:09 * 3) "Roni" – 4:35 * 4) "Rock Wit'cha" – 6:20 * 5) "Don't Be So Hard" – 4:52 * 6) "She Ain't You" – 5:44 * 7) "Sapphire" – 4:44 * 8) "This Is My Song" – 5:10 * 9) "Revelation" – 4:55 * 10) "Don't Be Afraid" – 5:20 * 11) "Dancing in the Rain" – 4:46 Personnel Design * Michael Boddicker – Fairlight synthesizer programming * Babyface – keyboards, drum programming, background vocals * L.A.
