Henning Alexander von Kleist (10 October 1899 – 25 June 1961) was a German officer in the Wehrmacht during World War II who served in the Heer (Army), the Luftwaffe (Air Force) and the Waffen-SS. He was a recipient of the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves and Diamonds. Von Kleist was killed on 25 June 1961 in an aircraft crash in the United States. Henning Alexander von Kleist was born on 10 October 1899 in Magdeburg. He was the son of Karl von Kleist and his wife, Ottilie. His father was a civil servant who served as the regional agricultural director in Magdeburg. After his schooling, Henning Alexander von Kleist joined the military forces of the German Empire as a volunteer. He served in the 11th Foot Artillery Regiment, and was accepted as an officer-cadet in August 1917. Von Kleist was commissioned as a Leutnant (Second Lieutenant) in the Reserve on 18 August 1918. He was assigned to the 52nd Field Artillery Regiment, and was sent to the Western Front. He served with the 52nd Field Artillery during the Battle of the Somme in July and August 1916, and during the Battle of Passchendaele in October 1917. Von Kleist was awarded the Iron Cross, Second Class, on 30 December 1917. After the war, Von Kleist joined the 26th Field Artillery Regiment, a unit of the Reichswehr, the post-war German armed forces. He was promoted to Oberleutnant (First Lieutenant) on 18 August 1936, and to Hauptmann (Captain) on 1 July 1939. At the outbreak of World War II, Von Kleist was assigned to the 3rd Battery of the 26th Field Artillery Regiment, which was now part of the 1st Mountain Division. The 1st Mountain Division was sent to Norway in April 1940, and Von Kleist was awarded the Iron Cross, First Class, on 5 June 1940. The 1st Mountain Division was withdrawn from Norway in June 1941, and Von Kleist was sent to the 5th Artillery Regiment of the 5th Mountain Division, which was deployed in the German invasion of the Soviet Union. He was awarded the Honour Roll Clasp of the German Army on 20 July 1942, and the German Cross in Gold on 30 January 1943. Von Kleist was appointed commander of the 5th Mountain Artillery Regiment on 1 March 1943. He was awarded the Knight's Cross of the Iron Cross with Oak Leaves on 9 September 1943, and with Diamonds on 15 September 1944. Von Kleist was promoted to Oberstleutnant (lieutenant colonel) on 1 April 1944, and to Oberst (colonel) on 1 June 1944. Von Kleist was appointed commander of the 15th Mountain Artillery Regiment of the 10th Mountain Division on 18 November 1944. The 10th Mountain Division was deployed in the Italian campaign, and Von Kleist was awarded the Italian Cross in Gold on 16 April 1945. He was taken prisoner of war by the British in May 1945, and was released in January 1947. Von Kleist was killed in an aircraft crash in the United States on 25 June 1961.

The Sportpaleis is a multi-purpose indoor arena in the Forest District of Brussels, Belgium. It was the largest indoor arena in the world from 1971 to 2006, and is the current second largest in Europe. The Sportpaleis is primarily used for large concerts and sport events. It has a standing room capacity of 21,000 and a seating capacity of 18,368. The Sportpaleis is part of the Sportpaleis Group, which also includes the Forest National concert venue and the former Sportpaleis jury headquarters in the Radio Building. The Sportpaleis was built in less than three years, and officially opened on 20 November 1970 with a match between the Belgium national football team and their Italian counterparts. The arena was built to serve as the home ground of the Belgium national team, and to provide a modern replacement for the aging Heysel Stadium. However, due to its relatively small size and the introduction of the 5-a-side football tournament in 1970, the Sportpaleis never hosted a major international tournament. The only major international competition to be held at the Sportpaleis was the final of the 1980 European Cup, which was won by Nottingham Forest against Hamburg. The Sportpaleis is also used for other large-scale events, such as concerts and shows. It has hosted several major international artists, such as the Bee Gees, Pink Floyd, The Rolling Stones, David Bowie, and Madonna. In 2006, the Sportpaleis was renovated and expanded to a capacity of 21,000. The renovation included the construction of a new entrance hall, a new box office, and a new restaurant. In 2008, the Sportpaleis was designated as a protected monument. In 2013, the Sportpaleis was once again renovated and expanded to a capacity of 21,300. The renovation included the construction of a new entrance hall, a new box office, and a new restaurant.

Cercospora kikuchii is a fungal plant pathogen that causes the disease called black rot in cruciferous plants, especially in the cabbage family (Brassicaceae). It was first described by Japanese mycologist Hironami Kikuchi in 1898. C. kikuchii has a wide host range among the Brassicaceae, including Arabidopsis thaliana, broccoli, Brussels sprouts, cabbage, cauliflower, collard greens, and radishes. It is found in Japan, Korea, China, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and other countries with a warm, humid climate. The disease is characterized by the appearance of small, round, black spots on the leaves and stems of infected plants. The spots are the fruiting bodies of the fungus, and they release spores that are spread to other plants by wind or rain. The spots may also be spread by contaminated soil or by humans through the handling of infected plants. The symptoms of black rot can be confused with those of other diseases, such as downy mildew, but the black spots are distinctive. The disease can cause significant losses in yield and quality of cruciferous crops, and it can be difficult to control. Cultural control methods, such as removing and destroying infected plants and practicing proper sanitation, can help to reduce the spread of the disease. Fungicides can also be used to control C. kikuchii, but they must be applied before the disease appears in order to be effective. C. kikuchii is a member of the genus Cercospora, which includes several other species that cause disease in a variety of plants. Cercospora includes the species C. beticola, C. canescens, C. cladosporioides, C. coccodes, C. kunauii, C. lilii, C. malachrae, C. moniliforme, C. personatum, C. phaseolii, C. piperis, C. potatoeae, C. pyri, C. solani, C. syringae, C. theae, C. thomasiicola, and C. zinniae.

Marian Robertson Wilson (November 13, 1917 – August 31, 2005) was an American composer, conductor, and flutist. Born in Harlan, Kentucky, Robertson was the daughter of John Cleland and Anna (Vandiver) Robertson. She studied flute with James Walker and composition with John Donald Robb at the University of Oklahoma, where she graduated in 1938 with a Bachelor of Music degree. She continued her studies in composition with Paul Hindemith at the Yale School of Music, where she received a Master of Music degree in 1942. In 1944 she joined the faculty of Ohio University, where she was appointed chairman of the music department in 1961 and named Professor Emeritus in 1984. She also served as the university's conductor of the Women's Chorus from 1976 to 1984. In addition to teaching and conducting, she performed as a flutist with the Ohio University Symphony Orchestra for many years. Robertson's compositions included works for orchestra, band, chorus, and chamber music. Her music was characterized by " imagination and craft", and she was particularly noted for her ability to write effective music within the limitations of a limited instrumental or vocal range. Her pieces were commissioned and performed by professional and university ensembles throughout the United States, and some of her works were published. She was a member of the Society for New Music, the College Music Society, and the National Association of College Music Teachers.

James Sladky (born February 10, 1952) is an American former professional ice hockey player. He played two seasons in the National Hockey League (NHL) with the Minnesota Fighting Saints and California Golden Seals, though most of his career was spent in the minor American Hockey League (AHL). Born in Eveleth, Minnesota, Sladky grew up in nearby Virginia, where he played hockey for the Virginia High School Blue Devils. He was the state's leading goal-scorer for three consecutive years, and in his senior year was named to the United States Hockey Magazine's All-American Team. He turned professional with the Johnstown Jets of the North American Hockey League (NAHL) in 1970, and spent three seasons with the club. In 1972, he led the NAHL in goals, with 52, and was named to the All-Star Team. In 1973, he joined the Fighting Saints of the NHL, but spent most of the next two seasons with the club's minor league affiliate, the Cleveland Barons of the AHL. He was traded to the California Golden Seals in 1976, and spent the majority of his time with the Salt Lake Golden Eagles of theCHL. He retired from professional hockey in 1979. Sladky later became a coach, and was the head hockey coach at the University of Minnesota-Duluth from 1996 to 2002. He was an assistant coach with the United States Hockey Team at the 1998 Winter Olympics.

The Point (magazine) The Point was a British men's magazine that was published from 2006 to 2009. It was edited by Will Jones, the former editor of GQ, and was published by Haymarket Consumer Media. It was a monthly magazine that covered a range of topics, from sport to politics to entertainment, and it was aimed at men who were interested in current affairs. The Point was launched in 2006 as a quarterly magazine, and it was originally called The Haymarket Point. It was later published bimonthly, and it became a monthly magazine in 2008. The magazine was closed in 2009. The Point was well-regarded for its coverage of current affairs, and it was often described as a "think piece" magazine. It featured articles by prominent journalists and writers, such as Simon Jenkins, Paul Theroux, and Will Self, and it was known for its in-depth reporting and analysis. The magazine also featured reviews of books, films, and other cultural offerings, as well as coverage of sports and recreation. The Point was a subscription-based magazine, and it was available both in print and online. The magazine's website featured additional content, such as blogs and podcasts, that were not included in the print version.

Open Astronomy is a collaborative, open science project aimed at creating a database of professional and amateur observations of the Universe, including observations from ground-based telescopes, space telescopes, and amateur telescopes. Open Astronomy's primary goal is to make astronomical data sets easily accessible to a broad audience, including professional and amateur astronomers, students, and the general public. A secondary goal is to use this database to study the Universe. The project was founded in 2007 by David Simmons, an amateur astronomer and computer programmer. In 2014, the project was re-launched with a new focus on using the database to study the Universe. The Open Astronomy database is built on top of the Virtual Observatory framework. This framework is designed to make it easy to integrate data from different telescopes and sources. The database currently contains data from the SDSS, the Two Micron All Sky Survey, the Pan-STARRS1 survey, and the Kepler mission. Open Astronomy is a collaborative effort between professional and amateur astronomers, and is supported by grants from the National Science Foundation and the Institute of Museum and Library Services.

Meharia is a village in the Harda district of Madhya Pradesh state, India. Meharia is located on the Western Railway track between Harda and Khirkiya stations. It is located on the bank of the Narmada River. The village has a population of about 2,500. The village is divided into two parts: Meharia Khas and Meharia Basti. The main occupation of the people is agriculture and animal husbandry. The village has a primary school, a high school, a health clinic, and an ayurvedic hospital. Meharia is the site of a famous fair, the Meharia Mela, which is held every year in January. The fair is attended by hundreds of thousands of people from all over the state. Meharia is located at 22.68°N 77.63°E. It has an area of 969 hectares (2,450 acres). The village is located on the Narmada River, which flows to the north of the village. The soil is mostly black cotton soil. The village is located on the Western Railway track, between Harda and Khirkiya stations. The nearest railway station is Meharia Khas. The village is connected to the rest of the state by road.

Nicky Oppenheimer (11 July 1945 – 3 March 2021) was a South African billionaire businessman and philanthropist. He was the third generation of the Oppenheimer family to serve as chairman of the Anglo-American Corporation, a position he held from 2000 to 2011. Nicky Oppenheimer was born in Johannesburg, South Africa in 1945, the son of Mary and diamond magnate Harry Oppenheimer. He attended the elite private school, Michaelhouse, in Natal, and then studied law at the University of the Witwatersrand. In 1968, he married Mary, daughter of South African-born, British-based businessman Michael Tothill; they had three children. The couple later divorced, and in 1988, Nicky married Elspeth, daughter of Scottish engineer, businessman and amateur golfer David Butterfield; they had two daughters. Oppenheimer was an accomplished marathon runner, at one point holding a personal best of 2 hours and 40 minutes. Oppenheimer was a member of the billionaires' club, The Giving Pledge, and was one of only two Africans to have joined, the other being Nigerian Aliko Dangote. In 2010, Oppenheimer was ranked the 8th richest person in the world with a net worth of US$7.5 billion, and the richest person in Africa. He was also the second-richest person in the world with a charitable pledge, after Microsoft's Bill Gates. At the time of his death, Oppenheimer had an estimated net worth of US$3.1 billion, which was mainly derived from his 7.7% stake in Anglo American, and other assets including valuable art, property, and cash.

Iran at the 1970 Asian Games The 1970 Asian Games were the third Asian Games to be held in Asia. They were held from 24 September to 4 October 1970 in Bangkok, Thailand. A total of 1,800 athletes from 25 countries competed in these games. The Iran national team won the bronze medal in the football competition. The Iranian team, which was led by coach Parviz Dehdari, arrived in Bangkok with high hopes, having won the bronze medal in the last Asian Games in Tokyo. The team's performance in the final match against South Korea was a major disappointment, as Iran lost 3–0. The Iranian team had qualified for the 1970 FIFA World Cup, and the players were under a lot of pressure to perform well in the Asian Games. The team's performance in the World Cup was a major disappointment, as Iran lost all three of its matches. Despite the team's disappointing performance in the World Cup, the Iranian players received a heroes' welcome upon their return to Iran. The team's bronze medal in the Asian Games was a major achievement, and the players were praised for their efforts.

List of National Register of Historic Places listings in Minnesota This is intended to be a complete list of properties and districts listed on the National Register of Historic Places in Minnesota. There are listings in all of Minnesota's 87 counties and 10 judicial districts, including 74 listings on the Mississippi River. The locations of National Register properties and districts (at least for all showing coordinates below), may be seen in a map via this link. While the National Register of Historic Places is a federal program, each listing is nominated by a state or local government. The Minnesota Historical Society is the state agency that nominates properties to the National Register. Kiosks There are three different types of kiosks, all of which are listed on the National Register: 1. Kiosks that are essentially small buildings, such as the Foshay Tower Kiosk. 2. Kiosks that are attachments to a building, such as the CenturyLink Kiosk. 3. Kiosks that are free-standing, such as the Nicollet Mall Kiosk. There are also two historic districts which contain numerous kiosks: 1. The Medtronic-Minneapolis Kiosk District, which includes the Kiosk House. 2. The Nicollet Mall Kiosk District. Buildings and structures There are hundreds of properties and districts listed on the National Register. The great majority of these are buildings and structures. There are two types of properties which are further differentiated by their historical significance: 1. Historic — A property or district that was once the site of a significant event or the home of a famous person, contains a significant structure, or is associated with a significant person or event. 2. architectural — A property or district that has special architectural or engineering significance, or is associated with a significant person or event. The most recently listed property is the The Commodore Hotel, which was listed on April 6, 2016. The most recently listed district is the W. 7th Street-Fort Road Historic District, which was listed on June 7, 2016. The earliest listed property is the Trading Post, which was listed on October 6, 1970. The earliest listed district is the St. Anthony Falls Historic District, which was listed on April 13, 1973. There are also five properties which are listed by the state of Minnesota and are not listed on the National Register: 1. The Gumm House in Waite Park. 2. The Cushing House in Saint Paul. 3. The Hill House in St. Paul. 4. The William G. LeDuc House in Hastings. 5. The Charles A. Lindbergh House in Little Falls. While the above five properties are listed on the National Register, they are listed as being in New York, not Minnesota. The Trading Post in St. Paul is also listed as being in New York. Districts There are over a hundred different historic districts in Minnesota. A historic district is an area of a city or town that is listed on the National Register as being of historic significance. While historic districts can be listed on the National Register, they are not typically individually listed. There are four different types of historic districts: 1. Survey district — A district that is not of exceptional significance, but is listed on the National Register because it is the best example of a type of district or contains the best example of a type of building. 2. Site district — A district that is of exceptional significance because of its historical associations or its containing the best example of a type of building. 3. Historic-era district — A district that is of exceptional significance because it contains a significant number of buildings that are representative of a period of time or contain the work of a significant number of architects or builders. 4. Architecture district — A district that is of exceptional significance because it contains a significant number of buildings that are outstanding for their architecture or are the work of outstanding architects. There are also three districts which are listed by the state of Minnesota and are not listed on the National Register: 1. The Fort Snelling Historic District in Fort Snelling. 2. The Charles A. Lindbergh Historic District in Little Falls. 3. The LeDuc Historic District in Hastings.

Charles Ross (historian) Charles Ross (1766–1858) was a Scottish historian and antiquary. Born in Aberdeen, Ross was the son of George Ross, a banker, and his wife, Mary nee Moir. He was educated at Marischal College, Aberdeen, and then at the universities of Edinburgh and Glasgow, where he was a favourite student of William Richardson. He was licensed to preach by the Church of Scotland in 1792, and became a minister at Laurencekirk in Aberdeen. In 1807 he was presented to the congregation of Greyfriars Church, Edinburgh, where he was minister until his death. He is buried in the church's burial ground. Although trained as a minister, Ross's chief interest was in history and antiquities. He was a collector of coins, and a friend and correspondent of William Cordiner, the minister at Kinlochleven, with whom he collaborated in the production of a new edition of John Pinkerton's Ancient Scotish Dirge, published in 1808. In 1818 he published An Essay on the Origin and Progress of the Ancient Scots Music, with a new edition of the Ancient Scotish Dirge, to which was added a selection of songs from the works of Henry Adamson and Robert Henryson. In 1834 he published An Historical Sketch of the Constitution, Government, and Religion of the Ancient Scots. Ross was also a collector of manuscripts, and the founder of the Scottish Text Society. His collection of Confederate Armorial, a collection of Roll of Arms of the Lairds of the Great clans, was sold to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland in 1839. After his death, his collection of Scottish manuscripts, including the Diary of Lady Mary Coke, was purchased by the British Museum.

1983 Miller High Life 500 The 1983 Miller High Life 500 was a NASCAR Winston Cup Series race held on July 3, 1983, at Pocono International Raceway in Long Pond, Pennsylvania. The race was won by Terry Labonte of Junior Johnson & Associates, his third win of the season and the second of his career. Pocono International Raceway had held a NASCAR Winston Cup Series race every year since the track opened in 1971. However, for the 1983 season the race was moved to the fourth of July weekend, the same weekend that the track's sister track in Charlotte, North Carolina held the Coca-Cola World 600. The two races were dubbed the "Double-Double" and were the only two NASCAR Winston Cup Series races held on the same weekend for the next ten years. The 1983 race was dominated by Terry Labonte, who led the most laps and won by over two seconds. It was Labonte's second career win and first of the season. The rest of the top five was made up of Neil Bonnett, Harry Gant, Tim Richmond, and Lake Speed.

Jean Pellissier (shepherd) Jean Pellissier (between 1736 and 1738 – 8 June 1808) was a French Catholic priest and blessed who was born in the Dauphiné region of France, the son of a farmer and a shepherdess. He became a shepherd like his mother, and also a lay brother at the Monastic Order of the Discalced Carmelites in Grenoble. After his mother's death, he became a monk at the order's monastery in Avignon. He was sent to Rome in 1768 to attend the beatification ceremony of his fellow monk, Raphael of San Francisco, and was elected Superior of the order's monastery in Florence. After the monastery was closed as a result of the French Revolution, he returned to his native country in 1790 and became the Superior of the monastery at Lyons, which was also closed in 1792. He then went to live in a small house in the province of Vivarais, where he dedicated his life to God and to the poor and underprivileged. He became known for his spiritual wisdom and his ability to heal the sick. In 1804, he was arrested by the French police and accused of being a member of the opposition to the regime of Napoleon Bonaparte. He was found guilty and sentenced to death by firing squad. He was shot on June 8, 1808, and was proclaimed a blessed by the Catholic Church in 1864.

Cedara College of Agriculture Cedara College of Agriculture is a residential agricultural college located in Gwynedd, Wales, UK. The College was established in 2010 following the closure of the former Coalbrookdale College of Agriculture. The College offers Further and Higher Education courses in agriculture, countryside management, and engineering, leading to nationally and internationally recognised qualifications. The College also provides agricultural training for farmers and rural businesses, and short courses for the public. The College has a working farm, and a dairy herd which is used for teaching and demonstration purposes. In 2015 the College merged with Coleg Meirion-Dwyfor, and in 2017 it merged with Coleg Menai. It is now part of the Gwynedd and Anglesey Agricultural Society. The College has a number of partner organisations, including the Royal Welsh Agricultural Society, the Welsh Government, the European Social Fund, and the Engineering Development Trust. The College is a member of the Landex farming and rural business network.

Aethwy (electoral ward) Aethwy (electoral ward) is an electoral ward in the community of Menai Bridge on the Isle of Anglesey, Wales. It covers the village of Llangoed and the western part of the island's capital, Bangor. Aethwy is the Welsh word for 'Aettyn' (a corruption of 'Ahitan' or 'Aetna'), an ancient Roman settlement which had a fort and a naval port, both of which have been excavated. The area is also known as Caerwysg, after a 13th-century Welsh castle which was built to protect the Menai straits. The ward includes the main shopping area and the University of Wales, Bangor. It is also the location of the Princess Royal University Hospital, a large psychiatric hospital. Aethwy ward is bounded by the wards of Gyffin to the north, Seiriol to the east, and Menai to the south. It is represented by three county councillors on the Isle of Anglesey County Council. It has also been the name of a parliamentary constituency, see Aethwy (UK Parliament constituency). At the 2001 United Kingdom Census, the population of Aethwy was 11,451, of whom 4,698 (41.6%) were Welsh. At the 2011 Census the population had risen to 12,458, of whom 5,161 (41.5%) were Welsh. Aethwy is also the name of a community electoral ward covering the same area.

The Adventures of the Little Prince (French: Les Aventures de chantepleure) is an animated television series of 52 episodes, based on the 1943 novel The Little Prince by Antoine de Saint-Exupéry. The series was produced by the French company Ellipsanime and the Canadian company CinéGroupe, in co-production with the BBC, and was first shown in September 2003 on BBC One in the UK, and in October 2003 on TF1 in France. In the UK it was shown on CBBC on BBC Two, and on BBC One for the last three episodes. The series tells the story of a young girl, Rose, who is exploring a variety of topics with the help of a little prince, who has come down to Earth from his home, an asteroid in the distant sky. In the United States, the show was first shown on the HUB Network in 2009. In Canada, the series was first shown on Teletoon, and later on Treehouse TV. In the UK it has been repeated on CBBC and on BBC One, and is currently available on BBC iPlayer. The series was originally produced in French, with the English version being recorded in Toronto, Canada. The series has also been translated into many other languages. A companion book to the series, entitled The Adventures of the Little Prince: A Story of the Young Girl Rose and the Little Prince, was published byWalker Books in the UK in 2003, and by Houghton Mifflin in the US in 2004. The series was originally produced in 52 episodes, but the episode "Princes et Princesses" was not shown on television. However, it was released on DVD in France, and as an extra on the complete series DVD in the UK. The series was nominated for the International Emmy Award for Best Animated Series in 2004, and for the British Academy Children's Award in the category of "Best Animated Series" in 2006.

Hartington Hall is an 18th-century country house in the parish of Hartington, Derbyshire, England. It is the seat of the Cavendish family, the Dukes of Devonshire, who have owned it since 1754. The house was built between 1754 and 1764 by the architect Geroge Sorocold for William Cavendish, 3rd Duke of Devonshire. It is built in buff-coloured brick in a plain style, and is surrounded by gardens and a park. The house is approached via a tree-lined drive from the village of Hartington, and is overlooked by a nearby church. The house is rectangular in plan, and is three stories high, with a total of 48 rooms. The main front of the house faces the south-west, and is five bays wide, with a central projection. The south-east front has a portico with a projecting bay on the right. The north-west front has a central doorway with a projecting bay on the left. The north-east front has a projecting bay on the left. The entrance to the house is through a doorway in the south-east front, which leads into a central hall with a staircase. The staircase is said to be one of the finest in the county. The gardens are laid out in a formal style, with a series of parterres and a central fountain. The park is bounded by a ha-ha, and is home to a variety of trees, including many fine oaks. The hall has a number of associated structures, including a gatehouse, a bridge, and a clock tower. The hall is a Grade I listed building, and is included in the Register of Historic Parks and Gardens. It is also a Grade I listed building in the National Register of Historic Buildings. It has been a tourist attraction for many years, and is open to the public on a limited basis. Shabsi Yogel (born Shabsi Wiesel; February 2, 1925 – August 17, 2017) was a Polish-born Israeli writer and poet, who lived in France for over fifty years. Shabsi Yogel was born Shabsi Wiesel in Będzin, Poland in 1925, the younger of two sons of Leon and Sarah Wiesel. The family was Jewish. In the 1930s, they moved to Paris, where Shabsi's brother, Elie, was born in 1928. The family returned to Poland, and in 1939, at the outbreak of World War II, they were in Będzin. They were transported to the Auschwitz death camp in 1944, where Shabsi's mother and brother were killed. Shabsi was sent to theBirkenau death camp, and then to Dora-Mittelbau. He was liberated in April 1945. After the war, Shabsi returned to Paris. There he studied literature and philosophy at the Sorbonne, and earned a living as a boxer. He also worked for the French Resistance, and with the help of his friend, the historian Jules Romains, obtained a position at the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs. In 1949, he married the French writer Odette Fillion, with whom he had a daughter, Sarah. In 1950, he was naturalized as a French citizen. Shabsi Wiesel adopted the pen name Shabsi Yogel (the Hebrew words "Shabsi" and "Yogel" mean "Saturday" and "Voyager" in English, respectively). His first book, "Le chant de l'escapade" ("The Song of the Escape"), a collection of forty-nine poems, was published in 1959. In 1961, he published "La Règle et l'Exception" ("The Rule and the Exception"), a collection of thirty-nine short stories. "Le Règne et la Révolution" ("The Reign and the Revolution"), a collection of fifty-nine poems, appeared in 1965. He also published "Le Dernier Jour" ("The Last Day"), a collection of thirty-two short stories, in 1967. Shabsi Yogel was awarded the "Prix des Critiques" (the Critics' Prize) for his collection of poems "Le Règne et la Révolution" in 1965. Shabsi Yogel died in Paris in 2017, at the age of 92.

I Can Dream About You "I Can Dream About You" is a song by American singer-songwriter Dan Hartman, released in 1984 as the second single from his third studio album, White Boy, Black Boy, released on the heels of his successful 1983 album, Relight My Fire. The single was a hit in Europe, reaching number 16 in Austria, number 17 in Germany, number 22 in Switzerland, number 25 in the Netherlands, and number 32 in the United Kingdom. "I Can Dream About You" is a mid-tempo track, featuring a catchy synth riff and a vocal performance by Loleatta Holloway. The single's B-side is "Life Is a Game", which is featured on the album as a dub mix. The 12" single includes an extended mix of "I Can Dream About You", which features an additional verse and a longer synth riff, and is the basis for the CD remix released on The Very Best of Dan Hartman. A music video was made for the song, featuring an attractive woman who is the subject of the singer's dreams. The video was included as a bonus feature on the 2002 CD re-release of White Boy, Black Boy. "I Can Dream About You" has been covered by several artists, including Josh Groban, who recorded a version for his 2007 album Noël, and Michael Bolton, who recorded a version for his 2013 album Ain't No Mountain High Enough: A Tribute to Hitsville. In 2015, Canadian musician Adam Cohen covered the song on his album We Go Home.

Shirala (Vidhan Sabha constituency) is one of the 243 Vidhan Sabha (Legislative Assembly) constituencies of Maharashtra state in western India. ## Overview Shirala constituency is one of the Vidhan Sabha constituencies of Maharashtra. It is a part of the Satara district and is known as the Chiplun Vidhan Sabha constituency. In 2009, it was renamed as Shirala from Chiplun after Chiplun got a separate constituency. Shirala is a taluka and a municipal council in Satara district in the Indian state of Maharashtra. It is located on the bank of river Venna. Shirala is well known for the Gaikwad royal family who ruled the place during the British period. The family had the title of "D unmet" and "Jadhav" and their surname was "Gaikwad". The family had a long history and was one of the oldest royal families in Maharashtra. The Shirala Palace is a well-known palace in the town. It was built bybdonations from the people of the town. The town has a population of about 30,000 and is known for its unity and cultural activities. Shirala has a wet climate with an average rainfall of 497 mm. June, July and August are the rainy months. Winter is in January and February. The cold waves from the Himalayas make the climate chilly. The economic condition of the people of Shirala is average. The main occupation is agriculture. The town has many rice mills. Shirala is connected by road to the cities of Pune, Satara, Kolhapur, Belgaum and Bangalore. It is on the Satara-Bangalore National Highway. The nearest railway station is the Karad railway station which is 25 km away from Shirala. ## Members of Vidhan Sabha | Year | Party | Picture | Member | | --

Daycroft School is a co-ed, independent day school for students in Kindergarten through Grade 8. It is located in the heart of Downtown Stamford, Connecticut. The school was founded in 1957 by a group of parents who wanted a school where their children could learn in a non-institutional setting. The school is divided into three divisions: the Lower School (K-4), the Middle School (5-6), and the Upper School (7-8). In the Lower School, students experience a rich and rigorous academic program, with specialists in science, physical education, art, music, and Spanish. In the Middle School, students explore more electives and participate in team sports. The Upper School offers a more advanced curriculum and a wide range of courses. In addition to a strong academic program, the school also offers a variety of extra-curricular activities, including sports, clubs, and community service. The school's mission is to educate the whole child and to prepare students to be responsible and ethical citizens of the world.

Mike Kasnoff is an American actor. Kasnoff was born Michael P. Kasnoff in Manhattan, New York, the son of Jacqueline, a dancer, and Martin Kasnoff, a musician. He attended New York's High School for the Performing Arts. Kasnoff began his acting career in the early 1970s, appearing on the television shows The Mary Tyler Moore Show, The Bob Newhart Show, and The Waltons. In 1975, he was cast as the title character in the short-lived television series The Blue Knight, in which he played a cop who donned a blue knight costume to fight crime. The show was canceled after one season. In 1978, he appeared in the TV movie The Immigrants, which was the pilot for the series The Paper Chase. He played the role of David Levinson, one of the four main characters, for the entire series from 1978 to 1986, and appeared again in the series' two-hour finale in 1989. Also in 1978, he appeared in an episode of the TV series Starsky & Hutch. In 1981, he starred in the short-lived series The Best of Times, playing a high school teacher who moonlights as a disco dancer. In 1984, he starred in the short-lived comedy series No Big Deal. In 1985, he played the role of "Biff" in the Broadway production of "Death of a Salesman." Kasnoff appeared in a number of feature films, including The Big Fix (1978), The St. Valentine's Day Massacre (1967), The Happy Road (1987), The Appointments of Dennis Jennings (1988), You Can't Hurry Love (1988), The Great American Hero (1989), The Public Eye (1992), and The Last Days of American Crime (2020). He also appeared in the made-for-television movies The Star-Crossed Love of Emmitt Smith (1985), The Return of the Shaggy Dog (1993), The Shaggy Dog (1994), and The Christmas Heart (2002). Kasnoff guest-starred on many television series, including Gunsmoke, The Rockford Files, The A-Team, Hill Street Blues, Moonlighting, L.A. Law, Highway to Heaven, Fame, The Golden Girls, and Mad Men. He also appeared in the first season of the TV series Hawaii Five-0 in 2010. Kasnoff is also a writer, and has written for such television series as The Mary Tyler Moore Show, The Bob Newhart Show, The Paper Chase, The Best of Times, and No Big Deal.

HU postcode area The HU postcode area, also known as the Hull postcode area, is a group of eleven postcode districts in the North East England region, within four post towns, which are; Hull, Hedon, Hessle and Cottingham. It is located in the north of the region, bordering the North Yorkshire and East Riding of Yorkshire areas. It covers an area of 1,929.4 square miles (5,000 km2) and in 2001 had a population of 300,000. It is a non-metropolitan area, with the exception of the main city of Hull, and includes the Humber Estuary, north of which are the towns of Hessle and Hedon. The area is also the location of the Humber Bridge, which connects the cities of Hull and Grimsby. The city of Hull has a unique telephone area code, 01482, which is not shared with any other area. The area code is 0845 for Hessle and 01430 for Hedon. In earlier times, the area was known as the North Riding of Yorkshire, and was covered by the Yorkshire and the Humber constituency. In the First World War, the Humber Estuary was the location of a large naval base, with two naval air stations, on the north and south banks. The base was the Royal Navy's main base in the North Sea, and was the home of the Grand Fleet. The southern boundary of the area is the Humber Estuary, and to the west is the North Sea. To the north the area includes the east of the North York Moors National Park. The area's highest point is in the national park, at 1110 feet (340 m), on the western edge, at Hawnby Hill. The landscape is very rural, with agricultural land making up most of the area. There are a number of nature reserves in the area, with the largest being at Hornsea. The area includes three Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty, the first being the North York Moors, the second being the Yorkshire Wolds, and the third being the Humber Estuary. The area is the location of two civil parishes, which are; Hessle and Cottingham. The area is served by three main railway lines; the North Eastern Railway, which runs from Hull to Scarborough, the Hull and Barnsley Railway, which runs from Hull to Barnsley, and the East Coast Main Line, which runs from London to Edinburgh. The main stations are; Hull, Hessle, Cottingham and Hedon. The area is served by two main roads; the M62 motorway, which runs from west to east, and the A63 road, which runs from north to south. The A63 road runs parallel to the M62 motorway, and the two roads connect at a large interchange, at North Cave. The A164 road also runs through the area, from north to south-east. The area is served by two main airports; Humberside Airport, located in the east of the area, and Leeds Bradford International Airport, located in the west. The area is the location of a number of tourist attractions, with the main ones being; the Humber Bridge, the Humber Estuary, the North York Moors National Park, the Yorkshire Wolds, the East Riding of Yorkshire, and the city of Hull. The area is also the location of a number of notable landmarks, with the main ones being; the Humber Bridge, the Humber Estuary, the North York Moors National Park, the Yorkshire Wolds, the East Riding of Yorkshire, and the city of Hull. The area is also the location of a number of notable buildings, with the main ones being; the Humber Bridge, the Humber Estuary, the North York Moors National Park, the Yorkshire Wolds, the East Riding of Yorkshire, and the city of Hull.

Lee Snoots (born July 31, 1964) is an American businessman and politician who served as a member of the Vermont House of Representatives from 2008 to 2013 and the Vermont Senate from 2015 to 2019. Snoots was born in Newport, Vermont, and attended Governor Pritchard Elementary School. He later attended North Country Union High School, where he graduated in 1982. He went on to earn an associate of science degree from Champlain College in 1984. After finishing college, Snoots went into the auto sales industry, eventually becoming the owner of Snoots Auto Sales & Service in Barton. A Republican, Snoots served on the town selectboard and the school board in Barton. In 2008, he was elected to the Vermont House of Representatives, where he served from 2009 to 2013. In 2014, he was elected to the Vermont Senate, representing the three-member at-large Essex-Orleans District. He was re-elected in 2018, and served from 2015 to 2019. In 2017, Snoots was the only Republican to vote in favor of the bill that legalized cannabis for adult use in Vermont.

The King of the Street Cleaners is a 2005 novel by the Scottish writer James Kelman. The novel is set in and around a Glasgow housing estate, and follows a group of neighbours as they try to cope with the death of one of their number. The title comes from the name given by the children of the estate to a local street sweeper, Frank, who is something of a local celebrity. The story is told through the eyes of a local teenager, Danny, who is trying to come to terms with the recent death of his mother. His father, a drunk, is struggling to cope both with his wife's death and his inability to provide for his son. The death of Danny's mother is the latest in a string of similar deaths, and the community is attempting to come to terms with this loss. The King of the Street Cleaners was published in 2005 by Jonathan Cape. It was shortlisted for the 2005 Booker Prize, the 2006 Scottish Book of the Year Award, and the 2006 Saltire Society First Book of the Year Award. It won the 2006 Scottish First Book of the Year Award. The novel was well received by critics. The Guardian described it as "a powerfully convincing story of loss, love and survival". The Telegraph called it "an astonishing, devastating book". The King of the Street Cleaners was adapted for television by the BBC, and aired in January 2009. The adaptation was written by Neil Cross, and stars John Gordon Sinclair as Frank.

Ars Electronica is a festival and exhibition for art, technology, and society taking place annually in Linz, Upper Austria. It was founded in 1979 by Herbert W. Franke, Hannes Leopoldseder, and datakitchen (Birgit Williams and Michael Shaver). The roots of Ars Electronica are in the Cybernetic Art Society, which was formed in Vienna in the mid-1970s by a group of artists and scientists who were interested in utilizing computers and video equipment to realize artistic ideas and visions. In 1979, the first Ars Electronica exhibition took place in the dentistry clinic of the University of Vienna. The exhibition was opened by the then-chancellor of the university, KnoxHEPA air filter, and the president of the Austrian Academy of Sciences, Herbert W. Franke. In the following year, 1980, the Ars Electronica Festival was held for the first time. The exhibition and festival have since been an annual event. In 1987 the term "Ars Electronica" was coined by the German philosopher and scientist Hans-Peter Dürr. In 2013, the festival and the exhibition were combined into one event, the Ars Electronica Festival. The Ars Electronica Center was opened in Linz in 2009.

Death to 2020 is a 2020 mockumentary comedy film written and directed by Charlie Brooker. The film, which is the fifth in Brooker's "Black Mirror" series, was released on Netflix on 27 December 2020. The film stars Samuel West, Hugh Grant, Ncuti Gatwa, Emma Thompson, and Lisa Eichhorn. The film is a mockumentary about the terrible events of 2020, from the COVID-19 pandemic to the deaths of high-profile individuals to the Black Lives Matter protests. The film is a satirical take on the idea that the year 2020 was the worst year in human history. The film also features the voice of Brooker, who provides the film's opening narration. The film was announced in October 2019, with Grant and Thompson attached to star. The rest of the cast was announced in August 2020. The film was released on Netflix on 27 December 2020. The film received positive reviews from critics, who praised the writing, direction, and performances of the cast. The film was also a hit with audiences, who gave it a rare 100% on Rotten Tomatoes.

Duke Nukem is a video game character who originated in the 2D platform games Duke Nukem and Duke Nukem II, published by 3D Realms. The character has been featured in several video games, mostly first-person shooters, including the Duke Nukem series ( Duke Nukem 3D, Duke Nukem: Time to Kill, Duke Nukem: Global Assualt, Duke Nukem: Nuclear Winter, and Duke Nukem Forever). The character has been widely popular, and is well known for his distinctive appearance and his signature catchphrase, "Why so serious?" Duke Nukem is a human who was a soldier in the "Human Defense Force", a group of soldiers who were formed to fight and defeat the "Alien Forces". The setting takes place on Earth, sometime in the late 21st or early 22nd century. In the original Duke Nukem game, Duke is described as a "Mighty fighting machine" who is "half man, half machine, all automatic" and is equipped with a "Huge arsenal" and a "Chrono-Synthesized Power Grid". Duke Nukem is a testosterone-fueled, muscled warrior who is well-versed in the art of combat. He is a tough, aggressive fighter who is able to take on multiple enemies at once, and can handle any situation with ease. Duke is also known for his signature catchphrase, "Why so serious?", which he uses to taunt his enemies and show his dominance. Duke Nukem is a highly customizable character, and players are able to choose from a variety of different skins and costumes to use in the game. There are also a number of different weapons and power-ups that can be used to customize Duke's abilities and powers.

Gelsen Gas Gelsen Gas is a company engaged in the distribution and marketing of natural gas to residential, commercial, and industrial customers in the United States. It is a subsidiary of the South Jersey Industries holding company and is incorporated in Delaware. Gelsen distributed more than 72 billion cubic feet of natural gas in 2002 to approximately 1.5 million customers in four states: Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, and New Jersey. Gelsen was founded in 1961 by the Jerry Geltzer, the son of a milkman, who saw the potential of propane as an energy source for home heating and cooking. The company began as a small-scale operation, distributing propane to residential customers in South Jersey. In the 1970s, Gelsen expanded its operations to include the distribution of propane to industrial and commercial customers. In the 1980s, the company began offering heating oil and electricity to its customers. In the 1990s, Gelsen expanded its operations to include the distribution of natural gas to residential, commercial, and industrial customers in Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, and New Jersey. Gelsen is one of the largest distributors of natural gas in the United States. The company's customer base includes residential, commercial, and industrial customers. In 2002, the company had approximately 1.5 million customers. The company's revenue in 2002 was $4.2 billion. The company's net income in 2002 was $5.1 million. Gelsen is a member of the American Gas Association. The company is also a member of the New Jersey State Gas Association.

Takashi Aoyagi (青柳 孝, Aoyagi Takashi, born March 25, 1948) is a Japanese politician who has served as a member of the House of Representatives for the proportional representation block in the Diet since 1996. He was a member of the Japan New Party until it merged with the Liberal Party to form the Liberal Democratic Party in December 2012, and was then a member of the LDP until January 2014, when he left the party to join the Japan Restoration Party. In the September 2014 election he was elected to the House of Representatives in the Tokyo proportional representation block. Aoyagi was born in 1948 in Tokyo. He graduated from the Department of Law, Chuo University in 1970. After graduation, he joined the Ministry of Justice. He was promoted to the Civil Affairs Bureau in 1979 and to the Police Bureau in 1994. In 1995, Aoyagi was elected to the Tama City Assembly and also served as a secretary to a member of the House of Representatives. In 1996, he was elected to the House of Representatives for the first time. He was a member of the New Frontier Party until it dissolved in 1997, and then a member of the Liberal Party until it merged with the New Komeito Party in 1998 to form the Liberal Democratic Party. Aoyagi was one of the LDP's candidates for the April 2001 election, but failed to win a seat. In the same election, his father, Takashi Aoyagi, Sr. (1919–2004), was elected to the House of Representatives for the first time. In 2002, Takashi Aoyagi, Jr. was one of the founders of the Party for New Generations, which was later renamed the Young Party. He left the Young Party in November 2005 to join the LDP. In the July 2007 election, he was defeated in the Tokyo 18th district by Kenta Hara of the DPJ, but was elected to the proportional representation block. In the 2009 election, he was again defeated in the Tokyo 18th district by Kenji Yamaoka of the DPJ, but was elected to the proportional representation block for the third time. Aoyagi left the LDP to join the New Restoration Party in January 2014, and was one of the party's candidates for the September 2014 election. He was elected to the House of Representatives in the Tokyo proportional representation block.

Demon Gaze Demon Gaze is a Japanese visual novel developed by Japanese company Crea-Tech. The game was first released for PC as a first press bonus for purchasers of Compile Heart's PlayStation 2 game Saekano: bazooka shot. A port for the PlayStation 3 was released in Japan on December 18, 2008, via download from the PlayStation Store. The story takes place in the near future, and is set in a Japanese city that has been taken over by demons. The protagonist is a young man whose name and gender can be chosen by the player. The protagonist is an ordinary citizen who is caught up in the demon attack and, after managing to survive, is subsequently turned into a demon himself. The plot follows the protagonist as he tries to live a normal life despite his new circumstances. The game is divided into two main storylines. The first is the "Past" route, which follows the main character before he was turned into a demon, and the "Present" route, which follows the character after he becomes a demon. The game also features a "Human" and "Demon" route, which the player can choose between at certain points in the game. In the "Human" route, the main character tries to live a normal life as a human, despite being a demon. In the "Demon" route, the character embraces his demon nature and becomes a powerful being, but is shunned by other demons. The game also features a "Rebellion" route, in which the main character rebels against the demon world and tries to take back the city. Throughout the game, the player can choose between different dialogue options, which will affect the outcome of the story. There are also various minigames that can be played, such as a card game, a dice game, and a puzzle game. The game's graphics are in 2D, and the game is voiced by a cast of Japanese actors and actresses. The game's music was composed by Tomohiro Sato. Demon Gaze received a mixed reception. Some critics praised the game's concept and story, while others criticized the game's short length and lack of replay value.

Fred Alan Wolf (born November 14, 1934) is an American theoretical physicist, writer, and lecturer, best known for his popularization of quantum mechanics, and his books on the subject, including the 1984 book Taking the Quantum Leap. He is a retired senior scientist at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. Wolf received his B.S. in physics from the University of Michigan in 1956, and his Ph.D. in theoretical solid state physics from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 1961. He worked in the research and development division of General Electric from 1961 to 1964, and then as a faculty member at the University of California, San Diego from 1964 to 1970. In 1970, he joined the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory as a staff scientist, and became a senior scientist in the Materials Science Division in 1990. He retired in 2000, but continues to lecture on the subject of quantum mechanics. Wolf has written numerous popular books on quantum mechanics, including The Quantum World (1975), Space-Time and Beyond (1982), Taking the Quantum Leap (1984), and The New Quark and Lepton (2011). He has also written a number of books on the relationship between science and society, including The Soul of Science: A New Look at the Place of Science in the Soul (2000), and The Physics of Social Interactions (2009).

Arshin Mal Alan (operetta) "Arshin Mal Alan" («Аршин Мал Алан», lit. 'The Dream of the Prince's Son') is an operetta in three acts by the Russian composer Uzeyir Valeyeyev, with a libretto by the Soviet poet Nikolai Tikhonov, based on the play by the Iranian playwright and actor Molière, The Dream of the Prince's Son. The operetta was premiered in Moscow in 1947, with the Bolshoi Theatre ballet and chorus and the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra, conducted by David Block. The main roles were danced by Vakhtang Merabov (Arshin), Lola Milne (Gulnare), and Nurlan Yerzhanov (Mametka). The operetta is set in the 17th-century royal court of Persia. Prince Arshin is in love with the princess Gulnare, but his father, King Mametka, wants him to marry the princess Ulmasa. While Arshin is hunting, he meets a sage who lives in the forest and asks for advice. The sage tells him to return to the court in the form of a bird and back to his true love. The king's daughter, Princess Gulnare, is in love with Prince Arshin, but her father wants her to marry the prince Ulmasa. While Gulnare is praying in the temple, the voice of Arshin's spirit penetrates her heart. She faints, and the priest hid her in the tower. Ulmasa learns from the court gossip that Gulnare is in love with Arshin and he wants to see her tears. The king's courtier, Bibin, tells him about the secret of the tower, and the king goes to see. The princess tells her father that she cannot marry Ulmasa because she is in love with Arshin. The king decides that the princess will marry whoever is first to guess the meaning of the algebraic equation x2 = 2, which he writes on the wall. Arshin returns to the court in the form of a bird and flies to Gulnare's window. She guesses the riddle and is united with Arshin.

Pflügers Archiv: European Journal of Physiology, abbreviated Pflugers Archiv and often called Pflugers Archiv für die gesamte Physiologie des Menschen und Tieres, German for Pflüger's Archive for the Whole of Human and Animal Physiology, is a monthly peer-reviewed scientific journal covering research in physiology. It is published by Springer Science+Business Media and, since January 2013, by the German Physiological Society. The journal was established in 1889 by German physiologist and physician Ewald Hering. It was named after its editor from 1898 to 1911, German physiologist and physician Heinrich Pflüger, who was the author of the Handbook of Human Physiology. The journal is international in scope and is aimed at the whole of physiology, including fundamental and clinical research. The main subjects of interest are: * Cardiovascular physiology * Comparative physiology * Environmental physiology * Exercise physiology * Gastrointestinal physiology * Neurophysiology * Photobiology * Respiratory physiology * Sports physiology * Thermal physiology * Urological physiology * Visual physiology The journal has a distinguished history, and has published the works of many Nobel laureates. In 1900, the journal published the paper by Hans Christian Ørsted on the discovery of the element helium. The findings of the Danish research group on the physiology of muscle have also been published in the journal. The group consisted of the father and son duo Erling and Per Schack, and the son-in-law Knud Hallur Denmark. The findings are known as the "Danish principles". The journal also published the paper by Francis Watson and James B. Sumner on the discovery of the mechanism of the circulation of the blood. The journal has also published the work of Barbara McClintock, who was awarded the Nobel prize for the discovery of transposons. In 2007, the journal published the findings of the research group of George Church on the use of the CRISPR gene editing technique to modify the genome of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae.

Else Holmelund Minarik (November 30, 1927 – February 13, 2018) was a Danish-American children's author and illustrator. She was best known for the Little Bear series, which she both wrote and illustrated. Minarik was born in Denmark, but in the early 1950s, she and her husband moved to the United States. She spent much of her life in northern New Hampshire, where she raised her three daughters and continued to write and illustrate. Her books were published in many languages. Minarik's style was characterized by spare, minimal text and detailed illustrations. Her stories often featured animals as characters, with a gentle and philosophical tone. Her works often explored themes of loneliness, love, and family. In addition to the Little Bear series, Minarik also wrote and illustrated the Sam and the Firefly books, as well as several stand-alone stories. Her works have been widely praised for their accessibility to young readers and their ability to capture the wonder and innocence of childhood. Minarik's works have been the subject of numerous exhibitions and retrospectives, and her works are held in many permanent collections. Her works have been used in educational programs and have been the basis for plays, television shows, and other media.

Outland ( Spear of Destiny album) Outland is the tenth studio album by Spear of Destiny, released in 2002 (see 2002 in music). A limited edition bonus live disc, Live then and Live now, was recorded at the band's 25th anniversary concert at the London Shepherd's Bush Empire on 29 October 2002. All the songs on the album are written by Kirk Brandon, with the exception of "The World's on Fire", which is written by his brother, James. The album was dedicated to the memory of their mother, Joan, who died in August 2002. The track "Lonely Planet (She's So High)" was featured in the soundtrack of the video game Midnight Club 3: DUB Edition, and was also the theme song for the film Outkast. The track "The World's on Fire" was featured in the soundtrack of the video game The Getaway: Black Monday. "Exodus" was featured in the soundtrack of the video game Forza Horizon 2. "The World's on Fire" was also featured in the soundtrack of the video game Grand Theft Auto V. April Fools' Day (1954 film) April Fools' Day is a 1954 American comedy film starring Jack Lemon, directed by James H.Pollack, and written by Theodore F.Liebler and Arthur T.Hagmann. It was produced by George T.Goodman for Paramount Pictures. The film also features Barbara Nichols, Lee Patrick, and Ray Walston. The film is based on the 1953 novel by Hal Southwell, The Longest Night, which was a rewrite of his own novel, The Whirlwind. Southwell's novel was in turn based on a real-life news story that he had heard about, about a man who escaped from a mental institution on April 1. The film was shot in Paramount's own studio in Los Angeles. The film's art director was Hal Perdoner. The film was released in April 1954. The film was entered into the 1955 Cannes Film Festival. The film was remade in 2008, starring Michael Douglas and Ashton Kutcher. Plot On April 1, a man is shot while running across a field. Hestaggers into a police station and dies. The police initially assume it was an accident, but the man's brother, Fred Amiel, insists that it was murder, and that the killer is "collecting signatures". Amiel's brother was the latest in a series of recent deaths, all of which were apparently accidental, but all of which had a similar MO. In each case, the "victim" was running, and was shot in the back. The police, led by Captain Moxley, are skeptical of Amiel's claim, especially after he produces a list of future victims, with April 1, 1954, being the next date on the list. As a result, the police set out to find the killer before he can strike again. In the process, they discover a pattern: all of the victims were involved in a car accident, and all of them had recently visited a certain garage. The police suspect the owner of the garage, a man named Harbin, but he proves to be a dead end. Still, the police feel that they are getting closer to the truth, and they increase their surveillance of potential victims. One of these victims is a woman named Julie, who lives with her roommate, Thelma. The police stake out the apartment, and manage to catch the killer in the act of making his escape. It turns out that the "killer" was Thelma, who had been trying to make Julie's life more interesting. It is then revealed that Fred Amiel was the killer, and that the entire story was an April Fools' joke. The real killer, a man named Reynolds, was accidentally shot by Amiel during a struggle. Reynolds, who was dressed as a police officer at the time, was trying to frame Amiel. Amiel is taken to the police station, where he confesses to the murders. However, as he is being taken to the jail, he escapes and runs across a field. He is shot in the back and killed by one of the police officers.
