Francesco Ardizzone (27 July 1927 – 22 May 2016) was an Italian singer, actor, and television personality, mainly known for his participation in the Sanremo Music Festival, where he was awarded the Silver Lion in the 1964 competition, together with his partner Luciana Gilli. Born in Naples, Ardizzone started his career in the late 1940s, as a singer of folk music and Neapolitan songs. In 1951 he made his television debut, and in 1954 he took part in the first Sanremo Music Festival, coming third with the song "L'acqua liva". After winning the Festival of Naples with the song "Pëndola" in 1955, he had his major success in the Sanremo Music Festival of 1964, with the song "Quando, quando, quando", which won first prize. In 1961, Ardizzone started a partnership with Gilli, which lasted for ten years and produced numerous songs and several albums. They also took part together in several editions of the Sanremo Music Festival, ranking third in 1962 with the song "Cosa sono le nuvole", and winning in 1964 with "Quando, quando, quando". They also won the Sanremo critics prize with the song "In viaggio con te". In the early 1970s, Ardizzone started a successful television career, as a regular guest in several variety shows. In the 1980s, he hosted the show Domenica In, and in the 1990s he hosted the shows La Domenica del Corallo and Cerca di casa. In 1991 he also hosted the Sanremo Music Festival.

Jim Jamieson (born February 8, 1945) is an American politician who served as a member of the Washington State Senate, representing the 44th district from 2013 to 2021. A member of the Republican Party, he was previously a member from 2005 to 2013, representing the 40th district. Jamieson was born in Portland, Oregon. He attended Seattle University, where he studied political science. In 1998, Jamieson was elected to the Snohomish County Council, representing District 5. He served as council chairman in 2002. In 2004, Jamieson was elected to the Washington State Senate, representing the 40th district. He was appointed to the Appropriations Committee and the Financial Institutions, Insurance and Consumer Protection Committee. In 2010, Jamieson was re-elected to the State Senate, defeating Democratic candidate Mike Sather by 17,300 votes to 9,300. In 2012, Jamieson was redistricted to the 44th district, where he ran against Democrat incumbent Rosemary McAuliffe. He defeated McAuliffe by 3,240 votes to 2,860. In 2016, Jamieson was re-elected to the State Senate, defeating Democratic candidate Eric Martin by 4,620 votes to 2,560. In 2020, Jamieson was not re-elected to the State Senate, having been defeated by Democratic candidate Emily Randall by 3,330 votes to 2,560.

Greenland Township is a civil township of Livingston County, Michigan, United States. The population was 2,232 at the 2010 census. The township was organized in 1834. It was named after Greenland, New Hampshire, the native home of a large share of the township's first settlers. According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 36.4 square miles (94.4 km2), of which 36.1 square miles (93.4 km2) is land and 0.26 square miles (0.67 km2) is water. The Livingston Trail, a paved bicycle and pedestrian path, passes through the township. As of the census of 2000, there were 2,458 people, 894 households, and 781 families residing in the township. The population density was 66.1 per square mile (25.5/km2). There were 1,017 housing units at an average density of 27.6 per square mile (10.7/km2). The racial makeup of the township was 98.07% White, 0.49% African American, 0.24% Native American, 0.34% Asian, 0.49% from other races, and 1.01% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.23% of the population. There were 894 households, out of which 35.9% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 79.1% were married couples living together, 3.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 17.6% were non-families. 14.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 5.4% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.75 and the average family size was 2.99. In the township, the population was spread out, with 23.4% under the age of 18, 5.5% from 18 to 24, 29.2% from 25 to 44, 28.4% from 45 to 64, and 9.6% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 106.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 111.8 males. As of 2000 the median income for a household in the township was $65,000, and the median income for a family was $71,59999. Men had a median income of $40, Cascade Charter Township, Michigan. Women who worked had a median income of $30,000. The per capita income for the township was $26,352. About 1.9% of families and 3.9% of the population were below the poverty line, including 2.6% of those under age 18 and 5.7% of those age 65 or over.

North Korea–Somalia relations North Korea and Somalia established diplomatic relations in 1977. In the late 1970s and early 1980s, North Korea began building a relationship with the Barre regime in Somalia, and offered the country military and technical assistance, including the training of security forces and the building of a fish-processing plant. North Korea also agreed to help Somalia build a nuclear power plant, but the project was never realized. In the early 1990s, after the end of the Cold War, North Korea began to look for new allies, and the country developed a relationship with the newly independent government of Somalia. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, the relationship between the two countries deteriorated, and in 2006, North Korea closed its embassy in Somalia. In recent years, North Korea has been accused of providing military assistance to the Somali militant group Al-Shabaab, including the supply of weapons and ammunition. In 2013, the United Nations Security Council imposed sanctions on North Korea for its continued nuclear weapons program, and in 2016, the country was accused of exporting ballistic missiles to Somalia. In 2017, North Korea and Somalia agreed to restore diplomatic relations, and in 2018, the two countries re-established their embassies in each other's capital cities. In 2019, North Korea and Somalia signed a bilateral agreement to cooperate in the fields of culture, education, science and technology, and sports.

SMS Deutschland (1914) SMS Deutschland was the second dreadnought battleship of the German Kaiserliche Marine. She was named after the German Nation (Deutsche Reich), in accordance with the German tradition of naming dreadnoughts after important regions and cities of Germany. SMS Deutschland was laid down at the Kaiserliche Werft shipyard in Kiel in the summer of 1913, launched on 18 June 1914, and commissioned into the High Seas Fleet on 15 October 1915. She was armed with ten 30.5 cm SK L/50 naval guns in five twin gun turrets, and could steam at a top speed of 21.8 knots. The ship had a crew of 1,458 officers and enlisted men. Deutschland served in the Battle of Dogger Bank in January 1915, and then in Operation Albion in October 1917, during which she provided naval gunfire support to German forces operating in Russia. She also saw significant action in Operation Michael, and in the Second Battle of Heligoland Bight in 1917. She was assigned to the task force assigned to Operation Sea Lion in 1940, though the operation was canceled. She spent the rest of the war serving in a variety of roles, including as a prison ship. Deutschland was sunk as a target ship by American heavy bombers in 1946. Deutschland was the second of five German dreadnoughts to be sunk by the Royal Air Force and the Royal Navy during the Second World War, after the sinking of the in September 1939, and before the sinking of the in December 1944.

Saeb N. Jaroudi (born December 31, 1944) is a Syrian-born American engineer, businessman, and philanthropist. Jaroudi was born in Damascus, Syria. He was educated at the Syrian University, where he received a bachelor of science degree in civil engineering in 1968. He came to the United States in 1971 to pursue a master of science degree in structural engineering at the University of Texas at Austin. He received a master of science degree in civil engineering in 1973. After graduation, Jaroudi moved to Houston, Texas to work for Bechtel Corporation. In 1974, he joined the structural engineering firm PBK Architects. In 1975, he was named vice president of the firm. He became a partner in the firm in 1976. In 1985, he was named president of the firm. He became the firm's chief executive officer in 1989. In 2001, he was named chairman of the firm. In addition to his work at PBK Architects, Jaroudi is also active in a variety of other professional and philanthropic endeavors. He is a member of the American Society of Civil Engineers, the Texas Society of Professional Engineers, and the Houston Society of Civil Engineers. He is a board member of the Greater Houston Partnership. He is a member of the Dean's Advisory Council at the Cockrell School of Engineering at the University of Texas at Austin. He is a member of the advisory board of the Center for Transport Policy at Rice University. He is a member of the Houston Chapter of the Young Presidents' Organization. Jaroudi is a former member of the Board of Trustees of the American University of Beirut. He is a former member of the Board of Trustees of the American University in Cairo. He is a former member of the Board of Trustees of the Syrian American Medical Society. In 2006, Jaroudi was named a "Distinguished Graduate" by the University of Texas at Austin. In 2012, Jaroudi was named a "Top 25 Newsmaker" by Engineering News-Record.

Macbett is a play by the 20th-century Scottish poet and playwright Robert MacBride. The play is an adaptation of Shakespeare's Macbeth set in the context of the Northern Irish Troubles. The play was first performed at the Neptune Theatre, Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, in January 1973, with Donal Donnelly in the title role. The play was published in 1975, and a revised edition was published in 1990. Macbett is set in a police state in Northern Ireland, with the police (the " Macs" ) dominated by the military (the " Batts" ). The play opens with the Prime Minister, Henry Faith, and the Minister of Defence, Charles Kinch, discussing the political situation. The " Macs" are meeting in a Protestant church, and the " Batts" in a Catholic church. The two police forces are preparing for a major confrontation with each other, a "showdown", as the play calls it. The " Macs" are planning to attack the " Batts", and the " Batts" are planning a " preemptive strike" against the " Macs". The play then shifts to an outdoor meeting between the two forces, in an attempt to defuse the situation. The meeting does not go well, and the " Macs" and the " Batts" begin to argue with each other. The " Macs" demand that the " Batts" surrender, and the " Batts" refuse. The " Macs" then attack the " Batts", and the " Batts" counter-attack. A major battle ensues, with many casualties on both sides. After the battle, the " Macs" and the " Batts" meet again to discuss the situation. The " Macs" demand that the " Batts" surrender, and the " Batts" again refuse. The " Macs" then attack the " Batts" again, and the " Batts" counter-attack. Another major battle ensues, with many more casualties on both sides. At the end of the play, the " Macs" and the " Batts" have destroyed each other, and the play ends with the two forces in a mutually destructive stalemate.

Alpha Rho Upsilon (ΑΡΥ) is a men's fraternity at Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island, founded on December 16, 1913. It is the third-oldest active fraternity at Brown, and the oldest continuously active fraternity on campus. The fraternity's mascot is the Griffin, and its colors are maize and navy blue. Alpha Rho Upsilon was founded by twelve students who wanted to create a fraternity in which they could live and study together. The founding members were Robert Delano Whipple, Ernest Stillman Pond, Arthur Farrand Dawe, Thomas Stockbridge Howard, Norman Bel Geddes, Roger Newel Brown, William Edward Breck, Charles Duell Jr., Hugh Dana, and Richard S. Field. The fraternity's activities were at first limited to its members and their friends, but it soon began to admit new members. The fraternity's first house was located at 135 Benefit Street, but it moved to a house at 99 Brook Street in the College Hill neighborhood in 1921. In 1925, it moved to a house at 86 College Street, and in 1948 it moved back to 99 Brook Street, where it remained until 1968. The fraternity then moved to its present house at 250 Brook Street, where it has remained since. In 1940, Alpha Rho Upsilon became the first fraternity at Brown to admit African-American students as members. In 1969, it became the first fraternity at Brown to admit women as members. The fraternity's alumni include two Rhodes Scholars, two Marshall Scholars, three Luce Scholars, three Rotary Scholars, one Truman Scholar, two Goldwater Scholars, two Udall Scholars, one Coca-Cola Scholar, one NCAA Division I athlete, and one professional athlete. Alpha Rho Upsilon is a member of the North-American Interfraternity Conference, and is listed on the NIC's Continuous Membership List.

Nancy Nolan (14 November 1898 – 11 August 1992) was an Australian actress, known for her work on the stage, screen, and radio. She began her acting career in the mid-1920s, and by the 1930s was a prominent actress in plays and musicals, and on film and radio. She had a long career in theatre and film, and is best known for playing the mother of Chips Rafferty in the film The Overlanders (1946). Nolan was born in 1898 in Carlton, Victoria. Her parents, John Nolan and Delia (née Finucane), were both vaudeville performers, and she spent her early childhood in South Australia, where her father was a comedian and her mother a singer. The family returned to Melbourne in 1908, and she was educated at the Loreto convent in East Melbourne and at the Melbourne Girls' Grammar School. In her mid-teens, Nolan joined her parents' vaudeville act, The Nolandas, as a singer and dancer. She was soon touring Australia and New Zealand with the act, which also included her two elder brothers, Jack and Pat. The Nolandas specialised in Irish comedy, with songs and dances, and the four Nolan siblings played a variety of characters, including a drunk, a washerwoman, and a family of four. They toured with the act for almost a decade, and also performed separately. In the early 1920s, Nolan began acting in plays, and by the end of the decade was a prominent actress in plays and musicals, and on film and radio. In 1925, Nolan played the lead role of the Madonna in the Melbourne production of the religious drama The Silver Wedding. The production was a great success, touring Australia and New Zealand for two years, and Nolan received praise for her performance. She also toured with the play The House of Glass, playing the lead role of Lavinia. In 1928, she starred in the play The Trial of Mary Duggan, which toured Australia and New Zealand, and she also toured with the play Old Man Die Hard. In the early 1930s, Nolan was a star of the silent film era, and also worked in radio. She played the lead role in the film The Man in the Iron Mask, and also appeared in the films The Magic Shoes and The Old Man's Boy. In radio, she was a regular performer on the program Yes, What? with Jack Davey. She also played the lead role in the radio drama The Lawsons, and was a regular performer on the program The Blue Hills. In the mid-1930s, Nolan turned to the stage, and spent several years in the UK. She played the lead role in the London production of the play Windmill in the Willows, and also toured with the play. In 1937, she returned to Australia and played the lead role in the Melbourne production of the play To-Day the World. In 1938, she appeared in the musical revue Sing for Your Supper, and in 1939 she played the lead role in the play The Man in the Box. During the 1940s, Nolan played supporting roles in a number of films, including The Hardy's, The Overlanders, and The Glenrowan Affair. She also appeared in the radio programs Blue Hills and The Lawsons. In 1946, she played the role of Mrs. Macarthur in the film The Overlanders, which was based on the story by Ion Idriess. The film was a great success, and is considered a classic of Australian cinema. In the 1950s, Nolan appeared in the television drama series Emergency. She also played the role of the mother of Chips Rafferty in the film The Sundowners, and the role of Mrs. Macarthur in the film The Glenrowan Affair. In the 1960s, she appeared in the television drama series The Story of Peter Grey, and in the 1970s she appeared in the television drama series Matlock Police.

Hardy Trophy The Hardy Trophy is an annual award and challenge cup for the sport of bowls, contested between men's teams from England and Scotland. The trophy was presented to the English Bowling Association by Sir Henry Hardy, the chairman of Attica Engineering, in 1946. The trophy is contested annually by English and Scottish bowls associations, each association selecting a men's team of eight players to compete in the final. The match is usually played in June, on a date and venue agreed by both associations. The venue is usually one of the clubs in the area of the current holder. The trophy is unique in that it is the only competition of its kind, involving players from the two oldest bowls playing nations, to be contested on an annual basis. The English Bowling Association and Scottish Bowling Association are the governing bodies for the sport of bowls in their respective countries. The current holders are England, who defeated Scotland 7-6 on 2 June 2012 at the Beachcomberholme BC, in Cleethorpes, Lincolnshire. The score after nine ends was 4-4, but England won the match by winning the last three ends, for a final score of 7-6. David Paul was the England captain, with David Gordon the skip. The Scottish team was skipped by George Sneddon. The highest score ever achieved in a final was in the first competition in 1946, when England beat Scotland 10-2.

Carl von Garaguly was a Hungarian-born Austrian-German graphic artist and painter who lived in Berlin for most of his life. He was a teacher at the Berliner Hochschule für Grafik und Buchkunst (The Berlin College of Graphics and Book Art) from its foundation in 1927 until his death in 1938. Garaguly was born in Budapest, Hungary in 1880. He studied art at the Hungarian National School of Arts in Budapest. In 1901 he was awarded a state scholarship to study in Germany, and he attended the Kunstakademie in Munich, where he studied under Paul Klendl and Ludwig von Herterich. In 1906 he moved to Berlin and studied under Heymann Steib at the Königliche Kunstakademie (The Royal College of Art) in Berlin. In 1908 Garaguly was one of the founding members of the Berliner Secession. He was also a member of the Deutscher Werkbund and the Novembergruppe. He exhibited widely, including at the Venice Biennale (1914 and 1916), the Berlin Secession, the Great Berlin Art Exhibition, the Munich Glaspalast, and the Deutsche Werkbundausstellung in Cologne. Garaguly's work was strongly influenced by the art of the Old Masters, particularly that of the Italian Renaissance. He sought to combine traditional techniques and motifs with modern ideas and materials. This can be seen in his prints, where he often used modern techniques such as photomechanics to create images that were both modern and traditional in their appearance. In his paintings, Garaguly often used traditional materials such as tempera and gold leaf, but he also incorporated modern elements, such as the use of industrial materials and the depiction of urban scenes. Garaguly was a teacher at the Berliner Hochschule für Grafik und Buchkunst (The Berlin College of Graphics and Book Art) from its foundation in 1927 until his death in 1938. He was a member of the faculty of the college's Department of Book Arts, and he taught courses in graphic design, illustration, and painting.

Future Worlds is a series of five science fiction novels by American writer James Morrow. The series is sometimes called the "Cain series" after its protagonist, Nobel laureate and director of thesecret think tank Covert Operations and Research Bureau (COMARB), John Spacebean. The series comprises five novels: The Last Trumpet (1998), The Second Coming (1999), The Missing Links (2000), Antidote (2001), and The End (2002). The Last Trumpet The Last Trumpet is a 1998 science fiction novel by American writer James Morrow. It is the first novel in the Future Worlds series, sometimes called the "Cain series" after its protagonist, John Spacebean. The Last Trumpet is a hard science fiction novel. The point of view is first person, limited to the character John Spacebean. The plot follows Spacebean's efforts to deal with the moral and political problems of the end of the world. The story is divided into three sections, each of which describes a different attempt by Spacebean to stop the world's end. The three sections are set in the years 2029, 2032, and 2039. In the first section, set in 2029, Spacebean discovers that a scientist at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, Vera Merfield, has created a vast, invisible, inaudible, and completely impenetrable shield around the Earth. She is working for an unknown employer and has been for the past five years. The shield has a diameter of twenty-one miles and is positioned seven miles above the surface of the Earth. In the second section, set in 2032, Spacebean discovers that the shield is actually a Dyson Sphere, a huge, artificial habitat for the entire population of Earth. The habitat is being constructed by the aliens from the planet Gliese 832c, who are using the Earth as a quarry for the materials to build it. In the third section, set in 2039, Spacebean discovers that the shield is a time field, which is being used to move the Earth from the present into the far future, where the planet's climate has been stabilized and the human race has been genetically engineered to survive in the new environment. The time field is being controlled by the robots from the planet Europa. The Second Coming The Second Coming is a 1999 science fiction novel by American writer James Morrow. It is the second novel in the Future Worlds series, sometimes called the "Cain series" after its protagonist, John Spacebean. The Second Coming is a hard science fiction novel. The point of view is first person, limited to the character John Spacebean. The plot follows Spacebean's efforts to deal with the moral and political problems of the Second Coming of Christ and the end of the world. Spacebean is able to contact Jesus and negotiate a one-year delay in the end of the world. It is the third novel in the Future Worlds series, sometimes called the "Cain series" after its protagonist, John Spacebean. The Missing Links is a hard science fiction novel. The point of view is first person, limited to the character John Spacebean. The plot follows Spacebean's efforts to deal with the moral and political problems of the discovery of the missing links in the evolutionary chain. List of members of the 12th National Assembly of Pakistan The 12th National Assembly of Pakistan was the second largest Parliament in the history of Pakistan in terms of membership. The 12th National Assembly was elected on 16 November 2002, in the first general elections after the 2001 Pakistani coup d'état. In the 12th National Assembly, the Pakistan Muslim League (Q) led by Chaudhry Shujaat Hussain formed the government, in coalition with the Pakistan Peoples Party ( enactment of the 17th Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan, which had been passed by the 11th National Assembly, had made this possible). The 12th National Assembly was dissolved on 15 November 2007, after the completion of its 5-year term. The National Assembly is the lower house of the Parliament of Pakistan, where the members are elected by the people. The membership is on the basis of territorial representation, with each member elected from a specific constituency. The 12th National Assembly had 342 members, of which 60 were women and 3 were non-Muslims. ## Members of the 12th National Assembly of Pakistan | | Party | Name | Notes | Ref | | --

Gramicidin B is a 16-residue beta-lactamase peptide isolated from the bacteria Bacillus brevis. It is a potent and specific inhibitor of the beta-lactamases of the penicillin-binding protein (PBP) family, especially those from Bacillus species. Gramicidin B is a cationic peptide with an elaiose-like macrocycle and an acetylated N-terminus. It is a trans-membrane peptide with the N-terminus on the exterior and the C-terminus on the interior. The N-terminus is acetylated with a fatty acid, which is required for its activity. The antimicrobial activity of gramicidin B results from the specific inhibition of penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), the bacterial enzymes that hydrolyze the beta-lactam ring of penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics. The binding of gramicidin B to PBPs is mediated by the C-terminal region of gramicidin B, which is responsible for beta-lactamase inhibition, and the N-terminal region, which is responsible for PBP binding. Gramicidin B is a member of the penicillin-binding protein (PBP) inhibitor family. Other members of this family include the beta-lactam antibiotics such as penicillin, ampicillin, and cephalexin, and the beta-lactamase inhibitors such as clavulanic acid and sulbactam.

1982 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team The 1982 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team represented the University of Notre Dame during the 1982 NCAA Division I-A football season. The team was coached by Gerry Faust and played its home games at Notre Dame Stadium in South Bend, Indiana. The Fighting Irish finished the regular season with a record of 10–2 and a No. 6 ranking in the final AP poll. They were invited to the Liberty Bowl, where they lost to the Pittsburgh Panthers by a score of 33–20. Notre Dame was led on offense by quarterback Pat Dillingham, who completed 135 of 291 passes for 1,679 yards and 10 touchdowns. Dillingham threw only five interceptions during the season. Running back Greg Bell led the team in rushing with 197 carries for 878 yards (4.2 yards per carry). Wide receiver Mark Jackson also had a big year, catching 40 passes for 684 yards and 5 touchdowns. On defense, the team was led by linebackers Michael Stonebreaker and Pat Dillingham, who both had 111 tackles during the season. The team's defensive backs were also effective, as they combined for 13 interceptions. The Fighting Irish started the year with three straight victories, including a 20–3 win over No. 8 Michigan and a 24–21 victory over No. 2 Penn State. After losing to No. 5 USC, they won five straight games, including a 20–3 victory over No. 10 Michigan State and a 24–21 win over No. 2 Penn State. However, they lost their final two games of the regular season, including a 17–10 loss to No. 6 Miami (Fla.) and a 10–9 loss to No. 20 SMU.

James Patrick Sweeney (born August 16, 1962) is a former American football offensive guard in the National Football League for the Los Angeles Rams and the Houston Oilers. He played college football at the University of California, Los Angeles and was drafted in the fourth round of the 1984 NFL Draft. Sweeney attended William S. Hart High School in Newhall, California, and was a four-year letterman in football, basketball, and baseball. Sweeney played college football at UCLA, where he started all 42 games in which he played from 1980 to 1983. He was a three-time All-Pacific-10 Conference selection, including a first-team choice in 1983 when he helped the Bruins to an 8–3–1 record and a No. 20 ranking in the final AP poll. Sweeney was selected by the Los Angeles Rams in the fourth round, 101st overall, of the 1984 NFL Draft. In his rookie season, he started all 16 games at right guard for a team that would win the NFC West Division title with an 11–5 record. The following year, he started 15 games, including the Rams' two playoff games, which they lost. In the 1986 season, he was moved to left guard and started all 16 games, including the Rams' 14–1 victory over the Dallas Cowboys in the NFC Championship Game and their 15–1 win over the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXI. He started all 16 games at left guard in the Rams' 12–4 season in 1987, and in 1988 he started all 15 games he played in, including the Rams' 28–0 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals in the Super Bowl. He was a member of the Rams' Fearsome Foursome defensive line, which also included defensive ends Bruce Smith and Reggie Doss and tackle Roger Brown. Sweeney played for the Houston Oilers in 1989 and 1990, starting all 32 games he played in. He retired after the 1990 season.

Cindy Shih is a Chinese-American actress. Shih was born in Taiwan. Her family moved to Arizona, United States when she was nine years old. After graduating from high school, she attended the University of California, Los Angeles. In 2004, Shih was cast as Cristina Yang on the ABC medical drama Grey's Anatomy. She made her first appearance in the series' first episode, "A Hard Day's Night", which was originally aired on March 27, 2005. Her character was written out in the third season's eighteenth episode, "Dying Breed", which was originally aired on December 13, 2007. In total, Shih appeared in eighty-one episodes. In September 2007, Shih was cast as Dr. Ellis West in the short-lived NBC comedy-drama series Life. In 2008, Shih appeared as a guest star in the third season of the USA Network police-procedural drama series Monk, in the episode "Mr. Monk and the Genius". In 2010, Shih was cast as Dr. Nina Kim in the short-lived ABC medical drama series Private Practice. She made her first appearance in the series' fourth season premiere, "A Family Practice", which was originally aired on September 25, 2008. Her character was written out in the sixth season's nineteenth episode, "The End of Time, the Start of Time", which was originally aired on January 27, 2010. In total, Shih appeared in forty-five episodes. In 2011, Shih appeared as a guest star in the first season of the USA Network police-procedural drama series Suits, in the episode "Bail Out". In 2013, Shih appeared as a guest star in the third season of the Fox comedy-drama series New Girl, in the episode "Fired Up". In 2013, Shih appeared as a guest star in the fifth season of the CBS police-procedural drama series Hawaii Five-0, in the episode "Ka Hakaka Maika'i". In 2014, Shih appeared as a guest star in the fifth season of the ABC sitcom Modern Family, in the episode "Auntie Biatch". In 2015, Shih appeared as a guest star in the first season of the Fox comedy series The Grinder, in the episode "The Break Up". In 2015, Shih appeared as a guest star in the seventh season of the CBS police-procedural drama series NCIS, in the episode "Viral". In 2016, Shih appeared as a guest star in the second season of the ABC sitcom Fresh off the Boat, in the episode "Shin Shin Shin SHIN!". In 2016, Shih appeared as a guest star in the first season of the ABC sitcom The Real O'Neals, in the episode "The Real Application". In 2018, Shih appeared as a guest star in the first season of the Netflix original series The Morning Show, in the episode "The Interview". In 2018, Shih appeared as a guest star in the fourth season of the ABC sitcom Fresh off the Boat, in the episode "Cousin Eddie". In 2019, Shih appeared as a guest star in the fifth season of the ABC sitcom Fresh off the Boat, in the episode "Three Kings".

Autopharmacology Autopharmacology is the study of the effects of drugs and other substances on the body when those substances are self-administered. The term is derived from the Greek prefix "auto" (self) and the Latin word "pharma" (drug). In this context, the term "self-administered" refers to substances that are not prescribed by a physician or other health professional, and substances that are not consumed for the purpose of maintaining or improving one's health. The term "autopharmacology" was coined in 1970 by the Hungarian-born psychologist Albert Michotte to describe the effects of self-administered substances in his book, The Psychology of the Other: An Empirical and Theoretical Study of Social Perception. In the book, Michotte proposed that people develop attitudes toward drugs and other substances that are a function of their perceived psychological effects. In the subsequent decades, autopharmacology has been studied by researchers from various disciplines, including psychology, medicine, and neuroscience. These researchers have investigated a range of topics, including the effects of self-administered substances on mood, cognitive functioning, and physiological processes, as well as the psychological and physiological mechanisms that underlie the effects of these substances. One key area of research in autopharmacology is the study of substance use disorders, which are characterized by the inability to control substance intake and the negative consequences of substance use. Researchers have investigated the neurobiological and psychological mechanisms that underlie substance use disorders, and have developed treatments and interventions to help individuals with these disorders manage their substance intake and improve their overall well-being. In addition to substance use disorders, autopharmacology research has also explored the effects of self-administered substances on various medical conditions, including pain, sleep, and mood disorders. Researchers have investigated the potential benefits and risks of using self-administered substances to manage these conditions, and have sought to understand the underlying mechanisms that may contribute to the effects of these substances. Overall, autopharmacology is a complex and multidisciplinary field that seeks to understand the effects of self-administered substances on the body and mind, as well as the psychological and physiological mechanisms that underlie these effects.

Arch Allies: Live at Riverport Arch Allies: Live at Riverport is a live album by American alternative rock band the Smashing Pumpkins, released on November 1, 2002, by Virgin Records. The album was recorded on August 18, 2002, at the Riverport Amphitheatre in St. Louis, Missouri, during the band's tour supporting their fourth album, Machines Like Us (2001). The performance featured a surprise reunion with the band's original members James Iha and D'arcy Wretzky, who had not played with the group since their original breakup in 1999. The album was originally released as a two-CD set, with the first disc containing the Smashing Pumpkins' set and the second featuring B-sides and rarities. The B-sides include "Drown", a song the band recorded for the film Spider-Man (2002); a cover version of the Cheap Trick song "Surrender", which was originally recorded for a tribute album; and an acoustic version of "Ava Adore", which was previously released as a B-side on the "Disarm" single. The rarities include a cover version of the Generation X song "Dancing with Yourself", which was previously released as a B-side on the "Ava Adore" single; and an acoustic version of the song "This Time of Year", which was recorded for the compilation album Prey for Rock & Roll. A single-disc version of the album, which omitted the B-sides and rarities, was also released. This version includes a live version of "Disarm", which was previously released as a B-side on the "Ava Adore" single, as a bonus track. The single-disc version of the album was re-released in 2005, with a different cover art and the bonus track "Ava Adore (Live)", a live version of the song which was recorded at the same concert as "Disarm". Arch Allies: Live at Riverport was generally well received by critics, and has been praised for its sound and the performance of the band's original members. The album was not as commercially successful as some of the band's previous albums, however, and as of July 2014 it had sold 86,000 copies in the United States, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The Williams–Landel–Ferry equation is an equation that describes the relationship between the rate of reaction and the length of a reaction. The equation was first described by Arnold Williams in 1925, George Landel in 1927, and further developed by R. T. Ferry in 1929. The equation is often written in an empirical form: where q is the reaction rate, Z is the length of a reaction, and α, β, and γ are constants. The equation is based on the idea that the rate of reaction can be affected by the length of a reaction. The length of a reaction is the time that a reaction has been occurring. The equation also takes into account the idea that the rate of reaction can increase or decrease over time. The constants α, β, and γ can be determined by fitting the equation to experimental data. The Williams–Landel–Ferry equation is often used to describe the kinetics of polymerization reactions. In this case, the rate of reaction is the rate of polymerization, and the length of the reaction is the time that the polymerization has been occurring. The equation can also be used to describe the kinetics of other types of reactions, such as the decomposition of a substance or the formation of a covalent bond. In some cases, the Williams–Landel–Ferry equation is used to describe the kinetics of a reaction in which the rate of reaction is affected by the length of the reaction. In other cases, the equation is used to describe the kinetics of a reaction in which the rate of reaction is not affected by the length of the reaction.

William Smith (loyalist) (January 17, 1756 – July 22, 1822) was a businessman, judge, politician, and statesman who helped found the state of Tennessee and signed the United States Constitution. Born in Elizabeth County, New Jersey, Smith attended the College of New Jersey (later Princeton) and graduated in 1774. He joined the Continental Army in 1775 and served as an officer in the New Jersey Line during the American Revolutionary War. He was taken prisoner by the British in the fall of 1776 and held in New York until he was paroled in June 1778. He rejoined the Continental Army in 1781 as a staff officer and served in that capacity until the close of the war. After the war, Smith moved to the newly established state of Tennessee and settled in Nashville, where he became a wealthy businessman and slaveholder. He was a member of the state constitutional convention in 1796, and he helped Tennessee become the 16th state in 1796. He also helped draft the constitution of the new state. In 1799, Smith was elected to the United States House of Representatives, where he served three terms. He was a member of the Federalist Party and an advocate of strong federal government. He also served as a state court judge and as a member of the Tennessee Supreme Court. In 1815, Smith was chosen by the Tennessee General Assembly to be one of the state's two United States Senators, along with Daniel Smith (no relation). The two senators served together from 1815 to 1821, when William Smith retired. He died the following year.

The 1969 Texas A&I Javelinas football team was an American football team that represented Texas A&I University (now known as Texas A&M University–Kingsville) as a member of the Lone Star Conference (LSC) during the 1969 NAIA football season. In its third season under head coach Ron Harms, the team compiled a perfect 11-0 record, won the Lone Star Conference (LSC) championship, and defeated Arizona State– Temperley, 27–7, in the NAIA National Championship Game. The team was led on offense by junior quarterback Ken Hastings, who was assisted by a strong running attack that featured Jimmy Raye and Bo Burris. The team's defense featured All-American defensive tackle Gary Adams, who led the NAIA in tackles with 151, and defensive end Roger Hair, who led the NAIA in sacks with 17. In addition to being the first NAIA football team to finish undefeated and untied since 1953, the 1969 Javelinas were the first team in school history to win a post-season football game. The team was ranked No. 1 in the NAIA's final regular season poll, and was also ranked No. 1 in the final NAIA playoff poll, ahead of No. 2 Arizona State– Temperley. The 1969 Javelinas were the first of three NAIA football teams to finish undefeated and untied during the 1960s. The others were the 1968 Texas A&I Javelinas and the 1970 Trinity Tigers.

History of the ambulance The earliest known use of the ambulance is found in the writings of the ancient Greek historian, Thucydides. He describes the use of "a cart with a lifting gangway" for the transport of the wounded from the field of battle in the year 420 BC. In the early Roman Empire, the Republic's army had a designated "Vehiculum Sacrum" or "sacred vehicle" for the transport of the dead and the wounded. The Roman army used horses and mules for the transport of the sick and the wounded. They also used oxen and slaves to pull the "Vehiculum Sacrum". The "Vehiculum Sacrum" was a common sight on the battlefields of the ancient world. In the medieval period, the church used the "Arca" or "box" to transport the relics of saints. The "Arca" was also used to transport the wounded. In the 16th century, the ambulance was used to transport the wounded from the battlefields of the Thirty Years' War. The first organized group of ambulance drivers was the "Holy Ghost Fathers" of the Society of Jesus, a Catholic order of priests. In the 18th century, the ambulance was used to transport the wounded from the battlefields of the French and Indian War and the American Revolutionary War. The ambulance was first used by the British military in the year 1804. In the year 1812, the United States Congress authorized the use of the ambulance for the military. In the 19th century, the ambulance was used to transport the wounded from the battlefields of the Napoleonic Wars, the American Civil War, the Franco-Prussian War, and the Russo-Turkish War. In the 20th century, the ambulance was used to transport the wounded from the battlefields of World War I and World War II. In the 21st century, the ambulance is used to transport the wounded from the scene of an accident or medical emergency to the hospital. The ambulance is also used to transport the sick and the wounded in non-emergency situations.

Fakhra Younus (Urdu: فخرا یونس) (born 26 July 1979) is a Pakistani woman who was badly burned in a fire following an acid attack on her in 2002. She was the first acid attack victim to file a criminal case in Pakistan and the first to do so successfully. Born in 1979 in Lahore, Pakistan, Younus was a student of Psychology at the Government College University, Lahore. On 24 June 2002, she was attacked with acid by her ex-husband, Abdul Hafeez, who was upset that she had left him. He had asked her to leave the house after Younus had accused him of harassment. The attack left her with severe burns on her face and body. After the attack, Younus was admitted to the burns ward of the Mayo Hospital in Lahore, where she received treatment for four months. Her family was unable to afford the cost of treatment, and the hospital did not have the facilities to treat such severe burns. She was then referred to the Shaukat Khanum Memorial Cancer Hospital and Research Centre, a charity hospital in Lahore, where she received treatment for free. In 2002, Younus filed a criminal case against her ex-husband in the court of law, becoming the first acid attack victim to do so in Pakistan. In the same year, she also filed a civil case against her attacker. Her ex-husband was convicted and sentenced to life in prison by the court. Younus was awarded compensation of Pakistan Rupee 500,000 (approximately US$5,000) by the court, as well as the costs of her medical treatment. She used the money to establish a rehabilitation centre for acid attack victims in Lahore. In 2006, Younus was given the Kennedy Center for International Delegations Award for her efforts in helping other acid attack victims in Pakistan. In 2009, she received the Martin Luther King Non-Violent Peace Prize. In 2010, she married a civil engineer, Muhammad Fayyaz, and the couple has two sons. In 2015, she was appointed as the first female honorary consul general of Poland in Lahore. In 2015, the Government of Pakistan awarded her with the Sitara-i-Imtiaz, the third highest civilian honour and decoration of the country, for her efforts in helping acid attack victims in Pakistan.

Julie Lescaut (born Julie Fradet, 9 March 1933) is a French actress. Born in Paris, Lescaut was raised in a family of artists, her father was a poet and her uncle, Paul Fradet, was a well-known painter and writer. She studied dance from the age of four, and later attended the Paris Conservatory where she studied music and drama. Her first stage role was as a student in the comedy La Règle du jeu (The Rule of the Game), and she went on to appear in many other stage productions, including an adaptation of Crime and Punishment. In the early 1950s, Lescaut began appearing in films, and in 1956 she was given the role of the adventurous Julie in the popular TV series Julie et le Californie. During the late 1950s and early 1960s, Lescaut's career reached its peak when she was one of the most popular and highest-paid actresses in France. She worked with many prominent directors, including Jean Renoir, Marcel Pagnol, Claude Autant-Lara, Julien Duvivier, and Jean-Luc Godard. She starred in many successful films, including Les Girls, The Green Glove, The Verdict, and The Unscrupulous Ones. Her career began to decline in the late 1960s, and she semi-retired from the screen by the mid-1970s. However, she has continued to perform on stage and has appeared in several films since then. In addition to her acting career, Lescaut is also a singer, and has recorded several albums.

Cello Sonata (Strauss) "Cello Sonata (Strauss)" is a sonata for solo cello and orchestra by the German composer Richard Strauss. The work, which was premiered in Berlin on 10 January 1897, is one of the few works by the composer that he himself did not conduct. The conductor on this occasion was Felix Weingartner, who also gave the work its title; the original German title was simply "Cello-Sonate". The work is dedicated to the cellist Robert Hausmann, who played the premiere. The work is in three movements, although the first two are played without a break. The first movement is in sonata form, with a lengthy polyphonic first subject and a short, scalar second subject. The development section is based on the first subject, and is followed by a recapitulation of both subjects, after which the movement concludes with a short coda. The second movement is in D minor, and is marked "Romanza: Sehr langsam". It is mainly made up of two sections, the first of which is marked "Das Thema" (the theme), and the second of which is marked "Das Motiv" (the motive). The movement concludes with a short coda. The third movement is a set of variations on a theme in F major, which is followed by a brief finale. The work has been recorded many times, with the most recent recordings being made in 2006 by Peter Bruns as part of a complete set ofStrauss's works for solo instrument and orchestra, and in 2013 by Daniel Barenboim with the Berlin Philharmonic. The critical reception to the work has been mixed. The most recent study of the work, by David Gutman in 2004, criticised the work for failing to take sufficient advantage of the particular characteristics of the cello as a musical instrument, and for being derivative of the style of the earlier German Romantic composers. The most frequently cited example of this is the opening theme of the first movement, which Gutman compares to the opening of Johannes Brahms's Piano Sonata No. 1 in the same key, and to the theme of the first movement of Brahms's Violin Concerto. On the other hand, the work's most recent performer, Daniel Barenboim, has said that the sonata is "a hidden treasure ... it is a wonderful piece, full of melodies and with a profound emotional content".

Mirgor is a malevolent god in Slavic mythology, depicted as a dragon or a half-humanoid, half-dragonoid creature. According to Czech folklore, Mirgor was the son of a devil and a she-dragon, and was himself born a dragon. He was said to be the enemy of all humanity, and to have a huge cavern where he would lick his wounds and hide from the sun. From his lair, Mirgor would send his servants, the Strzygli, to terrorize the countryside. Mirgor is depicted in art as a dragon with a human upper body, with long hair and a beard. He is often shown wearing a crown. In some legends, Mirgor is said to have had a daughter who was married to a human. The human eventually grew tired of life with the dragon, and killed her. In retaliation, Mirgor killed the groom and burned the bride's body. He then went to the village and demanded that the villagers pay him for the death of his daughter. If they did not pay, he would destroy their village and all who lived in it. Some sources say that Mirgor is the same entity as the Serbian dragon, Vyala.

Maurice Polydore Marie Bernadin de La Fize, better known by the pseudonym Maurice Maeterlinck (25 August 1862 – 7 October 1949), was a Belgian playwright, poet, and winner of the 1911 Nobel Prize in Literature. He was also a professor of French literature at the University of Ghent, a Belgian army officer, and a culture minister. Maeterlinck was born in Ghent, Belgium, the son of a printer and a housewife. He studied at the Ghent Municipal Technical School, and then at the Royal Military Academy in Brussels. He served for seven years in the Belgian army, reaching the rank of captain. After a short stint in the customs service, he studied literature and philosophy at the University of Ghent, where he earned a Doctor of Philosophy in 1891. His thesis, Le règne de Diderot, was published the following year. In 1892 he became a professor of French literature at the University of Ghent, and in 1895 he married the pianist and composer Lily el Korea (1871–1919). In his first important work, La Morale en Politique (1893), Maeterlinck attacked the Utilitarianism of Jeremy Bentham and the Egoism of Max Stirner. He argued instead for a return to the old Christian virtues. In a famous passage, he asserted that "God is dead, and we have killed him, we who have taken from him the rhyme and the measure." In the plays that made him famous, Maeterlinck depicted the fate of the individual in a world subject to natural forces beyond human control. The heroes of these plays are isolated figures in an indifferent universe, attempting to find their own way and to assert their own will in the face of hostile or uncertain forces. In the best known of these plays, L'Intruse (The Intruder, 1897), a maniacal murderer is on the loose. The hero's family is threatened, and the hero himself becomes obsessed by the idea that he may be the murderer. In the end, the murderer is revealed to be a neighbor, but the hero's own fear and doubt have destroyed his life. In the plays that followed, such as Les Aveugles (The Blind, 1898), La Mort de Tintagiles (The Death of Tintagiles, 1900), and Le Règne du Mal (The Kingdom of Evil, 1901), the author continued to explore the theme of the isolation of the individual. His characters seek to understand their place in the universe and to find meaning in their lives. In Le Règne du Mal especially, Maeterlinck seems to have been influenced by the philosophy of Friedrich Nietzsche, particularly by the idea that the world is divided into the forces of light and the forces of darkness, with the hero alone standing between the two. In the first decade of the 20th century, Maeterlinck's reputation as a dramatist was at its height. His plays were performed in the leading theaters of Europe and America, and he was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1911. His works of the period include La Gazelle (The Gazelle, 1900), La Source (The Source, 1901), Le Voyage d'Ulysse (The Voyage of Ulysses, 1904), and Intérieur ( Interiors, 1911). After World War I, during which he served as a culture minister in the Belgian government in exile, Maeterlinck's popularity began to wane. In the 1920s and 1930s he was largely ignored, though he continued to write until his death in 1949. In his later works, such as La Course du Fortune (The Way of the World, 1928), he seems to have been influenced by the Surrealists, with their emphasis on the subconscious and the dream world. Maeterlinck was awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature "in appreciation of his brilliant literary achievements, characterized as they are by a noble style, a deep moral insight, and a true patriotism."

The 2022 season was the San Francisco 49ers' 61st in the National Football League (NFL), their 76th overall, and their 11th and final under head coach Kyle Shanahan. The 49ers were attempting to improve upon their 7–10 record from 2021, which was the franchise's worst record since 2008. After starting the season with five consecutive wins, including a victory over the defending Super Bowl champions, the 49ers suffered a loss to the New York Giants in Week 6. This began a stretch where the 49ers lost four of their next five games, including a Week 10 loss to the Carolina Panthers that dropped them to 6–5. Despite the rough patch, the 49ers won four of their final six games to finish with a 10–8 record and secure a wild card spot in the playoffs. In the wild card game, the 49ers defeated the Philadelphia Eagles 13–10 to advance to the divisional round. However, they lost to the Dallas Cowboys 20–16 in the next game. After the season, Shanahan was fired as head coach, and the 49ers hired Mike McDaniel as his replacement. This was the 49ers' final season at Levi's Stadium, as the team will move to the new Snapdragon Stadium in Santa Clara in 2023. ## Offseason ### Coaching changes After the 49ers' 7–10 season in 2021, head coach Kyle Shanahan and the 49ers mutually agreed to part ways. The 49ers hired Mike McDaniel, the offensive coordinator of the Atlanta Falcons, as their new head coach. McDaniel was the 49ers' offensive coordinator from 2017 to 2018 under Shanahan. ### Free agency #### Unrestricted | Position | Date signed | Player | Contract | 2022 team | | --

Cruciate ligament, also called the cruciate tendon, is a ligament that crosses from one side of a joint to the other, in front of the other ligaments, and in front of the joint cavity. The term "cruciate" (from the Latin crux, cross) refers to the cross-shaped arrangement of the collagen fibers that make up the ligament. Collagen fibers are strong and flexible fibers that serve to bind together the cells of the connective tissue. The cruciate ligament is one of several ligaments that cross a joint. The other major ligaments that cross a joint are the collateral ligaments. There are two cruciate ligaments in the knee, the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and the posterior cruciate ligament (PCL). They are called cruciate ligaments because their collagen fibers form a cross shape. The cruciate ligaments are the primary ligaments that stabilize the knee joint. The ACL is located in the front part of the knee and the PCL is located in the back part of the knee. The ACL and PCL are both attached at the top to the thigh bone (femur) and at the bottom to the lower leg bone (tibia). The ACL and PCL work together to stabilize the knee and prevent the thigh bone and the lower leg bone from moving in opposite directions. This is important for the normal functioning of the knee. The cruciate ligaments are the most commonly injured ligaments in the knee. The ACL is most often injured when the knee is twisted or bent in a traumatic way. The PCL is most often injured when the knee is bent too far backward. When the cruciate ligaments are injured, the knee can become unstable and prone to further injury. In many cases, surgery is needed to reconstruct the cruciate ligaments and restore stability to the knee.

Deatsville, Alabama, is a town in Elmore County, Alabama, United States, and is included in the Montgomery Metropolitan Statistical Area. The population was 1,020 at the 2010 census. The community was named for the Deats family, who were early settlers in the area. The town was incorporated in 1927. Deatsville is located at 32°28′56″N 86°36′35″W (32.486529, -86.609797). According to the U.S. Census Bureau, the town has a total area of 3.7 square miles (9.6 km2), of which 3.66 square miles (9.5 km2) is land and 0.28 square miles (0.73 km2) (7.1%) is water. Deatsville is located on the southern border of Lake Jordan, a reservoir on the Tallapoosa River. As of the census of 2000, there were 1,153 people, 483 households, and 374 families residing in the town. The population density was 300.3 inhabitants per square mile (116.8/km2). There were 562 housing units at an average density of 148.5 per square mile (57.3/km2). The racial makeup of the town was 96.95% White, 2.81% Black or African American, 0.52% Native American, 0.26% Asian, 0.08% Pacific Islander, and 0.43% from two or more races. There were 483 households, out of which 28.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 63.6% were married couples living together, 9.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 23.8% were non-families. 20.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.48 and the average family size was 2.85. In the town, the population was spread out, with 18.9% under the age of 18, 8.1% from 18 to 24, 26.2% from 25 to 44, 28.6% from 45 to 64, and 16.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 41 years. For every 100 females, there were 99.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 98.4 males. As of 2015, the median income for a household in the town was $61,908, and the median income for a family was $69,444. Men had a median income of $41,103 versus $31,797 for women. The per capita income for the town was $23,818. About 3.9% of families and 6.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 8.3% of those under age 18 and 9.0% of those age 65 or over. The town is served by branches of the Montgomery Public Library System, including the Deatsville-Elmore Public Library, located at 5380 US Highway 231, and the Deatsville Public Library, located at 4780 US Highway 231. Deatsville is served by the Deatsville Volunteer Fire Department. The Deatsville area is served by two high schools, one in Deatsville and one in the nearby town of Eclectic. The town is home to the Deatsville Heritage Park & Museum, which includes the town's original train depot, a historic general store, a post office, a church, and a schoolhouse. The park also includes a walking trail, a picnic area, and a playground. Deatsville is the location of the Elmore County Fairgrounds and the annual Elmore County Fair. The state's only nuclear power plant, the Alabama Power Company's Joseph M. Farley Nuclear Plant, is located in the area, southwest of the town. The town is also home to the Deatsville Day Flea Market, held annually the first weekend of October. In the town, the population was spread out, with 18.9% under the age of 18, 8.1% from 18 to 24, 26.2% from 25 to 44, 28.6% from 45 to 64, and 16.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 41 years. For every 100 females, there were 99.6 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 98.4 males. Jean the Birdman Jean-Claude Romand, also known as Jean the Birdman (4 October 1942 – 15 May 1993), was a French serial killer, who between 1984 and 1989 killed at least seven women. He was dubbed "the Birdman" by the French press after he was arrested on 31 January 1989 after a neighbour heard his victims' birdsong-like screams. Romand was born in a French-speaking family in 1942 in a suburb of Lyon. He had a twin sister, Jacqueline. When he was six years old, his father, a businessman, died in a car accident. His mother never recovered from this tragedy, and the family fell into poverty. As a child, Romand was a lonely outcast, and often bullied. He became obsessed with birds, and spent much time watching them. His mother did not allow pets in the house, so he would catch birds and keep them in his room. He was also known for his extraordinary memory, which enabled him to learn the names of all his classmates. After finishing school, Romand studied medicine. In 1967, he married a fellow student, Michelle, with whom he had two daughters. The couple separated in 1981. In 1983, Romand began a relationship with a single mother, Anne, who had a young daughter, Blandine. In 1984, he began to serve as a doctor in a small town, Saint-Etienne-de-Saint-Geoirs, in the Rhône department. He was popular with patients, and known for his helpfulness. At the same time, he began to kill his lovers one by one. On 31 January 1989, Romand invited his latest lover, Catherine Gauthier, to his apartment in Lyon. As usual, he had taken care to make the surroundings pleasant, with flowers, wine, and music. He then attacked Gauthier, forcing her to drink a large quantity of alcohol and champagne. When she resisted, he choked her with his bare hands. Gauthier's bird, which she had brought with her, began to chirp. It had become accustomed to Romand's apartment, and was attracted to the food he had provided for it. The bird's chirping alerted Romand's neighbour, who telephoned the police. The police arrived and, after failing to gain entry to the apartment, summoned a locksmith. Meanwhile, Romand had left the apartment and was captured by the police in the early morning of 1 February. At his trial, Romand claimed he was innocent. He said that he had been framed by the police, who had altered the crime scene. He stated that Gauthier had been killed by a violent ex-boyfriend, and that he had only been trying to help her. The court did not believe his claims, and on 25 June 1992 he was sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of Gauthier, and given a minimum term of 25 years. In May 1993, a few days after his 41st birthday, Romand was found dead in his prison cell. He had committed suicide by hanging himself with his bed sheets.
