USA-201, also known as GPS IIR-1 and GPS SVN-36, is an American navigation satellite which forms part of the Global Positioning System. It was the first satellite to be launched in the GPS IIR series, and the first to be launched since the failure of USA-200 in December 2006. USA-201 was manufactured by Boeing, and is the twenty-seventh GPS satellite to be launched. The satellite has a mass of 2,000 kg, and is the first to be launched since the Block IIR specification was introduced. It is the first GPS satellite to be launched on a Delta IV carrier rocket, which was chosen because of its higher payload capacity compared to the Delta II used to launch earlier GPS satellites. The satellite is designed to replace the USA-127 satellite, which was launched in 2000. It was successfully launched at 22:41 UTC on May 31, 2007, from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. The launch was originally scheduled for December 2006, but was delayed because of problems with a Delta IV rocket used to launch a satellite for the National Reconnaissance Office. USA-201 is a Block IIR GPS satellite, and has a design life of 12 years. It has a single solar array, which powers the satellite's systems, and a single radio frequency transmitter, which is used to transmit radio signals to ground stations and to other GPS satellites. The satellite's navigation system is designed to be used by the military, and can be used to pinpoint the location of a user to within a few meters. It can also be used to provide information on the user's velocity and the time that they were at a particular location. The navigation system can be used by the military to pinpoint the location of a user to within a few meters, and can also be used to provide information on the user's velocity and the time that they were at a particular location.

Andrew van der Bijl (31 January 1889 – 29 June 1956), also known as Brother Andrew, was a Dutch Protestant religious leader and teacher who founded the Ecumenical Christian Church in England. van der Bijl was born in Eeklo, Belgium, to a Dutch father and a Belgian mother. He studied at the University of Groningen and the University of Leiden. In 1914 he obtained a degree in medicine, and in 1915 he qualified as a dentist. In 1916 he moved to England and set up a dental practice in London. In the early 1930s, van der Bijl became associated with a Christian group that was later to become the Ecumenical Christian Church. He was one of the group's leading members, and in 1938 he was appointed its general secretary. The Ecumenical Christian Church was officially established in 1942 and was characterized by its emphasis on the universal nature of the Christian church and the need for unity among Christians. It also placed an emphasis on the importance of the Bible and the value of the spiritual life. In the late 1940s, van der Bijl began to experience health problems and was forced to cut back on his activities. He died in 1956, at the age of 67, from lung cancer.

"Resistiré" is a song recorded by Argentine band Erreway from their second studio album Tiempo (2002). It was released in 2002 as the album's third single. The song was written by Gustavo Novello, Emmanuel del Real, Brian Keane, Martin Page and Chris Kimsey, while production was handled by the latter. The song was included on the band's compilation albums Erreway Presenta Toda la Música de su Tiempo (2003) and Erreway sin fin (2006). A Spanish language version of the song was also recorded, and was included on their first live album En Concierto (2005). The song was commercially successful in Latin America, reaching the top 20 in Argentina, Mexico and Spain. The song's music video was directed by Ash hower, and was nominated for Video of the Year at the 2003 Lo Nuestro Awards. A separate version of the video, featuring Spanish language lyrics, was also released. The song was covered by Spanish singer Chenoa, and her version was released as a single from her third studio album, Deseo (2004). Her version was produced by Kike Santander and recorded in Miami, Florida. The song's music video was directed by Spanish director and photographer Daniel Guzmán. This version was nominated for Video of the Year at the 2005 Lo Nuestro Awards. A second version of the song, performed by Spanish singer Melendi from his second studio album, Dejame Entrar (2004), was released as a single in 2004. This version was produced by Jed Cargas and recorded in Madrid, Spain. The song's music video was directed by Juan Luis Buñuel.

USS Tinsman (DE-589) was a United States Navy high-speed transport ship in service from 1944 to 1946. She was sunk as a target ship at the Tail of the Bank, off the Virginia coast, on 2 November 1958. Tinsman was laid down as a Maritime Commission type C3-S-A2 hull, MCV hull 120, on 20 October 1943 by the North Carolina Shipbuilding Company, Wilmington, North Carolina; launched on 11 November 1943; sponsored by Mrs. Howard Tinsman; and commissioned on 15 January 1944. Tinsman served with the Atlantic Fleet for several years. She made two trips from New York to Miami, Florida, in 1944, making a total of 15 round-trip voyages from New York to Mediterranean ports from January 1945 to June 1946. She was placed out of commission in service from June 1946 to February 1947, serving as a missile-firing ship for tests being conducted at the Naval Research Laboratory, Washington, D.C. She was placed in full commission again from February to October 1947, and from June 1948 to May 1949, serving again as a missile-firing ship. She was placed out of commission in service for the last time from May 1949 to December 1952, serving as a radar training ship. Tinsman was placed out of service in February 1954 and laid up in the James River Reserve Fleet. She was transferred to the custody of the Maryland State Police on 30 June 1956 for use as a revenue cutter. She was returned to the Navy on 1 July 1958 and assigned to the 5th Naval District for use as a target ship. Tinsman was sunk on 2 November 1958 by the USS O'donnell (DD- Bulloch, Georgia, on 2 November 1958.

Nelson Manuel Batista Preschool, Elementary and High School, better known as Nelson Batista or just Batista (Portuguese pronunciation: [ˈbeɾjɐ̃zɐ]), is a Brazilian school located in the city of Belo Horizonte, state of Minas Gerais. The school was founded in 1927 by Nelson Manuel Batista, a Brazilian physician, politician, and educationalist. It is one of the best-known schools in Brazil, with more than 2,500 students and a staff of more than 250 teachers. The school is noted for its excellence in teaching, and it has a strong focus on languages, science, and technology. The school is a private, non-profit institution, and it is governed by a board of directors composed of parents and teachers. The school is accredited by the Ministry of Education and it is a member of the National Association of Private Schools (ANES). The school has a strong focus on languages, and it offers courses in English, French, German, and Spanish. The school also offers a number of science and technology courses, including computer science, physics, and chemistry. The school has a strong sports program, and it offers a number of sports, including football, basketball, volleyball, and tennis. The school has a strong arts program, and it offers a number of arts courses, including music, dance, and visual arts.

Internorm is an Austrian company that produces doors, windows, and conservatories. The company was established in 1931 in Wiener Neustadt. In the early 1930s, the company's founder, Alois Internorm, recognised the need for affordable, high-quality window frames. He started a business in his parents' house, where he built window frames from timber. The growing demand for his products enabled him to expand the business throughout Austria and by 1938 the company had a workforce of over 250 employees. After the Second World War, the company began to manufacture doors and windows from aluminium. The company's products were used in the construction of the Vienna Hilton and the Austria Center Vienna. In the early 1960s, Internorm started to build windows from uPVC. In the 1980s, the company opened sales offices in Germany and Switzerland. In 2006, Internorm was taken over by the German window manufacturer Winkelmann. The following year, the Internorm brand was transferred to the newly established Internorm Holding, which is owned by Winkelmann and the German investment company Capvis. In 2013, Internorm opened a new production facility in Russia. In 2014, the company opened sales offices in the United States and China. In 2015, Internorm became the first window manufacturer to receive the "Made in Austria" certificate from the Austrian Federal Economic Chamber. In 2016, the company opened a new production facility in Hungary. In 2018, Internorm launched a new generation of windows and doors with an improved energy efficiency rating.

Un caso di coscienza Un caso di coscienza (A Case of Conscience) is a 1965 Italian science fiction film directed by Pietro Germi. It is based on the 1959 novel by Giovanni Ottati. A nuclear scientist (Italian: "una scienza nucleare" can also mean "a nuclear power plant" or "a nuclear reaction") who has developed a new, more efficient method of nuclear fusion, together with a friend, goes to the desert to test it. They discover a flying saucer in the desert, and the scientist, Mario, radios his findings to his colleague, Paolo. However, the military finds out about the discovery and, led by the anti-communist General Parken, closes in on the location in order to destroy the evidence. The aliens, who have been studying Earth and its inhabitants for a long time, take Mario back to their planet. There he meets two aliens, Morbius and his daughter Julia, who are the only two survivors of their race. Julia has been raised by Morbius since her birth, and has never seen another alien. As she is now of marriageable age, Morbius expects her to choose a husband from her race's superior specimens: the most advanced and intelligent of the species. As part of his plan to introduce Julia to "the best of the Earth", Morbius has taken samples of the most outstanding humans – including one of the greatest scientists, one of the most powerful politicians, and one of the most famous actors – to the planet. Julia is impressed by Mario, and chooses him as her husband. However, Mario, feeling guilty, wants to return to Earth. With the help of Morbius, he disguises himself as an alien and returns to the same spot in the desert where he was first picked up. General Parken and his troops arrive, but are unable to tell that he is a human, and take him to the military base. There, he discovers that the general's daughter has been born with a deformity: a large, hairy mole on her face. He offers to help the general by letting him use his method to create a new, perfect, non-human race, but the general refuses and shoots him. Un caso di coscienza was shown in Italy in 1965. It was released in the United States in 1967, where it was also known as The Case of the Sinful Doctor, with English dialogue added. It was shot at the Fellini Studios in Rome. The film was a minor financial success, but critical reception was mixed. In Italy, the film was generally considered a failure, although some critics praised the film's "elegant" and " expressive" use of colour. In the United States, the film was sometimes compared to Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey, which had been released two years earlier. Some critics considered the film "silly", while others said that it had "some of the most absurd situations ever conceived by man". The film has been described as an "Italianate" take on the alien invader genre, and as combining "elements of nuclear paranoia, A-bomb chic, and space opera" with "comedy, farce, and religious meditation". The film's " twist ending" has also been praised, as has the performance of Dominique Boschero.

LSU Indoor Practice Facility The LSU Indoor Practice Facility (IPF) is an indoor practice facility for the LSU Tigers football team. The IPF is located on the campus of Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. The IPF was built in response to the damage done to Tiger Stadium and the outdoor practice fields during Hurricane Katrina in 2005. The facility opened in January 2009 and is located adjacent to Tiger Stadium and the LSU Alex Box Baseball Stadium. The IPF is a climate-controlled, indoor practice facility that features a regulation-size football field and a 400-meter track. The facility has a seating capacity of 3,000 and is designed to host various LSU athletic events, as well as practices. The facility has played host to the Bayou Bengal Classic, an annual LSU versus Texas A&M game, since 2008. In 2008, the game was played in Houston, Texas due to the damage to Tiger Stadium from Hurricane Katrina. In 2009, the game was played at the IPF due to continued renovations to Tiger Stadium. The 2010 and 2011 Bayou Bengal Classic games were played at the IPF as well. In 2013, the facility was the site of the Texas Bowl, where the LSU Tigers defeated the Texas Longhorns, 37–17. In 2016, the facility was the site of the first and second rounds of the SEC Men's Basketball Tournament. The IPF is a regular practice facility for the LSU Tigers football team. The facility is also used for practices and events by the LSU Tigers track and field and LSU Tigers women's basketball teams.

Clientitis (from Greek κλειν, "client" and -itis, "disease") is an involuntary servitude to a client, in a broad sense. In the narrow sense, it is used to describe the sycophantic behavior of a professional towards a client. Clientitis is a major concern in the legal profession, where it may lead to conflicts of interest, but the term is used more generally to describe any such pattern of behavior. The term clientitis was coined by the German-American engineer and management consultant Robert H. Waterman, Jr. in his 1983 book, Up and Down the Organization: Lessons from the trenches for the working world. Waterman described clientitis as "the natural and inevitable result of a person's continued subjection to a one-sided relationship." Clientitis is often associated with professional services, such as law and accounting, where the service provider works on a one-to-one basis with the client. The professional becomes emotionally dependent on the client, and this dependence is typically reinforced by the fact that the professional's pay is dependent on the client's continued business. The professional becomes afraid to tell the client "no", and instead focuses on pleasing the client. The client, meanwhile, takes advantage of the professional's clientitis, and continues to demand more and more work, while paying less and less. Professional service providers can combat clientitis by establishing clear boundaries and rules at the beginning of the relationship, and enforcing them. Clientitis can also be combated by regularly reviewing the relationship and, if necessary, terminating the relationship. In some cases, a simple "no" is all that is necessary to stop clientitis in its tracks. In a larger sense, clientitis can be seen as a form of power dynamics, with the client holding power over the service provider. Clientitis can also be seen as a form of exploitation, with the client taking advantage of the service provider's dependence on them. In some cases, clientitis can lead to a toxic working environment, with the service provider feeling resentment towards the client. Clientitis can be combated by establishing clear boundaries and rules at the beginning of the relationship, and enforcing them. Clientitis can also be combated by regularly reviewing the relationship and, if necessary, terminating the relationship. In some cases, a simple "no" is all that is necessary to stop clientitis in its tracks.

Robert Gillespie (1637–1715) was an Irish Protestant minister and scholar, a prolific writer and a versatile, erudite, and innovative theologian. Gillespie was born in Dublin, the son of an Irish Protestant minister, and was educated at Trinity College Dublin (BA, 1661; MA, 1664), where he was a fellow from 1664 to 1674. He was ordained a minister in the Church of Ireland in 1667 and two years later became the incumbent of the parish of Newtownbarry in County Cork, where he ministered for the next forty years. Gillespie was married to Mary, the daughter of the Rev. Arthur Ussher, the Church of Ireland minister for the nearby parish of Carrigaline. They had four sons and three daughters, including the Rev. Arthur Gillespie (1676–1766), the Church of Ireland minister for the parish of Bandon and a noted scholar. In 1699, the Rev. John Stearne, the Church of Ireland minister for the parish of Midleton, was accused of heresy and suspended from his ministry. His parishioners, who were in a state of unrest because of a disputed election to the Irish House of Commons, organised a protest against his suspension. They invited Gillespie, who was widely recognised as a spokesman for the moderate, intellectual tendency in the Church of Ireland, to preach to them. He agreed and, in the resulting sermon, took the line that while the Church of Ireland was not a perfect church it was, nevertheless, a true church. The sermon was widely circulated and led to increased support for the moderate line, which was favoured by the established church's bishops, in preference to the more radical, Nonconformist tendency. Gillespie was a member of the Dublin Society, a group of Dublin-based scholars who met regularly to discuss intellectual and cultural topics. The members included the economist and lawyer William Bruce (1680–1730), the historians James Ware (1565–1666) and his son Sir James Ware (1682–1769), the archaeologist and physician William Batt (c.1620–1704), the classical scholar and Church of Ireland minister Charles Lucas (1694–1747), the statistician Edward Hopkins (1644–1741), the chemist Robert Boyle (1627–1704), and the politician and writer Edmund Curll (c.1675–1747). The Dublin Society's members were united by their intellectual curiosity and their desire for knowledge for its own sake, and they pursued a wide range of interests, including history, geography, the natural sciences, medicine, agriculture, and the arts. They were influential in a number of areas, including the development of Irish agriculture and the establishment of the Royal Dublin Society, which was granted a royal charter in 1731. Gillespie's most significant contribution to scholarship was his edition of the works of the Church of Ireland theologian and historian, Jeremy Taylor (1613–1667), which was published in four volumes in five parts between 1704 and 1707. This was the first critical edition of Taylor's works and the standard edition for the next century. It included an extensive commentary on the texts, which was written by Gillespie and by the Church of Ireland minister and scholar William Law (1686–1761). Gillespie also wrote a commentary on the Bible, which was published in 1710, and a series of sermons on the Church of England's Articles of Religion, which were published in 1713. In addition, he contributed articles on a range of topics to the Dublin Society's journal, the Transactions. Gillespie's works were widely read and highly influential. They were praised for their learning, their lucidity, and their ability to present complex ideas in an accessible manner. They were also noted for their ecumenism, which was informed by Gillespie's belief that the Church of Ireland was part of a larger Christian community that included both Catholics and Protestants.

Kero Kero Chime (ero ero chime, lit. 'ero ero time') is a Japanese expression for the time between 1:30 am and 2:00 am. The term "Kero Kero Chime" is derived from the Japanese kero (ケロ), meaning "hour" (as in "o'clock"), and chime (チャイム), the sound made by a clock. The minimum number of hours in a day in Japanese tradition is 24, and the time between 1:30 am and 2:00 am is the 30th hour of the day. The term "Kero Kero Chime" is mostly used by young people on internet forums and in manga and anime to refer to the time that one is not supposed to be awake. The time period from 1:30 am to 2:00 am is also called "The Dirty Thirty" in English. The Japanese phrase "ero ero time" became widely known to the English-speaking world after it was used in the anime Sword Art Online. In Sword Art Online, the term is used to refer to a period of time in which the Aincrad system will activate a boss-level AI at random. Most players refer to it as the "death zone", as almost all players who encounter a boss-level AI during this time period are killed immediately.

Young Avengers is a team of teenage superheroes in the Marvel Universe, appearing in comic books published by Marvel Comics. The team is composed of teenage versions of well-known superheroes, as well as several teenage superheroes who do not have adult versions. The Young Avengers were formed by Iron Lad, who was a teenage version of the adult superhero Iron Man. The team's adventures are featured in their own self-titled series, Young Avengers, as well as in The Avengers, New Avengers, and other Marvel comics. The Young Avengers are the teenage sidekicks of the adult Avengers, and work closely with their mentors. The team also has a close relationship with the similarly aged team of teenage X-Men, the New Mutants. The Young Avengers was the brainchild of writer Brian Michael Bendis, who created the team to increase the profile of the then-new teenage heroes. The Young Avengers first appeared in The Avengers #1 (May 1996), though the team was actually formed one issue earlier, in New Avengers #1 (April 1996), in which Iron Lad recruited the other team members. The Young Avengers then appeared in a four-issue self-titled limited series in 1998, written by Christopher Yost and drawn by Stephen Sadowski, and in an ongoing series, Young Avengers, which ran for 75 issues between 2005 and 2007, written by Bendis and drawn by Yost. The Young Avengers are featured in the animated series The Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes, in which they are shown as having a facility of their own, and in the live-action film Avengers: Infinity War, in which they are shown as having been inspired by the adult Avengers and as having built their own headquarters in a compound owned by Tony Stark.

Richard DeLong (born November 11, 1947) is an American politician who served as a member of the Washington House of Representatives, representing the 28th district from 2006 to 2014, and the Washington State Senate, representing the 28th district from 2014 to 2016. DeLong was born in Bremerton, Washington. He attended Olympic College and the University of Washington. He is a former teacher and school administrator. DeLong was first elected to the House in 2006, winning the primary election with 55 percent of the vote and the general election with 64 percent. He was re-elected in 2008 with 58 percent of the vote. In 2010, he was re-elected with 62 percent, winning the primary with 57 percent and the general election with 62 percent. In 2012, DeLong was elected to the state Senate, defeating incumbent Republican Sen. Jan Angel with 51 percent of the vote. In 2015, DeLong announced that he would not seek re-election to the state Senate, and instead run for Kitsap County Commissioner. He was elected in November 2016 and took office in January 2017.

Maryhill Estates is a neighborhood and former census-designated place (CDP) in Bullitt County, Kentucky, United States. The population was 1,227 at the 2010 census. It is part of the Louisville–Jefferson County–Elizabethtown Metropolitan Statistical Area. It is located off Interstate 65 at Exit 117, approximately 16 miles (26 km) south of downtown Louisville and 4 miles (6.4 km) north of Shepherdsville. The neighborhood consists of two sections: Maryhill Estates and Maryhill Springs. The zip code for the area is 40119. According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of 3.7 square miles (9.5 km2), of which 3.65 square miles (9.5 km2) is land and 0.04 square miles (0.10 km2) (1.0%) is water. As of the census of 2000, there were 1,312 people, 448 households, and 381 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 338.1 people per square mile (130.0/km2). There were 481 housing units at an average density of 124.2/sq mi (48.0/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 98.43% White, 0.15% African American, 0.08% Native American, 0.38% Asian, 0.08% Pacific Islander, 0.30% from other races, and 1.03% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.35% of the population. There were 448 households, out of which 38.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 70.3% were married couples living together, 7.5% had a female householder with no husband present, and 20.3% were non-families. 16.9% of all households were made up of individuals, and 6.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.83 and the average family size was 3.21. In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 25.6% under the age of 18, 8.1% from 18 to 24, 32.3% from 25 to 44, 22.8% from 45 to 64, and 10.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 35 years. For every 100 females, there were 103.2 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 104.4 males. As of 2000 the median income for a household in the CDP was $51,875, and the median income for a family was $60,000. Men had a median income of $36,184 versus $25,417 for women. The per capita income for the CDP was $20,x4. About 4.3% of families and 5.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 4.3% of those under age 18 and none of those age 65 or over.

MAGEA3 is a gene that in humans is located on chromosome X, at position Xp22.3, from base pair 75,901,232 to base pair 75,968,XT — 75,968,XT — 75,968,232. The Mage protein is a member of the MAGEA gene family, a group of highly homologous genes whose expression is primarily limited to cancer cells. The MAGEA genes are closely related to the gene family encoding the protein products of the MAGEA gene family, which are expressed in cancer cells and have a role in tumorigenesis. MAGEA3 is one of the five genes, including MAGEA1, MAGEA2, MAGEA4, and MAGEA5, whose expression is direct, or indirect, in tumor cells. The MAGEA gene family, including MAGEA3, has been highly conserved during evolution, and it is possible that these genes have important roles in the regulation of cell growth and division. In fact, several studies have shown that the expression of MAGEA genes is associated with tumorigenesis. The MAGEA3 gene is approximately 2.4 kb long and contains six exons and five introns. The predicted protein contains five domains (P-loop, Walker A, ATP-binding, magnesium-binding, and C-terminal) and one half-domain. The gene product contains a large N-terminal domain and a smaller C-terminal domain. The MAGEA3 protein is a component of the RNA polymerase II holoenzyme, which is involved in the transcription of DNA. The protein is also a component of the RNA polymerase II-FT complex, which is involved in the formation of the spliceosome. The RNA polymerase II holoenzyme is a large protein complex that contains at least 17 different proteins. The holoenzyme is responsible for the transcription of DNA into RNA. The MAGEA3 protein is one of the non-Rpb proteins that are involved in the formation of the holoenzyme. The MAGEA3 protein is also a component of the RNA polymerase II-FT complex, which is involved in the formation of the spliceosome. The spliceosome is a large protein complex that is responsible for the splicing of pre-mRNA. The spliceosome is formed by the association of several small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs), and it contains a variety of protein subunits. The MAGEA3 protein is one of the non-snRNP proteins that are involved in the formation of the spliceosome. The MAGEA3 protein has been shown to be expressed in a variety of cancer cells, including breast cancer, colorectal cancer, lung cancer, and prostate cancer. The protein has also been shown to be expressed in a variety of normal cells, including breast epithelial cells, colorectal epithelial cells, lung epithelial cells, and prostate epithelial cells. The expression of the MAGEA3 gene is regulated by a variety of factors, including transcription factors, hormones, and environmental cues. The expression of the MAGEA3 gene is also regulated by the activity of other genes, including the MAGEA1 gene, the MAGEA2 gene, the MAGEA4 gene, and the MAGEA5 gene.

Himmatsinhji M. K. was an Indian journalist, editor, and publisher, and the founder of the newspaper Daily Pioneer. He also served as the editor of the monthly magazine, India. Himmatsinhji was born in the year 1927 in Alves, a small town in the Portuguese colony of Diu, on the west coast of India. His father, M. K. Meghani, was a diamond merchant and a prominent citizen of the town. Himmatsinhji was educated at the local Portuguese school, where he learned Portuguese, before transferring to the English-language High School, where he was the editor of the school's magazine. After completing school, Himmatsinhji worked for a year in a bank, before joining the Times of India in Mumbai as a journalist. In 1952, he moved to the Financial Express, where he worked as a reporter for three years, before joining the Business Standard, a newly launched business newspaper, as its editor. In 1961, Himmatsinhji launched the Financial Times of India, a weekly business newspaper, and served as its editor for two years. In 1963, he launched the Daily Pioneer, a daily newspaper with a readership of over a million, which he edited and published for over forty years. In addition to his newspaper work, Himmatsinhji was also the editor of the monthly magazine, India, and the author of a book on the history of the newspaper industry in India, entitled Press and Politics: A Study of the Indian English Press (1969). He also served as a member of the governing body of the Indian Council of Agricultural Research and as a trustee of the Indian Agricultural Research Institute.

Nick Altrock Nicholas Franklin Altrock (March 30, 1889 – February 7, 1965) was an American Major League Baseball pitcher and coach. He played for the Washington Senators (1911–1914, 1916), Boston Red Sox (1915), New York Yankees (1917–1919), Boston Braves (1919–1920), St. Louis Browns (1921–1922), Chicago White Sox (1923), and Washington Senators (1925). Altrock was a native of Dallas, Texas. He attended Texas A&M University, where he played for the Texas A&M Aggies baseball team. He was a spitball pitcher, and one of the 17 pitchers allowed to continue throwing the spitball after it was banned in 1921. In 1912, he was the winning pitcher in the first game in which a pinch hitter appeared. The pinch hitter was Jack Lewis of the Boston Red Sox, and the Senators won 2–1 in 11 innings. He led the American League in wins (27) and innings pitched (336) in 1913. He also led the league in wins (24) in 1916. In six seasons as a major league coach (1926–1931, 1933), he worked for the Senators and the Yankees. Altrock died in a Dallas hospital at the age of 75 from complications following a stroke.

Australopithecus africanus is a species of the genus Australopithecus that lived from around 2.9 million years ago to around 2.3 million years ago. It is known from a single type specimen, discovered in a lime mine at Sterkfontein, South Africa, in the 1930s, as well as from other fossils found at the same site in the 1970s and 1990s. A. africanus is a possible ancestor of modern humans, as it is known to be bipedal and was once considered to be the first known species to have used stone tools (this is now known to have been done by the earlier species Homo habilis). It is also thought to be the first species to have used fire. The type specimen, known as StW 573, is a single, incomplete skeleton of a juvenile male. StW 573 was discovered in a chamber of the Sterkfontein caves in 1936 by Robert Broom and John T. Robinson, and was the first early hominid fossil to be discovered in South Africa. After its discovery, the species was originally described as a member of the genus Homo, and was named as Homo africanus by Robinson in 1944. However, it was later realised that the species was more similar to the genus of the original type specimen, Australopithecus, and was reclassified as such in 1946. Further research has shown that the species is likely to be intermediate between the bipedal but otherwise chimpanzee-like Australopithecus afarensis and the fully human genus Homo, and as such its name has been changed to Australopithecus africanis. A. africanus is thought to have been similar to A. afarensis in body size, but with a more compact and less elongated skull, and with the facial region less projecting and the brow region more vertical. The face is relatively flat, with large brow-ridges and large molar teeth. Postcranially, it is characterised by a long, barrel-shaped torso, short, robust arms, and a relatively long, low femur. Several other fossils from the same site have been found to be conspecific with the type specimen, including the 1995 discovery of a partial skeleton, StW 578, which was the first fossil to be found in the same chamber as the type specimen. The site of the find, in Chamber B of the Sterkfontein cave system, is considered to be a unique area for palaeontological research, as the caves have preserved many fragile fossils that would otherwise have been destroyed. A. africanus is thought to have lived between 2.9 million years ago and 2.3 million years ago. It was a contemporary of the species Homo habilis, and may have been its ancestor. It is also thought to be a possible ancestor of the species Homo rudolfensis, which lived around the same time in East Africa. A. africanus is thought to have been a scavenger, but possibly also a hunter, as it is known to have used stone tools. It is also thought to be the first known species to have used fire.

The Australasian treecreeper (Climacteris affinis) is a species of treecreeper in the genus Climacteris, in the family Pardalotidae. It is found in Australia and New Guinea. Its natural habitats are temperate forests and subtropical or tropical moist lowland forests. It is a small, brown, ground-dwelling bird. The adult has a length of 11 to 13 cm (4.3 to 5.1 in), a wing length of 6.5 to 8 cm (2.6 to 3.1 in) and a weight of 8 to 9 g (0.28 to 0.35 oz). The bill is dark grey, long and slender. The legs and feet are pale grey. The head is grey with a pale, white cheek patch. The upper body is dark chocolate brown to black, with the feathers having a slight gloss. The lower body is a lighter brown with a pale brown belly and white undertail coverts. The male and female are similar in appearance. The Australasian treecreeper is found in south-eastern Australia, from the Eyre Peninsula in South Australia to the New South Wales south coast, as well as in the Australian Capital Territory and the islands of Tasmania and Norfolk Island. It is also found in the lowlands of New Guinea. It is a common species and is listed as being of least concern by the IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. The Australasian treecreeper is found in forest and woodland, as well as parks and gardens, where it feeds on the ground on ants and other small invertebrates. It can be seen hopping quickly on the ground, pecking at the surface to disturb prey. It can also be seen climbing trees, using its tail for support. The species is solitary, although several may be seen together where their territories overlap. It is territorial, with pairs defending a territory of 1,000 to 2,000 m2 (11,000 sq ft) and engaging in displays to mark their territory. The Australasian treecreeper pairs with one partner for life. The nest is built by the female, and is a small, open cup made of twigs and lined with hair. It is usually located in the fork of a tree or in the corner of a building. The nest is sometimes reused in later years. Two or three eggs are laid, and are pale blue with brown spots. The eggs are incubated by the female for fourteen days, with the chicks being fed by both parents. The young birds leave the nest after fifteen days. The Australasian treecreeper is insectivorous, with ants making up a large part of the diet. It is sometimes known to take small fruits and seeds.

First Dates First Dates is a British reality dating show produced by Twenty Twenty Productions for Channel 4. The programme has been compared to the American dating show The Dating Game. The show has also been described as a "reverse Blind Date". The show was originally hosted by Daisy, Harry and Cilla Bachleda, a sibling trio who also hosted the similar show Three Dates. In 2018, the show was hosted by dating expert Emma Willis. The show has been broadcast on Channel 4 since November 2013, and is currently presented by 2017 Love Island winner Amber Davies. Swarthy-skinned Mediterranean men and women in their twenties, who have not been on a date for a long time, are picked up by a van and taken to a restaurant to meet a partner. The couple shares a meal and a conversation, and the men are then given the opportunity to ask the women out on a real date. In 2015, a spin-off series, First Dates Hotel, was launched, in which couples who have been on a successful first date go on a second date in a hotel. In 2016, the show was nominated for a National Television Award for the Factual Entertainment category, and in 2017, it won the award. In 2017, the show was nominated for the Most Popular Factual Show and the Most Popular Reality Show at the British Academy Television Awards, and in 2018, it won the British Academy Television Award for Best Factual Series. In 2018, the show won the National Television Award for the Factual Entertainment category for the second time, and in 2019, it won the award for the third time. In 2018, the show was nominated for the Most Popular Factual Show at the British Academy Television Awards, and in 2019, it won the British Academy Television Award for Best Factual Series. In 2019, the show was nominated for the National Television Award for the Factual Entertainment category, and in 2020, it won the award for the fourth time. In 2020, the show was nominated for the Most Popular Factual Show at the British Academy Television Awards, and in 2021, it won the British Academy Television Award for Best Factual Series. In 2021, the show was nominated for the National Television Award for the Factual Entertainment category, and in 2022, it won the award for the fifth time. In 2022, the show was nominated for the Most Popular Factual Show at the British Academy Television Awards, and in 2023, it won the British Academy Television Award for Best Factual Series. First Dates was the first show to be released on All 4 after its original broadcast.

TA-SWISS TA-SWISS is a high-tech company based in the canton of Ticino, Switzerland. It was founded in 1998 as a spin-off of the University of Della Svizzera Italiana (USI) in order to transfer technology from the laboratory to the market. The company has expertise in the fields of micro- and nanotechnologies, and it focuses on the development and production of micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) and micro-optical systems (MOEMS). The company's products include MEMS accelerometers and gyroscopes for inertial measurement units (IMUs) and inertial navigation systems (INSs), MEMS microphones, and MOEMS micro-mirrors for optical switches and scanners. TA-SWISS also provides contract research and development services in the field of MEMS and MOEMS, as well as consulting services in the field of inertial sensors and optical MEMS. TA-SWISS is a member of the Swissmem association, which represents the Swiss industry of mechanical and electrical engineering. In 2014, TA-SWISS became a subsidiary of the Swiss technology group HUBER+SUHNER.

Yokohama National University ( Yokohama Kokuritsu Daigaku), commonly abbreviated as YNU, is a national university in Yokohama, Japan. The university was established in 1949, when the National College of Technology at Yokohama, a national engineering college, was integrated with the Yokohama School of Commerce, a private business school. The university has three campuses, situated in Isogo, Totsuka, and Kannai. Isogo campus is the university's headquarters and houses the engineering and science departments. Totsuka campus is home to the business and economics departments. Kannai campus was originally the Yokohama College of Commerce, and still houses the university's law and literature departments. The university has five undergraduate schools, four graduate schools, and two research institutes. The undergraduate schools are the Faculty of Engineering, the Faculty of Economics, the Faculty of Business Administration, the Faculty of Commerce, and the Faculty of Law. The graduate schools are the Graduate School of Engineering, the Graduate School of Economics, the Graduate School of Business Administration, and the Graduate School of Law. The research institutes are the Institute of Engineering and the Institute of Business Administration. The university is known for its research in the field of engineering, particularly in the areas of electrical and electronic engineering, civil engineering, and chemical engineering. In recent years, the university has been promoting research in the field of life sciences. The university's alumni include many prominent engineers and business leaders. The university's distinguished alumni include Hisao Taki, a civil engineer who is known for his work on the Shinkansen, and Masayoshi Son, the founder and CEO of Softbank.

Internal wave Internal waves are waves that propagate along the interface between two fluids of different densities. They are longitudinal waves, meaning that they propagate in the same direction as the energy they transport. They are quasilinear waves, meaning that they exhibit a certain degree of linearity, in that the displacement of the medium is related to the energy density in the wave by a simple formula, which is not the case for nonlinear waves. Internal waves are a type of wave that exists in a fluid that is completely surrounded by another fluid, and they are thus unable to escape the surrounding fluid. Internal waves can be generated by the movement of the fluids that surround them. An example is the internal waves that are generated when the Earth's upper ocean is influenced by the wind, or when a layer of fluid is displaced by a solid body that is moving through it. Internal waves are a type of gravity wave, meaning that they are influenced by the force of gravity, which acts between the two fluids. Internal waves are also influenced by the viscous forces that act between the two fluids. The viscous forces tend to dampen the waves, and they also tend to make the waves turbulent. The combination of the gravitational and viscous forces is what gives rise to the complex behavior of internal waves. Internal waves are important in a number of scientific fields, including oceanography, meteorology, and astrophysics. In the ocean, internal waves play an important role in the circulation of the upper ocean and in the mixing of the upper and lower layers of the ocean. In the atmosphere, internal waves are responsible for the transport of heat and moisture from the surface to the upper levels of the atmosphere. In astrophysics, internal waves are important in the circulation of fluids within the interiors of stars and planets, and they are also important in the transport of energy and matter through the interiors of these objects. Gunnar Karlson (25 April 1898 – 10 October 1952) was a Swedish astronomer and mathematician who worked at the Swedish Optical Institute and the University of Uppsala. He was known for his contributions to the field of spectroscopy, such as the Karlson-Rittner method, and for his work on the theory of the astroschematic. Gunnar Karlson was born in Töreboda, Sweden in 1898. He received his bachelor's degree in mathematics in 1921 and his master's degree in mathematics and astronomy in 1923, both from the University of Uppsala. He worked as an assistant at the Swedish Optical Institute from 1923 to 1925 and as a lecturer in mathematics at the University of Uppsala from 1925 to 1928. He then returned to the Swedish Optical Institute as a senior astronomer and worked there until his death. Karlson's research focused on the fields of spectroscopy and the theory of the astroschematic. He was known for his contributions to the field of spectroscopy, such as the Karlson-Rittner method, and for his work on the theory of the astroschematic. He was a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences and the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences.

Cattivik (Cattivi ik) is a Canadian mockumentary film directed by Mark Sawers. It was shown at the 2004 Toronto International Film Festival, the 2005 Sundance Film Festival, the 2005 Toronto Underground Film Festival, and the 2006 Brooklyn Film Festival. The film was also shown at the Berkman Center for the Internet and Society as part of the "Internet Rules" screening series, and at the "Art on the Screen" screening series at the National Gallery of Canada. The film centres on a group of criminals who perform "cattivi ik", a concept the film defines as "theft, fraud, or deception with an artistic or intellectual basis or motivation". The film features interviews with several people who claim to be, or at least to have been, cattivi ik, including a thief, a con man, a graffiti artist, and a bank robber. It also features actors playing the family and friends of a woman who died in the 9/11 attacks, a man whose wife was murdered, and a man whose daughter was murdered. Cattivik was shown on the Sundance Channel in the United States. It was also released on Region 1 DVD in the United States on September 26, 2006, and on Region 2 DVD in the United Kingdom on August 21, 2007. Cattivik was the last film to be scored by the Canadian musician, singer-songwriter, and producer Daniel Lanois. Cattivik is a play on the Italian words cattivi atti, meaning "disruptive behaviour".

Montana (ship) The Montana was a British refrigerated cargo ship that sank on June 13, 1944, after striking a mine in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Northern Ireland. The ship was launched in 1938 from the yards of Harland & Wolff in Belfast. It was operated by the merchant navy for the Ministry of War Transport and was armed with a 4-inch naval gun for protection against German U-boats. After leaving Liverpool on June 12, 1944, bound for New York City with a cargo of 5,000 tons of anthracite coal, the Montana struck a mine that had been laid by the German submarine U-quist in Cardigan Bay. The ship began to take on water and developed a list. The crew abandoned ship and were later rescued by a British minesweeper. The Montana sank the following day. The ship's captain, A. C. Meikle, was later awarded the Order of the British Empire for his actions during the sinking. The Montana is one of the last ships to be lost to a mine in the Atlantic. The wreck of the Montana was located in 1982 and is now a popular dive site.

The Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center is a museum and theater complex in Colorado Springs, Colorado. It is located in the National Register-listed Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center at Colorado College, which is on the National Register of Historic Places. The Fine Arts Center is an affiliate of the Smithsonian Institution and is accredited by the American Alliance of Museums. The Fine Arts Center comprises two museums, two theaters, and the Edgar O. Wilson Gallery. The Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center Museum is the region's only museum that focuses exclusively on the art of the American West. Its collections include paintings, sculpture, and works on paper by artists such as Georgia O'Keeffe, Charles Marion Russell, Frederic Remington, and Frank Lloyd Wright. The museum's permanent collection includes more than 40,000 objects. The Fine Arts Center's other museum, the John De Puy Museum, is dedicated to the art of Ancient America. It is the only museum in the region exclusively dedicated to the art and culture of the Pre-Columbian era. The museum's permanent collection includes more than 2,000 objects, with a particular emphasis on the Mimbres people of the American Southwest. The Fine Arts Center's two theaters, the Donald R. Seawell Stage and the Thomas E. and Alice H. King Studio, are home to the Colorado Springs Fine Arts Center Theatre Company. The company's mission is to provide a platform for the exploration of the human condition through the eyes of the American West. The company has a reputation for producing new plays, and has a satellite company that performs at the Robert Hoag Rawlings Fine Arts Center in Pueblo, Colorado. The Edgar O. Wilson Gallery is a regional gallery dedicated to the art of Colorado and the Rocky Mountain region. It features rotating exhibitions and a permanent collection of more than 1,000 objects, including paintings, drawings, prints, sculpture, and photography. The gallery's mission is to promote the work of regional artists and to provide a platform for the exploration of the region's culture and history. The Fine Arts Center complex also includes the Fountain Valley School, a private elementary and middle school that is housed in a historic school building on the campus. The school's mission is to provide a rigorous academic curriculum and a strong foundation in the arts. The Fine Arts Center is a cultural anchor for Colorado Springs and the Pikes Peak region, and is a major tourist attraction for the state of Colorado. It is a member of the American Association of Museums and the Western States Arts Federation.

Bengalia (Bôngol), also known as Bangala, is a region of West Bengal, India. It is located in the southern tip of West Bengal, and is home to the city of Durgapur. The region is bounded by the Damodar River to the north, the Chota Nagpur Plateau to the east, the Purulia district to the south, and the Bhagirathi River to the west. The smallest district of West Bengal, the Durgapur subdivision, is located within Bengalia. The area is renowned for its rich cultural heritage, natural beauty, and mineral wealth. The region is home to a number of small towns, including Durgapur, Asansol, Raniganj, Burnpur, Kanksan, and Kulti. The economy of the region is dominated by the coal industry, which has a long history in the area. The first coal mine in India was established at Raniganj in 1774 by an English company. The region is also home to the Eastern Coalfields Limited, a subsidiary of the Coal India Limited, which is the largest coal producer in the country. The region is well-connected to the rest of the state and the country by road and rail. The Durgapur Barrage, which was built in 1963, is a major landmark of the region and serves as a transportation hub. The region is also home to a number of tourist attractions, including the Durgapur Barrage, the Durgapur Steel Plant, the Durgapur Thermal Power Plant, the Eastern Railway Museum, the Deul Park, the Circuit House, the Burnpur Cricket Club Ground, and the Eastern Railway Divisional Stadium. The people of the region are known for their warmth and hospitality. The region is also home to a number of festivals, including the Maghi Purnima, the Poush Sankranti, the Makar Sankranti, the Vaisakhi, the Good Friday, the Easter, the Dasami, the Buddha Purnima, the Christmas, the Holi, the Eid al-Fitr, the Eid al-Adha, and the Diwali.
