Mark French (born January 21, 1966) is a Canadian former professional ice hockey player. He played 37 games in the National Hockey League (NHL) with the Minnesota Wild and Dallas Stars, though most of his career was spent in the minor American Hockey League (AHL). Born in Toronto, Ontario, French spent four seasons in the Ontario Hockey League (OHL) with the Toronto Marlboros and the Oshawa Generals, registering 53 goals and 120 points in 128 games. He was drafted in the eighth round, 163rd overall, by the Buffalo Sabres in the 1984 NHL Entry Draft. French spent the majority of his career in the AHL, where he played with the Rochester Americans, New Haven Nighthawks, and Springfield Indians. He also played in the International Hockey League (IHL) with the San Diego Gulls and the Detroit Vipers. He won the Governor's Trophy with the Nighthawks in 1989–90, and the Turner Cup with the Vipers in 1996. In his 37 games in the NHL, French recorded 11 points (3 goals and 8 assists) and 4 penalty minutes. He played two games for the Minnesota Wild during the 2001–02 season, and 35 games for the Dallas Stars in 2002–03, recording a +3 plus/minus rating and two penalty minutes. French played in the 2004 World Championships as a member of Team Canada.

Leicester Smyth was born on January 1, 1905, in Cobden, Ontario. He attended Ontario Agricultural College in the early 1920s, where he was a member of the college's championship debating team. He went on to earn a bachelor's degree in agriculture from the University of Toronto in 1925 and a master's degree in agriculture from the University of Wisconsin in 1928. Smyth began his teaching career at the University of Toronto in 1928. He was appointed assistant professor of agriculture in 1930 and associate professor in 1938. He became a full professor in 1945 and professor emeritus in 1970. Smyth was a pioneer in the field of plant breeding. He is credited with developing several new varieties of forage crops, including a variety of Timothy grass that is still in use today. He also conducted research on the breeding and genetics of barley, oats, rye, and other small grains. In addition to his work in plant breeding, Smyth was also a leader in the field of agricultural education. He was a founding member of the Canadian Society of Agricultural Education and was a strong advocate for the improvement of agricultural education in Canada. He was also a member of the executive committee of the Canadian National Institute for the Blind and a member of the board of directors of the Canadian Paraplegic Association. Smyth received numerous awards and honors for his contributions to agriculture and education. He was a fellow of the Royal Society of Canada and a member of the Order of Canada. He was also a recipient of the Queen Elizabeth II Coronation Medal, the Canada Medal, and the Ontario Medal for Distinguished Service. Smyth died on February 1, 1997, in Toronto, Ontario.

China–Malawi relations The Republic of Malawi and the People's Republic of China have had diplomatic relations since the 1970s. China has provided aid to Malawi since the country's independence in 1964, and in recent years has been funding infrastructure projects such as roads, a stadium, and an international airport. In 2006, the Chinese government donated US$3 million to the United Nations World Food Programme (WFP) in Malawi to help the country cope with a food crisis. In 2007, China provided US$5.5 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a severe drought hit the country. In 2008, the Chinese government provided US$1.5 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a second severe drought hit the country. In 2009, the Chinese government provided US$2 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a third severe drought hit the country. In 2010, the Chinese government provided US$3 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a fourth severe drought hit the country. In 2011, the Chinese government provided US$4 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a fifth severe drought hit the country. In 2012, the Chinese government provided US$5 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a sixth severe drought hit the country. In 2013, the Chinese government provided US$6 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a seventh severe drought hit the country. In 2014, the Chinese government provided US$7 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after an eighth severe drought hit the country. In 2015, the Chinese government provided US$8 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a ninth severe drought hit the country. In 2016, the Chinese government provided US$9 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a tenth severe drought hit the country. In 2017, the Chinese government provided US$10 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after an eleventh severe drought hit the country. In 2018, the Chinese government provided US$11 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a twelfth severe drought hit the country. In 2019, the Chinese government provided US$12 million to the WFP to assist with the relief effort after a thirteenth severe drought hit the country.

Temur Iakobashvili (Georgian: თემურ იაკობაშვილი [tʰɛmʰuːr iːakʰɔbɑːʃvɪlʲi]; Russian: Тёмур Айкобулашвили [tʲɵmʊr ajkɐbulɐʂvʲɪlʲɪ]; born April 11, 1977) is a Georgian politician and businessman who is serving as Minister of Foreign Affairs of Georgia since 18 June 2015. Iakobashvili was born inbilisi, Georgia. In 1994 he graduated from the Moscow State Institute of International Relations, and in 1996 he completed his bachelor's degree at the Faculty of Law of the Tbilisi State University. In 2013 he received a master's degree from the Georgian Institute of Public Administration. From 1996 to 2000, Iakobashvili was a member of the youth organization "Natsis Shelkoveti", which was founded by the Georgian Dream coalition. In 2000, he joined the youth wing of the Georgian Dream party, where he served as head of the legal department and as a member of the executive committee. In 2008, he was elected to the Georgian Dream political council. In 2009, he was appointed executive secretary of the party. In 2010, Iakobashvili was named as the head of the Georgian Dream's branch in the eastern Georgian region of Kakheti. In 2012, he was re-elected to the Georgian Dream political council. Following the 2012 parliamentary election, Iakobashvili was elected to the Parliament of Georgia on the Georgian Dream party list, winning a seat in the legislative body from the Samtskhe-Javakheti region. He was then elected to the parliamentary committee on foreign relations. On 18 June 2015, Iakobashvili was appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs of Georgia in the cabinet of Irakli Garibashvili. In September 2015, the Russian foreign ministry banned Iakobashvili from entering Russia for his alleged "provoking and supporting" the Russian-Georgian war in 2008.

Cronenberg, Wuppertal Cronenberg is a district of Wuppertal, Germany. It is located in the northwestern outskirts of the city, on the left bank of the Wupper river, which forms the border with Remscheid. Cronenberg was a separate municipality until it was incorporated into Wuppertal in 1929. Cronenberg's Coat of Arms Cronenberg's coat of arms shows the Wupper river and an industry, represented by a gear wheel. The gear wheel was added in 1954. The district has a population of 11,714 (as of 31 December 2013), most of whom live in the continuous built-up area of Wuppertal. Cronenberg is home to the Wuppertal-Cronenberg station, one of the main railway stations of Wuppertal. The Wuppertal-Ronsdorf station is also located nearby. Cronenberg is the site of the Ford Motor Company's Wuppertal engine plant, which opened in 1925. In 2006, the plant had approximately 1,500 employees and produced 200,000 engines. The plant was the subject of a major scandal in the early 1990s, when it was discovered that many of its workers had developed serious health problems due to exposure to carcinogenic substances. The headquarters of the West German branch of the Christian Democratic Union, the Christian Democratic Union of Germany, is located in Cronenberg. Cronenberg is the location of the Wuppertal-Cronenberg cemetery, one of the largest in Wuppertal.

San Siro di Struppa is a church in the frazione of Struppa, in the comune of Montescudaio, province of Pisa, Tuscany, central Italy. It is located at the end of a long, winding road that goes up the mountain from the village of Montescudaio. The church is built at the point where the south-western slopes of the mountain meet the sea. The church is dedicated to San Silverio, a 7th-century bishop who is said to have withdrawn to this isolated spot to live as a hermit. The current buildings date from the 15th century, with some later additions. The church has a single nave with a transept. The main altar is in the apse, and there are two smaller chapels in the transept. The walls are decorated with numerous paintings, the majority of which are from the 17th century. The church also has several sculptures, including a statue of San Silverio, a bas-relief of the Annunciation, and a wooden crucifix from the 16th century. The church is located in a picturesque landscape, and is a popular destination for hikers and cyclists. It is also a destination for pilgrims, who travel to the church on foot from the nearby village of Montescudaio.

Crips The Crips, also known as the Rollin' 20s, are one of the most well-known sets, or groups of individuals, in the gang member category. The Crips are known for their involvement in the Los Angeles drug trade. The Crips are a largely African American gang, but they have also been known to have Hispanic and other members as well. Their main rival gang is the Bloods. The Crips are known to be a more violent and aggressive gang, they are also known for their involvement in criminal activity. The Crips have been around since the early 1970s, and they have a long history of criminal activity and violence. They have been involved in many shootings and other violent crimes, and they have a reputation for being a very dangerous gang. The Crips are one of the most well-known gangs in the United States, and they have been featured in many movies and television shows. They are known for their involvement in the drug trade, and they are also known for their violence and criminal activity. The Crips are a very powerful gang, and they have been a major force in the Los Angeles drug trade for many years. They are a well-organized gang, and they have a very strong leadership structure. The Crips are a very successful gang, and they have been able to maintain their strength and unity for many years. They are a very well-known gang, and they have a strong reputation for their violence and criminal activity.

Yuka Tsujiyoko (辻樹樹archives) (born February 6, 1973) is a Japanese voice actress and singer from Tokyo, Japan. She is a graduate of the Japan Narration Acting Institute. She is well known for her work on the PlayStation video game series Final Fantasy, for which she has voiced Tifa Lockhart since Final Fantasy VII, and also her work on the Nintendo DS video game series Professor Layton, for which she has voiced Katrielle Layton since Professor Layton and the Diabolical Box. Tsujiyoko was born in Tokyo, Japan, and is a graduate of the Japan Narration Acting Institute. In addition to voice acting, she has also performed as a singer in several albums, including the theme song to the Japanese version of The Proud Family Movie. She is well known for her work on the PlayStation video game series Final Fantasy, for which she has voiced Tifa Lockhart since Final Fantasy VII, and also her work on the Nintendo DS video game series Professor Layton, for which she has voiced Katrielle Layton since Professor Layton and the Diabolical Box.

Mina Rzouki is a Canadian model, artist, YouTube content creator, and transgender rights activist. Rzouki was born in Montreal, Quebec, and spent her early years in Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, where she was subjected to discrimination and abuse as a result of her gender non-conformance. She returned to Canada in 2013 and began her transition in 2015, having been inspired by the story of Bruce/Caitlyn Jenner. In 2016, Rzouki was cast in the first season of Canada's Drag Race, becoming the first openly transgender woman to compete on the show. She placed fifth overall in the competition. In 2018, Rzouki was one of the recipients of the inaugural Jack.org Trailblazer Award, which recognizes "a Canadian who has made an impact on the landscape of mental health in Canada." In 2020, Rzouki was named one of the "Top 25 Most Influential People in the World" by Time magazine. In 2021, Rzouki launched a YouTube series, This Is Me Trying, in which she "explores the idea of trying – and sometimes failing – to be a good ally to marginalized communities."

Slobodan Kaličanin (Serbian Cyrillic: Слободан Каличанин; born 11 January 1948) is a Serbian former politician and convicted war criminal. He was the founder and leader of the Serbian ultra-nationalist organization Tigers, which was responsible for a series of murders, torture and other crimes during the Yugoslav Wars. Kaličanin was born in 1948 in Niš, Serbia, in what was then the People's Republic of Serbia, Federal People's Republic of Yugoslavia. He was a student at the Niš Faculty of Technology until the early 1970s, but dropped out in his third year. In the late 1970s, he formed the Association of Non-Conformist Students, which soon transformed into the Serbian nationalist organization known as the Tigers. The Tigers' initial goal was to unite the various Serbian nationalist groups in Yugoslavia and create a Serbian superstate, which would include all of Serbia, Montenegro, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and parts of Croatia. To achieve this, the Tigers conducted a series of murders, torture and other crimes against civilians, aiming to create a climate of fear and instability. The Tigers were also responsible for a number of political assassinations, including the murder of Serbian Prime Minister Zoran Đinđić. In the late 1980s, the Tigers began to cooperate with the Yugoslav government, and Kaličanin was appointed to a number of government positions. However, the relationship between the Tigers and the government began to deteriorate in the early 1990s, as the Tigers began to pursue their own agenda, and the government began to move towards a more moderate position. In 1992, the Tigers were banned, and Kaličanin was forced to go into hiding. In the late 1990s, Kaličanin was arrested and tried for a number of crimes, including the murder of Đinđić. In 2002, he was found guilty and sentenced to life in prison. Kaličanin is currently serving his sentence at the maximum security prison in Beograd.

The 1986 Philippine presidential election was held on February 7, 1986, pursuant to the 1986 Constitution. This was the first presidential election after the 1986 People Power Revolution, which saw the overthrow of Ferdinand Marcos by Corazon Aquino. The election was held under a transitory provision in the 1986 Constitution, which was supposed to be the last election under the Fourth Philippine Republic. This was the first time that a presidential election was held using the plurality voting system, as the previous elections used first-past-the-post voting. The 1986 Constitution also did not allow political parties, which had been a feature of previous elections. The election was boycotted by the two major parties, the Kilusang Bagong Sibol (KBS) and the Lakas ng Bayan (Laban), who chose instead to support the National Citizens' Movement for Free Elections (NAMFREL), which was organizing an independent election. The two major parties did not put up any candidate for president or vice president. The election was won by Corazon Aquino, the first female president of the Philippines. Her running mate, Salvador Laurel, won the vice presidential election. This was the only time in Philippine history that the president and vice president were elected independently of each other.

In mathematics, the projective line, also called the projective curve, is an algebraic curve in the projective plane, which is the space of all points in the plane no three of which are collinear. The projective line may be described as the set of all points which have the same configuration with respect to the planes defined by three given non-collinear points. More formally, the projective line may be defined as the set of points whose projective coordinates, when expressed in the basis of three given points, are all equal to one another. The projective line has a natural structure of a projective curve, but becomes an affine curve if we choose a basis in which three points are collinear. A projective line can be regarded as a projective generalization of a line in affine space. In the special case of a projective line in the real projective plane, we can choose a basis such that the real projective line is the set of all points whose first two coordinates are equal to each other and whose third coordinate is equal to zero. This special projective line is called the absolute projective line. A projective line is not in general the same as the set of all points on a line in affine space, because the projective line contains "extra" points which are not on any line in affine space. For example, the set of all points with two equal coordinates and one equal to zero contains, in addition to the points on any line in affine space, the "extra" point at infinity in the direction of the line. Projective lines can be used to defineprojective planes, projective spaces, and other geometric structures. In the theory of algebraic curves, the special case of a projective line is called a conic section. In the theory of complex projective spaces, the projective line is called a complex projective curve.

Paula Williams Madison is an American politician and former television executive serving as a member of the New York City Council from the 21st district, which includes portions of East Harlem and the Upper East Side in Manhattan. She is the first woman to represent this district, and the first African-American to represent any district in East Harlem. Madison was born in Manhattan and raised in East Harlem. She attended Hunter College High School and graduated from Harvard College in 1972 with a bachelor's degree in psychology. She then attended Harvard Law School, where she earned a Juris Doctor in 1975. After graduating, she joined the New York City Public Interest Group on the East Side and worked as an assistant to U.S. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. In 1978, she was hired as an assistant to East Harlem politician Herman Badillo, and in 1981 was appointed to the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission by Mayor Ed Koch. She was the first black woman to serve on the commission, and the first to chair the commission in 1990. In 1993, she was appointed to the New York State Assembly by Mayor David Dinkins, serving from 1994 to 1996. In 1996, she was elected to the City Council, to fill the seat left vacant by the election of Squadron to the New York State Senate. Madison was the first woman to chair the City Council's Transportation Committee. She also served as chair of the council's Committee on Standards and Ethics and as chair of the council's Land Use, Zoning and Franchises subcommittee. Madison served as an executive producer for the TV series Law & Order from 1996 to 2008. In 2005, she was nominated for an Emmy Award for her work on the series. In 2007, she was named as one of Crain's New York Business's "40 Under 40" for being a young influential member of New York City's business community. Madison has served on the board of trustees for the City University of New York, the New York City Ballet, and the New York Public Library, as well as on the board of directors for the New York City Opera, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and the Jazz Foundation of America. She is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. Madison is the co-owner of the television station NYC Life, and is the founder and CEO of the non-profit organization Madison Arts & Sciences.

Minor spliceosome The minor spliceosome is a group of small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNPs) that play a key role in the removal of introns from minor (or alternative) splice variants of pre-mRNA. snRNPs form a complex with the intron-containing pre-mRNA and participate in the splicing reaction. The minor spliceosome is composed of at least three Sm-domain-containing proteins: SnRNP core protein SmD3, SmD2, and SmD1. It also contains two other proteins: SmB and SmE. The minor spliceosome is involved in the removal of introns that are located in positions of intron-exon boundaries that do not match the consensus sequence for splicing (i.e. the 5' end of the intron has a purine nucleotide instead of the usual pyrimidine nucleotide). The resulting minor splice variant of the pre-mRNA will often be translated into a protein that is structurally and/or functionally different from the major splice variant of the pre-mRNA. The minor spliceosome can also be involved in the generation of chimeric RNA molecules. Such RNA molecules contain sequences from two or more different mRNAs. In the case of the minor spliceosome, the chimeric RNA molecules are generated by a trans-splicing reaction, in which the two RNA molecules to be joined have compatible 3' and 5' splice sites. The function of the minor spliceosome can be explained by the following reaction scheme: The minor spliceosome catalyzes the splicing reaction in a similar manner as the major spliceosome. In the first step, the attacking splice site is chosen. In the second step, the bond between the two splice sites is cleaved. Then, in the third step, the intron is released, and in the fourth step, the two exons are ligated. The steps 2 and 3 are the rate-limiting steps in the minor spliceosome-catalyzed splicing reaction. The catalysis of these steps is highly specific and requires the presence of a variety of small nuclear RNAs (snRNAs). The snRNAs are similar to the guide RNAs that are involved in the catalytic reaction of the major spliceosome. However, unlike the guide RNAs of the major spliceosome, the snRNAs of the minor spliceosome are not bound to a protein. The structure of the minor spliceosome has not been resolved experimentally. However, based on the conservation of sequence and structure of the Sm proteins, it has been proposed that the minor spliceosome forms a helical structure with the Sm proteins SmD3 and SmD2 forming a core that is surrounded by the Sm protein SmD1 and the snRNAs. In many cases, a particular pre-mRNA can be alternatively spliced to produce both major and minor splice variants. The decision which variant will be produced is often dependent on the cell type or the developmental stage of the cell. In such cases, the minor spliceosome can be in competition with the major spliceosome for the removal of the intron. In some cases, the minor spliceosome is the dominant splicing pathway, whereas in other cases the major spliceosome is the dominant splicing pathway.

List of honours of Estonia awarded to heads of state and royalty The President of the Republic of Estonia is the head of state and the highest-ranking official in the country. The President is elected by the people for a five-year term and can only serve for two consecutive terms. The President has an extensive reserve of powers. They are also the Commander-in-Chief of the armed forces and have the right to be heard in the Diet (the unicameral parliament). The President has the right to choose the Chief of Police and the head of the Central Bank. The President's Office is located in the Toompea Castle. The President also has an official residence, the Reislikukohtu (State Home), located in the Meiritzeta (Meiritz Street) of Tallinn. The Collar of the Order of the White Star The Collar of the Order of the White Star is the highest-ranking decoration of the Order of the White Star, which is the second highest order of Estonia. It has been awarded only twice, first to President Konstantin Päts in 1938, and then to President Arnold Rüütel in 2001. The Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana The Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana is the highest order of the Republic of Estonia. It is awarded for outstanding service to the Republic of Estonia. The Order was established on 18 November 1995. The collar was established on 17 December 2000. The Order has five classes: 1. The Collar of the Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana (for heads of state) 2. The Grand Cross of the Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana (for members of the government and parliament, and other prominent figures) 3. The Cross of the Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana (for members of the Defence Forces and other military personnel, as well as civilians, for outstanding service to the Republic of Estonia) 4. The Grand Commander of the Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana (for members of the Defence Forces and other military personnel, as well as civilians, for special merits to the Republic of Estonia) 5. The Commander of the Order of the Cross of Terra Mariana (for members of the Defence Forces and other military personnel, as well as civilians, for merits to the Republic of Estonia) The Order of the White Star The Order of the White Star was established on 8 November 1935. It is the second highest order of the Republic of Estonia. The Order of the White Star has five classes: 1. The Grand Cross of the Order of the White Star (for heads of state) 2. The Cross of the Order of the White Star (for members of the government and parliament, and other prominent figures) 3. The Grand Commander of the Order of the White Star (for members of the Defence Forces and other military personnel, as well as civilians, for outstanding service to the Republic of Estonia) 4. The Commander of the Order of the White Star (for members of the Defence Forces and other military personnel, as well as civilians, for merits to the Republic of Estonia) 5. The Star of the Order of the White Star (for members of the Defence Forces and other military personnel, as well as civilians, for merits to the Republic of Estonia)

3rd Battalion, 9th Marines, was one of the most decorated infantry units in the history of the United States Marine Corps. The unit, based out of Marine Corps Base Camp Smedley D. Butler in Okinawa, Japan, was known for its lineage, as well as its fighting ability. Raised in 1917, the unit was deployed to the European theater of World War II, where it participated in several major battles, including the Battle of Iwo Jima, the Battle of Saipan, and the Battle of Tinian. The unit suffered heavy casualties during these battles, but it also earned a reputation for its determination and fighting ability. After the war, the unit was assigned to the 1st Marine Brigade, and it was deployed to the Korean War. The unit was one of the first Marine units to enter the war, and it suffered heavy casualties during the early stages of the war. However, the unit also played a major role in the Inchon Landing and the subsequent capture of Seoul. The unit was again deployed to the Vietnam War, and it was one of the first Marine units to enter the country. The unit suffered heavy casualties during the war, but it also earned a reputation for its fighting ability. In the late 1970s, the unit was assigned to the 3rd Force Service Support Group, and it was deployed to the Middle East, where it participated in the Iran hostage crisis. The unit was also deployed to the Gulf War, and it played a major role in the initial stages of the war. In the late 1990s, the unit was assigned to the 1st Marine Expeditionary Brigade, and it was deployed to the Taiwan Strait, where it participated in the Taiwan Strait crisis. The unit was again deployed to the Middle East, where it participated in the Iraq War. The unit played a major role in the initial stages of the war, and it suffered heavy casualties. In the late 2000s, the unit was assigned to the 3rd Force Service Support Group, and it was deployed to the Middle East, where it participated in the Afghanistan War.

The Nordic model The Nordic model is a concept in social and political theory corresponding to the labour market and welfare system of the Nordic countries ( Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway, and Sweden). The model is characterized by a combination of a highly developed welfare state with a market-based economy. In the 1980s, the concept was brought to the attention of a wider audience by the American political scientist Robert K. Merton, who praised the Nordic model as a way to achieve both economic efficiency and social justice. The Nordic model combines a centralized, collective bargaining-based labor market with a highly progressive taxation system and a generous welfare state. The result is a system where wages and working conditions are determined through collective bargaining between trade unions and employers. Wages are standardized to prevent labor market segmentation and to encourage internal labor migration. The Nordic model has been associated with a number of specific policies. In the labor market, these include a centralized system of collective bargaining, wage-setting, and standardized contracts; a Nordic-style occupational classification; a dual education system with both academic and vocational tracks; and a high level of union membership. In the welfare state, the Nordic model is associated with a comprehensive social security system that includes health care, unemployment benefits, and a system of family leave; a high level of public spending on education; and a policy of "active labor market policy" to help the unemployed find jobs. The Nordic model has been praised for its combination of economic efficiency and social justice. It has also been praised for its positive effect on gender equality and its promotion of social mobility. However, the Nordic model has also been criticized for its high level of income inequality and for its failure to address the problem of unemployment.

Lincoln St. Marks railway station is one of two major railway stations in Lincoln, England. The other is Lincoln Central. It is on the East Coast Main Line and is the junction for the branch lines to Skegness and Lincoln Central. The station is managed by East Midlands Railway. The station was built by the Great Northern Railway and opened in 1876. It was originally named "Lincoln, St. Marks" in reference to the nearby church. The current station buildings were constructed in the early 1960s when the number of platforms was reduced from four to two. The station is on the East Coast Main Line between London King's Cross and Doncaster. It is the junction for the branch line to Skegness and is the next station north of Newark North Gate on the East Coast Main Line. The station has two platforms, one for services to London and one for services to the north and Skegness. East Midlands Railway operate all services at Lincoln St. Marks. As of the December 2007 timetable, they provide two trains per hour to London King's Cross, one via and one via . In the other direction, there are two trains per hour to Doncaster, one via and one via . There is also a single train per hour to Skegness. The station is a short walk from the city centre via a footbridge over the river Witham. The city's other main station, Lincoln Central, is located a little further away from the city centre, and is the station for trains to Sheffield, Newark and Nottingham. In the early 1960s, the station was re-built with a more modern design, and the number of platforms was reduced from four to two. The original station had a large overall roof which covered the platforms and tracks as well as the station buildings. This was demolished and replaced with a much smaller structure which covers the station buildings only.

Eirik Verås Larsen (born 26 May 1971) is a Norwegian jazz musician (tenor saxophone, clarinet, and bass clarinet), composer, music producer, and organizer. Larsen was born in Haugesund, Norway. He studied music at the Rogaland Folkehogskule in Stavanger (1984–88), at the Jazz Program of Trondheim Musikkonservatorium (1988–91), and at the Norges Musikkhøgskole in Oslo (1992–94). In 1993, he joined the band "Jaga Jazzist", and in 1994 he joined the band "Piggy Bank". From 1994 to 1995 he studied at the Manhattan School of Music in New York. In 1995 he started the band "Verve", and in 1996 he founded the record label Jævleborg Records. In 1997, he was one of the organizers of the Kongsberg Jazzfestival, and from 1998 to 2000 he was the festival's artistic director. In 1999, he was the director of the Jazz Program at Trondheim Musikkonservatorium, and in 2001 he was the director of the Jazz Department at the Norges Musikkhøgskole in Oslo. In 2000, he received the Norwegian Grammy for his album Eirik Verås Larsen. In 2002, he released the album The Inbetween Region, with the British band June. In 2004, he released the album The Hour of Bewilderbeast, with the British band Bad Luck. In 2006, he released the album Radium, with the American band Radium. As a composer, he has written music for the television series "Erik and Norway" (1998) and "PSar" (2003), and the films "Cinderella" (2002), "Insomnia" (2002), and "Seekingavenue" (2004). In 1998, he was the producer for the Kongsberg Jazzfestival, and in 2002 he was the executive producer for the Norsk Jazzforum. In 2003, he was the artistic director for the Norsk Jazzfestival.

François de La Rochefoucauld, Marquis de Montandre (1613 – 1680) was a 17th-century French writer who is best known for his maxims, which are listed in his book, Les Maximes du Marquis de Montandre. La Rochefoucauld was born in Paris, the son of Etienne de La Rochefoucauld, a fidalgo, or member of the nobility of the household of the King of France, and of Judith de Lencel, daughter of a Protestant family from the south of France. His mother was the sister of the mathematician and physicist Étienne Pascal. After his father's death in 1629, he and his mother and brother lived with their cousin, the philosopher and mathematician Blaise Pascal. Pascal had a great influence on La Rochefoucauld and his writing. La Rochefoucauld attended the University of Paris and completed his studies in 1633. He then served as an officer in the French army until 1646. He married his first wife, Catherine de Ligneris, in 1644, and his second wife, Jacqueline de La Vergenne, in 1651. He became the Marquis de Montandre in 1666. Montandre had many friends and acquaintances among the literary and intellectual elite of his day, including the writers Molière, La Fontaine, and Jean de Santeuil; the historians Louis de Beaufort and Louis Bergeron; and the philosophers Thomas Hobbes, René Descartes, and Nicolas Malebranche. His first published work was a collection of Latin poems, entitled La Lyre des Amants (The Lyre of Lovers), which appeared in 1639. His maxims were first published in 1665, under the title Les Maximes du Marquis de Montandre, but were later renamed Les Maximes de la Rochefoucauld. The maxims are a collection of approximately 500 epigrammatic statements that express such ideas as "Vanity is the foundation of all wisdom" and "We would often be cured of our passions if we could have them at will." The maxims have been compared to the philosophy of the ancient Greek historian Thucydides and the ancient Roman philosopher Seneca. La Rochefoucauld's work had a profound impact on the literature of the 17th century, and his maxims are often quoted in modern times.

Ottawa Jazz Festival The Ottawa Jazz Festival (French: Festival de jazz d'Ottawa) is an annual jazz festival held in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. In recent years, the festival has featured performances by jazz, blues, and soul artists, as well as some popular music acts. The Ottawa Jazz Festival was founded in 1984 by James Beveridge, who at the time was also the director of the National Arts Centre Orchestra. It was held at the National Arts Centre until 2002, when it was moved to Confederation Park. In 2008, the festival moved back to the National Arts Centre. The festival has always been held in July, and since 2004 it has been a three-day event. In 2002, the festival was the subject of a short documentary film, A Place to Hang Your Hat, directed by Andrewbuff. In 2010, the festival presented the TD Ottawa Jazz Festival Galas, a series of eight concerts by the National Arts Centre Orchestra and guest artists. The festival also presents the TD Jazz Summit, a series of free concerts by high-profile artists.

Michela Cerruti (born January 7, 1968 in Milan, Italy) is an Italian actress. Cerruti began her career as a fashion model, and was a regular on the catwalks during the 1980s. She also posed for the cover of the April 1983 issue of American Vogue, which was photographed by Bruce Weber. In 1984, she was named "Model of the Year" by the Camera Nazionale della Moda Italiana. Cerruti's first major film role was in The Ice House, which was directed by Daniel Petrie, Jr. and produced by Gene Siskel and Roger Ebert. She also had a role in the 1986 Academy Award-winning film The Mission, which was directed by Roland Joffé and starring Jeremy Irons. In 1987, Cerruti was cast as the female lead in the film adaptation of John Updike's short story "A&P". The film, which was directed by Paul Mazursky and titled American Passion, was never made. Cerruti had a minor role in the 1987 film Wall Street, and appeared in a number of Italian films, including the 1988 film Private Access. In 1989, she appeared in the horror film The House of the Devil, which was directed by Steve Miner. In 1990, Cerruti appeared in the film Three Businessmen, which was directed by and starred Michael Jeter.

Sampling (music) Sampling is the selection and manipulation of a short section of a sound recording and the use of that section as a musical element. Sampling is a form of interpolation; the sample is inserted into the new recording at the selected speed, and its pitch is optionally adjusted to match that of the other elements of the new recording. The process is also called "lifting" or "ripping" a sample. Sampling is used creatively in all genres of music, from hip hop to pop to dance to rock, and has been part of music production since the 1940s. In the early 1990s, sampling was recognized as a new art form in itself. The sample may be from a digital or analog source. Analog sampling requires analog-to-digital conversion. Digital sampling requires no analog-to-digital conversion. Sampling was originally accomplished by recording the desired sample to a second analog track on a multitrack analog tape recorder. The original source was then re-recorded, with the sample played simultaneously with the new source, to a third analog track. The sample would be blended with the new source, and both would be re-recorded to a fourth track, and so on. During the mixing stage, as much of the original recorded source would be faded out as desired, leaving only the sample. The use of sampling has generally increased throughout the history of music production. It has been suggested that this is because musicians are sampling other musicians' work and using it to create their own. In the 1940s, 1950s, and early-1960s, sampling was accomplished by simply using a portable analog tape player and feeding its output into a second tape recorder. The original source was then re-recorded, with the sample played simultaneously with the new source, to a third analog track. The sample would be blended with the new source, and both would be re-recorded to a fourth track, and so on. During the mixing stage, as much of the original recorded source would be faded out as desired, leaving only the sample. A sampler is a device or computer program used to create and play back samples. The sampler plays back the sample in the designated speed and optionally adjusts the pitch to match that of the other elements of the new recording. The album You've Got a Friend was a commercial success, and its title track, which she had written for her friend James Taylor, became her first big hit. Her follow-up album, Tapestry, was an even greater success, spending 15 weeks at number one on the Billboard album chart and winning four Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year. King has since released 24 studio albums, as well as five live albums, four compilation albums, and four extended plays. In 1961, King and her first husband, Gerry Goffin, signed a songwriting deal with Don Kirshner's Aldon Music, which was the music division of Aldon Pictures. Through this deal, they wrote more than two dozen songs for Aldon's in-house artists, including Bobby Vee, the Everly Brothers, and Little Eva. In 1962, King and Goffin were hired by ABC-Paramount to write for their stable of artists, including Paul Anka, George Hamilton IV, and Tommy Sands. The following year they wrote for Columbia Pictures' film All American Co-Ed, which featured the hit title track, performed by Oklahoma! star Gordon MacRae. In late 1964, Goffin and King were signed by Songery, a publishing company founded by singer-songwriter Neil Sedaka. The following year, they began working with singer-songwriter Barry Mann, who was also signed to Songery. The trio's first collaboration, "Goin' Back to Liverpool", was recorded by the British Invasion band the Searchers. Other hits written by the trio include "I'm into Something Good", "You've Got Your Love", "I Will Follow Him", and "One Fine Morning". After Songery's collapse in 1966, King and Goffin signed a new songwriting deal with Screen Gems. The following year they divorced, and King began a solo career. In 1970, King released her first solo album, Writer, which consisted mostly of her own compositions. Her follow-up album, Tapestry, was an even greater success, spending 15 weeks at number one on the Billboard album chart and winning four Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year. The title track, "You've Got a Friend", became her first big hit. In 1971, King released Music, which was less successful than her previous albums but still had two hit singles: "You've Got a Friend" and "Where You Lead". The following year she released Rhymes & Reasons, which contained the hit "The Locomotion". Her 1974 album, Wrap Around Joy, was her last with ABC and included the hit "I Feel the Earth Move". In 1975, King signed a new recording contract with Capitol Records and released two albums, The Way We Were and Thoroughbred, which were both successes in the United States and internationally. Her next two albums, Welcome Home and Piano Man, were less successful, but she returned to the top of the charts in 1979 with the album Touch the Sky. In 1980, King released the album Pearls, which was her first album of previously recorded material. The same year, she released a live album, In Concert, which was also her first collaboration with her new husband, Charles "Charlie" Larkey. In 1981, she released the album One to One, which was her last with Capitol. In 1983, King signed a new recording contract with Atlantic Records and released the album Nightshift, which was a commercial success. The following year she released the album I'm Your Woman, which was not as successful as Nightshift but still contained the hit single "The Locomotion". In 1985, she released her first greatest hits album, The Hits, and in 1987 she released her second, The Rhythm of the Road. In 1988, King released the album Pearls II, which was her second album of previously recorded material. In 1991, she released the album Love Makes the World, which was her last album of new material. Since then, she has released several compilation albums, including The Very Best of Carole King (1997), I Will Always Love You (2005), and The Essential Carole King (2010). In 2013, King released the album A Carole King Christmas, which was her first new album in 20 years. In 2015, she released the album The Living Room Tour, which was her first live album in 40 years. In 2016, she released the album A Songwriter's Legacy, which was her first career-spanning retrospective.

The Mizoram–Manipur–Kachin rain forests is a tropical moist broadleaf forest located in the border region of India and Myanmar, in the Indian states of Mizoram, Manipur, and the Kachin State in Myanmar. It is one of the richest and most diverse forests in the region. This forest region is one of the few areas in the world where both the Warm Season and the Cold Season types of broadleaf forests occur. The Warm Season forests are found in the low-lying areas, and the Cold Season forests are found in the higher hills and valleys. The forest area is home to a variety of floral and faunal species. It is the home to the Hoolock gibbon, which is found only in these forests and in the nearby state of Assam. It is also the home to the critically endangered sangai, or Manipur brow-antlered deer, which is found only in the higher hills of the state of Manipur. The forest region is also the home to several indigenous tribal communities, including the Chin people of Myanmar, and the Mizo, Naga, and Manipuri people of India.

Bloodstone (band) Bloodstone was an Australian heavy metal band formed in Sydney in 1983. They were one of the first heavy metal bands from Australia to achieve international success, and were particularly well known in Japan. Bloodstone's lineup consisted of guitarists David DePice and Steve Newman, bassist Peter Ewers, keyboard player Mike Chaves, and drummer Col Young. The band had a versatile sound, ranging from the speed metal of their early material, to the more conventional heavy metal approach of their later work. The band's name was derived from the title of their first demo, Bloodstone. The demo was recorded in 1983 at Sydney's Datsun Studio. The band's first single, "Rip the Heart Out", was released in November 1983, and their first album, Bloodstone, was released the following year. The album was later re-released as Bad Blood, and then re-re-released as Rock in the Road in 2002. The band's second album, On the Edge, was released in 1985. A third album, The Other Side, was released in 1987. The band broke up shortly after the release of The Other Side, but they have since reunited and released several new albums.

The 1984 Buffalo Bills season was the franchise's 15th overall season, and their 13th in the National Football League. The Bills finished the season with a 10–6 record, good enough for second place in the AFC East, one game behind the division-winning Miami Dolphins. The Bills had a promising season, winning their first six games before losing to Miami in Week 7. They went 2–3 over their next five games, but still had a chance to win the division with two weeks left in the season. However, they lost a close game to the New England Patriots in Week 14 and were eliminated by the Dolphins the following week. Despite the loss, the Bills finished the season with a 10–6 record and made the playoffs for the fourth time in five years. In the playoffs, the Bills defeated the Los Angeles Raiders, 31–17, in the wild-card game, but lost to the Dolphins, 28–30, in the divisional round. The Bills' 10 wins were their most since they went 11–3 in 1969. The Bills' offense was led by quarterback Jim Kelly, who threw for 3,088 yards and 15 touchdowns during the regular season. Running back Thurman Thomas added 1,200 yards and six touchdowns, and wide receiver Andre Reed had 851 yards and four touchdowns. The defense was led by defensive end Bruce Smith, who had a team-high 13 sacks, and safety Lawyer Milloy, who had five interceptions. The 1984 Bills were a very popular team, and their fan base grew significantly during the season. The team's attendance jumped from an average of 60,000 per game in 1983 to over 70,000 in 1984. The Bills also sold out every home game in 1984, including their two playoff games.

Papilio hyppason, the tailed emperor, is a butterfly in the family Nymphalidae, native to Sub-Saharan Africa. The tailed emperor is the largest butterfly in the African continent. The male is 60–80 mm in wingspan and the female is a slightly larger 80–95 mm. The male is smaller than the female, but has a longer tail. The body is quite hairy, and the abdomen is barred with grey and yellow. The head has a row of black spots and the antennae are pale. The male has an iridescent purple-blue abdomen and the female's abdomen is banded with brown, cream and white. The dorsal sides of the wings are brown with red-orange highlights and a row of black spots. The ventral sides are brown with small tails, and a row of black spots that are larger in the male than in the female. The tailed emperor is found from South Africa to Kenya and Tanzania, and further north to Uganda and the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It is a forest species, occurring in primary forests, but also in secondary forests and forest gaps. It is found at altitudes ranging from sea level to about 1500 metres. The tailed emperor is a solitary, territorial butterfly. Both sexes mud-puddle, and the male also engages in hill-topping. The male's territorial display consists of steep, spiralling flights, with the butterfly rising up to 15 metres in a few seconds, then gliding back down to the ground. The male will pursue any other butterfly that enters its territory, sometimes attacking butterflies as large as the African giant swallowtail. The tailed emperor has been observed mud-puddling in large groups. The butterfly also browses on sap, and visits flowers for nectar. It has also been observed feeding from dead carcasses. The male's territoriality and lek-mating system make the tailed emperor a model species for the study of sexual selection. The male's courtship display includes the usual wing-quivering and -waving, as well as the unique 'high-dive'. The male will take off from a high perch and dive steeply, sometimes up to 30 metres, then glide back to the ground. This is repeated several times. The male's 'high-dive' was featured on the BBC's programme, Planet Earth. The tailed emperor is a common butterfly in urban and suburban areas, and can be seen flying around streets and settlements. It is one of the most common species seen by travellers to the African continent. The species is fairly adaptable, and is able to utilize new urban and suburban areas. The tailed emperor is a member of the 'emperor' tribe of butterflies, named for their distinctive wing shape. The common name is derived from the long tails of the hindwings. The family Nymphalidae is the largest family of butterflies, and includes the danaids, the satyrs, and the nymphs.

American Advertising Museum The American Advertising Museum, formerly known as the American Advertising Archives, is a museum and research center in Richmond, Virginia, United States. The museum's collection is the largest and most comprehensive collection of advertising and business history in the world, with more than 2,500 pieces of advertising history. The museum was founded in 1968 by the American Advertising Federation. In 1998, the museum moved to its current location in Richmond, Virginia, and changed its name to the American Advertising Museum. In 2001, the museum was accredited by the American Alliance of Museums. The museum's collection includes outdoor advertising, radio and television commercials, print advertisements, posters, newspapers, magazines, and books. The museum's permanent collection includes works by artists such as Norman Rockwell, Andy Warhol, and Robert Rauschenberg. The museum also has a research library with more than 100,000 volumes and a database of more than 1.5 million advertisements. The museum offers tours, programs, and events for children and adults. The museum's education programs include workshops, lectures, and classes. The museum's research library is open to the public and researchers. The museum's collection has been featured in many publications, including The New York Times, Time, and Newsweek. The museum's research library has been used by authors and researchers from around the world. The museum's board of directors is chaired by James Martin, chairman and CEO of General Dynamics. The museum's president is Scott Williams, former chief marketing officer of NASCAR.

James Kelly (born 11 April 1987) is a former professional Australian rules footballer who played for the West Coast Eagles and the Geelong Football Club in the Australian Football League (AFL). Kelly was born in Leopold, Victoria. He played junior football for the Leopold Junior Football Club, and also played for the Geelong Falcons in the TAC Cup. He was drafted by the West Coast Eagles in the fifth round (No. 82 overall) of the 2005 AFL draft. He spent two years with the West Coast Eagles, playing only four senior games, before being traded to the Geelong Football Club in 2007. Kelly won the Norm Smith Medal for best on ground in the 2008 AFL Grand Final, as well as the Gary Ayres Award for best player in the finals series. He was also named in the 2008 AFL All-Australian team. In 2009, Kelly was awarded the best and fairest player at the Geelong Football Club, the Carji Greeves Medal. He was also selected in the 2009 AFL All-Australian team. Kelly won the Michael Tuck Medal for best on ground in the 2011 AFL Grand Final, and was named in the 2011 AFL All-Australian team. Kelly was selected in the 2009 and 2011 AFL trades. He was traded to the Geelong Football Club for the 2009 season, and then traded back to the West Coast Eagles for the 2011 season. Kelly was the subject of an investigation in 2009, after he was accused of sexual assault by a 20-year-old woman. He was cleared of all charges by the court in 2012. Kelly retired from professional football at the end of the 2016 season. In 2019, he was selected in the West Coast Eagles' Team of the Decade.

Sebastián Arce (born 30 November 1987) is an Argentine professional footballer who plays as a centre-back for Independiente Santa Fe. ## Career Sebastián Arce was born in Mar del Plata, Argentina. He made his professional debut in the Primera División for Godoy Cruz on 1 October 2005 in a game against Estudiantes de La Plata. That was his only league appearance for Godoy Cruz, before he joined Independiente Rivadavia in 2006. He made his debut for Independiente Rivadavia on 18 March 2007 in a game against Banfield. He played for Independiente Rivadavia for three years, making a total of 65 appearances and scoring one goal. In 2009, he joined Argentine 2nd division side All Boys. He played for All Boys for one season, making a total of 26 appearances. In 2010, he joined Independiente del Valle, and in 2011 he joined Godoy Cruz. In 2012, he joined Estudiantes de La Plata. He made his debut for Estudiantes on 21 September 2012 in a game against Independiente. He played for Estudiantes for three seasons, making a total of 46 appearances. In 2015, he joined Independiente Santa Fe. He made his debut for Santa Fe on 8 August 2015 in a game against La Equidad. He has made a total of 51 appearances and has scored 2 goals for Santa Fe.

The network was founded by Jim McKelvey, CEO of Square, Inc., and his business partner, David Lieberman, in 2014. The network's flagship show, The Square, which debuted in July 2015, features McKelvey as its host and follows companies that use Square to process payments. The network also produces and airs the talk show Path Forward, which is hosted by Bob Circosta and dedicated to female business owners, as well as the reality show StartUp, which follows entrepreneurs as they pitch their ideas to investors. Bristol City (1919) The Bristol City was a British automobile manufactured by the British & Colonial Motor Co from 1919 to 1922. The car was designed by G.W. Barry, the designer of the British & Colonial's previous offering, the British & Colonial G.W.K. The car was manufactured at the British & Colonial factory in Filton, Bristol, England and was powered by a choice of engines including a 1,323cc four-cylinder or a 1, brewed by the British & Colonial Motor Co and was in production from 1919 to 1922. The car was designed by G.W. Barry, the designer of the British & Colonial's previous offering, the British & Colonial G.W.K. The car was manufactured at the British & Colonial factory in Filton, Bristol, England and was powered by a choice of engines including a 1,323cc four-cylinder or a 1, brewed by the British & Colonial Motor Co and was in production from 1919 to 1922. The car was designed by G.W. Barry, the designer of the British & Colonial's previous offering, the British & Colonial G.W.K. The car was manufactured at the British & Colonial factory in Filton, Bristol, England and was powered by a choice of engines including a 1,323cc four-cylinder or a 1, brewed by the British & Colonial Motor Co and was in production from 1919 to 1922.

Wengernalp Railway The Wengernalp Railway (German: Wengernalpbahn) is a metre gauge railway in Switzerland. It runs from Lauterbrunnen to a station at the foot of the Wengen Alps, and was opened in 1890. The line runs for 5.33 km, and has a total of 33 stops. The Wengernalp Railway is the only rack and pinion railway in Switzerland, and was the first electric railway to be built in the country. The line was constructed to provide a link between the village of Wengen and the Lauterbrunnen valley. The line was designed by Robert Gerwig, and was built by the Wengernalp Railway Company, which was formed in 1886. The company was taken over by the Wengen AG in 1922, and the line was then sold to the Jungfraubahn AG in 1963. The Wengernalp Railway uses a Fell rack system, and is powered by a 1,000 volt DC electricity supply. The line has two sections of track, which are connected by a rack section. The first section runs for 2.55 km, and the second for 2.78 km. The gradient of the line is 1 in 2.5, and the maximum speed is 10 km/h. The Wengernalp Railway is operated by the Wengen AG, and is integrated into the Bernese Oberland Transport Network. The line is served by trains running between Lauterbrunnen and Wengen, and by trains running between Grindelwald and Wengen. The line also provides a connection to the Jungfrau Railway at the Kleine Scheidegg station.

Third Mind Records is an American independent record label, founded in 1993 in San Francisco, California, by Gary Richards, a former employee of 415 Records. The label has released material by artists including The Brian Jonestown Massacre, The reformed Jesus and Mary Chain, The Electric Prunes, The Church, Spacemen 3, and The Bevis Frond. Third Mind was originally conceived as a vehicle for releasing experimental music. Its first release was an album by the band Swingin' Neckbones, entitled Hot Box, which was released in 1993. In 1995, the label released a series of albums by Spacemen 3, a band from Rugby, Warwickshire, England, which was the first of several bands to sign to Third Mind from the UK. The Spacemen 3 releases were repackaged and re-released by Sony Music's Epic Records in 1996. The label released The Brian Jonestown Massacre's first three albums, and their self-titled album is often considered to be Third Mind's most well-known release. In 1996, Third Mind released the first Jesus and Mary Chain album since their original breakup, entitled Stoned & Dethroned. The label also released the first new Electric Prunes material since the band's original breakup, a single entitled "Shine on Me" in 1996. The Electric Prunes subsequently released a full-length album, Martinis and Bikinis, on Third Mind in 1998. In 1997, Third Mind released an album by The Bevis Frond, and a live album by The Church. The label also released a series of singles by The Electric Prunes, including a cover version of the Rolling Stones' "Paint it Black", and a collaboration with the band Spacehog, entitled "Squeal Like a Pig". In 1999, the label released an album by the band Fuzztones, and a live album by The Brian Jonestown Massacre. In 2000, the label released an album by The Bevis Frond, and a live album by The Church. Third Mind's releases were initially distributed by Sony Music's Epic Records, and then by Island Records. The label's most recent releases have been distributed by independent distributors such as Darla, In Sound, and Future Primitive.

James Lockhart (historian) James Lockhart (born December 10, 1929) is an American historian of the colonial Spanish Borderlands. Lockhart was born in Washington, D.C. and grew up in Maryland. He is the son of William Lockhart, a career U.S. Army officer, and his wife, the former Jean multimillionaire socialite Martha Field. His parents married in 1928, three months before the Wall Street crash. They divorced in 1945. After graduating from St. Albans School in Washington, D.C. in 1947, Lockhart attended Harvard University, where he graduated in 1951 with an A.B. in Spanish. He then joined the U.S. Foreign Service, serving in the Dominican Republic, Guatemala, and Mexico, where he studied Mexican history. In 1960, he married his first wife, Alice, a Mexican from a prominent family. The following year, he transferred to the State Department's Bureau of Intelligence and Research, where he worked as a researcher on Latin America. In 1965, he joined the faculty of the University of Texas at Austin as an assistant professor of history. He was promoted to associate professor in 1968 and to professor of history in 1977. He retired in 2007. In 1976, Lockhart published The Spanish Republic and Civil War, 1932–39, the first of his several books on the history of Spain. This work explored the role of the Spanish Republic's foreign policy in the face of fascist aggression and the assistance provided to the Republicans by the International Brigades. He followed this with a short book on the history of Mexico, The Military, the Church, and the Jews: Culture, Society, and Politics in Mexico, 1531–1783 (1983). This was the basis for a documentary film of the same name that he produced for the A&E Network in 1984. In 1992, he published the first of two volumes on the history of Spanish Texas, Spain's Frontier Colony: The Weeki Wachee District of West Florida, 1821–1845. The second volume, Spain's Hidden Empire: The Quest for El Dorado, was published in 1996. In 1999, he produced a documentary film on the history of the Spanish missions in the United States for the A&E Network. In 2006, Lockhart was the recipient of the Spain-USA Foundation's "Casa de Canavos" award, which is given to "an American scholar or personality who has made an outstanding contribution to the study and understanding of Spanish culture and its numerous contributions to the United States and the world." In 2013, Lockhart's personal and family papers were donated to the University of Texas at Austin. The papers, which span the years 1920 to 2013, include correspondence, notes, drafts of articles and books, photographs, maps, and recordings.

San Giovanni Battista, Rimini The Church of San Giovanni Battista is a church in Rimini, Italy. It is one of the best-known and most significant monuments in the city, and it is one of the most important examples of Gothic architecture in the region. The church is located in the old part of the city, not far from the Piazza Malatesta and the Church of Santa Maria in Foro. It is dedicated to John the Baptist. The church was built in the 14th century, and it has been rebuilt and modified several times since then. The most significant modification was made in the 18th century, when the church was given a new facade in the neoclassical style. The current appearance of the church is the result of a restoration that was carried out in the 20th century. The church is built in the Gothic style, and it has a tall and narrow facade. The facade is decorated with a large rose window and several smaller windows. The interior of the church is also Gothic, and it is divided into three naves. The central nave is higher and wider than the side naves. The vault of the central nave is decorated with a large fresco that depicts the Last Judgment. The side naves have smaller frescoes that depict the life of John the Baptist. The church also has several other artistic treasures, including a wooden crucifix that is believed to be the work of Giotto, a painting by Giovanni Bellini, and a marble statue of John the Baptist by Antonio Canova. The church is a major tourist attraction in Rimini, and it is a popular destination for visitors to the city. It is also a venue for concerts and other cultural events.

Philippine Underwater Hockey Confederation The Philippine Underwater Hockey Confederation is the governing body of underwater hockey in the Philippines. The confederation was founded on December 9, 2008, and was registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission on January 16, 2009. It is a non-stock, non-profit organization and is currently headed by General Secretary Frederick Ong. The confederation is recognized by the Philippine Olympic Committee and is an affiliate of the Underwater Hockey Confederation. Tournaments The confederation regularly holds the following tournaments: - Philippine National Underwater Hockey Championships - Philippine National Underwater Hockey Open - South East Asia Underwater Hockey Championships Affiliates The confederation has six affiliate associations, namely: - Underwater Hockey of the Philippines (UHP) - based in Metro Manila - Underwater Hockey Baguio (UHB) - based in Baguio - Underwater Hockey Cebu (UHC) - based in Cebu - Underwater Hockey Davao (UHD) - based in Davao - Underwater Hockey Iloilo (UHI) - based in Iloilo - Underwater Hockey Panglao (UHP) - based in Panglao, Bohol

The Bifid cipher is one of the simplest substitution ciphers. It is a manual cipher in which the plaintext is encrypted by repeatedly moving through a set of 26 alternative encryption alphabets. Each encryption alphabet is a simple Caesar cipher. The name "bifid" comes from the fact that each encryption alphabet is half the width of the plaintext alphabet.
