Calvin–Hope men's basketball rivalry The Calvin–Hope men's basketball rivalry is a college basketball rivalry between the Calvin Knights and the Hope Flying Dutchmen. The two teams have faced each other twice every year since 1960. Calvin College and Hope College are both located in Michigan, approximately 35 miles (56 km) apart. The schools are both private, four-year institutions with similar student enrollments (Calvin: 3,400; Hope: 3,200) and religious roots. The schools are also both members of the Michigan Intercollegiate Athletic Association, and the two men's basketball teams have been the MIAA's most successful programs since the turn of the millennium. The rivalry has been characterized by intense competition, close games, and a friendly rivalry between the two schools off the court. The rivalry was listed by Sports Illustrated as one of the 20 biggest rivalries in college basketball. In 2002, the teams combined to sell out every regular-season game at both schools' arenas. The two teams have won a combined 19 MIAA regular-season titles since 1996, including 15 by Calvin. The Knights have won the MIAA Tournament 14 times since 1996, while the Flying Dutch have won it six times. In the NCAA Division III Tournament, the two schools have faced each other five times, with Calvin winning in 1996, 1998, 2000, and 2002, and Hope winning in 2014.

Bura Irrigation and Settlement Project (Kenya) The Bura Irrigation and Settlement Project is an irrigation project in Kenya, on the Tana River in the Coast Province. It was initiated in the late 1970s, and the first phase was completed in 1988. The project has two components, the irrigation scheme and the settlement scheme. The irrigation scheme involves the construction of a dam on the Tana River, which will provide water for irrigation to farmers in the Tana River District. The settlement scheme involves the construction of a new town, which will provide housing for the farmers who will be displaced by the irrigation scheme. The project has been criticized for its environmental impact, and for its potential to cause social dislocation. The dam will flood a large area of the Tana River, and will change the way of life for many people who live along the river. The new town will also have a significant impact on the landscape, and will require the displacement of many people. The project is being implemented by the Kenya Sugar Board, and is being funded by the government of Kenya and by the World Bank.

Ruth Gregory (born Ruth Ion; 1 November 1927 – 5 January 2017) was a British philosopher and historian of philosophy. She was the first woman to be appointed a full-time philosophy professor in the UK. Gregory was born in 1927 in Beijing, Republic of China. Her father, Robert Eric Ion, was a British businessman and her mother, Helen, was from a Chinese family. The family moved to England in 1939, shortly before the Japanese invasion of China. Gregory was educated at Roedean School, near Brighton, and then read history at Somerville College, Oxford, where she gained a double first-class degree. After a brief spell as a civil servant, she returned to Somerville as a tutor in history of philosophy. She married the philosopher Richard Gregory in 1951. In 1957, Gregory was appointed professor of history of philosophy at the University of Aberdeen. She was the first woman to be appointed a full-time philosophy professor in the UK. She also held visiting appointments at Harvard University, the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, New Jersey, and the Chinese University of Hong Kong. Gregory's publications included The Shadow of Cebes (1995), a translation of the Greek philosopher Theophrastus's work on the Presocratics, and In Defence of a Dog: Galileo and the Counter-Reformation (2008), a study of the trial of Galileo Galilei. Her edition of The Essential Writings, published in 2002, is the standard collection of Galileo's writings. Gregory was elected a fellow of the British Academy in 1999. She was an honorary fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, an honorary fellow of Somerville College, Oxford, and a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. She died on 5 January 2017 at the age of 89.

Stampede is a 1949 American Western film directed by Lesley Selander and written by Norman S. Hall. The film stars Rod Cameron, his real-life wife Janis Carter, Jim Davis, and Harry Morgan. The film was released in 1949, by United Artists. In the film, a man is murdered in a small town, and the only clue is an odd-looking footprint. The town's sheriff (Jim Davis) calls in a noted tracker (Rod Cameron), who soon discovers a herd of strange-looking cattle with three toes, not four. He traces the cattle to a nearby ranch, where the owner (Harry Morgan) has been experimenting with a hormone to produce more meat. However, the hormone has a side effect, causing the cattle to become extremely aggressive. The tracker tries to warn the townspeople, but it's too late. The cattle go on the offensive, killing several people and causing a stampede. The tracker and the sheriff try to stop the stampede, but it's a losing battle until the tracker has an idea: he sets the cattle's watering hole on fire, driving the herd back into the desert. The film was shot in the Alabama Hills of Lone Pine, California.

Syed Shah Israil (Urdu: سيد شاہ عزمت سره) was a Pakistani writer, researcher, historian, and scholar who is known for his work on the history of Pakistan, particularly the history of the Sindhi people and the Sindhi language. He has been described as one of the "most authoritative and pioneering historians" of Pakistan. Syed Shah Israil was born on October 1, 1930, in Hyderabad, Sindh, in a literary family. His father, Syed Muhammad Akber, was a noted educationist, and his mother, Zubaida, was a housewife. He received his early education at the Hyderabad Public School and the University of Sindh, and then attended the University of Bombay, where he received a master's degree in history. He then went to the University of Cambridge, where he received a second master's degree and a PhD in history. Israil's research focused on the history of the Sindhi people and the Sindhi language. He was a strong advocate for the preservation of the Sindhi language and culture, and he wrote extensively on these subjects. He was also a noted scholar of the Indus Valley civilization, and he wrote several books and articles on the subject. Israil was a professor of history at the University of Sindh, and he was the director of the Institute of Sindhology at the university. He was also a member of the Pakistan Historical Society and the Sindh Historical Society. Israil was awarded the President of Pakistan's Award for Pride of Performance, one of the highest civilian awards in Pakistan, for his contributions to the field of history and culture. He was also awarded the Sitara-i-Imtiaz, one of the highest civilian awards in Pakistan, for his contributions to the field of history and culture. Israil died on July 18, 2018, in Karachi, Sindh, at the age of 87. He was buried at the Sakhi Shah Israil shrine in Matiari, Sindh.

Megaupload legal case On 19 January 2012, the United States Department of Justice charged seven individuals and two companies, Megaupload and Megavideo, with criminal copyright infringement. The companies' two principal owners, Kim Dotcom and his wife Mona, were arrested in New Zealand on 20 January 2012. The investigation into Megaupload began in 2008, when the company's website was used to store and distribute a pirated copy of the film The Hurt Locker. In 2010, an investigator took advantage of Megaupload's policy of giving free storage space to users who uploaded a large number of files, and uploaded a large number of files himself, none of which were copyright-infringing. This allowed the investigator to download the rest of the files on the site without any copyright-infringing material, and he identified several other copyrighted works that had been uploaded to the site. In August 2010, the FBI obtained a search warrant to enter the residences of Dotcom and his colleagues, but delayed the execution of the search warrant to avoid potential diplomatic complications, as Dotcom's residence was in New Zealand, a country with which the United States has an extradition treaty. The FBI obtained additional warrants to search the Megaupload corporate offices in Hong Kong and the Megavideo corporate offices in the United States. On 9 February 2012, Dotcom's lawyers filed a "Notice of Intention to Stand on Defective Search Warrant" in New Zealand. On 17 February 2012, the New Zealand High Court ruled that the search warrants were invalid, as the court had not been presented with evidence of criminal copyright infringement. As a result, the New Zealand government officially returned the seized property to Dotcom. On 20 February 2012, the U.S. government filed a request with the New Zealand government to extradite Dotcom. In July 2012, the New Zealand government rejected the request, citing that the United States had not provided enough information to extradite Dotcom, and that Dotcom's arrest had been improper. On 24 August 2012, the United States launched a second request for Dotcom's extradition. In December 2012, New Zealand granted the United States' request, and Dotcom's legal team launched a second appeal. On 17 April 2013, the New Zealand Court of Appeal ruled that Dotcom could be extradited to the United States. Dotcom's legal team stated that they would file a further appeal with the New Zealand Supreme Court. In February 2013, the United States Department of Justice had stated that it was working to have Dotcom returned to the United States, and that "the proper thing to do is for New Zealand to extradite Mr. Dotcom to the United States."

The Epic of American Civilization The Epic of American Civilization is a late 20th-century epic poem by the Chicano author Rudolfo Anaya. It is Anaya's most ambitious work, consisting of three parts in thirty-seven chapters. The first part, "The Great Songs of the Family", covers the history of the Anaya family from its roots in the ancient past to the present. The second part, "The New World", covers the history of the Chicano people in the United States from the early 20th century to the 1960s. The third part, "The Blood of the Conquistador", focuses on a single character, a mixed-race boy who is a product of the Mexican-Anglo culture war. The Epic of American Civilization is an attempt to create a Chicano version of the Spanish epic, the "Epic of the Cid". Anaya's epic is a story of the survival and triumph of the Chicano culture, in spite of the many challenges it has faced. It is a story of a people who have had to fight for their land and their rights, and who have overcome great odds to preserve their culture. The epic is a celebration of the Chicano people and their culture, and it is a call to action for Chicanos to continue to fight for their rights and their culture.

"By the Light of the Moon (The Vampire Diaries)" is the eighteenth episode of the fifth season and the 103rd episode overall from the supernatural drama television series The Vampire Diaries. The episode was written by Michael Grassi and was directed by Rob Hardy. It was originally aired on February 19, 2015 on The CW. In the episode, after learning from Elena that she has chosen to be with Damon, Stefan suffers from nightmares of a life he could have had with Elena. Caroline and Matt try to figure out a way to keep their secret about the pregnancy from Elena. Elsewhere, Tripp (leader of the community protection program) threatens to expose Matt and Caroline's secret to Elena, so they decide to speed up their plan to marry. At the end of the episode, Matt and Caroline get married with their friends and family in attendance, while Stefan gets drunk and crashes Jeremy and Matt's bachelor party. The episode received generally positive reviews. The episode was watched by 1.48 million viewers with a 0.6/2 share among adults aged 18–49. This episode is named after a song by The Animals. In 1492, a young Stefan is tormenting his older sister, Lily, who is to be married to a vampire named Fotis. Stefan asks for forgiveness from his sister, but she refuses, so he kills Fotis. Before she dies, Fotis curses Stefan to walk the earth as a vampire. In the present day, Stefan and Elena have been dating for six months, and Elena tells Stefan that she wants to be with Damon. Stefan is upset, and has nightmares about a life he could have had with Elena. At the end of the episode, it is revealed that the "Elena" in Stefan's nightmare was actually his sister, Lily, and the "Stefan" in the nightmare was Fotis. Lily tells Stefan that she will see him in another life, hinting that they will be together again.

Windhorse (film) Windhorse is a 1993 American drama film directed by Carroll Ballard and starring Richard Harris, Robert Wisdom, and Jeremy Irons. The film is based on the life of Frank Farmar, a horse trainer and jockey who, after suffering a career-ending injury, turned to training racehorses. The film is set in the horse racing industry in general and the sport of Steeplechase racing in particular. The title refers to the "wind horse," or "invisible horse" in Tibetan culture, a concept of happiness and good fortune, and the horse that carries the wind. Frank Farmar (Wisdom) is a gifted jockey and horse trainer whose career is ended by a serious fall. He begins training racehorses for wealthy businessman Sir Henry Lee (Irons), but the emotionally damaged Farmar is unable to take pleasure in his work. In a desperate attempt to regain his love for life, he decides to breed and train his own horse, despite his lack of money and resources. Farmar becomes emotionally attached to a young horse he names Windhorse, and his journey to heal himself is paralleled with the horse's own journey to recover from a broken leg. Windhorse was nominated for the Grand Jury Prize at the 1993 Sundance Film Festival. The film's theme song, "This House," was written and performed by Bruce Hornsby. The film was released on DVD by Warner Home Video on September 27, 2005. Carroll Ballard later directed a television series based on the film, also called Windhorse, which premiered on CBS in 1998. Windhorse (film) is a 1993 American drama film directed by Carroll Ballard and starring Richard Harris, Robert Wisdom, and Jeremy Irons. The film is based on the life of Frank Farmar, a horse trainer and jockey who, after suffering a career-ending injury, turned to training racehorses.

A Fable for Critics is a poem by James Boswell that ridicules the artificiality and excessive reliance on literary devices of the 18th-century British school of poetry, in particular that of Samuel Johnson and his circle. The title is a reference to Aesop's Fables, and the work is accordingly composed of a collection of 18 "fables" which are lightly veiled satires of the fashionable literary genres of the day. The genres targeted include the "epistle", the "song", the "epic" and the "tragedy", with the deadpan moral to each fable delivered in the style of the original. In the poem, Boswell ridicules the contemporary fashion for heightened sentiment and orotundity, andasters such as Johnson and his circle with their obsession for all things classical and their pedantic coterie. In the process, Boswell reveals himself to be, in the words of one critic, "a young man with a very high opinion of his own abilities and a very low one of other people's". The poem was never published during Boswell's lifetime, and the only known copy was lost in the 1920s. It was eventually published in the 1950s, after a single leaf of the text was discovered in the back of a copy of The Works of Samuel Johnson, a 19th-century edition. This leaf was sold in 1952 to a private buyer by the London bookseller Harold Mortlake, and the buyer had it bound with another 18th-century poem, "The Life of an Author", also allegedly by Boswell. This copy was sold by the same bookseller to the British Library in 1956. A typescript of the poem was also sold to the Scottish historian William Teeling in the 1950s, and this was eventually donated to the University of Aberdeen.

Benthem v Netherlands (Court of Justice of the EU) Benthem v Netherlands was a case heard by the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) on 11 November 2008. The case concerned the right of Dutch citizens to challenge legislation passed by the Dutch Parliament, and the relationship between the EU's legislative procedure and that of its member states. The case was initiated by Vera Benthem, a Dutch citizen, who challenged the constitutionality of the EU's Treaty of Nice, which had been passed into Dutch law in 2003. Benthem argued that the treaty, which was designed to amend the EU's institutions in preparation for the introduction of a Constitution, had been improperly adopted by the Dutch Parliament. She claimed that the treaty lacked a sufficient number of votes in favour of its adoption, and that the procedure used for its passage had been invalid. The Court of Amsterdam initially heard the case, and found in favour of Benthem, ruling that the Treaty of Nice was unconstitutional and that its adoption had been improper. The Dutch Government subsequently appealed to the CJEU. In its judgment, the CJEU held that the Treaty of Nice had been validly adopted by the Dutch Parliament, and that the procedure used for its adoption had been in line with the requirements of Dutch law. The Court further held that, while Dutch citizens did have the right to challenge the constitutionality of legislation passed by the Dutch Parliament, this could only be done within a limited time period, and that Benthem's challenge had been brought outside of this period. The case is significant as it is one of the first in which the CJEU has ruled on the relationship between the EU's legislative procedure and that of its member states, and on the right of citizens to challenge the constitutionality of legislation passed by their national parliaments.

The Brunhes–Matuyama reversal, also known as the Brunhes–Matuyama transition, was a planetary-scale reversal of the Earth's magnetic field that occurred relatively recently in the Earth's history, approximately 774,000 years ago. The event has been dated to the abrupt onset of the Matuyama period, an interval of reversed polarity in the Earth's magnetic field, which has lasted until the present day. The Earth's magnetic field is a vector quantity, characterized by both strength and direction, and is a result of the convection currents in the Earth's liquid core. The Earth's core has an internal magnetic field that is approximately equal in strength to the field observed on the Earth's surface. However, the direction of the internal magnetic field is opposite to that of the surface field: the north magnetic pole is located in the Earth's south, and vice versa. The Earth's field is the result of the interaction of the internal field with the surface field, and is characterized by a number of different components. The Brunhes–Matuyama reversal is the most recent magnetic reversal of the Earth's surface field. The previous reversal, the Olduvai event, occurred approximately 1.5 million years ago. There have been at least 100 reversals in the last 70 million years. The Brunhes–Matuyama reversal was first identified in 1906 by the French geophysicist Bernard Brunhes. Brunhes discovered the event by studying the magnetic properties of samples of volcanic rocks from the Pacific coast of Japan, which had been collected during a Japanese expedition to the Bonin Islands in 1895. The samples were of the right age to be associated with the Brunhes–Matuyama reversal, and the reversal was eventually confirmed by the measurement of the magnetic properties of other rocks and sediments. The Brunhes–Matuyama reversal is of particular interest because it corresponds to a period of dramatic climate change, including a number of rapid and intense glacial episodes. The reversal also corresponds to a period of increased volcanic activity, and a number of large volcanic eruptions have been dated to the Brunhes–Matuyama period. The Brunhes–Matuyama reversal is thought to have been caused by a process of secular variation, in which the Earth's magnetic field slowly changes in strength and direction over time. The secular variation is thought to be driven by the convection currents in the Earth's core, which are in turn driven by the heat from the Earth's interior. The Brunhes–Matuyama reversal was a particularly intense episode of secular variation, and the sudden change in the direction of the Earth's magnetic field had a number of dramatic effects on the Earth's climate and environment.

A chromatrope is an optical instrument that reflects a continuously moving spectrum of colors. It is sometimes called a "color top" or a "rainbow top." The chromatrope consists of a disk or a drum-shaped object with a series of holes or slits in the circumference. The holes are evenly spaced around the disk, and each hole has a different color. The disk is mounted on a rotating shaft. When the chromatrope is rotated, the holes or slits allow the user to view a continuously moving spectrum of colors. The speed of the moving spectrum can be controlled by adjusting the speed of the rotation. The chromatrope can be used as a scientific instrument to study the properties of light, or as a decorative item. It is often used as a demonstration tool in physics classrooms to show the separation of light into its constituent colors. The chromatrope is similar to the spectroscope, which is used to analyze the spectrum of light from a distant source. However, the chromatrope is used to generate a spectrum, rather than to analyze one.

William Cullen Bryant was an American romantic poet, journalist, editor, and professor. He is known for his promotion of poetry and higher education, and for his efforts to make poetry a profession. He has been called the "Father of American Poetry". The New York Evening Post, which he edited for forty years, was the most influential newspaper in the United States. With Henry W. Longfellow, James Russell Lowell, and Oliver Wendell Holmes, Jr., he was one of the five Fireside Poets. In 1821, Bryant graduated from Williams College, and he joined the staff of the New York Evening Post the following year. He traveled to Europe in 1825, where he met Samuel Taylor Coleridge and William Blake. He became the sole editor of the New York Evening Post in 1826, and he married Frances Cox of Philadelphia the same year. In 1829, he published his first major work, Thanatopsis, a poem that helped to popularize the concept of death as a beautiful experience. In 1834, he became a professor of languages at New York University, and he held the position for twenty years. In 1837, he was one of the founders of the American Literary Society. In 1845, he published his first volume of poetry, which included the poem "To a Waterfowl", often anthologized. In 1846, he was appointed editor of the Review magazine. In 1847, he published his second volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Country Church". In 1848, he was appointed professor of English literature at the newly formed New York City College. In 1850, he published his third volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Death of the Flowers". In 1851, he was appointed professor of poetry at the University of New York. In 1854, he published his fourth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Rose Buds". In 1855, he was appointed professor of moral philosophy at the University of New York. In 1856, he published his fifth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Life and Death of a Tree". In 1859, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of New York. In 1861, he published his sixth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Patriot". In 1868, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of Virginia. In 1870, he published his seventh volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Death of Philip Livingston". In 1871, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of South Carolina. In 1872, he published his eighth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Life of Captain William Cullen Bryant". In 1873, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of North Carolina. In 1874, he published his ninth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Song of the Redwood Tree". In 1875, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of Mississippi. In 1876, he published his tenth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Death of General Grant". In 1877, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of Georgia. In 1878, he published his eleventh volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Life of John Keats". In 1881, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of Virginia. In 1882, he published his twelfth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Last of the Forest". In 1883, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of North Carolina. In 1884, he published his thirteenth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Song of the Sea". In 1885, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of South Carolina. In 1886, he published his fourteenth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Life of Robert Browning". In 1888, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of North Carolina. In 1889, he published his fifteenth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Death of General Grant". In 1891, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of South Carolina. In 1892, he published his sixteenth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Life of John Milton". In 1893, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of Virginia. In 1895, he published his seventeenth volume of poetry, which included the poem "The Death of the Flowers". In 1898, he was appointed professor of literature at the University of Virginia.

Malate dehydrogenase (NADP+) Malate dehydrogenase (MDH) is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of malate into oxaloacetate using NADP+ as a cofactor. This enzyme, along with its substrate and cofactor, is involved in the citric acid cycle, specifically in the reduction of oxaloacetate to malate. This reduction is necessary in order to maintain the balance of the cycle, as the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA results in the production of oxaloacetate. The enzyme is found in the cytosol of mesophyll cells in plants, and in the sarcoplasm of skeletal muscle in animals. In plant cells, MDH is involved in the anaplerotic reaction which produces oxaloacetate from acetyl-CoA. This reaction is part of the glyoxylate bypass, which allows the formation of glucose from carbon dioxide in the absence of a functional glycolytic pathway. In animals, the MDH found in skeletal muscle is involved in the breakdown of glucose to produce lactate, which is necessary for the contractile function of muscles. This breakdown is known as glycolysis, and the energy released is used to fuel the movements of the body. The enzyme is a homodimer, meaning it is composed of two identical subunits. Each subunit has a molecular weight of approximately 37 kDa. It is also a membrane-associated protein, meaning that it is bound to the plasma membrane of the cell. In the plant enzyme, this binding is via a transit peptide, which is a short amino acid sequence that directs the enzyme to the plasma membrane. In the animal enzyme, however, the binding is more loosely defined, and the enzyme may also be found in the cytosol. The primary structure of malate dehydrogenase is very similar across species, although there are some differences. The enzyme is a decamer, meaning it is composed of ten amino acid chains. The primary sequence of these chains is as follows, with the bold letters representing the amino acids that are identical to the consensus sequence: [A]-[B]-[C]-[D]-[E]-[F]-[G]-[H]-[I]-[J] The secondary structure of the enzyme is also similar across species, although the loops of the protein are usually different. The secondary structure of the enzyme is as follows: The active site of the enzyme is located at the C-terminal end, and it is here that the substrate binds to the enzyme. The active site contains a large number of negatively-charged amino acids, which are necessary for the binding of the positively-charged substrate. The enzyme is activated by the binding of NADP+, which is the cofactor for the reaction. This binding results in the formation of a complex between the enzyme and the cofactor. The complex is then able to bind to the substrate and catalyze the conversion of malate into oxaloacetate. The enzyme is also regulated by the levels of the substrate and the cofactor in the cell. In plants, the enzyme is typically activated by the increase in light intensity, which results in the increase in the levels of carbon dioxide in the cell. In animals, the enzyme is typically activated by the increase in the levels of lactate in the cell.

Luke Rhinehart (born 1930) is an American writer and physician best known for his novel The Dice Man, a fictionalized autobiography about a psychiatrist who, as part of an experiment, embarks on a journey of self-discovery by making decisions based on the roll of a die. Born in Germany, Rhinehart was raised in the United States and attended college at the University of Wisconsin. He then attended medical school at the University of California, San Francisco. He completed his residency in New York City and fellowship in London. After residency, he joined the U.S. Public Health Service as a researcher at the National Institutes of Health, where he studied the effects of radiation on mice. In 1967, after two years of research, he left the Public Health Service to write fiction full-time. His first works were two novels, The Book of the Die and The Concrete River, neither of which were commercially successful. In 1970, he published The Dice Man, which became a surprise bestseller. The book's title refers to the die that the narrator uses to make decisions, and the story is a fictionalized autobiography. The book was a critical success and was adapted into a movie starring Richard Dreyfuss. In 1978, he published the novel The Search, which was not as commercially successful as The Dice Man, but was critically acclaimed. In 1982, he published the non-fiction book, The Book of Lists, which was a collection of lists that he had created for his own personal use. In 1984, he published the novel, Whack Job, which was a return to the style of The Dice Man and was also commercially successful. In addition to his novels, Rhinehart has also written several volumes of short stories, as well as a collection of essays.

Jean-Jacques Reubell (10 May 1923 – 11 March 2018) was a French classical pianist. Reubell was born in Paris, France. He studied at the Conservatoire de Paris, winning the first prize in piano in 1943, and later with Alfred Cortot. In 1947, he won the International Festival of Cultural Relations with France prize, which enabled him to perform in Belgium, Italy, and the UK. He also won the Grand Prix des Amis de Maurice Ravel in 1949, the Paris Conservatory's First Grand Prix in 1950, and the VIII International Piano Competition in Moscow in 1951. He became a professor at the Conservatoire de Paris in 1961, and was its director from 1991 to 1997. He was also a member of the jury of the International Piano Competition of Montreal in 1980, and of the International Chopin Piano Competition in Warsaw in 1985 and 1993. Reubell gave concerts in Europe, Asia, and South America. He made recordings for the Harmonia Mundi, La Voix de Son Maître, and Erato labels. Reubell died in Paris, France, at the age of 94.

Elijah H. Workman (September 21, 1817 – November 13, 1901) was an American politician and businessman. Workman was born in Mount Pleasant, New York in 1817. He attended Union College and graduated in 1837. He moved to Indiana in 1839 and settled in Marion County. He was a member of the Indiana House of Representatives from 1843 to 1844 and from 1847 to 1848. He was a member of the Indiana Senate from 1852 to 1856. In 1856, he was an unsuccessful candidate for the Republican nomination for Indiana governor. He was a member of the Indiana House of Representatives from 1873 to 1874. He was the president of the Marion County Board of Agriculture from 1873 to 1874. He was a delegate to the Republican National Convention from 1880 to 1888. In 1888, he was an unsuccessful candidate for the Republican nomination for U.S. Representative from Indiana. Workman was the founder and president of the Union Laundry Company, a company that manufactured laundry machinery. He was also a director of the Marion County Savings Bank and the president of the National Malleable Castings Company. He was a member of the Indianapolis Board of Trade and the president of the Indiana Manufacturers Association. Workman died in Indianapolis, Indiana in 1901.

Grace Vamos (May 30, 1918 – June 3, 2007) was an American musician, singer, songwriter, and actress of Greek descent, known for her work in the Lawrence Welk Show. Vamos was born in Detroit, Michigan, to Greek immigrant parents, George and Mildred Vamos. She had three older siblings. She attended Detroit's public schools and graduated from Detroit's Central High School in 1935. She studied the violin at an early age and was a singer and dancer in the high school's drama club. She attended the University of Michigan for one year, then transferred to the Juilliard School of Music in New York City, where she studied singing and violin. Vamos began her performing career in Detroit clubs, where she met her future husband, George Bell, a trumpeter and bandleader. The couple moved to New York City, where Vamos became a member of the Paul Lavalle Orchestra and the Henry Jerome Orchestra. She also worked in the Detroit-based radio station WXYZ's drama department. In 1948, Vamos and her husband moved to Los Angeles, where she joined the Lawrence Welk Show as a singer, musician, and actress. She remained with the show for 14 years, until the early 1960s. She and her husband, who also performed on the show, appeared together in many musical numbers. Vamos was known for her beauty, grace, and ability to sing in Spanish, Portuguese, and English. After leaving the Welk show, Vamos and her husband, along with two other couples, bought a restaurant in Los Angeles, the Spanish Kitchen, which they operated for several years. She also worked as a real estate agent and investor. Vamos died at her home in Los Angeles at the age of 89. She was survived by her husband, George Bell, two sisters, and a brother.

Haas VF-18 The Haas VF-18 is a Formula One racing car designed and built by Gene Haas's team Haas F1 Team for use in the 2018 FIA Formula One World Championship. The chassis was designed by Nick Chester, Ben Agathangelou, and Peter Gachet with the collaboration of producer Guenther Steiner and driver Romain Grosjean. The VF-18 was powered by Ferrari's 2018-19 F1 engine, the 062/3 1.6-liter V6 turbocharged hybrid power unit, making it the first American Formula One team to use a Ferrari engine and the first to use a hybrid power unit. The VF-18 was the first Formula One car to be designed fully using computer-aided design, with all aerodynamic parts being designed using computational fluid dynamics. The VF-18 was launched online on the team's website on February 20, 2018, and made its track debut at the 2018 Bahrain Grand Prix. The car made its competitive debut at the first round of the 2018 Formula One World Championship, the Australian Grand Prix, where it finished fourth and fifth with its drivers Romain Grosjean and Kevin Magnussen. The VF-18 took its first podium at the Austrian Grand Prix, where Romain Grosjean finished third. The VF-18 took its first win at the Brazilian Grand Prix, where once again Romain Grosjean was driving. The VF-18 finished the season in fifth place in the constructors' standings, with only one more podium finish and no other wins. The VF-18's best result in the constructors' standings was in 2016, when it finished fourth with 176 points. The VF-18's best result in the drivers' standings was in 2015, when it finished fifth with 138 points.

Kalai Kovil The Kalai Kovil (also known as the Kali Kovil) is a Tamil temple, dedicated to the Hindu deity Kali, located in the town of Kalai in the Indian state of Tamil Nadu. The temple is believed to have been built by the Chola king Parantaka I, who ruled from c. undefined 935 to c. undefined 955. The temple is one of four in the town dedicated to Kali, the others being the Amma Temple, the Manicka Vinayagar Temple and the Mariamman Temple. The Kalai Kovil is located in the centre of the town of Kalai, 2 kilometres (1.2 mi) from the town's railway station. The temple is dedicated to the Hindu goddess Kali, and is one of four in the town dedicated to the deity, the others being the Amma Temple, the Manicka Vinayagar Temple and the Mariamman Temple. The temple is built on a 2-acre (8,000 m2) plot of land, and is surrounded by a granite wall 8 ft (2.4 m) high. The four gopuras, the monumental towers typical of Dravidian architecture, are each built to a height of 40 ft (12 m), and are decorated with six sculptures each. The temple is accessed through a gatewayGrowth ofictional East gopura, which is followed by two more gopuras to the south and west. The temple is built in the Dravidian style, and is similar in design to the much larger Thanjavur Temple. The gopuras are Dravidian-style architectural elements, and are similar to the gopura at the Nataraja Temple in Chidambaram. The temple's main shrine is built in a Dravidgreech style, and is located in the centre of the temple, opposite to the east-facing gopura. The shrine is approached through two pillared halls, the Mad Writings and the Reading Room. The shrine is a small chamber, with a single window looking out to the east, and two doors, one to the left and one to the right. The shrine is topped with a Dravidigeek cupola, a square structure with a pyramid-shaped roof. The temple's outermost shrine is dedicated to Bhairava, one of the aspects of Shiva. The shrine is accessed through a corridor, and contains a small statue of Bhairava. The temple also contains a shrine to the goddess Durga, who is depicted as a 10-armed deity riding a lion. The temple's main festival is the annual 10-day Brahamotsavam, which is celebrated during the Tamil month of Karttikai. The festival is believed to have been celebrated for the past 1,000 years, and is one of the major festivals in the district. The festival is attended by thousands of people, and includes a number of processions through the streets of the town. The festival is also celebrated at the Amma Temple, the Manicka Vinayagar Temple and the Mariamman Temple. The temple is one of four in the town dedicated to Kali, the others being the Amma Temple, the Manicka Vinayagar Temple and the Mariamman Temple. The temple is built on a 2-acre (8,000 m2) plot of land, and is surrounded by a granite wall 8 ft (2.4 m) high. The Lancaster Inferno was a professional soccer team based in Lancaster, Pennsylvania that played in the National Premier Soccer League (NPSL), the third tier of the American soccer pyramid. The team was founded in 2007 and folded in 2013. The Lancaster Inferno played in the NPSL's Northeast Division from 2007 to 2010, and in the NPSL's Mid-Atlantic Division from 2011 to 2013. The team's home field was War Memorial Stadium. The Inferno was founded by Neil Sider, a native of Manchester, England, who came to the United States in 1987. Sider was involved with the Manchester City Football Club for many years, and was the owner and operator of the City of Manchester Pub in Philadelphia. The Inferno had a sister organization, the Pennsylvania Roar, that played in the WPSL from 2008 to 2010. The Lancaster Inferno had a team philosophy of playing "old-school" British football, and emphasized "passing the ball on the ground, and through the air, to feet." The team's style was "positively different" from the "kick and rush" style that is more common in American soccer. The Inferno also had a reputation for playing "heavy metal" music at its home matches, with songs such as "Born to Run", "Back in Black", "Baba O'Riley" and "Enter Sandman" blaring over the loudspeakers. The team also had a "Fan Cam" at home matches, with fans holding up cards with the letter "I" on them. The Inferno was the first team in the NPSL to have a live band perform at its home matches. The band, called "The Burn", played for the team's home matches in 2011 and 2012. The Inferno had an official supporter group, called the "Lancaster Old School Supporters Club", or "L.O.S.S.C.". The L.O.S.S.C. was founded in 2007, and had a membership of over 100 people. The L.O.S.S.C. had a close relationship with the team's management, and was involved in a number of community events. The group also had a "supporter of the year" award, which was given to a member who made an outstanding contribution to the group. The L.O.S.S.C. also had a number of traditions, including a "matchday ritual" where the group would gather at a local pub before each home match, and a "song of the season" which was chosen by the group. The L.O.S.S.C. had a number of rival groups, including the "New York Red Bulls Ultras", the "Philadelphia Union Ultras", and the "DC United Mania". The group also had a number of friendly relationships with other supporter groups, including the "New England Revolution Ultra's", the "Montreal Impact's Old Boys", and the "Vancouver Whitecaps Army".

Short-path distillation is a method of distillation in which the distillate is produced in a single pass. The short path is achieved by boiling the feedstock in the presence of a carrier gas in a heated chamber. The short boiling time (which can be as short as 0.01 seconds) allows the distillate to be produced in a single pass. The short-path distillation is used for the purification of thermally unstable substances, such as thermally unstable polymers, antibiotics, and organometallic compounds, which cannot be purified by conventional distillation because of the long residence time in the distillation column. Short-path distillation can also be used for the separation of thermally stable substances, such as isotopically enriched compounds, which can be separated by conventional distillation, but with a lower efficiency. The reason for the lower efficiency is the formation of azeotropic mixtures. The short-path distillation has the advantage that the distillate is produced in a single pass, and therefore the azeotropic mixture is not formed. The short-path distillation can be used for the purification of substances, which can be distilled at atmospheric pressure without the formation of a decomposition product. In this case, the distillate is produced in a single pass, and the purity of the distillate is higher than that produced by conventional distillation. The short-path distillation can be used for the separation of substances, which can be distilled at atmospheric pressure, and the boiling temperature of which is higher than the decomposition temperature. In this case, the distillate is produced in a single pass, and the purity of the distillate is higher than that produced by conventional distillation.

Lieutenant-general A lieutenant-general (lt-gen) is a general officer in the British Army, Royal Marines or Royal Air Force of the United Kingdom. The rank is also used in the British Army and Royal Marines reserve forces. The equivalent rank in the Royal Navy is rear-admiral (rd-adml) and in the Royal Air Force is air vice-marshal (av-mstr). The British Army and Royal Marines have a two-tier general officer structure: general officers (i.e. general, lieutenant-general, major-general, and captain) and field officers (i.e. major, lieutenant-colonel, colonel, and brigadier). The rank of lieutenant-general is equivalent to a one-star general officer; the other general officers are two- and three-star ranks. The Royal Air Force has no lieutenant-general rank, but its Royal Air Force Air Cadets organisation does. The origins of the lieutenant-general rank are complex. In the 17th century, the major was the second-in-command of a regiment and the lieutenant-colonel was the third-in-command. During the 18th century, the rank of lieutenant-colonel was elevated to that of colonel, the former rank being renamed lieutenant-colonel. However, the term lieutenant-colonel was used in a different context, to denote the second-in-command of a regiment, until the middle of the 18th century. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the terms lieutenant-colonel and colonel were used interchangeably, both meaning the second-in-command of a regiment. The British Army introduced the rank of lieutenant-colonel in replace of that of major in Cavalry and Indian regiments in 1856, and in the British, King's (later Royal) Army, in 1871. In 1877, the British Army introduced the ranks of lieutenant-colonel and colonel in the Royal Artillery and Royal Engineers. The Royal Marines had already been using these two ranks since the 1840s. The Royal Air Force did not have a rank of lieutenant-colonel equivalent until the Second World War, when it was used in the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve and the Royal Canadian Air Force. The Royal New Zealand Air Force had a rank of lieutenant-colonel from 1942 to 1968. The lieutenant-general is a senior officer rank, generally equivalent to the American military rank of lieutenant colonel in the United States Army and the United States Marine Corps. It is also comparable to the rank of captain in the other uniformed services of the United States, and to the rank of first mate in the British Royal Navy. In the British Army and Royal Marines, the rank of lieutenant-general can also be awarded as a military dignity, in which case it is not a rank, but an appointment, and the holder does not formally outrank other general officers. A lieutenant-general in this case is an officer of the rank of major-general, but holding the position of second-in-command of a major formation (such as a division or an aircraft carrier). The holder of the position of lieutenant-general is generally a highly experienced officer of the rank of major-general, and will have held the position of major-general for some years. The equivalent military dignity in the Royal Air Force is air commodore. The air commodore is not a rank but an appointment, and the holder does not formally outrank other officers of the rank of group captain. An air commodore is normally a group captain, but holds the position of second-in-command of a group (such as a Royal Air Force group, which is equivalent to an army division, or a Royal Air Force station, which is equivalent to a Royal Navy ship). The Royal Air Force Air Cadets has the military rank of lieutenant-general (LTGEN) for officers of the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve (Training Branch) of the Royal Air Force Air Cadets. The Royal Air Force Air Cadets also has the military rank of air commodore (AIRCDRE) for officers of the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve (Training Branch) of the Royal Air Force Air Cadets.

Francis E. Brownell (March 13, 1886 – June 7, 1954) was an American football player, coach, and college athletics administrator. He served as the head football coach at the University of Maine from 1908 to 1911, at the University of Vermont from 1912 to 1915, and at Harvard University from 1916 to 1924, compiling a career college football record of 75–52–9. Brownell was also the athletic director at Harvard from 1917 to 1924. Brownell was born in 1886 in Southboro, Massachusetts. He attended the public schools in Southboro and then the private Bancroft School in Worcester, Massachusetts. In 1905, Brownell enrolled at the University of Maine. He played football for the Maine Black Bears and was a member of the 1908 team that won the school's first national championship. After graduating from Maine, Brownell coached the football team at his alma mater for four years, leading the team to a 12–0 record in 1911. In 1912, he moved to the University of Vermont, where he coached the Vermont Catamounts for four years. In 1916, Brownell was hired as the head football coach at Harvard. He remained at Harvard through the 1924 season, during which his team compiled a record of 41–17–3. After stepping down as Harvard's football coach, Brownell became the school's athletic director. He served in that capacity from 1917 to 1924, during which time he helped to build Harvard's new indoor track and basketball facility, the Harvard Indoor Stadium. Brownell also served as the head coach of the United States Olympic track and field team at the 1920 Summer Olympics in Antwerp, Belgium, where his team won 40 medals, including seven gold. Brownell died in 1954 in Southboro, Massachusetts, at the age of 68.

Chloe Orkin (born 1973) is a British actress, known for her role as EastEnders' first HIV-positive character, Mel Owen. Orkin was born in Lupus, a district of Rome, Italy, to an English father, Michael, and a Scottish mother, Sandra (nee. McIver), who were both working in Italy at the time. The family returned to the UK two years later, settling in Kent. As a child, Orkin was a member of the Kent Youth Theatre. After leaving school at the age of 16, Orkin completed a two-year course in performing arts, and then spent three years at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art, where she won the Sir John Gielgud Scholarship in 1991. Her first television appearance came in 1992, when she played the role of Sandy in an episode of the Channel 4 series London's Burning. She then appeared as WPC Orkin in an episode of The Bill in 1993, and as Emma Green in an episode of Crimewatch UK in 1994. In 1994, Orkin was cast as Mel Owen in the BBC soap opera EastEnders. She first appeared in the series in June, and was introduced as the girlfriend of the already established character, Mark Fowler (played by hardman actor, Steve McFadden). Orkin's character was featured in a high-profile storyline in which Mark was diagnosed as HIV-positive, and the couple struggled to come to terms with this. Orkin decided to leave the series in 1996, after two years. Her final appearance was in October 1996. In 1997, Orkin starred in an episode of the BBC's medical drama series, Casualty, playing the role of Sarah Lytton. In 1998, she played the role of Det. Sgt. Karen Schiller in an episode of the ITV police drama, The Bill. She then appeared as Miss Mac in an episode of the BBC children's drama series, Byker Grove, in 1999. In 2000, Orkin appeared in an episode of the BBC comedy series, The Office. She has also made appearances in the BBC's Doctors (in 2002 and 2006), and the ITV police drama, Midsomer Murders (in 2009).

James Bond 007: Gamesmaster Pack is a PlayStation video game developed by Black Box and published by Electronic Arts. It was released in 2000, and is a compilation of various Bond games from the EA James Bond series, featuring several from the earlier James Bond: The Duelist Collection. Unlike the previous collection, which was mostly composed of games based on the movies, the Gamesmaster Pack features games based on the Ian Fleming novels, as well as the movie Casino Royale. In addition, it includes two games based on the short stories from the collection James Bond, 007: Ambition, and a game based on the novel Live and Let Die. The pack also includes the game GoldenEye: Rogue Agent, which was originally released for the Nintendo 64. The Gamesmaster Pack was released in Europe in September 2000, and in the US in October 2000. It was not released in Japan. Like the previous collection, it was released in two different versions. The standard edition featured only the six Bond games, whereas the collector's edition, sold at a higher price, featured the six Bond games, a bonus seventh game, and a special Bond DVD. The bonus game was the PlayStation game GoldenEye: 007, which was originally released in 1997. The Bond DVD was a special feature-length documentary about the making of the first four Bond films, titled Bond Girls Are Forever. In the UK, the collector's edition also included a copy of the novel Live and Let Die as a bonus. However, in the US, the novel was not included, due to copyright issues.

Elizabeth Miller (academic) Elizabeth Miller is an academic and author who specializes in the history of art and architecture of the Early Modern period, with a particular focus on the Italian Renaissance. She is currently the Paul A. Clement Professor of Art History at the University of Texas at Austin. Miller received her Bachelor of Arts degree in Art History and French from the University of Toronto in 1984, and her Master of Arts and Doctor of Philosophy degrees in Art History from the University of California, Berkeley in 1986 and 1990, respectively. Her doctoral dissertation, "The Career of a Renaissance Banker: The Chigi Family and the Art Market in Early Modern Rome," was awarded the William E. Suida Prize for excellence in art history. In 1990, Miller joined the faculty of the University of Texas at Austin as an Assistant Professor in the Department of Art and Art History. She was promoted to Associate Professor in 1997 and to Professor in 2004. In 2014, she was named the Paul A. Clement Professor of Art History. Miller has written extensively on the art and architecture of the Italian Renaissance, with a particular focus on the works of Raphael and his workshop. Her publications include "The Art of the Assumption: The Frescoes of San Severino in Piacenza" (1995), "The Renaissance in Rome" (with T. A. Price, 2002), "Raphael and the Madonna of Frascati" (2008), and "The Piochi Chapel: A Renaissance Intersection" (with David G. Uzzardi, 2016). Miller has received numerous awards and fellowships for her research and teaching, including a William E. Suida Fellowship from the Warburg Institute in London (2005–06), a Charles A. Dana Fellowship from the Council of the American Overseas Research Centers in Rome (2009–10), a National Endowment for the Humanities Research Fellowship (2010–11), and a Rome Prize from the American Academy in Rome (2017–18). Miller has also served as a curator and consultant for a number of exhibitions and projects related to the art and architecture of the Renaissance, including "The Renaissance in Rome" (Palazzo Venezia, Rome, 2002), "The Piochi Chapel" (Museo Nazionale del Cinema, Italy, 2014), "The Americas on Paper" (UT Austin, 2016), and "The House of Ovid: A New Look at Renaissance Art" (UT Austin, 2017). In addition to her academic work, Miller is also the author of a popular book on the life and times of Raphael, entitled "The Life and Times of Raphael" (2017).

Kentucky Gold The gold deposits in the United States were mostly discovered during the 19th century, while the metal was becoming a standard for currency and economic value. The first documented gold discovery in the United States was in North Carolina in 1799. The discovery of gold at Sutter's Mill, California, in 1848 sparked the California Gold Rush, the largest gold rush in United States history. The first discovery of gold in what is now the state of Kentucky was in the late 18th century, but the gold deposits were not mined until the 19th century. The first mine was opened at Gold Hill, near Mount Pleasant, in the early 1800s. The first gold rush in Kentucky was in the 1830s, and by 1840, the state was producing more gold than any other state except for Georgia. The most famous gold mine in Kentucky was the Sloss Mines, which were located in the town of Sloss, in the southeastern part of the state. The Sloss Mines were the largest gold mine in the state, and they produced more than $40 million worth of gold. The mine closed in the early 20th century, and the town of Sloss was eventually abandoned. There are still gold mines in Kentucky, but most of them are small, independent operations. The state is no longer a major gold producer, but it still has a rich history of gold mining.

An ordinary course of business is an activity that is consistent with the ordinary and usual manner in which a corporation or other business entity conducts its business. An act or omission is said to be an ordinary course of business if it is an activity that is commonly engaged in by similar enterprises, and is not extraordinary or unusual. The term is often used in connection with a claim for insurance coverage. The ordinary course of business may also refer to the common practice of a particular business, and may be used as a defense to a claim of unfair competition. In insurance law, the term "ordinary course of business" is often used to describe the operations of a business that are routine or typical for that type of business. For example, the insurance company may cover a claim if the damage or loss was caused by the ordinary course of business, but may not cover a claim if the damage or loss was caused by something exceptional, or outside the usual course of business. The term "ordinary course of business" may also be used in contract law, to indicate that a particular act or omission was consistent with the ordinary course of business, and therefore did not constitute a breach of contract. For example, if a business contract requires a company to deliver goods to a customer by a certain date, and the company delivers the goods after the due date, this may be considered a breach of contract. However, if the company can show that the late delivery was due to an extraordinary circumstance, and was not part of the ordinary course of business, the company may be able to avoid liability for breach of contract.

Douglas Saunders (born c. 1944) is a Canadian journalist and author. Saunders was born in Toronto, Ontario. He attended the University of Toronto, where he studied English and won the President's Award for having the highest grade point average in the faculty. After graduating, he worked for a time as a writer for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) and as a reporter for The Globe and Mail, then Canada's largest circulation daily newspaper. In the early 1970s, he became a reporter for The Toronto Star, the city's other major daily newspaper, where he was eventually appointed to the position of feature writer. In 1981, he joined the staff of The Globe and Mail, where he served as the paper's feature writer for more than twenty years. In 2002, he became a columnist for the newspaper. Saunders has also written for numerous other publications, including Saturday Night, Maclean's, and The Walrus. He has also been a frequent contributor to the CBC Radio programs Morningside, As It Happens, and The Current. In 1985, Saunders was made an Officer of the Order of Canada, the second highest civilian honour in the country. In 2001, he was awarded the National Newspaper Award for column writing. In 2005, he won the City of Toronto Book Award. In addition to his work as a journalist, Saunders has also published several books. His first book, The Life and Times of Canada's Teflon Governor, was published in 1984 and was a national bestseller. His second book, The Heretic: Tom Beatrice and the Shooting of John Diefenbaker, was published in 1996 and was also a national bestseller. His third book, Tangled Gardens: The Life of Frederick Banting, was published in 2002 and was a national bestseller. His fourth book, The Border: Canada's Half-Breed Highway, was published in 2006 and was a national bestseller. His most recent book, L.M. Montgomery: The Woman behind the Icon, was published in 2008 and was a national bestseller.

The Neuse River waterdog (Amphipithecus nebulosus) is a species of waterdog in the family Ground Waterdog, Cryptobranchidae. It is found in North America in the Neuse River of North Carolina and South Carolina, and in the Tar River and its tributaries in North Carolina. It is a federally listed endangered species. The Neuse River waterdog has a yellow-brownish body with a darker stripe on its back. It has a flat head and small eyes. They have short, smooth coats with yellow spotting on their throats and bellies. Their skin is loose, and they have four legs and a long tail. The Neuse River waterdog lives in the Neuse and Tar river basins in North Carolina. It lives in swift-flowing rivers over gravel, rock, and mud substrates. They also live in pools and backwaters. They burrow into the banks of rivers during the day and come out to forage at night. They eat small fish, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. The Neuse River waterdog is threatened by habitat loss. The Neuse and Tar river basins have been affected by urban and suburban development, and the waterdogs' habitat has been altered by the construction of dams. The waterdogs' populations have also been affected by pollution and disease.

Wang Xiaoyun (Chinese: 王小云; born July 1966) is a Chinese computer scientist and the current Vice President of Baidu. Wang was born in Shanghai in 1966. He received his B.S. degree in computer science from the Shanghai Jiao Tong University in 1988, and his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in computer science from the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1992 and the Shanghai Jiao Tong University in 1996, respectively. After graduation, he joined the Shanghai Institute of Microsystem and Information Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences as a researcher and then a senior researcher. He was a professor at the Shanghai Jiao Tong University from 1998 to 2000. He was a visiting scholar at the University of California, Berkeley from 1998 to 1999. He was a professor at the Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences from 2000 to 2003. He was a professor at the Shanghai Jiao Tong University from 2003 to 2005. He was a visiting scholar at the National University of Singapore from 2003 to 2004. He was a professor at the Tsinghua University from 2005 to 2008. He was a visiting scholar at the Princeton University from 2005 to 2006. He was a visiting scholar at the Stanford University from 2006 to 2007. He was a professor at the Shanghai Jiao Tong University from 2008 to 2011. He was a visiting scholar at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology from 2008 to 2009. He was a professor at the Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences from 2011 to 2014. He was a visiting scholar at the University of Washington from 2011 to 2012. He was a professor at the Tsinghua University from 2014 to 2015. He was a visiting scholar at the National University of Singapore from 2014 to 2015. He was a professor at the Shanghai Jiao Tong University from 2015 to 2016. He was a visiting scholar at the Princeton University from 2015 to 2016. He was a professor at the Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences from 2016 to 2017. He was a visiting scholar at the Tsinghua University from 2016 to 2017. He was a professor at the Shanghai Jiao Tong University from 2017 to 2019. He was a visiting scholar at the Princeton University from 2017 to 2018. He was a professor at the Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences from 2019 to 2021. He was a visiting scholar at the Tsinghua University from 2019 to 2021. He was a professor at the Shanghai Jiao Tong University from 2021 to 2022. He was a visiting scholar at the National University of Singapore from 2021 to 2022. He has been a professor at the Institute of Computing Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences since 2022. Wang's research interests include computer architecture, parallel computing, and computer security. He has published more than 40 papers in international journals and conferences. He is the co-author of the book titled "Microprocessor Architecture and Parallel Computing".

Machrihanish is a village and a community council area in Argyll and Bute, Scotland. It is located on the Kintyre peninsula, on the western shore of the Firth of Clyde, looking out to the Isle of Arran. It is the site of the Machrihanish Airbase and the Machrihanish Golf Course, which is said to be the first course in Scotland to have been designed by a woman, Mary Queen of Scots. The village's main street is the A83, which connects Campbeltown to the south and Brodick, Arran to the north. The village is served by Machrihanish Airport. It is also the site of a large Army training base, home to the Scottish Ammunition Company, which was formerly an MOD facility responsible for the manufacture, storage, and distribution of a wide range of ammunition. The facility was sold by the MOD in 2001, and now functions as a commercial business. It is also the home of the first appointed Machrihanish Community Council, which was established in 1980. The village has a small primary school, and is in the catchment area of Tarbet Academy in North Kintyre. The Machrihanish area is also home to a number of pre-historic sites, including the standing stones at nearby Dunaverty, which is also the site of a ruined medieval castle. The village was formerly served by Machrihanish railway station, which was the terminus of the Campbeltown and Machrihanish Light Railway. The railway closed in 1932. The village was also the birthplace and home of the poet and songwriter Robert Tannahill.

Centennial High School is a public high school in the Paradise Valley Unified School District. It is one of the largest high schools in the state of Arizona, with an enrollment of over 3,000 students. The school is located in the Phoenix suburb of Paradise Valley, Arizona, near the intersection of East McDonald Drive and North Tatum Boulevard. The school opened in the fall of 1979. The school's first senior class graduated in 1981. The school's mascot is the Colt. The school's colors are blue and silver. The school has a large athletic and academic programs, with a variety of extracurricular activities. The school has a large campus, with a variety of classrooms, laboratories, and athletic facilities. The school also has a large library and media center, as well as a variety of computer labs. The school's athletic facilities include a large gymnasium, a stadium, and a variety of outdoor athletic fields. The school's academic program includes a variety of core subjects, including English, math, science, social studies, and physical education. The school also offers a variety of electives, including art, music, and technology. The school has a variety of advanced placement and honors courses, as well as a variety of special education services. The school's athletic program includes a variety of sports, including football, basketball, baseball, soccer, and volleyball. The school also has a variety of club and intramural sports, including golf, tennis, and cross-country. The school's athletic teams are known as the "Colts", and they compete in the Arizona Interscholastic Association's 4A Conference. The school's clubs and activities include a variety of academic, service, and athletic groups, including the National Honor Society, the Spanish Club, and the Colt Backers booster club. The school also has a variety of performing arts groups, including the choir, band, and drama club. The school has a variety of community outreach programs, including a variety of volunteer and service-learning opportunities. The school also has a variety of partnerships with local businesses and organizations, including a variety of career and technical education programs.

Regional Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union The Regional Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (Russian: Региональный комитет Коммунистического партии Советского Союза, translit. Regional'nyj komitet Kommunisticheskogo partija Sovetskogo Sojuza) was the highest governing body of the Communist Party within each of the republics, regions, and autonomous republics of the Soviet Union. The Regional Committee was appointed by the higher bodies of the party - the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (CPSU) and the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union (CC CPSU) - and was subordinated to them. The Regional Committee was the highest body of the party in the region. It had the power to make decisions on the questions of principle that related to the region. It gave the necessary instructions to the lower bodies of the party. It was responsible for the implementation of the decisions of the higher bodies of the party and the implementation of the regional party program. The Regional Committee consisted of the representatives of the higher bodies of the party, of the party bodies from the districts and the cities, and also of the representatives of the local industry, agriculture, trade, and scientific organizations. The Regional Committee was headed by the Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union in the given region. The Secretary was the highest-ranking Communist Party member in the region. Besides the Regional Committee, there also existed the Republican or Regional Party Conference. The Party Conference had the right to elect or remove the Secretary and to discuss the questions of the party life in the region.

Love and Honor Love and Honor is a 2013 American biographical war drama film directed by Danny Mooney and starring Liam Hemsworth, Teresa Palmer, and Josh Hartnett. The film was produced by Michael London, Alexander Milchan, and Jonathan Yunger. The film tells the story of two best friends, Lieutenant Jake Harris (Liam Hemsworth) and Lieutenant Bobby Scott (Josh Hartnett), who are ordered to lead a Search and Rescue team to find a missing Marine in the Helmand Province of Afghanistan. As they and their team search for the lost Marine, the film tells the story of how the two officers grew up and became friends, and how their relationship affected their lives and those around them. The film was released in the United States on January 11, 2013, with a subsequent Region one (US and Canada) DVD release on June 26, 2013. Love and Honor was the first film to be released in the United States in 2013. At the 2013 Feature Film category, Love and Honor won the Hollywood Film Award for Outstanding Performance. The film was shot in New Mexico with principal photography starting on October 11, 2012.

Horizon Health Network Horizon Health Network (also known as Horizon Health) is the health authority that provides health services to residents of New Brunswick, Canada. Horizon Health Network is a regional health authority, with the head office located in Saint John, New Brunswick. The Health Network serves approximately 738,000 people in New Brunswick, in the areas of the province lying west of the City of Saint John and east of the Quebec border, except for Edmundston and the surrounding area, which is part of the North West Regional Health Authority. Horizon Health Network was created on 1 April 2001, when the Regional Health Authorities Act came into effect, replacing the nine health authorities that previously served the region. The area served by Horizon Health includes several counties and municipal districts, including Albert County, Borden County, Charlotte County, Northumberland County, Queen's County, and Westmorland County. Horizon Health Network is governed by a board of directors appointed by the Minister of Health. The board is responsible for establishing the overall strategic direction of the organization and ensuring that it meets the high standards of quality and accountability required by the Government of New Brunswick. The Horizon Health Network comprises numerous health-related organizations, including three hospitals, two health-science universities, three health-related research institutions, and numerous community-based health-care services. The largest hospital in the Horizon Health Network is the Saint John Regional Hospital, located in Saint John. The hospital is a tertiary-level hospital, providing a wide range of health services to the residents of the region. The hospital is a teaching hospital, affiliated with Dalhousie University and Memorial University. The Horizon Health Network also includes the Moncton Hospital, located in Moncton, and the Miramichi Regional Hospital, located in Miramichi. These hospitals provide general health services to the communities they serve. In addition to the hospitals, the Horizon Health Network includes the following health-related organizations: The New Brunswick Heart Centre, located in Saint John, provides specialized cardiac services to the region. The New Brunswick Cancer Centre, located in Saint John, provides specialized cancer services to the region. The Kidney Care Program, located in Saint John, provides specialized kidney services to the region. The New Brunswick Eye Centre, located in Saint John, provides specialized eye services to the region. The New Brunswick Hearing Aid Centre, located in Saint John, provides specialized hearing services to the region. The New Brunswick Assistive Devices Program, located in Saint John, provides specialized assistive devices to the region. The New Brunswick Home Oxygen Program, located in Saint John, provides specialized home oxygen services to the region. The New Brunswick Palliative Care Program, located in Saint John, provides specialized palliative care services to the region. The New Brunswick Hospice Palliative Care Program, located in Saint John, provides specialized hospice palliative care services to the region. The New Brunswick Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias Program, located in Saint John, provides specialized services to individuals with Alzheimer's disease and related dementias, as well as their families, in the region. The New Brunswick Division of Public Health, located in Saint John, provides public health services to the region. The New Brunswick Department of Health, located in Saint John, provides overall management and leadership for the health system in the region.

Duane Linklater (born 1977) is a Canadian artist of Cree and Dene descent. He was born in Prince Albert, Saskatchewan and grew up in Melfort. He later moved to Vancouver, British Columbia to attend the Emily Carr University of Art and Design. He is currently based in Toronto, Ontario. Linklater's work deals with the themes of indigenous identity, both on a personal and a collective level. His works are often installation-based and incorporate a variety of media, including video, photography, and text. One of Linklater's most well-known works is the video installation "This Is Not a Frankenhole". The work, which was exhibited at the Toronto International Film Festival in 2009, features a series of video interviews with indigenous people from across Canada, each of whom is asked the same question: "What does it mean to be indigenous?" The responses to the question are as diverse as the individuals themselves, and the work is a reflection of the diversity and complexity of indigenous identity. In addition to his own art practice, Linklater has also been active in the indigenous art community, both as an organizer and as a curator. In 2007, he co-founded the Indigenous Curatorial Collective, which is dedicated to the promotion and support of indigenous curatorial practices. In 2009, he was one of the organizers of the first national indigenous art conference in Canada, which was held in Vancouver. Duane Linklater has exhibited his work nationally and internationally, and his work is included in the permanent collections of the National Gallery of Canada and the Art Gallery of Ontario.
