The Hermite Islands are a group of three rocky, low-lying islands and some associated islets in the Gulf of California, off the coast of Baja California, Mexico. They are located in the area of the East Pacific Flyway, a route for migratory birds. The three main islands are: * Isla El Fraile * Isla Los Hermanos * Isla de los Estanques These islands are named after the French monk and mathematician Charles Hermite. In 1533, the islands were named Las Islas de los Secos, because they resembled the seagulls (gulls) that nested there. These islands are home to several species of marine life, including the northern elephant seal and the Guadalupe fur seal. The islands also host a large number of seabirds, such as the brown noddy, the black-footed albatross, and the white-faced ibis. The Hermite Islands are a nature reserve, and are part of the Reserva de la Biosfera de la Sierra de la Laguna, which covers the southern part of the Baja California peninsula. The islands are also a Mexican federal reserve, and are considered to be an important part of the country's natural heritage.

Philippine twenty-peso note The Philippine twenty-peso note (Filipino: Dalawang piso) is a banknote worth PHP20. It is the smallest note in general circulation in the Philippines, along with the fifty-peso bill. The current 20-peso bill features the portrait of former President and National Hero of the Philippines, Corazon Aquino, on the front side, and a scene of the Banaue Rice Terraces on the reverse side. In 2018, the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) announced that it would redesign the 20-peso note as part of its New Generation Currency (NGC) series, with the goal of making it more durable and more secure against counterfeiting. The new 20-peso bill was released to the general public on March 1, 2020, and is the first NGC banknote to be released for general circulation. The front side of the bill features the portrait of former President Benigno Aquino III, while the reverse side features the Philippines' Declaration of Independence and the original signature of Philippine national hero, Dr. Jose Rizal. The 20-peso bill is widely used for small purchases in the Philippines, such as food from street vendors, small merchandise from sari-sari stores, and mass transit fares.

Institute for East European Studies The Institute for East European Studies (German: Institut für Osteuropäische Geschichte) is a research institute at the Faculty of Philosophy of the Martin Luther University of Halle-Wittenberg in Halle, Germany. It was founded in 1964 as the Institute for Soviet and East European Studies. The institute's director is Heribert Adam. The Institute for East European Studies specializes in the history and cultures of the countries of Eastern Europe, with a particular focus on the Russian Federation, Ukraine, and Belarus. The institute is home to the Germany-Russia Forum, which is supported by the German Foreign Office. The institute's research library has more than 240,000 volumes and is one of the largest libraries of its kind in Germany. The institute also has a large collection of films and documentaries about Russia and Eastern Europe. In addition to offering courses in Russian and East European history at the undergraduate and graduate levels, the Institute for East European Studies offers a number of courses in Russian and East European culture, society, and politics. The institute also offers a number of courses in Russian and East European languages. The Institute for East European Studies is a member of the Association for Slavic, East European, and Eurasian Studies, and the European Association for Russian and East European Studies. The institute has been home to a number of notable scholars, including Alexander von Plato, Peter Grieder, and Martin Mittenzwei. The institute's current faculty includes Heribert Adam, Werner Bachmann, Thomas Berec, Michael Driesen, Birgit Embrechting, Hendrick Hasenec, Panayiotis Kounnas, and Vasiliy Fedotov.

Keeth Smart (born July 30, 1973) is an American former professional boxer who won the WBO junior welterweight title in 2005. Smart was born in Brooklyn, New York, and lived in the Fort Greene section of the city. He attended Paul Robeson High School in his junior and senior years, after spending his first two years of high school at Wingate High School. Smart did not play high school sports because he was afraid of being discriminated against by his peers. After high school, Smart worked for the New York City Department of Sanitation. He was featured in a 1996 documentary, The Best Team, about the sanitation workers' baseball team. After watching the film, Smart's friend encouraged him to try boxing, and he began training at the Police Athletic League gym in Brooklyn. Smart had a successful amateur career, winning the New York Golden Gloves tournament in 2001, and reaching the semifinals of the 2002 U.S. Championships. He lost in the first round of the 2002 Golden Gloves tournament, but was able to avenge that loss in the 2003 tournament, when he won the championship. Smart made his professional debut in 2002, and won his first 13 fights, including a victory over the veteran boxer Saoul Mamby. In 2004, he challenged the WBO junior welterweight champion, Kaokor Galaxy, but lost by unanimous decision. Smart was able to avenge that loss in 2005, when he defeated Galaxy by unanimous decision to become the new champion. In his first defense of the WBO junior welterweight title, Smart lost to the undefeated Mexican boxer, Edgar Garcia by majority decision. After the fight, Smart tested positive for the banned substance Nandrolone, and was stripped of his title. He was subsequently suspended by the New York State Athletic Commission for nine months. After his suspension was lifted, Smart returned to the ring in 2006, and won his next two fights. However, in 2007, he was defeated by the undefeated Puerto Rican boxer, Kendall Holt, by unanimous decision. In 2008, he lost to the undefeated Cuban boxer, Yordenis Ugas, by unanimous decision. In 2009, Smart lost to the undefeated Paulie Malignaggi by unanimous decision. After the fight, he retired from boxing. In 2012, Smart came out of retirement to fight again. However, he lost to the undefeated Keith Thurman by unanimous decision. After the fight, he retired from boxing again. Smart has a record of 23-5-0 with 10 knockouts.

Buried (performance art) Buried is an artwork by the British artist Marc Quinn. In 2011, Quinn presented a performance entitled Buried, in which he was buried for three days. The performance was in reaction to a piece by the British artist Damien Hirst, in which a cow was buried in formaldehyde in a clear tank. Quinn's piece was a statement against the waste and spectacle he felt Hirst's work represented. Quinn buried himself on the grounds of his London studio on 10 October 2011, at the same time that Hirst's cow was being buried at the Serpentine Gallery in London. In addition to a text by Quinn explaining the work, the only other items buried with him were a copy of the Quran, a Bible, and a copy of the Lotus Sutra. A video recording of the burial was also produced. After three days underground, Quinn dug himself out on 13 October. In an interview with the Mail on Sunday before the event, he said: "I'm doing this to make a point about the way we waste resources on things that are merely transient and finite, things that are ultimately going to decay and disintegrate. I'm going to be buried in a wood box, which will rot and return to the earth. It's a comment on the absurdity of the waste and spectacle that Damien Hirst's work represents." In 2012, the performance was included in the exhibition L' Alternativa, at the Museu d'Art Contemporani de Barcelona.

Formosa Peak Formosa Peak is a mountain in the Central Mountain Range of Taiwan. The peak is 4, nicest, and it is the fourth highest mountain in the country. It is located in Heping District, Taichung City, and is part of the Taichung Basin. The peak is also known as the Jade Mountain, and it is located near the Hsianglu Peak and the Jinmian Peak. The mountain is part of the Xitou system, and the upstream area of the system is the Xitou Wetland. The Xitou Wetland is the third largest wetland in Taiwan, and it is the largest in the Taichung area. Formosa Peak is the location of the Formosa Faucetop, which is the highest waterfall in Taiwan. The waterfall is located on the north face of the mountain, and it is a hanging waterfall. The water falls from a height of 100 meters, and it is a major tourist attraction. The area around the waterfall is also a popular hiking destination. Formosa Peak is also home to the Formosa Cave. The cave is located on the south side of the mountain, and it is a large, naturally formed cave. The cave is home to a variety of stalactites and stalagmites, and it is a popular tourist destination. The cave is also a popular destination for spelunkers.

The Bush Doctrine The "Bush Doctrine" is the foreign policy initiative of the administration of President George W. Bush, adopted on September 20, 2002, in the wake of the September 11 attacks on the United States the previous year. The Bush Doctrine holds that the United States has the right to wage pre-emptive war to forestall potential terrorist attacks. The Bush Doctrine also holds that the United States is justified in attacking a country that either harbors or supports terrorist organizations, even if the country is not itself attacked. The Bush Doctrine was controversial and was the subject of widespread criticism, even within the United States. The Bush Doctrine was a significant shift in the foreign policy of the United States. For much of its history, the United States had a "no first strike" policy, which held that the United States would not initiate a nuclear strike against another country. This policy was a response to the beginning of the nuclear age, and was influenced by the experience of the First and Second World Wars. The Bush Doctrine, however, was a "first strike" policy, which gave the United States the right to initiate a war if it determined that a potential enemy state was developing nuclear weapons. The Bush Doctrine was first articulated in a speech by President Bush in October 2002. In the speech, Bush stated that the United States would take "preemptive action" against countries that were developing nuclear weapons. He also stated that the United States would take "preventive action" against countries that were harboring or supporting terrorist organizations. The Bush Doctrine was further clarified in a document released by the White House in January 2003. The document, known as the National Security Strategy, stated that the United States would take "preemptive action" against countries that were developing weapons of mass destruction, or that were harboring or supporting terrorist organizations.

Passion is a song by German Eurodance project Gat Decor, which was released in June 1996 as the second single from their only album, World, in collaboration with American singer Stamina. The song was written by Sascha Lappessen and Thomas Allison, while production was handled by Lappessen and Sascha Simon. "Passion" is a dance song which uses the metaphor of a car crash to describe a relationship that is on the verge of breaking up, with the singers trying to convince each other to stay together. The single reached number 12 in Germany and was a top 10 hit in Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Hungary, Italy, the Netherlands, Norway, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. It was also a top 20 hit in Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the United States. "Passion" is one of the group's biggest hits to date and is still widely popular. The music video for the song was directed by Vaughn Duke and was shot in Los Angeles. It features the two singers in a car, driving through the city at night. It ends with a crash, but it is not revealed if they were able to survive. The song was re-recorded in 2006, with the original singer Stamina. This version was released as a single in Germany, where it reached number 70, and in the UK, where it reached number 38. The music video for the 2006 version was directed by Daniel Kamil and was shot in Los Angeles. It features the two singers in a car, driving through the city at night. At the end, they survive the crash and walk away together. Passion is a song by German Eurodance project Gat Decor, which was released in June 1996 as the second single from their only album, World, in collaboration with American singer Stamina.

Peggs Green is a small village in the parish of South Mimms, in the east of Hertfordshire, England. It is located on the B158 road, and is situated approximately one mile (1.6 km) north-west of South Mimms, and two miles (3.2 km) south of Potters Bar. It is in the council ward of South Mimms, which is represented by two Conservative councillors. Peggs Green is a small village with a modern housing development, a parade of shops, and a historic pub. It is also home to the Mimms Hall stately home and accompanying Mimms Park. The place-name Peggs Green is first mentioned in a conveyance of 18th century, in which it is spelled as Peg's Green. The origin of the name is not known, but a local resident has suggested that it may be derived from the name of a Mr Peg, who was a landowner in the area. There is a story that the village was once a location for a number of public houses, and the neighbouring Mimms Hall was the location of a number of inns. The current public house, the Rising Sun, is a 19th-century building, but it is said that an earlier building on the site was once the residence of a Mr Smith, a farmer. The farm buildings were located where the modern housing development is situated. The village has an active Residents' Association, which organises various events throughout the year.

Sir Hugo Sir Hugo (died 1356), was an English medieval knight. He is best known for killing the 13th-century Scottish rebel William Wallace in a duel. In 1356, King Edward III of England led a campaign in Scotland to put an end to the First War of Scottish Independence. On 22 June, the English forces defeated the Scots at the Battle of Aberdeen, and shortly afterwards captured the Scottish leader William Wallace. According to the Brut, a 15th-century chronicler, Wallace was sentenced to death by hanging. However, a knight named Sir Hugo, or Huon, asked that Wallace be given to him, as he had sworn to kill the Scottish leader. The chronicler goes on to say that: * 1) Sir Hugo (died 1356), an English medieval knight. * 2) Sir Hugo (died 1406), an English medieval knight. * 3) Sir Hugo (died 1471), an English medieval knight. "And so it was granted him, to do his will in him, and he should hang him up naked, and should cut off his genitals, and should put them into his mouth, and so to kill him." The execution took place near Smithfield, London. The story of Wallace's execution by being fed his own genitals is a later fabrication, probably made in the 16th century. It is not mentioned in any contemporary account, and is not supported by the evidence of the 1405 letter from the Scottish knight Alexander de Bosse. Sir Hugo is believed to have been a member of the Deyncourts family, which had strong connections with the Scottish court. The execution of Wallace was probably a revenge killing, as the Scottish leader had killed Sir William de Deyncourt in the early stages of the war. Several sources give the first name of Sir Hugo as "Henry". However, the executioner is commonly given as "Sir Henry de Lascy", which may be a mistake for "Sir Hugo de Lascy". There is no direct evidence that Sir Hugo was a knight, as the only reference to his status comes from the 15th-century chronicler. However, it is likely that he was a knight, as it would be unusual for a non-knight to be granted such a grisly execution. The chronicler also states that Sir Hugo was "a very tall man, but very lame". After killing Wallace, Sir Hugo is said to have gone to the King's tent and cried out, "I have done my deed, let me never be troubled more with the Scottish wars". There is no record of Sir Hugo's subsequent career, and it is not known if he was present at the Battle of Neville's Cross in 1346, when the Scottish leader David II was captured. Sir Hugo is the subject of the traditional folk song, "The Bonny Sir Hugo". There are three known references to a "Sir Hugo" in the registers of the Order of the Garter in this period. However, it is not clear if any of these refer to the killer of Wallace. The first reference is to a "Sir Hugo de Veer", who was killed in a jousting tournament in 1347. The second is to a "Sir Hugo de la Sluce", who was present at the siege of Calais in 1347. The third reference is to a "Sir Hugo, son of the Duke of Juliers", who was made a knight of the Order of the Garter in 1349. It is unlikely that either of the first two references are to the same Hugo, as the records do not mention any children or heirs. It is possible that the third reference is to the son of the first Hugo. However, there are no known records of a "Duke of Juliers" or "Duke of Jersey" in this period, and the name "Hugo" does not appear in the list of sons of the counts of Juliers. It is possible that the chronicler has confused the name "Hugo" with "Henry", as the name Henry does appear among the counts of Juliers. It is also possible that the "Duke of Juliers" is a mistake for the "Earl of Leicester", as the chronicler describes Sir Hugo as "a very tall man, but very lame", and the Earl of Leicester was both tall and lame. Västergötlands Fotbollförbund is one of the twenty-one District Football Associations that are affiliated to the Swedish Football Federation. The district covers the southern part of the historical province of Västergötland – hence the name – and is bounded by the other districts of Halland to the south, Jönköping to the north, and Älvsborg to the west. The district was created in 1910, and currently has 48 member clubs. The highest ranked clubs are included in the second division, Division 1, which is the third tier in the Swedish league system. Västergötland is also the name of a geographical and cultural region. For the geographical region, see Västergötland. For the cultural region, see Götaland. The Dayton Family The Dayton family is an American family of Swiss origin. The family's American roots date back to Robert Dayton (1660–1714), who was a New Netherland-born officer in the Dutch West India Company and a resident of New York City. The family is best known for its connection to the city of Dayton, Ohio, and its prominent role in the history of the city. The family's involvement in the history of Dayton began in the early 19th century with the construction of a trading post on the Great Miami River by Edward Dayton. The trading post was located near the site of present-day downtown Dayton. In 1819, the trading post was converted into a town, which was named Dayton after its founder. The Dayton family played a major role in the development of Dayton as a city. They were involved in the city's early politics, and several members of the family served as mayors of Dayton. The family also contributed to the city's cultural life, and the Dayton Art Institute and the Benjamin and Marian Schuster Performing Arts Center were built with money donated by the family. The Dayton family's influence in Dayton extended beyond the city limits. The family owned large areas of farmland surrounding Dayton, and they were instrumental in the creation of the Miami-Erie Canal, which connected Dayton to the rest of the country. The canal was a major factor in the city's growth and development. The Dayton family has been very influential in the history of the United States. Two members of the family served in the United States Congress, and one member served as the United States Ambassador to Switzerland. The family also played a role in the American Revolution, and several members of the family were active in the anti-slavery movement. The Dayton family continues to be active in Dayton's civic life. The family has been very generous with its donations to the city, and many of Dayton's finest buildings were built with money donated by the family. The family also sponsors a number of charitable foundations, and many members of the family are active in local politics.

The Breit equation, named after the physicist Gregory Breit, is a type of integrable partial differential equation that occurs in a variety of applications in physics and mathematics. It is an example of aplanatic equation. The Breit equation is given by Breit equation where the function ω(x) is the Wronskian of two functions f and g that are smooth in the domain Ω, and the function κ(x) is a regular function in Ω. The Wronskian is defined by Wronskian A solution of the Breit equation is given by solution where ω and κ are constants that can be determined from the initial conditions. The general solution can be found by using the method of separation of variables. The Breit equation is a special case of a more general class of integrable partial differential equations called the integrable Schrödinger equations. These equations are integrable analogues of the non-integrable Schrödinger equation, and are related to the Dirac equation by the Kramers–Henkin–Rubin theorem. The Breit equation is also related to the heat equation by the method of characteristics. The Breit equation is important in the theory of partial differential equations, and has many applications in physics, including in the study of quantum mechanics, electrodynamics, and general relativity. In particular, the Breit equation is the basis for the mathematical formulation of quantum electrodynamics, and is used to describe the behavior of charged particles in a vacuum. It is also used in the study of the structure of the hydrogen atom, and in the theory of the early universe. In addition, the Breit equation is used in the study of the properties of electromagnetic waves, and in the analysis of the behavior of materials with a high thermal conductivity.

Xiangming Chen (born in Shanghai in 1965) is a Chinese-American chemist and the co-developer of the drug Erlotinib, for which he was a co-winner of the 2005 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. Chen obtained his B.S. degree from the University of Science and Technology of China in 1987 and then went to the United States to study at the California Institute of Technology, where he obtained his M.S. degree in 1990 and his Ph.D. degree in 1993, under the supervision of Robert L. Letsinger. He then did postdoctoral research with Peter G. Schultz at the University of California, San Francisco. In 1997, Chen joined the faculty of the University of Chicago as an assistant professor. He was promoted to associate professor in 2000 and to professor in 2004. He moved to New York University in 2008, where he is the director of the chemistry department. The 2005 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to Chen and Richard R. Ernst for the development of the anti-cancer drug Erlotinib (marketed as Tarceva). Chen's portion of the prize was specifically for the design and synthesis of the precursor to erlotinib, an epidermal growth factor receptor kinase inhibitor. In addition to his research, Chen has been active in promoting the development of science in China. In 2007, he was the co-organizer of the first International Symposium on Chinese Researchers in the United States. In 2008, he co-founded the company Aviogenics Inc. for the development of therapeutic monoclonal antibodies. In 2009, he was appointed as the chief scientist of the National Institute for Communicable Disease at the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention. In 2013, he became the director of the National Institute for Communicable Disease. In 2014, he was appointed as the dean of the School of Pharmaceutical Science at Tsinghua University. In 2015, Chen was awarded the honorary doctorate degree from the University of Science and Technology of China.

2020 Houston Outlaws season The 2020 Houston Outlaws season was the third season of the Houston Outlaws's existence in the Overwatch League. The Outlaws began the season with three consecutive wins, two of which were shutouts. The team's first loss of the season came in their fourth match, as they were defeated by the Los Angeles Gladiators. The Outlaws finished the regular season with 28 wins and 21 losses, which was enough to claim the third seed in the North America region. In the North America playoffs, the Outlaws defeated the Dallas Fuel in the first round, but lost to the Los Angeles Gladiators in the second round. The Outlaws' final game of the season was against the Gladiators in the lower bracket finals, where they won 3–1 and claimed the third North America seed to the 2020 Overwatch League Grand Finals. At the Grand Finals, the Outlaws defeated the Seoul Dynasty in the opening round, but ultimately lost to the San Francisco Shock in the upper bracket finals. ## Preceding offseason ### Organizational changes In early September 2019, the Outlaws promoted Scott Logie to the role of head coach, after he had served as an assistant coach since the team's inception in 2017. The Outlaws also hired Chris Puckett as an assistant coach; Puckett had previously been the head coach of Overwatch Contenders team Second Wind. ### Player signings The Outlaws did not make any player acquisitions during the offseason. ### Midseason acquisitions The Outlaws did not make any midseason acquisitions. ## Regular season The Outlaws began their third Overwatch League season on February 8, 2020, against the Los Angeles Gladiators with a 3–0 victory. The Outlaws' first loss of the season came in their fourth match, as they were defeated by the Gladiators 3–1. The Outlaws finished the regular season with 28 wins and 21 losses, which was enough to claim the third seed in the North America region. ## Postseason As the third seed in the North America region, the Outlaws began their postseason on September 3 in the first round of the North America playoffs. The Outlaws swept the Dallas Fuel 3–0 in the first round. The Outlaws' next match was against the Gladiators in the second round, where they were defeated 3–0. The Outlaws' final game of the season was against the Gladiators in the lower bracket finals, where they won 3–1 and claimed the third North America seed to the 2020 Overwatch League Grand Finals. At the Grand Finals, the Outlaws defeated the Seoul Dynasty in the opening round, but ultimately lost to the San Francisco Shock in the upper bracket finals. ## Awards Houston Outlaws player Jay "sinatraa" Won was named the Overwatch League's Most Valuable Player. ## League standings ### Stage 1 | Pts | L | Stage 1 | Pos | W | Team | Rng | | --

Saul Teukolsky (born October 16, 1953) is an American astrophysicist, the William R. Kenan Jr. Professor of Physics and Astronomy at the University of California, Berkeley, and an adjunct professor at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. Teukolsky was born in New York City. He received a B.S. in physics from Cornell University in 1975, and a Ph.D. in astrophysics from Harvard University in 1979, supervised by John Huchra. After a postdoctoral fellowship at the California Institute of Technology, he joined the faculty of the University of California, Berkeley in 1983, and was appointed the William R. Kenan Jr. Professor in 1998. His research areas are cosmology, general relativity, and the formation and evolution of structure in the universe. He has published more than 250 papers, and has written or edited several books, including the undergraduate textbook Astronomy: The Universe in Your Pocket (with Don Goldman, Neil Dalrymple, and Michael Aivazis; Cambridge University Press, 2015), the graduate-level textbook Physical Foundations of Cosmology (with Michael Turner and Sidney Drell; Princeton University Press, 1997), and the reference work Cosmological Physics (with Andrew Hamilton; Cambridge University Press, 2007). Teukolsky has been a member of the faculty at the University of California, Berkeley since 1983, and was appointed the William R. Kenan Jr. Professor in 1998. He was a visiting professor at the California Institute of Technology from 1996 to 1997, at the Institute for Advanced Study in 1998, and at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas in 1998. Teukolsky has supervised the research of 40 doctoral students, and has advised 14 postdocs. He is a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the American Physical Society, and the International Society for General Relativity and Gravitation, and is a member of the American Astronomical Society and the International Astronomical Union. Teukolsky has won several awards for his research, including the National Academy of Sciences Award for Scientific Discovery (1992), the American Physical Society Julius Edgar Lilienfeld Prize (1998), the American Astronomical Society James Craig Watson Award (1999), the American Physical Society Abraham Pais Prize for Research in the Physical Sciences (2004), the American Astronomical Society Chambliss Award (2004), the American Physical Society Fundamental Physics Prize (2012), and the Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics (2013). He was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 1998, and to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1999.

Benjamin Franklin Tracy (March 25, 1808 – October 14, 1868) was an American lawyer, soldier, railroad executive, and politician who served as the 27th United States Secretary of the Treasury, the 8th United States Attorney General, and the 7th United States Secretary of State. Tracy was born in Washington, D.C. He was the son of lawyer and politician David Templeman Tracy and his wife Elizabeth, and was named after his famous grandfather, Benjamin Franklin. His father was the private secretary to President John Adams, and his grandfather was the United States Attorney General under President George Washington. Tracy attended the local schools and graduated from the University of North Carolina in 1827. He studied law and was admitted to the bar to practice law in 1829, at 21 years of age. After a brief career in law, he became a member of the state militia and rose to the rank of colonel before leaving the military to enter politics. In 1846, he was elected to the United States House of Representatives, serving from 1847 to 1849. In 1849, he was elected to the United States Senate, serving from 1850 to 1851. In 1852, he was elected Governor of the state of New York, serving from 1853 to 1854. He was a member of the Whig Party and became the chairman of the New York State Republican Committee in 1855. During the American Civil War, he served in the Union Army as a colonel and was taken prisoner by the Confederate forces in the Battle of First Bull Run. After his release, he was given the rank of major general and served as the chief of staff for General George B. McClellan in the Army of the Potomac. After the war, he was the president of the Union Pacific Railroad from 1866 to 1868. He died in a train accident while inspecting the construction of the railroad in 1868. Tracy was married to Louise Cox of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in 1832. They had five children.

D-3 (video) "D-3" is the name for a series of analog and digital video recording formats developed by Sony. The analog format was introduced in 1982, and the digital format was introduced in 1995. Both formats are now obsolete. The analog D-3 format was a three-quarter-inch (19 mm) videocassette format that was capable of recording one hour of color video. It was similar to Sony's Betamax format, but the recording was done with a higher bandwidth, giving a higher horizontal resolution. It also used a different recording mechanism. Unlike Betamax, which used a single video head, the D-3 format used three video heads, one for each color. This gave a better color response, but required more precision during the recording and playback process. The format was not popular, and it was discontinued in 1986. The digital D-3 format was a professional digital video format that was capable of recording two hours of uncompressed digital video data. It used a large, heavy tape cartridge that was similar in size and shape to the analog D-3 format. The digital D-3 format was popular for a while, but it was eventually replaced by other formats, such as the Sony XDCAM format.

Willow River is a village in Pine County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 895 at the 2010 census. The village is located along the Willow River, a tributary of the St. Croix River. U.S. Highway 8 and Minnesota Highway 95 are the main routes in the community. The community was originally incorporated as Willow River Township on April 30, 1873, and re-organized as a village on December 3, 1898. The name was taken from the river. According to the United States Census Bureau, the village has a total area of 3.60 square miles (9.37 km2), all land. As of the census of 2000, there were 852 people, 343 households, and 233 families residing in the village. The population density was 228.3 inhabitants per square mile (88.1/2). There were 387 housing units at an average density of 108.9 per square mile (42.7/2). The racial makeup of the village was 98.43% White, 0.12% African American, 0.12% Native American, 0.47% Asian, 0.12% Pacific Islander, 0.12% from other races, and 0.95% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.52% of the population. There were 343 households, out of which 28.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 56.7% were married couples living together, 6.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 31.2% were non-families. 27.0% of all households were made up of individuals, and 12.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.42 and the average family size was 3.00. In the village, the population was spread out, with 23.1% under the age of 18, 6.5% from 18 to 24, 26.7% from 25 to 44, 24.1% from 45 to 64, and 19.6% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 40 years. For every 100 females, there were 99.8 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 101.5 males. As of 2000 the median income for a household in the village was $35,417, and the median income for a family was $47,083. Men had a median income of $30,000 versus $19,375 for women. The per capita income for the village was $16,929. About 2.8% of families and 5.8% of the population were below the poverty line, including 4.4% of those under age 18 and 6.8% of those age 65 or over.

Holocytochrome-c synthase is an integral membrane protein found in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of the cell. It is involved in the synthesis and assembly of the heme cofactor into the cytochrome c molecule. The synthase is a dimer of two identical subunits, each consisting of three transmembrane spanning domains and a large luminal domain. The luminal domain contains two conserved regions, C1 and C2, that are involved in the recognition and binding of the heme precursor, porphyrin. The enzyme catalyzes two reactions: the first is the ATP-dependent condensation of two porphyrin molecules to form a dimethoxybenzoquinol, and the second is the transfer of the dimethoxybenzoquinol to the cytochrome c molecule. The dimethoxybenzoquinol is attached to the cytochrome c by a thioether bond to a conserved cysteine residue in the protein. The assembled holocytochrome c is then transported to the mitochondrial inner membrane, where it is involved in the electron transport chain. The holocytochrome c synthase is expressed in all tissues and is found in all eukaryotes, including plants, animals, and fungi. In humans, the gene encoding the synthase is located on chromosome 19, and mutations in the gene can lead to the development of anemia. The synthase is also a drug target for the treatment of malaria, as it is involved in the production of the heme cofactor for the malaria parasite. Kostenurka Island (Russian: Остров Костенурка; Japanese: コスツェヌールカ島, Kosutzenouluka Shima) is an island in the Sea of Japan, off the east coast of Russia. Its name is derived from the Russian word "kosyenok" ("miner"). Administratively, it is part of the Khabarovsk Krai. In Russian, the island is sometimes called Ratmanov Island, after a Russian explorer, Nikolai Ivanovich Ratmanov, who visited it in the early 20th century. The island is long, about 30 km (19 mi), and narrow, about 1–3 km (0.62–1.86 mi). It is covered by taiga forest. The highest point is Mount Kokos, located in the center of the island, with a height of 724 metres (2,400 ft). Kostenurka Island is located about 130 km (81 mi) northeast of Khabarovsk. It is separated from the Russian mainland by the Khabarovsk Gulf in the west, and from the Kamchatka Peninsula by the Karaginsky Gulf in the east. The island is home to brown bears, sika deer, and sea otters. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, the island was the site of a silver mine, and a town of the same name, established by a British company in 1880. The mine was active from 1898 to 1917, and was re-activated in the 1960s, when it was controlled by the Soviet Union. During the Russian Civil War, the island was occupied by the Whites, and then by the Soviets. In the 21st century, the island is a popular tourist destination for residents of Khabarovsk.

The Kalamazoo-class monitor was a group of eight monitors built for the United States Navy during World War II. The monitors were named after cities and towns in Michigan and were designed to provide naval gunfire support to forces ashore. The monitors were very large for their day, being much larger than the vast majority of other ships of the period. They were also the first U.S. Navy capital ships to be designed and built from the ground up since the Mississippi-class battleship 35 years before. The Kalamazoo-class monitors were laid down beginning in 1944, but not completed until after the end of the war. The monitors were equipped with a variety of weapons, including a single 16-inch gun in a turret forward of the superstructure, two to four 105 mm guns in an amidships turret, two to four 40 mm anti-aircraft guns, and various other anti-aircraft and anti-submarine weapons. The Kalamazoo-class monitors were placed into service with the U.S. Navy from 1946 to 1957, though most were placed into reserve or decommissioned before then. One of the monitors, the USS Kalamazoo, was sold to the Turkish Navy in 1954 and served with them until the 1980s. The other seven monitors were placed in the reserve fleet and were later sunk in naval weapons tests.

Sharyn November (born July 16, 1957) is an American editor and writer of children's books. November was born in New York City. She received her B.A. in English from the University of Rochester and her M.A. in English from New York University. She began her publishing career in the editorial department at Bantam Books, and then moved to Grosset & Dunalp, where she was an associate editor for the hardcover imprint. In 1982, she joined Harper & Row (which would later be acquired by Scholastic Corporation) as an editorial assistant, and three years later was promoted to associate editor. In 1989, she became the senior editor of the HarperCollins imprint, and in 1996 she was named editor-in-chief of the children's division. In 2000, she became editorial director of the trade division at Scholastic. In 2007, she left Scholastic to focus on her own writing and editing. As an editor, November has worked with many authors, including Caroline B. Cooney, whose books she edited for more than twenty years. In addition to editing, she has written more than a dozen books for young readers, including The Book of Life, The Armageddon Adventure, and the Ghosthunters series. Her books have been translated into multiple languages, including French, German, Italian, Portuguese, Spanish, Swedish, and Japanese. November lives in New York City.

2024 In the year 2024, the Earth will complete one revolution around the Sun, and the Moon will complete one revolution around the Earth. In the year 2024, the month of February will have 28 days and the month of June will have 30 days. In the year 2024, the equinoxes will occur on the 3rd of March and the 22nd of September. In the year 2024, the solstices will occur on the 21st of June and the 20th of December. In the year 2024, the Saint Valentine's Day will occur on the 14th of February, the Saint Patrick's Day will occur on the 17th of March, the Easter will occur on the 11th of April, the Earth Day will occur on the 22nd of April, the Teacher's Day will occur on the 27th of April, the World Book Day will occur on the 23rd of April, the International Workers' Day will occur on the 1st of May, the Mother's Day will occur on the 8th of May, the Father's Day will occur on the 15th of June, the Flag Day will occur on the 14th of June, the Independence Day will occur on the 4th of July, the Labor Day will occur on the 5th of September, the Columbus Day will occur on the 10th of October, the Veterans Day will occur on the 11th of November, the Thanksgiving Day will occur on the 22nd of November, the Christmas will occur on the 25th of December, the New Year's Day will occur on the 1st of January, and the Chinese New Year will occur on the 21st of January. This is an incomplete list of holidays in the year 2024.

ADAPT Act The ADAPT Act is bi-partisan legislation introduced by U.S. Senators Ron Wyden (D-OR) and Todd Young (R-IN) on March 3, 2017. The bill aims to increase U.S. government spending on adaptive sporting activities. The bill was passed by the Senate on September 7, 2018, and by the House on December 19, 2018. The ADAPT Act is intended to encourage community-based adaptive sports and recreation programs and improve access to adaptive sports equipment. The bill also seeks to increase the number of certified adaptive sports instructors. The bill has three main provisions. The first requires the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to establish a program to provide grants to eligible entities for the purpose of providing adaptive sports and recreation opportunities to disabled veterans. The second requires the Department of Defense (DOD) to provide adaptive sports equipment to eligible entities for purposes of providing adaptive sports and recreation opportunities to disabled service members. The third requires the Department of the Interior to establish a program to provide grants to eligible entities for the purpose of providing adaptive sports and recreation opportunities to disabled Native Americans. In addition, the ADAPT Act requires the VA, DOD, and Interior to designate an official to coordinate their respective adaptive sports and recreation programs.

Nine Stories Productions, LLC. is an American production company founded by Dan Jinks and Richard Suckle, two former studio executives, in 2015. It is based in Beverly Hills, California. The company's first production was the 2016 animated film Storks, which was produced in association with Warner Animation Group for release by Warner Bros. Pictures. In January 2016, the company hired former WME agent David Flynn to be its head of development. In June 2017, the company optioned the rights to a film adaptation of the musical Hamilton, to be produced in partnership with Hamilton creator Lin-Manuel Miranda and his Hamilton colleagues. The company will also produce a film adaptation of the musical In the Heights, with a script by Jeremy McCarter and music and lyrics by Miranda, who will also produce. In February 2018, the company signed a deal with Netflix to produce the original series The Society. In May 2018, the company hired former Sony Pictures Television executives James Costos and Michael Preger to oversee the development and production of television projects. In July 2018, the company acquired a script by Michael Lesslie for a film called The Little Mermaid, to be produced for Disney. In September 2018, the company hired veteran executive Andrew Mittman to head its television division.

Jody Harris (born April 25, 1958) is an American musician, songwriter, record producer, and author. In the early 1970s, Harris played guitar in a succession of bands, including the Java Blues Band (not to be confused with the British band of the same name), Tangerine Dream, and Plateau. In 1974 he became a member of the British band Egg, and played on their first two albums. In 1976 he joined the band Queen, as the replacement for Brian May's previous guitar technician, to play on their A Night at the Opera album. He also contributed to the making of the next two Queen albums, and co-wrote "It's In His Kiss" from the band's 1982 album Hot Space. In the early 1980s, Harris produced several recordings by the British musician Howard Jones. His production work with Jones included the hit singles "New Song", "What Is Love?", "Life in One Day", and "No One Is to Blame", and the albums Human's Lib and Dream into Action. In 1985, Harris produced the album Once Upon a Time by the Canadian singer-songwriter Kim Mitchell, including the hit single "Patio Lanterns", and the album by the American singer-songwriter Shana Morrison, who was the daughter of the musician Van Morrison. In the late 1980s and early 1990s, Harris produced the two Mercury/Polygram albums by the British band Kokomo, and the album The Great Jones by Howard Jones. In 1988, Harris co-produced (with Robert "Mutt" Lange) the album Bad Medicine by the American rock band Bon Jovi, including the hit single "Bad Medicine". In 1989, he co-produced (with Lange) the album Jersey Girl by the American singer-songwriter and actress Olivia Newton-John, which included the hit single "Love and Let Go". He also co-produced (with Steve Van Zandt) the 1990 album The Ghost of Tom Joad by the American musician Bruce Springsteen. In the early 1990s, Harris produced the two albums by the Canadian singer-songwriter Alannah Myles, including the hit single "Black Velvet". In 1995, he co-produced (with Lange) the album Loungin' by the American musician Barry White. As an author, Harris wrote the liner notes for the 2002 re-release of the Bon Jovi album 7800° Fahrenheit. In 2008, he wrote the book Fission: The Making of an Album, which was published by Jawbone Press. The book is a diary of the making of the album Fission by the British musician Steve Harris, which was released in 2006.

1309 Hyperborea 1309 Hyperborea is a large centaur (or possibly a smallish irregular satellite) in the outer Solar System, orbiting the Sun between Jupiter and Uranus. It was first discovered in 1925 by the Scottish astronomer James Hilton Brown, who found it by accident while observing Comet 1343 (Merson–PonsART). The name comes from the mythical land of Hyperborea. 1309 Hyperborea has a highly eccentric orbit, ranging from 5.4 to 19.5 times the orbit of Jupiter. The orbit is also inclined at an angle of 171 degrees to the plane of the planets, making it a retrograde orbit. The orbit is so retrograde that it is almost a mirror image of the orbit of Jupiter. The perihelion is located inside the orbit of Neptune. It has a semi-major axis of 21.4 AU, a perihelion of 4.34 AU, and an aphelion of 30.01 AU. The orbital period is about 243 years. 1309 Hyperborea was the first minor planet known to have a retrograde orbit. The retrograde motion was discovered in 1989 by the Canadian astronomer R. A. Kyle. The Minor Planet Center lists over 2,000 known minor planets, but the actual number is much higher, as many minor planets are lost in the solar glare and many have orbits too uncertain to be tracked. In addition, the Minor Planet Center only lists minor planets that have been observed at opposition within the last century. 1309 Hyperborea is approximately 100 miles (160 km) in diameter. It has a mass of 3.44 x 10^21 kg, making it one of the two most massive centaurs (the other being 5145 Pholus). The density is 1.33 g/cm³, which is close to the density of water. 1309 Hyperborea was first discovered in 1925 by the Scottish astronomer James Hilton Brown, who found it by accident while observing Comet 1343 (Merson–PonsART). The comet was discovered by the French astronomer Ernest Joseph Merson in 1898, and was lost shortly after its discovery. The comet was recovered in 1925 by the French astronomer Raymond Pons, who was using the same telescope that Merson used to discover the comet. Brown observed the comet in late April and early May, and noticed that it had a small companion. The companion was later identified as 1309 Hyperborea. 1309 Hyperborea was the first minor planet known to have a retrograde orbit. The retrograde motion was discovered in 1989 by the Canadian astronomer R. A. Kyle.

Hedy West (September 16, 1927 – November 30, 2005) was an American folk singer and songwriter, who performed and recorded music with her husband, singer-songwriter Robert West. Hedy was born Hedwig Eva Maria Kiesler in Vienna, Austria, the daughter of Joseph Kiesler, a Jewish dentist, and his wife, Elsa (née Altmann), a Catholic. Her father's family was from Hungary, and her mother's family was Austrian. She had two older siblings, Irene and Paul. When Hedy was six years old, the family moved to Palestine, then under the British Mandate, where she attended the Theresianum School in Jerusalem. At the age of 14, she was sent to a boarding school in England to complete her education. She received a bachelor's degree in English and French from the University of Cairo in 1949, and in 1952, she earned a master's degree in psychology from the University of Vienna. In 1947, Hedy met the American singer and songwriter Robert West (né Schmerhorn) in Jerusalem, where he was performing with the USO. The couple married in 1949 and lived in Israel, Egypt, and Europe before moving to the United States in 1953. In 1961, they settled in New York City, where they became fixtures of the Greenwich Village folk music scene. They performed as a duo, with Hedy accompanying Robert on guitar, and also played a key role in the development of the coffeehouse movement. Their concert appearances included a well-received performance at the Newport Folk Festival in 1965. The couple also appeared on television, including a 1961 episode of the folk music series Hootenanny, and in the 1966 BBC television documentary The Folk Song Revival. In addition to her work with her husband, Hedy West also released two solo albums, Hedy West (1966) and Lovin' in the Last Chance Saloon (1972). After a long battle with cancer, she died at the age of 78 in 2005. In 2011, the soundtrack to the documentary film The Road to Hope Rose was released, featuring previously unheard recordings of Hedy West.

Plexon Inc. is a company headquartered in Fremont, California, that designs and manufactures neural recording equipment. The company was founded in 1989 by two researchers at the University of Washington, William T. Newsome and Gordon M. Shepherd, to build equipment that shepherd and Newsome had designed to record neural activity in the retina and brain. Plexon's products include hardware for neural recording and analysis, such as the Multisite Data Acquisition (Plexon MDAD) system, and software for neural data analysis, such as the Plexon NeuroExplorer software. The company also offers a range of services, including data analysis and technical support. In 2014, Plexon launched the HD- irres centimetric neural recording system, which enables researchers to record neural activity in awake, freely moving mice. The system consists of a headstage, which is implanted in the mouse's head, and a cable, which is connected to the headstage and to a computer. The system is designed to record neural activity in the mouse's cortex and to be used in research on learning and memory, decision-making, and motor control. In 2015, Plexon launched the ProStudiosoftware platform, which is designed to enable researchers to create and manage custom software applications for data acquisition and analysis. The platform includes a development environment and a set of tools for building and deploying applications. In 2017, Plexon launched the Plexon Vivarium, which is a modular, scalable system for monitoring and controlling environmental variables such as temperature, humidity, and lighting in animal research laboratories. The system is designed to be used in conjunction with the company's other products, such as the MDAD system, to enable researchers to monitor and control environmental variables in real time. In 2018, Plexon launched the PixelluNeuro integrated photometry and electrophysiology system, which is designed to enable researchers to measure neural activity and calcium levels in cells in awake, freely moving mice. The system consists of a headstage, which is implanted in the mouse's head, and a fiber, which is connected to the headstage and to a light source and a photodetector. The system is designed to be used in research on learning and memory, decision-making, and motor control.

Yang Fuqing ( traditional Chinese: 楊富清; simplified Chinese: 杨富清; pinyin: Yáng Fùqīng; born January 1957) is a Chinese politician and the current Minister of Agriculture and Rural Affairs. Yang was born in Linyi County, Shandong in January 1957. After the Cultural Revolution, he attended the Linyi Normal School, and then entered the Huazhong Normal University in March 1978. After graduating in August 1982, he became a teacher at the High School of Liaocheng City, and then was promoted to the position of principal in 1984. In 1985, he entered the Shandong Institute of Education and was promoted to the Deputy Dean in 1990. In 1992, he was appointed as the Dean of the Shandong Normal University. In June 1995, he became the President of the Shandong Normal University. In September 1999, he was appointed as the Party Secretary of the Shandong Normal University. In March 2008, Yang was appointed as the Party Secretary of the Shandong University of Technology. In August 2011, he was appointed as the President of the Shandong University of Technology. In March 2013, he was appointed as the Party Secretary of the Jining No.1 High School. In August 2013, he was appointed as the Vice Mayor of Jining. In July 2015, he was appointed as the Mayor of Jining. In January 2016, he was appointed as the Secretary of the Shandong Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China. In April 2020, he was appointed as the Minister of Agriculture and Rural Affairs.

Charles Harnick (born June 15, 1927) is an American composer, writer, and producer. In 1955 he co-founded the record label Mercury Records, where he was the vice president and general manager. He produced the first recording of the opera Candide, with the New York City Opera, in 1956. He later became the head of the classical division at RCA Records, where he produced the original cast album of Company, the first studio recording of Godspell, and the revival cast album of The Sound of Music. He also produced the cast album of the ill-fated Broadway musical Harry, which was his only Broadway credit as a producer. In the early 1960s, Harnick wrote the words and music to the theme song of the television series It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World, which was performed by Sammy Davis, Jr. and later used as the theme for New York magazine's "The Week in Review" show. In the late 1960s, he wrote the music to the songs "To Life (L'Chaim)" and "If I Were a Rich Man" for the musical Fiddler on the Roof. Harnick is the author of the book The Man Who Wrote the Book, about the writing of the musical Annie.

Proto-Afroasiatic language The Proto-Afroasiatic language, or Proto-Khoisan, is the reconstructed language that is the ancestor of the Afroasiatic languages. It has been reconstructed using the comparative method from proto-Afroasiatic vocabulary, and, to a lesser extent, from proposed cognates in other language families, especially the Semitic, Cushitic, and Chadic branches of Afroasiatic. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is generally held to have had a Semitic-style (or Abrahamic) triliteral phoneme system, with a three-way distinction between oral, nasal, and velar consonants. This system is well-documented in the Semitic and Cushitic branches, and is also assumed to have existed in Chadic and the putative Khoisan and East African branches. The most widely used reconstruction of Proto-Afroasiatic is that of Ehret, with six vowels, three pairs of diphthongs, and twenty-eight consonants. The table below gives the symbols used by Ehret and their phonetic values in the IPA. TheProto-Afroasiatic language had a number of other notable features, including an extensive set of ejective consonants, a three-way distinction between central and lateral consonants, and a register- contrasts in the vowels. The language had a number of implosive consonants, which are preserved in the Cushitic and Chadic branches, and a number of "click" consonants, which are preserved in the Khoisan and East African branches. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a basic word order of subject–verb–object, although a number of alternatives have been proposed. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a rich set of grammatical case markings, with at least eight grammatical cases, possibly including ablative, genitive, locative, ablative/genitive, and locative/genitive. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a set of distinctive pronouns for the first and second persons, as well as a set of gender-specific pronouns for the third person. The Proto-Afroasiatic language may have also had a set of inclusive and exclusive pronouns for the first person, as well as a set of "clitic" pronouns for the second and third persons. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a rich set of grammatical agreements, with distinctive marking for number, gender, and case on nouns, adjectives, and pronouns. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a number of special grammatical markings forwords denoting actions, states, and locations. These markings are preserved in the Cushitic and Chadic branches, and are also found in some Semitic languages. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a rich set of grammatical moods and tenses, with distinctive markings for indicative, subjunctive, and imperative moods, as well as for past, present, and future tenses. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a number of special grammatical particles, which are used to mark the beginning and end of sentences, as well as to indicate new information and emphasis. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a number of special grammatical conjunctions and adverbs, which are used to mark the relationship between words and sentences, as well as to indicate time and place. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a number of special grammatical interjections, which are used to mark greetings and other social interactions. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a number of special grammatical suffixes and otherword-forming devices, which are used to form new words from existing words. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a number of special grammatical prefixes and otherword-forming devices, which are used to form new words from existing words. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a number of special grammatical infixes and otherword-forming devices, which are used to form new words from existing words. The Proto-Afroasiatic language is thought to have had a number of special grammatical elements, which are used to form new words from existing words.

Border Roads Organisation The Border Roads Organisation (BRO) is a road construction and maintenance sector of the Indian Army. The BRO is responsible for the construction and maintenance of roads and other infrastructure in the border areas of the country. It is a combined arms engineering force, with personnel from the Indian Army's Corps of Engineers and the civilian staff of the Border Roads Organisation. The BRO has also been involved in disaster relief operations in India. The Border Roads Organisation was founded on 7 May 1960. The organisation has never been granted the status of a Corps in the Indian Army. The organisation is headquartered in New Delhi. The BRO is responsible for the construction and maintenance of about 33,000 km of roads and about 19,000 m of permanent and semi-permanent bridges in the border areas of the country. It has constructed about 600 km of roads and 40 bridges in the last three years. Strategic complements are goods or services that are not directly interchangeable, but which are closely linked in the business-plan sense, in that they are components of a single business process and/or platform. The concept of strategic complementarity is the basis for much of the collaborative R&D that occurs between firms, as a way to expand the scope of their markets and to create new markets. A strategic complement is a product or service that adds extra value to another product or service. complements are not interchangeable with the product they complement. complements create new markets for the product they complement. complements are not stand-alone products. Borsele (Borssela in West Flemish) is a village and a municipality in the Belgian province of West Flanders. The municipality comprises the villages of Borsele, Cadzand, Eede, Ellewoutsdijk, and Grootebroek. Borsele is located in the extreme southwest of Belgium, on the border with the Netherlands. It is also located in the inlet of the Westerschelde. The municipality of Borsele is known for its long, sandy beaches and the large psychiatric hospital of Westerschelde. In 2021, the municipality had a population of 9,569. The name Borsele is thought to be derived from the Old English word "bore," meaning "deep hole," and the suffix "-sela," meaning "sandy soil." The name "Borssela" first appears in a charter from 1111. The village and the municipality were part of the territory of the counts of Flanders for much of their history. In 1583, the territory was acquired by Philip II of Spain, and it then became part of the Spanish Netherlands. After the French Revolution, the area was ruled by the French from 1795 to 1814. The Netherlands and Belgium were united as the United Kingdom of the Netherlands from 1815 to 1830, and Borsele became part of the province of Antwerp. After the separation of Belgium from the Netherlands, the area became part of West Flanders. Borsele is known for its sand dunes and beaches. The beach is a popular destination for tourists and day-trippers from Belgium and the Netherlands. The beach is also a popular destination for birdwatchers, as it is an important stop on the migratory path of many birds. The village is home to a number of restaurants and cafes, as well as a small grocery store. The main industry in the village is tourism. The village is also home to a number of artists and artisans. The municipality of Borsele is also known for its large psychiatric hospital, the Westerschelde Hospital. The hospital is located in the village of Westerschelde, and it has a long history. The hospital was founded in the 19th century, and it has been a major employer in the area for many years. In recent years, the municipality of Borsele has been working to promote the area as a tourist destination. The municipality has developed a number of tourist attractions and activities, and it has worked to improve the infrastructure of the area.

2797 Teucer is a large Jupiter trojan from the Greek camp, approximately 58 km in diameter. It was first discovered on 5 January 1982 by astronomers with the discovering telescope: the 1.52 m f/2.15 reflector + CCD of the former German Democratic Republic's Democratic Republic of Germany. The name Teucer was chosen after the Trojan prince Teucer, son of King Priam and Hecuba, and the brother of Paris and Hector. Teucer has been observed with the IRAS, the Spitzer Space Telescope, the Herschel Space Telescope, and the Juno spacecraft. In the night between 19 and 20 January 2017, the object was occulted by Jupiter's moon Europa. Teucer is one of the largest Jupiter trojans. It has been estimated that it has a mass of about 4.7 km (2.9 mi) excluding its icy layer, and a diameter of about 58 km (36 mi), based on IRAS observations. Later estimated mass is 7.3 km (4.5 mi) with a diameter of 57.3 km (35.6 mi). Teucer's surface is covered with blackish material, possibly a mixture of dust and tholins. The spacecraft Juno has observed a number of large-scale features on the surface, including a dark spot and a bright spot. Teucer's rotation period is approximately 7.5 hours.

Tim Bledsoe (born January 20, 1961) is an American actor, singer, and composer. Bledsoe was born in New York City, the son of author and actress Cherry Jones and the journalist and author Howard K. Smith. He attended the Usdan Center for the Creative and Performing Arts, and graduated from Hampshire College with a bachelor's degree in 1983. Bledsoe's Broadway debut was in the 1986 revival of My Fair Lady, in which he played the leading role of Professor Henry Higgins. He was also in the original Broadway cast of the musical The Secret Garden, playing the role of Colin. In 1988 he starred in the one-man show The Man Who Was Peter Pan, playing the title role. Bledsoe's film debut was in the 1987 film version of The Secret Garden, in which he played the role of Colin. He was also in the films The Bodyguard, The Good Mother, and Tootsie. His television credits include The Golden Girls, Barney & Friends, and Law & Order. Bledsoe is a singer/songwriter and has released two albums, Tim Bledsoe and You and The New Old-Fashioned Way.

Tetton, Kingston St Mary Tetton (also known as Tettan, Tuthan, or Tydnell) is an historic estate in the parish of Kingston St Mary in the county of Somerset. The estate was owned by the Tuttill family from the 15th to the 17th century, and then by the Nethaway family, before being sold to the Glanville family in the 18th century, who held it until the 20th century. The estate consisted of a capital messuage, two farms, 21 cottages, and about 200 acres of land. The estate was passed to the Tuttill family by the marriage of William de Tydnell to Agnes de Tuttill in the early 15th century. The Tuttill family lived at the estate for three generations, and then sold it to the Nethaway family in about 1570. In 1641 the Nethaways sold it to William Dunch, a clothier from Whichford, Oxfordshire. It then passed to his son, also called William, who was a member of the Dunch family of Over Norton, Oxfordshire. The younger William died in 1704, leaving the estate to his widow, Mary, for life. It then passed to his son, also called William, who died in 1757. By this time the estate was in financial difficulties, and it was sold to John Glanville of Milborne Port in 1761. When John died in 1808 he was succeeded by his son, William. William died in 1821, and the estate was then passed to his brother, Henry. The estate was sold to the Duke of Wellington in 1837. It was then sold again in 1889 to a Mr James, who sold it to a Mrope in 1899. In 1901 the estate was bought by Lord Bonomy, who sold it to a Mrs Stiles in 1908. In 1938 it was bought by Mr and Mrs Palmer, who sold it to Mr and Mrs Gregge in 1946. It was then sold to Mr and Mrs Dando in 1948, and to Mr and Mrs Brooks in 1950. In 1961 it was bought by a Mr Harris, who sold it to the Nettleton family in 1967.

Vien (Hebrew: בֵּין) is the name of a rabbinical dynasty that flourished in the 17th and 18th centuries in Moravia, then part of the Holy Roman Empire. It was named after the family's progenitor, David ben Jacob Vien, who was a tossefist and dayan in Moravia. The Viens were prominent Talmudists and Halakhists, and the dynasty produced at least three rabbis who held the office of Chief Rabbi of Moravia. The Vien dynasty began with David ben Jacob Vien (c. 1650 – c. 1710), a tossefist and dayan in Moravia. He was the author of Perek Cohanim (1692), a commentary on the Pentateuch. David's son, Judah Leib ben David Vien (c. 1670 – c. 1710), was a rabbi and author of Oz Lavan (1702), a commentary on the Pentateuch. He is also known for his opposition to the adoption of the Shulchan Aruch as the standard code of law for the Jews of Moravia. The Vien dynasty reached its peak with Joseph ben Judah Leib Vien (c. 1670 – c. 1757), a rabbi and author of commentary on the Pentateuch. He was also the author of Tosefot ha-Shas (1740), a commentary on the Gemara. Joseph's son, Judah Herschel ben Joseph Vien (c. 1700 – c. 1770), was a rabbi and author of commentary on the Pentateuch. He was also the author of Tosefot ha-Shas (1764), a commentary on the Gemara. The Vien dynasty ended with Judah Leib ben Judah Herschel Vien (c. 1750 – c. 1792), a rabbi and author of commentary on the Pentateuch. He was also the author of Tosefot ha-Shas (1788), a commentary on the Gemara.

I Know Who Holds Tomorrow "I Know Who Holds Tomorrow" is a song recorded by American country music artist Larry Gatlin. It was released in October 1973 as the third and final single from his debut solo album, The Pilgrim. The song was written by Gatlin, along with his brothers, Steve and Rudy, and became the group's first Top 10 hit. The song tells of a man who is in love with a woman, and who tries to convince her that he will be waiting for her tomorrow, despite his lack of wealth or social status. The song's title comes from a line in the chorus, in which the singer states that he knows "who holds tomorrow, and I know he holds the key". "I Know Who Holds Tomorrow" was Gatlin's first major hit, reaching number 6 on the Billboard Hot Country Singles chart. It was also the first of a string of top 10 hits that the Gatlin Brothers would have, beginning with their number 1 hit, "All the Gold in California", from their second album, Del Rio, Texas, Rio Grande, Texas. The song is featured on the 2008 album The Essential Larry Gatlin, which is a part of the Essential series of country music albums.

Edward Tyrrel Channing (13 September 1790 – 31 December 1856) was an English classical scholar, theologian, and author. He was born in London, the son of William Channing the younger and his wife Mary, and was educated at Charterhouse School, London, and at Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge. In 1812 he was elected to a fellowship at Caius, and in 1814 he took holy orders. He was assistant tutor at the college from 1816 to 1819, and tutor from 1820 to 1824. In the latter year he was appointed Blundell's Professor of Music in the university, an office which he resigned in 1840. In 1825 he was elected a fellow of the Royal Society. Besides numerous contributions to the Quarterly Review, the Edinburgh Review, and other periodicals, he published, separately, An Oration, delivered before the University of Cambridge, on the Benefits of the Study of History, in 1820, The Life of William Pitt, Earl of Chatham, in 1825, and The History of England, from the Peace of Paris, in 1815, to the Accession of George IV, in 1830, in 4 volumes. In the latter work he sought to combine the political history of England with a narrative of its social and economic development. The same plan was followed by his History of the United States, from their Settlement as Colonies, in 1776, to the Close of the Mexican War, in 1848, in 4 volumes, the first volume of which was published in 1855, shortly before his death, the second in 1857, and the third and fourth in 1860 and 1864, respectively. The fourth volume was completed by his son, William Leonard Channing. In addition to these works he published a series of volumes of sermons, lectures, and addresses, and a number of articles on classical and other subjects in the Quarterly Review, the Edinburgh Review, the Westminster Review, the Edinburgh Review, and other periodicals. He died in London on 31 December 1856.

Tettenhall College Tettenhall College is an independent day school for boys and girls aged 11 to 18. It is located in the village of Tettenhall, within the city of Wolverhampton, West Midlands, England. The College is a member of the Headmasters' and Headmistresses' Conference (HMC). In 2014, Tettenhall College was named the Independent School of the Year by the West Midlands' Chamber of Commerce. The College was founded in 1890 by the Rev. W. J. Galerie, who was also the first Headmaster. The school opened with eight boys and grew to just 25 in the first year. The first building to be erected was the central block, which is still in use today. In 2008 the College became fully co-educational, beginning with the admission of girls into the Sixth Form. In 2013 the College was acquired by the Alpha Plus Group and became part of the group's educational portfolio, which includes the London schools, Alpha Plus Academy, d'Overbroecks and Wetherby. In 2015 the College celebrated its 125th anniversary. The school offers a range of academic and extra-curricular activities, including drama, music, and sport. The College is a member of the Independent Schools Council and is inspected by the Independent Schools Inspectorate. In 2013, the school's inspection report stated that the College provided "an outstanding education for its pupils". In 2018, the school's inspection report stated that the College continued to provide "an outstanding education for its pupils". The school's most recent inspection took place in 2018.

Fairwater (Welsh: Y Faerwâr) is a district and community in the west of Cardiff, capital of Wales. It is situated in the east of the Vale of Glamorgan between the river Ely and the coast. The district is named after Fairwater Brook, which runs through it. The word 'fair' is derived from the Anglo-Saxon 'feir', meaning 'bright' or 'shining', and the Welsh 'awr' meaning 'course'. The name therefore means 'the bright stream'. Fairwater is a largely residential area, with a high proportion of detached housing. It has a number of schools, including Fairwater Comprehensive, which was built in 1964, and the private Fairwater Rudolf Steiner School. There are several parks in the area. These include Fairwater Park, which is next to the comprehensive school, and is host to a number of football matches in the summer. Limeslade Road Park is located further along the A4055, towards the coast, and is linked to the beach via a set of stairs. The A4055 road runs through the district, providing a link to the city centre to the east, and Barry and Penarth to the south. The M4 motorway passes to the north of the district.

Khan Tengri is a mountain in the Khövsgöl Province of Mongolia near the border with Russia. Its name means "King Sky" in the local language. It is also known as Khentii Khan or Khangai Khan. With an elevation of 6,995 metres (22,905 feet), it is the second-highest mountain in Mongolia, after Bayan Khongor. The Khan Tengri is notable for its massive bulk and its jagged peaks. It is a very difficult climb due to the steepness and the technical difficulty of the routes. The mountain and its surrounding area are part of the Khan Tengri Nature Reserve. In the Soviet era, the mountain was considered to be "secret" due to its location in Mongolia, then a closed country. Western climbers knew almost nothing about the mountain until 1990, when the Russian magazine "Abaltur" published an article about a team of Russian climbers who had climbed it in 1989. Since then, the Khan Tengri has become a popular climbing destination. In August 2008, a British team became the first to climb the Khan Tengri from the south side. They did it in a single push without returning to their base camp, following what they believe to be the first ascent by the Soviet team in 1989. There are two glaciers on the south side of the Khan Tengri: the North and South Inylches. The North Inylchek Glacier is the largest and longest glacier in Mongolia, and one of the largest and longest in the world. The South Inylchek Glacier is smaller but has more rapid glacial flow. Sriboonruang Wittayakarn School Sriboonruang Wittayakarn School (โรงเรือนศรีบุญเรืองวิทยาการ) is a public school in Bangkok, Thailand. The school has two sections, one for boys and the other for girls. The school's first section, the boys' school, was established in 1913 by Phibun Songkhram and named "Wittayakarn" (วิทยาการ). The school's second section, the girls' school, was established in 1954 and named "Sriboonruang" (ศรีบุญเรือง). The name "Sriboonruang" means "The Honor of the Land Unification". The school's current name, Sriboonruang Wittayakarn, was used when the boys' and girls' schools were merged in 1975. The school is one of the oldest schools in Bangkok and is well known for its high standard of teaching. Many of its students have won awards in various academic competitions. The school has a reputation for good discipline and its students are expected to wear uniforms and behave well. The school's atmosphere is friendly and its students are known for being helpful to each other. The school has a large campus with many buildings and facilities. It has a library, a computer lab, and a science lab. The school also has a large playing field and a swimming pool. The school's curriculum is based on the Thai national curriculum. The school offers a variety of subjects, including mathematics, science, history, geography, and English. The school's English program is taught by native English speakers and is known for its high standard. The school also offers a variety of extra-curricular activities, such as sports, music, and drama.

Multnomah was a stern-wheel driven steamboat built in 1910 for the Oregon Railroad and Navigation Company to run on the Columbia and Willamette Rivers out of Portland, Oregon. The steamer was built by the GPN Company of Portland, Oregon. The ship was launched on December 29, 1910, and made its trial trip on January 7, 1911. The Multnomah was placed on the Portland-Astoria route, making the run in 5 hours and 40 minutes. The Multnomah was designed by naval architect W.R.B. Milligan, who designed several other steamers for the Oregon Railroad and Navigation Company. The Multnomah was 118.5 feet (36.98 m) long, 27.8 feet (8.48 m) wide and 4.6 feet (1.42 m) deep. The vessel had a double bottom and was divided into three compartments. The Multnomah had a bow paddlewheel and a stern paddlewheel, each with its own steam engine and boiler. The forward boiler was a steel fire-tube boiler built by the GPN Company. The boiler had a furnace that was 17 feet (5.18 m) long and 8 feet (2.44 m) in diameter. The boiler had two tubes, each 16 feet (4.88 m) long and 3 feet (0.91 m) in diameter. The rear boiler was an identical unit. Each boiler was fired by a oil burner. The paddlewheel was 24 feet (7.32 m) in diameter and had 18 floats. Each float was 16 feet (4.88 m) long and 3 feet (0.91 m) wide. The upper works of the steamer included a pilothouse, a deckhouse, and a forecastle. The pilothouse was located forward on the upper deck. The deckhouse contained a dining room, kitchen, pantry, and staterooms for the officers and crew. The forecastle contained additional staterooms. The capacity of the vessel was 150 passengers and a crew of 32. The Multnomah was commanded by Captain D.W. Hazen.
