Charcandrick West (born November 8, 1989) is an American football running back for the Dallas Cowboys of the National Football League (NFL). He played college football at Abilene Christian and was signed by the San Francisco 49ers as an undrafted free agent in 2012. West was born in Beaumont, Texas, and attended Beaumont Central High School, where he played football, basketball, and ran track. He was a three-year letterman in football, where he played running back and defensive back, and a two-year letterman in track, where he was a member of the 4 × 100 m relay and 4 × 400 m relay. As a junior, he was an all-district selection at running back after rushing for 1,3341 yards and 18 touchdowns. As a senior, he was named the District 21-5A Offensive MVP after rushing for 1,4891 yards and 21 touchdowns. West attended Abilene Christian University, where he was a four-year letterman in football and a three-year letterman in track. In football, he played running back and was a return specialist. As a freshman, he appeared in 11 games, primarily on special teams, and returned 15 kickoffs for 334 yards and one touchdown. As a sophomore, he became the starting running back, carrying the ball 244 times for 1,104 yards (4.3 avg.) and 14 touchdowns. He also returned 19 kickoffs for 426 yards (21.5 avg.) and two touchdowns. As a junior, he carried the ball 242 times for 1,050 yards (4.3 avg.) and 12 touchdowns. He also returned 20 kickoffs for 475 yards (23.8 avg.) and two touchdowns. As a senior, he carried the ball 262 times for 1,285 yards (5.0 avg.) and 13 touchdowns. He also returned 20 kickoffs for 562 yards (29.1 avg.) and two touchdowns. West was considered only a late-round prospect in the 2012 NFL Draft, and was not invited to the NFL Scouting Combine. He was projected as a priority free agent by Sports Illustrated. West signed with the San Francisco 49ers as an undrafted free agent following the 2012 NFL Draft. He was cut from the team in August 2012, but was signed to the practice squad two days later. He was promoted to the active roster on October 16. He was released on August 31, 2013, and signed with the Washington Redskins on September 1, 2013. He was released by the Redskins on August 30, 2014. West was signed by the St. Louis Rams on September 1, 2014. He was released by the Rams on September 29, 2014. West was signed by the Dallas Cowboys on December 16, 2014. He was released by the Cowboys on September 5, 2015, and re-signed on November 16, 2015. West was promoted to the active roster on December 7, 2015, following the release of veteran running back DeMarco Murray. In the season finale against the Washington Redskins on January 3, 2016, West had 8 carries for 40 yards (5.0 avg.) and 2 touchdowns in the 27-17 victory. After the 2015 season, West signed a two-year contract to stay with the Cowboys. In the 2016 season opener against the New York Giants on Sunday Night Football, West had his first career 100-yard game, with 101 yards on 21 carries (4.8 avg.) and one touchdown in the 20-19 victory. West was placed on injured reserve with a broken ankle on September 25, 2016. West was promoted to the active roster on October 31, 2017, after the release of running back Darren McFadden. Jemaah Tarbiyah is an Islamic educational organization based in the city of Solo in Central Java, Indonesia. The organization was established by Kiai Abdullah Al-Haroni in the early 1950s. It is now led by his son, Abdul Halim A. Haroni. Jemaah Tarbiyah has played a significant role in the development of modern Islamic education in Indonesia. It has also been active in promoting inter-religious dialogue and harmony in the country. The organization has branches in several cities in Indonesia, as well as in other countries such as Malaysia, Singapore, and Australia. The organization's activities include the provision of Islamic education to children and adults, as well as the promotion of social and cultural activities. It also runs a publishing house, which has published a number of books on Islamic education, as well as a monthly magazine, Tarbiyah, which focuses on issues related to Islamic education. Jemaah Tarbiyah has been recognized for its contributions to the development of Islamic education in Indonesia. In 2006, it was awarded the Bintang Budaya by the Government of Indonesia, and in 2013, it was named as one of the top 10 Islamic organizations in the country.

Maria Herrmann-Kaufmann (15 September 1907 – 22 November 2018) was a German supercentenarian who was the oldest person in Germany and the second oldest person in the world at the time of her death. Herrmann-Kaufmann was born in the village of Wanfried in the German state of Hesse on 15 September 1907. She had three siblings, two of whom died in childhood. She spent her childhood in the village of Binger Scharlachberg (now part of the municipality of Binger Scharlachberg-Südost) and attended school in the nearby town of Bingen. She was a seamstress and worked in a factory that produced military uniforms until it was closed in 1945. She then worked as a clerk in a law office for a few years before taking up farming, which she continued to do throughout her life, on a small scale. She never married and had no children. Herrmann-Kaufmann was a resident of the Altenheim senior citizens' home in Bingen since 1998. She had no major health issues throughout her life, although she did have problems with her vision and hearing. She was able to remain in her own home until the age of 110, when she became ill and was admitted to the hospital. She recovered and was able to return to her home, but eventually moved to the Altenheim. She became the oldest person in Germany and the second oldest person in the world after the death of 114-year-old Georgian, Nino Jerusalem, on 20 September 2018. Herrmann-Kaufmann died in Bingen on 22 November 2018, at the age of 111 years, 70 days. She was the third German woman to die that year, after 115-year-old Maria Margaretha Fiebig and 110-year-old Marie-Josephine Cécile Delmotte. She was buried in the Bingen am Main cemetery.

Medusa (Trapeze album) Medusa is the fourth studio album by English rock band Trapeze, released in October 1971 on Island Records. It was the first Trapeze album to feature new singer John Sloman, following the departure of original vocalist Dave Holland. The album was produced by John Lodge, who was also in the band theMoody Blues. It was recorded in the summer of 1971 at Abbey Road Studios in London. Two of the album's songs, "You Can't Ask Me" and "Take Me To The Top", were also recorded at the Moodys' studio in Birmingham. The album was mixed at Island Studios in London. The cover art for the album was designed by Hipgnosis. The album was not released in the United States until June 1973, after the band had achieved success with their fifth studio album, On the Way Out. In 2007, Esoteric Recordings re-released Medusa on CD, with three bonus tracks. In September 2015, Esoteric Recordings released a 2-CD deluxe edition of Medusa, with a bonus disc containing a previously unreleased live concert recorded in December 1971 at theAce Hotel in London.

László Szőgyény-Marich Sr. (szögyény-marich means "sun-ray-blessed" in Hungarian) (February 8, 1889 – August 31, 1959) was a Hungarian track and field athlete and a prominent lawyer and politician in the 1920s and 1930s. He was born in Kecskemét, Hungary. He was Jewish. He competed for Hungary at the 1912 Summer Olympics in Stockholm, Sweden, and won a silver medal in the 4x400 metres relay, and a bronze medal in the 110 metres hurdles. After the Olympics, he went to study law at the University of Budapest, and later became a lawyer. He worked for theTax Office of Budapest for a short time, then became a lawyer in his father's office. He was an excellent lawyer and very successful. In the early 1920s, he was one of the founders of the Hungarian Olympic Committee, and also one of the organizers of the first Hungarian Olympic Games. He was a member of the Hungarian National Olympic Committee for more than 20 years. In the 1930s, he became a member of the Hungarian Parliament for a short time, and also served as the Minister of Public Welfare for a short time. He was the father of László Szőgyény-Marich Jr., a famous Hungarian athlete, who won a bronze medal in the 100 metres at the 1928 Summer Olympics in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

Air Force of the Democratic Republic of the Congo The Air Force of the Democratic Republic of the Congo ( Force Aérienne Congolaise) was the air force of the Democratic Republic of the Congo from 1964 to 1997. It was known as the "Forces Aériennes Zaïroises" or "FAZA" until the country's name change in 1971. The air force was established as a component of the National Army (French: Armée Nationale) by Law 64-006, which was passed on 15 September 1964. The army was itself a successor to the Congolese National Army (French: Armée National Congolaise), which had been established as the military force of the Congo after independence in 1960, and the earlier "Forces Armées Congolaises" (FAC). The FAZA was involved in the First and Second Congo Wars, and was known to have been involved in the delivery of supplies to the UN-backed Congolese Army (French: Armée Congolaise) during the 1993–94 war. It was subsequently integrated into the new Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo (French: Forces Armées du Congo) in 1997.

Music of Grim Fandango The music for Grim Fandango was composed by Peter McConnell, with additional music by Ricardo Latin Hawke, Abraham "Abramo" Mills, and Ed Harrison. The game's music is much different from traditional adventure game music, taking a Latin-inspired approach. McConnell chose this style of music both because he thought it would complement the game's Spanish setting, and because he wanted to do something "radically different" from the " sadness and despair" that characterizes much of the music in adventure games. The game's main theme, "Grim Fandango", is a salsa tune that is used in various arrangements throughout the game. The theme was originally composed as a Latin waltz, but was later rearranged as a salsa by McConnell, who also added a "descarga" or "improvised jam" section to the end. The "descarga" was added to give the theme a "Latin jazz feel", and to give the musicians a chance to "stretch out and get a little more soloistic". The game's score also includes a "romantic theme" that is used for scenes involving the character Manny Calavera and his love interest, Mercedes. The game's "credits theme", which is played over the end credits, is a 2/3 metal version of the main theme, with a "driving, aggressive" arrangement by Latin Hawke. The music for Grim Fandango was composed using a combination of live musicians and Digital Audio Workstation (DAW) technology. The live musicians were mostly based in the San Francisco Bay Area, and were contracted through the game's audio production company, Giant Sound. The music was composed over the course of about a year, and was completed in the summer of 1998. The game's sound effects were created by Giant Sound, and were recorded at the company's studio in Los Angeles.

Greece on the Ruins of Missolonghi At the foot of the mountains, on the western coast of Central Greece, lies the small town of Missolonghi. It is a town with a long and rich history, having been founded in the late 18th century by the Venetians. The town was a major trading center for the Venetians, and it was also the site of a major battle during the Greek War of Independence in 1821. The town's most famous landmark is the Fortress of Missolonghi, a large fortress that was built by the Venetians in the early 19th century. The fortress is located on an island in the middle of the Gulf of Missolonghi, and it is connected to the mainland by a narrow causeway. The fortress is a impressive sight, and it is a reminder of the town's rich history. Another major landmark in Missolonghi is the Church of Agios Spyridon, which is located in the town's main square. The church is a large and impressive building, and it is a major tourist attraction. The church is also home to a number of important paintings and icons, including a famous icon of Agios Spyridon that is said to be one of the most important icons in Greece. Missolonghi is also home to a number of other important landmarks, including the Themistokleous House, which is a traditional house that has been turned into a museum, and the Folklore Museum, which is a museum that focuses on the traditional culture and history of the town. In addition to its historic landmarks, Missolonghi is also a popular destination for its beaches and scenery. The town is located on a beautiful bay, and it is surrounded by mountains. The town's beaches are a major tourist attraction, and they are a great place to relax and enjoy the scenery. Missolonghi is a town with a rich history and a beautiful setting. It is a great place to explore history, and it is also a great place to relax and enjoy the scenery.

Bob Arbogast (born July 4, 1932) is an American sportscaster, primarily known for his work on the West Coast. Arbogast was born in Fort Wayne, Indiana. After graduating from Fort Wayne North Side High School in 1950, he attended Indiana University, where he was a member of the golf team. He graduated in 1954 with a bachelor's degree in speech. He began his broadcasting career in 1955 at WANE-TV in Fort Wayne, where he was a news and sports reporter and anchored the evening news. In 1958, he moved to Los Angeles, where he worked as a sports anchor for KNXT (now KCBS), and also became the first person to appear on two local channels at the same time, working for both KNXT and KTTV (channel 11). In 1961, he joined CBS network as a sportscaster, working on the West Coast game of the NFL on CBS. Arbogast was the first host of The NFL on CBS, the network's pre-game show, from 1961 to 1964. He also hosted the network's golf coverage, including the PGA Tour and the Masters Tournament. In addition, he covered the Rose Bowl Game and the Los Angeles Rams for CBS. Arbogast was the host of the Los Angeles edition of CBS Sports SPORTS IN DEPTH from 1962 to 1964, and the West Coast edition of SPORTS ON SOUNDBITE from 1965 to 1968. After leaving CBS, Arbogast worked as a sportscaster for KTLA, the Los Angeles Times and Fox Sports Net West. He was also the play-by-play voice of the Los Angeles Raiders from 1986 to 1994. In 2007, he was the narrator for the A&E reality series Gene Simmons Family Jewels.

CT Rei Pelé, or simply Rei Pelé, is a Brazilian football club from the city of Barretos, in the northern state of São Paulo. The club was founded on January 1, 1937, and plays its home games at the Estádio Rei Pelé, which has a seating capacity of 8,560. The club's greatest achievement was in 1987, when it won the Campeonato Paulista, the top-flight football league in the state of São Paulo, after beating Corinthians 2–0 in the final game. The club has also won the Campeonato Paulista Série A2, the second division of the São Paulo state league, on three occasions (in 1970, 1976 and 1999). Rei Pelé is one of the smallest clubs to have ever won the São Paulo state championship, and one of only two clubs from outside the city of São Paulo to have won it in the last 40 years (the other being XV de Piracicaba in 1978). The club's name is a reference to the Brazilian legend Edson Arantes do Nascimento, better known as Pelé, who was born in the nearby city of Santos. The club's logo is a stylized image of the player.

Nicolette Robinson (born August 2, 1987) is an American actress. She is best known for her roles as Nicola Landau on the ABC comedy series The Goldbergs and Foscca in the CBS police drama NCIS: Los Angeles. Robinson was born in New York City. Her mother, Deborah, is a casting director and her father, Craig, is a Broadway performer. She attended New York University, where she graduated with a bachelor's degree in Fine Arts in 2009. In 2011, Robinson appeared as a recurring guest star in the first season of the ABC comedy series The Goldbergs as ancestral grandmother Nicola Landau. In 2015, she became a regular cast member in the series' fourth season, and continued to portray the character until the series' eighth and final season in 2019. In 2013, she appeared as a guest star in the first season of the CBS police drama NCIS: Los Angeles as the sister of a kidnapped Marine, and returned as a recurring guest star in the show's sixth season in 2015. In 2016, she was promoted to a series regular, and continued to portray the character through the show's tenth and final season in 2022. In 2017, Robinson starred in the short-lived ABC legal drama series Conviction as Hannah Burley, a lawyer and the daughter of a judge. In 2019, she starred in the USA Network drama series Unsolved as Mine Teymur, a detective with the Los Angeles Police Department. In 2020, Robinson starred as Daisy in the ABC medical drama series The Baker and the Beauty. In 2022, she began starring as Kristin Knight in the ABC comedy series The Real Mayor of Beverly Hills. ## Personal life In 2015, Robinson married actor Alan Powell. The couple had their first child, a son named Louis, in November 2016. They welcomed their daughter, Alice, in August 2019.

A mere is a type of sword or knife popular during the Middle Ages. The word "mere" is derived from the Old English word myrige, meaning "beautiful," "fine," or "delicate." Meres were often long swords, though they could also be shorter knives. They were normally single-edged and had a blunt, hooked tip known as a "basket hilt." The name comes from the basket-like shape of the hilt, which was used to protect the blade's edge and tip. Meres were often used by medieval knights and were popular during the 14th and 15th centuries. There are several different types of meres, including the longsword, the backsword, and the saber. The longsword was a popular choice for medieval knights, as it was a powerful weapon for both offense and defense. The backsword was similar to the longsword, but it was usually shorter and had a blunt, hooked tip. The saber was a lighter, more curved version of the longsword, and was often used for fighting on horseback. Meres were typically made of steel or iron, and were often decorated with jewels or engravings. They were often used for fighting, but they could also be used for ceremony or decoration.

Discopolis is an album by the British electronic musician Richard D. James, under the name of Aphex Twin. It was released in 1994 on Rephlex Records, and contains some of the most recognised tracks in the ambient techno genre, including "Digeridoo" and "Phloam". The album is noted for its elaborate and abstract sounds, which have been compared to "the aural equivalent of a spirograph". The album was recorded between 1992 and 1993 in James' hometown of Cornwall, England, and was finished in Los Angeles. James used a variety of synthesisers and other equipment, including a Prophet VS, an Roland Jupiter-6, an Ensoniq ESQ-1, and a Korg Electribe SE-1. The album was mixed on an SSL console at the Music Factory, in Hollywood, California. The cover artwork for Discopolis was created by James and features a computer-generated image of a cityscape. The title is a pun on the word "disc" in reference to both the compact disc and the circular shape of the city. In 1994, James released a series of singles and EPs, including "Surrender" and "Digeridoo", to promote the album. "Digeridoo" is the most prominent track from Discopolis, and was featured on the soundtrack to the film Tank Girl. The track "Phloam" was also featured in the film adaptation of the comic book Spawn. In 2010, Discopolis was released as a limited-edition LP to celebrate the 15th anniversary of its original release. The re-release included a second disc of previously unreleased material, entitled Diskcopolis.

Raxibacumab is a monoclonal antibody designed for the treatment of severe pneumonia caused by the bacteria Streptococcus pneumonia. It is the first antibody to be developed by the Swedish company Sobi. The drug is currently in phase 3 clinical trials. In February 2013, raxibacumab was designated a breakthrough therapy by the US Food and Drug Administration. Severe pneumonia is an infection of the lung tissue, with symptoms including high fever, shaking chills, coughing, and difficulty breathing. It is typically treated with antibiotics, such as penicillin, but this may not be effective in all cases because some bacteria have become resistant to these antibiotics. In these cases, a different course of treatment may be used, such as raxibacumab. Raxibacumab is a monoclonal antibody, a protein that binds to a specific target. In this case, the target is the alpha-haemolysin toxin produced by the bacteria Streptococcus pneumonia. The antibody binds to this toxin, preventing it from binding to its receptor and causing damage to the host's cells. This results in less damage to the lungs and a reduction in symptoms. The drug is given as an intravenous infusion, typically over the course of 30 minutes. The recommended dose is 2.5 grams, which is given once every three months. Raxibacumab has been studied in two phase 3 clinical trials. The first, called RAPID, was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial that enrolled 1,078 patients with severe pneumonia. The second, called ARTEMIS, was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial that enrolled 908 patients with severe pneumonia. In both trials, patients were randomized to receive either raxibacumab or a placebo. The primary endpoint in both trials was the reduction in the risk of death at 60 days after treatment. In the RAPID trial, there was a trend towards a reduction in the risk of death at 60 days, but the difference was not statistically significant. However, there was a statistically significant reduction in the risk of death at 90 days, with a hazard ratio of 0.85. In the ARTEMIS trial, there was a statistically significant reduction in the risk of death at 60 days, with a hazard ratio of 0.85. The most common adverse events in both trials were nausea, headache, and fever. There were no cases of severe allergic reactions, called anaphylaxis, in either trial. Raxibacumab is currently in phase 3 clinical trials. The drug has been designated a breakthrough therapy by the US Food and Drug Administration, which means that it is considered to be a potential candidate for approval based on early clinical data. The company is currently working on completing the clinical development program for the drug. In February 2013, the US Food and Drug Administration designated raxibacumab as a breakthrough therapy. This means that the drug is considered to be a potential candidate for approval based on early clinical data. The drug is currently in phase 3 clinical trials. In August 2013, the company announced that the drug had been granted fast track status by the FDA. This means that the drug is considered to be a potential candidate for approval based on early clinical data. The drug is currently in phase 3 clinical trials. In April 2014, the company announced that the drug had been granted priority review status by the FDA. This means that the drug is considered to be a potential candidate for approval based on early clinical data. The drug is currently in phase 3 clinical trials.

Indian Mary Park is a state park in the U.S. state of Washington, located on the Pend Oreille River in unincorporated Pend Oreille County, northeast of the city of Metaline. The park is named after a Indian woman who lived along the river in the early 20th century. The park's main feature is a beach along the river, which is a popular destination for boaters, swimmers, and anglers. The park also includes a trailhead for the Pacific Northwest National Scenic Trail, which passes through the park on its way to the Canadian border. Indian Mary Park is located on the south bank of the Pend Oreille River, just east of the mouth of the Kalispel River. The park encompasses 3 acres (1.2 ha) and is one of two state parks in Washington to be located on an Indian reservation, the other being Tiger Mountain State Forest. The park is managed by the Kalispel Tribe, who also manage the nearby Kalispel Casino. The park is named after Mary Curley, an Indian woman who lived along the river in a log cabin for many years until her death in 1952. The cabin was located on the west side of the river, just north of the park's current location. The park's beach is a popular destination for boaters, swimmers, and anglers, and is also a launch point for boat tours of the river. The park's main trailhead is the starting point for the Pacific Northwest National Scenic Trail, which passes through the park on its way to the Canadian border. In 2015, the Kalispel Tribe proposed a land swap with the state of Washington in which they would acquire Indian Mary Park and the state would acquire other lands from the tribe. The state legislature approved the land swap in 2017, and the transaction was completed in 2018. As part of the deal, the state agreed to manage the park for the Kalispel Tribe.

Auguste Rodin, byname of Auguste Roideau, was a French sculptor, best known for his work The Thinker, The Kiss, and The Gates of Hell. Born in 1840, Rodin studied at the Petite École, then at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris, where he was a student of Louis David. He and his companion, Rose Beuret, had a son in 1864, but he died after only a few days. In the late 1860s, Rodin took a studio in Paris and began working on The Gates of Hell, a major sculpture that was to occupy him for the next 30 years. The Thinker, originally titled The Poet, was begun in 1880 and presented to the Salon in Paris the following year, where it was given the title The Thinker. It was later purchased by the French government for 5,000 francs and placed in the Musée du Luxembourg. The Kiss was originally titled The Embrace and was intended to be part of a larger work, The Gates of Hell. It was later sold as a separate work and purchased by the British government in 1907. It is now in the Tate Gallery in London. The Gates of Hell, which was never completed, is now in the Musée d'Orsay in Paris. Rodin's works were often critical of the conventional morality of the time. The Gates of Hell, for example, features various figures in hell, including a pair of lovers who have been damned for their adultery. Rodin died in 1917. His works are among the most popular exhibits in the world, and many of them have been reproduced as statues, paintings, and prints.

Transport Canada is the department responsible for transportation in Canada. Transport Canada's mandate is to: Promote a safe and secure transportation system that meets the needs of Canadians and is integrated with our international counterparts promotes the safety and security of all transportation modes, including the transportation of people, goods, and resources, by land, air, and sea; ensures that all transportation-related laws, regulations, and standards are followed; promotes the safe operation of airports and the safety of all air traffic; improves the safety of marine transportation and the safety of all navigation. This includes the monitoring of the Canadian shipping fleet and the inspection of foreign ships visiting Canadian ports; promotes the safe movement of people and goods across Canada's international borders; and monitors the movement of people and goods across Canadian borders to ensure that the rules and regulations are followed. In addition to these main responsibilities, Transport Canada is also responsible for: the transportation of dangerous goods by land, air, or sea; the registration of aircraft and the licensing of pilots, aircraft maintenance engineers, and air traffic controllers; the inspection of aircraft and the licensing of pilots, aircraft maintenance engineers, and air traffic controllers; the development and implementation of a national transportation policy; the development and implementation of a national transportation strategy; the coordination of federal, provincial, and territorial transportation departments; and the provision of advice to the Government of Canada on all matters relating to transportation.

Bickleton, Washington, is an extinct town in the U.S. state of Washington. It was located in Klickitat County, on the north side of the Klickitat River, near the mouth of the Youngs Creek. The town was established in 1867 by D.M. Ferry & Co. to support the local mining industry. The town was named after the first store owner, A.B. Wilkinson, who opened the first post office in 1880. The town was platted in 1884, and by 1890 the town had a population of 300. The local mines produced gold, silver, and copper, and the town was the location of a number of mills that processed the ore. The town also had a large number of cabins, a hotel, a general store, a post office, and a school. The town was connected to the outside world via the Northern Pacific Railway, which had a station in town. The town began to decline in the early 1900s, when the mines began to produce less ore. The town was largely abandoned by the 1930s, and the post office closed in 1939. The town was flooded by the construction of the dam at the nearby Lake Simcoe in the 1960s, and the remaining structures were removed. Today, the site of the town is located on the grounds of the Wahkiakum County Park, on the west side of Lake Simcoe. The lake and surrounding area are popular with anglers, and the county park has a number of campsites and a boat launch.

Demographics of New Brunswick According to the 2011 Census, the population of New Brunswick was 738,392, making it the ninth largest province in Canada. The largest city in the province is Moncton while the capital city is Fredericton. New Brunswick is the only officially bilingual province in Canada, with about one-third of the population able to speak both English and French. One of the first things visitors notice is the absence of a dominant ethnic group. This is in contrast to many other parts of the country, where the dominant cultural group is either English, French, or Aboriginal. Instead, New Brunswick has a rich mixture of the three dominant cultures in Canada. The main cultural and linguistic group is English and British, with 17.8% of the population. This is followed by French and Acadian, with 15.5% of the population. The third main cultural and linguistic group is Aboriginal, with 9.5% of the population. In addition, the population is also diverse with respect to religion, with the three largest groups being Catholic, Protestant and Muslim. New Brunswick has the largest percentage of French-speaking residents of any province, at 33.2%. This is followed by Quebec at 22.8%, and Ontario at 5.9%. New Brunswick has the second largest percentage of bilingual residents, after Quebec. New Brunswick has a large rural population, with 70.4% living outside urban areas in 2011. This is the highest proportion of rural residents of any province in Canada. New Brunswick's population is aging, like the rest of the country. In 2011, the median age was 45.9 years, the third highest in Canada. As of the 2006 Census, the population of New Brunswick was 709,575. The province had an average annual growth rate of 0.35% from 2001 to 2006, the third lowest in Canada. This was due to a loss of population through net out-migration, particularly to Alberta. New Brunswick had the highest net loss of population of any province, at 5.9% of the population. New Brunswick's population density is 8.5 people per square kilometer (21.7 per square mile), the second lowest of any province. The population density of the three largest cities (Moncton, Saint John, and Fredericton) is higher than the provincial average, at 19.2 per square kilometer (49.0 per square mile). New Brunswick has a wide range of ages. In 2011, 18.4% of the population was under the age of 14, 60.4% was between the ages of 15 and 64, and 21.2% was 65 or older. The average age was 45.9 years. In 2006, the median age was 44.4 years, the third highest in Canada. The average age was 42.9 years. As of 2006, over 90% of New Brunswick residents were Canadian citizens, and over 80% were born in New Brunswick. The largest group of non-Canadians were permanent residents (20.5%), followed by temporary residents (17.9%). In 2006, 1.9% of the population were Aboriginal, 9.3% were visible minorities, and 4.9% were neither Aboriginal nor visible minority. The three largest visible minority groups were those of English, French, and German origins. As of 2006, 67.8% of New Brunswick residents reported English as their mother tongue. This was followed by French at 32.4%, and the next most common mother tongues were Scottish (0.7%), German (0.5%), and Mi'kmaq (0.1%). New Brunswick is home to several linguistic minorities. The first is the French language, which is spoken by one-third of the population. The second is the Mi'kmaq language, which is spoken by approximately 2% of the population. The third is the German language, which is spoken by approximately 4% of the population. In 2006, approximately 5% of New Brunswick residents reported that they did not speak English or French. The most common non-official language was German, followed by Mi'kmaq, and then English. As of 2006, 80.9% of New Brunswick residents were Christians, making up the largest religious group in the province. The highest proportion of Christians was in the Edmundston region, where 97.6% of the population professed Christianity. The largest non-Christian religion was Hinduism, which was followed by 2.4% of the population. The next largest non-Christian religions were Buddhism, Islam, and Judaism, which were followed by 1.9%, 1.6%, and 1.0% of the population, respectively. In 2011, 23.6% of the population were Catholic, followed by 22.2% who

Charles Sumner House The Charles Sumner House is a historic house at 120 Mt. Auburn Street in Cambridge, Massachusetts. It is the former home of American statesman and senator Charles Sumner (1811–74), one of the leading Republicans of the 19th century. The house, designed by the architect Alexander Parris, was built in 1835 and is one of the few surviving examples of Greek Revival architecture in Cambridge. The house was occupied by Sumner from 1845 until his death in 1874. During that time, he became a prominent member of the Massachusetts state legislature and a United States senator. He was an avid abolitionist, and his house was a station on the Underground Railroad. The house was a focal point for the Cambridge abolitionist movement. On July 17, 1856, the house was bombed by a pro-slavery sympathizer, who threw a bomb through a window of the house while Sumner was sleeping. The bomb failed to explode, and the would-be bomber was later identified, tried, and sentenced to three years in prison. The house was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1973 and was designated a National Historic Landmark in 2001. It is now a museum, owned and operated by the Historic New England organization. The Charles Sumner House is located in Cambridge's Harvard Square, near Harvard University, and is a prominent local landmark. The house is a two-story wood-frame structure, three bays wide, with a side-gable roof and a large central chimney. The front and side elevations are fully three bays wide, with the main entrance in the center of the front. The house is surrounded by a high brick wall, which is topped with a wrought-iron fence that was added in the 20th century. A granite staircase leads up to the front entrance. The interior of the house follows a central hall plan, with a large parlor on the left, a drawing room on the right, and a dining room and kitchen at the rear. The second floor contains three bedrooms and a nursery, with a small room in the attic. The house has been restored to its c. 1855 appearance, with many of the original furnishings and decorations. The Charles Sumner House is located in the heart of Cambridge, just west of Harvard University, and is a local landmark. It is located on a busy street, just off Massachusetts Avenue, and is easily accessible by car and public transportation. The house is open for guided tours from April through December, and closed during the winter months.

Priestfield railway station serves Priestfield, a district of the town of Rochester in the English county of Kent. The station and all trains serving it are operated by Southeastern, and it is on the Chatham Main Line, between Rochester and Chatham. The station was opened by the South Eastern Railway in 1858 as one of three intermediate stations on the new line they built from Rochester to Chatham, the others being Borstal and Rochester West Gate. The line had been planned by the London, Chatham & Dover Railway, who had obtained permission to build it in 1853, but had been taken over by the South Eastern Railway before it was built. The station has two platforms, one on each of the two tracks that make up the Chatham Main Line, and a small ticket office on the "up" (towards London) side. The platforms are connected by a subway, with steps on both sides. The station is at the point where the Chatham Main Line passes under the A2 road. To the west of the station, the A2 crosses the railway on a bridge, while to the east the railway passes beneath the road in a tunnel.

Prickly City is a British television sitcom, produced by BBC Birmingham and screened on BBC Two. The show was written by Jon Brown, who also stars as one of the main characters, and was produced by Paul Jackson. It was set in Birmingham and focused on the staff of a small-time property management company, the ill-fated City Realty, and their efforts to make a success of their business. The title is a play on the name of the city, referring to the "prickly" nature of the characters, and the fact that they are stuck in the "sticks", away from the glittering centre of Birmingham. The show ran for two series, in 2003 and 2004, with a total of twelve episodes. The first series was directed by Martin Dennis and the second by Simon Lynds. The show was cancelled after the second series, due to low ratings. The show has not been released on DVD. Prickly City featured an ensemble cast, with five main characters. These were Jon Brown as Barry, the boss of City Realty; Natalie Jaresko as Emma, Barry's sister and the company's administrator; David Schofield as Gary, the company's letting agent; Dilys Laye as Mrs. Parking, the company's longest-serving employee; and David Ross as Richard, the company's sales agent. Other characters included City Realty's harassed secretary, Karen (Penny Bunton), and their mysterious office cleaner, Eric (Lesley-Ann Jane).

UAB Blazers men's soccer The UAB Blazers men's soccer team represents the University of Alabama at Birmingham in the sport of soccer. The team is a member of Conference USA. They play their home matches at the UAB Track and Field Stadium. The University of Alabama at Birmingham started men's soccer in 1978 as a club-level team, which it remained until the team moved to NCAA Division I in 1996. In its early years in Division I, UAB was a member of the Mid-American Conference and later the Sun Belt Conference. The team joined Conference USA in 2013. The team has an all-time record of 182-151-58 and has never made an appearance in the NCAA Tournament. The team has won the regular season Conference USA title three times, in 2008, 2010, and 2012, and the Conference USA Tournament once, in 2008. In 2008, the team made history by defeating the number one ranked team in the country, the UCLA Bruins, 2–1. The team also went on a four-game winning streak during the 2008 season, the longest in program history.

I'm Moving On (Yoko Ono song) "I'm Moving On" is a song by Yoko Ono, released as her first solo single in January 1973. It was produced by John Lennon and Phil Spector, and features Paul McCartney and George Harrison on guitar, and Billy Preston on electric piano. A music video was made for the song, directed by Michael Lindsay-Hogg, and featuring Eric Clapton and Klaus Voormann in the band. The song was recorded in London in October 1972, during the same sessions that produced "Happy Xmas (War Is Over)", and was intended to be released as a single at that time. It was delayed by Apple Records, who were concerned that the Christmas song would not receive sufficient radio play to make it a commercial success. In January 1973, the single was released as "Yoko Ono/Plastic Ono Band", with "Happy Xmas (War Is Over)" as the B-side. The song was included on the albums Onobox and It's Alright, and was also included on the compilation albums Shaved Fish and The Lennon Collection. The lyrics to "I'm Moving On" describe a person who has been in a relationship with someone, and is now moving on. The relationship is not specified, and it is not clear whether it is a personal relationship or a business relationship. The song has a positive tone, and the singer is not sounding sorry for the end of the relationship, but rather, looking forward to what the future holds. The music to "I'm Moving On" is upbeat and driving, with a repeating guitar riff and a pounding drumbeat. The electric piano adds a jazzy feel to the song, and the overall effect is a song that is both catchy and memorable.

The Ultimate is a jazz album by Elvin Jones, recorded in 1973 and released on Impulse! Records the following year. It features performances by Jones, Sonny Rollins, George Coleman, Joe Farrell, and Jack DeJohnette. The Ultimate was Jones' first major solo effort since the dissolution of his band, the Elvin Jones Jazz Machine, in the early 1970s. It was also his first album for Impulse! since the release of the live album Jazz Machine in 1970. In addition to the core band, Jones invited a number of guest musicians to participate in the sessions, including his old friend and colleague Sonny Rollins, who contributes a solo on "The Ultimate," the title track. The Ultimate was released in 1974 and was the final studio album as leader for Jones, though he would go on to record a number of live albums in the subsequent decades, including a 1984 reunion with DeJohnette and Farrell, and a 1991 live album with pianist McCoy Tyner. In the liner notes to the album, Jones described the title track, "The Ultimate," as a "a state of mind, a place you can go, where you can be anything you want to be, do anything you want to do." The song is a long, improvisational piece, with the musicians taking turns in the spotlight. The other tracks on the album are more concise, with the majority of them being under five minutes in length. The Ultimate was not a commercial success, but it was well-received by critics, who praised its adventurous spirit and the strong performances by the musicians. It would go on to be regarded as one of the best albums of Jones' career, and has been re-released on CD a number of times.

Papal inauguration of Pope Francis The papal inauguration of Francis took place on 13 March 2013 in St. Peter's Square. While previous papal inaugurations had been held in St. Peter's Square, the inauguration of Francis was the first to be held in the adjacent elliptical space, in front of the newly built Meta Sudio. The ceremony was attended by more than 150,000 people, who filled the square and the nearby streets. The number of attendees was surprising, given that the event was not well publicised. The Vatican had not arranged for the event to be shown live on television, and the local police had not expected such a large crowd. The ceremony began at 13:00 local time. In a break from tradition, Francis was not crowned with the tiara. After being presented with the pallium and the Ring of the Fisherman, he moved through the crowd to pray before the statue of Saint Peter, above which he had been elected. The ceremony ended with the singing of the "Regina Caeli". On the morning of 13 March 2013, Francis had breakfast with the cardinals who had elected him. He then received the congratulations of the diplomatic corps and was introduced to the office staff of the Holy See. In the afternoon, he met with the Curia, the dicasteries of the Roman Curia and the managers of the Vatican City State. In addition to the cardinals who had participated in the conclave, the inauguration was attended by more than 120 foreign delegations, including government officials from Argentina, Iraq, Japan, the United States and Venezuela, as well as from the European Union and the United Nations. The Israeli and Palestinian delegations were seated beside each other. The event was the first since the formation of the Kingdom of Italy in 1870 that a pope had been installed in the Vatican City. Since the Lateran Treaty of 1929, the Vatican City State has been the subject of a special, unique international status: it is not a member of the United Nations, and it is only partially recognized by some countries, including Brazil, France, Germany, Argentina and the United Kingdom.

The Norris University Center is the student activity center at the University of California, Santa Cruz. It is named after Donald Norris, a UCSC administrator and professor of economics. The building was dedicated on October 17, 1981, and was completely renovated during the summer of 2004. The Norris Center is the primary location for many of the student services offered by the university. These include the Office of Student Financial Services, the Bursar's Office, the Registrar's Office, the Academic Computing Department, the University Post Office, and the Office of Student Organizations. The Norris Center also houses the Cowell Coffee Shop, the Common Ground Cafe, and the Book Shop, which is run by the UCSC Bookstore and Student Union Assembly. The Norris Center is the main venue for student political activities, and is often the location for debates and other political events. In the 2016–2017 academic year, the Norris Center was the host of the university's annual First Generation College Student Conference, an event which welcomes and celebrates first-generation college students. The Norris Center was the original home of the University of California's Institute of Marine Sciences. The IMaS moved to a new building on the UCSC campus in 2002.

Wesley O. Smith was an American physician, researcher, and academic. He was the creator of the term "denervation" and the discoverer of the neurotrophic effect of exercise. Smith was born in Los Angeles, California in 1908. He attended the University of California, Los Angeles and graduated from the University of California, San Francisco in 1935. He was a researcher at the Joseph Ford Institute for Neurosciences, the National Institutes of Health, and the University of California, San Francisco. He also served as the editor-in-chief of the Journal of Neurocytology. In the early 1960s, Smith was the first to use the term "denervation" in the literature to describe the loss of nervous system input to a muscle or organ. In 1964, he was the first to report the "neurotrophic effect of exercise", the finding that the nervous system grows in response to exercise. In 1965, Smith was a founding member of the Society for Neuroscience, the world's largest organization of scientists and physicians devoted to understanding the brain and nervous system. He served as the organization's first secretary-treasurer and on its board of directors. In 1967, Smith was the editor of the first volume of the Handbook of Brain Microcircuits. Smith died in San Francisco, California in 1998.

Carl Wagner (painter) Carl Wagner (26 June 1898 – 13 February 1944) was a German expressionist painter and graphic artist. Wagner was born in Oberweimar. He studied at the Bauhaus in Weimar from 1921 to 1923, and then at the Akademie der Bildenden Künste in Dresden from 1925 to 1927. He then returned to the Bauhaus, where he was a master from 1927 to 1931. Among his students there were Marianne von Werefkin, Regina Sinke, and Ella Bergmann. Wagner's work was characterized by expressive color and a return to traditional techniques. He worked in a range of media, including oil, tempera, ink, and lithography, as well as producing a number of monumental works. He was also a writer and critic, and published a number of articles on contemporary art. Wagner's works include a number of portraits, including a series of portraits of his first wife, the dancer and actress Ellen Burman, and a series of self-portraits. He also produced a number of nudes, including a series of paintings of the dancer and actress Katalin Karády. Wagner was a member of the expressionist group Die Brücke, and his work was included in the exhibition of the group's work at the Berlin Gallery in 2008. Wagner died in a airplane crash in the Indian Ocean, while on a flight from Marseille to Cairo.

The Al-Nizamiyya of Baghdad was a center of education and knowledge in the Islamic world, which operated from the mid-11th century to the early 14th century. It was located in the city of Baghdad, which was the capital of the Abbasid Caliphate during this period. The Al-Nizamiyya was founded by the vizier to the caliph, Al-Kadhi Abu Ja'far al-Saqri, who was also a scholar and mathematician. The name "Nizamiyya" comes from the Arabic word "nizam", which means "order" or "arrangement". The Al-Nizamiyya was a center for the study of Islamic law, philosophy, and science. It was also a place where scholars from different cultures and religions could meet and exchange ideas. The Al-Nizamiyya had a strong influence on the development of Islamic thought and culture, and it produced many famous scholars, such as Abu Hanifa al-Dinawari, Abu al-Qassim al-Zahidi, Abu Ja'far al-Khwarazmi, and Al-Bitruji. The Al-Nizamiyya was destroyed in the early 14th century, during the reign of the Mongol emperor, Tamerlane. However, its legacy lived on, and it became a model for other educational institutions in the Islamic world.

Wells-Ogunquit Community School District The Wells-Ogunquit Community School District is a school district in Maine. It serves the communities of Wells and Ogunquit. The district has three schools. Wells Elementary School serves grades K-5. Wells Middle School serves grades 6-8. Wells High School serves grades 9-12. The district's superintendent is Catherine ring. The district's three school principals are Carla Murphy (elementary), Allyn Fears (middle), and Maryanne Harte (high school). The district serves approximately 3,600 students. It is one of four school districts in York County, the others being the York School Department, the Dover School Department, and the Kittery School Department. The district covers an area of approximately 92 square miles (239 km2), including several small islands. It is located entirely within the state of Maine, with a small portion extending into neighboring New Hampshire. The district was organized in the early 1970s, when the Ogunquit and Wells school departments were combined. In the 2012-2013 school year, the district had the highest percentage of students in the state who were eligible for free or reduced-price lunches, at 53.8%. It also had the highest percentage of students who were English language learners, at 4.8%. The district's total budget for the 2013-2014 school year was $51,253,088. The district is a member of the Maine School Administrative District #60, which also includes the York School Department and the Kittery School Department.

Ranger, Texas Ranger is a city in and the county seat of Eastland County, Texas, United States. The population was 3,391 at the 2010 census. It is best known for being the location of the Texas Ranger Hall of Fame and Museum, the former Texas Ranger Force headquarters. Ranger was founded in the early 1880s as a whistle-stop on the Transcontinental Railroad. The town grew when the Texas and Pacific Railroad constructed a line from Palestine, Texas, to Brownwood, Texas, passing through Ranger. The town was incorporated in 1886. Ranger is located in the heart of what is known as the Texas Hill Country, although the terrain is more rolling plains than actual hills. It is located about 2 miles (3.2 km) west of the Brazos River. According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of 3.9 square miles (10.2 km), all land. As of the census of 2000, there were 3,623 people, 1,324 households, and 894 families residing in the city. The population density was 896.3 people per square mile (345.5/km). There were 1,611 housing units at an average density of 397.7/sq mi (153.9/km). The racial makeup of the city was 96.01% White, 3.99% from other races, and 0.01% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 11.58% of the population. There were 1,324 households, out of which 27.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 51.9% were married couples living together, 10.2% had a female householder with no husband present, and 34.7% were non-families. 31.6% of all households were made up of individuals, and 16.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.26 and the average family size was 2.91. In the city, the population was spread out, with 20.7% under the age of 18, 6.6% from 18 to 24, 25.1% from 25 to 44, 21.4% from 45 to 64, and 26.2% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 43 years. For every 100 females, there were 90.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 88.1 males. As of 2000 the median income for a household in the city was $26,67, and the median income for a family was $36,848. Men had a median income of $25,033 versus $18,417 for women. The per capita income for the city was $13,738. About 9.2% of families and 12.2% of the population were below the poverty line, including 15.2% of those under age 18 and 10.3% of those age 65 or over. The Texas Ranger Hall of Fame and Museum is in Ranger. The museum covers the history of the Texas Rangers, from their foundation in the mid-19th century to the present day. It includes a recreation of the Ranger jail, as well as many exhibits of weapons used by Rangers and the outlaws they chased. The museum is located at the site of the former Texas Ranger Force headquarters. This building was constructed in the early 1930s by the Works Progress Administration. The museum opened in 1964 and was donated to the state of Texas in 1968. The Former Texas Ranger Hall of Fame and Museum, now known as the Texas Ranger Heritage Center, is located in the former Ranger jail, which was restored by the city in 2004. It features displays about the town of Ranger and the Texas Rangers, as well as a collection of historic photographs. Ranger is also home to the T.A. Blood Jr. Regional Airport. The airport, named after former Ranger mayor T.A. Blood, Jr., features a 4,300-foot (1,300 m) runway. Every third Saturday in October, Ranger holds the Texas Ranger Day celebration. The celebration includes a parade, a street dance, and the Miss Texas Ranger Pageant.

Wesley Jobello (born 18 January 1996) is a French professional footballer who plays as a right-back for FC Nantes. Born in Fort-de-France, Wesley Jobello began his career with the youth team of local club Golden Star and then joined the club's senior team in the French Guiana Honor Division, the top division in the French Guiana football league system. He made his debut for the club in 2013 and, after a successful season, moved to France to join professional club Nancy. At Nancy, Wesley Jobello spent a majority of his time with the club's reserve team in the Championnat de France Amateur, the fourth division of French football. He made his professional debut for the club in a Ligue 2 match on 17 October 2015 against Troyes. He came on as an 81st-minute substitute for Simon Deli as Nancy won 2–0. He made his first professional start three days later in a Coupe de la Ligue match against Paris FC. He played the full match as Nancy won 2–1. He made his first start in Ligue 2 on 15 December 2015 against Rodez. He played the full match as Nancy drew 0–0. After eight appearances in all competitions for Nancy, Wesley Jobello left the club and signed for hometown club, Fortaleza, in the top division of the French Guiana football league system. After one season with Fortaleza, Wesley Jobello returned to France and signed for FC Sud Ouest, a third division club in the Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region, during the 2016–17 season. After one season with FC Sud Ouest, Wesley Jobello returned to the top division in the French Guiana football league system when he signed withAJ Saint-Brès. After one season with AJ Saint-Brès, Wesley Jobello signed for FC Nantes in the summer of 2018.

Dirk Richter (born 4 September 1961) is a German musician, composer, songwriter, and record producer. Richter was born in Berlin. After an apprenticeship as a sound engineer, he studied musicology at the Technical University of Berlin. In 1985 he was awarded a grant from the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) and continued his studies at the University of California, San Diego. In 1987 he graduated with a degree in musicology. In the late 1980s, Richter became a member of the band Nina Hagen Band and in 1989 he joined the rock band Syssypops. In 1990 he began a collaboration with the singer, musician, and performance artist Christina Kubisch, which lasted until 1995. In 1996 he started his own band, Dirk Richter and the Deep Six, in which he was the front man until 1998. In the same year he also became the lead singer of the band Mambo No. 1. In 1997, Richter became a member of the band Terminal Choice, which he had founded with Klaus Schulze and Ernst Horn. The first Terminal Choice album, The Video from Hell, was released in 1998 and was followed by several others. In 2002, he started the band Eccentrics, which released three albums. Richter has also worked with other musicians, such as Udo Lindenberg, Peter Hammill, David Jackson, and producer Adam Nussbaum. In 2005 he was one of the founding members of the band Moonpups. In 2012, he started a solo career and released the albums Dirk Richter and the Upsidedownertists and Dirk Richter and the Secret Service. In 2014, he became a member of the band 17 Hippies and in 2015 he joined the band The Dead Brothers. In 2017, he released the album Black Box and in 2018 he released the album The Great Unknown.

Leandro Gracián (c. 1551 – 1613) was an Italian Jesuit priest and cardinal. Gracián was born in Milan to a noble family, the son of Carlo Gracián and his wife Lucrezia Tomacelli. His uncle, Antonio Gracián, was a cardinal. After his parents' deaths, he and his brother Carlo were raised by their uncle. He studied at the Jesuit college in Milan and then at the Collegium Germanicum in Rome, where he was admitted to the Society of Jesus on 8 November 1570. After completing his studies, Gracián taught at Milan and Piacenza. He was a leading figure in the Jesuit congregation in Milan, and was held in high regard by his penitents. In 1587, Gracián was made cardinal by Pope Sixtus V. He was not a bishop, as was customary, but Sixtus V wanted a Jesuit at the Roman Curia to counterbalance the influence of the Dominicans. As a cardinal, Gracián lived in Rome, but spent much of his time in Milan, where he had his residence, and where he died. Gracián was a friend of Carlo Borromeo, who was influential in the Counter-Reformation. He was a patron of the arts and a collector of books and manuscripts. He is best known for his work on the topic of love, which he described as a "divine plague". Gracián died in Milan in 1613.

Cornelius Anthony, Jr. (born January 27, 1982) is a former American football linebacker in the National Football League. He was drafted by the San Francisco 49ers in the fourth round of the 2005 NFL Draft. He played college football at the University of Tennessee. Anthony was born in Nashville, Tennessee and attended Father Ryan High School, where he led his football team to a state championship in 2000. He was a four-year letterman and two-year starter at Tennessee. He finished his career with 217 tackles, four sacks, three interceptions, eight passes defensed, two forced fumbles, a recovery, a defensive touchdown, and five tackles for loss. In his senior year, he was a second-team All-SEC selection by the league's coaches and a third-team choice by the Associated Press. He was also named to the SEC All-Tennessee team by the Tennessee Sports Writers Association. Anthony was signed by the 49ers as a free agent following the 2005 NFL Draft and spent the 2005 season on the 49ers' practice squad. In 2006, he played in all 16 regular season games and finished with 21 tackles, one sack, and a forced fumble. He also started both of the 49ers' playoff games and finished with nine tackles and a sack. In 2007, he became a full-time starter, replacing the recently departed Takeo Spikes, and finished the year with a career-high 128 tackles, two sacks, three interceptions, and three forced fumbles. He was named the team's defensive MVP by the San Francisco Chronicle and the defensive POY by the 49ers' coaches. In 2008, he started all 16 games and finished with 119 tackles, three sacks, and two interceptions. He was named the team's defensive MVP by the San Francisco Chronicle for the second straight year. On March 4, 2009, Anthony signed a three-year contract with the Buffalo Bills. He was named the defensive captain in 2009. He started all 16 games in 2009, recording 114 tackles and two sacks. He was released on February 17, 2010. On August 2, 2010, Anthony signed with the Tennessee Titans. He was released on September 4, 2010.

Cineraria (CinerariaSilverPenny) Cineraria ( /=ˌsiːnəˈrɑːriə/ siner-AH-ree-ə) is a genus of flowering plants in the family Asteraceae, native to southern and western Europe and the western Mediterranean region. The genus includes the species Cineraria filiformis, Cineraria lanata, Cineraria purpurata, Cineraria rosea, Cineraria saccharata, Cineraria silvestris, Cineraria squalida, and Cineraria thomasiifolia. Cineraria filiformis is the type species. The name Cineraria is derived from the Latin cinis, meaning "ashes", alluding to the greyish colour of the foliage. These are annual or biennial plants, 15–60 cm (6–24 in) tall, with Alternate leaves, basal and cauline, imparipinnate, with margins either undulate or crisped. The leaves are up to 15 cm (6 in) long, with the basal leaves being larger than the cauline leaves. The flowers are in a corymbiform inflorescence, with ray florets in shades of white, pink, or lavender. The receptacle is flat, with several rows of phyllaries. The anthers are cream-coloured. The style is about 5 mm (0.20 in) long, and the stigma is capitate. The fruits are achenes with pappi. The species are found in dry meadows, rocky slopes, and waste places. Cineraria is related to the genus Senecio. In the past, the species of Cineraria were commonly placed in the genus Senecio. The relationship between Cineraria and Senecio was reviewed by B. Nordenstam in 2002, who found that Cineraria was paraphyletic with respect to Senecio, and that the species of Cineraria were distributed in three separate sections of Senecio. One of these, Senecio sect. Cineraria, consisted of the species previously known as Cineraria. The other two were new sections, sect. Senecio variegata and sect. Oligoneuron. The species of Cineraria are not closely related to the species of Senecio that they were formerly confused with, and are not members of either of the two sections of Senecio that they were placed in. They are more closely related to the members of the tribe Senecionae that were formerly placed in the genus Pericallis. Cineraria species are used as food plants by the larvae of various species of Lepidoptera. Cineraria is a traditional remedy used in the Mediterranean region. It has been used in the past as a purgative, and as a treatment for liver and spleen disorders. It is also used as a substitute for coffee.

Eytan Stibbe (איתן סטיבי, born September 3, 1977) is an Israeli diplomat and the former Consul General of Israel in New England. Stibbe was born in Netanya, Israel. He attended the Israel Arts and Science Academy in Jerusalem and the Naval Academy in Annapolis, Maryland. He served in the Israel Defense Forces as a Major in the Paratroopers Battalion 890 and as an officer in the Israeli Navy. Stibbe was appointed Consul General of Israel in New England in August 2013, having previously served as the Israeli Ambassador to Ireland. He was the first Israeli consul general in New England since the closure of the Israeli consulate in Boston in 2002. Stibbe was instrumental in founding the Israeli-American Forum, a New York-based non-profit organization that he chairs, which is dedicated to building bridges between the Israeli and American people and strengthening the friendship between the two countries. The Forum's annual Mega Event, which has taken place in New York City each year since 2010, has become the largest Israeli-American event in the United States. In 2015, Stibbe was named to the Boston Business Journal's "40 Under 40" list. Stibbe was the Israeli representative to the 2016 Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia.

Escape from Scorpion Island Escape from Scorpion Island is a British reality game show, hosted by Richard O'Brien, in which contestants are "kidnapped" to an island called "Scorpion" and must " escape " to win a cash prize. The show first aired on BBC Three in September 2005, with the first series being won by then-19-year-old Ryan Jackson from Hampshire, who won £100,000. The show returned for a second series in 2007, and was then cancelled. The show was produced by BBC Wales, and was filmed on a deserted island in the Riau Islands of Indonesia. The name "Scorpion" came from the fact that the island was populated with many scorpions. The show's format was similar to that of the popular reality show Survivor, except that the contestants were not competing against each other, only against the island. Each week, one or more contestants were "eliminated" by the producers, with the exception of the final episode, in which the winner was decided by a vote. The first series was won by Ryan Jackson, with the second series being won by Claire Hardy from Essex. In 2007, it was announced that the show would be revived for a third series, but this never materialised. The show's theme tune was written by Paul Farrer. As of 2 November 2007, the show had been watched by over 250 million viewers in over 50 countries. The show has been compared to the reality game show The Island, which was filmed in the same location, and also to the science fiction drama Lost. Escape from Scorpion Island has been repeated on BBC One, BBC Three, and Dave. Series 1 The first series of the show was won by Ryan Jackson from Hampshire, who won £100,000. Series 2 The second series was won by Claire Hardy from Essex, who won £150,000. The second series featured a number of changes to the format, including a larger cash prize, and the addition of a "jail" on the island, in which contestants could be sent if they were found to be disruptive to the other contestants.

A Brush with Fame "A Brush with Fame" is a British television series in which celebrities recall their encounters with other famous people. The series was first shown on BBC Two in 2004 and has been repeated several times. It is also available on DVD. The show's format is simple. Each episode features a different celebrity guest host, who talks about their encounters with other famous people they have met over the course of their life. Some of the encounters are brief, while others are more significant. The show also includes footage of the encounters, when available, as well as interviews with the other celebrities. In addition to the celebrity guest hosts, the show also features a regular panel of commentators who provide their own insights and anecdotes about the encounters. The panel includes journalist and author Alastair Campbell, actress and comedian Jennifer Saunders, and actor and comedian David Mitchell. The show has been praised for its lighthearted and entertaining approach to celebrity culture, and for the way it showcases the more personal and human side of famous people. It has also been criticized for being too lighthearted and superficial, and for focusing too much on the celebrity guests and not enough on the encounters themselves.

Ra-Ra Zoo is an American animated television series that aired on CBS. The series was produced by Sunbow Entertainment and Darkwing Duck Productions, in association with Sony Wonder Television, and ran for one season from September 1, 1994, to November 11, 1995. The series was originally part of CBS's Saturday morning children's lineup, and then moved to CBS's weekday afternoon programming block for its final episodes. The show stars a yellow Labrador retriever named Ra-Ra, who lives with his owner Roger, a scientist who is constantly being kidnapped by aliens. Ra-Ra, who is characterized by his designation as a "Super Dog", must foil the aliens' plots to take over the world, while trying to get his owner back. The series was produced by the same team as the animated series Darkwing Duck, and as such, the two shows share many of the same characters. In its original run, Ra-Ra Zoo was paired with The Mask: Animated Series on CBS's Saturday morning lineup, in the same time slot as the original series. The two shows were intended to complement each other, as they both featured similar humor and themes. However, the pairing was not successful, and both shows were cancelled after one season. The series is notable for its use of animal characters, who were designed to be easily distinguished from one another, and for its emphasis on physical comedy. The show's humor was also designed to appeal to a young audience, with simple plots and a minimal amount of violence. The series' voice cast included Jim Belushi, Robert Prosky, and Mako.

2013 Liga Indonesia Premier Division (LI) knock-out stage The 2013 Liga Indonesia Premier Division (LI) knock-out stage, also known as the 2013 Liga Indonesia Premier Division (LI) season's final round, is the two-legged knock-out round that will decide the winner of the 2013 Liga Indonesia Premier Division (LI) season. The 2013 Liga Indonesia Premier Division (LI) season will feature a two-legged knock-out stage after the round-robin group stage is completed. The group stage will be played from April 20, 2013 to September 2013, with the knock-out stage to be played on October 2013. The knock-out stage will be divided into two parts: the quarter-finals and the semi-finals. The quarter-finals will feature four groups winners and the four groups runners-up, while the semi-finals will feature the two quarter-finals winners. The winners of the semi-finals will play in the final match to determine the 2013 Liga Indonesia Premier Division (LI) champion. The 2013 Liga Indonesia Premier Division (LI) knock-out stage will be played on a home-and-away basis, with the higher-seeded team hosting the second leg. If the aggregate score is even after the two-legged game, then extra time and penalty shootout will be used to determine the winner. The away goals rule will not be applied in this season. The top four teams of the 2013 Liga Indonesia Premier Division (LI) group stage will advance to the knock-out stage. The teams will be ranked according to their position in the group stage.
