Ramos de Azevedo is a municipality in the Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Norte. The municipality has an area of 487.325 square kilometers (188.53 sq mi) and a population of approximately 30,000 inhabitants, as of 2020. The municipality is located in the mesoregion of Nordeste Rio-Grandense, microregion of Crato, and has a border with the municipalities of Crato, Nova Olinda, Machico de Podence, Altos, and Itaúna. The name "Ramos de Azevedo" is a tribute to the Brazilian writer and diplomat Joaquim de Azevedo. In 1996, the municipality had a gross domestic product (GDP) of R$ 220 million, with a per capita income of R$ 29,600. The main economic activities are agriculture (rice, beans, manioc, and corn), industry (textiles, food, and furniture), and livestock raising. The city is connected by BR-235, BR-232, and BR-122 highways. In 2006, the city had an annual growth rate of 2.06%. In 2008, the city had an annual growth rate of 1.09%. In 2010, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.97%. In 2011, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.81%. In 2012, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.58%. In 2013, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.53%. In 2014, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.51%. In 2015, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.58%. In 2016, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.58%. In 2017, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.61%. In 2018, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.65%. In 2019, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.69%. In 2020, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.72%. In 2021, the city had an annual growth rate of 0.75%.

Riverside Polytechnic High School is a public school in Riverside, California, United States, and one of the two high schools in the Riverside Unified School District. The school was established in 1901 as a college preparatory school for the boys of Riverside. It is the third-oldest high school in California and the oldest in Riverside. The school is located at 3706 Victoria Avenue in the historic neighborhood of Victoria Woods in downtown Riverside. The school's teams are known as the "Poly High Bears". The school colors are blue and gold. The school yearbook is titled "The Polyglot". The school's main rival is the Arlington High School Lions, and the two schools compete in the annual "Battle of the Bell". The losing school in the annual rivalry game is forced to paint a silver bell the color of the winning school. The bell is then displayed at the winning school for the following year. In the early years of the school, the students were all male and were required to be members of the Presbyterian Church. The school was originally located in a two-story Victorian house near the corner of Main and Fourth Streets in downtown Riverside. The first principal was Captain William Edward Smith, who had been a captain in the U.S. Army during the Spanish–American War. In 1905, the school moved to a new campus at the corner of Sixteenth and Main Streets, and the school's mission changed from a college preparatory school to a secondary school. In 1913, the school moved to its present location at Victoria and Lime Streets. The school's first graduating class in 1905 consisted of 28 students. In the 1920s, the school added a large gym, a swimming pool, and a large concrete stadium with a capacity of 10,000. The stadium was named for Ralph White, the school's principal at the time. The stadium was later named Aquinas Stadium in honor of the school's long-time religion teacher and coach, Father Aquinas J.F. Dousharm. In the 1930s, the school added a wood shop, a metal shop, a print shop, and a girls' gym. In the 1940s, the school added a cafeteria and a fine arts building. In the 1950s, the school added a library and additional classrooms. In the 1960s, the school added a science building and a second gym. In the early 1970s, the school added a performing arts center and a visual arts center. In the 1980s, the school added a career/technical education building and a performing arts center. In the early 2000s, the school added a library/media center, a cafeteria, and additional classrooms. In 2006, the school completed construction on a new gym. The school is accredited by the Western Association of Schools and Colleges. The school has a diverse student body, with a majority of students being Hispanic and a significant African American and Asian minority. The school also has a large number of students who are eligible for free or reduced-price lunches. The school has a variety of sports teams, including football, basketball, baseball, soccer, cross country, track and field, and swimming. The school also has a variety of clubs and activities, including drama, band, choir, art, photography, ceramics, and computer science.

Viatris, Inc. is an American multinational pharmaceutical company headquartered in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. The company was created on November 16, 2021, following the merger of Mylan and Pfizer's generic drug business. The company operates in more than 40 countries and has approximately 37,000 employees. Viatris's products are sold in more than 165 countries and its manufacturing facilities are located in North America, Europe, and India. The company's largest customers include retail pharmacy chains, hospitals, health systems, and government health organizations. Viatris's marketed products include brands such as EpiPen, Norpramine, and Rexulti, as well as generic drugs. The company's largest selling products include the antipsychotic drugs Seroquel and Abilify, the asthma drug Xopenex, and the anti-allergy medication EpiPen. In 2021, the company had $26.5 billion in revenue and $8.7 billion in adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA). Viatris has been criticized for aggressively increasing drug prices.

Iain O'Brien (born 1 June 1976) is a British journalist, and the former political editor of The Daily Telegraph. Born in Norwich, O'Brien attended the independent University College School in London. He studied history at Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge. O'Brien joined the Telegraph in 1996 as a graduate trainee, and subsequently worked as a general news reporter in London and as a foreign correspondent in India. In 1999 he became the newspaper's first web writer, and in 2000 he was appointed as a political reporter, covering the 2001 general election and the 2005 general election. He became political editor in 2006, taking over from Philip Johnston. O'Brien was the first political editor of the Telegraph to cover a UK general election, the 2010 general election, in which he made a number of incorrect predictions. He also made a number of incorrect predictions about the 2015 general election, including the failure of the Liberal Democrats to win any seats in Scotland. He was the only mainstream journalist to correctly predict the election of Jeremy Corbyn as leader of the Labour Party in the 2015 leadership election. In September 2015, he was replaced as political editor by Peter Foster. In February 2018, O'Brien joined the staff of the UK's first online-only newspaper, The Independent, as a political reporter. He became the newspaper's political editor in June 2018. He left the Independent in December 2018. In January 2019, O'Brien joined the New Statesman as a political reporter.

Jeffrey M. Wilpon (born April 9, 1961) is an American businessman and the co-owner, with his brother, Stephen, of the New York Mets of Major League Baseball. Born in New York City, Wilpon is a graduate of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania with a bachelor of science degree in Economics. He is the son of former Mets co-owner, Joan Payson, and the grandson of the team's original founder, Charles Payson. Wilpon was named co-general partner of the Mets in August 2003, and is a member of the Mets' Board of Directors. He is the chairman of the Mets' Baseball Operations Committee and is the managing partner for the team's operating entity, Sterling Mets, Inc. In addition to his role with the Mets, Wilpon is the managing partner of the hedge fund Sterling Equities, which he founded in 1983. Wilpon's tenure with the Mets has been marked by high-profile controversies, including the team's trading of popular second baseman and fan favorite Mike Piazza, as well as the failure to make offers to free agents Albert Pujols and Prince Fielder. In 2010, he was widely criticized for his handling of the Mets' finances, which many believed to be an indicator of the team's poor performance. In 2011, the Mets' new owners, the hedge fund Binger Corporation, agreed to pay a record $1.5 billion for the team, which included a $1.1 billion mortgage that was held by the Wilpon family.

Shruti (music) In Indian classical music, shruti (श्रुति, literally "that which is heard"), is the smallest interval of pitch that can be identified by the human ear. The concept is closely related to the notion of pitch. A shruti is notated by the first three letters of the Indian alphabet, "ँ श र्ता" (na shra ta). The equivalent term in western music is "quarter tone", a half step or half-tone apart. However, shrutis are not precisely equivalent to quarter tones because they are melismatic. A shruti is defined as the pitch of a single note in the raga, and is the basic unit of measurement for distances between notes in the melody. However, the actual distance between two shrutis may be more or less than the distance between two Western quarter tones. For example, the pitch of the highest note of a piano (C5) to the pitch of the lowest note of a piano (C2) is an interval of 12 shrutis (the span of an octave), while the distance from the highest to the lowest note on a piano is 15 quarter tones. The 22 shrutis form a basic vocabulary of pitches from which the melodies of ragas are constructed. Indian classical music divides the shrutis into two groups: shadav-shrutis (literally, "sixteen shrutis"), and tivra-shrutis (literally, "six shrutis"). The shadav-shrutis form a system of 16 pitch classes, and the tivra-shrutis form a system of 6 pitch classes. The tivra-shrutis are sometimes called "chromatic" shrutis because they are what allow the musician to produce chromaticism, which is more common in Indian classical music than in Western classical music. In practice, the precise pitches of the shrutis are determined by the tune of the raga, and are not fixed. Furthermore, the distance between shrutis is not even. If an Indian classical musician is asked to produce the note "C", the musician will produce the note which is closest to "C" in the musician's own system of shrutis. Microtones are also found in other traditions of music in India, such as Indian folk music, as well as in Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nepal, Sri Lanka, and other countries with a strong influence from Indian classical music. However, the use of microtones in these traditions is generally not as developed as in Indian classical music.

The National Reality Television Awards are awarded annually in the United Kingdom. The awards are given out for the best reality television shows, as voted for by the public. The National Reality Television Awards were first awarded in 2001, and have been organized annually since. The awards are given out for the best reality television show in various categories, as well as for best personality, best newcomer, and best series. In addition, the National Reality Television Awards also give out the lifetime achievement award to a reality television show, as well as the outstanding contribution award to a person who has made a significant contribution to the genre. The National Reality Television Awards are given out by the National Reality Television Academy, which is a non-profit organization that was established in 2000. The academy is made up of producers, directors, writers, and other industry professionals who work in the field of reality television. The academy's goal is to promote the genre of reality television, as well as to recognize the best shows and personalities in the genre. In addition to the annual awards ceremony, the National Reality Television Academy also hosts the National Reality Television Conference, which is a three-day event that brings together industry professionals to discuss the latest trends and developments in the genre. The conference also features panel discussions and workshops, as well as the presentation of the lifetime achievement and outstanding contribution awards.

Willie Piazza, byname of William Francis Piazza Jr., (born August 16, 1981) is an American actor. Piazza was born in Los Angeles, California. He is the son of actress and talent manager Shawnda Piazza and the grandson of actress and talent manager Bonnie Piazza. He is of Italian (from his maternal grandmother), English, German, and Scottish descent. Piazza began his career as a child actor, appearing in several television commercials. His first major role was as a young Bruce Willis in the 1996 film Die Hard with a Vengeance. In 1998, he played the role of Jimmy Cooper in the film adaptation of the musical A Christmas Carol, as well as the role of Young Paul in the film Men in White. He also played the recurring role of Tyler Cassady in the series The Pinky and the Brain. In 1999, Piazza played the role of Eddie in the film The Dog of Wax, as well as the role of Carlo in the film Carlo's Wake. The following year, he played the role of Ricky in the film The Underground Comedy Movie. In 2001, he played the role of Jimmy in the film The Last Days of American Crime. In 2003, Piazza appeared as a contestant on the reality show The Surreal Life. In 2006, he played the role of Slim in the independent film The Lane. He also played the role of Keith in the film The Bogus Witch Project. In 2008, Piazza appeared as a contestant on the reality show The Great Debate. In 2009, he played the role of Army Doctor in the film The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3.

Wigglesworth Dole (April 17, 1841 – May 1, 1925) was an American lawyer, judge, civil servant, and politician from New York. Dole was born in Cambridge, New York. He was the son of David Dole (1809–1877) and Mary Merilla Wigglesworth (1813–1895), and the grandson of David Dole (1784–1855) and Lucinda Canfield (1787–1869), who were both born in Connecticut. The senior David Dole was a farmer and a member of the Connecticut House of Representatives. Dole was educated at Cambridge Academy and Cazenovia Seminary. He studied law, was admitted to the bar in 1864, and commenced practice in Albany, New York. He was an associate of Thomas J. Van Alstyne (1836–1917), a New York lawyer, politician, and businessman. In 1868, Dole was elected as a Republican to the New York State Assembly, representing Albany's 4th Ward. He served in the Assembly in 1869, 1870, 1871, and 1873. In 1871, Dole was appointed as private secretary to Francis C. Barlow (1825–1905), the Lieutenant Governor of New York. Barlow was elected Governor of New York in 1872, and Dole served as private secretary to the Governor from 1872 to 1873. In 1873, Dole was appointed as a justice of the New York Supreme Court to fill a vacancy caused by the death of John T. Sprague (1827–1873). He was re-elected in 1875 and 1880, and served until 1884. In 1884, Dole was appointed as a judge of the New York Court of Appeals. He was re-appointed in 1890, and served until 1895. Dole died in Albany, New York, and was buried at the Albany Rural Cemetery. Dole was married to Emma L. Noble (1845–1925), and they had three children, Grace L. (1877–1925), Paul S. (1879–1921), and James K. (1882–1883).

1967–68 Lancashire Cup The 1967–68 Lancashire Cup was the fifty-first occasion on which the Lancashire Cup competition had been held. The competition was won by Littleborough, who beat holders St. Helens in the final by the score of 16–13. The match was played at Central Park, Wigan, (historically in the county of Lancashire), and was watched by a crowd of 19,449. The attendance was receipts were £3,438 and the gate receipts were £19,438. Littleborough had never before won the competition, and this was their first appearance in the final. St. Helens had appeared in the final on fourteen previous occasions, winning the trophy ten times, in the years 1906, 1907, 1908, 1911, 1914, 1926, 1934, 1936, 1938, 1942, 1943, and 1966. This was the first of five consecutive appearances in the final by Littleborough, the last four of which were consecutive, and they won the trophy each time. It was also the first of three consecutive victories by Littleborough, the last two of which were consecutive.

Dissolution of Czechoslovakia On November 17, 1989, weeks after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the Velvet Revolution began in Czechoslovakia. Students and young people protested in Prague's Wenceslas Square, singing songs and calling for freedom. The protests were peaceful, and the police did not intervene. The following day, November 18, about 300,000 people gathered in the square. Civic Forum, a new opposition group led by writer-journalist Václav Havel, had called for a general strike after negotiations with the Communist government failed. The strike also received support from the trade union umbrella organization, the Czech Trade Union Association (ČMKOS). The Communist government's inability or unwillingness to put an end to the unrest led to the resignation of the entire party leadership, including the country's leader, Gustáv Husák. A new government was formed under the leadership of Prime Minister Marián Čalfa. The main task of the new government was to start the process of transforming the economy and preparing the country for free elections. The new government also introduced a number of immediate reforms, including the abolition of the system of universities and the return of private ownership of property. The free elections were held on June 8, 1990. Civic Forum, which won the most votes, and Public Against Violence, which came second, entered into a coalition government with the Christian and Democratic Union – Czechoslovak People's Party (KDU-ČSL), which won the third largest number of votes. The new government, headed by Prime Minister Václav Klaus, was sworn in on July 7, 1990. The first free presidential election was held on December 20, 1990. Václav Havel was elected president, and he was sworn in on December 29, 1990. On July 17, 1992, a group of concerned citizens, who felt that the country was being divided into two hostile camps, decided to launch a petition for the re-establishment of a democratic parliament, as they felt that the current parliament had been deformed by the communistic regime. The petition was launched on August 2, 1992, and by the end of the month it had received more than 50,000 signatures. A number of public protests were held in Prague and other cities in the autumn of 1992. The largest of these took place on October 27, when an estimated 500,000 people took part in a demonstration in Prague. The demonstration was organized by the Committee for the Defense of the Democratic Constitution, which was led by a number of well-known public figures, including Jaroslav Šedivý, Pavel Kohout, and Václav Malý. The petition for the re-establishment of a democratic parliament was handed to President Havel on October 28, 1992. The president then asked the Speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, Lubomír Zaorálek, to set up a committee to examine the petition. The committee, which was made up of members of the Chamber of Deputies, met for the first time on November 4, 1992. After lengthy negotiations, a new government was formed on December 16, 1992, under the leadership of Prime Minister Jan Stránský. The new government was sworn in on December 22, 1992. On December 24, 1992, the Chamber of Deputies voted to dissolve the country's borders with Germany and Austria. The vote was preceded by a number of public protests, including a large demonstration in Prague on December 18, 1992, which was attended by an estimated 350,000 people. On December 25, 1992, the Czech Republic and Slovakia officially separated. The president of the Czech Republic, Václav Havel, and the president of Slovakia, Michal Kováč, met in Prague on December 29, 1992, and signed an agreement on the peaceful division of the country. The agreement was approved by the Czech and Slovak parliaments in January 1993. As a result of the division, two new states were created: the Czech Republic and Slovakia. The Czech Republic, with its capital in Prague, was a parliamentary republic, while Slovakia, with its capital in Bratislava, was a constitutional republic. The two countries shared a common history, language, and culture, and had a similar economy. On January 1, 1993, the Czech Republic and Slovakia became independent states. The president of the Czech Republic, Václav Havel, and the president of Slovakia, Michal Kováč, were elected as the heads of state of their respective countries.

Royal Institute for Public Health and the Environment The Royal Institute for Public Health and the Environment (in Dutch: Koninklijk Instituut voor de Volksgezondheid en de Milieu, in short KIVM) is a Dutch research and education institute in the field of public health and environmental science. The institute is based in Bilthoven, The Netherlands. The institute was founded in 1952 as the National Institute for Public Health (in Dutch: Landelijk Instituut voor de Volksgezondheid). In 2013, the institute changed its name to KIVM. The institute's mission is to "contribute to a healthy future for all". To achieve this, the institute conducts research, provides information to the general public and gives advice to governments and other organizations. The institute also provides education and training in the field of public health and environmental science. The institute's research focuses on a wide range of public health and environmental science topics, including air pollution, climate change, infectious diseases, food safety, and the health effects of tobacco and alcohol use. The institute also conducts research on the health effects of electromagnetic fields, a topic that is not widely studied by other public health institutes. The institute's education and training activities include a bachelor's degree program in Public Health, a master's degree program in Environmental Science, and a PhD program in Public Health and Environmental Science. The institute also offers short courses and training programs for professionals working in the field of public health and environmental science. The institute is an autonomous organization, but it is partially funded by the Dutch government. The institute is also affiliated with several universities, including the University of Amsterdam, the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, and Wageningen University and Research Centre. In 2013, the institute was named as the best research institution in the field of public health in the Netherlands by the Dutch magazine Elsevier. In 2015, the institute was named as the best research institution in the field of environmental science in the Netherlands by the Dutch magazine Trouw.

George Washington Carroll (born January 28, 1931) is an American retired politician who served as the 24th Lieutenant Governor of Maryland from 1979 to 1983. Born in Baltimore, Maryland, Carroll attended the Baltimore City public schools. He graduated from Morgan State College in 1953 with a B.A. in history. He later took graduate courses at Morgan State and the University of Baltimore. In 1969, Carroll became the first black to be elected to the Maryland House of Delegates since the state was admitted to the Union in 1788, and the first black delegate to be elected to a full term. He was re-elected in 1970. In 1972, he was elected to the Maryland State Senate, where he served from 1973 to 1979. In 1978, Carroll was elected Lieutenant Governor of Maryland, defeating incumbent Democrat Blair Lee III with 55 percent of the vote. As lieutenant governor, Carroll chaired the State Board of Education, the State Board of Public Works, and the Commission on Maryland State Government Reform. He also served on the Maryland Stadium Authority and the Board of Visitors of the University of Maryland, Baltimore. Carroll ran for governor of Maryland in 1982, defeating incumbent Republican Harry R. Hughes with 56 percent of the vote. As governor, Carroll chaired the National Governors Association and the Southern Governors Association. He also served as chairman of the Democratic Governors Association in 1985. Carroll's first term as governor was marked by a steady economy and a balanced budget, as well as the expansion of the state's nascent biotechnology industry. However, his second term was marked by the collapse of the savings and loan industry, which threatened the state's economy. In addition, Carroll faced criticism for accepting gifts from lobbyists and for the use of state funds to renovate his home. In 1994, Carroll was elected to the Maryland State Senate, where he served from 1995 to 2003. He was the first black president of the State Senate, serving from 1999 to 2003. In 2002, he was the first black to be elected to the Maryland State House of Delegates since Reconstruction. He served one term and did not run for re-election in 2006. Carroll is a member of the Democratic National Committee and the Maryland Democratic Party State Central Committee. He has also served on the National Board of the National Conference of Black State Legislators. In 2008, he was named to the Morgan State University Board of Regents.

A Soviet air show was an event where military aircraft of the Soviet Union would perform for the general public. These were quite different from the airshows of the West, being much more spectacular and intended to wow the audience with the might of Soviet military power. Although the first Soviet air show took place in 1912, they became much more frequent during the 1930s, when the Soviet Union began its first serious attempts at creating a domestic aircraft industry. These shows were used to demonstrate the latest Soviet aircraft, which were often experimental and not yet in service. During the 1940s and 1950s, many foreign delegations were invited to Soviet air shows to witness the latest Soviet aircraft. The most famous Soviet air show was the annual Victory Day flypast on 9 May, which was held on Moscow's Red Square. This grandiose event was intended to demonstrate the might of Soviet aviation and was often attended by senior Party and military leaders, as well as foreign delegations. The flypast traditionally began with a parade of fighters, followed by a formation of Soviet strategic bombers. In the 1950s and 1960s, the Soviet Union also held an annual "Air Force Day" on 23 August, which featured a flypast over Moscow's Tushino Airport. In the 1980s, Soviet air shows began to feature more exotic aircraft, such as the MiG-29 and Sukhoi Su-27, which were intended to demonstrate the latest Soviet military technology. In the 1990s, after the fall of the Soviet Union, many of these aircraft were sold to other countries, who continued to perform in air shows. Today, Russian aircraft continue to perform in international air shows, such as the Royal International Air Tattoo and the Farnborough Airshow.

The Mercedes-Maybach 6 is a luxury concept car unveiled by German automotive manufacturer Mercedes-Benz at the 2015 Pebble Beach Concours d'Elegance. A front-engine, rear-wheel-drive two-door convertible, the car was designed primarily as a style showcase, with its proportions and lines intended to evoke Mercedes-Benz's classic cars of the 1950s and early-1960s. A number of elements were drawn from the Mercedes-Benz 300 SL roadster, including its basic proportions and shape, as well as its large, curved headlamps, a three-pointed star in the grille, and the shape of the rear reflectors. The car also shares some design elements with the Vision Mercedes-Maybach 6 concept car that was unveiled at the 2014 Paris Motor Show. The Mercedes-Maybach 6 is powered by aretro-futuristic, 6.0-litre, twin-turbocharged V12 engine producing 585 bhp (436 kW) and 1,000 Newton metres (738 lbf⋅ft) of torque. Power is sent to the rear wheels via a seven-speed, dual-clutch transmission and a limited-slip differential, allowing the car to accelerate from 0 to 100 km/h (0.0 to 62.1 mph) in 4.6 seconds, and go on to reach a top speed of 250 km/h (155.3 mph). The car's performance figures were stated by Mercedes-Benz to be "not intended for replication", and were said to be limited by the car's aerodynamic characteristics. The Mercedes-Maybach 6's exterior design was the work of Mercedes-Benz's advanced design studio, Mercedes-Benz Style, while its interior design was the work of Mercedes-Benz's design studio, Mercedes-Benz Design. The car's exterior and interior design themes were inspired by the Mercedes-Benz 300 SL. The Mercedes-Maybach 6 is 5,451 mm (213.5 in) long, 1,954 mm (77.0 in) wide, and 1,341 mm (52.6 in) tall, and has a 3,306 mm (130.7 in) wheelbase. The car's weight was not disclosed by Mercedes-Benz. The Mercedes-Maybach 6's interior features an Nappa leather-covered dashboard and instrument panel, as well as an Nappa leather-covered steering wheel, gear lever, and door panels. The car also features electrically adjustable, heated and cooled sports seats, a navigation system, and a Burmester surround sound system. The Mercedes-Maybach 6's exterior design was the work of Mercedes-Benz's advanced design studio, Mercedes-Benz Style, under the direction of designer Gordon Wagener. The car's design was influenced by Mercedes-Benz's classic cars, such as the Mercedes-Benz 300 SL roadster. The Mercedes-Maybach 6 is a front-engine, rear-wheel-drive, two-door convertible, and is powered by a 585 bhp (436 kW), twin-turbocharged, 6.0-litre V12 engine. The car's design elements include a large, curved radiator grille with a three-pointed star at its centre, large, curved headlamps, a rear spoiler, and the shape of the rear reflectors. The Mercedes-Maybach 6's interior design was the work of Mercedes-Benz's design studio, Mercedes-Benz Design, under the direction of designer Gorden Wagener. The car's interior design themes were inspired by the Mercedes-Benz 300 SL. The Mercedes-Maybach 6 is a two-door convertible, and is powered by a 585 bhp (436 kW), twin-turbocharged, 6.0-litre V12 engine. The car's interior design elements include an Nappa leather-covered dashboard and instrument panel, an Nappa leather-covered steering wheel, gear lever, and door panels, electrically adjustable, heated and cooled sports seats, a navigation system, and a Burmester surround sound system.

G9 is the ninth studio album by the Italian singer-songwriter Zucchero Fornaciari, released in 2004. The album was written and produced by Zucchero, and recorded in his home studio in the island of Elba, with the help of several musician friends. The album was mixed by Don Was in Los Angeles. The album was a commercial success, being certified 3× Platinum in Italy, and 2× Platinum in Switzerland. The first single, "Una Musica" was also a big hit, being certified Gold in Italy. The track "Il Tuo Eroe" was featured in the soundtrack of the movie Ocean's Twelve, and "Quelli che non pensano" was included in the soundtrack of the movie Crash (the Italian-language version of the movie). The album was re-released in 2006 with two bonus tracks, "Il Mare Calmo della Sera" and "Una Musica (Acoustic Version)", the latter being a re-working of the original track, featuring Scottish singer-songwriter Donovan. In 2009 the album was re-released again, this time as a double CD, with the second CD containing the acoustic version of the entire album. List of butterflies of the Republic of the Congo A list of butterflies of the Republic of the Congo is a list of butterfly species that can be found in the Republic of the Congo. Butterflies are insects in the macrolepidoptera (large-scale moths and butterflies) order, and they are a group of insects that is present in the Congolese forests. Several dozen species have been recorded, but the true number is unknown. Congolese butterflies are active during the day. The males are often territorial, and they defend their territories from other males. The females are often less colourful than the males. Most Congolese butterflies are solitary, but some species occasionally occur in groups. Many Congolese butterflies are threatened by habitat loss, and some are threatened with extinction. Congolese butterflies are important components of the Congolese ecosystem, and they are essential for the maintenance of the Congolese forests. Neil Gehrels (born July 11, 1951) is an American astrophysicist, best known for his contributions to the fields of high energy astrophysics and cosmology, and as the director of the American Museum of Natural History's Hayden Planetarium. Gehrels was born in Washington, D.C. in 1951. He earned a Bachelor of Science degree in physics from the California Institute of Technology in 1973, and a Master of Science degree and a doctorate, both in physics, from the University of California, Los Angeles in 1975 and 1977, respectively. After a year as a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Chicago, Gehrels joined the faculty of the California Institute of Technology in 1978, where he remained for the next thirty years. In 1978 he was also appointed a scientist at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory, where he served as the principal investigator of the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) from 1996 to 2002, and as the principal investigator of the Deep Space 1 mission from 1998 to 1999. In 2006, he joined the faculty of the University of California, Los Angeles, as a professor of physics and astronomy, and the following year he became the director of the Institute for Astronomy and Astrophysics at the University of Hawaii. In 2011, he joined the faculty of the American Museum of Natural History as a research professor and the director of the Hayden Planetarium, and in 2013 he became the chair of the Department of Astrophysics at the American Museum of Natural History. Gehrels's research has focused on the areas of high energy astrophysics and cosmology, including the study of the Galactic center, the detection and study of cosmic rays, and the search for evidence of dark matter and dark energy. He has also conducted research on the optical and ultraviolet properties of the interstellar medium, and on the evolution of the solar system. In addition to his research, Gehrels has also taught courses on high energy astrophysics, the physics of the interstellar medium, and the solar system.

Kyle Casey (born December 18, 1961) is an American actor and former professional American football player. A 6'3", 252-pound tight end, Casey was born in Springfield, Illinois and attended the University of Illinois. He was selected by the Buffalo Bills in the fourth round of the 1984 NFL Draft, and spent three seasons with the Bills and one with the Miami Dolphins. In his three seasons with the Bills, he played in all but one game, starting in all three seasons. He was a member of the Bills teams that made it to the Super Bowl in 1984 and 1990, although he did not play in the 1990 game due to an injury. During his time with the Bills, he was known for his ability to block kicks, a skill that he learned from his father, Mike Casey, who played for the San Francisco 49ers and St. Louis Cardinals. Kyle Casey began his acting career after retiring from football in 1991. His first role was as a guest star in the TV series Baywatch. In 1996 he played the role of Joe Petros in the movie The Crow: City of Angels. He also played the recurring role of Detective Mike West on the TV show The Practice. He had a small role in the 1998 movie Armageddon. He appeared in an episode of The X-Files entitled "All the greys make the dark". He also made a brief appearance in the 2000 movie The 6th Day. He played a major role in the 2006 movie The Last Days of American Crime.

Ming Shilu Ming Shilu (Chinese: 明时录; lit. 'The Account of the Ming Dynasty'), also known as the Zhenyuan Shilu ( Chinese: 真源实录; lit. 'The True Account of the Zhenyuan Era'), is an internal history of the Ming dynasty written by the historian Li Delun ( Chinese: 李德伦; 1541–1593), who spent his entire life in the Ming court. It covers the period from the founding of the Ming dynasty to the 44th year of the reign of the Ming emperor Wanli (1572). The Ming Shilu is one of the most important sources of the history of the Ming dynasty. After the Fall of the Ming, the Ming Shilu was continued by the Ming court as the diary of the corresponding era. The full title of the diary is Ming chunqiu ( Chinese: 明君曰; lit. 'The Lord of the Ming said'), and it was first started in the 1st year of the reign of the Hongguang Emperor (29 January 1568 – 29 January 1570), and was continued by the Ming court to the 42nd year of the reign of the Wanli Emperor (1605). The diary contains much information on the daily life and the inner court politics of the Ming dynasty, and is an important source for the study of the social history of the Ming dynasty.

Yamatogoto Yamatogoto (大和GOTO, "Japanese style GOTO") is a style of GOTO that was developed in Japan in the early 20th century, based on the Western GOTO programming language. It was the first Japanese language GOTO to be developed, and is thus also called the "original GOTO". It was developed in the early 1900s by Japanese mathematician and computer scientist Kazuhito Kohjiro Kondo (近藤 和仁, 1908–1998). The method was initially called the Kondo method, but was later renamed Yamatogoto. The first reference to this method in the literature was in a journal called "Mathematics and Computation" in 1970. The name "Yamatogoto" comes from the word "Yamato", which means "Japan" in Japanese, and "goto", which means "relay" in Japanese. The name thus means "Japanese style relay". The Yamatogoto style of GOTO is characterized by the use of the while loop instead of the unconditional branch found in more traditional GOTO implementations. The use of the while loop is similar to the use of the for loop in more modern imperative programming languages. The designers of Yamatogoto also incorporated the concept of "dynamic labels" into the language. A dynamic label is a label that is associated with a location in the program text instead of with a fixed position in the program. In addition to these changes, Yamatogoto also introduced the "data flow diagram", which is used to represent the flow of data through the program. The data flow diagram is similar to the flowchart, which is used to represent the flow of control through the program. The Yamatogoto style of GOTO has been influential in the development of other Japanese language GOTO dialects, such as JAL and JxAL. It has also influenced the development of the Pascal programming language.

Chorobates Rock is a balanced rock on the Island of Cyprus, located in the Limassol District. It is one of the most famous landmarks on the island and a popular tourist attraction. The rock is located on the edge of a cliff in the Amathus area, about 1 km (0.62 mi) from the Mediterranean Sea. It is a large, naturally formed, mushroom-shaped rock with a cap that rests on a pillar of rock. The cap is estimated to weigh about 250 tons. The rock can be reached by a path that leads to a staircase that ascends the side of the cliff to a point opposite the rock. A bridge connects the path to the rock. The word chorobates comes from the Greek words chora (area) and baths (walk), meaning "the place where one can walk". According to local legend, the rock was used as a natural bridge by an elderly woman who lived in the area. The woman had become too weak to walk to the church, so the rock formed a natural bridge to assist her journey. The rock has been a tourist attraction for centuries, and was depicted in medieval maps. It has been featured in literature, including in the works of the 16th-century Italian writer Giovanni Marrazzini, the 17th-century English writer Sir Walter Raleigh, and the 18th-century Irish writer Dean Jonathan Swift. In 2015, the rock was featured in the third episode of the American television series Ancient Aliens.

Henry Yelverton (Australian politician) Henry Yelverton (1 August 1888 – 11 March 1961) was an Australian politician. He was born in Melbourne to George Yelverton, a bootmaker from Cork, Ireland, and his wife Elizabeth (née Moloney), from Warrnambool, Victoria. He attended De La Salle College in South Melbourne and then the University of Melbourne, where he studied law. He was articled to a legal firm and in 1911 became a partner, remaining with the firm until his death. In the same year he married Millicent Gribble; she died in 1916, leaving him a widow with two sons. In 1939 he married Grace Winifred Furnell, a nurse. Yelverton was a member of the Labor Party and was elected to the Victorian Legislative Assembly in 1927 for the seat of Prahran, serving until his death. He was Minister of Public Works and Forests and Minister in Charge of Electrical Undertakings from 17 April to 15 June 1924, when the Labor government was defeated. He was again Minister of Public Works and Forests, and Minister in Charge of Electrical Undertakings, from 22 November 1928 to 18 May 1929, when the Labor government was defeated again. Yelverton died at his home in South Yarra from coronary vascular disease in 1961, aged 72.

Farma (Croatian for "The Farm") is a Croatian reality TV series broadcast by Fox televizija. The series was originally broadcast from November 2, 2015, to December 15, 2015, and it is currently in its fifth season. The show is set on a farm in the rural Croatian village of Bedekovčina, and follows the daily activities of the farmers who live and work there. The series is produced by Fox televizija in collaboration with the farmers who own the farm. The show is broadcast on Fox televizija's channel Foxlife. The show follows the farmers as they go about their daily lives, which include taking care of the farm's animals, growing crops, and maintaining the farm's equipment. The farmers also have to deal with the occasional wild animal that wanders onto the farm, as well as with the occasional visitor who comes to the farm to buy produce or to visit. The show is known for its realistic portrayal of farm life, and for its focus on the personal stories of the farmers who live and work on the farm. The show has also been praised for its educational value, as it has helped to raise awareness about the importance of agriculture in Croatia.

Italian Social Democratic Party The Italian Social Democratic Party (Partito Sociale Democratico Italiano, PSDI), was a social-democratic political party in Italy that was active from 1972 to 1992. The party was founded on 17 January 1972 by a group of splinters from the Italian Democratic Party of the Left (PDS), a component of the Popular Democratic Front (FDP), led by Giuseppe Saragat, a former president of the Italian Republic. The party was particularly strong in the early 1970s, winning 8.5% of the vote and 69 seats in the Chamber of Deputies in the 1972 general election, but it failed to win any seats in the Senate. In the next general election, in 1976, the PSDI won 9.3% of the vote and 79 seats in the Chamber, but again failed to win any seats in the Senate. In the 1979 election the PSDI won 8.2% of the vote and 67 seats in the Chamber, and 3 seats in the Senate. In the 1980s the party was a member of the European Social Democratic Party, and in the 1984 European Parliament election it won 4 seats. In the 1987 general election the PSDI won 6.9% of the vote and 56 seats in the Chamber of Deputies, and 4 seats in the Senate. In the 1992 general election the PSDI won 2.4% of the vote and 6 seats in the Chamber, but failed to win any seats in the Senate. The PSDI was dissolved in 1992, and most of its members joined the Democratic Party of the Left, which had been formed in 1991 as the new successor to the PDS.

Whitefield, Oklahoma Whitefield is a town in northwest Oklahoma, United States. It was incorporated in 1907, and the population was 586 at the 2010 census. Whitefield was established in the early days of the Cherokee Outlet in the late 1870s. A line of the Cherokee National Railroad was constructed through the area in the early 1880s, and the town was platted in 1886. The community was named for its founder, Richard A. Whitefield. The town became a shipping point for cattle and horses during the early part of the 20th century. During World War II, it was the site of a large ammunition plant. The plant was closed after the war, but a smaller plant remained in operation until the late 1970s. The town is located in the Cherokee Outlet, approximately 6 miles (10 km) west of Stillwater. U.S. Route 64 passes through the town, and U.S. Route 51 passes just to the south. As of the census of 2000, there were 665 people, 255 households, and 169 families residing in the town. The population density was 878.8 people per square mile (339.5/km2). There were 291 housing units at an average density of 397.8 per square mile (153.0/km2). The racial makeup of the town was 95.06% White, 1.08% African American, 2.99% Native American, 0.15% Asian, 0.60% from other races, and 0.45% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.06% of the population. There were 255 households, out of which 34.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 48.0% were married couples living together, 12.0% had a female householder with no husband present, and 38.0% were non-families. 34.0% of all households were made up of individuals, and 11.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.41 and the average family size was 3.15. In the town, the population was spread out, with 27.5% under the age of 18, 9.3% from 18 to 24, 29.2% from 25 to 44, 20.1% from 45 to 64, and 14.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 100.2 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 101.1 males. As of 2000 the median income for a household in the town was $32,788, and the median income for a family was $45,417. Men had a median income of $29,375 versus $19,444 for women. The per capita income for the town was $17,8. About 6.2% of families and 9.9% of the population were below the poverty line, including 12.2% of those under age 18 and 5.8% of those age 65 or over. In the early 20th century, Whitefield had a large population of Czech people. The community was served by St. Anne's Catholic Church, which was built in 1908 and is still in use. The Whitefield Carnegie Library, built in the early 20th century, is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Whitefield School District encompasses 100 square miles (260 km2) covering all of Whitefield and portions of Stillwater and Guthrie. The district has one elementary school and one high school. The current high school building opened in the fall of 1994. The old high school building, built in the early 1920s, was donated to the city of Whitefield and is now used as the Whitefield Community Center.

Tamnyaskey is an unincorporated community in the Canadian province of Nova Scotia. It is on the east bank of the Saint Marys River, which is a tributary of the Bay of Fundy, in the Annapolis Valley. The community is on the north boundary of the town of Digby. The community was first settled in the early 1700s and was known as "Tammany" after Tamanend, a Delaware Indian chief. It was the site of one of the first shipyards in the Atlantic Canada region. In his book "The History of Digby", J.W. Duckworth wrote in 1895 "The ship-building firm of John hall & Company, of London, engaged in the building of ships in the year 1792, in a yard at Tammany on the St. Mary's river, three miles below Digby. The first ship, the "James and Mary", was launched in 1793, and was followed by the "HMS surveyed", a 54-foot-keel, 20-ton gunboat, built for the British government for the protection of the fisheries. This was launched in 1796. The yard continued in operation for many years, and the "HMS Archer", a Rating four, 54-foot-keel gunboat, was launched there in 1811. During the War of 1812, the "HMS Archer" was on the Great Lakes, and was captured by the Americans at the Battle of Lake Erie. In 1825 the British government established the "HMS Dauphine" at Tammany, as a depot for the West Indies squadron. This was a Rating six, 64-foot-keel, 20-gun, brass-plated ship, built at Deptford, England, in 1824. It was commanded by Captain George Muttlebury. The ship left England in September 1824, arriving in Digby in October. The crew spent the winter of 1824–1825 there, suffering from " shipbuildingitis", a term used to describe what the author believed was the first case of what is now called "seasonal affective disorder". The "Dauphine" left Digby in May 1825 to join the squadron in the West Indies, and was later sold to the Portuguese government. A 20-gun, two-masted corvette, it was renamed the "D. pmo. Xavier" and served in the Brazilian navy until 1864. Tammany was the site of an Acadian village, and the French chapel at nearby "les Mines" was used by the Acadians, then the French, then the British. The chapel is now a memorial to the Acadians and is a provincial historic site.

Paul Drinkhall (born 8 October 1982) is a British former table tennis player. Drinkhall was born in Hull, Yorkshire, and was selected for the British team at the 2000 Summer Olympics in Sydney, where he competed in the men's singles event, reaching the second round. He also reached the quarter-finals of the men's doubles competition, partnering Shailesh Govindasamy. Four years later, Drinkhall was part of the British team that won the silver medal in the team event at the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens. He also reached the quarter-finals of the men's singles competition, losing to Peter Karlsson of Sweden. At the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, Drinkhall was part of the British team that won the bronze medal in the team event. He also reached the quarter-finals of the men's singles competition, losing to Dimitrij Ovtcharov of Germany. Drinkhall reached the quarter-finals of the men's singles at the 2012 Summer Olympics in London, defeating Wang Hao of China in the second round before losing to Dimitrij Ovtcharov. He also reached the semi-finals of the men's doubles, partnering Liam Pitchford. In the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio, Drinkhall reached the quarter-finals of the men's singles, where he lost to Vladimir Samsonov of Belarus. He also reached the semi-finals of the men's doubles, partnering Tom Jarvis. Drinkhall announced his retirement from competitive table tennis in January 2018.

Cale, Arkansas Cale is an unincorporated community in Washington County, Arkansas, United States. It is the location of (or the nearest community to) the Washington County Airport. The community is located on Arkansas Highway 16 between the cities of Fayetteville and Springdale. The community had a population of 49 in the 2000 census, all residents living in the rural hilltop community known as Mount Olive. Cale was the name of a small community that formed in the 19th century around a Rural Free Delivery post office. The community had a population of 49 in the 2000 census, all residents living in the rural hilltop community known as Mount Olive. The population in 2010 was listed as 108. The community is located on Arkansas Highway 16 between the cities of Fayetteville and Springdale. The community had a population of 49 in the 2000 census, all residents living in the rural hilltop community known as Mount Olive. The population in 2010 was listed as 108. The community is located on Arkansas Highway 16 between the cities of Fayetteville and Springdale. The community had a population of 49 in the 2000 census, all residents living in the rural hilltop community known as Mount Olive. The population in 2010 was listed as 108. The community is located on Arkansas Highway 16 between the cities of Fayetteville and Springdale.
