Tony Halik is an Australian actor, best known for his role as Jim Braggett on the television soap opera Home and Away. Halik was born in Sydney, Australia, and attended Marcellin College, Randwick. He began acting at the age of 16, appearing in a number of school plays, and had his first professional role at 18, in a Theatre Sports production. He went on to appear in a number of television commercials, before landing the role of David Wallace in the soap opera Sons and Daughters in 1985. In 1986, he joined the cast of Home and Away as Jim Braggett, and remained with the show for three years. In 1989, he appeared in the police drama Mission: Impossible, and in 1990, he played the lead role in the short-lived soap opera The Power, the Passion. He also made a brief return to Home and Away in 1990. In 1991, Halik appeared in the action film Bloodmoon, and had a guest role in the comedy series A Country Practice. He later appeared in the films No Escape (1994), killer fish movie Shark Tale (1998), and The Great Dividing Range (1997). He also had a role in the television movie Peter Brock: The Last Glory (1995), and appeared in the first episode of the series Black Jack. In 2008, he appeared as a guest judge on the reality show RPA, and appeared in an episode of the soap operaNeighbours. In 2013, Halik appeared in the Australian drama film Wog Boy 2: Kings of Mykonos.

Fireworks Entertainment is a Canadian independent record label and entertainment company, specializing in classical music, jazz, and world music. It was founded in 1984 by Canadian businessman David Foster and is based in Toronto. The company has an additional office in Los Angeles. Fireworks was originally established as a vehicle for Foster's discovery and promotion of new talent, and as such, it has played a key role in the early careers of artists such as Michael Bublé, Josh Groban, and Idina Menzel. In the 1990s, the company expanded into the management of established artists, including James Galway, Peter Cetera, and The Chieftains. Fireworks Entertainment has released more than 250 albums, including numerous Grammy Award-winning and platinum-selling recordings. It has also produced music for a number of films and television shows, including Armageddon, The Princess Diaries, and The Polar Express. In recent years, the company has expanded into the production of live concerts and events, including the annual David Foster & Friends concert, which features performances by some of the world's top classical and pop musicians.

Steve Cunningham (computer scientist) Steve Cunningham (born c. 1960) is an American computer scientist and engineer who has contributed to the field of computer security, including the design of the first network firewall, the first implementation of Kerberos, and the first systems to use digital signatures to provide non-repudiation. He is currently a Distinguished Engineer at Cisco Systems. Cunningham was born in Detroit, Michigan, United States. He received a B.S. degree in computer science in 1982, an M.S. degree in computer science in 1984, and a Ph.D. degree in computer science in 1988, all from the University of Utah. In the early 1980s, while a graduate student at the University of Utah, Cunningham was one of the designers of the first network firewall, the bastion host, along with colleagues Fred Grampp and Bill Young. In 1984, he was one of the designers of the first implementation of Kerberos, as part of the University of Michigan's Michigan Terminal System (MTS), and was also one of the designers of the first systems to use digital signatures to provide non-repudiation. In 1985, he designed the first public-key certificate system with David Chaum, which was also the first to use blind digital signatures. In 1986, he was the author of the first paper on provable security, which laid the foundations for the field of computer security as it is known today. After receiving his Ph.D., Cunningham joined the Systems Research Center (SRC) at Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) where, with Louis Monier, he was one of the two main designers of AltaVista, one of the first search engines to gain widespread use on the Internet. Following Compaq's acquisition of DEC, Cunningham worked briefly for Microsoft to prevent spamming. Shortly thereafter he joined Cisco Systems.

Keith McCambridge (born January 14, 1972) is a Canadian former professional ice hockey player. He played in the National Hockey League (NHL) with the Calgary Flames, Vancouver Canucks, Nashville Predators, and New York Rangers. He is the current head coach of the Portland Winterhawks of the Western Hockey League (WHL). McCambridge was born in Toronto, Ontario. He was drafted in the third round, 70th overall, by the Calgary Flames in the 1990 NHL Entry Draft. He played four seasons in the Ontario Hockey League (OHL) with the Ottawa 67's and Hamilton Dukes. McCambridge made his NHL debut with the Flames in the 1992–93 season, appearing in one game. The following season, he played ten games with the Flames and four with their American Hockey League (AHL) affiliate, the Saint John Flames. In 1995, he appeared in two games with the Vancouver Canucks and one with the New York Rangers, while spending the majority of the season with the AHL's Syracuse Crunch. McCambridge spent the 1996–97 season with the IHL's Manitoba Moose, then returned to the NHL the following year with the Nashville Predators, appearing in 51 games. He played two more seasons with the Predators, then retired from professional hockey in 2000. After his retirement, McCambridge returned to the OHL as an assistant coach with the Guelph Storm and the Owen Sound Attack. In 2004, he was named head coach of the Chilliwack Chiefs of the British Columbia Hockey League (BCHL), and in 2008 he moved up to the Victoria Grizzlies of the Alberta Junior Hockey League (AJHL). In 2012, he was named head coach of the Western Hockey League (WHL) team the Portland Winterhawks, with whom he won the league championship in 2013.

Riverhead, Kent is a village and civil parish in the English county of Kent. It is situated on the west bank of the River Medway, opposite the village of Snodland. In 2011, it had a population of 2,258. The village has a number of shops and businesses, and one school, Riverhead Infants' School. The Church of England church is dedicated to St Peter and St Paul; it is a grade II* listed building and has a 14th-century hammerbeam roof. The place-name 'Riverhead' is first attested in a charter of 862, in which it appears as Rivieram. The name is derived from the Old English riparia, meaning 'river'. In 946, King Edmund granted land at Riverhead to Odo, Count of Chartres. During the First World War, a hospital was established in the village for wounded soldiers. The A2 road passes through the parish, and the A20 road passes to the south of it. The civil parish includes the settlements of Halling, and The Fostall. The parish was formed in 1888 when it was separated from the civil parish of Snodland. Riverhead is also the name of a suburb of the Canadian city of Windsor, Ontario, which is located across the river from Detroit, Michigan.

Four Seasons (murals) The Four Seasons is a set of four murals by Italian artist Paolo Veronese, commissioned in 1576 by the doges of Venice, Andrea and Nicolò GRIMANI, to decorate the walls of the Sala del Maggior Consiglio (Hall of the Great Council) in the Doge's Palace, Venice. Each of the four paintings depicts a different season. The Four Seasons is a recurring theme in the history of Western art, representing one of the first examples of the use of the same subject matter in different artistic media, such as painting, sculpture, and music. The Veronese murals are particularly notable for their trompe-l'œil elements, such as the two spectators in the centre of the Winter scene, who appear to be in conversation with each other, but are in fact separated by a large gap in the wall. The four paintings were in the Hall of the Great Council for over 250 years, until they were moved to the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica in Rome in the 19th century. They were returned to the Doge's Palace in 2015.

Donat Makijonek (13 September 1884 – 10 May 1960) was a Polish politician, member of the Polish government in Exile, and activist for Polish scouting. He was born in Siedlce, Poland, to a family of teachers. His father, Antoni Makijonek, was the director of a local high school. His mother, zofia, was a teacher in a local school. He was a member of the Polish Scouting and Guiding Association (Polish: Związek Harcerstwa Polskiego, ZHP), and in the early 1930s, became the chairman of the Polish scouting chapter in Vilnius. After the Soviet invasion of Poland, he was arrested by the NKVD and spent three years in a prison in Vilnius. After World War II, he became one of the most active members of the Polish government in Exile, and a close friend of the President of Poland in exile, August Zaleski. He was a member of the Council of National Unity (Polish: Kolegium Obywatelskiej Jedności Narodowej), and supported the idea of a united Poland, with all the territories which had been part of the Polish state before the war. In 1953, he became the chairman of the political committee of the government in exile. Donat Makijonek was awarded the Order of Polonia Restituta, the Cross of Merit with V with Star and Sash, the Gold Cross of Merit with Star and Sash, the Order of the White Eagle, and the Virtuti Militari.

The Song of Songs (play) The Song of Songs is a romantic play by American writer Sheldon Harnason. It is based on the biblical story of the Song of Solomon, also known as the Song of Songs or Canticles. The play's title is taken from the first line of the Bible, "The Song of Songs, which is Solomon's." The play is set in the court of King Solomon. The king is old, and the action revolves around his search for a successor. The queen, Bathya, is a strong-willed, powerful woman, and the king's chief wife. She is concerned for the future of her son, Prince David, the heir apparent. The king's other wives, Naamah and Abishag, are lesser figures, although Abishag has a romantic relationship with the king. The king's main concern is the disposition of his wealth. He has accumulated vast amounts of gold, and he worries that his successor will not be able to keep it together. The king's wealth is the cause of much of the action in the play. The king's closest advisor, Benjamin, is the keeper of the king's wealth. The king's other advisor, Nathan, is the royal prophet. The king's two sons, David and Absalom, are in line to succeed him. David is the elder, and is married to the princess from Tyre, Taphath. Absalom is the younger, and is married to the princess from Egypt, Othniel. The king's other possible successor is his brother, Adonijah. Adonijah is not married, and is the king's favorite. The play is set in the months leading up to the king's death. The king is determined to choose his successor based on the wisdom of his counselors, and not based on the wealth or popularity of the potential successors. The king's main concern is to keep the wealth of the kingdom together. The play ends with the king's death, and the accession of David to the throne.

Mohamad Ridzuan Mohamad Puzi (born 6 August 1988) is a Malaysian professional footballer who plays as a goalkeeper for Malaysia Super League club Kedah Darul Aman. Born in Klang, Mohamad Ridzuan was a product of the Malaysia national youth system before he was called up to the senior team in 2008. He was a member of the Malaysia squad that won the 2009 Southeast Asian Games. Mohamad Ridzuan was also a member of the Malaysia U-23 team that won the bronze medal at the 2010 Asian Games in Guangzhou, China. He was also a member of the Malaysia U-23 team that won the gold medal at the 2011 Southeast Asian Games in Indonesia. In 2012, Mohamad Ridzuan was called up to the Malaysia B team for the 2012 Malaysia Premier League. In 2015, Mohamad Ridzuan was called up to the Malaysia B team for the 2015 Malaysia Super League. In 2016, Mohamad Ridzuan was called up to the Malaysia B team for the 2016 Malaysia Super League. In 2017, Mohamad Ridzuan was called up to the Malaysia B team for the 2017 Malaysia Super League. In 2018, Mohamad Ridzuan was called up to the Malaysia B team for the 2018 Malaysia Super League. In 2019, Mohamad Ridzuan was called up to the Malaysia B team for the 2019 Malaysia Super League. In 2020, Mohamad Ridzuan was called up to the Malaysia B team for the 2020 Malaysia Super League. In 2021, Mohamad Ridzuan was called up to the Malaysia B team for the 2021 Malaysia Super League.

The Yale romanization of Mandarin, also known as Yale romanization or pinyin, is a system of romanization of Mandarin Chinese developed by the Yale alphabetic system committee, which was headed by George A. Miller, during the early 1950s. The Yale system was an outgrowth of the Joint Commission on Chinese Romanization, which was composed of scholars from the United States and China and which met in New Haven, Connecticut, in the early 1950s. The Yale system was published in a report entitled Romanization of Chinese by the Yale-China Association in 1953. The Chinese government adopted a modified form of the Yale system as its official romanization in 1958, and it was given the name pinyin (literally, "romanization") in 1982. The Yale romanization system is based on the Mandarin dialect of Beijing. It uses the Latin alphabet to represent Mandarin sounds, with some diacritics to indicate tones. The Yale system can be represented in plain text without diacritics, though this has the disadvantage of losing the information about tones. The Yale system has been influential in teaching Mandarin to foreigners. It was used in the teaching of Mandarin at Yale University for several decades and was also used by other universities in the United States and elsewhere. It is still widely used in books and in the media, especially in the United States and Taiwan, and it has been influential in the design of other romanization systems. However, the use of Yale romanization has been decreasing, and it has been replaced by pinyin in most educational contexts.

Syed Arshad Ali (born 27 January 1943) is a Pakistani American writer, analyst, and scholar who has written extensively on the subjects of international relations, foreign policy, and defense and security issues. He has also written books and articles on the subjects of Islam and the West, and the history of science. Syed Arshad Ali was born in 1943 in Lahore, Punjab, in a literary and academic family. His father, Syed Zafar Ali, was a civil servant and his mother, Zareen Hussain, was a housewife. He was the second of their three children. After completing his early education at the Lawrence College, Ghora Gali, Murree (now in Pakistan), he went to the United States for higher studies. He attended the University of Washington in Seattle, and graduated with a bachelor's degree in political science in 1965. He then attended the School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS) at the Johns Hopkins University in Washington, D.C., where he received his master's degree in 1968 and his Ph.D. in 1972, both in international relations. After completing his education, Syed Arshad Ali began his career as an academic and writer. He worked as an assistant professor at the University of Wisconsin–Madison from 1973 to 1976, and then as an associate professor at the University of South Carolina from 1976 to 1982. In 1982, he joined the Foreign Service of Pakistan and served as an advisor on international affairs to the Chief Minister of Punjab, and then as the director of the Foreign Publicity Bureau in the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Islamabad. In 1985, he was appointed as the principal staff writer and then as the editor of the Foreign Office Journal. In 1988, Syed Arshad Ali was posted as the counselor in the Pakistan Embassy in Washington, D.C., where he served until 1991. He was then appointed as the ambassador of Pakistan to South Korea, and served in this position until 1994. He was also the ambassador to North Korea from 1992 to 1994. After retiring from the Foreign Service, Syed Arshad Ali resumed his academic and writing career. He worked as a research associate at the Center for International and Security Studies at the University of Maryland from 1995 to 1996, and then as a visiting professor at the School of Advanced International Studies at the Johns Hopkins University from 1996 to 1997. He also worked as a senior research fellow at the National Institute of Pakistan Studies at Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, from 1996 to 1997. In 1997, Syed Arshad Ali moved to New York City and worked as a writer and editor for the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) from 1997 to 2002. He then worked as a senior writer and editor for the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA) from 2002 to 2006. He was also the editor of the United Nations Economic and Social Survey of Asia and the Pacific from 2002 to 2006. Syed Arshad Ali has written numerous books and articles on international relations, foreign policy, and defense and security issues. His books include Pakistan's Foreign Policy: An Introduction, International Relations: A New Perspective, Foreign Policy of Pakistan: An Insight, and Islam and the West: A Historical and Political Perspective. His articles have been published in various newspapers and journals, including The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, Foreign Policy, Foreign Affairs, and The Journal of International Affairs. Syed Arshad Ali has also written on the subjects of history and science. His books on these subjects include The Life and Times of Sir Syed Ahmed Khan, and Science and Society in Ancient Greece. In addition to his writing, Syed Arshad Ali has also served as a consultant to various organizations and governments, including the United Nations, the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank, and the governments of Pakistan, the United States, and South Korea.

Chisago Lakes School District #95 is a school district serving the Chisago County area in Minnesota, United States. The district includes the cities of Chisago City, Lindstrom, and Shafer; and the surrounding rural area. The district has four elementary schools, one middle school, and one high school. The Chisago Lakes School District was organized in 1978 by the consolidation of three rural school districts. The three original districts were the Chisago City School District (established in 1868), the Lindstrom School District (established in 1898), and the Shafer School District (established in 1917). The school district's name refers to the three lakes that serve as boundaries for the district: Lake Chisago, Green Lake, and Lake Michigan. The district's service area covers approximately 125 square miles (323 km2). The district's high school, Chisago Lakes High School, is located in the city of Lindstrom. The high school was built in 1980, with an addition completed in 1990. In 2006, a second addition was completed, adding a new gym and a new wing with four additional classrooms. The middle school, named Chisago Lakes Middle School, is located in the city of Shafer. The middle school was built in 1968, with an addition completed in 1993. The elementary schools are: Chisago City Elementary School, located in the city of Chisago City Green Lake Elementary School, located in the city of Lindstrom Lake Michigan Elementary School, located in the city of Shafer Willow Lake Elementary School, located in the city of Shafer The school district also has a community education building, located in the city of Lindstrom, which houses the district's early childhood education program, as well as classes for adult education. The school district is a member of the North Suburban Conference (NSC) for athletic competitions. The NSC includes seven other area school districts. The school district's colors are purple and gold. The school district's mascot is a Viking. The school district has an open boundary policy, meaning that students living in the district's service area may attend any of the district's schools. The district also has a policy of accepting students who live outside the district's service area, provided there is room for the student in the district's schools. The school district is governed by a seven-member school board, which is elected by the residents of the district. The current board is made up of seven Republicans. The school district's superintendent is Dr. Susan Mahlom. The school district's business manager is Paul Olson. In addition to the main school campus in Lindstrom, the school district also owns and operates two other properties: Chisago Lakes Academy, a school for students with special needs, located in the city of St. Paul Chisago Lakes Online Academy, an online school for students in kindergarten through 12th grade Chisago Lakes School District is a member of the Minnesota State High School League and is in Region 5A. The schools compete in the following sports: Cheerleading Cross Country Dance Team Football Gymnastics Soccer Basketball Ice Hockey Wrestling Golf Tennis Baseball Softball Lacrosse Track and Field Volleyball The school district also has a cooperative agreement with the North Branch School District for the purpose of allowing students from both districts to compete together in the sport of ice hockey. The team is known as the North Branch/Chisago Lakes Patriots, and the school they represent is called Chisago Lakes Community Education and Recreation Center (C.L.C.E.R.C.). In addition to sports, the school district also has a performing arts program. The performing arts program includes a marching band, a jazz band, a concert band, a choir, and a drama program.

Freedom Is a State of Mind "Freedom Is a State of Mind" is the title of a song by the American rock band Boston from their second studio album, Don't Look Back. It was released as the album's third single in 1986. The song reached number 64 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart and number 13 on the Mainstream Rock chart. The song's main riff is very similar to that of the song "Uncle Salty" from the band's first album, Boston. The music video for the song was directed by David Van Hoogenaten and was released in 1986. It features a man in a dark room, with a single spotlight, singing the song. The man is played by lead singer Brad Delp's brother, Jim Delp. The song was re-recorded by the band for their 2006 studio album, Boston VI: Live to Win, with the title "Freedom Is a State of Mind (Live to Win)". "Freedom Is a State of Mind" was the last song performed by Boston live, at the Hollywood RockWalk on September 1, 2007. In the liner notes of the 2000 Boston box set, Delp said of the song: "This was the last song we wrote for Don't Look Back. We needed one more song to round out the album, and this one just fell together in the studio. It's one of those songs that is what it is, and it's hard to analyze. I like the guitar work on it, and the chorus is very singable. It's one of those songs that, when we play it live, people just instinctively start singing along with it."

The Confederacy (British political group) was a political group active in the United Kingdom from the late 1970s until the early 1990s. It was formed in 1978 by a merger of the National Front (NF) with the British National Party (BNP), and was led by John Tyndall. The group was active in the National Front until the early 1990s, and played a significant role in the foundation and development of the British National Party. The NF had been established in 1967 by a group of former members of the British Union of Fascists (BUF), and had won two seats in the House of Commons in the 1979 general election. However, it had become divided into two factions, one of which was led by Tyndall, who favoured a more working-class approach. In 1980, the two factions merged, with the group that supported Tyndall's ideas forming the core of the new Confederacy. The Confederacy was opposed to the 'multi-cultural society' and believed that the NF's approach was too extreme. It sought to develop a more pragmatic approach, and focused its activities on the working class, arguing that the NF's middle-class support was insufficient to win power. It also sought to develop a more professional approach, and adopted the title 'The British Nationalist Party' for its electoral candidates. In 1981, it won three seats in the House of Commons, and in 1982 it won a further two seats. However, the Confederacy was also beset by internal divisions, and in 1983 it split into two factions, one of which was led by Tyndall, and the other by Andrew Brons. The two factions reunited in 1985, but the group remained unstable, and in 1990 it finally split into two separate groups, the British National Party and the British Democratic Party.

Mikel Laboa is a Spanish singer and musician, one of the most representative artists of the "New Basque Song" musical movement. Mikel Laboa was born in Ondarroa, Biscay, in 1967. His father, from Ondarroa, was a docker, and his mother, from Madrid, was a cleaner. They divorced when he was two years old, and his mother moved to Madrid with his older sister, while he and his younger brother stayed with their father. When he was six years old, he started playing the violin, but he soon abandoned it. Then, at the age of eight, he began to play the txalaparta, a traditional Basque percussion instrument. He was attracted to rock music, and at the age of 12, he started playing the electric guitar. He soon became the leader of a group of friends who played covers of songs by groups like the Rolling Stones, the Beatles, and the Who. When he was 14 years old, he started his first serious band, called Zingirikizuna (which means "We will not give in" in Basque). After three years of playing covers, they started to write their own songs in Basque. They soon had their first hits, which were played on the radio and at parties. When he was 18 years old, he left the band and started another one, called Guria. After two years, he went solo. He released his first album, Mikel Laboa, in 1991. In 1993, he released his second album, Irrintzi, which included the hit "Aupa Euskadi!" ("Hail Euskadi!"). In 1995, he released his third album, 35/3, which included the hit "Pari Pari Handia" ("Go Forward"). In 1997, he released his fourth album, Herria, which included the hit "Maiydia" ("You Are the One"). In 1999, he released his fifth album, Elkarlilari, which included the hit "Titulik" ("Titulary"). In 2001, he released his sixth album, Irrintzi II, which included the hit "Gure Irrintzi" ("Crown of Irrintzi"). In 2006, he released his seventh album, Suen Arrakastalik, which included the hit "Gatiburuko" ("Good Day"). In 2008, he released his eighth album, Garrahan Haurzaran, which included the hit "Haurzaran" ("Suckers"). In 2011, he released his ninth album, Korrontziak, which included the hit "Pizkatzekoekin" ("You Know How to Do It").

Hammana is a village in the Bint Jbeil District in southern Lebanon. It is located 42 kilometers (26 mi) south of Beirut. Hammana has an elevation of 1,210 meters (3,990 ft) above sea level and a total land area of 3,200 hectares (7,500 acres). The village is located in the south of the Beqaa Valley, between the Western and the Eastern Beqaa, and it is the highest village in the district. The name of the village is derived from the Aramaic word "Hamman" which means "bath" or "spa", referring to the many hot springs in the area. In the early 20th century, the German scholar Alois Musil described Hammana as a "place of delightful, clean air". During the 2006 Lebanon War, Hammana and the surrounding area were heavily damaged by Israeli airstrikes. The inhabitants of Hammana are Druze, with a small Christian minority. The village has one school, which had an enrollment of 130 students in the academic year 2008–2009. The villagers work in agriculture, including the growing of olives, grapes, almonds, and other fruits and vegetables. The village has a population of 2,500, the majority of them being elderly.

Seaman (dog) Seaman (born c. 1942 – 14 July 2004) was a black and white English Cocker Spaniel, the pet and companion of author Sir Arthur Conan Doyle. Seaman was a gift to Conan Doyle from his wife Jean in the early 1950s after the couple's other dog, a Fox Terrier named Jack, had died. Jean named the new puppy Seaman after the Liverpool FC goalkeeper, who had just won the FA Cup. Seaman is believed to have been born in March or April 1942, and was seven weeks old when he was acquired by the Doyles. He lived with the family for more than 12 years, and was a favourite of Doyle's two children, Mary and Richard. In his book, The Life of Arthur Conan Doyle, Michael Coren writes that the famous author, best known for his creation of the Sherlock Holmes detective, "loved this little dog, and would often take him on his daily walk along the cliffs at Southsea, and on journeys to London and elsewhere." Seaman is featured in a painting by the artist Arthur Liston, entitled The Quaint Old Sea-Side Town of Southsea, which was commissioned by Doyle's daughter, Mary. Liston also made a number of charcoal sketches of the dog, and these are now in the possession of Seaman's owner, Richard Lancelyn Green. After Doyle's death in July 1930, Seaman is believed to have been inherited by the author's daughter, Mary, and spent the rest of his life with her and her husband, the film and stage actor Dennis Lotis. Seaman died in July 2004 at the age of 62, and was buried in the garden of Mary and Dennis's home in Crowborough, East Sussex. A headstone was commissioned by Richard Lancelyn Green, and erected in 2006. It bears the following inscription: Good old Seaman, Good old faithful friend You shared our home, our table, our bed We bought you a collar, you wore a tag But you preferred your old rope to rags You were with us through thin and thick A member of the family, not just a pet When we could no longer keep you with us We found a loving home for you, it was the best we could do We said goodbye to you, our hearts were heavy But we knew you wouldn't suffer, and that you would be happy Good old Seaman, we will never forget you You were with us for twelve years, a loyal and devoted pet We will always remember you, and the joy you brought us A lovely, friendly, happy little dog.

Cynthia Teague (born Cynthia Ann Parker; November 30, 1964) is an American politician serving as the 42nd and current lieutenant governor of Wisconsin since January 2023. A member of the Democratic Party, she was previously the 48th secretary of state of Wisconsin from 2015 to 2019. Born and raised in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, Teague attended the University of Wisconsin–Madison. In 1987, she earned a bachelor's degree in political science and in 1988, she earned a master's degree in education. In 1992, she earned a second master's degree in public policy from the Harvard Graduate School of Public Policy. In 1993, Teague began working for U.S. Senator Herb Kohl as a legislative assistant, eventually becoming his chief of staff. In 2005, she was appointed Wisconsin's secretary of commerce by Governor Jim Doyle, and in 2007 was elected to a four-year term. Teague was secretary of the Department of Commerce until she was appointed secretary of state by Governor Scott Walker in January 2015, and was elected to that position in November 2014. In August 2018, Teague was selected by Walker as the lieutenant governor candidate for the 2018 Wisconsin gubernatorial election. She was elected to that position in November 2018, and assumed office on January 7, 2019. After Republican Governor Scott Walker's retirement, Teague was elected to a full term as lieutenant governor in the 2022 election. Teague is the first African-American and the first woman to hold the office of lieutenant governor in Wisconsin.

Washington Bach Consort The Washington Bach Consort is a non-profit organization that performs regularly at the Washington National Cathedral and other venues in Washington, D.C. It was founded in 1954 by J. Reilly Lewis, who was also its artistic director for over forty years. The consort has presented over 2,000 performances of Bach's cantatas and other works, including several complete cycles of the cantatas at the National Cathedral. In addition to its own concert series, the consort has appeared at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, the Library of Congress, and the Folger Shakespeare Library. It has also toured extensively, including appearances in New York City, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Chicago, and London. The consort's performances are known for their artistic quality and technical precision. It has been praised for its "exquisite musicality" and "iple coordination". The consort's musicians are some of the most highly sought after specialists in the field of Baroque music, and many have appeared as soloists with the nation's leading orchestras. In addition to its performing activities, the consort is also committed to education and outreach. It offers a variety of educational programs for children and adults, and it sponsors an annual scholarship competition for high school students. The consort also provides opportunities for young musicians to study and perform with its artists.

Mildred Cozzens Turner (March 3, 1918 – December 27, 2016) was an American artist and illustrator. Turner was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota in 1918. Her father, L. C. Cozzens, was a carpenter and her mother, Florence, was a housewife. She had one older brother, Lynn. The family lived in a house they built in the city. Turner attended South Side Elementary School and graduated from Lincoln High School in 1936. She then studied at the Minneapolis College of Art and Design for one year before transferring to the University of Minnesota, where she graduated with a bachelor's degree in art in 1940. After college, Turner worked as an illustrator for the advertising firm of Day/Ducellier in Minneapolis. In 1943, she married Clarence Turner, a doctor, and moved with him to Cleveland, Ohio. She worked for the Cleveland Plain Dealer as an illustrator until 1950, when she gave up full-time work to raise her three children. In 1964, she began working part-time as a medical illustrator at the Cleveland Clinic, a position she held for 20 years. Turner began painting in oils in the 1960s, and her work was exhibited locally. In the early 1980s, she began to gain wider recognition for her paintings of family and friends, and for her landscapes. She had a solo exhibition at the Cleveland Museum of Art in 1985, and her work was included in the museum's "Women's Eye" exhibition in 1996. Turner was a fellow of the Ohio Arts Council and a member of the American Watercolor Society, the Transparent Watercolor Society of America, and the National Watercolor Society. In 2007, Turner's work was included in the "Minneapolis College of Art and Design Century Show", which celebrated the college's 100th anniversary. Turner died at the age of 98 in 2016.

Curtis Staples (born May 30, 1950) is an American country singer-songwriter. Staples was born in Dyersburg, Tennessee, United States, and grew up in Memphis, Tennessee. He began his musical career after high school, singing in a band called The Tennessee Werewolves. The band enjoyed regional success, but broke up after its lead guitarist, Michael Verne, died in a car accident in 1984. In 1986, Staples began a solo career, signing a recording contract with Columbia Records. His debut album, Walkin' the Dog, was released that year, producing the minor hit "40 Years in Michigan." The album's title track, "Walkin' the Dog," peaked at No. 68 on the Billboard Hot Country Songs chart. A second album, Ten, was released in 1990. Staples's third album, No Disguise, was released in 1992. The title track, "No Disguise," was a minor hit on the country charts, and the album's first single, "You're Still on My Mind," peaked at No. 68. After the album's release, Staples's contract with Columbia Records was dropped, and he signed a new contract with Atlantic Records. Atlantic released his fourth album, State of the Heart, in 1995. In 1997, Staples joined the band, The Wilburys, as lead singer and guitarist. The Wilburys released two albums, The Wilbury Record and The Big Enchilada. In 1998, Staples's fifth solo album, Time Well Wasted, was released on the independent Last Call Records label. His most recent album, From the Heart, was released in 2007. Staples has recorded more than 150 songs, primarily on independent labels. Staples's musical style is influenced by country music singer-songwriter, John Hiatt.

Capell Bedell Capell Bedell (c.1626 – 15 April 1704) was an English academic, lawyer, and politician who sat in the House of Commons at various times between 1659 and 1704. Bedell was the son of William Bedell of London and of Lincoln's Inn, and his wife Mary. He was educated at Charterhouse School, London and St Paul's School, London, and was admitted to Lincoln's Inn on 4 November 1642. He was also admitted to Caius College, Cambridge, on 3 July 1650, where he was awarded LL.B. in 1653 and LL.M. in 1654. He was chosen as a Member of Parliament for the newly created constituency of Aldborough in 1659, and sat in the Third Protectorate Parliament. He was called to the bar on 12 February 1655. In 1661, he was elected MP for Dunwich in the Cavalier Parliament and sat until 1679. He was re-elected in 1681 and sat until 1704. He was a member of the Ancient Society of Lincoln's Inn and a fellow of the Royal Society. He died at his house in Chancery Lane on 15 April 1704 and was buried in the church of St. Dunstan-in-the-West. His will, dated 1703, was proved 26 April 1704. He left £100 to the poor of the parish of St. Dunstan, £20 to the poor of the parish of St. Andrew, and his books to the Bodleian Library.

Yang Yongliang (born September 1965) is a Chinese politician and the current chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of the Tibet Autonomous Region. Yang was born in Jianyang, Sichuan in September 1965. He joined the Chinese Communist Party in May 1986. He studied political economics at Southwest College of Finance and Economics. He was the director of the Political and Legal Committee of Meishan County, Sichuan province. In November 2007, he was appointed the secretary-general of the Sichuan Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China. In January 2008, he was promoted to the vice-secretary of the committee. In October 2010, he was appointed the director of the Sichuan Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China. In September 2013, he was appointed the vice-governor of Sichuan. In October 2016, he was appointed the secretary of the Sichuan Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China. In September 2017, he was appointed the director of the Political and Legal Committee of Sichuan. In May 2018, he was appointed the vice-governor of Sichuan. In June 2020, he was appointed the secretary of the Sichuan Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China. In September 2022, Yang was appointed the chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of the Tibet Autonomous Region.

Bharo Mazara is a village in the Dantewada district of the Indian state of Chhattisgarh. It is located in the Abhujmar hills of the northern Bastar region. The village is known for the ancient cave paintings in the hills nearby, the first of which was discovered in 1910 by a British officer, who happened to chance upon it during a hunting expedition. These paintings are estimated to be over 10,000 years old. Bharo Mazara is located in the Abujmar hills of the Bastar region in the state of Chhattisgarh, India. It is located approximately 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) from the town of Dantewada. The village is located on the banks of a stream called the Jonk. The area is rich in minerals. Along with the streams, the area is also rich in forest resources. The climate of the region is tropical. It experiences very hot summers with a temperature of 47 °C (117 °F). The winters are cooler with a temperature of 29 °C (84 °F). The average annual rainfall is approximately 1,800 millimetres (71 in). The population of the village is approximately 1,000. The literacy rate is low, at only 41 percent. The main occupation of the people is farming. The main crops are rice and corn. The village is known for its ancient cave paintings, which are estimated to be over 10,000 years old. The paintings are located in the hills nearby, the first of which was discovered in 1910 by a British officer who happened to chance upon it during a hunting expedition. The caves are home to numerous paintings, including images of people, animals, and utensils. The paintings are done in a variety of colours, including red, blue, green, and yellow. The village is also known for its traditional dance, the Karma.

26th New York Infantry Regiment The 26th New York Infantry Regiment, also known as the 1st Scotch Regiment, was a volunteer infantry regiment of the Union Army during the American Civil War, led by Colonel James Cameron. The regiment was mustered into the Union Army on May 14, 1861, at New York City. The regiment was mustered out on June 25, 1865. The regiment was recruited primarily from New York City, and was led by Colonel James Cameron, a well-known Scottish-born politician and journalist. The regiment, which was also known as the 1st Scotch Regiment, was particularly noteworthy for its large number of Scottish immigrants, many of whom were skilled veterans of the British and Canadian armies. The Scotch Regiment, as it was commonly known, was one of the most distinctively uniformed units in the Union Army, with its men wearing the Cameron tartan kilt, and a unique chest plate which was designed by the regiment's quartermaster, William C. Church. The 26th New York Infantry was mustered into the Union Army in May 1861, and left for Washington, D.C. in June. The regiment was first assigned to guard duty at the capital, where it stayed for a few weeks, and then was sent to join the Army of the Potomac in Northern Virginia. The 26th New York saw its first combat at the First Battle of Bull Run, and then took part in the Peninsula Campaign. The regiment was also present at the Battle of Antietam, the bloodiest day in American history. In early 1862, the 26th New York was given the honor of being the first regiment to march through the streets of Washington, D.C. in their Cameron tartan kilts. The regiment also fought at the Battle of South Mountain, and was one of the first units to enter the city of Frederick, Maryland, after the battle. The 26th New York then took part in the Battle of Antietam, where it suffered heavy casualties. In December 1862, the 26th New York was given the assignment of guarding the headquarters of the Army of the Potomac, and it stayed in that capacity for the rest of the war. The regiment was mustered out of the Union Army in June 1865.

Raman Sreeraman (born May 2, 1954) is an Indian Administrative Service officer and a writer from Kerala, India. He is the former managing director of the Cochin International Airport and the former additional private secretary to the Chief Minister of Kerala. Sreeraman was born in Thrissur, Kerala. He did his schooling at Raja's high school, Thripoonithura and graduation in physics from Christ College, Irinjalakuda. He joined the civil service as a member of the Kerala cadre of the Indian Administrative Service in 1978. He served in various positions in the state government as well as in the central government. He was the private secretary to the Chief Minister of Kerala from 1996 to 2001. He was the additional private secretary to the Chief Minister from 2001 to 2004 and the private secretary from 2004 to 2006. In 2006, he was appointed as the managing director of the Cochin International Airport. He served in that position until 2013. He is married to Mini Sreeraman, a civil servant and the current director of the Kerala State Higher Education Council. They have two daughters. Sreeraman is also a writer and a columnist. He has published a collection of short stories, a collection of poems and three novels. His column, "Raman's Ray", appears in The Hindu newspaper.

OpenCorporates is a database of companies and their corporate relationships, including their ultimate beneficial ownership. The database is open for anyone to use and is licensed under the Open Database License. The database is owned and operated by OpenCorporates Ltd, a private limited company incorporated in the United Kingdom. The database has information on over 100 million companies in over 200 jurisdictions. The data is sourced from official company registers, and the database is updated daily. OpenCorporates was founded in 2010 by Matthew Baynes and Michael Garg. The company was originally incorporated in the United States, with the original name Global Witness. In 2011, the company changed its name to OpenCorporates and re-incorporated in the United Kingdom. In 2013, OpenCorporates raised $1.7 million in venture capital funding from Index Ventures. In 2015, it raised a further $3.5 million from various investors, including the Omidyar Network. OpenCorporates has been described as the "largest open database of companies in the world". It is used by journalists, researchers, and anti-corruption activists to investigate and expose corporate wrongdoing, such as money laundering and tax evasion. In 2013, OpenCorporates was named as one of the 50 most innovative companies in the world by American business magazine Fast Company. In 2015, it was named as one of the world's most innovative companies in the "Data Science" category by the same magazine.

Brentford Library is a library in Brentford, London, England. It was built in 1962 and has been Grade II listed since 2009. Brentford Library was one of the first libraries in the country to offer an internet service for its users. In 1996, it received a grant from the New Opportunities Fund to install four computers and provide access to the internet. The library was closed for four months in 2007 and re-opened in 2008 after a major refurbishment. The library is located on the corner of Windmill Road and Boston Manor Road, opposite the London Waldorf School. It is a two-storey building with a concrete frame, a rendered frontage and a flat roof. The library is built on a corner site and has two faces, one facing Windmill Road and the other facing Boston Manor Road. There is a large window on the first floor facing Windmill Road, with a cantilevered concrete balcony with a glass balustrade. The entrance is on the ground floor, facing Boston Manor Road, and is marked by a large rectangular frame with a deep-set porch. There are two large concrete planters in front of the library, and the forecourt is paved with York stone. The interior of the library is divided into two main spaces on the ground floor. The space facing Boston Manor Road is a single-height reading room, with a central desk and a series of bookcases around the edges. The space facing Windmill Road is a double-height reference room, with a series of study carrels and computer terminals around the edges. The first floor is a single-height space, with a series of study carrels and computer terminals around the edges.

Black and White: Sidney Poitier's Emergence in the 1960s as a Black Icon The first African-American film star to win a Best Actor Oscar, Sidney Poitier (1927–2022) played a pivotal role in the emergence of Black icons in Hollywood films. He made his film debut in the 1950 film No Way Out, and his breakthrough came with his first leading role in the 1955 film Blackboard Jungle. His work as a civil rights activist and as a Bahamian citizen also played a role in the early 1960s movement for the independence of the Bahamian colony from the British Empire. In the early 1960s, Poitier's work as a film, stage, and television actor began to receive awards and critical acclaim, and he became the first African-American male to win a Golden Globe Award for Best Actor for his work in the 1964 film Lilies of the Field. His other major roles during this period included A Raisin in the Sun (1961), Pressure Point (1962), and In the Heat of the Night (1967). Poitier's emergence as a Black icon was influenced by several factors, including his personal life, his Bahamian citizenship, his civil rights activism, and his work in the arts. His work as an actor and as a citizen of the Bahamas helped to break down barriers for Black actors and to change the way Black people were portrayed in the media. His work as a civil rights activist helped to raise awareness about racial inequality and discrimination in the United States.

The Adventures of Bullwhip Griffin is a comedy western film directed by Louis Leterrier. The film stars Robert De Niro as the title character, a tall tale spinning, gun-toting, whiskey-guzzling, woman-chasing cowpoke who shoots first and asks questions later. The film also stars Michael Pare, Pat Riley, Daniel J. Travanti, and R. D. Call. The film was shot in Montana, United States. The film's opening theme song, "The Ballad of Bullwhip Griffin", was written and performed by Irish rock band The Pogues. In the film, Griffin is a "cowboy's cowboy", a man of few words who is fiercely independent, never taking orders, and who lives by his own moral code. As a child, he is shown to be very sensitive, and is greatly influenced by his mother, who teaches him that the world is a dangerous place and that he must be tough to survive. He is also shown to be very bright, having taught himself how to read and write. As an adult, Griffin becomes a legend in his own time, a man who has lived a life of adventure and who has become a symbol of the rugged individualist. He is shown to be a man of strong principles, who is loyal to his friends and who is always ready to fight for what he believes in. However, he is also shown to be a bit of a hothead, and is often quick to use his gun to settle disputes. The film follows Griffin as he travels through the American West, spinning his tall tales and living his life of adventure. Along the way, he meets a variety of characters, including a group of outlaws, a band of Indians, and a group of settlers.

Hocuspocus (1953 film) Hocuspocus is a 1953 British horror film, directed by Sidney Gilliat and starring Margaret Rutherford in the title role of a village witch. The film also features Michael Redgrave, Noel Howley, Robert Flemyng, and Dora Bryan. The film was produced by Michael Carreras for Hammer Film Productions. It was shot at the company's Bray Studios in Berkshire, England, and on location around the village of Bray and at nearby Windsor Castle. The film tells the story of a kindly witch, Aunt Charlotte, who is the victim of a plot by a pair of corrupt local officials, thesmooth-talking but evil Abner and his hunchbacked sidekick Simms, to obtain her wealth by means of a forged will. After they succeed in disposing of her, they are haunted by her ghost, who engineers a series of grisly murders. The film ends with the pair being burned at the stake. The film was not particularly well-received by critics or audiences on its original release, but has since become a cult film, and the final scene, with the two main villains being burned at the stake, was voted number 6 out of 50 in the American Film Institute's 100 Years... 100 Laughs special. In the United States, the film was released as a second feature to the 3-D film House of Wax. In Britain, it was given a Blu-ray release in 2012, with a commentary track by film historian Steve Jones. In 2018, a stage musical version of Hocuspocus, with book, music and lyrics by Matthew Warchus, was performed at the Old Vic theatre in London.

Hunted Hunted is a British television thriller series, produced by BBC Drama, which first aired on BBC One in 2015. The series was cancelled after two seasons. The series follows the story of a group of British citizens who are taken to a secret location somewhere in eastern Europe, and their struggle for survival when they realise that they are part of a deadly experiment. The first series began broadcasting on 10 October 2015 on BBC One, and the second series began broadcasting on 11 October 2016 on BBC One. The first series was shown in the United States on BBC America from 27 October 2015, with the second series beginning on 19 September 2016. Hunted is a co-production between the BBC and HBO. The series was cancelled after two seasons. The series is written and created by David Farr, and stars Hugh Dancy, Rosamund Pike, Fionnuala Flanagan, and Robert Carlyle. In the first series, the group of strangers are abducted from a London street in broad daylight, and wake up in a disused prison hospital in a hidden location somewhere in eastern Europe. They are told they are part of a group of British citizens who are to be "hunted" by a group of former Soviet-era special forces soldiers, and their goal is to survive the next 10 days. The hunters are led by a former British soldier, now a hunter, played by Ben Righton. In the second series, the hunters are forced to hunt a new group of abducted people, after the British government discover the existence of the programme, and put a stop to it. The British government's involvement is played by Tom Wu.

Bidens hyperborea is a species of flowering plant in the family Asteraceae, native to northern North America. It is an herbaceous perennial plant that can reach 100 cm (39 in) in height. The stems are generally unbranched, and the leaves are 20–40 cm (7.9–15.7 in) long and 10–20 cm (3.9–7.9 in) wide, with petioles generally 5–10 cm (2.0–3.9 in) in length. The flowers are produced in mid-summer, with the ray flowers being either yellow or white and the disc flowers being yellow. The fruit is a cypsela with paired pappi. The species is divided into two varieties, var. hyperborea and var. glandulosa. The latter is distinguished by its glandular disc flowers. Bidens hyperborea is widely distributed throughout Canada, the United States, and Greenland. It occurs in coastal areas, open moist meadows, and along streams. The species is found at high latitudes, but not at high elevations. It can survive in temperatures as low as −40 °C (−40.0 °F). Bidens hyperborea is a nectar source for bees and butterflies. The seeds are eaten by songbirds, and the caterpillars of Silvery Checkerspot (Sarangesa protea) feed on the leaves. Bidens hyperborea is a traditional medicinal plant used by the indigenous peoples of the Americas. The leaves are used as a poultice for wounds and as a tea for colds, while the roots are used for the same purposes, as well as for stomach and intestinal ailments. The seeds have been used as a coffee substitute. The species was first described by Linnaeus in 1753 as Bidens hyperborea. It was later lumped into Bidens pilosa, but has since been restored to its own species.

Kalki Jayanti Kalki Jayanti is an annual festival observed in India, celebrating the birthday of Lord Vishnu's avatar Kalki, who is yet to appear. The festival is observed on the last Friday of the Hindu month of Bhadrapada, which falls between August and September. The festival is also known asGrey Thursday, as the day is marked by fasting and a day-long silence by the devotees. The fast is broken after sunset with the offering of an orange flag to the deity. Devotees offer special prayers and perform aarti. A feast is then served. The festival is observed by several communities, including the Vaishnava community, in India. It is primarily observed in the states of Karnataka, Maharashtra, Gujarat, and Telangana. It is also observed by the Telugu community in the state of Andhra Pradesh. In the state of Maharashtra, the festival is observed by the family of the 18th century saint, and the founder of the Pushtimarg sect, Gopalan Bhatta, at the Gopalan Bhatta Math in Maharashtra. The festival is also observed by the families of other Pushtimarg saints, such as the family of Santa Rampaul at the Santa Rampaul Math in Richardson, Texas, United States. In the state of Gujarat, the festival is observed at the Swaminarayan Temple in Rajkot. In the state of Karnataka, the festival is observed at the Sri Basaveshwara shrine in the village of Avani in the state of Karnataka, and at the Sri Kalishvara temple in the village of Kollur in the state of Karnataka. In the state of Telangana, the festival is observed at the Bhakti Aggies Resource Center in the city of Hyderabad.

Jamie Driscoll (born 3 September 1983) is an English stand-up comedian and actor. Driscoll was born in Newcastle upon Tyne, England. He studied drama at college and then took a degree in film and television studies at the University of Westminster. He began performing stand-up in 2007, and in 2008 was a finalist in the Chortle Student Comedy Awards. In 2011, he was a runner-up in the AmusedMoose Laugh-off, and won the Comedy Cafe's New Act of the Year competition. He was also runner-up in the BBC New Comedy Awards, and was placed in the final of the English Comedian of the Year competition. In 2012, he performed at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe with his show, "The Things We Did For Love", which received a number of positive reviews. In 2013, Driscoll performed at the Fringe with his show "The Machine", which received good reviews from The Guardian and Chortle. He also performed at the Dave Meets... showcase at the Fringe. In 2014, he performed at the Fringe with his show "Thank You for the Music", which received positive reviews from The Independent and The Scotsman. Driscoll has written for BBC Radio 4's The News Quiz and The Now Show, and has acted in the BBC sitcom Hebburn.

Joseph M. Warren (August 24, 1870 – July 25, 1938) was an American politician who served as a member of the United States House of Representatives from New York from 1895 to 1901, and again from 1911 to 1913. Warren was born in Boston, Massachusetts, and attended the public schools. He graduated from Harvard University in 1892, and then from the law department of Columbia University in 1895. He commenced the practice of law in New York City, and also engaged in literary and newspaper work. He was a member of the New York State Assembly (New York Co., 14th D.) in 1899. In 1900, Warren was the author of a book, The Banded Land: A Romance of the War of 1812, which was reviewed as "a work of great ability, and one which will take its place as a historical authority." Warren was elected as a Democrat to the 54th and 55th United States Congresses, serving from March 4, 1895, to March 3, 1901. He was an unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1900 to the 56th Congress. In 1910 he was again elected to the 59th Congress, and served from 1911 to 1913. He was an unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1912 to the 60th Congress. After leaving Congress, he resumed the practice of law. He died in New York City on July 25, 1938, and was buried in Mount Hope Cemetery, Boston.

Televisa Deportes is a division of the Mexican multimedia company Televisa, S.A., dedicated to the production and broadcast of sports events and programs. It has exclusive television rights to the Mexico national football team, the Mexican league and the Apertura and Clausura tournaments.
