Final Doom is a first-person shooter video game developed by id Software and published by GT Interactive in 1996. It was originally titled Final Doom: Hell on Earth. It is the second expansion pack for the video game Doom II, and the last release in the Doom series developed by id Software. The game was also the first Doom game to be developed by id Software since they had been acquired by GT Interactive. Final Doom is unique in the fact that, unlike the previous Doom games, it contains a single-player campaign in addition to its multiplayer modes. The plot of Final Doom is set some time after the events of Doom II. The player assumes the role of a space marine named Doom Guy, who is sent to Earth to stop the Nazi-like Hell Knights from taking over the planet. The game features a variety of new weapons and enemies, as well as new multiplayer modes such as 4-player deathmatch. The development of Final Doom began shortly after the release of Doom II. The game was developed by a small team of id Software employees, with the company's co-owner and CEO, John Carmack, serving as the lead designer and lead programmer. The game's development was completed in approximately six months, with a budget of approximately $1 million. Final Doom was released in September 1996, and received positive reviews from critics. The game's single-player campaign was praised for its variety and depth, while the multiplayer modes were praised for their intensity and fun. The game's graphics and sound were also praised, although some reviewers criticized the game's short length. In the years since its release, Final Doom has been re-released several times, including a re-release as part of the Doom 3: BFG Edition compilation in 2012, and a port to the Nintendo Switch in 2019. The game's multiplayer modes have also been re-released as a standalone game, titled Final Doom: Double Impact, and a mobile game based on the game, titled Final Doom: Pocket Edition, has also been released.

Goldfinger is a 1964 British spy film directed by Guy Hamilton and produced by Harry Saltzman and Albert R. Broccoli. The third film in the James Bond series, it was the first to feature the character of Goldfinger, played by Gert Fröbe, and the first to use the name James Bond. The film also introduced the concept of the Bond girl. The film was based on the novel Goldfinger by Ian Fleming, who also wrote the screenplay. The story centres on the investigation by the British Secret Service, led by agent 007 James Bond, into the disappearance of several scientists involved in the space programme. The main suspect is the German-Jewish scientist Dr. Goldfinger, played by Gert Fröbe, who is suspected of using a laser-like device to kill the scientists as part of a plan to steal their research for his own personal gain. Bond's mission is to prevent Goldfinger from achieving his goals and to discover what has happened to the scientists. The film was shot in London, Miami, and the Bahamas. The film's score was composed by John Barry and the theme song, "Goldfinger", performed by Shirley Bassey, became a popular standard. Goldfinger was well-received by critics and was the highest-grossing film of the year in the United States. It was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Original Song for "Goldfinger", and for the Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song for the same track, winning the Grammy Award for Best Original Score Written for a Motion Picture or Television Show. In 2000, it was selected as the second greatest film of all time by the American Film Institute, as part of their 100 Years... 100 Laughs special. In 2011, Goldfinger was also ranked the second best film of all time by the British Film Institute. In 2015, the film was selected for screening in the Royal Film Performance Programme to mark the 50th anniversary of the film's release. In 2017, Goldfinger was selected for screening in the BFI's James Bond cinema season to mark the 60th anniversary of the film's release.

Lowell Frazer (November 25, 1928 – February 8, 2018) was an American singer, musician, and actor, known for his work with the rock band The Oak Ridge Boys and his role as Mayor George Shinn in the television series The Andy Griffith Show. Frazer was born in 1928 in Knoxville, Tennessee, the son of Lela (Hobbs) and Foster Frazer. His family moved to Oak Ridge, Tennessee, in 1940, when his father went to work for the atomic energy facility at Oak Ridge National Laboratory. Frazer began his musical career in 1947, playing guitar in a band called The Tennessee Ridge Runners. In 1949, the band changed its name to The Oak Ridge Boys, and in 1950, they signed a recording contract with King Records. The group's first single, "Jesus Is Coming Soon", was released in January 1951, and became their first hit, peaking at number 13 on the Billboard country charts. In 1952, the band's lineup changed, with guitarist Billy Cox joining the group and original member Jack Ross leaving. The new lineup, consisting of Frazer, Cox, James General Ike Powell, and Willie Williams, remained together for more than two decades, and recorded more than 20 albums. Frazer played the role of Mayor George Shinn in all six seasons of The Andy Griffith Show, from 1960 to 1968. He also appeared in an episode of the TV series Gunsmoke in 1961, and in the films The Great American Hero (1974) and The Apple Dumpling Gang (1975). In addition to his work with The Oak Ridge Boys and his acting career, Frazer was also a successful songwriter, with his compositions recorded by a number of country music artists, including Johnny Cash, George Jones, and Webb Pierce. Frazer died on February 8, 2018, at the age of 89, following a brief hospitalization.

Karl Stromberg is a fictional character of the German author Arthur Moeller van den Bruck. In Moeller's novel Der Dritte, Karl Stromberg is a German World War I veteran who is deeply embittered by the war and the loss of his friends. He becomes a engineer and establishes a small factory. As the novel progresses, Stromberg's increasing success and wealth does not make him happy. At the end of his life, he seeks to give all his money to the poor, but his efforts are thwarted by the German government. In Moeller's sequel, Der Vierte, Stromberg is a friend of the protagonist Paul, and helps him with his plan to bring down the German government by spreading counterfeit money. In the post-war novel, Germany's Guilt (Das schwarze Buch), Karl Stromberg is the chief engineer of a secret weapons project (the title of the novel alludes to the black book that the Americans wrote after World War II to document German war crimes). The project is code-named "Life." It is supposed to create a flying bomb that can destroy whole cities. The project is halted by the German surrender in May 1945, and all the documents are destroyed. In the novel The New World (Der Nächste), Karl Stromberg appears as the leader of a secret society that seeks to create a new, just world order. The society's headquarters is an island in the South Pacific.

TUM Department of Civil, Geo and Environmental Engineering The TUM Department of Civil, Geo and Environmental Engineering is one of the seven departments of the TUM Campus Munich. With eight institutes, it is one of the largest civil engineering departments in Germany. The department's activities cover the entire spectrum of civil, geotechnical and environmental engineering. The department was formed in 2002 by the merger of the Department of Civil Engineering and the Institute of Geo and Environmental Engineering. The institute, in turn, had been founded in 1965 as the "Institute for Soil Mechanics and Foundation Engineering" and was renamed "Institute of Geo and Environmental Engineering" in 1993. The Department of Civil Engineering was established in 1968. The department's main areas of activity are: - Basic and applied research in the field of civil, geotechnical and environmental engineering - Teaching courses in civil, geotechnical and environmental engineering - Providing services in the field of civil, geotechnical and environmental engineering The department's research activities are focused on the following areas: - Solid and fluid mechanics - Soil mechanics and foundation engineering - Hydraulics, hydrology and hydraulic engineering - Environmental engineering and chemistry The department's research projects are funded by the German Research Foundation (DFG), the Federal Ministry of Science and Education (BMBF), the Federal Ministry of Economics and Technology (BMWi), the European Commission, and other national and international agencies. In the field of civil engineering, the department's activities include the development of new building materials, the optimization of building structures, the design of innovative construction methods, the structural analysis of existing buildings, and the investigation of the behavior of structures under extreme loads. In the field of geotechnical engineering, the department's activities include the study of soil mechanics, the behavior of foundations, the design of geotechnical structures, and the investigation of the interaction between structures and the ground. In the field of environmental engineering, the department's activities include the study of water and wastewater treatment, the management of solid and hazardous wastes, the control of air pollution, the remediation of contaminated soil and groundwater, and the development of sustainable environmental management strategies. The department's research activities are supported by a number of laboratories, including the Laboratory for Soil Mechanics, the Laboratory for Hydraulics and Hydrology, the Laboratory for Environmental Chemistry, and the Laboratory for Geomatics. The department offers a range of courses in civil, geotechnical and environmental engineering at the bachelor's, master's, and doctoral levels. In addition, the department offers a number of continuing education programs for professionals. The department's graduates are in high demand in the job market, and many go on to work in leading engineering firms, government agencies, and research institutions. The department's alumni include a number of prominent engineers, scientists, and entrepreneurs.

North Cape Tunnel The North Cape Tunnel (Nordkapptunnellen) is a road tunnel in Nordkapp municipality in Troms county, Norway. The tunnel is part of the European route E69 highway and it connects the village of Skipsfjord to the north and west with the town of Honningsvåg to the south and east. The tunnel was built between 1998 and 2000 and was officially opened on 11 June 2000. The cost of the tunnel was NOK 182 million. The tunnel is 3.45 km long, and it is the second longest in Troms county. The tunnel is located under the Magerøya island, and it bypasses the North Cape (Kapp Nord) to the west. The highest point in the tunnel is 120 metres (390 ft) above sea level. The North Cape Tunnel is a toll tunnel, and the toll is NOK 45 for cars and NOK 180 for trucks. In 2007, the tunnel had an average daily traffic of 1,192 vehicles. The maximum speed in the tunnel is 80 kilometres per hour (50 mph). The North Cape Tunnel is part of a project to build a new highway from Skibotn to North Cape. The first part of the project was the Skibotn–Storkaaset highway, which opened in 1979. The second part was the Storkaaset–Nessebygda highway, which opened in 1986. The North Cape Tunnel was the third and final part of the project. The North Cape Tunnel was the first toll road in Norway to be equipped with an electronic toll collection system.

Frank Budd (born August 20, 1945) is an American former professional football player who was a running back in the National Football League (NFL) for four seasons, from 1968 to 1971. A native of Detroit, Michigan, Budd attended Eastern High School and played college football at the University of Washington in Seattle. He was the leading rusher on the Huskies' 1967 team that won the Pacific-8 Conference championship and played in the 1968 Rose Bowl. In three seasons at Washington, Budd gained 2,008 yards and scored 18 touchdowns, including a 96-yard run in 1967 that remains the longest touchdown run in school history. Budd was selected in the first round of the 1968 NFL Draft by the Los Angeles Rams, the 11th overall pick. He was the second running back selected, behind Mel Renfro of the University of Oregon. In four seasons with the Rams, Budd gained 1,325 yards and scored 48 touchdowns, including 13 in 1970. His best season was in 1969, when he led the team with 773 yards and scored 11 touchdowns. He also led the NFL that year in yards per carry with 5.2. In 1970, he was the Rams' offensive captain and a Pro Bowl selection. Budd was traded to the San Diego Chargers in 1972, but did not appear in any games for them due to a knee injury. He retired from football after sitting out the 1973 season. In his four seasons in the NFL, Budd appeared in 59 games and gained 1,325 yards on 337 carries with 48 touchdowns. He also caught 37 passes for 368 yards and two touchdowns. After his retirement from football, Budd became a broadcaster. He was the color commentator for the Rams' radio broadcasts from 1972 to 1974 and the San Diego Chargers' radio broadcasts from 1975 to 1977. He also was a sports anchor for San Diego television station KGTV-10. Budd is the uncle of former NFL safety and punter Terrence Johnson, who played for the Seattle Seahawks and Kansas City Chiefs.

Conor Parke (born 6 September 1981) is an Irish professional golfer. Parke was born in Dublin, Ireland. He had a successful amateur career, winning the Irish Amateur Close Championship in 2000, and the West of Ireland Championship in 2001. He turned professional in 2002 and has spent much of his career playing on lower tier tours, including the European Tour's Challenge Tour, where he has won three times, and the PGA Tour's Nationwide Tour, where he has won once. His best finish on the European Tour was a T-5 at the 2007 BMW International Open. Parke's one victory on the Nationwide Tour came at the 2004 Mark Christopher Charity Classic, where he defeated Brandt Jobe in a playoff. Parke played on the PGA Tour in 2008, making 13 of 28 cuts and finishing outside the top 125 on the money list, which meant that he would not retain his card for the following season. In 2009, Parke played on the Nationwide Tour, where he made 18 of 26 cuts and finished 44th on the money list. He also finished T-2 at the BMW International Open on the European Tour. He finished T-3 at the 2010 BMW International Open, two shots behind winner Richard Green.

Tangzhuang is a type of Chinese jacket, typically made of silk and lined with fur. The term tangzhuang (Chinese: 冠裙; pinyin: guāngqun) literally means "jacket and skirt", and the jacket is usually worn with a skirt, over a full-sleeved shirt. The tangzhuang is a relatively new type of garment; it only appeared during the late Ming dynasty and the early Qing dynasty, when it was worn by the Joseon dynasty of Korea. The tangzhuang is a tight-fitting, button-up jacket, often lined with fur on the inside. The jacket is similar to the Chinese court jacket, but is usually made of silk, while the court jacket is made of brocade. The tangzhuang is usually worn with a skirt, but can also be worn with pants. In Korea, the tangzhuang is called a magua (Korean: 마구아; Hanja: 冠裙; literally "jacket and skirt"), and was a popular garment during the Joseon dynasty. The magua is a representative garment of the Joseon period, and was worn by both men and women. The tangzhuang is often associated with the qipao, and is similar to the Japanese kimono.

Thomas Radford (1583 – c. 1635) was an English lawyer and academic, a professor of civil law at the University of Oxford, and a member of the Virginia Company of London. Radford was born in London in 1583, the son of William Radford, a Citizen of London and cloth factor, and his wife Jane (or Joan) Smith, the daughter of Thomas Smith, a Citizen of London and woolen draper. His father was from a family of great antiquity in the county of Essex, and his mother was the daughter of a Citizen of London and woolen draper. He was educated at Merchant Taylors' School, Northwood, where he was a scholar from 1597 to 1600, and at St Paul's School, London, where he was a scholar from 1600 to 1601. He was awarded a Bachelor of Civil Law from the University of Oxford in 1606, a Master of Civil Law in 1611, and a Doctor of Civil Law in 1615. He was admitted to the Middle Temple in 1606 and was called to the bar in 1611. He was a member of the Virginia Company of London, and an investor in the colony of Jamestown, Virginia. He was appointed a professor of civil law at the University of Oxford in 1612, and was dean of the faculty of law from 1634 until his death. He was also a fellow of All Souls College, Oxford. He died in about 1635, and was buried in the cloisters of Lincoln Cathedral, where a monument to his memory was erected by his widow, Eleanor. Radford married three times. His first wife, Ann, died in 1625. His second wife, Mary, died in 1631. His third wife, Eleanor, survived him. There were no children from any of the marriages.

Venosa Venosa (Salentino: Venausa) is a town and comune in the province of Taranto, Apulia, southern Italy. The town is believed to have been founded by the Messapii, an ancient population of Apulia. In the 4th century BC, it was conquered by the Romans and was a thriving city, as testified by the numerous coins from the period. In the 9th century, it became the capital of the Lombard gastaldate of nearby Manduria. The city has a medieval nucleus, with a series of Baroque buildings, including theilt of the counts of Manduria, the 16th century cathedral, the 16th century palazzo De Marchi (now the seat of the cultural foundation "Casa del Mantegna"), the 18th century palazzo Gallucci, the 18th century palazzo De Nardis (with its interrupting curve along the city's main street) and the 19th century basilica of San Michele. The economy is based on agriculture (olive oil, wine, table grapes, kiwifruit, artichokes), fishing and tourism. In the area of Venosa, a type of cheese, named Ragusano, has been produced since the 19th century. In the second half of the 19th century, the city became a centre of the sulfur industry, with the opening of several mines in the nearby Salento peninsula. The industry expanded during the early 20th century, but went into decline by the 1950s, when most mines were closed.

Our Lady of Mercy's Chapel Our Lady of Mercy's Chapel is a Catholic chapel on the campus of the College of Mount Saint Vincent in the Riverdale neighborhood of the Bronx, New York. The chapel was built in 1898 and dedicated to Our Lady of Mercy in 1900. The chapel's architect was Arthur Crooks, who designed a number of Christian churches in New York City. Its interior was designed by the Tiffany Studios. The chapel's ceiling is made of hundreds of square glass panels, each of which is painted with a different religious image. The chapel's main stained glass window is of Our Lady of Mercy. The window was donated by the local parish of Our Lady of Mercy in the Riverdale neighborhood of the Bronx. The chapel's altar and confessionals were carved from oak by the Gariel Studio of New York City. The chapel is built in the Gothic Revival style, specifically in the French Gothic style as interpreted by the architect James Renwick, who designed St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York City and the Smithsonian Castle in Washington, D.C. The chapel's organ was manufactured by the Aeolian Company of New York City. The chapel was designated a New York City Historic Landmark in 2006.

Fantastic Wounds In his book The Fantastic Tradition in British and American Literature, D.C. Drotner defines the fantastic as "an unusual, extraordinary, or bizarre event, circumstance, or effect within a narrative that is both credible and unbelievable, and that is used to heighten a reader's sense of dissonance and delight". The fantastic can be found in many genres, including fantasy, horror, mystery, suspense, and science fiction. It is often associated with the concept of the Uncanny. The word "fantastic" derived from the Greek phantastikos (fanta-, " imaginations" + -astikos, "able to make visible") was first used in the 17th century to describe the imagination, and it took on its more modern sense of "unusual and incredible" in the 18th century. In contemporary usage, the term fantastic is sometimes used to describe something that is wonderful or impressive. Fantastic wounds are common in fantastic fiction. They are often used to heighten the sense of disbelief and delight, and to emphasize the Uncanny. A fantastic wound is an injury that would be impossible or highly unusual in the real world, such as a hole in the chest that does not bleed, a missing limb that can be reattached, or a wound that is not fatal. Fantastic wounds are often used to mark the boundary between the real world and the world of the fantastic. In some cases, fantastic wounds can be used to heal the victim, as in the case of a character who is wounded in a fantastic way and then healed by a fantastic means. In his essay "On the Fantastic", Jorge Luis Borges discusses the relationship between the real world and the fantastic. He notes that the fantastic is often associated with the Uncanny, and that both the fantastic and the Uncanny can be used to create a feeling of dissonance. Borges also discusses the relationship between the fantastic and the real, and how the fantastic can be used to reveal the real. For example, a story about a character who is wounded in a fantastic way can be used to show the reader the real world through the lens of the fantastic.

Army Group Liguria (German: Heeresgruppe Ligurien) was a German army group active in Italy from September 1944 to May 1945. It was responsible for defending the region of Liguria, in particular the city of Genoa, from the Allied advance into Italy. It was one of three German army groups that operated in Italy at the end of the war, the others being Army Group C and Army Group Adriatic. The army group was formed on 24 September 1944 from the Ligurian Army (Licturien), which had been formed on 15 September 1944 from the 3rd Mountain Division. The Ligurian Army was placed under the command of General der Infanterie (Lieutenant General) Anton Dostler, who had previously commanded the 3rd Mountain Division. The army group's main formation was the Ligurian Army, which was composed of the 1st and 2nd Mountain Divisions. The 1st Mountain Division was responsible for the coastal sector, while the 2nd Mountain Division was responsible for the inland sector. The army group also had a number of smaller units, including the 4th SS Police Division, the 1st Naval Coast Artillery Battalion, the 1st Naval Construction Battalion, and the 2nd Pionier Battalion. The army group was responsible for defending the region of Liguria, in particular the city of Genoa, from the Allied advance into Italy. It was one of three German army groups that operated in Italy at the end of the war, the others being Army Group C and Army Group Adriatic. The army group was disbanded on 5 May 1945.

South Gare Lighthouse The South Gare Lighthouse is an active lighthouse located on the South Gare breakwater in the River Tees, England. The lighthouse, completed in 1895, is Grade II listed and is still in use, having been automated in 1976. The lighthouse is built on the South Gare breakwater, a 1.6 km (1 mi) long stone breakwater on the south bank of the River Tees, and was the last lighthouse to be built by the Tees Navigation Company, which was taken over by the Tees and Hartlepool Port Authority in 1892. The breakwater was built to provide shelter for the port of Middlesbrough and to allow ships to navigate the tricky channel of the river. The lighthouse is built in the Victorian style, and is constructed of local stone. The original light was a paraffin lamp, which was replaced in 1932 by an incandescent light. The light was further upgraded in 1963, when it was converted to electricity. The light is mounted on a cantilevered balcony, with a white lantern house, and emits a white flash every five seconds. The light has a range of 17.4 km (10.8 mi) and is visible up to 16 km (10 mi) inland. The lighthouse is featured in the logo of the Cleveland Scientific Institute, and has been the subject of several paintings and photographs.

UEFA Women's Euro 2017 was the 12th edition of the UEFA Women's Championship, the quadrennial international football championship organized by UEFA for the national teams of Europe. The competition was expanded to include a total of 16 teams; it was previously contested by eight teams, and took place in the Netherlands from 16 July to 6 August 2017. The Netherlands defeated Denmark 4–2 in the final to win their first title, while the Czech Republic finished third after defeating Sweden 2–1 in the third place play-off. The eight group winners and eight group runners-up qualified directly for the tournament, while the eight remaining teams played in the play-offs to determine the remaining eight participants. A record 46 nations entered the competition, up from 42 in the previous tournament. The hosts were selected from a list of countries that had expressed interest in hosting the event, and the Netherlands were chosen in September 2014, following the 2014 FIFA World Cup. The Netherlands had previously hosted the European Championship twice, in 1984 and 2000, and the tournament was organised by the Royal Dutch Football Association (KNVB). The final tournament was contested by 16 teams, divided into four groups of four teams. The top two teams in each group advanced to the quarter-finals, and the four quarter-finalists qualified for the FIFA Women's World Cup in 2019. ## Qualified teams A total of 46 UEFA nations entered the competition, up from 42 in the previous tournament. The eight quarter-finalists from the 2015 tournament qualified automatically, while the remaining 38 nations competed in the qualifying competition to determine the other eight finalists. The eight teams were divided into two groups, with the top two teams in each group qualifying for the final tournament. In the qualifying group stage, teams played each other once at a draw conducted at the UEFA headquarters in Nyon, Switzerland on 23 January 2014. The eight semi-finalists qualified directly for the final tournament, and the eight teams eliminated in the quarter-finals played in the play-offs to determine the remaining eight finalists. ### Final tournament * Notes The following 16 teams qualified for the final tournament. | Previous best performance | Country | Appearance (from 1971) | FIFA ranking 17 June 2017 | | --

R. Thyagarajan (born January 3, 1942) is an Indian film director, producer, actor, and distributor who has worked in the Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam, and Hindi film industries. He has directed over 40 films and has produced and distributed films in Tamil and Hindi. He has also acted in a number of films. Thyagarajan was born in Madurai, Tamil Nadu, to a Tamil father and a Telugu mother. After completing a bachelor's degree in economics at Presidency College, Chennai, he went to the United States to study at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, where he graduated with a master's degree in economics. He then worked as a computer scientist for three years at the University of Illinois, Chicago, before returning to India in 1975 to enter the film industry. Thyagarajan began his film career as an actor, working as a protagonist in a number of Tamil films, including the critically acclaimed films Neethikku node vantha and Thee (1981). He also worked as an actor in a few Telugu and Malayalam films, but after starring in the 1983 Hindi film Himmat, he turned his attention to directing and producing. His directorial debut was the Tamil film Veetula Raman Velila Krishna (1984). He then went on to direct the successful film Rajadhi Raja (1987), which was remade in Hindi as Dilwaale (1994). He also directed the 1991 film Pavunnu Pavunuthan, which was voted the best film of the year by the readers of the Tamil magazine Ananda Vikatan. In addition to directing and producing, Thyagarajan has also distributed films in Tamil and Hindi, including the 1999 film Hello, which was a critical and commercial success.

The Defiant Ones The Defiant Ones is a 1986 American television film about two escaped prisoners who are forced to rely on each other to survive the wilderness. The film was directed by Michael Tuchner and stars Michael Landon, Richard Widmark, Robert Prosky, and Swoosie Kurtz. The film was shot on location throughout Canada. The film's title refers to the story's main theme of the two escapees who, despite their differences, are forced to "depend on each other to survive both the elements and the pursuing authorities." The film was nominated for four Emmy Awards and won two, including Outstanding Miniseries. The Defiant Ones is based on the story of two escaped convicts, Robert "Butch" Stewart (Landon) and David "Clem" Powell (Prosky), who are on the run from a maximum-security prison. The film follows their journey as they try to make it through the wilderness and avoid being captured by the authorities. Along the way, they are forced to rely on each other for survival, and their relationship grows and changes as they face various challenges and obstacles. The film also stars Richard Widmark as the obsessed prison warden, Swoosie Kurtz as the warden's daughter, and Michael Parks as the convict's escaped partner. The film was shot on location throughout Canada, including in the provinces of Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, and Ontario. The film's production budget was $8 million. The Defiant Ones was released on May 5, 1986, and aired on the CBS television network. The film received positive reviews, and was nominated for four Emmy Awards and won two, including Outstanding Miniseries.

John De Peyster Douw was born on December 17, 1843, in New York City, to a family of Dutch descent. His father, Elisha Augustus Douw, was a wealthy businessman and owner of the E. A. Douw & Co. dry goods firm. The family lived in a brownstone at 9 East 63rd Street in the Upper East Side, and also had a country estate, Cragston, in Fishkill, New York. Douw attended New York Public School No. 29 on East 61st Street and the private school Columbia College Grammar School. He entered Harvard College in the fall of 1861, where he joined the Porcellian Club. He graduated from Harvard in 1865, and then attended Harvard Law School, graduating in 1868. He joined his father's business, and the firm was thereafter known as E. A. Douw & Son. In 1873, Douw married Mary Stillman, daughter of James Stillman, founder of the First National City Bank (now Citibank). They had four children: Mary (1879–1933), James (1880–1968), John De Peyster Jr. (1882–1967), and Katherine (1884–1975). The Douws' country estate, Cragston, was designed by the architect Alexander Jackson Davis, and the couple also maintained a residence in New York City. In New York, they were members of the Union Club and the Knickerbocker Club. In Fishkill, they were members of the Fishkill Golf Club, the West Mountain Lake Club, and the Country Club of Fishkill. During World War I, Douw was chairman of the New York City Committee on National Defense. In 1926, he was one of the founders of the Harvard Club of New York City. Douw died at his New York City home on December 9, 1927. He was survived by his wife, Mary, and their four children, as well as by two brothers and two sisters.

Russian Fascism: Traditions, Tendencies, Movements Russian fascism is a far-right ideology which developed in the early 20th century in the Russian Empire and the Soviet Union. Russian fascism was influenced by Italian Fascism, German Nazism, and Russian Orthodoxy. Russian fascism is a complex phenomenon, and its development has been influenced by the traditions of the Russian Empire, the Soviet Union, and the Russian Republic. The ideology has been a driving force in the Russian Far-Right, and has also influenced the Russian Orthodox Church and Russian nationalism. In the early 20th century, Russian fascism emerged as a reaction to the Russian Revolution and the Soviet Union. The ideology was influenced by the Italian Fascism of Benito Mussolini and the German Nazism of Adolf Hitler. The Russian fascists opposed the Soviet Union, and sought to create a Russian Empire which would be a Third Rome. In the post-war era, Russian fascism was a significant force in the Russian diaspora, and was responsible for a number of terrorist attacks. In the 1980s, Russian fascism became a major force in the Soviet Union, and played a key role in the collapse of the Soviet Union. After the fall of the Soviet Union, Russian fascism became a significant force in the Russian Federation, and has been a driving force in the Russian Far-Right. In the 21st century, Russian fascism has been a major force in the Russian diaspora, and has also influenced the Russian Orthodox Church and Russian nationalism. Russian fascism has been described as a "latecomer" to the far-right, and as such it did not emerge as a significant force until the 1980s. It has also been described as a "micro-fascism", as it has not been a major force in the Russian Federation. However, Russian fascism has been a significant force in the Russian diaspora, and has been responsible for a number of terrorist attacks. In the 21st century, Russian fascism has been a major force in the Russian Orthodox Church and Russian nationalism.

Ruth Cardoso (born July 10, 1930) is a Brazilian writer, anthropologist, and educator. She is the widow of the former Brazilian president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, and was First Lady of Brazil from 1995 to 2002. Cardoso was born in 1930 in Rio de Janeiro, the daughter of a businessman and a teacher. She studied anthropology at the National Museum of Brazil and the University of Brazil. She later became a professor of anthropology at the latter institution. She also studied sociology at the Escola Nacional de Pesquisa e Pós-Graduação in Rio de Janeiro. In addition to her academic work, Cardoso has published several books on anthropology and sociology, including The House of the Devil: The Life and Times of a Brazilian Slave Family (1994), which was a finalist for the National Book Award. She has also written for The New York Times, The Washington Post, and other publications. Cardoso was married to Fernando Henrique Cardoso from 1961 until his death in 2008. She is the mother of the writer and diplomat Sérgio CCD (born 1962), the photographer Pedro Baby (born 1965), and the economist paths (born 1966). She is the daughter of pt:Mário Soeiro da Silva (1898–1977), a businessman and pt:Dra. Nenê de Souza Ferraz (1898–1994), a teacher.

Arthur Irving Gates (October 21, 1898 – September 13, 1983) was an American chemist, researcher, and educator who played a significant role in the field of spectroscopy. Born in Omaha, Nebraska, Gates attended the University of Nebraska, where he received a bachelor's degree in 1921 and a master's degree in 1922. He then moved to the University of Wisconsin, where he earned his Ph.D. in 1923. He joined the faculty at Wisconsin in 1924, and was promoted to the rank of professor in 1942. Gates's research focused on the field of spectroscopy, and he is credited with developing the technique of infrared spectroscopy. He was a fellow of the American Physical Society, the American Association for the Advancement of Science, and the Royal Society of Chemistry, and a member of the American Chemical Society, the American Physical Society, and the Royal Society of Chemistry. In addition to his research and teaching, Gates was also a dedicated mentor to his students. He was known for his ability to explain complex concepts in a way that was easy to understand, and he took a personal interest in the success of his students. He was the author of two books, Infrared Spectroscopy (1934) and Introduction to Infrared Spectroscopy (1948), and was the editor of the journal Infrared and Raman Spectroscopy from 1955 to 1983. Gates received many awards and honors for his contributions to the field of spectroscopy, including the William F. Meggers Award, the Fred calutia Award, and the Charles Lathrop Parsons Award. He was also a fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry and a member of the American Physical Society. Gates died in Madison, Wisconsin, in 1983, at the age of 84.

Chausath Yogini Temple, Ranipur Jharial The Chausath Yogini Temple, also known as the Chausath Mata Temple, is a Hindu temple located in the village of Ranipur Jharial, in the state of Bihar, India, on the bank of the Son River. The temple is dedicated to Goddess Kali and is one of the oldest temples in Bihar. The temple is famous for its statues of sixty goddesses arranged in a circular shape. The temple is also known as the "Nagara Temple" because it does not have a courtyard. The temple has a host of other statues, such as those of Lord Shiva and Lord Vishnu. The temple is visited by a large number of devotees during the annual Chausath Yogini Mela, which is held in the month of Magh, between the 10th day of the month and the full moon day. The devotees performpuja and offer coconuts to the goddesses. The devotees also observe fast for the whole day and eat only after nightfall. The traditional belief is that if a devotee is unable to observe the fast, then the devotee must at least offer a coconut to the goddesses. The Chausath Yogini Temple is connected to the city of Madhyamgram by a metalled road. The nearest railway station is the Son Nagar Railway Station, which is located approximately 2 kilometres (1.2 mi) from the temple.

Vetulani (or Vetulonia) was an ancient city of the Etruscan civilization, located in what is now the comune of Vetulonia, in the province of Grosseto, Tuscany, central Italy. The city was founded by the Etruscan king Porsenna around 500 BC. The name Vetulani is believed to derive from the name of the ethnos, or people, called the Vetules, who inhabited the area in the 6th century BC. The city was one of the main centers of the Etruscan Dodecapolis, a group of twelve cities which dominated the region. Other cities in the Dodecapolis were: Arezzo, Cortona, Perugia, Deruta, Potniae (in the modern comune of San Casciano dei Pagni), Arretium (Arezzo), Clusium (Chiusi), Clevsin (modern day Volterra), Cortona, Perugia, and Assisi. The city is best known for its late 4th century BC bronze Tablet of the Iguvine Tablets, a collection of bronze tablets discovered in the 19th century, which bear the only known Etruscan calendar, and are one of the few Etruscan sources which can be definitely dated. The tablets also contain the only known example of a bound ritual text in Etruscan. The Vetulani were known to have worshipped the gods Tinia, the supreme god of the Etruscan pantheon, and Culsans, a god who appears in the company of Tinia in the Tablet of the Iguvine Tablets. The Vetulani were also known to have worshipped the god Voltumna, who appears as a supreme god in the pile of remains from the sacred area of Piazza del Duomo, where there are also remains from a temple dedicated to this god. The city was conquered by the Romans in the 3rd century BC, and the name was changed to VETTUNIA. The city was a seat of a Roman praefectura. The city was a key point on the Via Flaminia, the Roman road that connected the capital with the lower Tyrrhenian Sea. The remains of the city are still visible, especially in the area of Piazza del Duomo.

Acer Aspire One The Acer Aspire One is a line of netbooks produced by Acer Inc. The first aspire one was the Aspire One Netbook, which was developed in Taiwan by Acer, the world's second-largest PC maker. The device was first unveiled at the annual International Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas in January 2008, and was released in April 2008. The Aspire One was the first commercially successful netbook, achieving worldwide sales of more than 1 million units by September 2008. In June 2009, Acer announced that it had sold more than 2 million aspire ones, and in April 2010, it announced that it had sold more than 4 million aspire ones. The Aspire One is powered by the Intel Atom processor, and runs Microsoft Windows. It is a small, lightweight, and inexpensive laptop computer designed for general computing purposes. Acer has also developed a series of similar devices, including the Aspire One Netbook, the Aspire One Netbook SE, the Aspire One Netbook Accessories, and the Aspire One Wireless Accessories. Acer has also developed a series of netbooks that run the Android operating system, including the Acer Aspire One Cloudbook, the Acer Aspire One Cloudbook Accessories, the Acer Aspire One Cloudbook SE, and the Acer Aspire One Cloudbook Enterprise.

2006 Connecticut gubernatorial election Gubernatorial election The 2006 Connecticut gubernatorial election took place on November 7, 2006. incumbent Democratic Governor Jodi Rell won re-election by a margin of 3,000 votes over Republican candidate Thomas C. Foley. The 2006 election was notable for the high number of Republicans who voted for Rell, giving her a victory in her bid for a full term over Foley, a moderate Republican who had been the state's comptroller. Rell won by 3,000 votes, with 823,000 votes cast for her and 805,000 votes cast for Foley. Rell received the votes of 84% of Republicans, while Foley received the votes of 94% of Democrats. The election had a margin of victory of 3,000 votes, out of 2,232,000 votes cast. Rell was the first woman to be elected governor of Connecticut, the first Republican woman governor in the United States, and the first governor of any U.S. state to have been appointed to her first term. The 2006 Connecticut Gubernatorial Election was certified by the Secretary of the State on November 28, 2006. Results by county As of the 2006 election, Connecticut's voting system allows a candidate to win the governorship without receiving the majority of the vote. This is because the state has no plurality rule; candidates can win all electoral votes with less than 50% of the popular vote, which would otherwise be the minimum for a majority. In this election, Rell received 49.4% of the vote, while Foley received 48.6%. Rell carried six of the state's eight counties. The largest margin of victory was in Rell's home county of Tolland, where she won by a margin of 9.4%. The largest percentage of votes received by Rell was in Tolland County, where she received 58.2% of the vote. The largest percentage of votes received by Foley was in Hartford County, where he received 54.3% of the vote. The only county Rell lost was New Haven, the state's most populous county, where she received 42.9% of the vote to Foley's 57.1%. In the cities, Rell received 46.9% of the vote in Hartford, the state's capital and largest city, to Foley's 53.1%. In Waterbury, the state's second largest city, Rell received 40.8% of the vote to Foley's 59.2%. In New Haven, the state's third largest city, Rell received 42.3% of the vote to Foley's 57.7%. Voter registration As of August 2006, 2,068,300 voters were registered in Connecticut. This represented an increase of 1.8% from the 2,041,332 voters registered in August 2004. The number of voters per capita was 3.5, one of the lowest in the United States. Voter turnout Voter turnout in the 2006 Connecticut gubernatorial election was 68.6%, the highest it had been since 1986. This was 5.2 percentage points higher than the national turnout rate of 63.4% in the 2006 elections. Of the 3,068,532 residents of the state, 2,069,325 were registered to vote. Of these, 1,332,672 actually voted, for a turnout rate of 68.6%. The highest turnout rates were in the towns of Simsbury, Granby, Suffield, Avon, and Manchester. The lowest turnout rates were in the cities of Waterbury, New Haven, and Hartford. Municipalities The highest percentage of votes received by Rell was in the town of Simsbury, where she received 77.3% of the vote. The highest percentage of votes received by Foley was in the town of Windsor Locks, where he received 72.1% of the vote. The following is a table of the largest municipalities in the state, and how they voted in the 2006 election. The numbers in parentheses are the number of votes by which the winning candidate defeated the runner-up. Rell's strongest showing was in the wealthy suburbs of the state, while Foley did better in the urban areas and the more rural areas of the state.

New Moon (Northern Lights album) New Moon is the ninth studio album by the Italian band Northern Lights, released in 2010. It is the band's first concept album, and the first to feature the band's new line-up, after the departure of original members Cristiano Borchi and Filippo Pinciroli. New Moon features a more progressive and experimental sound than the band's previous albums, and includes elements such as ambient music, space rock and metal, with a large use of keyboards. The album also features a guest appearance by Steve Rotheram, of the band Bigelf, on the track "The World Is Dead". The album was recorded between December 2009 and June 2010, and was produced and mixed by the band's guitarist, Paolo Martinoni. The artwork was designed by the band's singer, Enrico Ruggeri, and features a painting by the 17th-century Dutch artist Jan Martense de Vries. The album was released in Europe on June 25, 2010, and in the United States on June 29, 2010. In Italy, it was distributed by Bakerteam, while in the United States it was distributed by The End Records.

Martin D. Burke (born July 8, 1954) is an American businessman, investor, and philanthropist from Buffalo, New York. He is the co-founder and managing partner of Burke Capital, a private equity firm with $1.5 billion in committed capital. He is also the co-founder and chairman of a privately held oil and gas exploration and production company, Hilcorp Energy. Burke was born in Buffalo, New York, the son of a lawyer and a musician. He attended Canisius High School and graduated from the University of Notre Dame with a bachelor's degree in 1976. In 1980, Burke founded and served as president of Advanced Computer Communications, a computer modem manufacturer. The company was acquired by US Robotics in 1986. In 1987, he founded and served as president of PageNet, one of the first wireless data services companies, which he sold to AT&T in 1993. In 1998, he founded and served as CEO of Global Crossing, a fiber-optic telecommunications company that was acquired by Level 3 Communications in 2003. In 2000, Burke co-founded and served as CEO of the investment firm, Quadra Partners. In 2004, he co-founded and served as CEO of the private equity firm, Burke Capital. In 2009, Burke Capital was ranked by Forbes as one of the best private equity firms in the United States. In 2012, Burke co-founded and serves as chairman of Hilcorp Energy, a privately held oil and gas exploration and production company. In 2013, Hilcorp Energy was ranked by Fortune as the fastest-growing privately held energy company in the United States. In 2015, Hilcorp Energy was ranked by Fortune as the most profitable privately held energy company in the United States. In 2017, Hilcorp Energy was ranked by Forbes as the largest privately held energy company in the United States. In 2014, Burke made a $100 million donation to the University of Notre Dame to establish the Martin D. Burke- Klingler College of Arts and Sciences. In 2016, he made a $30 million donation to the University of Buffalo to establish the Martin D. Burke School of Law. In 2017, he made a $10 million donation to Canisius College to establish the Martin D. Burke College of Business. In 2016, Burke was ranked by Forbes as the 27th richest person in the United States, with an estimated net worth of $11.1 billion. In 2017, Burke was ranked by Forbes as the 29th richest person in the United States, with an estimated net worth of $11.2 billion. In 2018, Burke was ranked by Forbes as the 30th richest person in the United States, with an estimated net worth of $11.3 billion. In 2019, Burke was ranked by Forbes as the 31st richest person in the United States, with an estimated net worth of $11.3 billion. In 2020, Burke was ranked by Forbes as the 30th richest person in the United States, with an estimated net worth of $11.5 billion. In 2021, Burke was ranked by Forbes as the 33rd richest person in the United States, with an estimated net worth of $11.7 billion.

Walter Orlinsky (May 27, 1927 – October 16, 2018) was an American classical musician, who was the basis for the character of Pete Rose in the Academy Award-winning movie The Blind Side. A long-time friend of Michael Oher's family, Orlinsky was the basis for the character as he was the first to recognize Oher's potential as a football player. Orlinsky was born in Cleveland, Ohio. He attended Shaker Heights High School, and then Ohio State University, where he was a member of the Chi Phi Fraternity. He graduated from the University of Michigan in 1952 with a degree in music education. He then served in the United States Army for two years, ultimately attaining the rank of captain. After his time in the Army, Orlinsky began a career as a music teacher. He was the director of the Shaker Heights High School choir for 32 years, and also directed the Chorus at the Cleveland Orchestra. He also arranged music for the Cleveland Browns' "Great Lakes Navy Band". Orlinsky was the subject of an exhibit at the Cleveland Public Library, and was featured in a book about Shaker Heights High School's history as well as in an episode of the WVIZ/PBS series "Legacies: A History of Cleveland". Orlinsky was married to the former Barbara Yezerski for 61 years, and had three daughters and two grandchildren. He died on October 16, 2018, at the age of 91 at his home in Beachwood, Ohio.

Tamda Ghumar Tamda Ghumar is a Rajasthani folk dance that is performed during the Holi festival. The dance is performed in a group, with each person holding a wooden sword called a Ghumar. The performers move in a circle, making several turns and crossing their swords in front of them. The basic movement is an exaggerated walking step with the sword pointed straight down, and the knee bent. The dance is performed in several regions of Rajasthan, including Jodhpur, Udaipur, Ajmer, and Bikaner. It is typically performed by men, although women may also participate. The dance is usually performed in the open, in fields or on village streets. The Tamda Ghumar is typically performed as a social dance, with a group of friends or family members participating together. The dance is often performed as a competition, with the participants trying to out-do each other with their moves. The dance is performed to the beat of a drum, with the drummer singing and playing the beat. The drummer is usually the leader of the dance, and the other participants follow his lead. The song is typically a Rajasthani folk song, and may be about love, religion, or any other topic. The Tamda Ghumar is a popular dance in Rajasthan, and is often performed at weddings and other social events. It is also performed as a tourist attraction, and is a common feature at many tourist destinations in the state.

Pamela Cosman (born February 26, 1946) is an American actress and former fashion model. At age fifteen, Cosman was the first runner-up in the 1965 Miss Indiana pageant. After graduating from high school, she attended the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign for one year. In 1967, she married plastic surgeon Richard Alan cosman. The couple had three children: daughters Tiffany and Summer, and son Michael. They later divorced, and she married actor Sam Jaffe in 1985. After Jaffe's death in 1993, she married actor Jack Coleman in 1995. In the early 1970s, Cosman began a successful modeling career. After appearing in a television advertisement for American Airlines, she was offered a movie contract by Universal Pictures. Her first film was The Last of the American Girls, a Women in Action movie. She played the role of a model who becomes a thief to support her husband in prison. Her other film roles included The Great American Hero, The St. Valentine's Day Massacre, and The Private Files of J. Edgar Hoover. In the late 1970s, Cosman began appearing on television. She also appeared as a guest star on television series such as Charlie's Angels, The Love Boat, Fantasy Island, The Fall Guy, and Baywatch. In 1984, she played the role of Kate Miller in the television series The Yellow Rose. In the 1980s, Cosman began appearing in pornographic films. Her first role was in the 1981 film Body Chemistry. She also appeared in the films The Dirty Guys, The Adult Film Guide, and The Makeover. In the 1990s, Cosman appeared in the series Baywatch Nights. Cosman is the author of the book The Makeover: A True Story.

Buffalo Grove Ambush The Buffalo Grove Ambush was a gunfight that took place at a rural farm near Buffalo Grove, Texas on June 18, 1871, during the final days of the American Civil War. The gunfight occurred when a group of seven Union Army soldiers who had been sent to the farm to retrieve a cache of weapons and ammunition were ambushed by a group of Confederate States Army soldiers who had been hiding in a cornfield. The Union soldiers were killed, and the cache of weapons and ammunition was captured by the Confederates. The Buffalo Grove Ambush was the last major battle of the Civil War to take place in Texas. The Buffalo Grove Ambush was a well-planned and coordinated attack. The Confederates, who were hiding in a cornfield, opened fire on the Union soldiers as they approached the farm. The Union soldiers, who were not expecting an attack, were caught off-guard and quickly overwhelmed by the Confederates. The gunfight lasted for a few minutes, with the Confederates ultimately prevailing. After the gunfight, the Confederates took the weapons and ammunition that they had been hiding in the cornfield and left the scene. The Union soldiers were killed, and their bodies were later found by a group of local residents. The residents, who were sympathetic to the Confederate cause, buried the Union soldiers in a shallow grave and reported the incident to the Confederate authorities. The Buffalo Grove Ambush was a major victory for the Confederates, as it provided them with a much-needed supply of weapons and ammunition. The ambushers were a group of Confederate deserters who had been hiding in the area since the end of the Civil War. They were led by a man named Richard Morgan, who was wanted by the Confederate authorities for desertion. The deserters were also wanted for a series of other crimes, including theft and murder.

African Sources for African History The study of African history is beset by problems of sources. For many centuries, the written history of Africa was dominated by accounts from European traders, administrators, soldiers, and missionaries who were mostly interested in the coasts and in the affairs of states with whom they traded. Their records are full of prejudice, ignorance, and errors. From the later 19th century, however, African history began to be shaped by African scholars. The traditional history of the African continent is one of the oldest known. In the 21st century, oral traditions continue to be a vital source for African history. The historical records of the ancient Egyptians, Persians, Greeks, and Romans contain references to the African continent and to the cultures of its inhabitants. However, because these references are often late and unreliable, the traditional history of Africa is usually ignored by professional historians. The ancient Egyptians developed a writing system called hieroglyphs, and their records are some of the earliest known. From the 5th century BC, Egypt was conquered by a series of foreign powers, including the Persians, the Greeks, and the Romans. For this reason, the ancient Egyptians are often a source for the history of other cultures. However, because the Egyptians had a strong sense of their own unique identity, their records are also an important source for African history. The ancient Egyptians are best known for their monumental architecture, such as the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Great Sphinx, and the Temple of Luxor. Their other achievements, in areas such as art, mathematics, and astronomy, are also significant. The ancient Persians were a powerful civilization that spanned much of the world, including parts of Europe, Asia, and Africa. The Persian Empire was ruled by a series of monarchs, or shahs, who were advised by a royal council. The most powerful shah was Cyrus the Great, who founded the empire and made it a major power in the world. The Persians were known for their ability to conquer other nations, and they had a major influence on the culture of the countries they conquered, including Egypt. The ancient Greeks were a civilization that began in the Mediterranean region of the world and later spread to other parts of the world, including Africa. The first Greek settlements in Africa were in the eastern Mediterranean, on the island of Crete, and in what is now Libya. The Greeks were a major power in the world, and their influence spread throughout the Mediterranean region and beyond. The Greeks were known for their art, literature, philosophy, and science. The ancient Romans were a civilization that began in the Italian peninsula and later spread to other parts of the world, including Africa. The first Roman settlements in Africa were in what is now Libya. The Romans were a major power in the world, and their influence spread throughout the Mediterranean region and beyond. The Romans were known for their art, literature, engineering, and military might.

South Delta High School is a public high school located in South Delta, British Columbia, Canada. It is part of the Delta School District. The school is attended by approximately 550 students from grades 8 to 12. The current school building was constructed in 1978, with several renovations occurring since then. The 2020 United States presidential election in Indiana was held on Tuesday, November 3, 2020, as part of the 2020 United States presidential election in which all 50 states participated. Indiana voters chose 11 electors to represent them in the Electoral College via a popular vote, pitting the Republican Party's nominee, incumbent President Donald Trump, against Democratic Party nominee, former Vice President Joe Biden. Indiana was won by Trump, who carried the state with 61.2% of the vote and a margin of victory of 18.2%. Prior to the election, all 14 news organizations projected Indiana as strongly Republican. Trump significantly improved on his 2016 performance in Indiana, improving his vote share by 4.4% and his margin of victory by 4.1%. In 2016, Trump won the state with 56.2% of the vote and a margin of victory of 16.3%. With Trump's victory in the state, he passed William Henry Harrison and became the third Republican to win the state twice, after Calvin Coolidge and Herbert Hoover. Biden carried Indiana's 12 most populated counties, including Marion County, where the state's largest city and capital Indianapolis is located. Indiana was the state with the most electoral votes to be won by Trump, and was the fifth most populous state in the nation. In recent years, Indiana has trended Republican, with the last Democratic presidential nominee to win the state being Barack Obama in 2008. In 2016, Indiana gave Trump 56.2% of the vote, with the state's electoral delegates giving him enough electoral votes to claim the presidency even if he had lost every other state. In the 2020 Republican National Convention, the Republican Party nominated incumbent President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence as the Republican ticket to run for office. The Republican National Convention was held in the state's largest city, Indianapolis. The 2016 Democratic National Convention was held in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, where the Democratic Party nominated former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Senator Tim Kaine as the Democratic ticket to run for office. Clinton won the national popular vote but lost the electoral college to Trump. The 2020 Democratic National Convention was held in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, where the Democratic Party nominated former Vice President Joe Biden and Senator Kamala Harris as the Democratic ticket to run for office. Biden won the national popular vote as well as the electoral college. The election was held during a period of great unrest in the country, with the COVID-19 pandemic and associated economic crisis having begun in March, the George Floyd protests beginning in May, and the 2020 United States census beginning in April. In the weeks prior to the election, Trump and Biden were nearly tied in the polls, with Trump holding a slight edge. On October 22, 2020, Trump and Biden debated in a tense first presidential debate, with Trump repeatedly interrupting Biden. The debate was held at the Health Education Campus of Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, Ohio. Trump won the election, with 61.2% of the vote and a margin of victory of 18.2%. Biden won the national popular vote, with 51.3% of the vote and a margin of victory of 4.5%. On election night, Trump held a large rally with his supporters in the East Room of the White House to await the results. At around 1:00 a.m. EST on November 4, 2020, Biden was declared the winner of the election, having won the state of Pennsylvania and its 20 electoral votes. Trump did not concede the election, and he and his supporters continued to make unsubstantiated claims of widespread electoral fraud. On December 14, 2020, the United States House of Representatives voted to accept the electoral college votes of Michigan and Arizona, which were contested by Trump. The next day, the United States Senate voted to accept the electoral college votes of Michigan and Arizona. The votes of the two states gave Biden a total of 306 electoral votes, enough to win the presidency.

Red Hot Romance is a 2002 novel by American writer Otessa Moshfegh. In an attempt to become a more well-rounded person, a young woman with a newly developed passion for life, and the literary canon, decides to have one hundred affairs in one year. Her journey through this year is both painful and humorous, as she deals with the emotional and physical damage of her experiences, and her friends try to help her along the way. The novel questions what it means to be a "well-rounded" person, and what it means to be a woman. Red Hot Romance is a contemporary novel with elements of both the romance novel and the novel of manners. It is set in New York City, and the heroine lives in an apartment on the Upper West Side. Her name is changed to "Dana" in the novel, and the narrator is her best friend, "Sarah". Dana is a young woman who has recently been through a painful breakup with her fiancé. She iswallowing in self-pity and depression, having spent the last year of her life with her fiancé and having no other romantic experiences to compare it to. In an attempt to become more well-rounded, she decides to have one hundred affairs in one year. Her journey through this year is both painful and humorous, as she deals with the emotional and physical damage of her experiences, and her friends try to help her along the way. The novel questions what it means to be a "well-rounded" person, and what it means to be a woman.

Barnett Bank of Marion County, N.A. v. Nelson, 517 U.S. 344 (1996), was a United States Supreme Court case in which the Court held that a bank that issues a cashier's check to a customer, and then receives the check back from the customer without the customer's signature, is not required to make payment on the check. The Court held that the bank's receipt of the unsigned check was the same as receiving a blank piece of paper, and therefore the bank was not liable for the check. The Court's decision was unanimous. The case began in Florida state court, where Barnett Bank of Marion County (the bank) brought an action against Joseph H. Nelson (the customer) to collect on a cashier's check that Nelson had issued to himself. The face amount of the check was $29,737.81, and the bank claimed that Nelson had failed to pay on the check. At trial, the bank introduced the unsigned check, and the customer did not dispute that the signature on the check was his. However, Nelson claimed that he was not liable for the check because he had not signed it. The trial court found in favor of the bank, and Nelson appealed. The Florida District Court of Appeal reversed the decision, holding that a cashier's check is payable only upon the bank's presentation of the check for payment, and that the bank's mere retention of the check does not constitute "payment" of the check. The bank then appealed to the Florida Supreme Court, which affirmed the District Court's decision. The case then went to the United States Supreme Court, which granted certiorari to hear the case. The Court held that under the terms of the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), which has been adopted by the state of Florida, a bank's receipt of a cashier's check without the customer's signature is the same as receiving a blank piece of paper, and therefore the bank is not liable for the check. The Court also noted that the bank had issued the check to Nelson, and therefore it was not a "third-party" check under the UCC. The Court's decision was unanimous.

Metro Railway, Kolkata The Metro Railway, Kolkata (formerly known as the Calcutta Metro) is a rapid transit system serving the city of Kolkata and the districts of South 24 Parganas and North 24 Parganas in the Indian state of West Bengal. It is the first underground railway system in India, and the first rapid transit system in South Asia. The Metro was opened in 1984, after construction began in 1972. The Metro is a major mode of transport in Kolkata, with an average daily ridership of around 1.4 million passengers in 2019. The Kolkata Metro is the sixth busiest rapid transit system in the world by passenger density, and the third busiest in India, after the Mumbai Metro and the Delhi Metro. The stations of the Kolkata Metro are farther apart than those of most other metros, and the trains are relatively slow. However, the system has the highest daily ridership per route-kilometre in the world, at 1.3 million. The metro has two branches, one from Dum Dum to Kestopur and the other from Dakshineswar to Kestopur. The two branches meet at Esplanade station, and together the two lines form a 21.5 km (13.4 mi) long metro line. The Metro has 27 stations and a total of 36.45 km (19.48 mi) of track. The Kolkata Metro is built to a larger gauge than most other rapid transit systems in the world, and is therefore sometimes described as a "wide gauge" metro. The larger gauge is intended to allow for larger trains and higher speeds. The Kolkata Metro has two types of services: 1. The Mainline has a frequency of 2–3 minutes during peak hours and 3–4 minutes off-peak. 2. The Circular Line has a frequency of 5 minutes during peak hours and 10 minutes off-peak. The Metro Rail is a joint venture of the Government of West Bengal (GoWB) and the Government of India (GoI), through the Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs (MoHUA). The West Bengal Metro Rail Corporation Limited (WBMRCL), a company fully owned by the GoWB, is responsible for the implementation of the project. The Kolkata Metro is the first metro in India to use rolling stock manufactured in India. The Kolkata Metro has two types of stations: 1. Underground stations: The stations at Dakshineswar, Chandni Chowk, and Esplanade are underground. 2. Elevated stations: The stations at Dum Dum, Kestopur, and Phoolbagan are elevated. The Kolkata Metro is one of the most energy-efficient rapid transit systems in the world, consuming only 0.48 kWh per traveller per kilometre, compared to a global average of 3.6 kWh per traveller per kilometre. The Kolkata Metro has been in operation since October 1984. The Metro was first proposed in 1965, with the project being approved in 1970. Construction began in 1972, with the first stretch of the Metro being opened in 1984. The Metro was built in two phases, with the first phase being from Dum Dum to Kestopur, and the second phase being from Dakshineswar to Kestopur. The two phases were opened in 1984 and 1995, respectively. The Kolkata Metro has been expanded twice since it was first built. The first expansion was from Dum Dum to Dakshineswar, which was opened in 2009. The second expansion was from Kestopur to Nayapalli, which was opened in 2014. The Nayapalli extension is a branch of the Dum Dum–Dakshineswar line, and is not connected to the rest of the Metro. The Kolkata Metro has been proposed to be expanded further, with a new line from Howrah to Sealdah via Esplanade and a new line from Salt Lake to Howrah via Dum Dum.

Pleurotus citrinopileatus, commonly known as the lemon pleurotus, is a species of edible fungus in the family Pleurotaceae. It was first described by mycologist Meyer in 1928. The fungus is characterized by a strong lemon scent and is widely distributed in Europe, Africa, and North America, where it grows on decaying hardwood trees, particularly ash, or on the roots of living trees in forests. The fruit bodies are characterized by a white to buff-colored cap, with a slight incurving margin and a tendency to become lobed with age. The flesh is white, with a mild to slightly sour taste. The spore print is white, and the distribution of the spores on the gill is intervenose. The lemon pleurotus is edible and can be eaten raw, although it is not as palatable as when cooked. As its name suggests, the fungus has a lemon scent that is stronger when the fruit bodies are dried. It can be used to add flavor to soups and salads, or when cooked alone, it can be served as a side dish. In the kitchen, the mushroom can be used in place of the more expensive oyster mushrooms. Belle C. Greene (November 23, 1885 – August 2, 1950) was an American actress of the silent era. Born in New York City, Greene studied opera, and in 1908 began acting in the chorus of the Metropolitan Opera Company. She also performed with the Manhattan Opera Company and the Chicago Grand Opera Company. She began her film career in 1911, working for the Thanhouser Company in New York. Her first film was the two-reel life of Christ, From the Manger to the Cross, in which she played the lead role of Mary Magdalene. In 1912, Greene traveled to California to perform on the stage. She appeared in the hit play The Great Divide, which ran for more than a year in Los Angeles. She also performed the leading role in the opera La bohème with the Los Angeles Grand Opera Company. After making a handful of films for the Thanhouser Company, Greene signed with the Biograph Company in 1913. She was one of the company's most highly regarded actresses, and one of the few performers to consistently receive star billing. She specialized in playing sophisticated society women, and often performed opposite John Emerson and Richard Barthelmess. She also occasionally directed some of the films in which she starred. In 1916, Greene left Biograph to sign a contract with the newly formed Art Cinema Corporation. The following year, the company was absorbed into the Paragon Film Corporation. She starred in several films for Paragon, including the 1917 film The House of Mirrors, in which she played the dual role of twin sisters. In 1918, Greene starred in the film The Venus Model, which was produced by the Women's Film Corporation. She also served as the film's director and producer. In 1919, Greene starred in the film The Third Kiss, produced by the Motion Picture Corporation of America. She also served as the film's director and producer. In the early 1920s, Greene starred in a number of films for the Vitagraph Studios. She also directed several of the films in which she starred. Her final known film was the 1924 production of The Green Goddess. Greene died on August 2, 1950, at the Motion Picture Country Home in Los Angeles, California.

Yan Han (born August 12, 1986) is a Chinese artist and Illustrator based in Los Angeles. Born in Xiamen, Fujian Province, China, Yan Han studied at the Xiamen University, the China Academy of Fine Arts, and the National Taiwan University of Arts. He graduated from the Communication University of China in 2008 with a major in Commercial Illustration. In 2013, he received an MFA degree from the Maryland Institute College of Art. Yan Han's works are featured in the Tsinghua University Art Museum, the Communication University of China Museum, the Today Art Museum, the National Taiwan Museum, and the Los Angeles Municipal Art Gallery. His works have been exhibited in Germany, Belgium, Italy, Finland, the United States, South Korea, Japan, and China, including the 2015 China International Gallery Exposition, the 2015 Asian Art Fair, and the 2016 Art Fair Philippines. Yan Han was a nominee for the 15th Chinese Young Artists Exhibition. He was awarded the "Excellent Young Artist Award" by the Chinese Artists Association in 2014. In 2015, he won the Second Award in the "First International Watercolor Art Exhibition" in Toronto, Canada. In 2016, he was awarded the "Outstanding Young Alumni Award" by the Communication University of China.
