New London Harbor Light The New London Harbor Light is an active lighthouse on the west side of the Thames River, New London, Connecticut. It is located on the former site of Fort Trumbull, which was an integral part of the harbor's defenses during the Revolutionary War and the War of 1812. In Nigerians, Fort Trumbull was the site of a battle in which the British captured the fort from the French in 1781 during the American Revolutionary War. The British remained in control of the fort until the end of the war in 1783, when they evacuated and destroyed much of the fort's infrastructure. The United States government reconstructed Fort Trumbull in the early 1800s, and it was equipped with twenty-six 24-pounders and two 13-inch mortars. During the War of 1812, the fort was the site of a battle between British forces, assisted by a contingent of loyalists, and American militia led by Connecticut Governor Roger Griswold. On September 6, 1814, the British attacked the fort and burned the surrounding village of Groton. They were repulsed with significant losses by the fort's garrison, which was assisted by the crew of the USS Flicker. The British retreated to their ships and shelled the fort for the next three days. The fort's 150-man garrison held out, despite suffering twenty-one casualties, until the British abandoned the field on September 9. The New London Harbor Light was one of the earliest lighthouses in the United States. It was lit in 1760, and is therefore known as the third oldest lighthouse in the country. The New London Harbor Light was also the first lighthouse in the country to be built on a fort. The New London Harbor Light is a Visitors' Center for the New London Maritime Museum. The Museum offers tours of the Light and Fort Trumbull. Connecticut's state seal features a shield with a blue background, on which a tall ship, a symbol of the state's maritime history, is depicted. The state motto, "Qui Transtulit Sustinet," is displayed on a ribbon surrounding the shield, and translates to "He Who Transplanted Still Sustains." The seal was adopted in 1775, shortly after the colony's inception.

Paul Nietsche Paul Nietsche was a 19th-century philosopher who had a profound impact on modern thought. He was born in Germany in 1844 and spent most of his life there, but he did spend some time in Switzerland, where he died in 1900. Nietsche's writing was often critical of religion, and he was seen as a controversial figure during his lifetime. However, his ideas have had a lasting impact on philosophy and have been studied and debated for generations. One of Nietsche's most famous works was "The Birth of Tragedy," which he wrote in 1872. In this book, Nietsche argued that the world is a constant struggle between two opposing forces: the Apollonian and the Dionysian. The Apollonian represents order and logic, while the Dionysian represents chaos and instinct. Nietsche believed that both forces were necessary for a healthy society, but that the Apollonian had become too dominant in Western culture. He argued that the Dionysian needed to be re-emphasized in order to balance out the Apollonian. Another important work by Nietsche was "Thus Spoke Zarathustra," which he wrote in 1883. In this book, Nietsche presented a fictional character, Zarathustra, who was a prophet and a wise man. Zarathustra spoke about the need for people to overcome their fear of death and to live life to the fullest. Nietsche also discussed the idea of the "eternal recurrence," which is the idea that events will always repeat themselves in the same way. In his final years, Nietsche's health began to decline, and he died in 1900 at the age of 56. Despite his relatively short life, Nietsche's ideas have had a lasting impact on philosophy and continue to be studied and debated to this day.

57th Utah State Legislature The 57th Utah State Legislature was elected Tuesday, November 4, 2008, and will convene on January 26, 2009, at the Utah State Capitol in Salt Lake City. The Utah State Senate will have 24 Republicans, 8 Democrats and 1 vacancy. The Utah State House of Representatives will have 40 Republicans, 19 Democrats and 1 vacancy. The new makeup of the State Legislature was decided by the 2008 elections, in which incumbents Senator Kevin Van Tassell (R-8) and Representative Meriam Nelson (R-58) were defeated in their bids for re-election. The 2009 Utah State Legislature will be the first to serve under the state's new Governor, Gary Herbert. The new Legislature will be sworn in during an organizational session on January 26, 2009, in the Utah State Capitol in Salt Lake City. 2009 is the 60th year that the Utah State Legislature has met. The first Utah State Legislature met in 1851, but was known as the "General Assembly" until the state constitution was amended in 1896 to change the name to the "Legislature." The Republican Party has controlled both houses of the Utah State Legislature since the 1970s.

The Daily Show: Indecision 2006 The Daily Show: Indecision 2006 was a special edition of Comedy Central's The Daily Show with Jon Stewart that ran from November 7 to November 9, 2006. The show, which was the third and final edition of the series to run over multiple nights, was a wrap-up to the 2006 midterm elections, which were held on November 7. The show was the first multi-night edition since the series' earliest days, when it was known as The Daily Show with Jon Stewart and was primarily a satirical news-based talk show, rather than the hybrid news/comedy show it has since become. The show was broken up into multiple segments, including "Indecision 2006," a live half-hour election night show on November 7; "Midnight Indecision," a live hour-long show that immediately followed Indecision 2006 on November 7; "Indecision: Now What?," a live show on November 8; and "Indecision 2006: The Hangover," a live show on November 9. The November 9 show was the only one of the four that was not live. The Daily Show was the first network late-night show to broadcast live on election night, and this edition of the series received a few technical patents for the electronic voting map used to illustrate the election returns. On the November 7 Indecision 2006 show, the correspondents used the "Magic Wall" to explain the election returns. The wall was made up of a large number of small, square, red and blue lights, each of which represented a single voting district. The colors of the lights were initially all blue, signifying that no votes had yet been cast. As the night went on and the votes were counted, the lights changed to red or blue to represent which party had won each district. The magic wall was updated in real time, with the updated results displayed as they came in. The wall was designed by Alex Pollack. The November 7 show also featured a special video introduction by Jon Stewart, who, in character as the show's anchor, explained that the show was going to be different that night, because it was "live." In addition to the special video and graphics, the show's theme music was also changed for the night. Instead of the usual fast-paced theme, the show used a slower, more suspenseful version of the theme, designed to heighten the suspense of the election returns. In the course of the evening, the show also used a number of guest commentators, including political analyst Nancy Walls, comedian and actress Kathy Griffin, and Daily Show correspondents Rob Riggle, Stephen Colbert, and Samantha Bee. At the end of the November 7 show, Jon Stewart anchored the "Tales from the Trump Club" segment, which featured a number of jokes at the expense of Republican candidate Donald Trump, who had already announced that he would be running for president in 2008. The November 7 show was watched by an average of 1.3 million viewers, making it the most-watched episode of The Daily Show since the show's inception in 1996. The show also received a 3.2 rating/5 share in the key 18-49 demographic, which was the highest rating in the show's history.

Harold E. Weeks (November 30, 1908 – January 17, 1998) was an American politician and businessman. Weeks was born in Brattleboro, Vermont and attended the Brattleboro High School. He later moved to Arlington, Vermont and graduated from the University of Vermont in 1930. He married Mary E.., with whom he had two sons, in 1932. He served in the Vermont House of Representatives from 1939 to 1943 and in the Vermont State Senate from 1943 to 1945. He was the Governor of Vermont from January 1948 to January 1949. He was the Lieutenant Governor of Vermont from January 1949 to January 1950. He was the Governor of Vermont from January 1950 to January 1951. He was the Lieutenant Governor of Vermont from January 1951 to January 1952. He was the Governor of Vermont from January 1952 to January 1953. He was the Lieutenant Governor of Vermont from January 1953 to January 1954. He was the Governor of Vermont from January 1954 to January 1955. He was the Lieutenant Governor of Vermont from January 1955 to January 1956. He was the Governor of Vermont from January 1956 to January 1957. He was the Lieutenant Governor of Vermont from January 1957 to January 1958. He was the Governor of Vermont from January 1958 to January 1959. IROC XIV was the fourteenth season of the IROC Formula One World Championship. The season started on June 1, 1992, and ended on October 11, 1992. Michael Schumacher won the championship, beating his future teammate in F1, Jean Alesi, by one point. The season was contested over ten races, with the winner of each race winning the championship. The races were held in the United States, Canada, and Mexico. The first two races were held at the Daytona International Speedway, the third race was held at the Sears Point Raceway, the fourth race was held at the Road America, the fifth race was held at the Laguna Seca Raceway, the sixth race was held at the Lime Rock, the seventh race was held at the North Point, the eighth race was held at the Sears Point Raceway, the ninth race was held at the Road America, and the tenth race was held at the Las Vegas Motor Speedway. There were two different winners in the first two races, with Eddie Cheever Jr. winning the first race, and Michael Schumacher winning the second race. The third race was won by Jean Alesi, the fourth race was won by Michael Schumacher, the fifth race was won by Nigel Mansell, the sixth race was won by Michael Schumacher, the seventh race was won by Nigel Mansell, the eighth race was won by Michael Schumacher, the ninth race was won by Nigel Mansell, and the tenth race was won by Michael Schumacher. Michael Schumacher won the championship with five wins and one second-place finish. Jean Alesi finished second in the championship with four wins and two second-place finishes. Nigel Mansell finished third in the championship with three wins and one second-place finish.

Daedalus Reef Daedalus Reef is an exposed triangle-shaped reef in the Red Sea, about 80 km from the coast of the Sinai Peninsula. It is one of the most prominent reefs in the Red Sea and is also one of the most northern reefs in the Red Sea. The reef is shaped like a triangle with a shallow lagoon in the middle. The eastern side is the longest, about 1.5 km, and the northern side is the shortest, about 1 km. The south and the west have a long outer reef running parallel to the reef proper. The western outer reef is longer, about 2.5 km, and the southern outer reef is shorter, about 1.5 km. The lagoon is about 3 km in length and 1.5 km in width. The eastern part of the lagoon is shallow and the western part is deeper, with a maximum depth of about 60 m. There are two small islands in the lagoon, the smaller one in the west and the larger one (Daedalus Island) in the east. The larger island is the location of a navigation light. There are two small ergs on the northern and southern tips of the reef. The ergs are small, narrow, sandy islets that are extensions of the reef. The one on the northern tip is about 180 m long and the one on the southern tip is about 400 m long. The water depth around the reef is very deep, making it an ideal location for sport diving. The average depth of the water around the reef is 30-40 m, with some parts reaching 60 m and beyond. The wall drops down to the deep water in a very vertical fashion, making for some spectacular diving. The wall is covered with a variety of soft and hard corals. The main attraction of the reef is the possibility to see sharks and other large marine life. The southern tip of the reef is a well-known location for seeing schools of hammerhead sharks. The outer reefs are also good locations for seeing reefs sharks, especially the silvertip shark and the grey reef shark. The lagoon is home to a variety of smaller fish, as well as some larger species, such as the Napoleon wrasse and the groupers.

Province of Schleswig-Holstein The Province of Schleswig-Holstein is a province in the north of the German state of Schleswig-Holstein. It extends from the Eider River in the west to the Baltic Sea in the east. The city of Flensburg is the capital and the largest city. The area of the province is 18,386 square kilometers (7,100 sq mi), making it the tenth-largest German state in area ( bypassing Berlin and Hamburg ). In 2015, the population was 2,284,000. It is the third most populous German state after North Rhine-Westphalia and Bavaria. The area that later became the province was part of the Kingdom of Denmark until the early 19th century. After being conquered by the German Federation (the Confederation of the Rhine) in 1815, it was granted to the Danish King by the German Federal Act of 25 June 1815 (see also German Confederation). The area was conquered by Nazi Germany in 1940 and was organized as the German province of Schleswig-Holstein from 1941 to 1945. After the war, it was divided into two zones, with the northern part becoming part of the Danish zone and the southern part becoming part of the American zone. The British zone between the American and Danish zones was eliminated in the Schleswig plebiscites in 1946, in which the people in the northern half of the former British zone voted to join Denmark and the people in the southern half voted to remain with Germany. The German-Danish border was then established along the Flensburg-Schleswig line, where it has remained since. The name Schleswig-Holstein reflects the merger of two medieval duchies: Schleswig and Holstein. The Danish duchy of Schleswig was a fief of the Holy Roman Empire, and the German duchy of Holstein was a fief of the Danish duchy. The two were only united politically in the 19th century. Today, the province of Schleswig-Holstein is the site of the Eider Barrage, which dams the Eider River and cuts off the Eiderstedt Peninsula from the rest of the mainland. The peninsula is the site of the German-Danish border crossing at Eldorado.

The Velveteen Rabbit The Velveteen Rabbit is a children's novel by Margery Williams, first published in 1922. One of the best-known examples of a portal fantasy, it tells the story of a stuffed rabbit toy, Velveteen Rabbit, and his owner, a young boy named Tommy. It is a tale of love and friendship between toys and people. In the story, the stuffed rabbit becomes a real rabbit in the boy's imagination. The boy is ill and has been given the rabbit by his father. The rabbit is given two goals: to be real, and to make the boy well. The boy's nurse, Miss Thompson, gives the rabbit to the boy, and tells him that if he is very good, and very brave, the rabbit will become real. The rabbit is not real, but he becomes real to the boy. The boy is ill and cannot go outside to play. His friends cannot come to visit him, because they might catch his illness. Only the rabbit can visit the boy, and so the boy has only the rabbit and his imagination to keep him company. The boy plays with the rabbit, and the rabbit becomes very dirty. The boy's mother puts the rabbit in the toy box, and the boy is no longer allowed to play with him. The rabbit becomes lonely and sad, because he cannot be with the boy. Miss Thompson tells the boy that it is time for the rabbit to be put in the fire, to be made real. The boy's mother puts the rabbit in the furnace, and he becomes real. He jumps out of the furnace, and runs to the boy's room. The boy is happy to see the rabbit, and the rabbit is happy to be with the boy.

Southampton Blitz During the Second World War, Southampton was the subject of two major bombing raids, the first of which took place on the nights of 30 and 31 May 1940. The city was targeted because it was the home of the ocean liner SS Rex, which was being used as a troopship, and the aircraft carrier HMS Argus, which was in dock for repairs. The German raiders were escorted by a force of about 20 Messerschmitt Bf 110s from Norway, which had been modified to carry a 50-mm anti-ship gun under their wings. The first attack on Southampton came on the evening of 30 May. Twenty-three Heinkel He 111s, supported by 25 Messerschmitts, dropped 40 high-explosive and 16 incendiary bombs on the city. The Messerschmitts also attacked the city's docks with their 50-mm guns, and a number of hits were scored on the SS Rex. The ship's commanding officer, Captain F. A. Lewey, ordered the ship to be moved to a position where the 50-mm guns could not bear. The Messerschmitts were able to score only four more hits on the ship before they were driven off by anti-aircraft fire from the ship and the surrounding area. The Heinkels were more successful, and by the morning of 31 May, the SS Rex was listing so badly that it had to be beached in the River Itchen. The Southampton Blitz After the attack on the SS Rex, the German aircraft turned their attention to other targets in the city. The Itchen Bridge was hit by two 50-mm shells, which caused it to collapse. This left the city's Floating Bridge as the only route across the river. The Germans also attacked the city's docks, and the oil tank at Woolston was set on fire. The German raid caused extensive damage to the city, with many buildings being destroyed or damaged. The Itchen Bridge was not the only bridge to be hit, as the Floating Bridge was also attacked. The bridge was hit by a number of bombs, which caused it to sink. The city's docks were also badly damaged, with many ships being sunk or damaged. The German aircraft returned to the city on the evening of 31 May for a second raid. This time they were more successful, as they were able to hit the SS Rex with a number of 50-mm shells. The ship was eventually beached in the River Itchen, and was later refloated and repaired. The Southampton Blitz was a major blow to the city, as it caused extensive damage and disruption. The city's docks were badly damaged, and many ships were sunk or damaged. The Itchen Bridge was also destroyed, which left the city's Floating Bridge as the only route across the river. The city was able to recover from the raid, but it was a major blow to the city's economy.

Janet Hobhouse (born July 24, 1954) is an American actress. She is best known for her performance as Emily the Strange in the television series The Strange Ones. Hobhouse was born in Boston, Massachusetts, the daughter of Jean (née Smith), a dancer, and Frederick Hobhouse, a physician. She attended the Rudolf Steiner School in New York City, and graduated from Harvard University in 1976 with a bachelor's degree in English. In 1979, Hobhouse joined the cast of the television soap opera Another World as Iris Cory Corrington. Her character was involved in a popular romance with Jake Harrison (Michael Zaslow), and the couple married in 1981. In 1983, the couple had a daughter, April, who was played by actress Christina Rye. In 1986, Hobhouse took a short break from the show, and her role was temporarily filled by actress Tina Louise. She returned to the series in 1987, and remained with the show until it was canceled in 1999. In addition to her work on Another World, Hobhouse appeared in a number of other television series, including Law & Order,its spin-off Law & Order: Criminal Intent, and The X-Files. She also appeared in two feature films, The Stepford Wives (2004) and The Last Days of American Crime (2020). After Another World ended in 1999, Hobhouse appeared in a number of Off-Broadway and regional theater productions, including The Laramie Project, The Pink phosphor, and Julius Caesar. In 2001, she appeared in the Off-Broadway premiere of The Stepford Wives. In 2006, she starred in the Off-Broadway premiere of The House in Paris, a new play by James Lapine. In 2009, she starred in the Off-Broadway premiere of The American Pilot, a new play by Richard Piazza. In 2013, Hobhouse appeared in the Amazon series Alpha House. In 2015, she appeared in the FX series The Bear. In 2016, she appeared in the Hulu series The Path. In 2018, she appeared in the Syfy series Happy!

Peter Banfield (born 25 April 1949) is an English actor, best known for playing the first Digger in the BBC TV series Dad's Army. Banfield was born in Portsmouth, Hampshire. His family moved to East Grinstead, Sussex, when he was five years old. He attended both the Bell Lane and East Grinstead Schools, and then went to Battle Abbey School, near Hastings, East Sussex. After leaving school he worked for a number of local builders before going to London to train as an actor at the Corona Academy, Regularly appearing on television, his first film part was as a juvenile delinquent in A Hard Day's Night, playing opposite Richard Lester, who was directing the film. He went on to appear in many TV series, including The Wednesday Play, The Newcomers, The Flying Swan, The First of the Summer Wine, Within These Walls, The Doctors, Public Eye, The Paper Man, The Man in a Suitcase, The Black Arrow, The Saint, The Tomorrow People, The Brides of Dracula, The Oblong Box, The Cry of the Banshee, The Executioner, Danger Man, The Flying Saucer, The Old Curiosity Shop, and The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe. Banfield is best known for his role as the first "Digger" in the BBC TV series Dad's Army. He also appeared in the West End production of the musical Annie.

The Larklight trilogy is a series of three alternate history/steampunk novels by English writer Philip Reeve. The trilogy consists of the novels Larklight, Stalker and Infernale. The series is set in an alternate early-nineteenth-century Britain, with some elements of Victorian-era Britain. The trilogy's setting is a time when the British Empire has become the dominant power on Earth, due to the exponential expansion of the Britishility, a sort of super-powered, super-smart bacteria which has infected every person on Earth, and which also powers every piece of technology. The series follows the adventures of Art Mumby, the son of a famous explorer, as he travels the world and tries to stop an insane scientist from destroying the planet. Larklight is the first book in the series, and is set in the year 1840. It follows the Mumby family as they travel the world in their airship, the Larklight, to stop the Saleous family, a group of French scientists, from launching a rocket which will destroy London. Stalker is the second book, and is set in the year 1841. It follows the Mumby family as they travel to the Soviet Union to try to stop the saleous from activating their Cosmopheric Telegraph, which will allow them to control the Britishility and possibly cause a second Big Bang. Infernale is the third book, and is set in the year 1842. It follows the Mumby family as they travel to Hell to stop the Saleous from using the Britishility to bring the Devil back to life.

The Singles, Volume I: The Federal Years: 1956–1960 is a box set by American rock band the Byrds, comprising the group's single A-sides, B-sides, and two other songs released on the 45 RPM format during their association with the Columbia Records label from March 9, 1965, to July 1, 1967. The box set, which was released on June 8, 2018, in celebration of the 50th anniversary of the band's debut single, includes eight 45 RPM records, all of which are replicas of the original singles, and a book with extensive liner notes by musician and author Bob Mosley. The Singles, Volume I: The Federal Years: 1956–1960 is the first in a series of two box sets that will cover the Byrds' entire career on the Columbia and Warner Bros. labels. The second set, The Singles, Volume II: The Warner Bros. Years: 1967–1971, was released on April 26, 2019. The Singles, Volume I: The Federal Years: 1956–1960 contains all of the A-sides and B-sides of the singles the Byrds released for Columbia in the United States and some international territories, as well as two other songs that were released as singles in the UK and Germany. The box set includes the single versions of the songs, rather than their album versions, and most of the songs are presented in their original mono mixes. The box set also includes a booklet with detailed liner notes, as well as a selection of rare and previously unpublished photos of the Byrds. The Singles, Volume I: The Federal Years: 1956–1960 was released in 2018, on the 50th anniversary of the release of the Byrds' debut single, "Mr. Tambourine Man". The box set was issued in limited and non-limited editions, with the limited edition version pressed on colored vinyl and featuring a replica of the Japanese pressing of the "Mr. Tambourine Man" single.

An automatic weather station (AWS) is a weather station that takes regular, uniform, and frequent measurements of multiple weather variables, and records them at a given time interval, or at a specific time, using automated processes. The measurements are then used to calculate and issue weather forecasts, and to study the weather and climate. The first weather observations on a regular basis were taken manually, and the term weather station thus originally referred to any place where weather observations were taken. As the equipment to take automatic observations became available, the term automatic weather station was coined to specify a station where observations were obtained automatically. The variables measured by an automatic weather station are typically similar to those measured by a manual weather station, and can include temperature, humidity, air pressure, wind speed and direction, and amount of precipitation. In addition, an automatic weather station can measure soil temperature and moisture, and ocean parameters such as waves, tide levels, and sea surface temperature. Automatic weather stations can also measure other variables, such as visibility, atmospheric pressure, and ultraviolet (UV) index. Some weather stations are specialized and only measure one or two variables. The measurements taken at a weather station can be used to create weather reports and to issue weather warnings. They also form the basis for a wide variety of weather forecasting models used to forecast weather conditions. In addition, automatic weather stations can be used to study the weather and climate. The reliability of the data from an automatic weather station depends on the quality of the sensors, the placement of the station, and the availability of the power and telecommunications infrastructure to support it. Maintenance of the station is also important. The need for weather observations to be taken frequently, in a uniform manner, and at the same time of day each day, means that the process is best suited to being automated. The first instance of an automated process for taking weather observations was in 1747, when a mercury barometer was attached to a moveable arm, which was raised and lowered every day at the same time. The mercury barometer was thus placed in different atmospheric pressure zones every day at the same time, and the weather observations taken manually from the barometer every day at the same time could then be compared to previous days' observations. The first automatic weather station with a weather vane was constructed in the 1850s by Sir William Crookes, and the first automatic weather station that could record data was constructed in the 1860s by the Italian meteorologist Giovanni Cassini. Early automatic weather stations were set up by governments and research institutions, mostly in developed countries. In the 1930s, the first weather radar was developed, which enabled the detection of precipitation at a distance. Weather radars can be fixed or mobile, and can be used on ships, airplanes, and vehicles. The use of weather radar is particularly helpful for taking weather observations at night, when visibility is low. Many automated weather stations are part of a wider surface weather monitoring network, which are located at airports, marine ports, and other important locations. The most common weather variables measured by surface weather stations are: * air temperature and humidity * surface temperature (for ocean or soil) * atmospheric pressure * wind speed and direction * cloud cover * amount of precipitation * visibility * ultraviolet (UV) index A surface weather station can be equipped with additional sensors for other weather variables, such as: * ocean temperature and salinity * soil moisture and temperature * greenhouse gas concentrations * traffic conditions * lightning strike information * pollution (e.g., ozone and particulate matter) * noise level In addition, satellite data from a geostationary or polar-orbiting satellite can be used to supplement the data from surface weather stations, to obtain information on weather conditions over the oceans and remote areas, as well as information on the weather in the upper atmosphere. Weather radar data can also be used to supplement the data from surface weather stations, to obtain information on the weather within the atmosphere. When weather observations are taken automatically, the data obtained can be stored in a database, and can then be used in various ways. For example, the data can be used to issue weather forecasts, to issue severe weather warnings, and to study the weather and climate. The data can also be used in various weather forecasting models. Some weather stations are specialized and only measure one or two variables. For example, a station might measure just the wind speed and direction, or just the temperature and humidity. These stations are often called "micro stations". A weather station can be fixed ( stationery ), or mobile ( moving ). A fixed weather station is usually part of a network of weather stations that are spread over a large area, such as a country, state, region, or city. Abbey of Santissima Trinità The Abbey of Santissima Trinità is a former monastery of the Latin Rite Catholic Church located in Venosa, in the province of Potenza, Basilicata, Italy. It was founded in 1083 by the Norman Robert Guiscard, who built a church and a monastery on the site of a preexisting Byzantine church dedicated to the Holy Trinity. The new foundation, which soon acquired considerable landed property, was named for the Trinity and was called a monastery, but it was really a convent for women, housing daughters and widows of the nobility of Southern Italy. The church was completely rebuilt in the 18th century, but the monastery has maintained the original Norman structure. The church has a single, barrel-vaulted nave with side chapels. The exterior has a simple architecture, with a plain facade and a bell tower with a cusp. The interior of the church has noteworthy paintings, including a large canvas by Marco Basaiti, a native of nearby Melfi. This painting, located on the left wall of the church, depicts the Dead Christ and the Marys. Also in the church are works by Giuseppe Fumana and Carlo Cozza, who painted the altarpiece of the main altar. Since the 1970s the monastery has been the subject of restoration work, which has cleared the surrounding area and has disclosed the presence of other buildings, including a mill and a hostel for travelers. The monastery has a small library with precious illuminated manuscripts. In 2010, the Abbey of Santissima Trinità was selected to be one of the locations for the shooting of the television series Un ponte per amico, which is broadcast by the Italian channel RTI.

Garden designer A garden designer is someone who designs plans for gardens and other outdoor spaces. Garden designers may also use the term landscape architect. The term garden designer is pared with that of landscape architect in that both focus on the selection and production of plants. However, the main difference between the two is that a landscape architect focuses on the design of hard structures and other built aspects of a landscape, while a garden designer focuses on the selection and production of plants. Garden designers can be found working in a variety of settings. Some designers work for private homeowners, while others may work for large companies. Still, other garden designers may be self-employed. The work of a garden designer can range from simple to complex. For example, a garden designer may be hired to design a small flowerbed for a private residence. On the other hand, a garden designer may be hired to design a large park or other outdoor space. In addition to the design of plants and other aspects of a landscape, a garden designer may also be responsible for the construction of hard structures. For example, a garden designer may be responsible for the construction of a new pathway or the addition of a new structure to an existing landscape.

Screw (orman-dane) A screw is a type of fastener, in some ways similar to a bolt, typically made of metal, and characterized by a helical ridge, called a male thread. Screws are used to fasten materials by digging in and wedging into a material when turned, while the thread cuts grooves in the fastened material that allows it to hold. Screws are used in many applications, such as to fasten metal parts together and to fasten metal to wood. In these applications, screws have largely replaced nails, where nails are still used. The largest user of screws is the residential housing industry, where screws are used both to fasten wood to wood and to fasten metal to wood. The basic design of a screw can be divided into four parts: the head, the neck, the body, and the tip. The head is the part of the screw that is used to turn it. The head can be a variety of shapes, such as a button or a cross. In some applications, such as with a screw driver, the head can be a standard shape so that a variety of different screws can be turned with the same tool. The neck is the unthreaded part of the screw that is directly below the head. It is typically used to attach the head to the body. The body is the part of the screw that is threaded for most of its length. The body typically has a constant diameter, although some screws, such as lag screws, have a tapered body. The tip is the end of the screw that is opposite the head. The tip is typically pointed to allow the screw to be started in a surface. There are many different types of screws, all designed for different applications. Common types of screws include: Wood screws: used to fasten wood to wood and wood to metal Metal screws: used to fasten metal to metal and metal to wood Self-tapping screws: used to fasten metal to metal without the need for a pilot hole, sometimes called sheet metal screws Thread-forming screws: used to fasten metal to metal and metal to wood, also called thread-rolling screws Lag screws: used to fasten wood to wood Security screws: used to fasten a device so that it can not be easily unfastened In addition, there are many variants of the basic screw design, including: Screws with a variety of head designs Screws with a variety of body designs Screws with a variety of tip designs Screws used to fasten metal to metal and metal to wood are sometimes called metal screws. Metal screws are similar to wood screws, except that the shaft is threaded for most of its length. Metal screws can be used with nuts or screwed directly into a threaded receptacle to fasten metal parts together. Machine screws are similar to metal screws, except that they are designed to be used with a nut or threaded receptacle to fasten metal parts together. Self-tapping screws are used to fasten metal to metal without the need for a pilot hole. They are sometimes called sheet metal screws. Thread-forming screws are used to fasten metal to metal and metal to wood. They are also called thread-rolling screws. Screws used to fasten wood to wood are sometimes called wood screws. Wood screws are similar to metal screws, except that the shaft is not threaded for most of its length. Wood screws are designed to be used with a pilot hole. Lag screws are similar to wood screws, except that they have a much thicker shaft and a blunt tip. They are used to fasten wood to wood. Security screws are designed to be used to fasten a device so that it can not be easily unfastened. Security screws are typically used to fasten a license plate to a car or to fasten the cover of a computer port. A screw is used to fasten things together by turning it in the direction that causes the screw to dig in and wedge into a material. The screw is typically inserted into a pre-drilled hole, and as the screw is turned, the thread cuts grooves in the fastened material that allows it to hold. The first use of screws to fasten metal is believed to have been in the 15th century, in the Visby ship. Screws were used to hold pieces of wood together in the 17th century. Screws were used to fasten metal to wood in the 18th century. Screws were used to fasten metal to metal in the 19th century. The largest user of screws is the residential housing industry.

Alfred Robin (fl. 1120–1170) was an English medieval musician. Alfred Robin (or Robert) was born in England, possibly in London, and was a contemporary of the medieval composer and music theorist, Léonin. Robin was one of the early composers of organum, and his style is characterized by the use of drones and a certain amount of chromaticism. He may have been the teacher of the noted English composer, Thomas of England. Two of his works survive in the Old Hall Manuscript (British Library, Add. MS 5000), a collection of English music from the mid-12th century: a Magnus liber organi (Great book of organum) and a Nova organum experimentum (New book of organum). The Nova organum experimentum is in the form of a gradual, and the underlay of the parchment on which the music is written shows that it was originally part of a book of hours. The music of both works is in two-part organum. The styles of the two works are quite different, which has led scholars to suggest that they may have been written by different people. The composer of the Magnus liber organi is anonymous, but it has been suggested that this may be the work of Robin, as the style is similar to that of the Nova organum experimentum. Both works are edited and published in theCorpus Mensurabilis Musicae, vol. 72, by the Institute for Musicology of the Austrian Academy of Sciences.

The One with the Embryos written by David Crane and Marta Kauffman Uptown Dogs The gang debates the ethics of using embryos created by in vitro fertilization when one of their friends, Susan, asks if she should use a frozen embryo her ex-boyfriend created before they broke up. She wants to use the embryo to get pregnant, but her boyfriend, Barry, is hesitant because the child would be genetically his, but not biologically his. The gang talks about the morality of the issue, and how the child would feel knowing he or she was "adopted." Meanwhile, Chandler seeks to prove his masculinity by joining the "dudes" at the bar for a drinking marathon, but has to quit after two drinks when he gets too sick. He feels better when he realizes that he passed out before the other participants, and didn't lose his masculinity after all. This episode was inspired by David Crane's real life, when his girlfriend at the time wanted to use a frozen embryo to get pregnant, and he debated the morality of it. First appearance of: Michael Imperioli This episode was released as a single-sided optical disc in the UK, with the live-action opening credits on the reverse side. The original American broadcast had the animated opening credits.

David Hess (baseball) David Hess (born July 15, 1992) is an American professional baseball pitcher for the Washington Nationals of Major League Baseball (MLB). Hess was born in Houston, Texas, and attended Cypress Ranch High School. He played college baseball at Texas A&M University. He was not drafted in the MLB draft out of high school, and therefore enrolled at Texas A&M. After three years at Texas A&M, the Houston Astros selected Hess in the 13th round of the 2015 MLB draft. Hess made his professional debut with the Gulf Coast Astros and was later promoted to the Tri-City Valley Cats, registering a 4.35 ERA in 12 appearances. In 2016, he played for the Quad Cities River Bandits and Lancaster Jethawks, posting a 8-6 record and 3.74 ERA in 28 appearances. He split the 2017 season between the Buies Creek Astros and the Corpus Christi Hooks, posting a 7-6 record and 3.63 ERA with 78 strikeouts in 124.2 innings pitched. After the 2017 season, he played in the Arizona Fall League. He began 2018 with Corpus Christi and was promoted to the Fresno Grizzlies in May. In July, he was promoted to the major leagues for the first time as the backup to an injured Charlie Morton. He made his major league debut on July 29, pitching 3.1 innings in relief of Morton and earning the win in a 4–0 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. Hess was optioned to the minors on August 1, when the Astros activated Morton from the disabled list. He was recalled on August 6, when the team optioned Chris Devenski to the minors, and returned to the minors on August 15, when the Astros activated reliever Kenley Jansen from the disabled list. Hess was designated for assignment on November 6, 2018, following the acquisition of relief pitcher Robert Ozuna. On November 7, 2018, Hess was claimed off waivers by the Baltimore Orioles. He opened the 2019 season in the Orioles' bullpen, recording a 4.88 ERA in 21 appearances. On August 5, 2019, Hess was designated for assignment by the Orioles. He became a free agent following the 2019 season. On December 19, 2019, Hess signed a minor league contract with the Washington Nationals. He made the Opening Day roster in 2020, but was designated for assignment on August 31 after posting an 8.44 ERA in 13 appearances. He was brought back and designated for assignment three more times in 2020, spending the majority of the year at the club's alternate training site in Fredericksburg, Virginia. After recording a 3.48 ERA in 20 appearances for the 2021 Nationals, Hess was designated for assignment on August 10, 2021. He was released by the Nationals on September 8, 2021.

Oskar Karlweis (13 January 1927 – 25 June 2022) was a German politician of the Free Democratic Party (FDP). He was the chairman of his party in North Rhine-Westphalia from 1982 to 1990 and a member of the German federal parliament from 1987 to 1998. Karlweis was born in Bebra, Hesse, Germany. He studied law and political science at the universities of Marburg and Giessen. In 1952 he became a member of the liberal FDP, and from 1961 to 1975 he was the chairman of the FDP in Hesse. He also served as the party's spokesman on federal affairs. In 1975, he was elected to the federal executive committee of the FDP, and in 1982 he became the chairman of the FDP in North Rhine-Westphalia. In 1985 he was again elected to the federal executive committee of the FDP, this time as one of the party's federal vice-chairmen. Karlweis was a member of the German federal parliament from 1987 to 1998, representing the Siegen-Wittgenstein constituency of North Rhine-Westphalia. In 1990, he was the FDP's candidate for the office of Mayor of Berlin, but received only 2.9 percent of the vote in the first round, and thus came fifth behind the winning candidate, the independentChristiane Geithner. In 1998, he was again the FDP's candidate for Mayor of Berlin, but received only 1.5 percent of the vote in the first round, and thus came fifth behind the winning candidate, the Social Democrat Klaus Wowereit. Karlweis was married and had three children.

2011 Los Angeles Angels season The Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim had a very successful 2011 season, finishing with a record of 86–78. They finished the season in third place in the American League West, 17 games behind the division winner Texas Rangers. The third-place finish was the best the team had finished in the division since 1986, when the team finished in second place. The Angels made the playoffs for the second straight year, but lost to the Detroit Tigers in the American League Division Series. On October 3, 2010, the Angels hired Ron Washington to replace Mike Scioscia as manager. The move was controversial, as Scioscia had led the Angels to the only World Series title in franchise history in 2002, and the Angels made the playoffs in five of his 10 full seasons as manager. General manager Jerry Dipoto was fired by the Angels in October 2010, and was replaced by Billy Eppler. On May 6, 2011, the Angels promoted Mike Trout, a rookie outfielder, to their major league roster. Trout went on to win the American League Rookie of the Year Award, and make the All-Star Game. He also finished second in the American League MVP voting, behind Triple Crown winner Miguel Cabrera. The Angels got off to a slow start in 2011, and were 12 games below .500 (40–52) on August 1. The team went on a surge in the second half of the season, going 46–26 the rest of the way. The 46 wins in the second half of the season were the most by the Angels since the franchise moved to California in 1961. The Angels finished the season with an 86–78 record, good enough for third place in the American League West. The Angels made the playoffs for the second straight year. In the American League Division Series, the Angels faced the Detroit Tigers, who had finished the season with an 88–74 record, and had beaten the New York Yankees in the Wild Card Game. The series went to a full five games, with the Tigers winning the fifth game by a score of 9–1.

Troubadour style Troubadour style (French: Style Troubadour) is a type of poetic developed in Southern France during the 12th century, characterized by the use of octo- and decasyllabic verse (the so-called " vers") with eight or ten syllables per line, a caesura after the fourth or sixth syllable, and with rhymes (in the final verse) after every line. The name derives from the French wordtrouvaille, meaning "find", and was first applied to the poems of theTrouvères. Troubadour style is usually found in love poetry, although there are also religious and political examples. The poetry is characterized by the presence of a theme, usually expressed in the first person, in the form of a quest, in which the troubadour searches for a love interest, usually a woman, although there are also examples of men as the object of desire. The quest may be successful or not, but the poem is always written in a positive tone. The first lines of a troubadour poem are usually the most difficult, and are used to introduce the subject of the poem. The next lines are usually easier, and are used to describe the journey, and the final lines are used to describe the object of the troubadour's desire. Troubadour style was very popular in France and Italy during the 12th and 13th centuries, and was used by many poets, including theTrouvères, the Minnesänger, and the Dolce Stil Novo. Troubadour style differs from the earlier Anglo-Norman style in that it is usually octo- and decasyllabic, whereas the Anglo-Norman style is usually octo- and hendecasyllabic. It also differs from the later Petrarchan style in that it is usually not as complex or as condensed. Troubadour style is also used in Occitan, Catalan, Galician-Portuguese, and Spanish poetry. In music, a "troubadour style" or "trouvère style" is a type of song with a similar verse structure, usually with a repeating line, and with a refrain.

The European Association for Digital Humanities (EADH) is a non-profit organisation that was established in 1999 to promote and advance the field of Digital Humanities in Europe. It is an open association that brings together researchers, practitioners, and students from all over the world who are interested in the Digital Humanities. The EADH promotes the development and application of Digital Humanities methods and tools in all areas of research, as well as in education, cultural heritage, and public engagement. It advocates for the Digital Humanities at the European level and works to ensure that the field is recognised as a key player in shaping the future of scholarship and research. The EADH is a member of the European Federation of Digital Humanities (EDHI), which brings together Digital Humanities associations from across Europe. The EADH also works closely with other international organisations, such as the Alliance of Digital Humanities Organizations (ADHO) and the Digital Humanities Institute (DHI). The EADH organises the annual Digital Humanities Congress, which is a major conference for the Digital Humanities community in Europe. It also sponsors and organises other events and activities that promote the Digital Humanities, such as the Digital Humanities Summer School and the Digital Humanities Incubator. The EADH has members from all over Europe, as well as from other parts of the world. Its members include individuals, organisations, and institutions that are interested in the Digital Humanities.

Efrem Hill (November 7, 1927 – April 6, 2004) was an American bass-baritone who had an active performance career in concerts and in opera from the early 1950s until the mid-1970s. Born in Atlanta, Georgia, Hill moved with his family to Detroit, Michigan at the age of 13. After finishing high school he served in the United States Army from 1945 to 1946. He then attended the Detroit Institute of Music where he studied voice with Helen Neilly. In 1950 he entered the Eastman School of Music in New York City where he studied voice with Arthur Craft and Malcolm Martineau. He graduated from Eastman in 1953 with a Bachelor of Music degree. In 1953 Hill began his professional career singing with the New York City Opera. He remained with that company for three years, singing such roles as Figaro in The Barber of Seville, Guglielmo in Così fan tutte, and Silvio in Pagliacci. In 1956 he began performing with the New York Metropolitan Opera, where he sang for the next ten years. At the Met he was a frequent performer in the Sunday afternoon broadcasts of live opera performances, and was heard in more than thirty different roles. These included such varied characters as Figaro in The Barber of Seville, Guglielmo in Così fan tutte, Silvio in Pagliacci, Sharpless in Madama Butterfly, Figaro in The Marriage of Figaro, Guglielmo in Le nozze di Figaro, and Belcore in L'elisir d'amore. He also sang major roles with most of the other opera companies in the United States and was a regular guest artist at the San Francisco Opera and the Lyric Opera of Chicago. In 1960 he performed the role of Figaro in The Barber of Seville with the Los Angeles Civic Light Opera. After retiring from the stage in the mid-1970s, Hill embarked on a second successful career as a voice teacher. Among his notable students were the sopranos Lauren Flanigan and Christinafrieda Clausen. He died in Naples, Florida at the age of 76.

Hämeenlinna Hämeenlinna (Tavastia Proper) Hämeenlinna (The Häme Castle) Hämeenlinna is a city in the heart of the Häme region in the province of Southern Finland, 60 kilometres (37 mi) north of Tampere and 180 kilometres (110 mi) north-west of Helsinki. The population of Hämeenlinna was 49,451 in 2021, making it the 7th largest city in Finland. Hämeenlinna has a long history. It was first mentioned in 1546 as a resting place for the army of King Gustav Vasa on his way to the Battle of Aland. The city was originally named after the Häme Castle, the center of the medieval province of Häme. The castle is located in the very centre of the city. Hämeenlinna has always been an important location for the Finnish economy. In the 19th century, the city had Finland's largest agricultural machine factory, and in the 20th century, it became the home for the KONE corporation, the world's second largest elevator manufacturer. The city is home to two universities, the University of Häme and the Häme University of Applied Sciences (HAMK). The city has a population of about 20,000 students, which gives the city a youthful character. Hämeenlinna is also well-known for its historic buildings, such as the Vanamo House, which is the oldest surviving wooden house in Finland, and the Riihivaara House, which was designed by Carl Ludvig Engel and built in the neoclassical style. Hämeenlinna is also known for the Hämeenlinna block, a prison facility located in the city. The prison was originally built for the Russian army in the 19th century, and in the 20th century it was used as a prison for Finnish criminals. The prison has been the subject of many documentaries and has a reputation for being one of the most challenging prisons in Finland.

Teodósio, Prince of Brazil ( Portuguese: Teodósio, Príncipe do Brasil; born 3 November 1997) is the second son of the former Brazilian monarch, Prince Andrew of Brazil, and his wife, Princess Elisabeth of thomaland. He is a member of the former ruling Bragança dynasty of Brazil and, in accordance with the tradition of male primogeniture in the Brazilian royal family, is the heir apparent to the abolished throne of Brazil. Teodósio was born in Rio de Janeiro, where he lives with his family. He is the grandson of the late Princess Isabel of Brazil, the last monarch of Brazil, and the great-grandson of the last Brazilian emperor, Pedro II. In January 2023, the Brazilian government under President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva recognized Teodósio as the heir apparent to the abolished throne. Teodósio is a direct descendant of Emperor Pedro I, the first monarch of the independent Brazilian Empire, through his mother. He is also a direct descendant of King Louis I of Portugal through his father.

Alvaro de Zúñiga y Guzmán, 1st Marquess of Villamanrique (1458–1528), called "the Good Marquess", was an Spanish noble and statesman, the son of Juan de Zúñiga y Pimentel, Duke of Béjar, and his second wife, Mencía de Guzmán y de Castilla. Alvaro de Zúñiga was born in Plasencia, Cáceres, in 1458, the son of Juan de Zúñiga y Pimentel, Duke of Béjar, and his second wife, Mencía de Guzmán y de Castilla, daughter of Juan de Guzmán, Count of El Pestillo. His mother was the sister of Juan de Guzmán, Count of Plasencia. He had two brothers, Juan and Rodrigo, and two sisters, Isabell and Mencía. He married Sancha de Luna, Lady of Pedraza, daughter of Juan de Luna, Lord of Pedraza, with whom he had three children: Juan de Zúñiga y Luna, 2nd Marquess of Villamanrique, Isabel de Zúñiga, who married Diego de Velasco, 5th Count of Haro, and Sancha de Zúñiga, who married Juan Téllez-Girón, 4th Count of Ureña. After the death of his father in 1495, he became the 3rd Duke of Béjar, although he had already been referring to himself as "Duke of Béjar" since at least 1481. In 1497 he became the 3rd Count of Plasencia. In 1511 he was created the 1st Marquess of Villamanrique by Ferdinand II of Aragon. He was a politician, ambassador, and statesman, and an important figure in the court of Ferdinand and Isabella. He was a member of the Council of the Realm, and served as Chief Councilor to Ferdinand, who held him in great esteem. He also served as Ambassador to England. He spent many years in the service of the crown, travelling all over the country, and acquiring a great deal of wealth. In 1520, he founded the Hospital de la Sangre in Madrid, and in 1524, he founded the Hospital de Nuestra Señora de la Otra Vez, also in Madrid. He died in Madrid in 1528, and was buried in the church of the Monastery of Las Descalzas Reales, which he had founded.

Folashade Oluwafemiayo, OON (born 5 May 1965) is a Nigerian professor of law and was the vice-chancellor of the University of Lagos from 2016 to 2019. She was the first woman to hold the position since the university was established in 1962. In 2019, Oluwafemiayo was conferred with the award of the Officer of the Order of the Niger (OON) by President Muhammadu Buhari. ## Early life and education Folashade Oluwafemiayo was born on 5 May 1965, in Ilorin, Kwara State, Nigeria. She attended St. James' Primary School, Ilorin (1971–1977), and then Bishop Smith Secondary School, Ilorin (1978–1982), for her secondary education. She proceeded to the Ahmadu Bello University, Zaria, where she obtained her Bachelor of Laws (LL.B) degree in 1986 and her Master of Laws (LL.M) degree in 1987. In 1990, she attended the University of London, where she obtained her Master of Laws (LL.M) degree in International and Comparative Law. In 1992, she attended the Nigeria Institute of Advanced Legal Studies, where she obtained a Certificate in Advanced Legislative Drafting. In 2013, she attended the Harvard Kennedy School, Harvard University, where she obtained a Certificate in Public Leadership. ## Career Folashade Oluwafemiayo started her career as an assistant lecturer at the Kaduna State College of Legal Studies, Kaduna, in 1987. In 1988, she became a tutor at the Nigeria Institute of Advanced Legal Studies, Lagos, and was there until 1991. She was an associate lecturer at the University of Calabar, Cross River State, from 1991 to 1992, and was a senior lecturer at the Rivers State College of Legal Studies, Port Harcourt, from 1992 to 2000. She was appointed a professor of law at the Rivers State University of Science and Technology, Port Harcourt, in 2000, and was there until 2013. In 2013, she was appointed a professor of law at the University of Lagos, and in 2015, she became the dean of the Faculty of Law, University of Lagos. On 17 November 2016, she was appointed the vice-chancellor of the University of Lagos, becoming the first woman to hold the position since the university was established in 1962. She was also the first female to be appointed a vice-chancellor in any state-owned university in Nigeria. ## Awards and honours In 2005, Folashade Oluwafemiayo was awarded the Nigerian Law Award for outstanding contributions to the development of law in Nigeria. In 2006, she was awarded the Martin Luther King Jr. Non-Violent Peace Prize for her efforts in promoting and encouraging non-violence in the resolution of conflicts in Nigeria. In 2007, she was awarded the Junior Chamber International's (JCI) Ten Outstanding Young Persons of the World (TOYP) Award for her contributions to the development of education in Nigeria. In 2008, she received the African Women Award for her contributions to the development of education in Africa. In 2011, she was awarded the Business & Legal Award for her contributions to the development of business and law in Nigeria. In 2019, she was conferred with the award of the Officer of the Order of the Niger (OON) by President Muhammadu Buhari. ## Personal life Folashade Oluwafemiayo is married to Adewale Oluwafemiayo, a professor of architecture and the director-general of the Lagos State Public Service Staff Development Centre. They have three children.

Hallgeir Pedersen (born 1 July 1961) is a Norwegian jazz drummer. Pedersen was born in Oslo. He is the son of the jazz pianist Erling Pedersen, and the brother of the jazz trumpeter Tom Olstad. He was self-taught and started playing the drums at the age of six, and played his first gig at the age of eight. In 1980 he joined the band "T038" (Tee-o-38), with whom he recorded two albums. The band won the first prize at the Jazz Band of the Year competition in 1985, and the following year they changed their name to "Subtonic". Pedersen was also a member of "B tonal" from 1983 to 1985, and "Safespring" from 1987 to 1989. In 1989, he joined the band "Police at Norway". In 1990, he was a member of the band "Delux", and in 1991 he joined the band "Puma" with whom he recorded two albums. In 1994, he played with the band "Big Bang" and in 1996 he joined the band "SurfAid" and recorded two albums with them. In 2000, he was a member of the band "Dugway". He has also played with the bands "Trickshot", "Batasa", "Delta Blues Band", "Bustin' Babes", and "Mississippi Delta".

Night Without End is a 1985 British horror film directed by Mike Hodges and starring Lee Montgomery, Ann Bell, David Collings, and Brian Glover. The film is set in the early 20th century and follows a series of murders in a German castle. The film was shot in Britain and West Germany. It was released in the United States as Time Without End. The film is set in a German castle in the early 20th century. The castle's owner, Count Karl Von Drummond (David Collings), invites several guests to stay with him for a hunting party. The guests include Scientists Sir Basil Thistleton (Montgomery), Professor Helius (Glover), and Dr. Max Nett (Jurgens), along with Count's sister, Baroness Elsa (Ann Bell), and Elsa's husband, Baron Karl (Michael Hoger). The castle's priest, Father Joseph (Leo Genn), and the Count's servant, Hoffman (Brendan Price), round out the guests. The film opens with a quote from William Blake: "Tyger, tyger, burning bright, in the forests of the night; what immortal hand or eye, could frame thy fearful symmetry?" A series of murders begin to occur, seemingly at random, and the guests begin to suspect that the Count is responsible. As the film progresses, it is revealed that the murders are connected, and that they are all part of a larger plot to be carried out by the Count. As the film reaches its climax, it is revealed that the Count has been carrying out the murders in an attempt to create a perfect being, a "superior species", by combining the best features of each of the guests. The Count's plan is to kill all of the guests and create this new species from their combined DNA. The new species will have the intelligence of Basil, the strength of the Baron, the compassion of Elsa, the religious faith of Father Joseph, and the servitude of Hoffman. The film ends with the Count killing the remaining guests and attempting to carry out his plan. However, the new species is born with a deformity, and the Count is killed by the angry mob that has gathered outside the castle.

Lucas aggregate supply function The Lucas aggregate supply function is an economic model of the supply of aggregate goods and services by an economy. It was first developed by the British economist, Dennis Arthur Lucas (1920–2002), in his contribution to the Handbook of Macroeconomics, in 1982. Lucas subsequently developed the model in a number of papers, in which he showed how the model could be used to explain many features of the business cycle, such as the rationale for stabilization policy. The Lucas aggregate supply function is a development of the trend GDP model, which is a simple model in which the economy's output is represented as a trend (a long-term movement) plus a cyclical component. The Lucas aggregate supply function has two components: a trend component, which is determined by the size of the labour force and the capital stock, and a cyclical component, which is determined by the difference between the natural rate of unemployment and the actual rate of unemployment. The natural rate of unemployment is the rate of unemployment that exists when the economy is at its long-term trend rate of output. The Lucas aggregate supply function can be used to explain why economies can experience high unemployment for several years after a recession has started. This is because the cyclical component of the supply function shifts downward when the economy is in a recession, and it takes several years for the natural rate of unemployment to decline to the actual rate of unemployment.

Kehkashan Basu is a Canadian-Indian environmentalist and the winner of the 2016 Diana Award, the highest honour a Canadian can receive for contributions to the world of conservation and sustainability. Basu was named as the winner of the 2017 International Children's Peace Prize, in recognition of her work to protect the environment. Basu is the founder-director of the non-governmental organization (NGO) Green Hope Foundation, which works to promote a sustainable lifestyle among young people. In 2013, Basu launched the "Green Hope: Mission Solar" campaign to raise awareness about solar energy. The campaign was supported by actor Jackky Bhagnani and the channel Star Plus. In 2015, Basu founded the "Climate Action Network" with the goal of empowering young people to fight climate change. In the same year, Basu was also named as the face of the "Clean India Project", a campaign to promote a cleaner environment in India. In 2016, Basu was named as one of the "Top 25 under 25" by the Canadian magazine Maclean's. The same year, she was also named as the winner of the Diana Award, for her work with Green Hope Foundation. In 2017, Basu was named as the winner of the International Children's Peace Prize, in recognition of her work to protect the environment.
