Platon Alexeevich Obukhov (Russian: Плато́н Алексе́евич Обу́хов; 16 December [O.S. 4 December] 1898 – 1 November 1987) was a Russian Soviet meteorologist and hydrographer, oceanologist, and academician (1969). Obukhov was born in Moscow. He was a student of the outstanding Soviet meteorologist Alexander Vil'mont, and began his scientific career in the field of atmospheric physics, studying the physics of rain and the structure of clouds. In the 1930s, he became interested in the problems of the World Ocean, and turned to the field of hydrography. He proposed a system of Recording bottles for the Collection of a water sample from a given depth, the so-called Obukhov system, which was widely used by oceanographers for several decades. In the field of physical oceanography, he is known for the theory of the wind-driven circulation of the World Ocean, the so-called Obukhov circulation, which is an important element of the large-scale circulation of the World Ocean. In the theory of ocean waves, he is the author of the so-called Obukhov equation. Obukhov was a member of the Editorial Board of the journal Oceanology from 1965 to 1986, and was the editor of the Soviet Hydrology Journal from 1950 to 1985. He was a Corresponding Member of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR from 1946, and a Full Member of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR from 1953. He was also a Full Member of the Russian Academy of Sciences from 1990. Obukhov was awarded the State Prize of the USSR (1946), the Lenin Prize (1970), the USSR Academy of Sciences' V.I. Vernadsky Prize (1986), and the Russian Federation's State Prize (1994).

Anne Woodroffe (born 30 September 1952) is a British actress, best known for her role as Dr. Elizabeth Carlyle in the BBC soap opera Doctors. She has also appeared in other British soaps such as EastEnders, Holby City, and Casualty. Woodroffe was born in Birmingham, England, and trained at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (RADA), where she won the Mary Selway Award for outstanding achievement. She has worked extensively in theatre, film, and television since the early 1970s. Her television credits include: Z-Cars, Crossroads, The X-Files, Touched by an Angel, Baywatch, and She-Wolf of London. She also appeared in the video game Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater as the voice of Campbell. In 2006, she was cast as Dr. Elizabeth Carlyle in Doctors, after being spotted by the show's casting director. Her first episode as Carlyle was broadcast on 7 February 2007. She had previously appeared in the show as several other characters. Her last appearance in Doctors was on 14 October 2016, after which her character was written out.

Ada Bittenbender (11 January 1901 – 18 November 1950) was a German stage and film actress. Bittenbender was born in Berlin, the daughter of a civil servant, and grew up in the city's Charlottenburg district. After completing her schooling she attended the Deutsche Tanz- und Kunstschule, a dance school in Berlin. She subsequently became a member of the chorus of the Berlin State Opera, and then a pupil of the opera singer Ernst Haefliger. She made her stage debut in 1922 at the Lessingtheater in the role of Hilde in a performance of the operetta The White Horse Inn, and subsequently appeared in numerous plays and operettas, including the premiere of the operetta The Sultan's Court in 1924. She also performed at the Magic Theatre in Berlin. Bittenbender began to appear in films in the late 1920s, and in 1930 she starred in the German film version of The White Horse Inn, replacing the American actress Helen Twelvetrees who had played the role of Hilde in the original Hollywood production. She subsequently appeared in a number of German-language films, including the 1936 German film version of Pygmalion, in which she played the role of Eliza Doolittle. She also appeared in several films directed by Paul May, including the comedy The Model Husband (1937) and the drama The Fox of Glenarvon (1940). Her final film appearance was in the German drama His Royal Highness (1950). Bittenbender was married to the actor Hans Schlenck, and the couple had one daughter. She died in Berlin at the age of 49 from complications following a stomach ulcer.

John Moore, Baron Moore of Lower Marsh was an English businessman, politician, and philanthropist. Born in Marylebone, London, the son of a leather factor, Moore was initially employed as a clerk by the London and County Banking Company, before becoming a partner in the firm of John Jones and Co., Factors and Commission Agents, and then setting up his own business as a commission agent, John Moore and Co., in 1842. In 1860, he took his brother, William, into partnership, and the firm was renamed John Moore and Brothers. The firm was a great success, and the business expanded to include estate agency, and, in 1889, it was floated on the London Stock Exchange as Moore and Sons, Limited. The firm was a large employer in the Marylebone area, and also had offices in Paris and Milan. In 1871, Moore bought the estate of Marylebone from the Duke of Portland for £250,000. In addition to his business interests, Moore was also a property developer, and the next twenty years saw the rapid development of the area, with many of the fine houses in the Portland Place and Wimpole Street areas being built during this period. Politically, Moore was a Liberal, and in 1880 he was elected as one of the first London County councillors for the Marylebone East division. In 1885, he was elected to the House of Commons as one of the two members for Marylebone West, and he held the seat until he was defeated in 1900. In 1898, he was raised to the peerage as Baron Moore of Lower Marsh, in the County of London. Lord Moore was also a generous philanthropist, and gave large sums of money for the benefit of his employees and the local community. He provided a hospital and an infirmary for his staff, and also contributed towards the cost of building a new church in nearby St John's Wood, where many of his employees lived. He also funded the building of a large public hall in Marylebone, which was named after him. Lord Moore died in April 1911, aged 75. He is buried in the eastern section of Highgate Cemetery.

Two Against the World is a 1932 American pre-Code drama film directed by James Tinling and written by Frank Condon and James Tinling, adapted from the play by Frank Condon. The film stars Paul Lukas, Ann Dvorak, and Lee Tracy. It is based on the true story of a con man who was tried for killing a cardsharp, and was the basis for the 1952 film High Noon. In the small town of Yellow Sky, Texas, secretary Mary Joe Farrow (Ann Dvorak) is being courted by two men, one a local cattleman named Henry Drummond (Paul Lukas), the other a shifty stranger named Martin Bales (Lee Tracy). Mary Joe is aware that Bales has a reputation as a "con man" but he talks his way out of her suspicions, and she falls in love with him. When Bales' past catches up with him, he murders a cardsharp named Steve Ransom (Prudence Bradley) and escapes from the town with Mary Joe. The local sheriff, Jake Pierce ( Forrest Tucker), assembles a posse to go after Bales. The film is a chase film, similar to The Texas Rangers, with the addition of a love triangle. It differs from the later High Noon in that the hero is not a lawman, but an ordinary man on the run with a woman he loves. Two Against the World was the fourth film in a series of six "A" pictures for which 20th Century Fox borrowed Lee Tracy from M-G-M; the others were The Rich Man and the Poor Man, The Power and the Glory, The Mad Dog of Europe, Charlie Chan in London, and Hot Saturday.

George Woolf (born Goldie Woolf; January 21, 1898 – February 10, 1946) was an American Hall of Fame jockey. Born in San Francisco, California, Woolf was Jewish. His parents were Louis and Anna (Drezner) Woolf. He had two older brothers, Sam and Phil, and a younger sister, Frances. The family lived at 1204 O'Farrell Street in San Francisco, close to the old Civic Center, where the family's relatives, the Mayberg family, owned a clothing store. Woolf attended the United States Military Academy at West Point, New York, on a football scholarship, where he was a teammate of future General Dwight D. Eisenhower. However, he injured his knee and was unable to continue with the sport. Woolf then began his career as a jockey in 1918. He won his first race at the age of 20 at the Oakland Race Course in Oakland, California. In 1922 he was one of the first jockeys to ride a winner at Santa Anita Park, in Arcadia, California. He was the leading jockey at the park that year. In 1923 he was the leading jockey at Del Mar Racetrack in Del Mar, California. Woolf was the jockey of the future Hall of Fame inductee Sir Barton when he won the first American Triple Crown in 1919. He also rode on two other Triple Crown winners, Sir Beldon and Morvich. Woolf won the Kentucky Derby in 1925 and 1926. He also won the Preakness Stakes in 1925 and the Belmont Stakes in 1926. In addition, Woolf won the Travers Stakes four times, the Wilson Stakes, the Continental Turf Handicap, the Chicago Derby, the Washington Park Derby, and the Oak Park Derby. Woolf was the regular rider of the Hall of Fame inductee Zev, on whom he won the 1927 Hollywood Gold Cup. Woolf died in a plane crash on February 10, 1946, in Berkeley, California. He was survived by his wife, Beverly, and two children, George and June.

Jean Baptiste Bissot, Sieur de Vincennes (c. 1700 – 1754) was a Canadian explorer, soldier, and fur trader. Born in New France, Bissot joined the military and was sent to Fort de Buade (Fort Michilimackinac) in 1721. He was sent to the western territories the following year, and was one of the first Europeans to travel through the area that would become the state of Indiana. He established a trading post at Kekionga, near the site of the future Fort Wayne. In 1725, he explored the region to the south and east of Lake Erie, reaching as far as the Ohio River and Lake Chautauqua. Bissot was commandant of Fort de Buade from 1729 to 1731. He was captured by the British in the War of the Austrian Succession, and was held prisoner in England for two years. He was released in 1744, and returned to Canada, where he was appointed as a captain in the French colonial troops. In 1747, he was sent to Fort de Buade for a second time, where he remained until the fort was destroyed by the British in 1754, during the Seven Years' War. Jean Baptiste Bissot, Sieur de Vincennes was born in Montreal, New France, around 1700. His father, Jean Bissot, was a French colonist and a soldier in the French colonial troops. His mother was Louise Dugué, the daughter of a French colonist and an Ottawa woman. In 1721, Bissot joined the military and was sent to Fort de Buade (Fort Michilimackinac), a French fort and trading post on Lake Huron. The following year, he was sent to the western territories with orders to find a route to the Mississippi River and to establish trading posts in the area. He was one of the first Europeans to travel through the area that would become the state of Indiana. In 1723, Bissot established a trading post at Kekionga, a portage between the St. Joseph and St. Marys rivers near the site of the future Fort Wayne. He was joined there by his younger brother, Antoine Bissot. The brothers established another trading post at Fort Crevecoeur, on the Illinois River. In 1725, Bissot explored the region to the south and east of Lake Erie, reaching as far as the Ohio River and Lake Chautauqua. He was the first European to explore the area that would become the Western Reserve in Ohio. In 1726, Bissot was sent to Fort Niagara, where he was put in charge of recruiting Native Americans for the French military. He was at Fort Niagara for only a few months, as he was ordered to return to Fort de Buade in the spring of 1727. Bissot was commandant of Fort de Buade from 1729 to 1731. In 1731, he was succeeded by his younger brother, Antoine Bissot. In 1739, Bissot was sent to Fort de Buade for a third time, as commandant. He was still in command of the fort in 1745, when he was captured by the British and taken to England as a prisoner of war. He was released in 1747, and returned to Canada, where he was appointed as a captain in the French colonial troops. In 1751, Bissot was sent to Fort de Buade for a fourth time, as commandant. He remained at the fort until 1754, when the fort was destroyed by the British during the Seven Years' War. Bissot died at Fort de Buade in 1754, and was buried there. The location of his grave is unknown.

Rashid Al-Mannai (born 1977) is a Qatari rally driver. He is one of the first Qatari drivers to compete in the World Rally Championship (WRC). He made his debut in the series at the 2008 Qatar National Rally, which was the opening round of that year's World Rally Championship, driving a Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution X for the QMM Team. In 2010, Al-Mannai won the FIA Middle East Rally Championship (MERC) with a record points score in the series. He won the 2011 Qatar Rally, the opening round of that year's World Rally Championship, after winning two of the three legs, beating out Qatar's Nasser Al-Attiyah, who was making his return to the series after a five-year absence. He won the 2012 Qatar Rally for the second consecutive year, beating out a field of 78 cars, after coming first in the event's final leg. In 2013, Al-Mannai finished second in the Qatar Rally, after losing the event by one second to his Qatari compatriot Nasser Al-Attiyah. He finished fourth in the 2014 event. In 2015, Al-Mannai finished second in the Qatar Rally, after losing the event by one second to his Qatari compatriot Nasser Al-Attiyah. He finished third in the 2016 and 2017 events.

Apocalypse Production Crew is an American television production company founded in 2005 by David Michael Latt, which specializes in horror and science fiction programming. The company's name is derived from the Greek word "apocalypse", which means "revelation" or "disclosure". In 2005, Latt founded the company after producing the first season of the television series Undead. Since then, the company has produced a number of horror and science fiction television series, including The Walking Dead, Fear the Walking Dead, Gangs of London, The 100, and Z Nation. In 2017, the company launched a subsidiary, Valhalla Entertainment, which focuses on developing original television series, films, and digital content. The company has also produced a number of horror and science fiction films, including The Task, Hell House LLC, and The Doomsday Device. In 2015, the company launched a podcast network, The Apocalyptic Network, which features a number of podcasts related to horror and science fiction. In 2018, the company launched a streaming service, The Apocalyptic Cinema Club, which features a number of horror and science fiction films and television series.

The 1998 Northern Territory referendum was a referendum held in the Northern Territory on Saturday, 30 November 1998, to determine whether the Northern Territory should become a state of Australia. A majority of the voters voted in favour of the question "Are you in favour of the Northern Territory becoming a State?" and the referendum passed. The result was 56.9% in favour (31,928 votes) and 43.1% against (22,232 votes). The Northern Territory was previously administered as part of the Northern Territory (NT) Australia Act 1978, which also provided for the possibility of the Territory becoming a state. The Act was amended in 1994 to provide that if the Territory was to become a state, it would be known as the Northern Territory. The Constitution of Australia did not provide for the creation of new states, and the legal questions surrounding the process were not completely settled. The referendum was the third attempt to make the Northern Territory a state, following earlier referendums in 1967 and 1974, which failed with 52% and 54% of the vote, respectively. The 1998 referendum resulted in a change to the Australian Constitution to allow the Northern Territory to become a state, if they so choose. The referendum also provided for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) to become a state, if a majority of its voters so choose. However, unlike the Northern Territory, the ACT did not achieve the required majority, with the vote being 52% in favour and 48% against. The referendum also had other changes to the Constitution, including to provide that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people would be counted in the census and to allow the Australian Parliament to legislate for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people living in the Northern Territory.

The Optimists of Nine Elms In the early part of the 20th century, a group of Jewish boxers based in the London borough of Lambeth, particularly in the area of Nine Elms, earned the nickname "The Optimists of Nine Elms" because of their cheerful attitude and their ability to always look on the bright side of things no matter how bad their circumstances were. The term was coined by the American boxer and manager Jack "Kid" Berg, who trained at the noted Jewish Lads' Club in the area. Berg explained that he had given the fighters this nickname because of their ability to stay positive and look to the future despite the fact that they were often poor and had problems with anti-Semitism. The Optimists of Nine Elms were known for their exceptional ability to take a punch, as well as their ability to give one. They were also known for their durability and their ability to keep fighting no matter how tough the odds were. The group was made up of fighters such as Morris "The Bluebell" Abrahams, who was the British lightweight champion, and Harry "Kid" Booth, who was the British featherweight champion. Both of these fighters were known for their ability to take a punch and their durability. The Optimists of Nine Elms were also known for their ability to make the most of their opportunities. For example, when Harry "Kid" Berg was given the opportunity to fight for the British featherweight title, he took advantage of the opportunity and won the title. In addition to being known for their ability to take a punch and their durability, the Optimists of Nine Elms were also known for their ability to stay positive and look to the future. They were always optimistic about their chances of success, no matter how tough the odds were. The Optimists of Nine Elms were a group of fighters who were known for their ability to take a punch, their durability, and their ability to stay positive and look to the future. They were a group of fighters who were always optimistic about their chances of success, no matter how tough the odds were.

NDISWrapper is a free and open-source software driver wrapper that enables the use of Microsoft Windows network drivers on Linux, FreeBSD, NetBSD, OpenBSD, Mac OS X, and other Unix-like operating systems. It is implemented as a loadable kernel module, and uses the existing Linux kernel framework for supporting Microsoft Windows drivers. Microsoft Windows network drivers are generally designed to run only on Microsoft Windows, and are not compatible with Unix-like operating systems. NDISWrapper provides a kernel-level compatibility layer that enables Windows drivers to run on Unix-like systems by implementing a subset of the Windows NDIS (Network Driver Interface Specification) API. NDISWrapper is free software, released under the GNU General Public License. Microsoft does not provide NDIS compatibility for Unix-like systems, but some network manufacturers provide Unix drivers for their products. In other cases, NDISWrapper can be used to provide compatibility with Microsoft drivers. When used in conjunction with the Wine Windows compatibility layer, NDISWrapper can enable a Unix-like system to use Windows-only networking hardware or software. Wine provides an implementation of the Windows NT kernel API, and NDISWrapper provides an implementation of the Windows NDIS API. NDISWrapper was originally developed by Martin Pool as an undergraduate project at the University of Cambridge. It is currently maintained by Artyom Tarasov and is included in most popular Linux distributions, including Debian, Ubuntu, Red Hat Enterprise Linux, CentOS, Fedora, Slackware, and FreeBSD. It is also included in the ports tree of NetBSD and OpenBSD, and can be compiled from source on most Unix-like systems.

Reijo Taipale (born January 1945) is a Finnish former rally driver. He was born in Hollola, located in the province of Häme, which is also the home town of Reijo's father, Eino Taipale, who was also a rally driver. After winning the Finnish Rally Championship in 1972, Reijo Taipale became the first Finn to win the Safari Rally in Kenya in 1973. He finished second in the World Rally Championship in 1973, and third in the world in 1974. After finishing second in the Safari Rally in 1975, Reijo Taipale won the world championship in 1976, ahead of his teammate and countryman Hannu Mikkola. During his career, he also won the 1000 Lakes Rally in Finland in 1972, the Safari Rally in Kenya in 1973, the Critérium des Cévennes in France in 1973, the Circuit of Ireland in Ireland in 1974, the 1000 Lakes Rally in Finland in 1975, the Safari Rally in Kenya in 1978, and the Critérium des Cévennes in France in 1978. After retiring from competitions, Reijo Taipale became the managing director of the Finnish Ford Motor Company in the early 1980s, and later the Finnish Toyota dealer. In 1988, he was the founder of the Toyota Team Europe, which evolved into the present Toyota Gazoo Racing Team.

Stranger in the City is a 2004 American drama film written and directed by James Ivory, produced by Ismail Merchant, and starring Richard Gere and Ben Kingsley. The film is set in Bombay (now Mumbai), India, and was shot on location there. Stranger in the City is the final film to be directed by James Ivory, the last film to be produced by Ismail Merchant, and the final film in the Merchant-Ivory Productions library. At the 2004 Cannes Film Festival, where the film premiered, Richard Gere won the prize for Best Actor. Gere plays a lonely American diamond merchant whose life is changed when he meets a lively but suspicious Indian man (played by Ben Kingsley). The two men become friends and change each other's lives. The film is a tribute to Mumbai, which Ivory has called his "spiritual home". In the film, Gere plays Victor Miesel, a Jewish American who is the head of a diamond company and lives with his Jewish American wife, Carmichael (and her mother), in a luxurious apartment in Mumbai, with a view of the Arabian Sea. However, his wife and mother-in-law do not get along with Victor, and his wife is having an affair with his business partner. One day, while jogging on the beach, Victor sees a Parsi-Indian man, who goes by the name "Bombay" (played by Kingsley), sitting on the sand, watching the ocean. The two men strike up a conversation and become friends. Bombay tells Victor that he is a wealthy man who is tired of his wealth and his arranged marriage to a Parsi woman, and that he wants to shed his identity and live as a poor man. At first, Victor does not realize that Bombay is not poor, as he lives in a luxurious apartment and drives a Mercedes-Benz. But when Victor visits Bombay's apartment, he meets Bombay's servant, who tells Victor that his master is not poor, and is still married. Undeterred, Victor continues to visit Bombay, and the two men become good friends. Bombay suggests that Victor should get rid of all his possessions and live as a poor man. But Victor cannot bring himself to do so, because of his strong attachment to his possessions and his sense of responsibility toward his business. In the end, Victor is unable to follow Bombay's way of life, and Bombay says goodbye to him. But before he leaves, Bombay tells Victor that he will always be a "stranger in the city" of Mumbai.

Feleti Sevele (born 3 November 1967) is a Niuean politician. Sevele was born in Niue. He was educated at St. Joseph's School, Niue, and then at Auckland University, New Zealand, where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in 1989. He returned to Niue and was a civil servant for four years, before moving to New Zealand in 1993, where he was a community worker for six years. In 1999, he was elected to the Niue Assembly as a member for the village of Hakupu, and was appointed Minister of Finance and Economic Development in the Cabinet of Sir Sionetama. He retained his seat in the 2002 election, winning the highest number of votes in any constituency. He was re-appointed Minister of Finance and Economic Development in the Cabinet of Young Vivian. In the 2004 election, he was again re-elected to the Niue Assembly, winning the highest number of votes in any constituency for the third consecutive time, and was appointed Minister of Finance, Economic Development, and Health in the Cabinet of Sir Sionetama. In the 2008 election, he was again re-elected to the Niue Assembly, winning the highest number of votes in any constituency for the fourth consecutive time, and was appointed Minister of Finance, Economic Development, and Infrastructure in the Cabinet of Sir Toke Talagi. In the 2011 election, he was re-elected to the Niue Assembly and was appointed Minister of Finance, Economic Development, and Information in the Cabinet of Sir Toke Talagi. In 2014, he was again re-elected to the Niue Assembly and was appointed Minister of Finance, Economic Development, and Natural Resources in the Cabinet of Sir Toke Talagi. Sevele was the Niuean delegate to the United Nations General Assembly from 1999 to 2014, and was the Niuean delegate to the United Nations Economic and Social Council from 2004 to 2014. He was also the Niuean delegate to the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization from 1999 to 2014. Sevele was the Niuean delegate to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation from 1999 to 2014, and was the Niuean delegate to the Pacific Community from 1999 to 2014. Sevele was the Niuean delegate to the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank Group from 1999 to 2014. Sevele was the Niuean delegate to the Organization of American States from 1999 to 2014. Sevele was the Niuean delegate to the United Nations Environmental Program from 1999 to 2014. Sevele was the Niuean delegate to the United Nations Human Settlements Program from 1999 to 2014. 2010 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team The 2010 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team represented the University of Nebraska–Lincoln in the 2010 NCAA Division I FBS football season. The team was coached by Bo Pelini and played their home games at Memorial Stadium in Lincoln, Nebraska. They were members of the Big 12 Conference. They finished the season 7–6, 4–5 in Big 12 play. The Cornhuskers began the season with a home loss to the Oregon Ducks, a team on a national championship run, and a road loss to the Missouri Tigers, a team that would finish ranked in the top 10. Nebraska then beat both teams that would finish ranked lower than them: the Washington Huskies and the Colorado Buffaloes. After a loss to the Texas A&M Aggies, Nebraska beat the Kansas Jayhawks, a team they had not beaten since 1968, and the Oklahoma Sooners, a team they had not beaten since 2002. These two wins helped Nebraska achieve bowl eligibility for the first time since 2004. The Cornhuskers were invited to the 2010 Holiday Bowl, where they lost to the Washington Huskies, 23–17, in a repeat of their regular season game. The Cornhuskers finished the season with four All-Big 12 Conference First Team selections: Ndamukong Suh (defensive tackle), Prince Amukamara (defensive back), Alex Henery (placekicker), and Roy Helu Jr. (running back). Amukamara and Henery were also named to the 2010 College Football All-America Team. This was the final season for long-time athletic director and former Nebraska football player Tom Osborne, who retired after the 2010 season.

Battle of Yongsan The Battle of Yongsan was fought during the Korean War, on August 4, 1950, in Yongsan, South Korea, a district of Seoul, by United Nations (UN) forces against the North Korean People's Army (NKPA). The battle was a victory for the UN forces, and resulted in the destruction of the Yongsan district. On June 25, 1950, the NKPA invaded South Korea. The United States and other UN members responded by forming the UN Force Korea (UFK), and sending troops to South Korea to defend the country. By August 4, the NKPA had successfully occupied most of South Korea, and was closing in on the capital city of Seoul. In an attempt to push the NKPA out of Seoul, the UFK launched a counterattack on the city. The battle for Seoul began on July 5, 1950, with the Battle of Inchon, and continued with the Battle of Anzio, and the Battle of Yongsan. The UFK forces were successful in liberating the city on September 27, 1950. The battle for Yongsan began on August 4, 1950, when the NKPA attacked the city. The UFK forces defended the city, and by August 5, they had pushed the NKPA out of the city. The UFK then began a counterattack, and by August 7, they had driven the NKPA out of the city, and had taken control of the city. The UFK forces then began a major offensive in the area, and by August 10, they had driven the NKPA out of the city, and had taken control of the city. The offensive was successful, and the UFK forces were able to drive the NKPA out of the city, and had taken control of the city.

White Face White Face is an underground hip hop artist from Toronto, Ontario, Canada. He is signed to the influential American hip hop label Strange Music, and is a part of the group ¡MAYDAY! alongside fellow Canadian and Strange Music labelmate ¡MURSDAY!. White Face grew up in Toronto and was first introduced to hip hop at the age of eight, when his father gave him a copy of The Chronic. He began rapping under the name "White Face" in the mid-2000s, and in 2009 he released his first album, The White Face LP. In 2010, White Face met ¡MURSDAY!, and the two began collaborating on music together. They released a number of singles and worked with other artists, including Lil' Kim, before signing to Strange Music in 2012. Since joining Strange Music, White Face has released two more solo albums, as well as two albums with ¡MAYDAY!. He has also made guest appearances on the albums of several other artists, including Tech N9ne, Krizz Kaliko, and Rittz. White Face's music is characterized by its dark, futuristic sound and introspective lyrics. He has been noted for his ability to combine elements of hip hop, electronic music, and rock, and has been described as a "hip hop chameleon" for his diverse musical style.

Claude Flemming (January 6, 1909 – June 11, 1998) was an American basketball player and coach, tennis player, teacher, coach, and school administrator. Flemming was born in409 West 51st Street in Chicago, Illinois, the son of Claude Sr. and Rose Flemming. He attended Englewood High School where he led his basketball team to the Chicago city championship in 1927. After high school, he attended the University of Illinois where he played basketball from 1927 to 1931, lettering three years. He was a member of the Illinois team that won the Big Ten Conference title in 1929, and that finished second in the nation in both the 1929 and 1930 seasons. He was a consensus All-American in 1930 and 1931, and was selected as the team's Most Valuable Player in 1930. In 1931 he was named the Big Ten Conference Basketball Player of the Year. After his college career was over, Flemming played one year of professional basketball for the Chicago Bruins of the Professional Basketball League of America. He also played one year of minor league baseball for the Muskegon Reds in the Western Michigan League. Flemming began his coaching career at Thornton Township High School in Harvey, Illinois, where his teams won three regional championships and one state championship. In 1943, he was named the school's principal, a position he held until his retirement in 1979. During his tenure as principal, the school grew from serving 350 students to serving 4,500. In 1976, the school won the Illinois state basketball championship, led by future NBA player Mark Aguirre. In addition to his duties at Thornton Township, Flemming was also the head basketball coach at the University of Illinois at Chicago from 1967 to 1971, where he led the team to a 72–32 record and two NCAA Division II national championships. Flemming died in 1998 at the age of 89.

Australian rules football in the Middle East The Australian rules football league in the Middle East is run by the Middle Eastern Australian Football League (MEAFL), which is made up of four clubs from around the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia, and is affiliated with the Australian Football League. The MEAFL was originally formed in 2008 by fourfoundation clubs, the Abu Dhabi Falcons, Dubai Dingoes, Doha Kangaroos and the Muscat Magpies. The league was re-established in 2014 by the same clubs, after a two-year hiatus. The MEAFL runs two competitions, the Premier League and the Division 1. The Premier League has been running since 2014, and the Division 1 was re-established in 2016 after a two-year hiatus. The MEAFL has four clubs based in the United Arab Emirates and one in Saudi Arabia. The league has female participants from the UAE, Saudi Arabia, Oman, Lebanon and New Zealand. The MEAFL season runs from October to March, with a four-team finals series. The Grand Final is played in late March. The Premier League has been dominated by the Dubai Dingoes and the Abu Dhabi Falcons since the league's inception, with the two clubs sharing the title six times. The Muscat Magpies have won the title three times, while the Doha Kangaroos have won it once. The Division 1 was won by the Abu Dhabi Falcons in 2015 and 2016, and by the Muscat Magpies in 2017. The MEAFL has been working to establish the game in the region, and has been running clinics and competitions for junior players. The league has also been working to grow the game among female participants.

Midget car racing, also known as dwarf car racing, is a form of auto racing which uses heavily modified versions of production cars, called midgets, to race on racing circuits, ice tracks, and on dirt tracks. The cars are powered by four-cylinder engines, and have a tubular frame, with the driver sitting in the center. The cars are very small, with a strict weight limit of 800 pounds (360 kg) without the driver. The sport's history can be traced back to the early 1920s, when the cars were used as a way to teach drivers the basics of racing. The cars were so small that they were often called "dwarfs" or "midgets", and the term "midget car" eventually became the official name of the sport. The cars are typically built for racing, with a tube frame and a fiberglass body. They are powered by a four-cylinder engine, and can reach speeds of up to 100 miles per hour (160 km/h). The cars are raced on racing circuits, ice tracks, and on dirt tracks. In the United States, midget car racing is a form of auto racing that is popular in the Midwest. The cars are built to the strict regulations of the American Midget Racing Association, and are powered by four-cylinder engines that produce up to 125 horsepower. The cars are raced on dirt tracks, and can reach speeds of up to 130 miles per hour (210 km/h). The cars are built with a tube frame, and are powered by a four-cylinder engine. They are raced on dirt tracks, and can reach speeds of up to 100 miles per hour (160 km/h).

Demonizing the enemy The demonizing of the enemy is the deliberate use of misleading or untrue statements in order to demonize an enemy, to make them appear more harmful, dangerous, or immoral than they really are. The demonizing of the enemy is a common technique used in politics, media, and propaganda. The goal of demonizing the enemy is to make the enemy less sympathetic, and to help justify, or gain support for, an attack or other actions against the enemy. The demonizing of the enemy is often associated with the use of the enemy image, in which the enemy is depicted in a way that makes them appear more evil or dangerous than they really are. This can include the use of negative stereotypes, or the portrayal of the enemy as a monster. The demonizing of the enemy can also include the use of lies or misinformation in order to portray the enemy in a negative light. For example, the enemy may be portrayed as being responsible for actions or events that they did not actually cause, or as having motivations that are not actually true. The demonizing of the enemy can also include the use of personal attacks or character assassination in order to make the enemy appear more harmful or immoral than they really are. For example, the enemy may be portrayed as being corrupt, or as having unethical or immoral personal habits. The demonizing of the enemy can also include the use of hyperbole orbole in order to make the enemy appear more harmful or dangerous than they really are. For example, the enemy may be portrayed as being a threat to national security, or as being a threat to the safety of the public.

Plaza Venezuela is a central landmark and one of the most important transportation hubs in Caracas, Venezuela. The sub-centro of Los Chaguaramos where the Plaza is located was one of the first areas to be settled in the city. The original name of the square was Plaza de los Indios, a name that arose in the early 16th century when it was the site of one of the first Indian councils to be summoned by Spanish conquistador Juan de Salinas. In the 20th century, the name was changed to Plaza Venezuela in honor of the country's independence, with the addition of a large statue of Simon Bolivar, one of the Liberators of Spanish America, on the southern side of the square. Plaza Venezuela is one of the few plazas in Caracas that is not surrounded by buildings, allowing for a clear view of the mountains that surround the city. It is a frequent gathering place for political rallies and celebrations. One of the most recognizable features of the Plaza is the La Guairita Hotel, better known as the Water Tower, a 150-meter (500 ft) tower with a spherical tank on the top, which supplies water to the city. The Plaza is also home to the Church of San Francisco, the National Library, the Museum of Fine Arts and the Central University of Venezuela (UCV). Under the square, there is a large underground shopping mall, the Centenary Walkway, which was built to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the founding of Caracas. At the eastern side of the square is the Parque Central complex, which includes the Hilton Hotel, the Caracas Stock Exchange, and the offices of some of the most important banks in the country. The complex is also the home of the Telefépolis building, which was the first multi-story building in the country to have a glass facade.

Curtiss Tanager is a species of small passerine birds in the tanager family Thraupidae. It is the only species of the genus Curtissi. The species is endemic to western and north-western Peru. The Curtiss Tanager was first described by the American ornithologist Alexander Wetmore in 1934. It was named in honor of the American zoologist Earl Curtiss. The Curtiss Tanager is a small tanager, 11.5–12.5 cm long. The adult has a long, pale grey-white pointed bill, dark grey legs, a pale grey-white face and pale grey-white underparts. The upperparts are dark grey with a pale grey shoulder patch. The central tail feathers are longer than the lateral feathers. The male and female are similar. The Curtiss Tanager occurs in low-lying areas on the Pacific coast of Peru, from the Department of Tumbes in the north to the Department of Ica in the south, and also in the western part of the Department of Ancash in the Andes, at altitudes of up to 2,100 m. It prefers open areas such as fields, pasture, roadsides, and the edges of forests, where it can be seen solitary, or in pairs, or in small groups. The Curtiss Tanager feeds on nectar from the flowers of tall, thin-stemmed plants, and on small invertebrates such as insects, which it finds on the ground or in the bark of trees. The Curtiss Tanager is a seasonal breeder, with the season lasting from September to April. The nest is built by the female alone, and is a small cup shape made of grass and moss lined with mud. It is placed in a low fork of a tree or bush. Two eggs are laid, and are pale blue-green with brown spots. The nest and eggs are preyed on by snakes and monkeys. The Curtiss Tanager is uncommon and localised, and is declining as its forest habitat is cleared for agriculture and settlement. It is therefore classified as Near Threatened by the IUCN.

Henry Kessler (February 12, 1888 – April 13, 1949) was an American professional baseball player and manager. He played all or parts of five seasons in Major League Baseball, from 1912 to 1916, for the Boston Red Sox (1912–13), Chicago White Sox (1914), Philadelphia Phillies (1915) and Brooklyn Robins (1916), primarily as a catcher. Kessler was born in Cleveland, Ohio, and attended the University of Michigan. He played summer baseball in Canada for the London Tecumsehs in 1910 and the Brantford Red Sox in 1911. He began his major league career with the Red Sox, appearing in 20 games in 1912 and 43 games in 1913. The Red Sox finished in last place in the AL in both years, and Kessler was one of several players traded to the White Sox in a multiplayer trade after the 1913 season. He played only one season in Chicago, appearing in 26 games and batting .200, before being traded to the Phillies in August 1914 for catcher Pat Moran. The Phillies finished last in the National League that season, and Kessler appeared in only 13 games for the club in 1915, batting .itor higher. He was traded to the Brooklyn Robins in January 1916 and appeared in 20 games for them that season, batting .250, before returning to the minor leagues. Kessler played for the Toronto Maple Leafs of the International League in 1916 and 1917, the Baltimore Orioles of the Atlantic League in 1918, and the Rochester Red Wings of the International League from 1919 to 1921. He was a player-manager for the Red Wings in 1920 and 1921. His playing career ended with the 1921 season, after which he remained in the Rochester area and operated a sporting goods store. Kessler died in 1949 at age 61 at his home in Greece, New York.

Vladimir II Monomakh, Grand Duke of Kiev (r. 1113–1125) was the son of Vladimir Monomakh and Eupraxia of Kiev. His father was the eldest son of Olga of Kiev by her second husband, Prince Boris. Vladimir II Monomakh succeeded his father as the ruler of Kievan Rus' in 1113. During his reign, Kievan Rus' was in a state of decline due to constant warfare with the Cumans, the Pechenegs, and the Polovtsy. The state was also threatened by the rise of the Mongols in the East. Despite this, Vladimir II was able to maintain the unity of Kievan Rus' and to keep the capital safe from the invaders. In 1114, Vladimir II concluded an alliance with the Cumans. The following year, the Polovtsy attacked Kievan Rus', but were repelled. In 1116, the Pechenegs invaded from the south, but Vladimir II defeated them and made a peace treaty with them. In 1119, the Cumans, under their Khan, attacked Kievan Rus'. Vladimir II was forced to conclude a treaty with the Cumans, in which he agreed to pay tribute to the Khan. In 1124, the Cumans invaded again, but were defeated by Vladimir II and his allies, the Polovtsy. Vladimir II Monomakh died in 1125 and was succeeded by his son, Vladimir III Monomakh.

Microcleidus Microcleidus is a genus of echinoderms belonging to the order Hemicystida. This genus is composed of two species, M. departens and M. papillosus, which are found in shallow seas in the Caribbean region and the Gulf of Mexico. The adults are composed of two parts, a cyst and a movable demosoma, the body. The cyst is made up of three layers of calcium carbonate exoskeleton, the outer layer is thick and has no sculpture, the middle layer is also exoskeleton but has a small sculpture, the inner layer is endoskeleton and has a radial symmetry. The demosoma is the movable part of the body, it is composed of a central disk with radial symmetry and five arms. The disk and the arms are made up of radial rows of plates which are connected by a flexible membrane, the so-called pellicle, which is the main organ of the demosoma. The pellicle is composed of radial rows of small plates connected by a thin membrane. The plates are small and numerous, they form a kind of basket which contracts and expands, allowing the demosoma to move. The arms are used for food collection, they are also used for locomotion, the animals move by bending the arms back and forth. The mouth is located in the center of the disk, and is surrounded by a group of tentacles. The Microcleidus are dioecious, the individuals are either all male or female. The eggs are laid in a basket shaped structure, which is brooded by the parent. The genus Microcleidus was erected by George Muir in 1961. The type species is M. departens.

Cor Boonstra (born 2 June 1944) is a Dutch politician and businessman who served as Minister of Agriculture, Nature Management, and Food Quality in the Cabinet of the Netherlands from 8 January 2003 until 22 February 2007. Boonstra was born in Noordwijk. After finishing the Hogereburgerschool in Leiden in 1962 he studied agriculture at Wageningen Agricultural University from 1962 to 1966. He then joined the family business, a farm in Noordwijk. In 1975 he became chairman of the Noordwijk agricultural cooperative. Boonstra became a member of the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA) in 1975. He served on the CDA national board from 1987 to 1997, and again from 2000 to 2002. He was also chairman of the CDA in South Holland from 1997 to 2000. After the CDA had joined the Cabinet Balkenende I, Boonstra was asked to join the cabinet as Minister of Agriculture, Nature Management, and Food Quality. His term started on 8 January 2003. In November 2006, he announced that he would not stand for the election of 2006. His term ended on 22 February 2007.

Wang Yi ( Chinese: 王毅; November 11, 1927 – January 9, 2015) was a Chinese librarian and writer. He served as the director of the National Library of China from 1985 to 1990. Wang was born in 1927 in Beijing. After graduating from the Department of History at the National University of Peking in 1950, he worked at the National Library. He was assigned to work in the library's documents department, where he was promoted to director in 1979. In 1985, he became the director of the National Library, and he served in this position for five years. After retirement, he served as the director of the China Library Association and the editor-in-chief of the Library Research journal. Wang was a member of the 6th and 7th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Committee. He was a member of the Standing Committee of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Committee and the president of the China Library Association. He was also an alternate member of the 14th and 15th CPC Central Committee. Wang died in Beijing on January 9, 2015, at the age of 87.

2020 in Saudi Arabia The year 2020 in Saudi Arabia was marked by events related to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Saudi oil and gas industry, and the state visit of the Russian president Vladimir Putin. On 5 March, the first case of COVID-19 in Saudi Arabia was reported. As a result, education in all levels was suspended until 30 March. On 13 March, the Government of Saudi Arabia suspended all international, land, and sea travel to and from the country for a period of two weeks, which was later extended to 31 March. On 9 March, Saudi Aramco's stock was traded on the international markets for the first time. On the same day, the company's market capitalization reached $1 trillion, making it the first company in the Middle East to achieve this milestone. In March, the Minister of Health, Dr. Tawfig Al-Rabiah, announced that the Kingdom had allocated a total of SR 55 billion ($14.7 billion) in spending to combat the coronavirus pandemic. In May, the Kingdom launched a three-phase plan to resume economic and daily activities. In the first phase, which began on 17 May, the Government of Saudi Arabia lifted the ban on international, land, and sea travel and resumed international flights to and from the country. The Government also resumed all commercial activities and public transportation, and allowed the re-opening of public parks and sports activities. In June, the Kingdom launched the second phase of the plan to resume economic and daily activities. In the second phase, the Government resumed all educational activities, and allowed the re-opening of restaurants, cafes, and entertainment centres, as well as the re-start of all sports activities, including the Saudi Pro League. In August, the Kingdom launched the third phase of the plan to resume economic and daily activities. In the third phase, the Government resumed all religious, cultural, and social activities, and allowed the re-opening of all public libraries, archives, and historical sites. In September, the Ministry of Justice announced that the total number of COVID-19 cases in the Kingdom had reached 201,450, including 52,361 active cases and 1,312 deaths. In October, the Minister of Health announced that the Kingdom had allocated a total of SR 32 billion ($8.8 billion) in spending to combat the coronavirus pandemic, including SR 4 billion ($1.1 billion) to support research and development efforts. In December, the Ministry of Health announced that the total number of COVID-19 cases in the Kingdom had reached 249,068, including 48,111 active cases and 1,595 deaths. In December, the Government of Saudi Arabia launched a COVID-19 vaccination campaign. The campaign was launched in three phases, with the first phase targeting health workers and the elderly. In January, the Kingdom signed a deal with the Russian company Norilsk Nickel to develop a $2 billion copper mine in the country's northern region. In March, the Kingdom signed a deal with the French company Total to develop a $9 billion solar power plant in the country's western region. In April, the Kingdom signed a deal with the Russian company Lukoil to develop a $6 billion oil and gas field in the country's eastern region. In May, the Kingdom signed a deal with the Chinese company Huawei to develop a $5 billion technology park in the country's capital, Riyadh. In June, the Kingdom signed a deal with the French company Alstom to develop a $1.5 billion high-speed rail line in the country's western region. In August, the Kingdom signed a deal with the German company Siemens to develop a $1.5 billion wind power plant in the country's northern region. In September, the Kingdom signed a deal with the Chinese company Haier to develop a $3.5 billion manufacturing hub in the country's eastern region. In November, the Kingdom signed a deal with the French company Bolloré Group to develop a $1.5 billion logistics and transportation hub in the country's western region. In December, the Kingdom signed a deal with the Chinese company Doosan Heavy Industries to develop a $1.5 billion desalination plant in the country's eastern region. In January, the Kingdom launched a new tourism visa regime, allowing citizens of 49 countries to obtain a visa on arrival at airports in the country. In March, the Kingdom launched a new e-visa regime, allowing citizens of 80 countries to obtain a visa online. In April, the Kingdom launched a new multiple-entry visa regime, allowing citizens of 49 countries to obtain a multiple-entry visa valid for 90 days. The Battle of Smolensk was a battle of the Napoleonic Wars, fought on 17 August 1812 between the Russian Empire and the French invasion. The battle took place near the city of Smolensk, 350 kilometres (220 mi) west of Moscow, on the Dnieper River, one of the major tributaries of the Volga, which the French crossed on their way to the capital. After their victory in the Battle of Valutino, the Russian forces under General Nikolai Ivanov prepared a defensive line along the Dnieper, hoping to halt the French advance. The French forces, under Napoleon, instead launched a rapid offensive, attempting to bypass the Russian lines by crossing the Dnieper at a point 30 kilometres (19 mi) east of Smolensk. The Russians were unprepared for this move, and the French broke through, winning a victory and inflicting heavy casualties on the Russians. Despite the victory, the French offensive had exhausted their supply of food and ammunition, and the Russians were able to withdraw most of their forces intact. The French suffered from desertion and disease, and were now significantly behind schedule. The battle was the first of three major battles between the French and the Russians in August 1812, preceding the Battle of Borodino and the Battle of Moscow, and was the first of five major battles the French forces would fight in the three-week period from 16 August to 6 September. After the capture of Smolensk, the French were able to replenish their food and ammunition, and the Russians were forced to retreat. However, the French were now in a position where they had to defend their line of communication, and they could not afford another major battle like that at Smolensk. The Russians, meanwhile, had been able to withdraw most of their forces and had preserved their strength. As a result, the French were unable to press their advantage, and the Russians were able to withdraw in good order to their new defensive positions along the Moscow-Smolensk highway.

Walt Disney Cartoon Classics Walt Disney Cartoon Classics is a series of seventy-eight animated shorts produced by Walt Disney Studios, based on popular stories and fables. The series was first shown on television in the United States during the fall of 1983, and continued through the spring of 1992. Each short has a runtime of seven minutes. In the United States, the series was shown on The Disney Channel, with some segments shown as part of the Disney cartoon shorts program on sister network ABC. The series was also shown on CBS, with some segments shown as part of the CBS Saturday morning children's lineup. The series has also been shown in the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, and many other countries. Each short features a traditional story or fable, such as The Tortoise and the Hare, The Three Billy Goats Gruff, and The Golden Goose, with the stories told by a narrator and the characters voiced by Disney staff members. The series was produced by Disney's " Analog Studio", which was primarily responsible for the company's short films and specials. The Disney Film and Video Department, which produces the company's feature films and television shows, produced the two-minute introduction at the beginning of each short. In 1992, Walt Disney Cartoon Classics was re-shown on The Disney Channel with a different set of seventy-eight shorts, including some of the shorts from the original series and some previously unseen shorts. The shorts were shown in two-hour blocks, with one short shown in the first half-hour and two shorts shown in the second half-hour, with the exception of the final block, which included three shorts. The series ended with a one-hour special, which featured four shorts and a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the series. Walt Disney Cartoon Classics is currently shown in the United States on the Disney Channel's "The Mickey Mouse Clubhouse" and "The Sofia the First" TV series. In 1999, a companion series, Walt Disney Television Animation, was aired on The Disney Channel. The series, which was primarily composed of short cartoons, was canceled after two seasons. Walt Disney Cartoon Classics was one of the final projects that Walt Disney personally worked on before his death in December 1966.

Annette van Dyck-Hemming (born 22 May 1950) is a Dutch politician of the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA). She was the first female mayor of the municipality of Heerlen, from 1 January 2001 to 1 June 2008. She was also the first female mayor of the city of Heerlen, from 1 January 2001 to 1 January 2005, when the municipality and the city were separate. In 2008 she became the first woman to be elected into the Eerste Kamer, the Dutch House of Representatives, from the province of Limburg. Born in Heerlen, van Dyck-Hemming was a member of the municipal council of Heerlen from 1982 to 2001, serving as an alderwoman from 1986. She also served on the municipal council of her birthplace, from 1974 to 1982. From 1 January 2001 to 1 June 2008, van Dyck-Hemming was the mayor of the municipality of Heerlen. She was also the mayor of the city of Heerlen, from 1 January 2001 to 1 January 2005, when the municipality and the city were separate. She was the first woman to be mayor of the city of Heerlen. In 2008, van Dyck-Hemming was elected into the Eerste Kamer, the Dutch House of Representatives, from the province of Limburg. She was the first woman to be elected into the Eerste Kamer, from the province of Limburg. In 2012, van Dyck-Hemming was re-elected into the Eerste Kamer.

Raja (2019 film) Raja is a 2019 Indian Tamil-language political drama film directed by debutant Aishwarya Rajamohan and produced by Kaviyaads. The film stars Santhanam in the lead role, while Rio Raj, Sathyaraj, and Kovai Sarala play supporting roles. The film is based on a true story that occurred in the 1990s and was shot in 2016. The film is set in the backdrop of the 1991 economic crisis in India. The film was released on 25 April 2019. Raja is a political drama set in the backdrop of the 1991 economic crisis. The film is based on a true story that occurred in the 1990s. The film is shot in a documentary style. The film is about a man who goes to any extent to ensure his family's welfare. The film is a message-based film. The film is directed by debutant Aishwarya Rajamohan. Aishwarya Rajamohan is an assistant of Shankar. The film is produced by Kaviyaads. The film is distributed by Escape Artists Motion Pictures. The film has music by Santhosh Dhayanidhi. The film has cinematography by R. D. Rajashekhar. The film has editing by R. Devanathan. The film was shot in 2016. The film was released on 25 April 2019. The film was distributed by Escape Artists Motion Pictures. The film's runtime is 110 minutes. Stekene is a municipality located in the Belgian province of East Flanders. The municipality comprises the towns of Kerksken, Nevele, Stekene proper, and Wingene. It is located in the easternmost part of East Flanders, on the border with the Flemish province of West Flanders and the Walloon province of Hainaut, Belgium. In 2013, Stekene had a total population of 24,153. The municipality has an area of 85.08 km² (33.00 sq mi). The municipality of Stekene is located in the Denderstreek, a sub-region in the east of East Flanders, and along the Dender river. It is one of the three municipalities (with Dendermonde and Erpe-Mere) that make up the Denderstreek. Stekene is located on the busy N8 road, running from Bruges and Zeebrugge in the west to Quesnoy-sur-Dender in the east, and providing a connection to the E40 highway. In the west, the N8 road passes through the town of Belsele. In the east, the road passes through the town of Erbisoele. The R44 road also passes through the municipality, from west to east. The Dender river forms the northern border of the municipality, and the Lieve river forms the southern border. The two rivers join just east of the municipality, in the Dendermonde suburb of Denderheide. The municipal government of Stekene comprises a municipal council and an executive council. The municipal council is made up of 27 councillors, elected by registered voters in the municipality. The executive council is made up of 7 members, elected by the municipal council, and has a duty to implement the decisions of the municipal council. The municipal government has its seat in the town of Stekene. The municipality of Stekene is part of the judicial district of Ghent. The municipality has three police stations, located in Kerksken, Nevele, and Stekene. The municipal flag of Stekene is made up of three vertical stripes, the left and right stripes in blue and the middle stripe in white. The flag is a stylized version of the coat of arms of the municipality, which depicts a white castle on a blue field, with a red door and window. The flag and coat of arms were designed by the Belgian artist Louis-Clément Pille. The postal code for the municipality of Stekene is 8840 to 8844. The municipality is divided into four postal sectors, which are: Nevele (8840), Stekene (8841), Kerksken (8842), and Wingene (8844). The telephone area code for the municipality of Stekene is 055. The municipality is covered by the Dialling Plan 2000, which is a telephone numbering plan for Belgium. The plan was introduced in 1999, and is organized based on the eight provinces of Belgium. The code for Stekene is 55 5X XXXXXX. The municipality of Stekene is served by two hospitals, located in Dendermonde (Sint-Martinus Hospital) and in Aalst (Aalst General Hospital).

Pig City: The Legend of the Chinese Zodiac is an Australian animated film based on the Chinese zodiac, in which the main character is a pig. The film was produced byTele Pictures, and was released in Australia on 5 May 2000. The film is set in a city called Pig City, which is populated with anthropomorphic pigs, and is situated on the banks of the Yellow River. The story follows the life of a young pig named Hamlet, the son of a wealthy pig named Walter. As the film opens, it is Hamlet's birthday, and he is to receive the gift of a girlfriend. However, when he discovers that his father has chosen a lazy, obese pig named Sooba as his mate, he refuses and runs away from home. As he travels through Pig City, Hamlet meets a wise old pig named Old Man, who tells him about a legend that says that when the pigs of the city see the chosen one, a new age will begin. The chosen one is said to be a pig with a "star" on his shoulder, and when he is born, the "star" will shine and all will know that he is the chosen one. Old Man tells Hamlet that he is the chosen one, and Hamlet realizes that he does indeed have a star on his shoulder. With this knowledge, Hamlet sets out to return to his home and claim his position as the chosen one. Along the way, he is joined by a group of friends who help him to fight against the evil forces that are trying to stop him from returning to Pig City. In the end, Hamlet is able to return home and claim his position as the chosen one.

Bulls, New Zealand, is a small town in the centre of the North Island, and is the service centre for the Rangitikei District. It is located 20 kilometres (12 mi) south-west of Taihape, and 90 kilometres (56 mi) north-east of Palmerston North. The town has a population of 1,128 as of the 2006 Census, and is the seat of the Rangitikei District Council. The town's name is believed to have originated from a legend in which a bull was killed there after swimming the river during a flood. The Bulls area was first settled by Europeans in the 1840s, with the Moutoa Gardens area, 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) north-east of the present town, being the site of the first European habitation in the district. The town was founded in 1870 after the arrival of the railroad, and the original site of the town was at the intersection of Railway and High Streets, where the train station was located. The town was moved to its present site when the New Zealand Government completed the new railway line to Wellington in 1885. The original town was then demolished to make way for the present day town, with the old town's main street becoming the new town's High Street. The town is located on State Highway 1, and is also on the North Island Main Trunk railway line. It has a small railway station that is no longer in use, as the nearest station is in Taihape. The town has a number of historic buildings, including the Bulls Hotel, built in 1885, and the Empire Hotel, built in 1912. The town's high school, Bulls High School, was closed in 2007, but the town still has a primary school. Bulls was the original home of the international company Zespri, which was founded in the town in 1908 as the New Zealand Kiwifruit Marketing Board. The company's headquarters are now located in Mount Maunganui, and the company is now known as Zespri International.

MN1 (gene) The MN1 gene (mobile element derived 1 gene) is a gene that codes for the protein Meis1. The gene is located on the short arm of chromosome 20 (20p11.2). It spans 3.3 kb and comprises 3 exons and 2 introns. The MN1 gene encodes a protein called Meis1, a DNA-binding protein that is a transcription factor and regulator of cell differentiation and growth control. The gene is expressed in all tissues, with higher levels in testis and lower levels in kidney. The MN1 gene is evolutionarily conserved, with homologs in both vertebrates and invertebrates. In humans, the gene has 4 alternatively spliced variants, 3 of which encode the same protein and 1 that is a pseudogene. The MN1 gene is involved in the regulation of cell growth and differentiation. It is a transcription factor that binds to the DNA and regulates the expression of target genes. The gene is involved in the regulation of cell cycle, cell growth, and cell differentiation. The MN1 gene is associated with the development of several cancers, including acute myeloid leukemia, chronic myeloid leukemia, and acute lymphocytic leukemia. The gene is also associated with the development of Wilms' tumor, a type of kidney cancer. The MN1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene, which means that it helps to regulate cell growth and differentiation and can prevent cells from becoming cancerous. The gene is thought to be involved in the regulation of cell cycle, cell growth, and cell differentiation.
