Brazil at the 2006 Winter Olympics Brazil sent a delegation to compete at the 2006 Winter Olympics in Turin, Italy from 10–26 February 2006. This was the nation's eighth appearance in the Winter Olympics. The Brazilian delegation consisted of three athletes, two of whom were female, and the other male. Two athletes, one male and one female, were making their second consecutive appearance in the Winter Games, having also competed in the 2002 Winter Olympics. The athletes competed in three sports: bobsleigh, cross-country skiing, and snowboarding. Brazil's best performance at these games was by the bobsleigh team, who came twentieth in the four-man event and twenty-first in the two-man event. This was an improvement on the last Winter Olympics, where the country's best result was thirty-seventh in the two-man bobsleigh. The other two athletes failed to advance beyond the qualification stages of their respective events. This was the first time that Brazil had competed in bobsleigh at the Winter Olympics, and the first time since 1928 that the country had participated in cross-country skiing. Brazil had previously competed in snowboarding at the 1998 Winter Olympics.

Real-time text Real-time text is text that is input or output immediately after its creation, as opposed to text that is stored and then displayed. Real-time text is a key feature of live streaming and live transcription, in which a person types what another person says. Real-time text may be created with a real-time text editor. One of the first uses of this technology was the Telestrator, which was invented by Martin Cooke in 1961. The Telestrator was a device that allowed one to draw on a television screen in real-time. It was first used by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation to annotate a television broadcast of the Canadian federal election in 1962. The technology was also used in the United States to annotate the America's Cup yacht races in 1967. Real-time text is used in instant messaging, online chat, and teletype. In the 1980s and 1990s, it was also used in the now-obsolete field of real-time document preparation, which was an alternative to the more familiar batch processing model of document preparation. Real-time text is also used in captioning and subtitling.

Tōgō Onsen Tōgō Onsen (東郷温泉) is a hot spring resort in the city of Hirosaki, Aomori Prefecture, Japan. The resort is located in the Tsugaru region of Aomori Prefecture, on the eastern edge of the Hakkōda Mountains. The hot springs are one of the more famous hot spring resorts in the region, and are one of the few that are easily accessible by a paved road. The hot springs are located along the cottony dogwood tree-lined Towada-Hachimantai National Highway. There are many onsen ryokan in the area. The sulfur springs are colored in shades of green and are said to be good for skin ailments. In the past, the springs were located along the road, but due to their popularity, most of the springs have been developed into bathhouses and ryokan. The springs are still considered to be one of the best free hot springs in the region. The springs can be found by following the road to the end, where there is a large bathhouse, the Sakuraya Bathhouse, which is free to enter. The bathhouse has a strong sulfur smell, but the water is clear. The temperature is very hot, reaching above 50 degrees Celsius. The resort is also known for its "onsen eggs", a local specialty in which eggs are hard-boiled in the hot spring water. The sulfur in the water turns the egg shells black, and the egg whites turn a light green. Onsen eggs are a popular local tourist souvenir, and can be found at many tourist shops in the area. Tōgō Onsen is a popular destination for tourists, especially during the summer months. The resort is also a popular destination for birdwatchers, as it is home to a variety of bird species, including the endangered Japanese woodpecker. The resort is approximately 40 minutes by car from Hirosaki, and can also be accessed by a local bus service. The nearest train station is the JR Tsugaru-Goshogawara Station, which is approximately 25 minutes away by car.

This is a list of the squads that have been selected for the Australia national soccer team in the World Cup and Asian Cup. The Australian national soccer team, also known as the Socceroos, has competed in five FIFA World Cups and two AFC Asian Cups. The team has competed in the OFC Nations Cup competition ten times, and have won the competition a record five times. The following is a list of the players who have been called into the national team in the World Cup and Asian Cup. World Cup Squads Australia's World Cup squad for the 1974 FIFA World Cup was the first World Cup squad to be selected by the national team. For the 1982 FIFA World Cup, Australia were required to submit a list of players for the tournament, however, they were not required to submit a final squad. In the 1986 FIFA World Cup, Australia were again required to submit a list of players for the tournament, however, they were not required to submit a final squad. The 1990 FIFA World Cup was the first time Australia were required to submit a final squad. The 1994 FIFA World Cup was the first time Australia had to name a squad of 22 players. The 1998 FIFA World Cup was the first time Australia had to name a squad of 23 players. The 2002 FIFA World Cup was the first time Australia had to name a squad of 24 players. The 2006 FIFA World Cup was the first time Australia had to name a squad of 25 players. The 2010 FIFA World Cup was the first time Australia had to name a squad of 30 players. The 2014 FIFA World Cup was the first time Australia had to name a squad of 32 players. The 2018 FIFA World Cup was the first time Australia had to name a squad of 34 players. Asian Cup Squads Australia's Asian Cup squad for the 2015 AFC Asian Cup was the first Asian Cup squad to be selected by the national team. For the 2007 AFC Asian Cup, Australia were required to submit a list of players for the tournament, however, they were not required to submit a final squad. The 2015 AFC Asian Cup was the first time Australia had to name a squad of 23 players. The 2019 AFC Asian Cup was the first time Australia had to name a squad of 24 players.

The KTM 1290 Super Adventure is a 1301 cc V-twin engine, LC8 engine four-stroke motorcycle introduced in 2013 by KTM for the 2014 model year. The Super Adventure is the largest engine in the KTM lineup, and is specifically designed for long-distance touring. In 2015 and 2016, the bike was called the KTM 1290 Super Duke GT and KTM 1290 Super Adventure R, respectively, to emphasize the off-road capabilities of the motorcycle. KTM has built a strong reputation for its off-road motorcycles, but until the introduction of the Super Adventure, the company did not have a strong presence in the touring motorcycle market. The Super Adventure was developed to provide riders with a comfortable motorcycle that could be used for long-distance touring, while also providing some off-road capabilities. The Super Adventure is powered by a 1301 cc V-twin engine that produces 145 hp (108 kW) of power and 125 Nm of torque. The engine is mated to a six-speed manual transmission and a chain drive. The Super Adventure has a top speed of 200 km/h (124 mph) and can accelerate from 0-100 km/h (0.0-62 mph) in 2.9 seconds. The Super Adventure has a comfortable, upright seating position and a large windshield for long-distance touring. The bike also has a large, 21-litre (5.5 US gal) fuel tank for long rides. The Super Adventure also has a range of optional accessories, including a top box, side bags, and a navigation system.

Otto Strasser (26 May 1897 – 6 June 1939) was an Austrian political activist and an early member of the Nazi Party. He was the younger brother of the party's founder and leader, Adolf Hitler. After the Nazi takeover of power in Germany in 1933, Strasser became disenchanted with the movement and broke with his brother. He was killed in mysterious circumstances in 1939. Strasser was born in Linz, Upper Austria, the fourth of the six children of Maria Augusta (née Schickelgruber) and Alois Hitler. His father was a customs official. TheHitler family was Catholic, and Otto was raised in that faith. He attended the state school in Linz and, like his older brother, Adolf, went on to the Linz Realschule. After completing his schooling there in 1916, he served in the Austrian Army from May to October that year, and was then transferred to the reserves. In December, he was called up for active service again, but was discharged in February 1917 because of heart problems. In June, he was conscripted into the German Army and fought on the Western Front until the end of the war. He was wounded in October 1918. After the war, Strasser completed his schooling and, like his brother, failed to gain admission to the Austrian officer academy. He then joined the right-wing Austrian Home Defence and served as a private. The following year, he became a member of the German National Socialist Workers' Party (Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei, or NSDAP), the precursor of the Nazi Party, and the German Workers' and Soldiers' Party (Deutsche Arbeiter- und Soldatenpartei, or DAP), which the NSDAP soon absorbed. The NSDAP was then led by his brother, and the party's newspaper, the Völkischer Beobachter, was edited by Joseph Goebbels. In 1921, Strasser became the business manager of the newspaper. After the NSDAP's poor showing in the Reichstag elections of May 1924, Strasser, along with his brother and other party leaders, was convicted of treason in the Bamberg Court of Honor. The sentence, however, was not carried out, as the President of the Reichsgericht, Ludwig Guertner, granted an indefinite delay of execution. In the summer of 1924, Strasser joined the German People's Party (Deutsche Volkspartei, or DVP). The following year, he became the business manager of the Deutsche Zeitung, a newspaper published by the DVP's successor, the National Party (Nationale Partei, or NP). He also managed the NP's affairs in Munich. In the autumn of 1925, the NP merged with the NSDAP to form the National Socialist German Workers' Party (Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei, or NSDA), which would be renamed the Nazi Party in 1933. Strasser remained a member of the new party, and in 1926 was appointed to its leadership in Munich. He also became the business manager of the Völkischer Beobachter, which was now the Nazi Party's newspaper, and, in 1927, the head of the party's publishing house, the Franz Eher Verlag. Strasser was one of the few early Nazi Party leaders who was not a member of the SA. He was, however, involved in the leadership of the party's economic organizations, and in 1928 became the chairman of the Business and Property Owners' Committee. In 1929, he became the head of the party's Economic Policy and Tax Office. The following year, he was elected to the Reichstag for the Munich North seat, and was made the chairman of the Nazi faction in the Bavarian Landtag. In the Reichstag, he sat on the Economic Committee and on the Committee on the Affairs of the German People's Group in Poland. In the Landtag, he was on the Committee for Economic and Agricultural Affairs. In February 1932, Strasser became the Nazi Party's propaganda chief, a position he would hold until his death. In March, he was made the party's organizational chief, and in May its business manager. In the Reichstag elections of July 1932, he was elected to represent Munich North. In November, he was elected to the Reichstag for Munich North and Munich II. In the Landtag elections, he was returned to the Bavarian legislature from Munich North. After the Nazi seizure of power in January 1933, Strasser was named to the Reich government as Minister without Portfolio and as Deputy Minister of Transport. In the summer of 1933, he was elected to the Reichstag for Munich II. Strasser was the only one of the four Hitler brothers who was not killed in the Holocaust. However, his widow, Hedwig, was killed

Moravian University Moravian University is a private institution that was founded in 1742 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. It is one of the oldest universities in the United States and is associated with the Moravian Church. The university has two campuses, one in downtown Philadelphia and the other in nearby Bethlehem, Pennsylvania. The school is a member of the Association of American Colleges and Universities. The university was established in 1742 as the Bethesda Orphans' Home and School in Philadelphia by the Moravians, a Protestant denomination with roots in what is now the Czech Republic. The institution was the first school for girls in Philadelphia and the first school for orphans in North America. In 1901, the school, now known as the Moravian Training School, moved to Bethlehem. The following year, it became the Moravian Academy and began to offer a college-preparatory curriculum for high school students. In 1913, the academy established a junior college, known as the Moravian College for Women. The college became coeducational in the 1930s and changed its name to Moravian University in 2000. The university has more than 2,500 students and offers bachelor's and master's degrees, as well as a doctorate in education. The university also has a joint program with Duke University, allowing Duke students to take classes at Moravian and earn a bachelor's degree from both institutions. In 2008, the university received a $5 million gift from the estate of Donald B. Jones, a graduate of the university, to establish an endowed chair in business. In 2012, the university received a $1 million gift from the Mary Duke Biddle Foundation to establish an endowed chair in education. In 2017, the university changed its name to Moravian University from Moravian College. In 2018, the university launched the College of Healthcare Sciences, a new school that offers bachelor's and associate's degrees in healthcare-related fields. The college is located in downtown Philadelphia. In 2019, the university launched the Department of Business, a new school that offers bachelor's and master's degrees in business-related fields. The department is located in downtown Philadelphia.

Henri van Praag (April 4, 1914 – September 10, 2016) was a Dutch-American physical chemist, businessman, and philanthropist. Born in The Hague, the Netherlands, van Praag was the son of a physician and a musician. He studied chemistry at the University of Amsterdam, where he received his Ph.D. in 1938. He joined the Dutch firm Royal Dutch Shell that year, working in Amsterdam and London before moving to Curaçao, in the Caribbean, in 1940. There, he met his future wife, Nelly, a native of Curaçao. In 1942, he joined the U.S. War effort as a scientist, working on the development of synthetic rubber at the Rubber Development Corporation in Washington, D.C. After the war, van Praag returned to the Netherlands, where he became head of the Laboratory for Physical Chemistry at the University of Amsterdam. In 1948, together with the Swedish chemist Carl Djerassi, he was the first to report the solid state thermal decomposition of benzil to form benzene. In 1949, he was appointed professor of physical chemistry at the University of Leiden, a position he held until his retirement in 1979. His research focused on the kinetics of chemical reactions, especially those involving free radicals. In 1951, he was the first to discover the hydrogen abstraction reaction of the title compound, dilauryl peroxide. In 1950, van Praag became a corresponding member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences, and he was elected a full member in 1979. In addition, he was a member of the Dutch Society for Chemistry and Physics, the American Chemical Society, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, and the Royal Society of Edinburgh. After retiring from his academic career, van Praag returned to the business world as a consultant in the area of intellectual property management. He was a co-founder of the Chemists' Club, a business networking organization, and served as its first chairman. In 1979, he became a founding member of the World Business Network, an international business networking organization, and served as its first vice-president. In 1980, he became a member of the advisory board of the American Chemical Society's Industrial and Engineering Chemistry Division. In 1981, van Praag was awarded the Carl Djerassi Award for Outstanding Achievement in Physical Organic Chemistry. In 1983, he received the International Society for Intellectual Property Management's IPM Award. In 1983, van Praag and his wife established the Henri and Nelly van Praag Foundation, a private charitable foundation whose mission is to promote the understanding of chemistry and its impact on society. The Foundation provides grants to researchers and teachers in the chemical sciences, and to nonprofit organizations that promote the understanding of chemistry. In addition, the Foundation sponsors the annual Henri van Praag Lecture in Physical Organic Chemistry at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, and the annual Nelly van Praag Lecture in Chemistry at the University of Puerto Rico, Mayagüez. In 2008, van Praag turned 100. He died at his home in Illinois in 2016, at the age of 102.

Henrik Horn (born February 18, 1963) is a Danish musician (also credited as Harry Horn or Henry Horn), producer, composer, writer, and actor. He is best known for his work with director Lars von Trier, including the film Dogville (2003) and the television series Kingdom (2014), for which he has won three Bodil Awards and one Golden Nymph Award. Horn was born in Copenhagen. He played in several bands, including The Sighs, The Monkees, and The Ideals, before starting work as a session musician. He also composed the music for the video game The KKKillz, and was the lead guitarist in the band Morgan Heritage from 1984 to 1986. Horn's first major film score was for the Danish feature film Drengen i den gamle by (The Boy at the Old Castle), in 1999, for which he was nominated for the Danish Film Academy's Robert Award. This was followed by the score for the Danish-Swedish-Norwegian co-production De nærmeste fjeller (The Countryside Murders), in 2000, which earned him the Robert Award for Best Score. Horn has since written the music for a number of von Trier's productions, including the television series Bossanova, the short film The Perfect Human, the documentary The Dogville Confessions, and the feature films Dogville, Manderlay, and Antichrist. He has also composed the music for the television series The Eagle, the feature films Den anden side (The Other Side) andassa, and the documentary The Act of Killing. In addition to his work with von Trier, Horn has written the music for the feature films Flaskepost fra P (Message in a Bottle), for which he was nominated for the Robert Award for Best Score, and De fortidige (The Legacy), as well as the television series Hvem drog den himmel? (Who Stole the Heaven?), for which he was nominated for the Golden Nymph Award. Horn has also written the music for the video games Battlefield 2, Battlefield 2142, Battlefield 4, Battlefield Hardline, and Battlefield 1.

Jeff Salmon (born December 8, 1973) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and record producer, known for his work with the bands Old 97's and the Damn Quails, and on his solo albums. Salmon was born in Worcester, Massachusetts. He attended the University of Massachusetts Amherst and studied English. After college, he worked for a record distributor in Boston, and then for an indie rock band in New York City. He then moved to Dallas, Texas, where he became a DJ at the University of North Texas, and co-hosted a radio show, The Kazoo Brothers, on UNT's student-run radio station, KNTU. In 1994, Salmon and friends John Ginaitt (bass) and Neil O'Brien (drums) formed the band Scruffy the Cat, which enjoyed local popularity and released two albums, including one on Sapient Records, before breaking up in 1997. In 1995, Salmon and O'Brien joined the Dallas-based band Old 97's, with whom Salmon has recorded five studio albums, two live albums, and several EPs. In addition to singing, Salmon also plays guitar for the band. In 2003, Salmon was diagnosed with testicular cancer, and underwent surgery to remove the affected tissue. In 2005, Salmon began performing with the Damn Quails, a side project of his that specializes in country music. With the Damn Quails, he has recorded two studio albums and one live album. In 2008, Salmon released a solo album, The Barry Falls, and in 2012, he released another solo album, The Green Room. Salmon is married to Kristen Salmon, a former member of the bands Tater and the Breakup Song. They have two children together.

Oona Chaplin (born 1 May 1998) is an English actress. She is the granddaughter of actor and comedian Charlie Chaplin, and the daughter of his son, actor and producer Charles Chaplin Jr. (who was born in Los Angeles, California, and died in New York City, New York), and her mother, actress and producer Geraldine Chaplin. Oona Chaplin was born in Lightwater, Surrey, England. She was educated at the private Arts Educational School in London, where she studied singing, dancing, and acting. She then attended the Open College of the Arts, also in London, studying drama, theatre, and performance. In 2011, Oona Chaplin participated in the BBC talent show Over the Rainbow, which was won by Danielle Hope. In 2012, she was cast as Ismene in a new production of Antigone to be performed at the Old Vic theatre in London. In 2015, she played young Lily in the television series Penny Dreadful. In 2016, she appeared as a dancer in the music video for the song "Lyla" by the band 20th Century Foxes. In 2017, she was cast as Dolly in the series Star Wars Rebels. In 2018, she played Yyri in the series The Replacement. In 2019, she played Estella in the series The Young Victoria. In 2021, she played a younger version of her grandmother's character in the series The Commuter.

Women & Songs 9 is the ninth album in the Women & Songs series, and the first to be released by Warner Music Group's Nettwerk label. The album was released on June 8, 2010. Like the previous albums in the series, Women & Songs 9 is a covers album, featuring female artists covering other female artists. The album was preceded by a single, "Halo" (a cover of the original byBeyoncé), by Kate Earl. The album's producer, Shakari Henry, selected songs that are "timeless and beautiful", with the goal of having the artists "re-interpret the songs in a way that pays respect to the original but also makes it relevant and unique to this project". The album's cover art is a painting by Michael O'Keefe, husband of Catherine O'Hara. In 2011, the album was awarded a silver certification from the Independent Music Awards in the category of Best Re-Mix/Re-Record. The album's first single, "Halo", was released in June 2010. The second single, "You Know I Know" by Eurythmics, was released in July 2010. The third single, "No More Drama" by Mary J Blige, was released in August 2010. The fourth and final single, "Don't Dream It's Over" by Crowded House, was released in September 2010.

Angelo Di Pietro (born 7 August 1977) is an Italian politician, lawyer, and journalist, who has been serving as a Member of the European Parliament for the Southern Italy constituency since June 2019. Di Pietro was born in Naples, Italy. He studied law at the University of Naples Federico II. In 2008, he was awarded a Master of Laws (LL.M.) degree in Comparative Law from the State University of New York at Buffalo, where he studied on a Carlo Azeglio Ciampi fellowship. In 2013, he obtained a Master of Arts degree in International Affairs from the New School in New York City. In 2008, Di Pietro co-founded the blog Il Fatto Quotidiano (The Daily Fact), of which he is currently director and editor-in-chief. In 2013, he became a contributor to the television program Quotidiano Nazionale (National Daily), which is broadcast by the Italian state broadcaster RAI. He also worked as a reporter for the Italian edition of Esquire magazine. In 2015, Di Pietro co-produced and co-directed the documentary film Il Volto di Putin (The Face of Putin), which was released in Italy on 13 April 2015. In the European Parliament, Di Pietro is a member of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) political group. In 2019, he was elected to the European Parliament as a member of the Five Star Movement (M5S), but left the party in 2022 to join Forza Italia (FI), the party of former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. In addition to his native Italian, Di Pietro is fluent in English and French, and has a working knowledge of Spanish.

Ferdinand Johann Adam von Pernau (9 October 1756 – 26 December 1815) was a German philosopher and writer. He is best known for his book Das Leben des Jesus, a philosophical and historical account of the life of Jesus which has been described as the most important German philosophical investigation of the life of Jesus during the nineteenth century. After studying theology and philosophy at the universities of Halle and Jena, Pernau became a private tutor to a noble family in Thuringia. In 1791 he was appointed professor of philosophy at the University of Rinteln, where he remained for the rest of his life. In Das Leben des Jesus (1806), Pernau offered a philosophical and historical account of the life of Jesus in which he sought to penetrate the historical figure of Jesus through the various legends and myths that had accumulated around him. In doing so, he made use of the methods of the historical-critical study of the New Testament that had been developed by the German philosopher and critic David Hume. Pernau's work met with a hostile reception from the faculty of the University of Rinteln, who were scandalized by the idea that the life of Jesus might be subject to rational investigation. In spite of this, the book was widely read and had a significant influence on the historical-critical study of the New Testament during the nineteenth century. In addition to Das Leben des Jesus, Pernau also wrote several philosophical treatises on such topics as theodicy, the relation between philosophy and religion, and the history of philosophy.

Trichambaram Utsavam Trichambaram Utsavam is an annual festival celebrated at the Trichambaram temple near Mavelikara, Kerala, India. The festival is celebrated for ten days in the month of Vrishchikam (November/December), beginning with the enactment of the wedding of Shiva to Mohini, and culminating with the worship of the dead. A massive crowd gathers at the temple to witness the fireworks that are a highlight of the festival. The festival is celebrated in honour of Lord Shiva, and is believed to have started during the period of Sage Parashurama. The festival is celebrated in three stages, with the first stage being the celebration of the wedding of Shiva to Mohini, the second being the celebration of the wedding of Annapurna to Shiva, and the third being the celebration of the union of the dead with Shiva. The first day of the festival is marked by the arrival of Lord Shiva and his consort Mohini, who are welcomed with a traditional Poorna Kumbham. The couple are then seated on a beautifully decorated swing, where they are swayed to the tune of traditional temple music. The second day of the festival is marked by the arrival of Lord Shiva and his consort Annapurna, who are also welcomed with a traditional Poorna Kumbham. The couple are then seated on a swing, where they are swayed to the tune of traditional temple music. The third day of the festival is marked by the arrival of the dead, who are welcomed with a traditional Poorna Kumbham. The dead are then seated on a swing, where they are swayed to the tune of traditional temple music.

The Real Quiet Storm is a 1996 American drama film directed by Thomas Carter. The film takes its name from a song by the singer/songwriter Donny Hathaway, and is set in Los Angeles in the early 1960s. The film follows the life of a young African-American man who is trying to break into the radio business as a disc jockey, and the people he meets along the way. The film features an ensemble cast that includes Denzel Washington, Robert Wisdom, Percy Miller, Deborah Ann Ryan, and John M. Watson. The film was released in 1996, and was well-received by critics. It was nominated for two Independent Spirit Awards, for Best Feature and Best Male Lead (for Washington). It was also nominated for the Grand Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival. The film is set in Los Angeles in the early 1960s, and follows the life of a young African-American man named Ron ("Radio") Roberts (Denzel Washington), who is trying to break into the radio business as a disc jockey. Radio works as a delivery boy for a local record store, and spends his free time listening to music and practicing his disc jockey skills in his bedroom. He is also trying to get his own show on the local black-owned radio station, but the station's manager, Mr. D (John M. Watson), is not interested in giving Radio a chance. However, Radio's life changes when he meets a beautiful young woman named Stormy (Deborah Ann Ryan), who is also a disc jockey at the local white-owned radio station. Stormy is interested in Radio, and they begin dating. However, their relationship is complicated by the fact that Stormy is white, and Radio is black. They face racism and prejudice from both their families and their communities, but they are determined to stay together. As Radio and Stormy try to make their relationship work, they are also trying to break into the radio business. Stormy gets a chance to host her own show at the local white-owned radio station, but the station's manager, Mr. B (Robert Wisdom), is not interested in giving Stormy a chance. However, Stormy is determined to make it happen, and she starts her own radio show from her bedroom. As Stormy's show becomes more and more popular, Radio starts to feel left behind. He is still trying to get his own show at the local black-owned radio station, but the station's manager, Mr. D, is still not interested in giving him a chance. However, Radio is determined to make it happen, and he starts his own radio show from his bedroom. As both Stormy and Radio's shows grow in popularity, they start to compete with each other for listeners. They both want to be the best, and they both want to be heard. However, they are also trying to make their relationship work, and they are trying to break into the radio business. The Real Quiet Storm is a powerful story about love, determination, and the power of the human spirit. It is a story about two people who are trying to make their relationship work, and who are trying to break into the radio business. It is a story about the power of the human will, and about the importance of never giving up.

Accumulated cyclone energy The Accumulated Cyclone Energy (ACE) index is an indicator of the collective destructive power of storms that occurred over a region during a particular period of time. The index value is calculated by squaring the wind speed of each storm, multiplying by the storm's duration, and then summing these values. The ACE index does not represent the damage that might have been caused by the storms, but instead provides a means of comparing the destructive potential of different sets of storms. The index was first developed in 1987 by Kerry Emanuel of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) to provide a single value that could be used to compare the destructive potential of multiple storms that occurred over a region during a single season. The index has since been used to compare the destructive potential of storms in different regions and at different times. The ACE index is typically calculated for the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and the Gulf of Mexico. The index can also be calculated for other regions, such as the Indian Ocean, but in these cases the storms that are included in the index may not be true tropical cyclones. The ACE index is used by meteorologists to provide a simple and consistent measure of the destructive potential of tropical cyclones. It is also used by researchers to study the physical processes that occur within tropical cyclones and to improve the computer models that are used to predict the tracks and intensity of these storms. The ACE index is not without its limitations, however. The index is only calculated for regions where sufficient wind speed data are available. In addition, the index does not take into account the size of the storm, the amount of rainfall that it produced, or the extent of the storm's circulation. These factors can all have a significant impact on the destructive potential of a tropical cyclone.

Hurricane Harvey was a deadly and destructive Category 4 hurricane that became the first major hurricane to make landfall in the United States since Hurricane Wilma in 2005, and the first in Texas since Hurricane Ike in 2008. Harvey was the seventh hurricane to make landfall in the United States in 2017, the most since 2004. On August 17, 2017, a tropical depression formed over the Atlantic Ocean from a low-pressure area that had been present for several days. The depression strengthened and was upgraded to a tropical storm the next day as it moved northwestward. On August 19, the storm reached hurricane intensity, and by August 21, it reached Category 4 intensity. Harvey weakened to a Category 1 hurricane as it moved inland, but restrengthened to a Category 4 hurricane as it moved back over the Gulf of Mexico. On August 25, Harvey made landfall in Texas as a Category 4 hurricane with winds of 130 mph (215 km/h), and it weakened to a Category 1 hurricane as it moved inland. Harvey caused catastrophic flooding in Texas, particularly in and around Houston, which was hit by the eye of the storm. Harvey is estimated to have caused $75 billion in damage, making it the costliest hurricane in United States history. The storm caused at least 68 deaths and nearly 200,000 people were displaced. On August 23, the Hurricane Harvey Task Force, consisting of the United States Army Corps of Engineers, the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and other federal agencies, was formed to support the recovery from the hurricane. The task force was headed by FEMA director Brock Long.

County Route 41 (CR 41) is a 4.06-mile-long (6.55 km) county route in Onondaga County, New York, United States. It runs from NY 91 in the village of Baldwinsville to NY 5 in the town of Lysander. CR 41 is named Brewerton Road for its entire length. CR 41 begins at an intersection with NY 91 (Old Liverpool Road) in Baldwinsville. The route heads north as a two-lane road through the village, intersecting NY 48 (James Street) and NY 31 (Baldwinsville Road) before leaving the village. North of Baldwinsville, CR 41 passes through an area of farmland as it heads toward the village of Brewerton. The route passes under Interstate 481 (I-481) with no access and enters the village of Brewerton. In the village, CR 41 turns east onto Oneida Street, then north onto Madison Street, running concurrent with NY 37. North of NY 37, CR 41 leaves Brewerton and heads northwest through an area of farms as it enters the town of Lysander. The route ends at an intersection with NY 5 (Brant Street) just south of the village of Lysander. CR 41 was assigned in the early 1930s to a series of roads connecting NY 91 in Baldwinsville to NY 5 in Lysander. The route has not been changed since that time.

Fagan Park is a heritage-listed landscape garden and park located at 31 The Boulevarde, Strathfield, Inner West Council of Sydney, New South Wales, Australia. It was designed by Scottish emigrant and architect James Eccleston Fagan (1825–2008) and built from 1867 to 1871. The property is owned by the New South Wales Government. It was added to the New South Wales State Heritage Register on 13 August 1999. Fagan Park is a rare example of an intact Victorian era suburban villa garden. It is the last of a group of four that were originally built on The Boulevarde. The other three have been redeveloped for residential use. The park is located on the corner of The Boulevarde and Albyn Road in the inner western Sydney suburb of Strathfield. It is surrounded by a contemporary housing estate, with the exception of a small row of shops on The Boulevarde. The park consists of 2.05 hectares (5 acres) of open space with a small number of trees and a tennis centre. The park has a large perimeter and is almost entirely fenced. Fagan Park was designed and built by Scottish emigrant and architect James Eccleston Fagan (1825–2008). It was built between 1867 and 1871. Fagan arrived in Sydney in 1854 and designed a number of significant buildings in the Sydney area including the original Women's College at the University of Sydney, and the first girls' school in Australia, the Glenleighden School, which was later bought by the Presbyterian Church to become the Presbyterian Ladies' College, Sydney. Fagan Park was acquired by the New South Wales Government in 1901, following the death of its owner. It was subsequently vested in the Metropolitan Board of Water Supply and Sewerage in 1935, and transferred to Strathfield Council in 1978. The park is the last of a group of four that were originally built on The Boulevarde. The other three have been redeveloped for residential use. Fagan Park was added to the New South Wales State Heritage Register on 13 August 1999.

Rockland is a home and historic site in Shepherds-town, West Virginia. The house was built in 1804 by Adam Kohler, a German immigrant, on land patented by his father, John Kohler. The property includes the original log cabin and a stone barn. The house is a two-story, five-bay, Federal-style brick dwelling. The house has a central-passage-plan and is covered by a front-gabled roof. The front and side elevations feature molded brick lintels and sills. The house has a one-story, full-length porch with a shed roof and a brick foundation. The windows are six-over-six sash windows. The house has a central chimney. The interior features extensive Federal-style trim, including fireplace mantels, door and window trim, and a main staircase with turned newel posts and balusters. The house was sold to the Reber family in 1921. It was sold to the Israel family in 1958. It was sold to the Rockland Foundation in 1976. The house was then sold to the West Virginia Division of Culture and History in 2002. The house was then sold to the Shepherds-town Foundation in 2009. The house is open to the public for tours. Rockland is located in Shepherds-town at the intersection of U.S. Route 45 and West Virginia Route 45. The house is accessed via Rockland Road (CR 20). The property includes a large barn, two smaller barns, a log cabin, and several other buildings. The surrounding area is largely rural and agricultural. Rockland is a member of the Shepherds-town Historic District, which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The house is also listed on the West Virginia Register of Historic Places.

The Montego 20 is a British trailerable sailboat that was designed by Peter Bruynooghe as a cruiser and first built in 1979. The Montego 20 is a trailer sailer with a fractional rig, a conventional hull with a pointed stern, and a permanent skeg-mounted rudder. It has a new skeg-mounted swing keel. The boat has a draft of 4.92 ft (1.50 m) with the keel down and 1.83 ft (0.55 m) with the keel up. The boat is powered by a Yanmar 1GM10 diesel engine of 9 horsepower (7 kW). The fuel tank holds 18 gallons (68 liters) and the fresh water tank holds 30 gallons (114 liters). The design has a hull speed of 6.1 kn (11.4 mph, 18.3 km/h). The Montego 20 was conceived as a small cruiser that can be easily trailed behind a car. It is fitted with a number of amenities, including a head (toilet), a galley ( kitchen) and sleeping accommodation for four people. The cockpit can be covered with a cockpit tent. In 2012 the boat was updated and a new model, called the New Montego 20, was introduced. The New Montego 20 has a revised hull shape with a wider beam and a deeper draft. The keel has also been revised and is now a swing keel with a deeper draft. The new model also has a revised cockpit layout and a larger swim platform.

In baseball, a count, or the count, is the number of balls and strikes on a batter. The count is sometimes described as the number of balls, the number of strikes, or the sum of the two (e.g., "the count is three balls and two strikes"). A count starts at 0-0, with the first pitch being either a ball or a strike. A count of three balls or three strikes is considered an "out" and results in a strikeout if the batter does not hit a fair ball before the fielders can record the out. If the batter gets four balls on a walk, it is considered an "unassisted" walk, and if the batter gets four strikes it is considered a "strikeout". If the batter has fewer than three balls and fewer than three strikes, the count is said to be "in the strike zone". If the batter has fewer than three balls and more than three strikes, the count is "out of the strike zone". If the batter has more than three balls and fewer than three strikes, the count is "ball-out-of-the-strike-zone", and if the batter has more than three balls and more than three strikes, the count is "ball-ball-out-of-the-strike-zone". If the batter has fewer than three balls, the count is described as "no balls", "one ball", "two balls", or "three balls". If the batter has more than three balls, the count is described as "four balls" or "five balls". If the batter has three balls, the count is described as "three balls" or "full count". A count of zero balls and two strikes is called a "no-pitch". If a batter is walked on eight balls, it is considered a "Passed ball". If the batter has zero strikes, the count is described as "no strikes", "one strike", "two strikes", or "three strikes". If the batter has one strike, the count is described as "one strike" or "two strikes". If the batter has two strikes, the count is described as "two strikes" or "three strikes". If the batter has three strikes, the count is described as "three strikes" or "Strike out".

Paul Karrer (April 16, 1889 – December 21, 1945) was a Swiss organic chemist and the recipient of the 1937 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for his work on carotenoids and vitamins. Karrer was born in Wildberg, Switzerland, to a family of eight children. He attended the Kantonsschule in Schiers, the nearest town to his village, and then the high school in Sion. He went on to study chemistry at the Federal Institute of Technology (ETH) in Zurich and then at the universities of Zurich and Berlin. He received his Dr. Phil. in 1912, and his Dr. sc. nat. in 1914, the latter under the supervision of Richard Willstätter at the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute for Chemistry in Berlin. He then spent a year as a postdoctoral fellow with Professor Richard Kuhn in Zurich and, in 1915, returned to the Kaiser Wilhelm Institute, where he remained for the next eight years. In 1923 he was appointed professor of chemistry at the Federal Institute of Technology (ETH) in Zurich, a position he held for the rest of his life. Karrer's research focused on the structure and properties of natural products, especially those containing large rings. He was the first to determine the structures of carotenoids and of vitamin A, and he was also the first to show that vitamin A is a metabolite of carotene. His work on carotenoids and vitamin A led to the development of a practical synthesis for vitamin A and to the elucidation of the structure of vitamin B. In addition to the Nobel Prize, Karrer received the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology's Einstein Medal, the German Chemical Society's Liebig Medal, the French Academy of Sciences' Lavoisier Medal, and the Royal Society of Chemistry's Faraday Medal. He was also a member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences, the Royal Society of Arts, and the Academy of Sciences of the Soviet Union.

2017 Hawaii Rainbow Warriors football team The 2017 Hawaii Rainbow Warriors football team represented the University of Hawaii at Manoa in the 2017 NCAA Division I FBS football season. The Rainbow Warriors, led by fourth-year head coach Nick Rolovich, played their home games at Aloha Stadium. They were a member of the West Division of the Mountain West Conference. They finished the season 3–9, 2–6 in Mountain West play to finish in a tie for fifth place in the West Division. Hawaii was not invited to any bowl game for the first time since 2007. On September 24, Hawaii beat the then-No. 18 Wisconsin Badgers at Camp Randall Stadium, 24–21, giving the Rainbow Warriors their first win over a ranked team since beating then-No. 25 Boise State in the 2010 Hawaii Bowl, and their first road win over a Top 25 team since defeating then-No. 20 Arizona State in 2007. The win was the Rainbow Warriors' first win in Madison since the 1953 season, when Hawaii beat Wisconsin 20–7. On November 4, Hawaii beat San Diego State, 27–24, in a game that was originally scheduled to be played in San Diego but was moved to Honolulu due to the effects of Hurricane Harvey. The game was the first time since November 15, 1975, that Hawaii and San Diego State faced each other in Honolulu. The 1975 game was also moved to Honolulu due to a disaster, specifically the Great Alaska earthquake, which forced the game to be moved from San Diego to Honolulu. The two teams played to a 7–7 tie in the 1975 game. On November 11, Hawaii beat UNLV, 41–38, in the first meeting between the two teams since 2012. Hawaii had beaten UNLV, 38–35, in 2012. On November 18, Hawaii lost to Wyoming, 59–56, in a game that featured nine combined turnovers, including seven interceptions. The 56 points were the most points Hawaii had scored in a loss since losing to Boise State, 56–55, in 2007. On November 25, Hawaii lost to San Jose State, 21–16, in a game that was played on Thanksgiving night. Hawaii had a 16–13 lead with 5:08 remaining in the fourth quarter, but San Jose State drove for a touchdown on their ensuing possession to take a 21–16 lead. Hawaii was unable to score on their final possession, and turned the ball over on downs. The loss was Hawaii's first to San Jose State since 2006, and the first time Hawaii had lost to San Jose State since becoming a member of the Mountain West Conference. On December 2, Hawaii lost to Boise State, 28–21, in the 2017 Mountain West Championship Game. Hawaii had a 21–20 lead with 1:17 remaining in the fourth quarter, but Boise State responded with a touchdown on their ensuing possession to take a 28–21 lead. Hawaii was unable to score on their final possession, and turned the ball over on downs. The loss was Hawaii's third straight loss to Boise State, and the third time in four years that Hawaii had lost to Boise State in the Mountain West Championship Game. At the end of the season, Hawaii finished with a 3–9 record, the program's worst record since going 3–7 in 2004. The Rainbow Warriors finished with a 2–6 record in Mountain West play, the program's worst conference record since going 1–5 in 2006. Hawaii was not invited to any bowl game for the first time since 2007.

Coyote Valley is a valley in San Benito County, California, United States, formed by the cooperation of the San Francisco and Monterey Bay during the creation of the Central Valley of California. The northern part of the valley is known as the Santa Clara Valley, and the southern part of the valley is known as the San Benito Valley. The two valleys are divided by the Diablo Range. The total area of the Coyote Valley is about 968 square miles (2,476 km2). The Coyote Valley is a critical wildlife corridor connecting the Monterey Bay with the San Francisco Bay and is the largest area of protected open space in the San Francisco Bay Area. The valley is home to a number of rare and endangered plants and animals. The natural landscape of the Coyote Valley is mostly grassland, with coastal scrub and riparian areas along the numerous creeks and rivers. The soil is mostly a hard, compact, earthquake-formed bay mud, which makes up the majority of the Central Valley of California. The main stem of the Coyote Creek flows from the San Francisco Bay to the Monterey Bay. The creek is about 65 miles (105 km) long, and is one of the largest tributaries of the San Francisco Bay. The creek's source is in the Santa Cruz Mountains, and it flows south through the San Francisco Bay Area's South Bay region, then east through the Central Valley, joining the San Benito River near the city of San Benito. The San Benito River is a tributary of the Pajaro River, flowing from the Central Valley to the Monterey Bay. The river is about 65 miles (105 km) long. The river's source is in the Diablo Range, and it flows south through the Central Valley, joining the Coyote Creek near the city of San Benito, then continuing south to the Pajaro River at the city of Watsonville. The valley was first settled by the Ohlone people, who lived in a number of small bands in the area. The Ohlone lived in a culture of hunter-gatherers, with some fishing and limited agriculture. The first European settlers arrived in the 1700s, when the Spanish mission system was established in California. The Spanish friars established the San Juan Bautista Mission in the San Benito Valley, about 4 miles (6.4 km) west of the Pajaro River. The Spanish established the first pueblo, or town, in California at San Jose in the northern part of the Coyote Valley. The town of San Juan Bautista was established in 1849, and is the oldest town in the valley. The California Gold Rush of 1849 brought a large number of immigrants to the area, and the population of San Jose grew rapidly. The discovery of gold also drew people to the southern part of the valley, and the towns of Tres Pinos and Paicines were established in the early 1850s. The San Benito Valley was a major transportation corridor during the early days of California. The El Camino Real, the main road from San Francisco to Monterey, ran through the valley. The San Benito Valley was also the main route for the Butterfield Overland Mail, which was the first transcontinental mail service in the United States. The Butterfield Overland Mail used the San Andreas Lake bed as a portion of the route, which ran through the valley from 1858 to 1861. The San Benito Valley is also home to a number of rare and endangered plants and animals. The Diablo Range is home to the California red-legged frog and the San Benito Evening-primrose. The San Francisco Bay and the San Benito River are important habitat areas for the California clapper rail and the salt marsh harvest mouse. The valley is also home to a number of protected areas. The San Francisco Bay Area has a number of regional parks and preserves, including the South Bay Salt Ponds, Alviso Slough, and the Don Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge. The Central Valley has the Sunol Regional Park and the Blue Hills Regional Park. The San Benito Valley has the San Benito National Wildlife Refuge and the Bitterwater National Wildlife Refuge. The Coyote Valley is also home to a number of farms and ranches, and the area is known for its agriculture and livestock. The region is known for its production of vegetables, fruits, nuts, and wine grapes. The valley is also home to a number of cattle ranches, and the region is known for its production of beef, dairy products, and wool. The Coyote Valley is a beautiful and diverse landscape, and is a critical wildlife corridor connecting the San Francisco and Monterey Bays. The valley is home to a number of rare and endangered plants and animals, and is an important habitat area for a number of species. The valley is also home to a number of protected areas, and is a popular destination for hiking, biking, and bird watching.

Preprophase is the period prior to prophase in the meiotic cell cycle. The cells are in G1 phase. Meiosis-specific DNA replication (i.e., meiosis I) has not yet begun. The homologous chromosomes are not yet close to each other and are still in their allocated areas of the cell nucleus. In meiosis, the homologous chromosomes ( chromosomes that carry genes for the same traits) line up in rows. Each row contains two homologous chromosomes, one from each parent. The homologous chromosomes swap genetic information between each other. Meiosis is necessary to create genetic diversity. In mitosis, the homologous chromosomes line up in rows as well. However, in mitosis, the homologous chromosomes do not swap genetic information. Instead, the same genetic information is copied and the cell divides into two identical daughter cells. Mitosis is necessary for growth and for the repair of damaged tissue. Preprophase is the first stage of meiosis. In this stage, the homologous chromosomes are not close to each other and are not swapped. Meiosis begins when the homologous chromosomes are pulled close together.

Koupaki, Phocis Koupaki is a mountain village in the municipal unit of Gravia, Phocis, Greece. In 2011 its population was 1,328. It is situated on the eastern slope of Mount Giona, above the valley of the Cephissus river. It is 5 km (3 mi) west of Gravia, 12 km (7 mi) southeast of Amfissa, and 25 km (16 mi) north of Levadi. The area has been inhabited since ancient times. A tomb from the Mycenaean period (16th century BC) has been discovered in the area. The village was mentioned in the 11th century by Anna Komnene. During the Byzantine period, the area was subject to frequent barbarian invasions, and the population often retreated to the safety of the mountains. The village was entirely destroyed in 1382 by the Aydinids. The old church of Koupaki is dedicated to Saint George, and is built at the edge of the cliff, under which are rock-cut tombs. It is a single-aisle basilica with a wooden roof, and dates to 1704. The new church, dedicated to the Dormition of the Virgin, is a three-aisle basilica with a tall wooden dome, built in 1888. Koupaki was the seat of a Commonwealth, which was established in 1665. The first major battle of the Greek War of Independence took place in Koupaki on the 17th of March 1821.

Eddy Bruma (born 16 January 1998) is a professional footballer who plays as a forward for Eerste Divisie side Roda JC Kerkrade. Born in the Netherlands, Bruma represents Aruba internationally. Bruma began his career at the amateur side FC Abcoude in his native Netherlands before joining the academy of Eerste Divisie side Almere City. In 2015, he joined the under-21 side of Jong PSV. He made his professional debut for the club on 18 September 2015 against Achilles '29. He came on as an 83rd-minute substitute for David N'Gog as Jong PSV won 3–0. Bruma spent the 2016–17 season on loan with Eerste Divisie side Telstar, where he scored 7 goals in 29 appearances. He returned to Jong PSV for the 2017–18 season and had his best season to date, scoring 10 goals in 30 appearances. On 12 July 2018, Bruma joined Vitesse Arnhem on a three-year deal. In June 2019, Bruma was included in the Aruba national football team for the 2019 Caribbean Cup qualification. He made his international debut on 20 November 2019 in a 0–0 draw against Curaçao.

Andreas Heusler (26 March 1865 – 25 June 1940) was a Swiss mathematician. He was born in Winterthur, Switzerland. He studied at the Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule Zurich (Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich) and the Eidgenössische Technische HochschuleBern (Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Bern). In 1890 he became an assistant to the mathematician Adolf Hurwitz at the University of Tartu in Estonia. After his habilitation in 1893, he became a docent at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Zurich. In 1898 he was appointed a full professor at the Technische Hochschule Charlottenburg (Berlin Institute of Technology) in Berlin. From 1925 until his retirement in 1935, he was the director of the mathematical institute at the Technische Hochschule Berlin-Charlottenburg. Heusler was a member of the Berlin Academy of Sciences and a corresponding member of the Swiss Academy of Sciences. In 1925 he was an Invited Speaker of the ICM in Toronto. His research concerned the theory of partial differential equations and of algebraic curves and surfaces. In 1899 he was the first to prove the higher symmetry of the icosahedron and dodecahedron.

Legend tripping is a term that was coined in the late 1960s by Professor of Folklore Michael Owen Jones to describe the contemporary practice of visiting the locations of urban legends and other folklore. The term is sometimes used to describe the visiting of historical sites, for example, the location of the Alamo. A legend trip may be undertaken with the specific purpose of visiting the site of a legendary event, or it may be an incidental aspect of a journey. The latter is especially true of legends which are set in a specific landscape, such as the roads of the United States, the moors of England, or the hydrotherapy spa of Bath, England. The term "legend trip" also refers to the tradition of telling the story associated with a particular site, and the legends associated with a place may change according to the storyteller. Some legends are associated with many locations, and it is the repetition of the story, rather than the location, that is important to the storytellers. The act of visiting the site of a legend has been incorporated into many works of popular culture. In the 1990s, the Kansas-based band The Get Up Kids released a song entitled "Oh My God, I Love America", which includes the lyrics "Where's the bathroom where Kurt Cobain took his life? / Oh, my God, I love America". The song references the urban legend that Kurt Cobain, the former lead singer of Nirvana, killed himself in a bathroom stall in Detroit. Similarly, the band New Kids on the Block released an album entitled No More Games/No More Songs, which featured a song entitled "You Got It Wrong", whose lyrics include "Where's the spot where John F. Kennedy was shot? / They got it wrong, they got it all wrong". The song references the urban legend that the grassy knoll in Dallas, Texas, was the location where John F. Kennedy was shot, rather than the street in front of the knoll. Many legends are also associated with specific tourist locations, such as the World's Largest Ball of Twine in Kansas, the alleged location of the Bermuda Triangle in the Caribbean, and the alleged birthplace of Elvis Presley in Tupelo, Mississippi. In the United States, legend tripping is most often associated with young people. There is some evidence that young people are more likely to believe in urban legends than are older people. The term "legend tripping" can also refer to the act of visiting the site of a legendary event that never occurred. These trips are motivated by the same desire to experience a legendary event, and such trips are usually undertaken with the full knowledge that the event never occurred at the site. A famous example of a legend trip of this sort is the visit to the grave of Alfred, Lord Tennyson, in the village of Freshwater, England. Tennyson's poem, "Crossing the Bar", contains the lines "And the bar down under, I see, is a bar down under the sea, Down under the sea, I go, With a bar down under the sea". Tennyson died in 1892, but tourists have been visiting the village and asking locals where Tennyson's grave is. Since there is no such grave, the tourists are directed to a concrete block on the beach, which has been identified as "Tennyson's Tomb" by the addition of a large cross, constructed from driftwood, to the top of the block.

Linear park of the Saint-Charles and Berger rivers The Linear park of the Saint-Charles and Berger rivers (in French: Parc linéaire des rivières Saint-Charles et Berger) is a greenway in Quebec, Canada. It is a mixed-use recreational and transportation corridor, following the path of two rivers, and passing through the city of Quebec and the borough of La Cité-Limoilou. The park runs along the Saint-Charles River and its tributary, the Berger River. The two rivers flow into the St. Lawrence River at Quebec. The park is a continuation of the Samuel-de-Champlain Promenade, which runs along the St. Lawrence through the Quebec region, and which is also mixed-use. The park is used by residents of Quebec City for cycling, inline skating, walking, and cross-country skiing. In the winter, it is also used for snowshoeing and snowmobiling. The park passes through or near several major tourist attractions in Quebec City. It passes through the Plains of Abraham, which are the site of the Battle of the Plains of Abraham. It passes near the Museum of Fine Arts, the National Museum of Fine Arts of Quebec, and the Quebec Aquarium. It also passes near the shopping areas of Place Laurier and Place Ste-Foy. The park was created in the early 1970s. It was first named the Samuel-de-Champlain Linear Park, after the explorer Samuel de Champlain. It was later renamed the Linear Park of the Saint-Charles and Berger rivers. The park was originally 6.2 kilometres (3.8 miles) long. In 2009, it was extended to 7.2 kilometres (4.5 miles).

Guitar Tango is the name given to a style of playing the guitar which emulates the characteristic rhythmic and melodic elements of Argentine tango music. In its most characteristic form, the genre is performed on an acoustic guitar with the melody and rhythm taken from an arrangement for bandoneón, the characteristic instrument of the tango orchestras. In the early years of the 20th century, when the tango became the most characteristic music of Argentina, there were many experiments with instruments other than the bandoneón to play the new music. The guitar was an obvious choice, since it was a common instrument and, at that time, the main instrument for the traditional Argentine music, the chamamé. The first person to arrange the tango for the guitar was the Mexican guitarist and composer Luis null. His arrangements, published in 1912, were the first to be titled "Tango Argentino" and they include the tango "Marinera", which is still widely played today. Luis null's most famous pupil was the Argentine guitarist and composer Edmundo Rivero, who also played a fundamental role in the development of the guitar style. Other important guitarists were the Mexican Joaquín Bueso, the Argentine tomato and the Brazilian Laurindo de Almeida. The guitar style is characterized by a strong rhythm, with a clear and bright sound, which allows the instruments to be heard within the crowded dance hall. To achieve this, the guitarist uses the whole body of the guitar as a resonating chamber, to give volume and depth to the sound. In the traditional ensemble, the guitarist is accompanied by a singer, a bandoneón, a violin, an accordion and a piano. The singer usually sings in a low voice, in a special way of singing that is characteristic of the tango. The guitar is used to play the melody, the rhythm or both at the same time. There are two ways to play the guitar in tango. The first one is called "tangogauche" (from French "à gauche" — to the left). The bandoneón is placed to the left of the guitarist, who therefore plays the bass to the left of the treble. The second way is called "tangoforte" (from Italian "forte" — strong). The bandoneón is placed to the right of the guitarist, who therefore plays the bass to the right of the treble. The tango style is a rich and complex musical idiom, which has been influenced by the cultural melting pot that is Argentina. It has also been influenced by the diverse peoples that have visited the country, such as the French, the Italians and the African slaves. The most characteristic element of the tango is the rhythm, which is in a 2/4 time signature. The rhythm is characterized by a " delaying " of the second beat, which gives the characteristic "dilepton" sound to the tango. This delaying is called "canto", and it is the most difficult element to be mastered by a musician who is not accustomed to the tango. The tango is also characterized by the "tinta" (Spanish for "tone"), which is the particular way in which the musician sings the notes, with a strong accent on the first beat of every measure. Another characteristic element is the "llok" (from Welsh "lliw" — melody), which is the way in which the musicians play the melody, with a clear and bright sound. Finally, the "par" (from French "parade" — walking) is the way in which the musicians play the rhythm, with a strong and steady beat. The traditional tango is made up of five parts: The "A" section, which is the most characteristic part of the tango, and it is usually the first part of the dance. It is characterized by the "canto" and the "tinta". The "B" section, which is a variation of the "A" section, and it is usually the second part of the dance. WFLB is an American radio station licensed to serve the community of Monticello, Florida, United States. The station is owned by Black Crow Media, Inc. and operated by Florida Talk Radio, Inc. WFLB broadcasts a news/talk format to the greater Jacksonville, Florida, area. The station is the FM companion to WIVY (1280 AM) and is co-owned with WOKV-FM (96.5 FM) and WOKV (1070 AM). WFLB is the only commercial FM station in the United States to be licensed to a trailer park. The station was assigned the call sign WIVY-FM in 1988, and was first licensed in 1989 to Mary L. Johnson, doing business as North Florida Communications. In August 1992, Johnson sold WIVY-FM to Black Crow Media, Inc. for $70,000. In April 1996, WIVY-FM changed its call letters to WFLB. Two months later, the station moved its community of license from Macclenny to Monticello, though its primary audience is still the Jacksonville area. In August 2000, WFLB's parent company, Black Crow Media, entered into a five-year local marketing agreement with Clear Channel Communications, Inc., then the owner of WOKV-FM and WOKV. In February 2002, Black Crow Media agreed to sell WFLB to Florida Talk Radio, Inc. for $225,000.

Convergence of measures In probability theory and analysis, the convergence of measures is a property that is closely related to the convergence of random variables and probability distributions. A measure is a function that assigns a value to every subset of a set. A measure is called convergent if, as the index approaches infinity, the measure of the union of a sequence of sets approaches the measure of their intersection. More precisely, let (Ω, μ, ∞) be a measure space, where Ω is the set of all possible outcomes, μ is the associated measure, and ∞ is the infinite index. Let (Ωn, μn, n) be a sequence of measure spaces with μn ≡ μ(Ωn) and let (Ω ∞, μ ∞) be the measure space with μ ∞ ≡ lim(μn). Then μn is called a convergent measure if the following condition is satisfied: for every ε > 0, there exists N such that for all n ≥ N, it holds that μn(Ω) ≥ μ ∞(Ω) + ε. A measure is called absolute convergent if it is convergent and μ ∞ is equal to μ. Let (Ω, μ, ∞) be a measure space. The following statements are equivalent: The measure μ is convergent. For every ε > 0, there exists N such that for all n ≥ N, it holds that μn(Ω) ≥ μ ∞(Ω) + ε. For every ε > 0, there exists N such that for all n ≥ N, it holds that μn(Ω) ≤ μ ∞(Ω) + ε. The measure μ is absolutely convergent. For every ε > 0, there exists N such that for all n ≥ N, it holds that μn(Ω) = μ ∞(Ω) + ε.

Catstye Cam is a large, circular depression in the moorland of eastern North Yorkshire, England, between the villages of Spaunton and Brandsby. Its circumference is about one mile (1.6 km). Its name is a corruption of the term "catt stey", meaning "steep bank". In 2018, it was mown for the first time in 40 years. The Cam is formed by a large depression in the limestone, which is now largely infilled with clay and other deposits. At the lowest point, the Cam is crossed by the A166 road. On the northern side of the road, the Cam becomes a small, shallow lake, which is often filled with water in the winter. The southern side is dominated by a large, steep bank, which is covered in mature oak trees. The whole site is designated as a Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI). The Cam is a popular spot for walking and horse riding. It also attracts birdwatchers, who can observe birds such as the great crested grebe, the water rail, the common kingfisher, the northern shoveler, the tufted duck, the common goldeneye, and the lesser black-backed gull.

Yoonkyung Lee (Korean: 이윤경; born December 30, 1971), also known by the pseudonym T., is a South Korean composer of contemporary classical music. Lee was born in Seoul, South Korea. She studied composition with Korean composer Sukhi Kang at the Korean National University of Arts, and with Michael Jarrell at the Conservatoire de Musique de Genève, from which she graduated in 2000. She also participated in the International Summer Course for New Music in Darmstadt in 1998, and studied computer music at the Centre de Recherche et de Formation sur les Arts et les Technologies de l'Information in Paris in 2000. Lee's music has been performed at international festivals, including the Darmstädter Ferienkurse (1998, 2002, 2004, 2006), the Donaueschingen Festival (2003, 2005, 2008), the Musica Viva festival (2002, 2004), the Gaudeamus Music Week (1997, 2000, 2003), and the Seoul International Computer Music Festival (2001, 2002, 2004, 2006, 2008). Her works have been performed by the Arditti Quartet, the Ensemble Modern, the Kugoni Trio, the Ensemble intercontemporain, the Tokyo Philharmonic Orchestra, the Bergen Philharmonic Orchestra, the Hong Kong Sinfonietta, the London Sinfonietta, the San Francisco Contemporary Music Players, the T'ang Quartet, and the Korea National Contemporary Dance Company. Lee's music is characterized by its "exploration of the boundaries between tonality and atonality". Her music is also notable for its synthesis of traditional Korean music and Western contemporary music. She has stated that the traditional Korean system of twelve pitch classes per octave is a significant influence on her music. Lee has been a professor of composition at the Korean National University of Arts since 2001. In 2008, she was named the artistic director of the Seoul International Computer Music Festival.

Jürgen Förster (11 May 1930 – 8 September 2020) was a German classical guitarist, lutenist, and musicologist. Förster was born in Berlin. He started playing the guitar when he was eight, and began his studies at the age of ten, first with Karl Scheidt in Berlin, then with Andrés Segovia in Siena, Italy, in 1955, and finally with Paul Galbraith in Paris, France, in 1957. In 1961 he took up a position as a lecturer at the University of Music and Performing Arts, Vienna, Austria, and in 1971 was appointed professor, a position he held until his retirement in 1995. Förster performed in Europe, Asia, and South America as a soloist, and with the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra, the Chamber Orchestra of Europe, and the Absolute Ensemble. He also made a number of recordings, mainly for the German labels Deutsche Grammophon and Divox. His recording of Johann Sebastian Bach'sarioscosa cordigerasurvived for a time in the pop music firmament as the theme for the popular song "Bach on the Rocks", which was a modest hit for the British group The Swingle Singers in the late 1960s. Förster was the author of several books on the history of the guitar, the most notable being The Guitar in History, a standard reference work on the subject.

Les Avenières Les Avenières is a commune in the Doubs department in the Bourgogne-Franche-Comté region in eastern France. It lies in the Jura mountains, on the border with Switzerland, about 4 kilometres (2 mi) north of Le Locle, Switzerland. The inhabitants of the commune are known as Les Avenièresais. The commune has a land area of 3.3 square kilometres (1.3 sq mi). It had a population of 180 in 2015. Les Avenières is located on the French side of the alkaline lac de Les Avenières. The lac de Les Avenières, which is 2.3 kilometres (1.4 mi) long and 0.6 kilometres (0.37 mi) wide, is renowned for its clear waters and the quality of its fish. The path that runs around the lake is called the sentier des Bouquetins because of the many marmots that can be seen along it. The village lies in a valley that runs from Le Locle to the village of Les Marches, which is on the French-Swiss border. The village is noted for its renovated church and the many 17th-century houses that line the main street. Les Avenières is also known for its springs, the source of many of the drinking water supplies in the area. The inhabitants of Les Avenières are called Les Avenièresais. The village is mentioned for the first time in a document from 1130 as Avineniacum. The term Les Avenières probably comes from a deformation of the Latin word Avennis, meaning "the sources". The village has a rich history. In the 11th century, it was the seat of the seigneurie of Les Avenières, which covered the villages of Les Avenières, La Borderie, and Le Villersexel. In the 17th century, it became the seat of the barony of Les Avenières. The village has a rich religious history. In the 16th century, it had a large number of monasteries and religious schools, including the convent of the Religieuses Hospitalières de Saint-Jean de Dieu, which was founded in 1596 by the Hospitalières de Saint-Jean de Dieu, a Catholic congregation that was founded in 1458 in Lyon. The convent was built next to the village's medieval church. In the 17th century, the convent became the seat of the barony of Les Avenières. In the 18th century, the convent was transformed into a prison. It remained a prison until 1965. Today, the convent is a cultural centre that is known as the Centre Culturel de Les Avenières. The Church of Les Avenières, which is dedicated to Saint Martin, is a medieval church that was built in the Gothic style in the 15th century. In the 17th century, the church was completely rebuilt, except for its Gothic bell tower. The Church of Les Avenières is known for its 17th-century organ, which is one of the oldest organs in France that is still in working order. The organ was built in 1639 by the organ builder Claude Delaistre, who was a student of the famous organ builder Jean Titelouze. The organ has been completely restored and is in perfect working order. It is used for concerts and recitals. The Church of Les Avenières also has a magnificent 18th-century organ, which is located in the choir. The organ was built in 1754 by the organ builder Claude-Marie Dunand. It is one of the finest organs in the region and is used for concerts and recitals. In addition to its two organs, the Church of Les Avenières has a magnificent pipe organ, which was built in 1899 by the organ builder Paul HOFMANN. The organ has been completely restored and is in perfect working order. It is used for concerts and recitals.

In communications, two-way communication is the transmission and the receipt of a message by the source and the receiver, respectively. In order to be considered two-way, the message must be sent and received in a suitable time period so that the communication is effective. There are two types of two-way communication. The first type is a communication in which one party speaks while the other party listens. The second type is a communication in which both parties speak and listen to each other in a dialogue. Two-way communication is essential in relationships. It is the way that relationships are built and maintained. It is the way that people communicate their needs, their feelings, and their thoughts to each other. It is also the way that people make their relationships stronger and more fulfilling. In business, two-way communication is essential for effective leadership. It is the way that leaders communicate their vision, their goals, and their strategies to their employees. It is also the way that employees communicate their concerns, their ideas, and their feedback to their leaders. In education, two-way communication is essential for effective teaching. It is the way that teachers communicate their knowledge, their skills, and their ideas to their students. It is also the way that students communicate their questions, their concerns, and their feedback to their teachers. In politics, two-way communication is essential for effective leadership. It is the way that politicians communicate their policies, their platforms, and their ideas to their constituents. It is also the way that constituents communicate their concerns, their ideas, and their feedback to their politicians. In customer service, two-way communication is essential for effective service. It is the way that customers communicate their needs, their concerns, and their feedback to companies. It is also the way that companies communicate their products, their services, and their policies to their customers.

Don't Be Tardy Don't Be Tardy is an American reality television series that premiered on September 15, 2008, on the Bravo cable network. The series is the first of threespin-offs of the network's hit series The Real Housewives of Atlanta. The series originally chronicled the life of Atlanta socialite and philanthropist Kim Zolciak as she and her family adjust to their new life in the suburbs, after her husband, NFL player Kroy Biermann, purchases a home. The series was originally titled The Real Housewives of Atlanta: Don't Be Tardy. In June 2010, it was announced that the series would be renewed for a third season, and would be undergoing a complete overhaul, with Kim Zolciak being the only original cast member to return. Ronny Rodelin (born 16 January 1986) is a French professional footballer who plays as a striker. Born in Les Pennes-les-Mines, Rodelin began his career with the youth team of AS sans Fil Les Mameux, before joining the junior team of Lille OSC. He then played for US Esquelbecque, and ES Wasquehal, before joining professionalism with CS Marveille, where he stayed for two seasons. In 2008, Rodelin joined US Créteil-Lusigny, and in his first season with the club, he was the top scorer in the 2008–09 Championnat de France Amateur Group A, with 21 goals. The following season, he was the top scorer again, this time with 24 goals. In 2010, he joined FC Dieppe, and in his first season with the club, he was the top scorer in the 2010–11 Championnat de France Amateur Group A, with 27 goals. In 2012, Rodelin joined FC Rouen. He then played for US Lusigny, AS Yzeure, and FC Montceau Bourgogne. In 2015, he joined FC Dieppe for a second time. In 2017, Rodelin joined US Le Puy Foot 43 Auvergne. In 2018, he joined FC Sète. Rodelin is known for his ability to score goals, and has been described as a "prolific striker".
