'Bravo! Brubeck!' is a 1967 album by the Dave Brubeck Quartet. The title is an anagram of the group's name. The cover was designed by Dave Brubeck himself. The album was recorded in 1967, at the time that the Dave Brubeck Quartet were recording their 'Time Out' album (their first album for Warner Bros.), and was originally released on the Fantasy Records label. The original cover was designed by the renowned San Francisco-based graphic designer, Alexander Isley. The album was re-released on CD in 2005, with the addition of three bonus tracks, including a rare performance of 'Don't Worry, Be Happy' by Paul Desmond, which was recorded live at the 1967 Monterey Jazz Festival. The title track, 'Bravo! Brubeck!', was recorded in a single take, and features Paul Desmond on alto saxophone, Paul Smith on bass, and Colin Bailey on drums. The song is a self-reference, and features a musical anagram of the group's name. The song is in fact a Desmond solo piece, with the group joining in for the last eight bars. 'Dancin' in the Night' is a Brubeck original, which was also recorded by the Dave Brubeck Quartet for their 'Time Out' album, but which was not used. The piece was inspired by Brubeck's recent experience of hearing gospel music in a black church in Washington, D.C. 'Ode to a Legend' is a Paul Desmond composition, dedicated to the recently deceased jazz legend, Lester Young. The piece is a bossa nova, and features a solo by Desmond. 'S'crazy Pad' is another Brubeck original, which features a rare Brubeck solo. 'Blue 7' is a blues by Paul Desmond, which is performed by the Dave Brubeck Quartet, but which was also recorded by Desmond with the Robert Gordon Quartet, and which was used as the theme tune for a TV show in the United States. 'For All We Know' is a Brubeck-Desmond composition, which was recorded by the Dave Brubeck Quartet for their 'Time Out' album, but which was not used. The piece was featured in the film 'Good Times', and was also recorded by the Carpenters. 'Don't Worry, Be Happy' is a single by Bobby McFerrin with the Dave Brubeck Quartet, which was released in 1988. The song was written by Bobby McFerrin and Roger Brown, and was recorded at the 1988 Montreaux Jazz Festival, with Paul Desmond, who had recently returned to the group.

Indirect DNA damage Indirect DNA damage, or indirect DNA injury, is a form of DNA damage that is not directly caused by an external agent. Rather, it is caused by a chain of reactions, which can be initiated by a variety of external agents, including ionizing radiation, ultraviolet (UV) radiation, and non-ionizing radiation, as well as chemical agents and viruses. The type of DNA damage produced will depend on the type of external agent, the dose, and the cellular context. The end result is a modification of the DNA that can lead to genetic instability, which means that the genetic information encoded in the DNA is no longer stably transmitted from one generation to the next. Indirect DNA damage can result in a variety of genetic alterations, including point mutations, chromosomal rearrangements, and gene deletions. These genetic alterations can lead to cell death, genetic instability, and cancer. The main way that indirect DNA damage causes genetic alterations is through the formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS), which are highly reactive molecules that can damage DNA. ROS can be formed by a variety of external agents, including ionizing and non-ionizing radiation, as well as chemical agents and viruses. These agents can cause the formation of free radicals, which are unstable molecules that can react with DNA to produce genetic alterations. Indirect DNA damage can also be caused by the formation of DNA adducts, which are chemical compounds that can bind to DNA and cause genetic alterations. These adducts can be formed by a variety of external agents, including ionizing and non-ionizing radiation, as well as chemical agents and viruses.

William Adams (Master of Pembroke) (c. 1685 – 1748) was an English academic, the master of Pembroke College, Cambridge, from 1737 until his death. William Adams was born in 1685 in Wicken, Cambridgeshire, the son of Thomas Adams and his wife, Elizabeth. He was educated at the Free School, Ely, and then at Pembroke College, Cambridge, where he was admitted in 1701 as a sizar, that is, a poor student who would receive financial support from the college. He was later elected a scholar, and in 1707 was awarded his Bachelor of Arts degree. Two years later he gained his Master of Arts degree, and in 1713 he became a Fellow of the college. In 1737, Adams was appointed the master of Pembroke, in succession to his old friend, John Whalley. During his time as master, the college's finances improved considerably, and Adams was able to improve the college's buildings and other facilities. He also enhanced the reputation of the college by encouraging the pursuit of academic excellence. In 1745, Adams was instrumental in the foundation of the Cambridge University Press, which was to become the world's oldest printing press. The first book to be published by the press was a collection of essays by Adams's friend, Sir Roger North. Adams died in 1748 and was buried in the college chapel. A tablet in his memory was placed in the chapel by his friends and admirers, and a tradition began which has continued to this day, whereby the master of the college, on his appointment, plants a tree in the college grounds.

Thomas Reid (10 December 1849 – 17 March 1912) was a Scottish Baptist pastor, journalist and editor of The Baptist newspaper from 1880 to 1904. Reid was born in Aberdeen, Scotland, and was educated at the University of Aberdeen and the University of Edinburgh. In 1874, he was appointed a pastor at the Baptist church in his native city, and in 1880 he became the editor of The Baptist, the organ of the Scottish Baptist Association, which he had joined in 1876. He also contributed regularly to the Scottish Baptist Journal. In 1885, Reid became the pastor of the recently built Aberdeen Baptist Church, and he remained in this post until his death. The church was said to be the largest Baptist church in Scotland, and its premises became the focus of Reid's activities within the Baptist movement in Scotland. He was a strong advocate of the temperance movement, and in 1888 he took part in the foundation of the Aberdeen and North of Scotland Temperance Society. In 1898, he became the editor of the Temperance Journal, and he also contributed to the Scottish Temperance Leader. Reid was a member of the Aberdeen Public Library Committee for many years, and he was also a member of the Aberdeen Town Council from 1905 to 1908. In 1908, he was appointed to the Aberdeen Board of Education, on which he served until his death. He was also a member of the Aberdeen and North of Scotland Committee for the Pan-Anglican Congress, which was held in the city in 1908. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Reid was one of the leaders of the Baptist movement in Scotland, and he was a strong advocate of the temperance movement. He was also a prominent member of the Aberdeen community, and he served on the town council and on the board of education.

The Roscrea Brooch The Roscrea Brooch is a late 8th-century copper-alloy and enamel brooch from Ireland, which takes the form of a bent ring. It is highly decorated with fine enamel work, and is one of the few pieces of jewellery from the time and place to survive the Islamic invasion of Ireland in the early 9th century. It is named after the town of Roscrea, where it was found in the 19th century. The brooch is made of copper alloy, and is decorated with enamel work in a number of different colours. The general design is of a ring, bent in the centre. The ring is not perfectly round, and is made up of two half-ring parts which are not quite identical. The two half-rings are held together by a pin which passes through both of them, and then through a loose ring on the back. The pin is held in place by a catch. The brooch also has a hinge, allowing it to be folded in half for easier and safer storage. The enamel work is of the highest quality. The dominant colour is a translucent green, with yellow and blue enamel also used. The enamel work is used to decorate the brooch in a number of different ways. In some areas, it is used to create a geometric design, while in others it is used to create a cloisonsé effect. In some cases, the enamel is used to write letters of the Latin alphabet. The back of the brooch is decorated with a fleeced dog. The brooch is held in the National Museum of Ireland.

Bwanga Tshimen is a traditional mancala board game played with stones or seeds in Africa, particularly in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. The game is also known as Bwamanda, Kwele, or Kasapa. The name Bwanga Tshimen means "good stones" in Swahili. The game is usually played on a board consisting of a series of pits dug in the earth or marked out in a line on the ground. The board is typically accompanied by a cup or hook for moving the stones. The stones are usually small, smooth, and of equal size. The basic rules of Bwanga Tshimen are similar to those of other mancala games. Each player controls one end of the board, and the objective of the game is to capture all or some set of the opponent's stones by capturing them in one's own cups or pits. Each turn, a player removes all stones from one of their own pits and then "sews" them across the board, landing in the next pit which is either empty or contains the opponent's stones. If the stones land in an empty pit, the player's turn ends. If the stones land in a pit with the opponent's stones, the opponent's stones are captured and removed from the board, and the player's turn continues. A distinctive feature of Bwanga Tshimen is the manner in which a player's turn ends. A player may end their turn by "bumping" one of their own stones against the side of an opponent's pit, and capturing it together with any stones it has captured. A player may also end their turn by "loading" one of their own stones into an opponent's pit, which captures any stones in the pit and also ends the player's turn. A player may also end their turn by "throwing" one of their own stones onto an opponent's stone in the same pit, which captures the opponent's stone and ends the player's turn.
